Prohemye
Great thankynges lawde and honor we merytoryously ben bound to yield and
offer unto writers of hystoryes / which gretely have prouffyted our mortal
life / that show unto the reders and herers by the ensamples of things passyd
/ what thing is to be desired / And what is to be eschewed / For those things
which our progenytours by the taste of bytternes and experyment of great
Ieopardyes have enseygned / admonested and informed us excluded fro such
peryllys / to know what is prouffytable to our life / and acceptable / and
what is vnprouffytable and to be refused / He is / and ever has been reputed
the wysest / which by the experyence of adverse fortune has byholden and seen
the noble Cytees / manners / and variau^t condycions of the people of many
diverse Regyons / For in him is presupposed the lore of wisdom and polycye /
by the experyment of Ieopardyes and peryllys which have grown of folly in
diverse parties and contrayes / yet he is more fortunat / and may be reputed as
wise / if he give attendaunce without tastynge of the storms of aduersyte
that may by the redyng of historyes conteynyng diverse customs Condycyons /
laws and / Acts of sundry nations come unto the knowleche of and
understanding of the same wysedom and polycye / In which hystoryes so wreton
in large and aourned volumes / he sitting in his chamber or study / may read
/ know and understand the polytyke and noble acts of all the world as of
one Cite / And the conflyctes / errors. Troubles / and vexacions done in the
said universal world / In such wise as he had been and seen them. in the
propre places where as they were done / For certain it is a greet beneurte
unto a man that can be reformed by other and strange men's hurtes and scathes
/ And by the same to know / what is requysyte and prouffytable for his life /
And eschew such errors and Inconuenytys / by which other men have been hurt
and lost their felycyte / Therefore the cou^seylles of Ancient and white heeryd
men / in whom old age has engendryd wisdom / ben gretely preysed of younger
men / And yet hystoryes so much more excelle them / As the dyuturnyte or
length of time Includes moo ensamples of things and laudable acts. than
thage of one man may suffyse to see / Historyes ought not only to be Iuged
most proffytable to young men / which by the lecture / redyng and
understanding make them semblable and equale to men of greter age / and to old
men / to whom long life has mynystred experymentes of diverse things / but
also thystoryes able and make right pryuate men digne and worthy to have the
governance of Em^yte^ ^ noble Royammes / historyes moeue and withdraw
Emperors and kings fro vycious tyranny / Fro vecordyous slouthe / unto
tryumphe and vyctorye in puyssaunt bataylles / Historyes also have moeued right
noble knights to deserve eternal laud which follows them for their
vyctoryous merytes / And cause them more valyantly to enter in Ieopardyes of
batayles for the defense and tuicion of their country / and publyke well /
hystorye also affrayeth cruel tyrauntys for dread of Infamye and shame Infynyte
/ by cause of the detestable acts of such cruel persons ben oftymes plantyd
and regystred in Cronykes unto their perpetuel obprobrye and dyuulgacion of
their Infamye / As thactes of new and such other / Truly many of hye and
couragyous men of great empryse / desyryng their fame to be perpetuelly
conseruyd by lyberal monumentis / which ben the permanente records of every
vyrtuouse and noble Act / have builded and edefyed ryall and noble Cytees /
And for the conseruacion of the well publycke have mynystred and establysshed
dyscrete and prouffytable laws / And thus the pryncipal laud / and cause of
delectable and amyable things / in which man's felycyte stondeth and rests
ought and may well be attributed to hystoryes / which word historye may be
descryued thus / Historye is a perpetuel conseruatryce of thoos things / that
have be done before this present time / and also a cotydyan witness of
bienfayttes of malefaytes / great Acts / and tryumphal vyctoryes of all manner
people. And also if the terryble feyned Fables of Poets have much styred and
moeued men to pity / and conseruynge of Justice / How much more is to be
supposed / that Historye assertryce of veryte / and as mother of all
philosophye / moeuynge our manners to virtue / reformeth and reconcyleth ner
hand all thoos men / which through the Infyrmyte of our mortal nature has
led the most part of their life in Ocyosyte and myspended their time passed
right soon out of Remembrance / Of which life and death is egal oblyuyon /

The fruytes of virtue ben Inmortall / Specially wh^nne they ben wrapped in the
benefyce of hystoryes /

Then it must follow / that it is most fair to men Mortalle to suffer
labors and pain / for glory and fame Inmortalle / Hercules when he lived
suffryd greet labors and peryllys wylfully puttyng him self in many terryble
and ferdful ieop^rdyes to obtain of all people the benefaytes of Inmortal laud
and renommee / We read of other noble men / sum lords and sum other of
lower astates reputed as gods in diverse regyons / the whose famous acts /
and excellent virtues only hystorye has preseruyd fro perysshyng in eternal
memory / Other monymentes distributed in diverse chaunges / enduren but for a
short time or season / But the virtue of historye dyffused and spr^dd by the
universal world has time / which consumes all other things as
conseruatryce and kepar of her work /

Ferthermore eloquence is so precious and noble / that al most no thing can
be founden more precious than it / By Eloquence the greeks ben preferryd in
contynu^l honor to fore the rude barbares / Orators and learned clerks in
like wise excelle vnl^rn^d and brutyssh people / Sith this eloquence is such
that causes men emonge them self sum texcelle other / after the qualyte of
the virtue and eloquence by seyn to be of val^w / For sum we Judge to be good
men digne of laud / which show to us the way of virtue / and other have
taken another way for tenflamm^ more the courages of men by fables of poesye /
than to prouffy^e And by the laws and Institutes more to punysshe than to
teache So that of these things the vtylyte is myxt with harm / For sum
sothly techyth to lie / But historye representynge the things like unto the
words / enbraceth al vtylyte and prouff^^^ It shows honest / and makes
vices detestable / It enhaunce^h noble men and depresseth wicked men and fools
/ Also things that historye deseryueth by experyence / much prouffyten unto a
ryghtful lif / Then sith historye is so precious and also prouffytable / I
have delybered to write two books notable / retenyng in them many noble
historyes / as the lives / miracles / passions and death of diverse holy saints which shall be comprysed by thayde and suffraunce of almighty god in
one of them / which is named legenda aurea / that is the golden legende / And
that other book is named polycronycon / in which book ben comprised briefly
many wonderful historyees / First the descripcion of the universal world / as
w^l in length as in bread with the diuisio^s of countries roya^mes and empyres
/ the noble cytees / hye mou^tayns famous ryuers / merueylles and wondres / and
also the historial ^ctes and wonderful deeds sith the first making of heaven and
earth unto the beginning of the regne of king edward the fourth / and unto the
year of our lord M / CCCClx. As by thayde of almighty god shall follow al a
long / after the composynge and gaderynge of dan Ranulph monk of chestre
first auctour of this book / and afterward englisshed by one Treuisa vycarye
of barkley / which at request of one Sir thomas lord barkley translated this
said book / the bible and bartylmew de proprietatibus reru^ out of latin in to
englyssh / And now at this time symply emprynted and set in form by me
William Caxton and a little embelysshed fro tholde making / and also have added
such stories as I could find fro the end that the said Ranulph fynysshed his
book which was the year of our lord.M.CCClvij unto the year of the same MCCCClx
/ which ben an honderd and three year / which work I have finysshed under the
noble protection of my most dr^d naturel and sovereign lord and most christian
king / king Edward the fourth / humbly besechyng his most noble grace to
pardone me if any thing be said therynne of Ignorance / or other wise than it
ought to be^ And also requyryng al other to amend where as there is defaute /
Wherein he or they may deserve thank and merit / And I shall pray for them that
so do / For I knowleche mine Ignorance and also symplenes / And if there be
thing that may plese or prouffite any man / I am glad that I have achieued it /
And following this my prohemye I shall set a table shortly towchyd of the most
part of this book / And where the said Auctor has all his work in seven
books / I have set that which I have added to after a part. and have
marked it the last book / and have made chapytres acordyng to the other work
/ Of which accomplysshyng / I thank Almighty God To whom be given Honor /
laud / and glory / in secula seculorum Amen /

Deo gracias

Sith the time that the great and high tour of babilone was bylded ^en have
spoken with diverse tongues / In such wise that diverse men be strange (...)
other and understood not others speech / Speech is not known but if it be
learned common lernyng of speech is by hering^ and so always he that is deef is
always dombe for he may not here speech for to / learn / So men of fer countrees
and lands that have diverse speches / yef neither of hem have learned others
langage / nether of hem wot what other meneth / though they mete and have great
need of informacion and of loor of talkyng and of speech be the need never so
great neither of hem understands others speech no more than / gaglinge of
gees For Iangle that one never so fast that other is never the wyser though he
shrewe him instead of good morow^ This is a great meschyef. that folo^eth now
mankind / But god of his mercy and grace has ordained double remedy / One is
that sum man lerneth and knows many diverse speches / And so between
strange men of the which neither understands others speche^ Such a man may
be mean an^ tell either what other wole mene^ That other remedy is that one
langage is learned. used. and known in many nations and lands. And so latin is
learned known and used specially on this half greece in all the nations and
lands of Europe / Therefore clerks of her godnes and curtosye make and written
their books in latyn^ For her writing and books should be understand in
diverse nations and lands And so Ranulphus monk of C^estre wrote in latin his
books. of Cronykes that descryueth the world about in length and in bre^de /
And makes mention and mind of doings and deeds of meruaylles and of wondres^
and rekeneth the years to his last days / fro the first making of heaven and of
earth And so therinne is great and noble Informacion and loore to hem that can
therinne read and understand Therefore I would have these books of Cronykes /
translated out of Latin in to English for the moo men should hem understand
and have thereof con^yng Informacion and loore The Clerk These books of
Cronykes ben written in latin / And latin is used and understood on this half
greece in all the nations and lands of Europa And comynly English. is not so
wide understand used ne known And thenglysshe transl^cion should noman
understand but Englyssh men allone / Then how should the moo men understand
the Cronykes though they were translated out ^f latin that is so / wide used
and known / in to English that is not (...) and known but of englyssh men
allone The lord This question and doubt is easy to assaylle For if these
cronykes were translated out of latin in to Englyssh / then by that so many
the moo men should understand hem / as understand English and no latin The
clerk Ye cunne speak read and understand latin. then it needs not to have
such an englyssh translacion The lord. I deny this argument For though I can
speak read and understand latyn^ there is much latin in these books of
Cronykes that I can not understand / nether thou without studyeng auisement
and lokyng of other books. Also though it were not nedeful for me / it is
nedeful for other men that understand no latin The clerk Men that understand
no latin may learn and understand The lord Not all For sum may not for
other manner business / Sum for elde Sum for defaute of wit Sum for
defaute of catell other of friends to find hem to scole / And sum for other
diverse defautes and lettes The Clerk Hit needs not that all such know the
Cronykes / The lord Speak not to straytly of thing that needs For straytly to
speak of thing that needs / only thing that is and may not faylle needs to
be. And so it needs that God be / for god is and may not faylle / And so for
to speak noman needs for to know the cronykes / ffor it might and may be that
noman hem knoweth^ Otherwise to speak of thing that nedeth^ somewhat needs for
to sustain or to have other things thereby / And so mete and drink needs for
keeping and susteynaunce of life. And so for to speak no man needs for to know
the cronykes^ But in the thyrdd manner to speak of thing that needs / all
that is prouffytable needs / and so for to speak all men need to know the
Cronykes Tle clerk Then they that understand no latin may axe and be
informed and y taught of hem that understand latin The lord Thou spekest
wonderly for the lewd man wot not what he should axe / and namely of loore of
deeds that come never in his mind ner wot of whom comynly he should axe / Also
not all men that understand latin have such books te^forme leude men also some
connen not and sum may not have while / and so it needs to have an english
translacion The clerk The latin is both good and fair / therefore it needs not
to have an englyssh translacion The lord This reason is worthy to be plunged in
a pludde and led in powder of lewdnes and of shame / It might well be that thou
make only in myrthe and in game. The Clerk The reason must stand but it be
assoylled^ The lord A bleere eyed man but he were al blind of wytt might see
the Solucion of this reason / And though he were blind he might grope the
solucion / But if his feelyng him faylled^ For if this reason were ought worth
/ by such manner arguyng me might preue that the three score and ten
Interpretours and aquila Symachus Theodocion and Origenes were lewdly occupied
when they translated holy writ out of hebrewe in to grue and also that saint
Iherome was lewdly occupied when he translated holy writ out of hebrewe in
to latin / For the Ebrewe is both good. and fair and y writ by Inspyracion
of the holy ghost And all these for her translacions ben hyely preysed of al
holy church Then the forsayde lewd reason is worthy to be powdred^ leyed a
water and y soused Also holy writ in latin is boothe good and fair / And yet
for to make a sermon of holy writ al in latin to men that can English and
no latin / it were a lewd deed / for they be never the wyser / For the latin
but it be told hem in English what it is to mean / And it may not be^ told
in englyssh what the latin is to mean without translacion out of latin in to
English / Then it needs to have an english translacion / and for to keep
it in mind that it be not foryeten it* is better that such a translacion be
made and written. than said and not written / and so this foresaid lewd reason
should meue no^an that has any wit to leave the making of English
translacion The Clerk A greeet dele of these books stondeth much by holy
writ. by holy doctors and by philosophye^ then these books should not be
translated in to English The lord It is wonder that thou make so febel
arguments and have goon so long to scole / Aristotle's books and other books
also of logyk and of philosophye were translated out of grue in to latin /
Also at prayeng of king Charles Johan Scot translated denis books out of
grue in to latin. and then^e out of latin in to ffrensshe. then what has
English trespaced that it might not be translated in to English Also king
Alurede that founded the university of Oxenford translated the best laws in to
English tongue / And a greet dele of the Sawter out of latin in to English /
And caused wyrefrith bishop of wyrcetre to translate saint gregoryes books.
the dialogues out of latin in to Saxons Also Cedmon of whythy was enspyred of
the holy ghost and made wonder Poysyes in englisshe nyghe of all the stories
of holy writ Also the holy man beda translated saint John's gospel out of
latin in to Englisshe Also thou wotest where the Apocalips is written in the
walls and roof of a chapel both in latin and in Frensshe Also the gospel and
prophecye and the right feyth of holy church must be taught and prechd to
Englisshe men that conne no latin Then the gospel and prophecye and the right
feyth of holy Church must be told hem in english / and that is not don but
by Englissh tra^lsaco^n for such englissh prechyng is very tra^slaco^n / and
such englisshe prechyng is good and needful. then englissh tra^slacion is
good and needful. The clerk / if a translacion were made that might be
amended in any point / Sum men it would blame The lord / If men blame that is
not worthy to be blamed / then they ben to blame / Clerks know well ynowgh
that no sinful man does so well that it ne might do better. ne make so good a
translacion that he ne might be better^ Therefore Origenes made two translacions
/ And Jerome translated thryes the sawter / I desire not translacion of these
the best that might be for that were an idle desire for any man that is now
alive / But I would have a skylfull translacion that might be know and
vnderstonden The Clerk Whether is you lever have a translacion of these
Cro^ykrs in Ryme or in prose The lord In prose For communly prose is moore
clear than ryme. more easy and more plain to know and understand The Clerk
Then god gran^ce us grace grathly to gynne / wit and wisdom wisely to
worche Might and mind of right menynge to make. translacion trusty and true.
Plesyng to the Trynyte three persons and one god in mageste^ that ever was and
ever shall be and made heaven and earth and light for to shine / And departed
light and derknes. And callid light day and derknes night / and so was made
euetyde and morrow tide one day / that had no morowtyde The second day he made
the firmament between waters And departed waters that were under the
firmamente^ fro the wat^^s that were above the firmamente: And called the
firmament heaven / the third day he gadred watres that been under the firmamente
in to one pl^ace and made the earth vnheled^ and named the gadryng of waters
Sees and dry earth land / And made trees and gras The fourth day he made
son and Moan and st^rres / and set hem in the firmament of heuene there for
to shine and to be tokenes and signs to depart times and years night and day
The fyfthe day he^ made fowls and birds in thayer and fysshes in the Water
The sixth day he made beestes of the land and man of the earth and put hem in
paradys for he should wyrche and won therinne / But man brake gods heste
and fylle in to sin and was put out of paradys in to woe and sorrow worthy to
be dampened to the pain of hell without any end / But the holy Trynyte had
mercy of man / And the fader sent the sone / And the holy ghost a light on a
maid. And the sone took fflesshe and blood of that blysful maid and deyde on
the Rode to save mankind / and aroos the third day glorious and blysful. and
taught his disciplis / and ascended in to heaven when it was time / And shall
come at day of dome and deem quycke and deed / Then all tho that been
writon in the book of life shall wend with him in to the bliss of heaven. and
ben there in body and soul / and see and know his godhede and manhede in
Joy without any ende^

Thus ends the dyalogue
The Epistle of sir Johan Treuisa chapelayn unto lord Thomas of Barkley upon
the translacion of Polycronycon in to our English tongue
WElthe and worship to my worthy and worshipful lord sir Thomas lord of
Barkley^ I Johan Treuisa your priest and ledeman obedyent and ^nxom to work
your will. hold in heart / thenke in thought and mien in mind your nedefful
menyng and speech that ye spak and said that ye would have english
translacion of Ranulphus of chestres books of cronykes / Therefore I wole fond
to take that trauayll and make English translacion of the same books as god
grants me grace / For blame of (...) I not blynue^ For envy of enemies
(...) of evil spekers wol^ I not leave to do this (...) For trauayll will I not
spare / Comfort I have in medeful making and plesyng to god and in knowing
that I wot that it is your will^ For to make this translacion clear and plain
to be known and vnderstonden. In sum place I shall set word for word and
actyf for actyf and passyf for passif arowe right as it stondeth without
chaungynge of the order of words / But in sum place I must change the
order of words and set actyf for passyf and ayenward / And in sum place I
must set a reason for a word. and tell what it meneth / But for all such
chaungyng the menyng shall stand and not be changed. But sum words and
names of countries of lands / of cytees of waters of Ryuers of montaynes and
hills / of persons and of places must be set and stand for hem self in her
own kyndr / as Asia Europa Affryca and Syrya Mount Athlas Syna and Oreb Marach
Jordan and arnon^ Bethleem^ Nazareth Iherusalem and damascus^ Hanybal Rasyn.
assuerus and cyrus and many such words / And names. if any man make of these
books of Cronykes a better Englissh translacion and moore prouffytable god do
him mede / And by cause ye make me do this medeful deed / he that quiteth all
good deeds quyte your mede in the bliss of heaven in welthe and lykyng with
all the holy saints of mankind and the nine ordres of Angelis As angels
Archangels. Pryncipates. potestates virtutes. dominaciones / Trones cherubyn
and seraphyn to see god in his blysful face in Joy without any end Amen

Thus ends he his Epistle
Prolicionycion Prefacio prima ad historiam Capitulum primum /
AFter solemn and wise writers of Art and of science that had swetenes and
lykyng al her lif time to study and to trauaille about connyng and knowleche
of kyndly things and about sobrenes and redynes of thewes / they ben worthy to
ben hyely prey sed / as though it were putting and medlyng to gyder prouffyt
and swetenes^ For they wrote and left to us written meruaylles and wondres.
great berynge out and deeds of our forn faders / of stalworth / wight wise.
and worthy and of diverse manner men that were in old time For in the making of
books of stories that been to us sent and byquethen by great business of the
writers of Cronykes blasen and shynen clerly the right rewle of thewes.
Ensample of living / knowing of goodness. the metyng of the three ways of the
virtues of dyuynyte / and the metynge of the four ways of the four pryncipal
virtues of thewes of Ryal clothyng

Of the which things our lytil cunnyng might not take knowleche ne follow the
fourth / but besynes of writers to our vncunnynge had shadde and stremed
mind of Ancient and old deeds For why short life dull wit slow
understanding and idle occupacions let us to know many things foryetyngnes
always kythyng the craft of a stepdame is enemy of mynde^ Also now in our
time Art Science and law were lost Ensample of noble deeds were not known /
Nobylyte and fair manner of spekyng were all lost / But the mercy of God
almighty had ordained lettres and writing in remedy of the vnperfyghtnesse
of mankynde^

I pray you / who should know Emperors wonders of the Philosophers or else
follow thappostles^ But their noble deeds and their wonder works were not
wreton in hystoryes and so kept in mind / who should know lucillum but
Seneca in^ his Epistles had written his deeds / writing of Poets is more
worth to praysyng of Emperors than all the welthe of this world and Rychesses
that they welded while they were a live / For storye is witness of time /
Mind of life Messagyer of oldenesse / storye weldeth passing doings / story
puts forth her professoures^ Deeds that would be lost story renews /
Deeds that would flee out of mynde^ Storye callith again / Deeds that would
deye storye keeps hem for evermore Wherefore among other noble trauayllours of
the three paths arne most worthy to ben praised fair flourysshers and
embelysshers of words and of meter. that have of their trauaylle gotten great
prys and lawde / We may not (...) praise hem that in Historyes meten and
descryuen all the world wide / But without any dread they shall resseyue
their mede of him that rewardeth^ and quyteth all them that well work. By the
worthynes and ensample of noble writers that herto fore have wreton not
boostynge of mine own deeds ner scornynge / ne blaming other mennys deeds I
have cast and ordained as I may to make / and to write a treatys that I have
gadred out of dyuerce books of the estate of the Ilonde of Brytayne.
otherwise called England unto the knowleche of hem that shall come after us /
Then special lords that knew mine entente / And had desire to know greet
men's deeds prayed me bysyly / that I should also write the famous hystoryes^
and acounte the years from the beginning of the world unto our time / Tho
took I heed that this matier as Labo^^ntus Dedalus house has many halkes and
hurues wonderful ways wyndynge and wrynklynges that will not lightly be
opened and showed / Me shamed and dread to take on me to grant so ferdful
aboone / For ydlenes and slowthe let greet works that men would wyrche / My
wit is full lytil to* vnwynde^ the wrappynges of so wonderful works / The
matiere is large / Writers therinne ben many and greet / For the fullness
thereof men ben al sad and take the less heed and lightly would find fawte
on this simple werke^ And as enemies whette their tongues and bend their brows
/ Of such men speaks Gregorius Nazauzenus that wole lightly blame defawtes of
other men / And not follow so lightly goodness. All this I had in mind And
also I knew mine own pouerte and shamed and dredde after so noble spekars that
sowned as trompes to put forth my barayne speech hoose and snochyng as who
recheth up mulberyes and serves lychorous men that lives in liking with
sour grap^s / For if after the labor of Hercules and after the first
tourneyes strife and Ioustes of Olympye a Pygmeye busketh him to bataylle and
arayeth him to fight. Who might then leave to lawhe / Also who would shonte
to scorn if I pipe with an ooten reed / and vnhighte so noble a / matier with
mowyng gruntynge and whystlynge after so noble spekars that sowned at best
And of hem fair facounde and renable speech flowed and stremed all her life
tyme^ But I have well in mind what Booz seyde to Ruth that was shamefast / and
leese up the eres after his Ryp men / He said noman shall wrath the^ ^ And to
his rypmen he said / If she will with you Ripe / forbede you her not / And
her for to leese or gleyne noman shall let. The Poet also Mantuanus Marro
Virgilius says eth libro decimo / And Oracins as says Hugucio Pisanus in
dininaciouibus suis Capitulo peruiso When Enemies despised Oracius and bare him
on hand that he had taken sum of Homeres versis^ and meddled among his and
called him a gader^^ of old wrytynges^ He answerde and said it were right
greet strength^ to wreste a maas out of Hercules hand / Therefore I pray
that noman blame me / though I fare as sonde and ashes. For though they be dym
and foul hem self. they cleanse other things and make shine full bright. And
many other things that have not in hem self / yet yeuen to other. So seyth the
Poet Satiricus I fare as a whestone that makes iron sharp and kene. Item
Gregorius in suo Pastorali says / I have peynted a well fair man / And am my
self a foul^ peyntoure. Therefore I trust on that Charity that Gregory speaks
of in his Omelye / that wit virtues and strength / that vncunnyng de nyeth /
And auntre me in to Repyng that is fulle of trauaylle and waking in caas
despised of enuyous men and proud. And yet I hope it shall be prouffytable to
good studyers and meke^ ^ shall enter in to the feldes of our fornfaders / And
follow the Rypmen / if I may in any wise leese and gadre somewhat of the
crommes that fallen from Lords bordes that sometime were fulfilled and left
their releef to her childeren And also if I might gadre any scrappes of the
releef of the.xij kipes or lepes^ And some what putto and encre^e writing of
Auctours as a dwerf sitting on a geants neck wherthurgh yonglynges mow be
brought to loore / And gretter men to use and besynes set / mow be informed
and taught by this short treatys. that have not seen the great volumes and
large that been of stories ^reton / Not subtylte of sentence / ne fair
flourysshynge of words. But sw^tenes of devotion of the matters that Regne in
this book In the which book and tretyse well nyghe all the Problemes and
questions of the wysest men ben planted Also many things that been not wreton
in other books / I have gadred of the comyne as though it were of a storye and
wreton in th^^ treatys / by cause men should know hem after our tyme^ For
somdele by malice of enemies. somdele by the slouthe of wrytars knowleche by
great deeds is so nyghe lost and foryeten that scarsely bare names of places
we have not in mind / Though feynyng and sawes of mysbyleuyd and lawles men
And wondres and meruaylles of diverse countries and l^^des ben planted in this
book. such seruen and is good to (...) known of Christian men Virgyle sought
gold of wit an^ wisdom in the fenne of Ennij the Poet And the children of
Israel in her going unto the land of Biheste spoylled the Egypcyans that is
in other books wreton well wide and par celmele planted / Here it is put to
geder myrthe to sadness / and hethen to Christian people eueryche among other
that strange stories ben so a^^egged / shorted and lengthed / that the
historye is hoole and sothnes not changed / Nevertheless more certain sum
is holden than other / For Augustinus de Ciuitate dei says we should trow and
worship the myraclee of god^ And not hem dispreue by disputicion^ Wondres ben
not all to be vntro wed / For sum tell many^ wondres which thou shall
find that thou would not bileue And yet they ben full sothe / kind may not
do ayenste god lord of kind Also of many things that semen full sothe /
Netheles skylfully it is to be doubted Y^dorus eth^ quintodecimo seyth If reason
is uncertain of the building of Rome. what wonder though men be uncertain of
the buyldyng of other Cytees and towns / wherefore we shall not blame makers and
writers of historyes that dyuersly spe^en and written. For long passing of time
and elde of deeds make hem unknown and writers to err / Therefore Iherome says
it is semely to believe their sawes that gaynsaye not our bileue ne sothnes that
is knowe^^ wherefore in the writing of this historye I take not upon me to
afferme for truth all that I write. but such as I have seen and re^de in
diverse books I gadre and write without envy and common to other men For
thappostel says not all that is written is soth But he says all that is wreton
is wreton for our doctrine and loore. And though I take it of other men's / I
call this story mine / And for that I write other whiles mine own words and
sentence of old men / the Auctours that I in the first beginning of this book
take for shelde^ and defense me for to save and keep against enemies that me
would despise strangely and blame / first for my self and for mine own / name I
write this lettre R Here I write and reherce the names of the Auctours of which
this Cronyke is special gadred and drawn / Josephus Iudeorum historicus in
signis qui ab inicio seculi vsque ad ^xiiij (...) domiciani libros antiquitatum

Prefacio secunda ad historiam
ANd for as much as this Cronyke conteyneth berynges and deeds of many times /
therefore I clepe it Policronicon that is the Cronyke of many times / In the
which werk by the ensample of the first wercher that wrought all his works
in six days and / rested in the seventh. For his doing is our doctrine. This
work I depart and dele in seven books / The first book descryueth places
contreyes and lands and all the wide world The other six books by the nombre
of the six ages that conteyneth beryng and deeds from the beginning of the
world unto our time Netheles in the first book of this work as who descryueth
general common and special / mappa mu^di is portrayed and peynted therinne^
which is the cloth that the shappe of the wide world is painted Inn Then in
his chyef parties the world is deled And for this story is trauaylled by cause
of brytayne every prouynce and land is descryued until we come to brytayne
last of all as most special And therein ben contained fyften chapytres
nedeful to the knouleche of the Ilonde of Brytayne as though it were an
Inbryngynge to gretter knowleche in other books that follows / that who that
may not come to fulle knowleche of the full storye may by such forledynge have
liking to leave shrewdnes and sin The second book auentureth for to tell
beryng and deeds with destripcion of the less world And for the ages of the
world be not al euene and of beryng and of deeds and eueery book is even and
conteynth like Therefore the second book conteyneth the berynge and deeds of
the four ages fro the making of our formest fader to thebrennyng of the
temple of the Jews. The thyrdde book from the transmygracion of the pepole to
the coming of Criste / The fourth fro Criste to the coming of the saxones /
The fyfthe from the Saxones to the danes / The sixth from the danes to the
Normans / The seventh from the Normans to our time that is under the regne of
king Edward the thyrdde after the conquest / And so by the prophecy of ysaye
this great story is departed in seven stremes so that both hosed and shooed
gods people may pass thereby

Prefacio tercia ad historiam Capitulum^ Tercium
TO hem that wole have full knowleche of historyes^ it needs eygthe things to
know descrypcions of places / states of things / distynction of times after
following of kingdoms / dyuersyte of living / passing of ages / Manner of doing
and in all these very acountyng of years. The first of these shall be
remembryd in the first book^ And the other in the other books shall be openly
wreton / Touching the second take heed of two estates / One fro the beginning
of the world to Criste^ and that is called the state of mysgoyng. The second
state fro Criste to the worlds end. And that is named the state of grace and
of mercy / For the thyrdde take heed of three times / One to fore the law
wreton^ the second in the time of law wreton^ And the thyrdde under the new
law of Criste of which law is under grace and mercy / ffor the fourth take heed that sometime there were four pryncipal Kingdoms / that is to wete of the
assyryens / Perces / Greeks and Romans / Netheles touching the course of the
world and the process of holy writ the first Kingdom was under our
forfaders fro Adam to Moses. The second fro moses to saul. The thyrdde under
kings fro Saul to Zorobabel / The fourth under Bisshoppes fro Zorobabel to
Criste / For the fyfthe take heed of five manners of living / The first was in
the first age under the law of kind common to all men. the second in the
second age was the living of mysbyleuyd men / when mawmetrye began in Nynus
time king of Nynyue. the thyrdde in the thyrdde age under the law wreton /
when circu^sico^n and law departed the children of israel fro laws and
mysbyleued men / The fourth living of Christian men bigan under Criste. when
bileue and grace of Sacrament hallowed her self. The fyfte living of Sarasyns
began under macho mete as it shall be said in the fyfte book / and after the
time of heraclius the emperor openly showed / ffor the sixthe take heed of sex
ages / One is fro Adam to Noe. The second fro Noe to Abraham / The thyrdde fro
Abrahain to David / The fourth fro david to the transmygracion that was when
Israhel was brought in to thraldom of Babilone / The fyfthe fro the
transmygracion to Crist. The sixthe fro Crist to the worlds end / And here
take heed that ages of the world ben not delid by evenness of years / but by
merueylles that byfelle in her beginning / as the first age began fro the
beginning of the world / The second from Noes flood / The thyrdde fro the
Circumsicion. The fourth fro the beginning of kings / the fyfte from the
transmygracion^ The sixthe fro thyncarnacion of Crist / For the seventh take heed of seven persones^ whose deeds ben wreton in storyes^ that is to were King
in his Royamme / Knight in bataylle / Judge in plee. bishop in Clergy lauful
men in the people / Husbonde in hows. Relygyous man in the church. Of the
which spryngeth out seven famous doings. Buyldyng of Cytees^ Vyctorye of
enemies Making of lawes^ Correction of trespass / help of the common prouffyt^
Gouernyng of meyne and of household / Getyng of blifful mede^ In the which
blaseth and shyneth rewardyng of good men and punysshyng of evil men / For the
eyghte / take heed of echt diverse manner of acountyng of years / Three the
Jews use. three the Greeks / One the Romans / And the Christian men oue / ffor
the Jews in tretys^ and couenauntes have a year vsual^ And begins in
Ianyuer^ In devotion and sacryfyce they have a year lawful and begins in
march / Also they have a year of apperyng that they use in Calculyng and in
Cronyke / And begins in May when they passed out of Egypt. Also the
greeks in three manner wise acount^n their years First for Joy of the vyctorye
they acounte her years fro the taking of Troy. Afterward they acounte her by
olympiades that been the times of their Ioustes and tournementes / But after
that they reigned they acounted their yere^ by her regnyng in this manner Anno
Regni Grecorum quinto vel tercio tali vel tali sicut patet in libro Machabeorum
/ when the Romans waxed in her flowers they acounted her years fro the
buyldyng of the Cite ab vrbe condita^ But Christian men fro the Incarnacion of
Criste acou^ten her years / But when me comes to that place men must take heed / that the Calculyng of denis that england and F^aunce folowen has less
by xxij year than the calculyng of Iherome that follows the Gospel / willelmus
Malmesburyensis bbro.4^ de pont says that marianus scotus. and the monk
prysoned in maguncia a town of almayn about the year of grace a / M / three
score / and / xvj. looked bysyly in books and acounted and fond that dyonisyus
exiguus acordeth not with the gospel in acountyng of yeres^ ffor this Scot
marianus acou^ted all the years from the beginning of the world and put to
xxii year that lacked of denis acountes. And wrote a great cronyke and an huge
/ the which book Robert bishop of herforde deflored. and that for it is that
the common Cronikes that foloweden denis faylled al daye^ ffor I^erome in
translatyng the cronyke of Eusebij say^h that years lack between Cristes
passion and vaspasianus tyme^ And also.xij. years lack about decius cezars
time as it is showed in the / vj^ age / This error bifalleth for days and
months were vnrekened that kings reigned over full years. Also days and
months that voyded between two kings were forgoten. wherefore in this book I
shall mark as I may how and what years such defawtes fylle / So that I shall
hyghte the margyns by the hedes of the historyes sum wych double and sum
with treble rows of years. ffrom Abraham to the cite y buyld^ I set to
geders the year of the age of the world and of the ledare. ffro the Cite y
buyld to Criste I set to gyder the year of the age of the cite and of the
ledare. And fro Crist^ forthward I write to geder the year of grace / and of
the prince that reigned

Cronica Ranulphi Cistrensis Monachi De orbis dimensione prescianus in
Cosmagraphia Capitulum quintum
IVlius Cezar by counseyl of the Senators / And Aldermen of Rome sought and
serched historyes and books of his years of doing and deeds. And ordained
wysemen and ready to mesure and descryue all the world about. Then fro
Julius time to Saturmus time xxxij year. Messagers wise men and well y taught in
the practyke of Geometrye cunnyng and prouffytable to mesure and g^sse hygnes
and lownes^ length and bread and depnes also were redyly sent to every land
about to Iugges and Capytayns / to Governors of lands / ffor they should
mesure and descryue Land and water / woods and laundes valeys and playnes /
Montaynes and downs. And the sea stronde and every place where any man might
goo or ride. or ship sayle^ And write and certefye the senators where and
what wondres were founden / R. This witnesses Iherome in translatyng the
hystorye of Eusebi libro secundo / cao. secundo / there he says that pylate
Judge of the Iurye certefyed. Tiberyus cezar of merueylles and wonders that
Criste wrought in the Iewrye / and Tiberius certefyed the Senatours^ but the
Senators byleued not^ ffor they had not herd a fore so wonder works /
prescianus and so by warnyng and certefyeng of Capytayns of lands it was
founden and known that all the world about has sees of diverse names ^xxx^
Ilondes / lxxij. Famous montaynes / xl / Prouynces / lxxviij / Noble cytees /
iij.C / lxx Great Ryuers / lvij^ Diverse nations an. C and fyfe and twenty /
The roundenes of the world about is three honderd sythes / and fyften sythes an
honderd thousand paas The length of the earth that men dwell Inn fro the
eeste to the weste / that is fro Inde to the pylers of hercules in the Sea
Gadytan is iiij score sythes. and / v / sythes. an^ C / lxxviij mile / but the
way from that one end to that other is much less by waterthan by land. The
bread of the earth fro the southe to the north that is from the clyf of Occean
in Ethyopia the land of blak men to the mouth of the River of Thany is well
nyghe haluen dele less than the length. and conteyneth / liiij.C / and / lxij
mile also it is fond that the deppest place of the Sea of myddel earth
conteyneth down right fyften furlonge deep. R / Tholomeus says that the
Roundenes of a Cercle about conteyneth thryes so much as the bread and the
seuendele of the bread / So that the proporcion of two and twenty to seuen^ So
that is acounted that the roundenes of the earth about conteyneth twenty
thousand and forty mile / if we depart that sum a three and the seventh part
of the third. the thycknes of the earth thurghout is almost sex thousand and
five honderd. four score and enleuen mile / Then half the thyknes of the
earth inward / and down right / is three thousand two C^ five and forty myle^
and somewhat over as it were half a mile / So if hell is in the myddel of the
earth down right it may be known how many mile it is to hell.

De orbis diuisione / Augustinus de cinitate dei libro sexto capitulo / Octauo
Capitulum Sextum
THe departing of the world take heed that the great See of Occean beclyppeth
all the earth about / And the Earth is departed in three great parties. Asia
that is one parte^ Europa that other / And Affryca the thyrdde / But the three
parties ben not all even like much / ffor Asia one of the three conteyneth
half the earth / And stretches fro the southe by the eeste unto the north /
And is closed about with the sea of Occean / But it ends wes^ward at great
See / Beda de naturis. his ends ben the mouth of the River Nylus in the south
and of the River thanays in the north. Ysidorus libro quarto / decimo /
capitulo quarto / That other part europa stretches dounward fro the River
thanays by the north / Occean to the costs of Spain and joins to the great
See by Eeste and by southe And ends in the Ilonde Gades. Item / Ysidorus /
capitulo quinto / Affryca the thyrdde part stretches fro the west to the
southe unto the Coost of Egypt / And these two parties Affryca and Europa ben
departed a sounder by an Arm of the Sea Before libro 3o. co. po. The mouths
of that Arm conteynen ffyften thousand paas in length / and five thousand
paas in breed. And of thylke mouths the Sea of myddel earth begins / And by
diverse arms spredeth and wexeth inward the lands

De parcium orbis descripcione^ before liliro sexto^ prescianus in
Cosmagraphia Capitulum septimum
ASia is most in quantite / Europa is less / And like in nombre of people /
But Africa is lest of all the iij parties both in place and in nombre of
people^ And therefore sum men that knew men and lands acounted but two
parties of therthe only^ Asia and Europa. And they acounted that Affryca is
narowe in bread and evil doers / Croupt ayer^ wild beestes / And venomous
dwellen therein / Therefore they that acounte Affryca the third part acounte not
by space and mesure of length and bread / But by diverse disposicions better
and worse and depart Affryca fro Europa and Asya as a sore membre that is not
fro membrys that been hoole and sound and in good point at the best Also
Affryca in his kind has less space. And for the sturenes of heaven it has
the more wyldernes / And though Affryca be lytil. it has more wyldernes and
waste land. ffor great brennyng of hete of the son / Then Europa for all
the chele and great cold that is therinne / ffor why all that lives and
grows may better endure with cold than with hete^ But mesure rules both /
Before libro sexto / Therefore it is that Europa nouryssheth and brings forth
fair men larger and gretter of body myghtyer of strengthen hardyer and bolder
of heart and fayrer of shappe than Affryca. ffor the son beme always abides
upon the men of Affryca / And draws out the humors and makes hem short of
bodyes^ black of Skyn / Crypse of beer / And by drawyng out of spyrytes makes
hem coward of heart / The con^^^rye is of northeren men In the cold without
stops smal^ hooles and porus. and holds the hete withinne^ And so makes
hem fatter gretter and whyter withinne. and so hardyer and bolder of heart

De mari magno medio sieve mediterraneo Before libro 3o. capitulo primo^

nono. And that see is swetter shorter and more mysty For ffresshe Ryuers al
about run and fallen thereto. In that great mouth and baye ben ylondes as

/ Cytees and towns that it passes by / and happes that fall therein is

De Occeano / ysidorus libro 13o. Capituluin nouum
The sea of Occean byclyppeth all therthe about as a garlond. and by times
comes and goth / ebbyng and flowyng and flows in sees and casts hem up /
And wyndes blown therein. Before libro secundo / / capitulo 99 / The high
flood of Occean aryseth upon the costs of brytayn four score Cubits high And
that rysynge and depnes is better known by the clyues than in the high see /
ffor betynge of veins is better known in the utter parties of the body than
in ward in the myddel within Eueryche flood aryseth more in occean than in the
great see that is for the hoole to gyder is myghtyer and stronger than any
party by him self / Or for the hool Occean is great and large and receives.
more workyng of the moon than any party by him self that is smaller and lasse^
Therefore lakes / Ryuers / Pondes and other ffresshe wuters ne ebb ne flow as
Occean does / Before libro secundo^ capitulo 7. Occean spredeth and shedeth in
to dyueerse mowthes and costs toward the land / And in many places well nyghe
touches the Inner sees. so neyghe that the mouth that is called^ Arabicus /
and is the mouth and the cost of the reed see is fro the sea of egypt. but
fyfty thousand paas also the mouth and see that is called caspius is but three
honderd / lxxv / mile fro the great see that is called Eusinus / Beda de
naturis. Among all the mowthes and sees that comes toward the land and out
of the Occean three ben holden most famous. The mouth and see has two names
and is called gadytanus and athlantycus also The second is called caspius / and
enters out of nor^heest and departs bitwene the northsyde of Inde and Sicia
that land An^ that stretches toward the great mouth and see that is named
Eusmus / The thyrdde mouth and see is the reed see and comes out of the
northeest. and departs the south side of ynde fro ethiopia and egypt / ffro
thylke two lands then the reed see stretches forth and departs in ij
mouths and sees. that one is named persicus and stretches northward / that
other is named. Arabicus and stretches westward and toward the great see. This
read see is not reed of kind / but it flassheth and wasseth on the reed
cleues and stones and so is y dyhed reed as a roose / therefore of the clyues and
stronde of the reed see is gadred vermylon and read precious stones-Solmus. by
the sea that is called caspius ben hills that been called (...) hills of
caspij and have in length^ (...) / thousand paas / and in bread vn^ethe the
space of a cartwaye / In the sides of the hills of caspij salt veins melte
and wose (...) humors and moisture y dreyed and clongen by heete of (...) ne.
joins and cleueth to gyder / as yse or glass / And so men (...) not clymme on
the hills the weye is so slyther. Also every draught is full draw in the space
of xxviij / thousand paas^ the land is dry without socoure^ and addres and
serpents fallen therto^ so that but it be winter there may no man come
therinne^.R / Marcianus says that the yates of Caspij ben fast shette wi^h
iron barris and in spryngyng time fast barred for serpents and adders / And
the master of historyes says that at prayers of king Alexander the hills
of caspij were closed and joined to gyders / Paulus in historia long. lio. po.
/ There ben many swole wyngys and whirlyngys of waters by the sea brynkes tweyne
ben in the sea of myddel earth between Italye and the Ilonde Scicilia / thylke
two swolowes ben called scylla and carybdys of the which speaks vyrgyle / and
seyth Scilla is perilous in the rightsyde / and carybdys in the lift side /
Other swolewys and perils of water ben in Occean / One is in the west^ clyue
of brytayn and is called the nauel of the sea / the other is between brytayn
and gallycia^ and it is said that these swolewes twyes in the night and day
swole with in stremes and flodes and cast hem up agayn^ Also it draws in
ships and casted hem again as swyftly as an arowe to a man's sight.

De prouyncijs orbis / Et primo de Paradiso. Capitulum decimum
FOr the knowleche of erthly paradyse / three points must be known / wherefore
three questions must be axed^ the first question axeth if any such place is on
earth / The second axeth whytherward^ and where is paradyse in earth. the
third axeth what country and place is paradyse in erthe^ ffor the first four
manner witnessis we have that paradyse is in earth / ffyrst stories that lykened
Sodom er it were ouertourned to paradyse^ The second witness is of hem that
assayed^ wrote and said that they had seen that place / The thyrdde wytnes /
ben the four Ryuers that rennen out of paradise. ffor the heed of thylke
ryuers ben not founden in see ne in ffresshe water ner in land that men dwell
Inn though Kings of Egypt and many other trauaylled well often and sought there
after. Therefore Ysid ^xiij. eth^ says that Iherom took head that other
understanding byhoueth of the Ryuers of paradyse than Auctours written. Also
Basilius in exam^ron / ysid eth^ libro xiiij. and Josephus libro primo sayen
that waters falling of the highest hylle of paradyse maken a great ponde / and
out of that ponde / as it were a well the four Ryuers spryngen / Petrus
capitulo 14 / Of the which four Ryuers the first is physon / And is to menyng
full wexynge of plente / That River physon passes in to Inde and draws with
him golden grauel^ Phison has another name^ and is called ganges of a King of
Inde. which was named Gangarius. But Ganges is to say. Felawship and
Company. For it receives t^n great Ryuers that rennen thereto / The second is
called / Gyon and Nylus also. And goth about Ethiopia and Egypt The thyrdde
is Tygris / And as Josephus says dyglath also that is to say sharp. ffor it
is swyfte as Tygris which is a right swyft beeste. And Tygris passes toward
Assyria that land / Ysidorus libro tercis decimo^ The most certain Auctour
Salustius says that there comes a well out of Cerannes the hills of Armenye
and spryngeth out of the foot of the hylle that is called Cancasus. And that
well is the heed of tweyne Ryuers^ of Tygris and of Eufrates. the which two
Ryuers sometime ben^ departed a sonder and sometime medlid to gyders. and of^e
time they ben swolowed in to the earth / And after spryngen up again. And long
after goon about. Mesopotonya that land / and dounward in to the reed Se^e.
R. And though men read in books that Nylus comes out of Paradyse / Yet sum
men affermen and say that Nylus spryngeth in the weste side of the land of
Ethiopia not fe^ fro the hylle that is named Athlas / And gooth about Ethiopia
and dounward by Egypt / Seche the proprete of Nylus in the Chapter Egiptus^
The fourth witness and proof that such a place is in Earth that is called
Paradyse^ is old Fame and long durynge^ ffor men shall bileue old fame that is
not withseyde^ But Fame of Paradyse has endured without gaynsayeng six
thousand year and more. For fro the beginning of the world unto our days it
has endured. And Fame that is false endures not so long. ffor it falls out
of mind or is dispreuyd by Sothnes known / Of the second question that Axeth
in which side of the world and in what place paradyse should be^ Though that
short wytted men and lytil of assaye say that paradyse is long sayllyng out
of the earth that men dwell Inn^^ And also departed from the earth. and is as
high as the moon / it is not to be bileued^ ffor nature and reason both
withsaye it / ffor if paradys were departed atwynne fro the earth that men
dwell Inne^ ne water ne eyer might bear such a burden / also the fuyer
occupyeth all the myddel space between thayer and the moon / then paradyse
is not there^ ffor then nothing might live therinne / also if paradyse were
so hyghe^ sometime it should take a way the light and make eclypse of the moon.
but of such an eclypse herd we never Also if paradyse were so high and
departed a sonder from every land and earth. how should the four Ryuers that
spryngen out of paradyse pass by the air and the wide see and come in to
lands that men dwell Inn / And if men say that paradyse is so high that in
one place it contynueth to the earth that men dwell June / Then the earth is
enlong and not round al about as wise men descryuen hit^ but that may not
stonde^ For it is know by experyence and assaye that in every eclypse of the moon the earth makes a round shield / Therefore the earth with all his parties
must needs be rounde^ And so wise men conclude that paradyse is in the
vttermest ends of the eest. and that it is a great country of the earth no
less than Inde or Egypt / and a large place and couenable for all mankind to
dwell Inne^ if mankind had not sinned. Of the thyrdde that axeth of paradyse
what manner place it should be. ysid says / libro 14 / ca / 3o. / that this name
paradis y turned out of grue in to latin is as much to say as an orchard but
paradise in ebrew is called ede^ that is to say lykynge^ The which tweyne y
put to gyder makes an Orchard of lykyng.R. no wonder^ ffor in that place is
all thing that acordeth to lyf^ Ysid libro quarto decimo / There is health for
the eyer is attemperat neither to hot ne to cold so that nothing that lives
may deye therinne. that withnessith Enok and hely that yet ben there a lyue^
Johannes damascenus that place has fair weder and myrthe / ffor it was the
celer and place of all fairenes. no manner tree leseth there his leaves. ne
flowers there fade There i^ myrthe and swetenes of fruit and trees that grow
there / Genesis secundo capitulo / It is wryton every tree therinne is sweet to
ete and fair to sight / Therinne is sykernes and sewrte. for the place is high
/ R / petrus / ca^ 13o. says that the water of the great flood comes not in
paradyse Though sum men say that paradyse is high as the moon / that is not
soth in words and in deed but that speech is saved by an excusacion of spekyng
that is called yperbolyca / So that they that speken would mean that paradyse
in heyght passes all other lands / Treuisa / So we praise an erthly man
Jordan or Iohan^ and say that he was the best man that ever was. and yet he
was never so good as criste^ So in words that / subtle men well dyuyne the
menyng is true and good / but alas as ysidorus says libro nono. capitulo
primo Our way to paradyse is fast stopped by cause of the sin of our forn
fader / hit is closed al about with a brennyng wall so that the brennyng thereof
arecheth to heaven. as sum men would wene paradyse is closed with that wall to
hold out mankind / angels stonden / on that wall to keep well paradys that none
evil goostes mow come therein.

De Asia and prouincijs eius. Ysidorus libo. / 14 Capitulum vndecimum
YSydorus says that asia has the name and is called after a woman that
dwelled therinne / which was named Asia In Asia ben many prouynces and lands
the which I shall descryue and rekene al along. and begin with ynde. ynde
has in the est side the son rysyng / In the south the sea Occean / In the
weste the River of ynde. In the north the hylle that is called Cancasus. And so
ynde is end. In ynde ben men of color and hew dyed / In ynde is a byrd that
is named phytacus. elephantis peper^ and a tree that is called hebanus / yuory
and precious stones beryls / Crisopassis / Carbunclis^ adamantis. and golden
hills. to the which it is full hard for to come / For dragons and grypes and
for diverse manner men grysly and wonderly shapen^ Among all the lands of
this world / ynde is grettest and most rich strengest and most full of
people / In wonder and meruaylles most wonderful. In Inde a croppe of a fyghe
tree is so great and so wide sprad^ that many companyes of men may sytte at
mete well enough there under / That causes the goodness of the land / temperure
of weder and plente of water^ Before libro sexto / capitulo / 19 / In ynde ben
many kings and peoples / Sum of hem tylleth the land / Sum uses chaffare
and marchandyse Sum knygthode and chyualrye. And sum ben great clerks In
ynde ben treees that have tops as high as men shall shote with an arowe. Also
of a gobet between tweyne knottes of a reed in ynde men make a boot that bears
three men attones over a deep water / In ynde ben men of five Cubyte long that
wexe not seek n^r yield up the breath. Also there ben satiri and other diverse
men grysly and wonderly shapen. There Inn ben men of a Cubyte long / and ben
named pygmey. These pygmey geten childeren. and engenderen in the fourth yere^
and wexe hoar in the ^v^ They gadre a great host / and ryden upon weders and
Rams to fight with Cranes / and destroyen their nestes and her eggs For the
Cranes that been their enemies should not encrece and wexe to many / There ben
bis^ philosophers that biholde on the son all the day long / Also sum have
heedes as it were hounds. And the voys that they make / is lyker to berkynge
of hounds than to man's voys They ben clothed in wild beestes Skynnys / And
Armed with her owen teth and nails and lyuen by huntyng and hawkyng. Other
there ben that have no mouth and lyuen by odor and smellis / and ben clothed in
moss and heery toftes that grow out of trees / Other wexe hoer in yongthe and
wexen black in elde / In some hills of ynde ben men that have the sooles of
their feet ouertorned and.viij. fyngers in one hand. Tull de tust / 9o. / In
one country of ynde every man has many wives. but when the husbonde is deed.
the wives shall goo to gyders and look which of hem was best byloued of the
husbonde / and she shall be buried with him and put in the earth quyck and a
live / And in that country that is the fairest hap and fortune acounted and
also worship that any wife might have / Petrus / 19 / 6^ In ynde hen trees that been called trees of the son and of the moon. Prestes that ete of the Apples
of thylke trees lyuen v / C / year / they were called the trees of the son
ffor eueryche of them quaked / and shook as soon as the son beme touched his
top / and answered men that stood about. The same doing was of the trees of
the mone^ By these trees. the great king Alysaundre was forboden that he should
never come in babylone / Ysydorus libro / 15 / Offyr is an Ilond of Inde there
Inn is great plente of gold / And the passage thereto out of greece is by the
reed see

Capitulum duodecimum De parchia Ysid libro. 14
YSydorus shows that parchia that kingdom for mygh^ (...) strength of men of
that land that her name spradd (...) the lands of Assiria and media and was
woonte to cont^^^ (...) the land of four contreyes^ of Assiria^ Media Persida
and of (...) mania / the which londe^ perchia stretches in length fro the
Se^ that is called caspius unto the Reed See / And in bread from the River of
Inde / to the River that is called Tigris / That is the bygynnyng of the land
/ that is named. Mesopotonya / Trogus libro decimo capitulo / quynto. Perchij
the men of Perchia in the langage of the country of Scicia were outlawes^ and
when the kingdom was taken from the men of Media to the men of Persidia /
then were the perchi as it were pray to the vyctours and were as it were
unknown emonge men of the eeste l^ndes unto the time that men of macedonia
bycam kings and lords of lands. Then afterward they served the Macedoyns
when the macedoyns were vyctours in the eeste lands / But at last they were
parteners with the Romans and deled / lordship with hem^ These perchij vseden
the manners of men of Scicia* that put hem out sometime. therefore her arms and
wepen ben fethery. swellyng wits. gyleful espyes Men they acounte violente^
and wynmen mylde. and ever they ben vnesy to her owen neighbors or to strange
men / They ben comynly stylle and lytil of speech / more ready to do than for
to speke^ therefore they holden pryue good happes / and bonchyef. as well as evil
happes and meschyef They ben obedyent to their lords for dread and not for
shame / They ben all disposed to lecherye with their own wives / eueryche of
them has many wives / No trespaas among them is punysshed so grievously as
aduoultrye by her law. therefore they forbeden their wives open sight. festes
and company of other men^ They lyuen scarcely and by lytil mete^ and ete no
fflessh but veneson. Giraldus.17. Thylke men after they left king S^lencus
dwelleden under the king Arsaces^ And therefore they were called Arsacide / That
king Arsaces taught hem first laws. he gadred knights and builded castellys
/ Cytees and strong walled towns. And at last Arsaces the king joined the
kingdom of hircania to his Empire / And so men of hircania longed to his
empire. Emonge the which afterward among other kings come Metridates.
Metridates soon after the death of Crassus consul of. Rome / Reigned and held
the kingdom.xliij yere^ In the which time he did many viages and had many
fair vyctoryes as it is declared within forth in his place / Trogus libro.14 /
parchij the men of Parchia ben in the myddel between Scitas men of Scicia and
medes men of media that land / And Parchij have many bondmen emonge them. For
they ben never made free. their fre men ryden always on horsbak^ And their
bondmen goon a foote^ And in battle they fyghten on horse / they goo^ to pryue
office / and to common festes^ but they teache bysyly their childeren to ride and
to shote. And eueryche of hem by his richesse and power find to their kind
horsemen in bataylle for to fygthe^ they conne not fight in common manner. ner
they conne not bisege castles nor strong walled towns / they fygthe on horse
rennyng in full course and tornyng again / And often in strengest and hardyest
fight / they feyne for to flee and suddenly torn / and fight aagayn that they
mow the slylyer win and slay their enemies / In battle they use tabours and
no trompe. and they mow not endure long for to fight / No men should hem
awelde and withstonde if they were as strong and stalworth to endure^ as they
ben angry and hasty to fighte^ their buryeng is wonderful ffor beestes teeren^
eten and al to halen their flessh. And they burye only but the bones

De assiri^s ysid libro.14 Capitulum / 13 /
Take heed that Assiria has the name of Assur^ Se^mes sone for he was. the
first that dwelled therinne after noes flode this land Assiria has in the
eest side Inde. In the south media / In the weste the River tigris and in the
north the hylle that is called cancasus / there ben the yates of caspye^ there
the hills ben long and narowe / trogus libro / 42 / Egeus was king of Athenes
/ Medus was Egeus sone and followed the deeds of Jason that was his own
stepfader^ and buylt the cite of media and called the cite Media also / In
worship of his mother that was named Medea / that land medea has in the north

EGipte has the name of egypt danays brother / and highte sometime Aeria and

nylus / and is rich of corn of fruit and of Marchandyse^ Petrus capitulo^ 94
Egypt against kind of other lands when it has plente of corn. it is bareyn
of pasture^ And grass grows afterward in time. There ben Cocodrylly and
ypotamy also that been water horses. Egypt has in the ceste side a great
wilderness and dyuerce manner beestes wonderly shape^ and in the west canopea /
the which Ilond is the end of egypt / and beginning of libia. there is the
mouth of Nylus. ffor there Nylus falls in to the great see. R^ Though men
read in books that Nylus that is named gyon renneth out of Paradyse / Yet it
is said that Nylus spryngeth up in the west end of Ethiopia not fer from the
hylle that is named Mons. Athlas / And then nylus goth for^h about Ethiopia
and down in to Egypt and ouerfloweth the plain countrees of Egypt. and by
cause of slyme that renneth therwi^h it makes the land fat and good to here
corn and fruit. so seyth Jerome upon the prophet Amos by gods owen
ordenaunce^ Nylus ouerfloweth and watreth all the land of Egypt / For heepes
of grauel stop his course that it may not lyg^tly fall in to the great see^
But after that it has so biflowe and watered the land the heepes of grauel
depart and fall / And then the water falls in to the chanel again and
renneth in to the great see. Netheles. Ysid seyth libro 13 / that nylus is
driven again and let^e of his course with the northeren wynde^ And so the water
swells flows and wexeth grete^ But beda in libro de naturis seyth that the
Northeren wind blowith in may and stopped the course of the water of Nylus
with heepes of grauel and so the water aryseth and ouerfloweth the land / But
when the wind ceseth the grauel to shedeth and the water falls in to the
chanel and so renneth dounward in to the great see

Capitulum. 17 /
TEre take heed of two lands that each of hem is named Scicia / the over is in
Asia / and the nether is in Europa. The over Scicia is a great land in the
north / and has much wilderness by cause of great cold and chele and
stretches sometime estward unto Inde / northward toward oecean / And southward
to the hylle caucasus And westward unto Germania but now it is made less and
ends in the west side to hircania / in the which land ben the hills
Iperborey. great gripes^ gold and smaragdes. and other precious stones^ Trogus
libro secundo Thylke men destyngeth not nether mark her feldes by bounds / ne
by dyches they have none hows for to dwell in^ their wives and her childeren
they led in cartes^ and they ben clothed in wyld beestes skynnes. woollen
clothes use they none^ they live by mylk and by honey. they recche not of gold
ne of Silver they make nothing that they dread to leese / they account no
trespaas gretter than Robbery / their men of war and vyctours desire nothing
but worship^ they were never subget yet to any man. They overcame vesor the
king of Egypt in war and bataylle / they chaced and fered darius the king
of Perce / and made him flee / They sloughe Cyrus the king also / they
destroyed Zephirona and his riches / Zephirona was the great Alysaunders
Capytayn. thryes they co^querd asia^ and asia was afterward to hem a thousand
and five honderd year / the men of this people be by hem self / And the wymmen
by them self Also they made kyngdoms of dyuerce lands. the men made of
perchia and bactria^ And the wymmen of Amasonia kyngdoms mighty and strong /
And so it is emonge hem uncertain and unknow whether is more worthy and more
noble in nature and kynde^ men or wymmen. In the first journey in asia after
that they had driven chaced and poursewed vasor the king of Egypt. In the
tornyng again they abode / xv. year for to make pees in asia. But wives made
great pleyntes and sorrow that her husbondes were so long from home / and so the
men were sent fore and turned home / and dwelled with their wives. In the
second Journey the men were by treson y slain / and the wives took great wreche
of the enemies / In the third journey the men were out and absent four years
to geder. And the wives wedded her own servants and bond men that were
left at home for keeping of beestes But when her lords and husbondes had the
vyctorye / and turned home again / the wives and the new husbondes gadred hem
to geders and arrayed hem in a great bataylle to fight again their old lords
and husbondes that were coming homeward / and when they met to gyders Fortune
was unstable and unsteadfast ones with that one side and efte with that other
that the lords bithought hem and concluded to fight other wise with their
own land men than with their enemies of strange lands / And cast away her
owen Armor and wepen of knygthes. and bare whippes in her hondes. And so
feered the chorles and the false wives that had broken their wedlock that they
had shameful death. ffor sum were slain with iron and sum were hanged full
high / After this journey was peace in Scicia unto the time of darius king of
Persida / then darius was overcome of the Scytes men of Scicia^ And in the
tornyng homeward he overcome macedones that been men of macedonia of that land.
And warred upon Athenienses men of Athenes / Bactria is a land that cham Noes
sone dwelled first in / And stretches fro the Sea Caspius unto the River of
Inde^ And has in the west side the mount cancasus and in the south perchia
This hille cancasus is lengest of all the eest hills and most famous / and
stretches fro the ends of Inde unto the hille that is named mount Taurus / So
that mount Taurus and cancasus is contained al one hylle. but sum men say
that the weste side of cancasus that is toward Armenia / is. and heyte mount
Taurus / That mount cancasus has in the north side the sea that is named
caspius and hircania that land. And in the south side perchia and assiria and
babylon / That hille by cause it stretches to diverse contreys and lands has
many and diverse names^ that hylle is highest on the eest side / And for
whytnes of snow that lies always theron^ it is called mons cancasus. that is
to say the white hille. Albertus says that hille is so high that men that
dwell thereby seen the son beme in the weste side three hours within night
And so many hours to fore the day in the eest side of the hille^ Hircania that
land has in the eest side the Sea caspius. In the south Armenia / In the north
Albania / And in the west Iberia that lond^ And lies by the side of the mount
cancasus / and has the name of that wood that is called hircania. In that
land ben diverse wyld beestes and fowls. Tigris that beeste and pantera also /
That land is wide and large / and has.xliiij. manner men / Sum tyllen land.
And sum lyuen by huntyng^ And sum eten man's flesshe^ there ben birds that been called hircane: her feathers shynen by nyght^ Iberia that land lies under
mount Taurus / and lies westward fast by pontus / and joins to armenie /
albania that land has in the est side the sea caspius and stretches dounward
by the mouths of the north Occean unto the waters that been named meotydes /
And the men of that land ben born with white here and with yelowe eyes y
peynted / And seen better by night than by day. The hounds of that land ben
so great so grym and so strong that they throw down bulls and sleen lions
One of thylke hounds was sent to king Alysaunder and faught with in lystes

Capitulum^ 18 /
CApadocia that land nouryssheth and fedeth many horses. and has in the eest
