first in the north side it conteyneth bythinia in the beginning upon the Sea
against Tracia / and is named also the more ffrigia^ The chyef cite of bythinia
is named Nychomedia. Then is galathia and has the name of men that were
Gally that come at prayer of the king of Bithinia to help him in his warris
and dwelled in that land galathia^ but tho that land was called gallogrecia /
And the men of that land gallogreci as men y medlyd of gallys and of grecis.
But now they ben called galathe. and to hem Poule writes his epistle ad
Galathas^ The thyrdde is the less ffrigia^ And has the name of frigia
Europaes dougther / Agenors dougther / and that frigia was named dardania also
of dardanius Iupyters sone in that land is the cite of troy that is named
Ilium also Troy is named after troos erictonius sone that was dardanius sone
that was Iupyters sone That land has in the eest side lidia / and in the west
the mowth and the Sea Elespontus The fourth is lidia / and is in the eest side
of the eeste ffrigia / In that lidia reigned sometime the rich king Cresus. But
when that land was to lytil for two brethren that were kings that highte
lyddus and Tirenus. hit happened by lotte that Tirenus went out with many men
and gate him a land in the over party of Galya / and called his land Tirea /
It seems that the Sea Tyrenus has the name of this king Tirenus as the land
lidia has the name of his brother liddus. The chyef Cite of lidia is called
smyrma to that cite saint Johan euangelyst writes in thapocalipsis / the chyef
River of lidia is named pactolus and brings forth golden grauel as poets
tellen / The fythe prouynce of the less Asia is called pamphilia and Isauria
also^ the chyef cite of that land is namod Selencia. that cite selencus.
Anthyochus builded and arered^ Then is Scilicia^ and conteyneth licia / and
that is called licaonia therein were noble cytres lystris and derben as it is
wreton in Actibus apostolorum By thylke Cytees men saylle out of Siria to
Italya / But the chyef cite of all these was Tharsis dounward toward the Sea
Amasonia that land is sum in Asia. And sum in Eur^pa and is neygh to
Albania^ The first Amazones were the wives of goths that took wrecche of her
husbondes death that were traytourly slain. For they took prays and slow men
and saved wymmen. and lived long without husbondes^ And afterward made hem two
queen's / that one lad the Ooste and mayntened the warre^ And warred fast* That
other queen was at home and reuled the land and governed the people at home.
And these wymmen held under hand a great dele of Asia about an honderd year /
And at last these wymmen would have childeren^ And took husbondes of the
next contreys aboute^ And certain times let their husbondes lie by them and
certain times absteyned them

But they slew all the men childeren / And saved the maid childeren / And
taught hem for to shote^ And to do deeds of Arms and of chyualrye. And for
great breasts should not let hem to shote / of every maid of seven year old
they burnt of the right breast. And therefore they were called vrimamme. that is
to say burnt breasts / And they were named Amazones that is to say without
breast. Hercules was the first that chastysed the ylle disposicion of these
wommen / And then Achilles / And at last the great Alysaunder / And though
ysid eth^ 14. seyth that the great Alysander destroyed Amazones / netheles the
storye of Alysaundre says that when king Alysaunder axed of hem trybute.
Thalestrys the queen of Amasones wrote to king alysander in this maner^ Of thy
wit is wonder that thou desyrest to fygthe with wymmen. For if fortune
favor us / And thou be overcome it shall be great shame and vylonye when thou
art overcome of wymmen / and if our gods be wroth with us and thou overcome
us for to win the maystrye of wymmen / thou getest but lytil worship / King
Alysander was plesyd with this and granted hem fredom / and said wymmen must
be overcome with fayrenes / and love and not with steornes and dread / Trogus
bbro / 2 / This queen Thalestrys after that she had been king Alysaunders lemman
forty days she turned again in to her owen land / And afterward in short
time fyl in with her owen people

De Affryca et eius prouyncijs ysid libro 14 Capitulum / 19
All Auctores of. historyes witness that affryca has the name of affer
Madians sone abraham's sone that was gotten on Cethura. Affryca stretches forth
from the ends of Egypt by the south by the nether Ethiopia unto the hylle of
Athlas / And is closed in with the great see both in the eeste side and in the
north side also / and has in the west side the weste Occean / R. Josephus
libro primo capitulo octauo^ And Ysidorus libro nono / sayn that this Affer lad
his ooste toward libia^ and overcome his enemies by the help of the more
hercules and named the men and the land after his own name Affryca. hercules
wedded ethea affers daughter and gate on her dederym. Of dederym came pharon^
This Affryca conteyneth many prouynces and lands / First it conteneth the west
dele of Ethiopia^ then libia. tripolis getula^ numidia. and two maritania /
Of all these now by order is our speech. Ethiopia has three parties the first
is hylly and mo^tuous. and stretches fro the mount Athlas unto / Egypt / The
myddel party is full of grauel. The thyrdde that is the eest party is almoost
al wyldernes that party is between the south occean and the River Nylus And
has the Reed see in the eest side / And heyte Ethiopia of the color and hew
of the men of the land that len blac men. and is for the great brennynng and
heet of the son. which is to hem full nygh / In Ethiopia ben many diverse
people wonderly and grysly y shapen / some ar named goromantes and sum
trogodyte which ben swyftyer than hertes / And sum curse the soune for his
great heete. Sum ete serpents and addres / sum hunte lions and panters.
Sum dygge caves and dens and dwell under earth and make her noise with
gruntyng and chirkyng of teth^ more than with voys of the throat Sum goo
naked and do no work / Sum without heedes and have mouth and eyes in the
breest / Among sum of hem ben four footed beestes without eeres / And
Olyfantes also. Sum of hem have on hound for her king and dyuyneth by meuyng
and styryng of hym^ sum live only by honysoukles y dreyd with smoke or with
the sonne^ There ben also cameleons and basylyscus^ vnycornes camels^ pardes and
dragons that have in her brayn and heedes many precious stones / Camelion is a
flekked best in color like to a lupaerd. and so is pardus and panthera also
and somdele of the kind But pantera is friend to all manner beestes sauf to
the dragon alone. For him be hates as deth^ Basylyscus is king of serpents
that with smell and sight sleeth beestes and fowles^ ysid libro terciodecimo In
Affryca among the people that been called trogodyte is a well that makes hem
that drink thereof to have good voys shry^^ and clear. Also among the other
people garamantes is a well all the day so cold that noman may drink therof^
And all the night it is so hot that noman may touch. Libia Cirenensis that
land has in the eeste side Egypte^ In the south Ethiopia / In the west the
peryllous place of the sea that is called the more Cirtes and tragoditas also /
And in the north the great see (...) libro quinto seyth that libia has the
name of that (...) named lib^s and is the wind that blows out of Affryca
(...) libia has the name of libia Epaphies daughter. that Epaphye was Iupytres
sone. That woman libia reigned in that land libia. And the people of that land
heyghte phutey of phut chames sone / Tripolitana that regyon has in the eest
side aras philenorn the antres and wyndes of that people that been set between
the people trogodyte and the more Syrtes. Syrthes maiores ben perylous places
fast by the grauelly see that is named mare Arenosum And Tripolitana has in
the southe side getulos and garamantes that stretches unto the Occean of
Egypt. and has in the west side bisancium unto the lake that is called lacus
salmarum / And in the north side he has the sea of myddel erthe^ and the
peryllous place that is called sirtes minores / the less sirtes^ Getula is the
myddel land of Affryca and has the name of gethes that folk of the gothes^
And in an Omely saint Gregory seyth that thylke men have no ffysshers

iij^M were opend. Mauritana is the name of two lands / the first cezarencis

occean Mauritania^ has the name of mauron that is blac as it were the country

fer from occean. And Athlas is so high over other hills that lewd men wenen

De Europa et eius partibus Capitulum 21
YSidorus libro quarto seyth that Europa has the name of Europa Agenors
daughter king of libia and Jupiter king of Creta rauesshed Europa Agenors
daughter. But this Europa is the thyrdde dele of this wide world / And
begins fro the River thanay. and the water meotydes and stretches dounward
by the north Occean unto the ends of spain at ylond Gades. and is byclypped
by eest and also by south with the great see. In Europa ben many prouynces and
Ilondes the which now shall be descryued / But first take heed that in the north
side of the world / the water meotydes and the River thanays depart a sonder
the more Asia and europa / the river thanays has the name of thanas the first
king of Scicia / that River thanays begins fro the hills ripheis and goth
down in to the sea of myddelerthe / ysidorus libro quartodecimo. the lower
scicia / that land is full of cold^ and begins from the River thanays and
stretches between the River danubius and the north Occean unto the germania
that country. Alama is a party of the lower Scicia And stretches somdele fro
the waters meotydes toward dacian / misia that land is closed in the northeest
with the mouth of danubius and joins in the southeest to Tracia / And in the
southe to macedonia / In the weste to histria. and in the southe weste to
dalmacia / Misia is a good land of corn and of whete / therefore the old cereris
called it a berne^ Sclauia is a party of Misia. there ben also two lands
either is named Sclauia^ the more is named properlych Sclauonia and conteyneth
sum ofDalmacia / and Sarmatas and has wild men. And See thieves / The less
Sclauia stretches fro wandalia and bohemia unto Saxone / And therinne ben more
myld men and people Pannonia has the name of penninis Alpibus / that been
hills that are called Alps. And thylke hills depart pannonia and ytalia /
there is another pannonia beyond the waters meotydes in the yonder scicia out
of the more pa^nonia hinny went an hontyng and passed long by marreys and
waters and followed the trace of hertes as Erodotus seyth / and so at last
they fond the less pannonia and turned home again / and took with hem great
strength and came again in to the less pannonia and put out the men that
were therinne / And called the land hongaria But a party thereof is named
bulgaria / And has in the eest side Misia / In the Southe eeste histria. In
the weste Alps the hills that so be named In the weste gallia belgyca that is
France / And in the north that River Danubius and Germania that land This
land Bulgaria has veins of gold and hills in the which men dygge marble
and salt good at best /

Degrecia et eius prouincijs. Capitulum 22
AVctours tellen that Greece with the prouynces thereof is lady of kingdoms
noryce of knyghthode and of chyualrye / Mother of philosophy fyndar and master
of Art. and of science And has the name of one grecus that reigned there
sometime / Netheles that land is called comynly Ilyricus / The men thereof ben
called greci / Graij^ Achei. Achim / Argini^. Acciti. Jove's Ionij and Ellenes
But when the great constantin made consta^tinopolim the chyef cite of thempyre
of rome Then were the Greeks called Romanij / as it were men of new Rome so
seyth Rabanus And unto this ^aye the Greeks be but Romayses. And were sometime
stalworth. orped / and best men of Arms and natheles subget to laws Ysidorus
/ d. Capitulo / 17 In this land was sometime the study / and the Scole of
Pallas and minerua^ of grettese Art and seyence of knyghthode and of Chyualrye
And the Clergy and the chyualrye held so to geders that in the common
prouffyte was always good ^peed / And the old Graij auentured and gate many
things by Clergy and deeds of Arms / But that virtue keled and withdrowhe in
hem that came afterward and passed from the Greeks to the Latyns. So that to
fore where wells / were ben now but lakes. or more verily dry channels without
water For now they hold synonys feynyng vlyxes gyle / atrenis cruelnes and
fight with sleyghte and with (...) (...) cawtelis and not with Armure and
wepen / This land Grecia is fast by the great see^ and conteyneth many
prouynces that been Tracia / lacedimonia / Macedonia. Achaia Archadia^
Thessalia. elladia and boecia / tracia is called epyrus also for epyrote dwell
lyd therein and has in the south side the sea Egyus / In the west Macedonia /
In Macedonia dwelled sometime diverse men that hyghte massagete sarinate and
gothy. ysid libo. / 15 / In this land is a well that quenchyth brennyng
brondes^ and tends brondes that be acquenchyd. The chyef cite of this land
is constantinopolis in the est side openly y seen between the two sees ponticus
and propontydes / and openly y seen out of water and of land And was sometime
the chyef Cite of the eeste / right as Rome was of the weste / and higthe
sometime Bisanciu^ / of this Cyt^ W / libro quarto Regum speaks in this manner
The great constantinus bylded and made this Cite even and pere to Rome / and
demed that the emperor should not be the chyef the apostlis were chyef and
namely y crowned / / And he brought also many relyquyes of holy seyntes that
might help against their enemies / images of false gods and tripodes
delphycos that were Appollynes images he brought to be scorned and spyght to
them that beheld hem and saw. So this Emperor vouched sauf to bylde^ the
Chyef Cite of thempyre in good corn countree^ where there is good temprure of
heaven and of weder beside the land Misia that has great plente of corn and
fruit That Cite is y seen and showed to all shipmen that sayllen thyderward
out of what land that they come of Asia and of Europa^ And is well nygh
byclypped al about with the great see and is cornerd within the clyppyng of
the wallys fast by the sea sydr. And is byclypped with a wall of twenty
thousand paas. therewith heepes and huppels of stones and of grauel cast in to
the sea besides the cite / the land is eched and made more^ Also the River
danubius that is callid hister also is y let and y lad in to dyuerce places of
the Cite by goters vndrr earth In this manner when the water shall run in to
the cite men take out a bar that the water is stopped with. and let the
water run / and stoppen when hem lyken / And so Danubius fyndeth water enough
to an hunderd stretes^ In this cite constantinus arered and bylded two famous
chirches but Iustinianus the emperor builded afterward the third church in
worship of Diuina Sophia that is our lord Criste that Agia calls diuina
sophya^ in English the wysedom of god. And men tell that the work passes
all the buyldyng of the world. And is more noble than men can telle^ Thither
brought saint helene the holy cross that our lord Criste deyde on. There
resten thappostles Andrewe and James that was called frater domini / In
English our lords brother / there rests Mathias and Prophets also.
Helyseus samuel. and Daniel. and also luke the evangelist and marters full many
/ also confessors Johan with the golden mowth / vasyleus and gregorius
Nasasenus and vyrgyns Agatha and Lucia / Lacedomonia that heyghte spartanya /
also^ is a prouynce of grecia fast besides Tracia / Men of that prouynce ben

Trogus libro 3 These men sometime beseged the Cite Mesena ten year to gyder /

Athemensis men of athenes used first craft of wolle of wine and of oil / and

sone at his faders heste sought his suster Europa that Jupiter had rauesshed
and might not find her he dradde his faders wratthe And he could none other
read but fledde^ as an outlawe / It happened that he followed the foot of an ox.
and fond the place that the ox lay in. and called it Boecia / And builded
there the cite thebe^ In that Cite bella Ciuilia debanuerunt / and there was
appollo born and hercules in thylk more thebanus also / In that land is a lake
wonderful and wode^ For who that drynketh there of shall brenne in wodenes of
lecherye^ there ben also two wellys in that land. who that drynketh of that one
he shall be foryetful. And who that drynketh of that other^ he shall have good
mind / Petrus^ take heed that men of thebe in egypt ar called thebei / And
men of thebe that is in grecia ar called thebani / and the men of thebe in
Judea ben called thebyt^

Capitalum / 23 /
YSydorus libro quartodecimo. we read in stories that greeks dwelled sometime in
Italia / and called that land the great grecia that land hight sometime
hesperya of hespera the sterre that ladde the greeks when they saylled theder
and was her lodesterre^ hespera that is venus. Afterward that land hight
saturnia of saturnus that dwelled there / For saturnus hid him self there in
that land for dread of his own sone Jupiter. And called that land lacium /
that is saturnus hydles^ After that that land hyghte Eusonia of eusonius
vlixes sone^ But ate last that land was called ytalya of Italus rege
siculorum king of Scicilia. And is the noblest prouynce of al Europa. And is
closed in the north side with the mouth and see Tirenus^ And in the west with
the sides of the hills that hight Alps. Out of thylke hills spryngen three
the noblest Ryuers of al Europa / that been called the River danubius^ and rone^
ysid libro tercio decimo In this Italia is Cetheroes well that heleth sore
eyes. there is also the lake clitorius who that drynketh of that lake no wyn
shall him grieve / Before libro secundo capitulo o^todecimo. Fast by the hills
that been called Alps Apennini is that well Nouacius that welleth and

Treuisa Alps Appennini that been penitus hills / Hanibal was a great duke and

De vrbe Romana Capitulum. xxiiij
AVctours written and tellen that the Cite of Rome is y builded in Tuscia that
is a party of Italya / Of the fondacion thereof and Gouernynge. Auctours write
many diverse doings and specially. Martinus de condicione eius / Magister vero
gregorius. of the wo^dres of the cite writes shortly many things that been
worthy to be kept in mind Martinus it is write that many Kings reigned about
the place of Rome / For Eustodius says that after that toure babel was y buylt
and men bigonne to speak diverse tongues and langages. Noe with certain men took
a ship and saylled in to Italia / And builded a Cite of his name and ended
there his life Then Ianus Iaphets sone that was Noes sone builded Ianiculum by
yonde the River Tiberis There is now a Church of saint Johan that heyght
saint Iohans church ad Ianiculum. About that time Nemproth that hight Saturnus
also which was gelded of his own sone Iupyter come to the forseyd Ianus
kingdom / And builded a Cite there as the Capitol is now. Also Italus that time
the king with Sciculis men of Scicil^a come to Ianus and to Saturnus and buylt
a cite fast by the River Albula / That River is now called Tyb^r and is a River
of Rome Also hercules Italus sone builded a cite named galeria bynethe the
Capytol^ After that Tiberis the king come out of the este^ And euander the
king out of Archadia and builded Cytees / Vyrgylius acordeth herto and seyth /
then the fader euander at Rome was maker of towers / Then afterward come
Romulus and closed within one wall all thylke cytees about and made one
great cite of all closed in one / And brought gentilmen and noble out of
ytalia with their wives for to dwell therinne / Titus while that Cite was
pour. was no place more holy^ ne rycher of good ensample. But afterward riches
gadred and encreaced And syn they have been coueytous and lecherous^ Marcus Two
brethren that were born at one burthon / Remus and Romulus buylden Rome in the
hille palatinus And was buyld the / xj Kalendes of Maye^ Tho bigan the vij
Olimpus that was the first year of Achaz king of Judah. and four honderd /
liiij year after the taking of troy R / But more verily as Solynus seyth^ four
honderd and xxxiiij / after the taking of troy. Marc^ / The which Cite of
Rome was afterward / wonderly y highte with walls. with toures with yates.
with te^ples^ with palays^ and dyuse and wonderful works / and had on the
walls three honderd / lxj towers and conteyneth about two and twenty mile
without that is by yonde tiber and the Cite leonina / But as men seyn it
conteyneth al about two and forty mile and had in all ^xvj pryncipal yates /
ten a thishalf tybre that were named port capu^na^ port apia^ port latina: port
Asmaria / port matronij / port leuycana port numentana / port salaria. port
princiana and port colina / Also by yonde tybre ben three yates^ And three in the
cite leonina Gregorius among the wonders of this cite that yet ben seen / seyth
if is a great wo^dre of so many defensable towers of so many buyldynges of
palayces whether. it were by wycchecraft or by man's deed. R / So that now ben
veryfyed the versis that hildebertus episcopus cenonean made. and willelmus
malme^sb puts hem in his book of kings as here follows / Rome nothing is
pere to the / though thou neygh al falling be* On all thou show thy bounde^
how great thou were when thou were sound

De palacijs Rome
THere were many palayces ryal and noble y build in Rome in worship of
Emperors and of other noble men also Among the which the grettest and most
palace of all was in the myddel of the cite in toke^ of one principalite of
all the world wide / Also the palace of pees^ therein Romulus did do set his
own image of gold and said / hit shall never fall til a maid bear a child /
And that image fylle when Criste was born / Dioclisians palace has pylers as
high an a stone cast / and so great about that an c men al a year worchyng
should uneath hew one of thylk pylers. Also there was a palace of sixty
emperours^ and yet stondeth a part thereof. that al Rome may not destroy / De
templis There as pantheon the temple of all mawmetrye was is now a church of
all halowen And by cause our lady is after Criste is chyef and holiest of all
mankind / that church has the name of our lady. and is called sancta maria
rotunda that is the round church of our lady. And has in bread the space of /
ij / C^lx^ foot / Fast by that temple is an Arche of Marble. And that is the
Arche of Augustus Cesars victoryes and great deeds / In that Arche ben all his
great Acts descryued There is also Scipions Arche^ he overcome hauibal. At
saint steven in piscina was the temple olouitreum that was made of cristal and
of gold. there was Astronomye y graven and y peynted with sterres and signs of
heuene saint sebastian destroyed that temple^ Also the capitol was arrayed with
glass and with gold as it were the myrour of all the world about / There the
consuls and senators governed and rewlid all the world as much as was in her
power / And there was Iupyters temple. And in that temple was Iupyters image of
fyn gold syttyng in a trone. R Here takehedr that only three temples were in
Rome that had flamynes. that were bisshops to serve / falls gods and mametrye
and highte flamynes as it were filamynes of filo that is a threde that they
bond about her heed. when they might not in the holy day suffer on her
pylyons and her cappes for hete / In Iupyters temple served fflamen dialis that
is the day bisshop^ For Iupyter was cleped diespyter / that is the fader of the
day. Also in Mars temple was flamen Marcialis / that is mars bishop And in
Romulus temple was Flamen quyrinalis that is quirinus bisshop^ For Romulus was
called quyrinus also De domibus In rome was an hows y made well nyghe al of gold
and lefette ^ with precious stones / Men said that / that hows was worth well
nygh the thyrdde part of of all the world / In that hows every land and prouynce
had an image y set by Nigromancie. Eueryche of thylke images bare his own
lands name wreton an on his breast. And a cokerbelle of silver honged about
his neck. So that if any land rebelled or aroose against Rome / Anon the Image
of that land turned his bak toward the image of Rome and the belle about his
neck should ring / And the priests that kept that hows / eueryche by his
course. warned the princes of that doing / there was also an horsman of bras on
high on the coppe of that house and meued also with a spear in his hond^ and
turned the point of his spear toward that land that would so arryse^ And so
the Romans might lightly come upon their enemies unware In that hows also was
a fire that no man might quench. And men axed of the crafts man that made it^
how long it should endure^ And he answered and fayde hit should endure for
evermore unto. that a maid had born a child / and the same night that Criste
was born that^ hows fylle down. and the fire was quenchyd that same night and
time Also beaneus appollo that man closed a confeccion of brymsto^n and of blak
salt in a vessel of brass. and set it a fire with a candel that he had
halewed in his manere^ and made there a bath with bathyng places that al way
were hoote / There was also in an hows an image of iron. and was named
Bellefrontes image / which weyed fyftene M pound with his horse that he sat on
And henge in the air with no post ne piler bynethe under set / ne hold
with cheyne above but adamante stones that were in the vawte and in^ the Arches
about drowhe even the iron eueryche to his side so that the iron image might
not dounward ne upward ne toward neither side but henge always even a mydde / De
Artificijs. There is a^ place in Rome in Eraclea and is called theatrum^ that
is a place to stand or sytte Inn / for to look well about / there in is
wonderly graven cabans and dens. diverse outgoynges benches and seges al
aboute^ and is hoole and sound al on marbel stone^ and this werk is set vppn
vj crabbes y hewe^ of hard marbelst one In that place may noman so pryuely
speak. ne to him self ne to another man / But all that he says be herd al
about / Fast by Augustus Cezars palace is awalle made of burnt tile / And
stretches dounward out of the high hills by the yate port asmaria. that
wall is made upon great Arches and huge that wall stretches a days Journey
from Rome in a great conduyte vpan that wall the watres and stremes of the
wells of the montaynes rennen in to Rome^ And then it is departed in dyuse
conduytes and pipes of bras. and so ran sometime in to every palace of Rome /
For the water of tiber is hoolsom and good for horse / And vnhelsome and evil
for men / therefore the old Romans made fresshe water come out of four parts
of the cite by weyes craftily made / and thereof men might take all that they
would while the comins of rome were in her flowers. By that wall is the bath.
that bianeus made of the which bath was spoken to fore. In Albisterio a place
that hight mutatorium Cezaris were made white stoles for emperors / Also there
was a candelstyk made of a stone that higthe Albeston. when it was ones yteyned
and set a fire and y set without there could noman quench it with no craft
that men could deuyse / R In this manner it might be that the geant pallas
about the year of our lord a thousand and fourty^ that yer was found in Rome
a geants body buried hool and sound / the space of his wound was four foot
long and an half^ The length of his body passed the heygthe of the walls.
at his heed was y found a lantern brennyng always that noman could quench
with blast ne with water ne with other craft / unto the time that there was
made a lytil hoole under the light / bynethe that the air might enter. Men
seyen that Turnus slowghe this geant Pallas when eneas fought for lauina that
was Eneas wife. This / geantes epytaphium is this the writing of mind of him
that lay there was this Pallas euanders sone lies here^ him turnus the knight
with his spear slowhe in his manner De statuis et signis There was at Rome a
bulle^ of bras in the shap of Jupiter ouercast and shape to men that looked
thereon. That bulle seemed lowhyng and startelyng^ There was also the image of
venns al naked in the same manner as venus shewde her self to that man Paris
sometime of troy / and was so craftily made that in the mouth and lips that
were as white as any snow seemed fresshe blood and new. there is also at Rome a
wonder copped pyler and is Romulus Piler. that pyler pylgryms and palmers that
fast can^ lie call hit saint Peter's corn hupple and sayen that when nero
the emperor had rauisshed it hit turned in to an hylle of stone. as great as it
was before of corn / Emonge all pilers Julius cezars pyler is most wonderful
/ and has in heyghte two honderd and fyfty foot. In the coppe thereof in a
round thing of bras ben Julius cezars bones and ashes / Of that pyler and
arche ben verses y. made that been thus to menynge and namely of the ouermest
stone / if the stone is one. tell what craft brought him upon. And if they be
many stones. tell where they ioynen at ones^ This arche and pyler is y founded
and set upon four lions / pylgryms full of lesynges / call this arche and
pyler saint Peter's nelde and lie and say that thylk man is clean of sin that
may crepe under that stone^ there ben also in Rome two great horses of marbel
stone / For in Tiberius time two young philosophers praxitellus and Fibia /
come to Rome and yeden al naked. And when the emperor axed him why and wherefore
they went so naked / they answered. and said. For we have forsaken al thing.
And for all thing is to us naked and bare and openly known. ye sir Emperor and
all that thou spekest in counseyl and pryuete we know at best / Treuisa the
first point of this doing and answer techeth that who that forsakes / al
thing forsakes his clothes^ And so it follows that they that been well clothed
and goth about and beggeth and gadreth money and corn and catel of other men
forsakes not al thing R The Emperor assayde and fond soth all that they said.
and at her owen prayer / made in mind of hem two great horses of marbel^ there
is another sign and token before the popes palace an horse of bras and a man
sittyng thereon And holds this righthonde as though he spoke to the people and
holds his bridle in his lift hand and has a cucko between his horse heeres.
And a seek dwerf under his feet Pilgrims clepen that man. Theodoricus And the
comyns call him Constantinus / But Clerks of^ the court call him Marcus and
quintus cursius also^ this sign stood sometime to fore in piters awlter^ In
the Capitoyl upon the four pilers of bras / but saint gregory threw down horse
and man and set him to fore the popes palace / They that call him marcus tell
this reason and skylle There was a dwarf of the kynred of mesenis his craft was
Nygromancie when he had subdewed kings that dwelled nygh him and made him
subgette to him. Then he went to Rome to war with the Romans / And with
his crafte^ he bynam the romans power* and might for to smite. and biseged hem
long time y closed within the cite / This dwerf went every day tofore the
soune rysyng in to the field for to do his craft: when the romans had espied
that manner doing of the dwarf they spak to marcus a noble knight and bihighte
him lordship of the Cite. and a Memorial in mind for evermore if be would
deffende^ hem and save the Cite / then^e Marcus made an hool through the wall
longer it were day for to abide his craft to cache this dwerf^ And when it was
time the cucko sange and warned him / of the day Then marcus raised to. and
by cause he myghtnot hitte the dwerf with wepen he caught him with his hand /
and bare him in to the cite / And for dread lest he should help him self with
his craft if he might speak. he threw him under the horse feet / And the horse
alto trade him / And herfore that / image was made in remembrance of this deed
/ They that call that image and sign quintus cursius tell this skylle and
reason / there was sometime in the myddel of Rome a great clyfte or hoole in the
earth out of that hool come smook and brymstone and slew many men^ then
Quintus cursius took counseyl of phoebus and armed hym^ and entered in to the
hool^ then anon fleygh a cuckou out of the hool^ and then the earth closed
to gyder and so the hool was stopped. Another sign is colloseus image that is
called also the image of the son or of Rome / There is great wonder how it
might be yoten or arered / the image is so great the length thereof is six
score foot and six. this image was sometime in the ybond herodius fyften foot
heygher than the heyghest place in rome. this image bare in his right hand a
spear al round y shape as the world^ And in his lift hond a swerd that
bytokeneth might of batayll^ in token that it is less maystrye to win and to
conquer than it is to keep and to save that / that is conquered and won. this
image was of bras but it was so ryally ouergylt that it shone in derknes and
yaf great bemes of light^ Also it meued about with the son in such a manner
that always his face was toward the son. All the Romans that come thereby
worshipped that image in token of subjection and of thraldom Saint gregory
destroyed that image with fire ffor he might not destroy it with strength /
Of that image is only y left the heed and the right hond holdyng the spear /
that is the Roundenes and the likeness of the world. For of all that image left
no more vnbrente that heed and that hand ben now to fore the popes palace upon
/ ij / pylers of marble^ and wo^derly by craft of milting that bras was y yoten
/ that the here seems soft to a man's sight. and the mouth as though it
were spekyng Polier / ^^bro secundo / For to highte the noblete of this Cite
the Romans made a woman's image in bras^ that image h^ld in (...) hand a spear
the shape of the wide world / And when the image was full made him seemed that
the legs were to feeble for to bear such an image. hit was so great and so
huge. But the crafts man that hit made answered and said / the legs shall
dure always and ^ere the image at the best and never fayll unto a maid bear a
child / but the legs faylled and the image fylle down when Criste was born /
Fast by vaspasianus palais is a stone that is called parius. in that stone is
y coruen a white sow with xxx / pigges that give water to hem that will wesshe
there. there is also a tabel of bras that forbedeth sin / therein ben wreton
the chyef points of the lawe^ there ben wreton as it were reules in metre^ the
menyng thereof is vndersta^de^ in this writing neext folowyng^ Every night where
a cock waketh some man er it dawe / Al his song in a flocke^ may like noman
by the lawe^ when somer is hote^ the throstle syngeth with merry note when the
day goth away / the bird is stylle and leueth his laye^ In town as it longes
/ The osul twiterith merry songs / At night for dread / truly no song does he
grede / when flower spryngeth on rote^ the nyghtyngale in his note / Twiterith
well fawnyng with sweet song in the dawnyng^ Thral makes his fare / with mouth
/ then chiterith the stare / Of morrow song kynde^ they have at even no mind

De quibusdam Romanorum institutis et obseruancijs ysidorus eth libro
octodecimo. capitulo de triumphis et hug capitulo tris. Capitulum / 25
When Duc / king. consul / or Emperor had don any great voyage and vyctorye
and come in to Rome / At his coming he should be received with three manner
worship / All the people should come against him with all the solempnyte mirth
comfort and joy that they couthe make / All the prysonners should follow his
chare with her hondes y bounden byhynde her backes^ This vyctour should hem self
were on Jupiters cote / And sit on a chare that four white horses should draw
unto the capitoyl Thereof speaks ouidius with four horses al snow white / thou
shall sire emperor wend / yet among all this worship^ For he should not
foryete him self / this one Anoye he had / A Chorle was with him in his
chare. and smote him always in the nekke and that for two skylles / That one
was / For he should not be to proud of that great worship^ That other skylle
was for every man should hope to come to that worship. if he made him self
worthy by his deeds / While the chorl smote the vyctour. he should often say to
him / in this manner notho solitos that is to say know thy self / as who seyth
be not to proud of this worship / And also that day every man had leave to say
to the vyctour. what someuer he wolde^ and no blame should be take therefore And
so were many dispyteous words said to Julius Cezar. And he took thereof no
manner wreeche^ One said to Julius at siche a time salve Calue that is hayl
balard^ And another said hayle king and quene^ R. Look within in Julius cezar.
In vita Iohis Elemosinarij / when themperours of Rome were crowned should come
to him crafts men that make tombs and axe of hem of what manner stone or metal
they should make their tombs as who seyth thou shall deye / Govern. myldely
the people Hug capitulo Clarus When the Romans would war in any land / one
should goo to thendes of that land and clearly declare and show the mater^ and
cause of the war / and that declaracion was called clarigacion / then a
spear y pyght in the land warned that the Romans would war Ysidorus
libro.19. capitulo / visesimo secundo. while consuls rewled Rome^ the knights
of Rome should were reed clothes the day to fore that they should fight /
That was don for they should not know and be abashed when they saw the reed
blood run on her clothes and such knights were named Rosati / as it were y
clothed in Rooses R Take heed what papie seyth Virgyle calls the Romans
togati. that been men clothed in gowns / three manner gowns they used and were
called pretaaxta palmata and candidata / the first manner gown pretaxata
gentilme^s childeren used for to were of xiiij^ year old / the second manner
palmata used vyctours for her noble deeds / the third manner goun candidata
vsed^ lords and maystres rulers of the law. Hug / ca. fastus / the days that
the Romans well spedde were named fasti that is leueful. For it was leeful to
hem thylk days to use diverse doing and deeds / the days that the romans
myspedde were called nephasty as it were not leeful^ and they heelde thylk
days and wrought not. but for no love ne deuocions but for dread of evil
happes / Hug / ca / 5 / the feste of thylk days is called quinquatria that is
the five black days for the sorrow and bytternes that the romans had when the
Frensshemen and hanybal beseged them al about / For then^e no romain durst
ones goo out of the toun^^ Hug / c. classis. when romulus had ordained for the
common prouffit ^e departed a sondre the great and the mean / and cleped either
party classis / In worship of hem he ordeygned a month and called it Mayus.
that is the month of the grete^ men^ The mean men were called the second
Classis. And in worship of hem he ordeygned a month and called it Iunius that
is the month of younger men Afterward the Romans were departed in four
parties. In the first party were consuls and doctours^ In the second classis
were tribuni and men of^ less dignite / In the third were for men^ and in the
fourth were bondmen. tribunus is he that receives tribute and paieth knights
and a leder or^ capitain of thousand knights hight Tribunus Hug. c / calon /
The Romans used / sometime in every monethe to make a fair and the fair began
the first day of the nonas and dured to the first day of Idus Idus is as
much to say as delyng and departing for then the fair was departed / Also
for the beginning was oftyme unknow to Merchants and to chapmen / therefore
the first day of the month hight kalende of calo calas that is call and
crrye^ A cryour should stand upon a tour^ And as many days as were from that
day to the beginning of the fair he shodd cry calo. Therefore it is that in
sum month in the calendar has but four nonas / and sum has six / And
that don for thieves that were hid in wodes for to aspye chapmen should not
know when the fair should bygynne / Hug / ca / mereor. Sometime knights after
that they were^ lx / year old were not compellyd for to do deeds of Armes^ But
men yaf hem feldes or towns. or somewhat else of the common tresorye whereby
they should live / And then such a knight was cleped Emeritus or emerite
milicie as it were a knight set out of the nedeful deeds of Chyualrye / R
Therefore Anatarn that is by yonde Tiber heyght Emerytor^a / For such knights
spente there what they had to fore gotten and ywonne / Hug^ ca / lita It was
usage in Rome that the cytezeyns should do not ellis to fore none but dispute
of the common prouffyt^ therefore comin wymmen of rome were cleped nonarye / for
they should not to fore none goon out to her common place / lest they should
let young men from the common prouffyt Hug. ca. nepa Sometime in Rome fader and
mother should not norysshe and teache her own childer^n / For it was supposed
that they would be to tender and not chastyse and beat hem. Neither maystres^
that were al strange and out of the kynne should teache childeren of Rome. lest
they would recche to lytil of the childeren and beat hem to sore / therefore
maystres should teache the childeren of Rome that were not to neygh ne to far
of her own kynne Hug. capitulo^ proles There were sometime in Rome that serves
of naught else but for to get childeren / and dwelled always in the cite / and
were / not compelled to deeds of Arms. And such men were cleped proletarij
that is to say geters of childeren R Netheles in hanybals time they were
constreyned sor to goo out for scarsenes of knights / Vale / libro 2

An honderd year and lx after that the cite was y buyld / was no deuorse made
between a man and his wife / Netheles Carbilius a bastart was the first that
left his wif only / for the woman was bareyn though he seemed y meued of
Reason. yet he was not al blamels for he. put couetise of children to fox the
feyth of wedlok ysidorus li 6 Though the greeks write first in wax with

of iron but with poyntels of boon Poli libro secundo Who that will look books
of stories Among all men that were sith Rome was first made. he shall find
that the Romans were most covetous and proud / he shall find also that the
maystrie that they had in the world about they gate hit by punysshyng of people
by false wyles and by gyle so ferfoth that uneath any of her princes lived his
life kyndely to his ende^ therefore every Romayn that ouercometh other is overcome
with flateryng and with fair words / And if words faylle. yeftes shall him a
welde / if yeftes faylle. worship makes him prisoner / Pol^ libro septimo
decimo / capitulo / 11 / while the Cytees. of ytalia loved pees and worshipped
right wysenes and leued false oaths / then they had lykyng and welthe in her
owen londe^ But when they give hem to falsehed and to strif Anon the pride of
the Romans. and the wodenes of duche men or sum other wrecbe of god Almighty
falls upon hem. unto the time they amend by penance and contrition. For
trespaas of that people puts away al pryncipalyte or makes her prince more
mylde

De Germania / et eius prouyncijs / ysid / ech^ / 14 ca / 26.
YSidorus says that very germania has in the eest side the mouth of the River
danubius in the south the Ryn that river / and in the north and in the west the sea of occean^ there ben two lands / either is called germania^ the over
Germania stretchith besides Alps to that mouth^ and cost of the great see.
that is called adriaticus^ there the sea is as it were lakes in the contreys of
aqu^lia. the other germania is lower toward the weste about the Ryne^ and is
comynly called Almania / or trutonia^ In either Germania ben many prouynces and
londes^ that been boemia westfalia / bauaria / thuringia. Sueuia / Saxonia^
Franconia lothangia / frisia / and selandia Paulus libro p. the north contre is
fer from the son and wholesome for men to dwell in and able to bring forth
childeren / therefore it is that there is more multipli^acion and encreace of
men and childeren in the north contre than in the south that is full nygh the
son^e and^ vnholso^ and seke^ew for men to dwell in / And so though every
land and. contre have his own proper name. Netheles all the country and
land from the River thanays unto the west is called germania. For hit gendreth
and brings sorth mo men and childeren than it may well sustene^ Therefore it
is that so often goon diverse men out of that side of the world in to other
lands / by lotte or against her will or by her good will for to get other
lands / so did gothi wandali / saxones^ wynnily and longobardi Boemia is the
first prouynce of the eeste germania / And has in the eest side Misia and
Alania. In the southe the River Danubius and Pannonia In the west bauaria and
turingia / And in the north and northweste Saxonia. and is closed almost about
with hills and wodes and has great plente of leese and grass that smells
full sweet and of diverse wild beestes^ Among / the which is one beeste and is
called booz in the langage of boemia^ But he deffe^deth not him self with his
horns but he has a large Ryuel as it were a bag under his chynne / therinne
he gadreth water and heteth it in his rennyng skaldyng hoote and throws it
upon hunters and hounds that poursiewe him and skaldeth of the here of hem
and brenneth hem full sore / Thuringia has in the eeste boemia / In the / weste
Franconia / In the north westfalia And in the southe the River Danubius.
Franconia is as it were the myddel prouynce of Germania. and has in the eeste
thuringia / In the west sueuia. In the north a party of westfalia / and in the
south bauaria and the River Danubius Bauaria has in the eest the River
Danubius and Retica / westfalia has in the est side saxonia in the west Frisia
/ in the north Occea^ In the south a party of France and of sueuia^ Sueuia
has in the eeste Bauaria / In the weste the River that is called the Ryne In
the north a party of Franconia^ and in the southe Rethica and Alps / Saxonia
has in the eeste Alania in the west westfalia / In the north Occean^ And men
of that country ben more lighter and strenger on the sea than other scommers or
theuys of the sea and pourfiewe here enemies full hard and both by water and by
land and ben called Saxones of Saxum that is a stone For they ben hard as
stones and vnesy to fare with. In the hills of Saxonia is well nygh al manner of
metals founden referued tyn In Germania ben saltwelles. Of the which wells is
salt made as white as any snow / Fast by that hylle that copper is dug in
/ is a great hylle of which hylle the stones smelle as sweet as violet / Also
fast by the monasterye of saint Michel is marble founden the fairest that may
be^ Beda / c. visesimo quinto / the old saxones have no king but many knyghtes^
of her own rule^ But in time of battle they cast lot which of her knights
shall be leder and capitain And they follow him that is so chosen by lot. as
chyef lord and master during the bataylle But when the battle is don then
shall he be as he was byfore^ that is to wete he and other all lyche great of
power and of might / Pleuius libro quinto Frisia is a land upon the cost of
the west Occean. And begins in the south side fro the Ryne and ends at
see of Denmarke^ Men of Frisia ben high shaven about / And ever the more
gentilman and noble the higher he is shorn The men ben fair of body Cruel and
bold of heart And use speres instead of Arowes / and love fredom most of any
thing / Therefore they suffer noman to be a kynght that would be her lord.
Netheles they ben^ governed and ruled by domes men and Iuges / And every year
they chese of hem self her own Iuges they love well chastyte and keep besily
her childeren and suffer hem not to marie til they be four and twenty year old
/ Therefore they have strong and stalworth childeren / they have no wodes /
therefore they make hem fire of turues / S^landia is a lytil land upon the sea /
which renneth through the land and causes xvij Ilondes and about eueryche a
ship may saylle / And has in the est holandia In the north Frisia in the
west Occean / and in the south Flandria / And is environed with water and high
banks to bold out the rysynge of the sea and floodes. there is good cornlond
and scarsete of trees for the Rotes may not take depenes ne farnes for saltnes
of the earth The men ben great of body and mylde of heart / Paulus libro
primo^ In the west side of Germania is a people called scribonius that has
snow all the somer time / and eteth raw flesh and ben clothed in ghoot buk
skynnes. In her country when the night is short. men may see all the night
the son bemes / And after^ in the winter when the day is short though men
see / the light of the son / yet the son is not seen / Item fast beside
that people scribonius under the clyf of Occean is a den under on high stone^
therinne slepen seven men and have long slept and ben hool and sound in body
and clothyng and al withouten we^me ffor which cause the common people have hem
in great worship and reuence. they are supposed romans by her clothing there was
a man sometime that for couetise would stripe one of hem^ and have his clothyng /
but forwith his arm waxed al dreye It may be that god list to keep hem so hool
and sound for mysbyleued men in time to coming should through hem be converted
and turned to good believe

De Gallia et / Francia R / Capitulum. 27
^It is wreton in stories that gallia which is ffrancia has that name gallia
of whytenes of people / Gala is a w^^de in grew and is lac in Latin. and milk
in English T^^rfor Sibilla called hem gallos that is white And says that the

gyleful. In gallya wytty men and wise R Here take heed as Augustinus de
Ciuitate dei libro secundo capitulo quinto touches that Gally in one manner
speech were the priests. that were in the temple of that goddess that hight
Cibeles^ And have that name not of that land gallia / but of that River gallus
that is in Frigia. All they that drank of that River should wexe wood and were
all gelded in their mind of that child Athis that thylk goddess Cibelis
loved with all her myght^ / That child wax wood and gelded him self for fraud
and gyle that he had don to that goddess Cibeles so says Ouidius de fastis /
But of galli that been Franci and frensshe men / Entropius libro 2 / seyth gally
ben well hasty and her bodies passen the common stature of other men But it is
fou^den by assaye that as the gally ben more hasty than strong in the first
refe or bront / so afterward in fyghtyng they ben more feeble than wymmen. For
as they ben like alps in gretenes of body so they be somewhat like to the snow
that lies upon the Alps that breketh out in swote and melts with heete of
fyghtyng as snow does with hete of the son Git / capitulo. septimo decimo /
then gallea with his parties al hoole has in the north side Germania / In

There is that fair flower the cite of Paris which is noryce of thewes^ Boteler

The Frensshe men that been called Franci also and many other men the strengest
of europa / come of the trojans. For after that Troy was taken^ Antenor with
his men fled away by waters that hight paludes meotydes and by the River
Thanays and dwelled in pannonia / And bulde there a Cite and called it
Sicambria / Of that Cite he and all his were afterward called Sicambri^ After
anthenors death they ordained hem two leders and capytains Trogotus and Franco /
And of thylke Franco they were afterward called Franci / Turpinus de gestis
karo^^ seith that when king Charles had made spain subgette and was come home
to paris agayne^ he made all the bond men of gallia free in worship of seint
James and of seint denis / But they should every year offer four pens to the
Church work of seint denis / And so they were called Franci sancti dionifij /
that is to say seint denis free men^ And so it came about / that Gallia was
called Francia by cause of that fredom. Other men tellen that valentilianus
the emperor called hem francos as it were ferancos that is stern and wyther in
the langage of attica. that is grecia^ For sicambri that been frensshe men were
tributary to Rome long time to fore valentinianus time also / But when Alani
men of allania were enemies to Rome^ Sicambri had her tribute foryeuen / for
ten year for to war against the men of Allania. and when the ten year were don
and Alani ouercomen the Romans axed their tribute. And Sicambri warned it and
would none pay. therefore valentinianus the emperor warred upon hem with a great
hooste / and had the vyctorye / then for that myshappe Sicambri were sore
wroth and warred in the lands of Rome / and also on the lands that were.
subgett to rome also / therefore Sicambri were afterward called Franci as it were
feranci / that is wyther and stern / And of that duc Franco they were called
Franci as it were Francoes men^ also of her fredom that king charles yaf them
they ben named Franci / that is free me^ for to mean Treuisa but how that ever
they come to that name Franci ben frensshe men and hight both Sicambri^ and
gally / and so it is al one people Sicambri / gally Franci and ffrensshe men. R

/ This charles followed the sentence of his forfaders and held the kings of

But at last in Gayus Julius cezars time gallia that is France was made
subget^ and so occupied by Romans about a four honderd year unto the last time
of valentinianus the emperor / when diverse men of strange lands werred in
gallia^ For first wandaly and hinni / then sueui and burgondi that been of
sueuia a land of Almania that is Almain^ then gothi and sicambri. then
norways and danes made hem self cytees in gallia / In gallia that is France
ben many prouynces and lands that been / Braban / Flaundres Pycardye^

Flaundria that is fflaundris a prouynce of Gallia belgyca. andis upon the cost

Pycardia^ And in the west occean. and inthe north a party of Englond^ and

havens of the sea and of good towns / The men of fflaundres hen fair strong
and rich and bring forth many childeren and ben pesible to her neighbors and
true to strau^gers^ noble crafty men and great makers of cloth / which is
sent about well nyghe in all Europe / The land is pleyn and skarse of wode /
therefore instead of wode they brenne turns that smells worse than woode^
and makes fowler ashes Braban is bysouth eest fflaundres and is plentiuous of
marchandyse and making of cloth / For of the wulle that they have out of
england they make cloth of diverse colors. And send it in to other prouynces
and lands as fflaundres does / For though England have wolle at best / it
has not so great plente of good water for diverse celours and hewes as
fflaundres has and braban^ Netheles at london is one well that helps well to

the town that hete ponticus / that now is called phyten so seyth Erodotus /

Tournay and many other^ And lies between Flaundres in the north^ide and

heet neustria also and has that name of Norwayes that sailled out of norway

in vortigers time king of Britons^ as is wreton and contained in the story of
brytons This prouynce has in the eest. side Andegauia. that is Andegoy. In the
north normandye. In the south guyan. In the weste Occean acquytanicus / that is
the sea that is by the side of guyan. Giraldus in toppicis In this britayne is
a well if the water of that well be take in a bugles horn and poured upon a
stone next to the well. be the weder never so fair ne dry anon it shall reyne
/ And in France is a well fast by the castle of pascense the water thereof is
right good for men and naught for wymmen. Noman can hete that water of that
well with fire ne with any craft that any can deuyse Pyctauia that is peytow.
is a prouynce of gallia Narbonenses / English men. Scotts and pyctes seylled
and dwelled there / and cleped the country pictauia / And the chyef Cite
pyctauus that is peyters so seyth Erodotus / this prouynce scretcheth far
upon the Occean / And in the eest side turonia / thereby passes the River of
leyr / In the southe side spain / In the north the less brytayn and the sea
of guyan^ and in the west the sea of Occean / the men of that land ben of the
conditions of Frensshe men by cause they meddle with them and of the country
that is so neyghe to them So that they be now strong. of body fair of face
hardy of heart / and fell of wit

De Aquitania / Capitulum. 28
AQuitania that is guyan^ And has that name Aquitonia of aquis that been waters
For the water of the river of leyer goth about a great dele of that lo^d. many

when spain was overcome so says Erodotus the writer of histroyes / The men of
that land ben called now basclenses and ben swyft and hardy and use balls
and arblestres and gladly do rob and reue^ and so they be strong thieves /

Senosenses and stretches unto Alps pirenei / and has that name burgundya of
borugh towns that Austrogoti bylded therein when they purposed to destroy
ytalia. this land is full cold toward Alps pirenei^ Men that dwellen toward
that side of burgoyne have botches under the chynne y swollen and bagged as
though they were double chynned / that is by cause of great cold of waters of
snow that melts among hem always

De Hispania / Trogus libro vltimo and ysidorus libro auinto decimo / Capitulum
/ 29
TRogus says that Trigonia is spain al hool^ and the hills pirenei ioynen
spain in the north side to gallia Narbonenses and is closed in the other sides
al about with the sea of occean and with the sea Tirenus / And so spain is well
nyghe al an ylond / For it is byclypped with the sea well nygh al about But there
ben two spaines the hither begins fro the playnes and valeys of pyreneis.
and stretches by cantabria and ends at cartago spataria / the yonder spain
conteyneth the west party unto the sea gadytanus. where as hercules set his
pylers beside the mount Athlas / This spain is a plain land. and has great
p^ence of castles of horses of metal and of honey. And heete sometime hisperia of
hespera the eve sterre that lad the greeks thither and was her lodesterre / A
fterward hit was called hiberia^ of the River hiberus but at last it hete
hispania of the river hispalus / or of hispanus that hercules ordained
governor and king there^ In hispania ben sex prouynces as terraconensis /
lusitania^ galicia bethica tingitina Astruria / and arogonia / ysidorus libro
quinto decimo capitulo secundo / This Cartago of spain is called spataria^ For
to have difference bitwene this cartago and the great Cartago of Affryca. that
Scipio consul of Rome destroyed / Affri men of affryca made this cartago
spataria / And at last gothy destroyed it / For gothy were lords of spain
long time and specially in honorius themperours tyme^ But afterward the
sarasyns were overcome of charles the grete^ and lost the west lands of /
spayn gallicia and luscitania / and held only the este lands and countries
of spain

GAdes is co^^nably first set among the Ilondes of the great see and

sometime the strength of the wind that is within makes to break out heepes

/ there is a well in scicilia if aman comes thereto clothed in red. anon the
