De Iusulis Occeani / Ysidorus libro quinto Capo. 31
INsule fortunate that been the gracious Ilondes and ben of good temprure of
wind and. of weder y set in the west Occean / And of some men named paradyse
by cause of goodness of the land and of temperate weder There ben gracious
tymes^ The hills ben couerd with Corn And herbs grow as it were grass.
Therefore by cause of plente of Corn and of Fruit they ben called Fortunate
that is gracious / For there ben trees of seven score foot high There is the
Ilonde Capria that is the Ilonde of Gheet. For there ben many gheet^ and weders
also / there is the Ilond Canaria. that is the Ilond of hounds / Dacia that is
denmark is an Ilond that joins to the northsyde of germania / Men of that
Denmark were sometime full stern and good men of Arms. Therefore they occupied
sometime great countrees in brytayne and in France / and ben called daci as it
were dagy^ For they come of the goths there ben many men in dacia and ben fair
of stature and semely of face and of here. And though they ben stern ayenste
their enemies / they ben esy and mylde to good men and true But it may not be
forgoten that they brought great drynkyng in to England. Wyntlandia that Ilond
is by west denmarke^ and is a bareyn land. and men out of believe they selle
wind to the shipmen that come to their ports and hauenes as it were closed
under knottes of threde / And as the knottes be vnknytte the wind wexed at
their will / Iselond that Ilond has in the este side Norwaye / In the north
the froren see / that is mare congelatu^ The men of^ that land ben short of
speech and true of their words and clothed in wild beeste skynnes. and ben
Fysshers and have one man both king and priest. There ben gerfawcons and
gentil hawks. and there ben white beers that breken the yse for to draw out
Fysshe. there ben no sheep in that land ne corn but ootes and that is for
great cold. That Ilond is from Irlond and from brytayn three days sayllyng
Solinu^ de mirabilibus Tyle is the vttermest Ilond of Occean / between the
north and the west coost by yonde brytayn. And few men know that land
Before libro secundo^ Tyle has the name of the son for from spryngyng time
when the day and night be eue^ unto heruest time it is always byschyne with the
son^e / and efte from that time to spryngyng time again / when the day and
night be. eue^ about september it has no light of the son / but always derk
night and no day and therefore the lord is not couenable for me^ to dwell in.
In somer for heete. and in winter for cold / and derknes. and by cause thereof
there may no corn grow / also the sea is there hard y frore / Bitwene that
Ilo^d and britain ben the ylo^des that hight^ sca^dia lingos and vergyon /
Netheles tile is vj days saylling out of brytain / R / gir in top / ffor seint
augustyn / d^ ci / de / speaks of tile^ and says that it is an ylo^d of ynde
and that the trees of tile leese never their leaves. but be ware^ that thou be
not begyled by lykenes of names For that ylond of ynde is called Tilis in the
nominatif^ caas^ And the ylond of Occean is named Tile in the nominatif caas /
and ben lyche in other^ As if thou can declyne thylke two names and speak
latin so seyth ysidore eth libro quinto decimo Norwaye stretches somdele eest
toward denmark and gothia^ And has in the southsyde scotland and in the
northsyde Iselond / the Ilond is brood byclypped about with the sea and is full
sharp and cold and has many hills and wodes^ wild beestes white beres
bawsons and brockes and scarcete of corn / Men of that land live more by
fisshyng and huntyng than by bread and corn. In the northsyde of that land
many nyghtes in the somer time about the stintyng of the son / the son
goth. not down but shyneth al night / And efte as many days in the winter
about the stintynge of the son / the son aryseth not to give hem light^
therefore all that time they must work by candel light / what work that hem
needs. In that land is a well that tourneth tree and lether in to stone^ and
it abide therinne a year hool^ The men of that land ben shipmen and theuys of
the sea / Treuisa For to know what the stintyng of the son is to m^^nyng
take heede^ that the son styntith twyes a year / ones at somer when it goth
none higher ^ And eftsoon at winter when it gooth no lower / And so in either
time is the stinting of the son

De hybernia ^ ^ Capitulum 32
HYbernia that is Irlond. And was of old time incorperate in to the lordship of
britain so seith Giraldus in sua topographia where he descriueth it at fulle
yet it is worthy and semely to praise that land with larger praising. For to
come to clear and full knowleche of that lo^d^ these tytles that follow opene
the way Therefore I shall tell of the stead and place of that land how great and
what manner land it is / Whereof that land has plente. and whereof it has
defawte^ Also of what men that dwellid therinne first. Of men Of manners of
that land of the wondris of that land of and worthynes of halowes and saints
of that land. De situ hibernie locali. / Irlonde is the last of all the weste
ylondes and height hibernia of one hiberus of spayn that was hermonius brother
For these two brethren gate and wan that land by conqueste / Or it is called
hibernia of that River hiberus that is in the weste end of spain And that
land heyghte Scotland also / For scotts dwelled there sometime er they came in
to that other Scotland that longed to brytayne Therefore it is wreten in the
martiloge^ Such a day in Scotland saint bryde was bore / and that was in
Irlond / this land has in the southest side spain three days sayllyng
thennes a sydehalf And has in the eest side the more brytayn^ thennes a days
sayllyng In the weste side it has the endels occean. and in the northsyde
Iselond three days sayllyng thens Solinus but the Sea that is between Britain
and Irlond is all the year full of great wawes and vnesy^ So that men may selde
saylle sikerly between / that see is six score mile brood / De eius quanto et
quali / Irlond is an Ilond grettest after brytayn and stretches northward from
brendans hills unto the land Columbina and conteyneth. viij / days iourneyes
Every journey of.xl / mile And from deuelyn to patriks hilles^ and to the sea
in that side in bread is four iourneyes And Irlond is narower in the myddel
than in thendes al otherwise than brytayn is^ as Irlond is shorter northward
than brytayn / so it is longer southward / the land is not pleyn but full of
montaynes^ of hills / of wodes of mareys and of mores. the land is soft
rayny^ wyndy^ and low by the sea side and withyn hilly and sondy. Solynus /
there is great plente of noble pasture and of leese / therefore the beestes must
be often drive out of their pasture leeste they ete ouermoche for they should
shende hein self if they might ete at their wylle^ Gir^ Men of that land have
comunely their health / and strangers have often a peryllous flux by cause of
the moisture of the mete / the flessh of kyen is there wholesome and swynes
flesh vnholsome^ Men of that land have no fever but only the fever ague.
and that right selde / therefore the holsomnes and health of that land and the
clennes out of venyme. is worth all the boost and richesse of trees of herbs
of spycerye / of rich clothes and of precious stones of the eeste lands / The
cause of the health and holsomnes of that land is the attemperat hete and
cold that is therinne / In quibus rebus sufficit In this land ben moo kyne
than Oxen / more pasture than corn. more gras than seed / There is great
plente of samon of lamprayes of Eelis and of other see fysshe Of Egles / of
Cranes of pecokes / of Curlewes of sperhaukes / of goshaukes and of gentil
faucons. Of wolves / and right shrewd myse / there ben attercoppes blood
soukere and eeftes that done none harm / There ben feyres lytil of body and full
hardy and strong / There ben bernacles fowls like to wild ghees / which
grown wonderly upon trees as it were nature wrought again kind / Men of
Religyon ete bernacles on fasting days by ^ause they ben not engendryd of
fflesshe wherein as me thinks they erre^ For reason is against that^ Fro if a
man. had eten of Adams legge^ he had eten flesshe^ And yet Adam was not
engendered of fader and moder^ but that fflesshe came wonderly of therthe and so
this fflesshe comes wonderly of the tree / In this land is plente of honey and
of mykle of wyn and not of vineyards / Solinus and ysidorus written that
Irlond has no bees Netheles it were better written that Irlond has bees and no
vyneyerdes Also Beda says that there is great hunting to robuckes / And it is
y know that there ben none. It is no wonder of beda for he saw never that land
but sum men had told him such tales / Also there grows that stone saxogonus
and is called Iris also / as it were the rain bow / if that stone be hold
against the son anon it shall shape a reynbowe^ there is also founden a stone
that is called gagates and white margery perlis In auibus rebus deficit^ whete
corns ben there full small uneath y cleansed with man's hond Reserved men^
all beestes ben smaller there than in other lands. there lacked well nygh all
/ manner ffysshe of Fresshe water that is not gendred in the see^ there lacken
unkind fawcons gerfawcons. partrychis Fesaunte Nyghtyngale and pyrs / there
lacken: also Roo and bucke and ylespyles wontes and other venomous beestes
therefore sum men ^^ynen and that favorably that saint patrik cleansed that
land of worms and of venomous beestes^ But it is more probable and more
skillful that this land was from the beginning always without such wormes^ For
venomous beestes and worms dyen there anon if men bring hem theder out of
other lands / And also venyme and poison brought theder out of other lands /
lesen their malice as soon as it passes themyddel of the Sea / Also powdre and
earth of that land cast and sown in other lands driven away worms so
ferforth that if a turf of that land be put about a worm it sleeth him or
makes him thrille the earth for tescape away / In that land cocks crow but
lytil to fore day^ so that the first crowyng of cocks in that land and the
thyrdde in other lands ben like far to fore the day

De Incolis prioribus Capitulum 33
GYraldus says that Casera Noes nece drad the flood and fled with three men
and fyfty wymmen in to that Ilond and dwelled therein first the last year to
fore noes floode / But afterward bartholanus Seres sone that come of Iaphet
noes sone come theder with his.iij. sons by hap or by craft three honderd
year after noes flood and dwellid there and encreced to the no^bre of ix / M /
men / And afterward for stenche of kareyns of geants that they had kyld / they
deyden al save one ruanus that lived a thousand and five honderd year unto
saint patriks time / And informed the holy man of the foresaid men / and of al
their doingisand deeds / then the thyrdde time come thither Nymeth out of
Sichia with his four sons and dwelled there ij honderd year and sixtene. and
at last of his ofsprynge by dyuse mishappes of wars and of moreyn they were
clean destroyed and the land left void.ij / C year after^ the fourth time
five dukes that were brethren ga^dius / genandus Sagandius / Rutheragus
sclauius of the foresaid nimethis successors come out of greece and occuppyed
that land and deled it in five parties. And every party contained / xxij /
candredes A candrede is a countraye that conteyneth an honderd towns / and
they set a stone in the myddel of the land as it were in the nauel and
beginning of / v / kingdoms / At last slanius was made king of all the
londe^ the fyfte time when this nation was.xxx. year to gyder they wexe feeble.
four noble men that were myllesius the kyngis sons come out of spain with
many other in a Nauye of / lx / shippis / and two of the worthiest of these
four brethren that hite hiberus and hermon deled the land bitwene hem tweyn
But afterward covenant was broken between hem both and hiberus was slain
then hermon was king of all that land / and from his time to the first
patriks time were kings of that nation sex score and euleuen. and so fro the
coming of the hybermensis unto the first patrik were a thousand year and
viij^C / They had that name hibermenses and hibernici of the foresaid hiberus.
or else of hiberos a River of spayne^ they were called also Gaytels and
scotts of one / gaytelus that was phenius neuew / this gaytelus could speak
many langages after the langages that were made at nemproths tour / And wedded
one scota pharoes daughter / Of these dukes come the hibermenses Men say that
these gaytelus made the yryshe langage and called it gaytelaf. as it were a
langage gadred / of all langages and tongues At last Belinus king of bretayn
had a sone that hight gurguncius^ As this gurguncius come out of denmark at
Irlondes Orcades he fond men that were called basclenses and were come thither
out of spain. these men prayde and besoughte for to have place to dwell
Inne^ And the king sent hem to Irlond that was tho void and waste. and
ordained and sent with hem dukes and capitayns of his own / And so it seems
that Irlond should long to. brytayn by right of old time ffrom the first saint
patrik unto Fedlinudius the kyngis time four honderd year reigned xxxiij. kynegs
eueryche after other in Irlond In this Fedlinudius time Turgesius duke and
capytayn of Norweyes brought thither men of Norweye and occupied that land and
made in many places deep dyches and castles sengle double and treble and many
wards strongly walled / and many thereof stand yet alhoole / But Irysshe men
retche not of castels^ For they take wodes for castles and mareys and mores for
castle dyches But at last Turgesius deyde by gyleful wyles of wymmen / And
English men seyn that gurmundus wan Irlond and made thylke dyches / and make
no mention of Turgesius / And yrysshe men speak of Turgesius / And know not of
gurmundus. therefore is to wete that gurmundus had wo^ne brytayn and dwelled
therinne / And sent Turgesius with great strength in to yrlond for to win
that land / and by cause Turgesius was Capytayn and leder of that viage and
journey and seen emonge them therefore yrysshe men speak much of him as a noble
man that was seen in that land and known. At last when gurmundus was slain
in Fraunce^ Turgesius / loved the kings daughter of meth in Irlond. And her
fader behyghte Turgesius that he would send her him to the low lacherin with
xv. maidens. And Turgesius promised to mete hem there with.xv^ of the noblest
men that he had / And held covenant and thought no gyle. but there come / xv
/ yo^g berdles men clothed like wymmen with short swords under her clothes /
and fylle on turgesius and slew him right there and so he was traitoursly
slain after he had reigned / xxx / yere^ Not long after three brethren amelanus
Syracus and iourus come in to Irlond with her men out of Norwaye as it had been
for lone of pees and of marchandyse and dwelled by the sea sides by assente of
Irysshe men / that were always ydel as paul's knights / And the norwayes bylded
three cytees^ deuelyn waterford and lymeryche. and encreced and after wexe
rebelle against men of that land and brought first sparthes in to Irlond / So
fro Turgesius time unto Rotheriks time king of cannaccia that was the last
that was king of all the land were xvij kings in Irlond And so the kings
that reigned in Irlond from the first hermons time unto the last Rotheriks time
were in all an honderd four score and one knygis that were not crowned nether
enoynted ne by law of heritage. but by might maystrye and by strength of
Armes^ The second harry king of England made this Rotherick subgette the year
of king harryes age forty. and of his regne xvij^ the year of our lord.xj.C
lxxij

De Incolarum moribus Solynus^ Capitulum / 34
SOlinus says that men of this land ben strange of nation houseles and great
fyghters / and acounte right and wrong al for one thing and ben syngel of
clothyng scarce of mete cruel of heart and angry of speech. and drynketh first
blood of deed me^ that been slain and then wesshen their vysages there with /
and hold hem paid with fflesshe and fruit instead of mete and with mylke^ instead of drink / and use much pleyng Idleness and hu^tyng and trauaylle full
lytil / In their childhode they ben hard norysshed and hard fedd and they be
unseemly of manners and of clothyng and have breche and hosen all one of wolle
and strayt hodes that scretcheth a cubyte over the sholders behind and
foldynges instead of mantels and of clokes / Also they use no sadles / boots
ne spores when they Ride. But they drive their horses with a Chambred yerd in
the over ende^ instead of byttes with trenches and of brydles of Reest they
use brydles that let not their horse to ete their mete / they fight unarmed
naked in body netheles with two darts and speres^ and with brood sparthes
they fight with one hand / these men forsake tylyeng of land and kepen pasture
for beestes / they use long berdes and long locks hanging down behind her
heedes^ they use no craft of flax of wolle of metal ne of marchaundyse but
give hem to ydlenes and to slouthe and rekene rest for likyng and fredom for
Richesse / And though Scotland the daughter of Irlond use harp tymbre and
tabour. Netheles Irysshe men be connyng in two manner Instrumentis of music in
harp and tymbre that is armed with wyre and strenges of brass. In which
Instruments though they play hastily and swyftly / they make right merry
Armonye and melodye with thyck tewnes werbles and notes. And begin from
bemol^and play secretly under dymme sown in the great strenges and torn
again unto the same. So that the grettest party^ of the craft hides the craft
/ as it would seem as though the cra^^ so hid should be ashamed / if it were
take / these m^n ben of (...) manner in her living they pay no tythes^ they
wedde lawful^^ they spare not their alyes but the brother weddeth the brode^^
wif they ben besy for to betraye their neighbors and other. they (...)
sparthes in their hondes instead of staves and fight ayens^ them that trust
most to them these men ben variable and vnst^^faste trechours and gyleful^
who that deleth with them (...) more to be ware of gyle than of craft of pees
than of brennyn^ brondes / of honey than of galle^ of malice than of knyghthode
^ They have such manners that they ben not strong in wars in battle ne^
true in pers. they become gossibs to them that they will falsely bitraye in the
gossibrede and holy kynrede / eueryche drynketh others blood when it is shed.
they love somdele her no^ice ^ her pleyfers which that souke the same milk
that they souked while they were childeren And they poursiewe their brethren
their cosins and their other kyn^ And despisen their kyn while ^ they live /
And avenge their death when they be slain / So long^ has the usage of euille
cu^tomme endured emonge them that (...) has gotten the maistrye over them and
turned treson in to kind so ferforth that they ben traitors by nature / and
alyens and m^n of strange lands that dwell among them folowen their manners
that uneath there is none but he is besmitted with their treson also / Among
them many men pissen syttyng and wymmen standing. there ben many men in that
land foul shapen in lymmes and in body / For in their lymmes they lack the
benefi^e^ of kind / So that nowher ben none better shapen than they that be
there well shapen and none worse shapen than they that be evil shapen And
skylfully nature hurt and defowled by w^ckednes of living brings forth such
foul gromes and evil shapen of hem that with unlawful delyng with fowl manners
and evil living so wyckedly defowleth kind. and nature / In this land and in
wales old wives and wymmen were woonte and ben yet as men seyne often for to
shape them self in likeness of hares for to milk their neighbors kyne and
stele her mylk / And often gerhoundes rennen after hem and poursiewe them and
wenen that they be hares / Also sum by craft of nygromancye make fat swyne
for to be reed of color and selle them in markettis and feyres^ But as soon as
the swyne pass any water they turn in to their own kind / whether it be
straw / heye gras or turues / But these swyne may not be kept by no craft for
tendure in likeness of swyne over three days / Among these wonders and other
take heed that in the uttermost end of the world falled often new merueylles
and wondres. As though kind playde with larger love secretly and fer in
thendes than openly and neygh the myddel / therefore in this Ilonde ben many
grysly wonders and meruaylles

De locorum prodigijs^ Giraldusus Merueylles of Irlond / Capitulum / 35
MAny men tellen that in the northside of. Irlond is the land of life. In that
Ilond noman may deye but when they ben old and be vexed with great s^kenes^
they ben born out in to the next land and deye there / There is another ylond
in Irlond that no woman therein may bear a childe^ but yet she may conceive Also
there is an Ilond in which no deed body may roten In vltonia that is vlster is
an Ilond in a lake wonderly departed in tweyne / In that one party is great
disturbaunce and discomfort of Fendes / And in that other party great lykyng
and comfort of holy Angels^ there is also saint patriks purgatory that was
showed at his prayers to conferme his prechyng and his lore^ when he preached to
mysbyleued of sorrow and of pain that evil men should suffer for her wicked
works / And of joy and bliss that good men shall resseyue for her holy deeds.
He tells that who that suffers the pains of that purgatorye^ if it be
enjoyed him for penance. he shall never suffer the pains of helle-but he dye
finally without repentance of sin / as the ensample is set more fulle at
this chapytres end Treuisa / But truly noman may be saved. but if he be very
repentaunt what sommeuer penance he do / And every man that is very
repentaunt at his lives end / shall be sikerly saved / though he never here of
saint patriks purgatory / There is an Ilond in Cannacte Salo that is in the sea of Conaccia halewed by saint Brandan / that has no myse. there deed bodies
ben not buried but ben kept out of therthe and roten not / In mamonia is a
well / who that wassheth him with the water of that well he shall wexe hoar on
his heed / there is another well in vltonia. who someuer is wesshen therein he
shall never wexe hoar afterward / There is a well in mownstre or momonia / if.
any man touch that well anon shall fall great rain in all the prouynce / And
that rain shall never cesse / til a priest that is a clean maid singe a mass
in a chapel fast by and bless the water and with milk of a Cow that is of
one here besprynge the well / And so reconcyle the well in this strange
manner At glyndalcan about the Oratorye of saint keywyn withges berith apples
as it were apple trees and ben more holsom than sauery / that holy saint
brought forth these apples by prayers for to heel his child that was seek There
is a lake in vlster and much fyssh therein which is.xxx mile in length and xv
in brede^ the River ban renneth out of that lake in to the north Occean And
men say that this lake began in this manner / there were men in that country
that were. of evil living / coeuntes cum brutis / And there was a well in
that land in great reverence of old. time and always couerd^ and if it were
left vncouerd the well would rise and drown all the land: and so it happed
that a woman went to that well for to fetch water And hied her fast to her
child that wept in the cradbe and left the well vncouerd / than the well
sprang so fast that it drowned the woman and her child and made all the country
a lake and ffyssheponde^ for to preue that this is soth it is a great argument
that when the weder is clear / Fysshers of that water see in the ground under
the water Round towris and high shapen as steples and chirches of that land /
In the northsyde of Irlond in the country of Ossiriens. every seven year at
prayer of an holy abbot. tweyne that been wedded a man and a woman must needs be
exyled and forshappen in to lykenes of wolves and abide out seven year / And
at the end of seven year / if they live they come home again and take again
their own shappe / And then shall other tweyne goo forth in their stead and so
forshapen for other seven year / there is a lake in this land if a pool of tree
be pyght and stycked therein that part of the shaft or pool that is in therthe
shall torn in to iron / And that part that abides in the water shall torn in
to stone^ And the part that abides above shall be tree in his owen kind. Also
there is a lake that torneth hasell in to asshe and asshe in to hasell if it be
don therein / Also in Irlond ben three samon leepes^ there as samons lepee
ayenste a roche a long speres length / Also in lagenia is a ponde / there be
seen colmans birds / the birds ben cleped certelles and come homly to man's
hand. but if men do hem wrong or harme^ they gone a way and come not again /
and the water there shall wexe bitter and stynke / And he that did the wrong
shall not asterte without wreche and meschyef but if be do amends / R As
touching patriks purgatorye^ ye shall understand that the second s^int patrike
that was abbot and not bishop while he preached in Irlonde labored and studied
for to torn thylke wicked men that lived as beestes out of her evil life for
dread of pains of helle^ And for to conferme hem in good life / And they said
they would not torn but sum of them might know somewhat of the great pains /
and also of bliss that he spak of Then saint Patrik prayed to god almighty
therefore / And our lord ihesu crist appierid to saint patrik and took him a
staf / and ladde him in to a wild place and showed him there a Round pytte
that was derke within and said / that if a man were very repentaunt and stable
of bileue and went in to this pytte and walked therinne a day and a night he
should see the sorrows and the pains of evil men and the joy and bliss of
good men / Then crist vanyssyhed out of patriks sight / And saint patrik
arered and bylded there a chirche^ and put therein chanons Reguler^ and closed
the pytte about with a walle^ and is now in the church yerd at est end of
the church / and fast shytte with a strong door / for noman should goo in
nycely with out leave of the bishop or of the Priour of the place Many men
went in and came out again in patriks tyme^ And told of pains and joy that
they had seen^ and the merueylles^ that they saw ben there yet wreton. And by
couse thereof many men turned and were converted to right bileue^ also many men
went in and came never again In king steue^s time king of England a knight that
hight oweyn went in to saint patriks purgatory / and came again and dwelled
ever after during his life in the needs of thabbay of ludensis that is of
thordre of cistews and he told many wonders that he had seen in patriks
purgatory. the place is called patriks purgatorye^ and the chirch is named /
Reglis / No man is enjoined for to goo in to that purgatory but counseylled
that he should not come therinne But take upon him other penance / and if / a
man have auowed and be stable and wole need goo therinne he shall first goo to
the bishop / And than he shall be sent with lettres to the prioure of the place
/ and they both shall counseylle him to leave. and if he will needs goo thereto /
he shall be in prayers and in fasting / xv. days. And after.xv. days he shall
be houseld and lad to the door of the purgatory with procession and letanye.
and yet he shall be counceylled to leave it And if he be steadfast and will enter
the door shall be opened: And he y blyssyd and goo on gods name and hold
forth his way / And the door shall be fast shette til the next day And when
the time is the priour shall come and opene the door / And if the man be comen
he ledeth him in to the church with procession. And there he shall be xv /
days in prayers and in fasting

De preconijs sanctorum / Capitulum 36
HCre Graldus makes mind that as men of this nation ben more angry than other
men and more hasty for to take wreche whiles they ben alive. So seyntes and
halowes of this land ben more wrecheful than sayn^es of other lands / Clerks
of this land ben chaste and sayen many prayers and don great abstynence a day
and drynketh al night. So that it is acounted for a miracle / that lecherye
regneth not there as wine regneth^ And they that been evil of them ben worst of
all other / so good men among them though they be but few ben good at best
/ Prelates of that country ben full slow in correction of trespaas and besym
contemplacion and not in prechyng of gods worde^ Therefore it is that all the
saints of that land. ben confessors and no martyr emonge them and no wonder.
For all the prelates of this land ben chosen out of abbayes in to the
clerg^e / And don as monks sholde^ what Clerks and prelates should do is to
them vnknowen^ therefore when it was put ayenste the bishop of Cassil how it
might be that so many saints ben in Irlond and never a martyr among hem all
sith that the men ben so shreud and so angry / and the prelates so recheles and
slow in correction of trespaas / the bishop answered frowardly ynowgh and
said our men ben shrewd and angry ynowgh to hem self. but to gods servants
they ^eye never hand / but do to hem great reverence and worship^ But
English men come in to this land that can make martres and were wont to use
that craft / R The bishop said so by cause that king harry the second was tho
new comen in to Irlond fresshly after the marterdom of saint thomas of
Counterbury / Gir^ in this land in wales and in scotland ben belles and staves
with crooked heedes and other such things for relyquyes in great reverence and
worship / So that men of this land dreden more for to swear upon any of thylke
belles and gold staves than upon the gospel^ The chyef of all such relyquyes
is y hold Ihesus staf^ that is at deuelyn / with the which staf^ they say
that the first saint patrik droo^ the worms out of Irlond Augustinus de
ciuitate d^i / Capitulo septimo. if men axe how it may be that diverse manner
beestes and of dyuerce kind that been kyndly gotten bitwene male und female come
and ben in Ilondes after noes flood / Men supposen that such beestes swam in
to Ilondes aboute^ And first to the next and so forth in to other Or else men
seylly^^ in to ylondes brought with hem such beestes f^r love of hunting or
angels at god almyghtyes commandment brought such beestes in to Ilondes
about. or the earth brought hem forth first and fulfilled tho gods
commandment that commanded the earth to bring forth gras and quyck beestes

De Scocia Capitulum / 37
Hit is a common saw that the Country which now is named Scotland is an out
stretchyng of the north party of britayn^ and is departed in the southside^
from britain with arms of the sea / And in the other sides al about byclypped
with the sea This land heet sometime Albania^ and has that name of Albanactus
that was king brutus sone / For Albanactus dwelled first the^nne / Or of the
prouynce Albania. that is a country of Scicia and nygh to amasona^ therefore
Scotts ben called as it were scites^ For they came out of Scicia / Afterward
that land heet pyctauia. For the pyctes reigned therinne a thousand year /
and.lxx / Or sum men tell a thousand three honderd.lx^ year And at last
heet hibernia as Irlond heygthe / Gir in top For many skylles one skyl is for
affynyte and alye that was bitwene them and yrysshe men / For they took wives
of yrlond and that is o^enly seen in her bileue^ in clothyng in langage and in
speech in wepen and in manners Another skylle is for Irysshe men dwelled there
sometime / Beda / libro primo Out of yrlond that is the propre countraye of the
scotts come yrysshe men with her duke that was called renda^ And with love and
with strength made hem chyef sees and cytees beside the pyctes in the
northsyde Gir / Now the land is shortly called scotland of scotts that come
out of yrlo^d and reigned therinne ^iij / C / xv / year unto the read williams
time that was malcolyns broder^ R. many euydencis we have of this scotland that
it is often called and heyte hibernia as yrlond does / therefore beda libro 2. c^
p / seyth that laurence archibisshop of dunbar was archibisshop of scotts that
dwelled in an ylond that heet hibernia and is next to brytayne. Also beda li /
3^ c / 27. seyth Pestelence of moreyn bare donn hibernia / Also. libro tercio^
capitulo secundo seyth that the scotts that dwelled in the south side of
hibernia / also libro 4^ capitulo tercio / he says that chadde was a yonglyng
and learned the rewle of monks in hibernia / Also libro quarto capitulo
visesimo secundo / Egfridus king of northumberland destroyed hibernia. Also
libro^ 4 ca. 15. The most dele of scotts in hibernia / And in the same
chapter he clepeth hibernia proprely named / That west ylonde is an honderd
mile from eueryche brytayne and departed with the sea bitwene / And called
hibernia that countray that now is callid scotland / there he tells that
adanman abbote of this ylond seyled to hibernia for to teache yryshmen the
lawful ester day And at last came again in to scotlo^d^ Ysi / ethli 14. Me^
ofthis scotland / ben named scotts in their own la^gage and pyctes also^ for
so^tymeher body was peinted in this man. they would sometime with a sharp egged
tole prycke and kerue her own bodyes^ and make thereon dyuse figures and shappes
/ and peynte hem with Ink or with other peynture / or colour^ And by cause
they were so peynted they were called picti / that is to say peynted Erodotus
Scotts ben light of heart. strange and wild ynowgh / but by. medlynge of
English men they ben much amended / they ben cruel upon their enemies And
hates bondage most of any thing / And hold for a foul slouthe if a man deye
in his bed And great worship if he deye in the field. They ben lytil of mete
and mow fast long / And eten selde when the son is up / And ete flesh
fysshe milk and fruit more than breed. And though they ben fair of shappe
They ben defowled and made unseemly ynowgh with their own clothyng. they
preyse fast the usage of their own forfaders^ And despysen other men's
doing / her ^onde is fruytful ynowgh in pasture gardyns and feeldes / Gir / de
/ p / capitulo / 18 / The princes of Scotts as the kings of spayn ben not
wont to ben enioynted ne crowned. In this Scotland is solemn and great mind
of saint andrew thappostel. For saint Andrew had the north contreys of the
world scytes and pyctes to his lotte for to preche and convert the people to
Cristes bileue / And was at last martred in achaia in Grecia in a cite that
was named patras / And his bones were kept two honderd ^lxxij / year unto
constantinus themperours time / And then they were translated in to
Constantinoble and kept there an.C / and ten year unto theodosius themperours
tyme^ Then vngust king of pyctes in Scotland destroyed a great party of
brytayn and was bisette with a great host of britons in a field called merk /
And he herd saint Andrew speak to him in this manner / vngus / vngus / here thou
me cristes apostle / I promise the help and socour / when thou have ouercomen
thyn enemies by mine help. thou shall give the third dele of thyn heritage in
alms to god almighty and in worship of saint Andrew^ and the sign of the
cross went to fore his hooste. And the thyrdde day he had vyctorye and so
turned home again / and deled his heritage as he was boden. And for he was
uncertain what cite he should dele for saint andrew / he fasted three days / he
and his men prayed saint andrew that he would show him what place he would chese
/ And one of the wardeyns that kept the body of saint andrew in Constantynoble
was warned in his sweuene that he should go in to a place whyder an angle would
led him. And so he came in to Scotland with seven felaws to the top of an
hille named Ragmund / The same hour light of heaven bishone and byclypped the
king of pyctes that was coming with his hooste to a place called carceuan /
There anon were heled many seek men / there met with the king Regulus the
monk of constantynoble with the relyques of saint Andrew There is founded a
church in worship of saint Andrew That is head of all the chirches in the
land of pyctes that is scotland / To this church comen pylgryms out of all
lands / there was regulus first abbot and gadred monkes^ And so all the
tienthe land that the king had assigned him he departed it in diverse places
among ab^^yes /

De wallia
Now this book takes on hand
Wales to fore england
So take I my tales /
And wend in to wales /
To that noble blood
Of priamus blood
Knowleche for to win.
Of great Jupiters kynne
For to have in mind
Dardanus kind
In these four titles I fond
To tell thestate of that land
Cause of the man I shall tell
And then preyse the land and well
Then I shall write with my pe^ne
All the manners of the men
Then I shall fond
To tell merueilles of the land
Of the name how it is named wales
Wales now is called wallia
And sometime it heet cambria
For camber brutes sone
Was prince and there did wone
Then wallia was to mean /
For gwalaes the queen
King ebrancus child
was wedded thither myld
And of that lord gwalon
withdraws of the soun
And put to / l^ i^ a
And thou shall find wallia /
And though this land
Be much less than england
As good glebe is one as other
In the daughter as in the mother
Of the commodytees of the land of wales
Though that land be luyte.
It is full of corn and of fruit
And has great plente ywys
Of flesh and eke of fysshe
Of beestes tame and wild
Of horse sheep oxen mylde
Good land for all seeds /
For corn gras and herbs yt spredes
There ben wodes and medes /
Herbs and flowers there spredes
There ben rivers and wells
Valeys and also hills
Valeys bring forth flood
And hills metals good
Cool grows under land
And gras above at hand
There lyme is copious
And slattes for hows.
Honey and milk white /
There is deynte and not lyte
Of braket methe and ale
Is great plente in that vale
And all that needs to the live
That land brings forth ryue.
But of great riches to be draw
And close many in short saw
Hit is a corner small
As though god first of al
made that land so feel
To be selere of al hele
Wales is deled by /
A water that heet twy /
Northwales from the southe /
Twy delith in places full couth.
The southe heet demecia
And the other venedocia /
The first shoteth and arowes beres.
that other deleth al with speres.
In wales how it be
Were sometime courts three
At carmarthyn was that one
And that other was in moan
The third was in powysy
In pengwern yt now is shrousbury
There were bisshops seven
And now ben four euen^
Under saxons al at hand
Sometime under pinces of yt la^d
Of manner and rites of the walssmen
The manner living of yt londe^
Is well diverse from england
In mete and drynk and clothyng
And many other doing /
They be clothed wonder well
In a shirt and in a mantel
A crisp breche well fayn
Both in wind and in rain.
In this clothyng they be bold
Though the weder be right cold
Without shetes always
Evermore in this array
They goo fight pleye and lepe
Stand sit lie and sleep
Without surcot goun cote and kirtell.
Without iope^ tabard cloc or bell /
without lace and chaplet yt her lappes
Without hode hatte or cappes^
Thus araid goon ye segges
And always with bare legs
They keep none other going /
Though they mete with ye king
With arowes and short speres
They fight with them yt he^ deres
They fight better if they neden
When they go tha^ wha^ they ride^
Instead of castle and tour
They take wode and mareis for so /
When they see it is to do cour /
In fyghtyng they wol be a go^
Gildas seyth they ben varyable
In pees and not stable
If men axe why it be
It is wonder for to see
Though men put out of land
To put out other would fond
But al for nout at this stand
For all many wodes be^ at gro^de
And upon the sea among
Ben castles builded strong
The men may dure long un ete
And love well comune mete
They can ete and ben mury /
Without great cury.
They ete breed cold and hoot
Of barley and of ote
Broad cakes round and thynne
As well seems so great kynne
Selde they ete breed of wheet
And selde they done ones ete
They have gruel to potage
And lekes kind to companage /
Also butter milk and chese
Y shape enlong and corner wese
Such messes they ete snel
And that makes he^ drynk well
Methe and ale that has might
Thereon they spend day and night
Ever the redder is the wyn.
They hold it the more fyn
When they drink at ale
They tell many a lewd tale
or when drink is an ho^dling
They ben full of Iangling /
At mete and after eke
Her solace is salt and leke
The husbond in his wise
Tells that a great prise /
to give a caudron with gruele
To hem that sitten on his mele
He deleth his mete at mele
And yeueth every man his dele.
And all the ouerpluse
He keeps to his own use /
Therefore they have woo
And mishappes also
They ete hoote samon always /
All though phisik say nay
Her howses ben low with all
And made of yerdes small
Not as in citres nyhe /
But fer a sonder and not to hihe
When al is eten at home /
Then to her neighbors will they
and ete what they may find and see /
And then torn home a ye. rome
The life is idle that they ledes
In bre^ning sleping and such deeds
Walsshmen use with her myght^
to wesshe their ghestes fret a nyt
If he wessh her feet al and somme^
Then they know yt they be well
They live so esily in a rowte
That selde they bear purs about
At her breche out and home come
They hong their money and comb /
It is wonder they be so hende
And hate crak at nether ende^
And without any core^
Make their wardroppe at door
They have in great mangery /
harp tabour and pipe for mi^stralcie
They bear corpse with sorrow gret^
and blow loud horns of gheet
They praise fast troyan blood
For thereof come al her broad /
Neyh kyn they will be
Though they passen an ^C / degree /
above other me^ they will he^ dit
and worship prestes with her myt
As angels of heaven right
they worshipe servants of god.
Often giled was this brood
And yerned batayl al for wode
For merlins prophecy almyt
And often for sortelegye.
Best in manners of britons.
For company of saxons
Ben turned to better right
That is known as clear as light
they tille^ gardins field and dounes
And draw hem to god tounes
They ride armed as wole god
And goo y hosed and y shood
And sitten fair at her mele
And sleep in beds fair and fele^
So they seem now in mind
More englissh than walssh kind
If men axe why they now do so
More than they woonte to do /
They lyuen in more pees
Because of their riches
For their catel should slake
If they used often wrake
Dread of loss of her good
Make them now stylle of mode
Al in one it is brought
Have nothing and dread naught /
The poet seyth a saw of preef /
the fotema^ sings to fore ye thef /
And is bolder on the way /
than the horsemen rich and gaye
Of the marueylles and wonders of wales
There is a pool at brechnok
therein of fish is many a flok
often he changes his hew on cop
And bereth^ above a gardin crop
Often time how it be
Shape of house there shall thou see
When ye pole is frore it is wonder
Of the noise that is there under
If the prince of the land hoote /
Briddes singe well merry noot /
As merrily as they can
And singe for none other man /
Besides carlion
Two mile fro the town
Is a roche well bright of leem
Right against the son beme /
Goldelyf that roche heyghte
For it shyneth as gold full brit
Such a flour in stone is naught
withowt fruit if it were sout /
If men could by craft undo
ye veins of therthe. and com thereto
Many benefyce of kind
Ben now hid fro man's mind
And ben unknown yet /
For defawte of man's wit
Great tresour is hid in ground
And after this it shall be found
By great study and besynes
Of hem that come after us /
that old men had by great need
We have by besy deed / Treuisa
In books ye may read
that kind failleth not at need /
When noma^ had craft in mind
then of craft halp god and kind
When no techer was in land
Men had craft by gods hand
they that had craft so then /
taught forth craft to other me^ne
some craft yt yet come not in place
some man shall have by gods grace
R^ an ylond is with nois and strif
In west walis at kerdyf
Fast by seuarn stronde
Barry hiht that ylond
In that hither side in a chene /
Shall thou here wonder dene
And diverse noys also
If thou put thyn ere to.
Noys of leaves and of wind
Noys of metal thou shall find
Froting of yre^ and whestones thou
Hetyng of ouens then with fire
all this may well be shall here /
By wawes of the sea
that breketh in their
With such noys and fare /
At penbrook in a stead.
Fendes do often quede
And throws foul thing in
And despyseth also sin.
Neither craft ne bedes may /
Do thens that sorrow away
when it greueth so
To the men it bodeth woo^
At crucinar in west wales
Is a wonder burials
Every man that comes it to see
Seems it even as much as (...)
Hool wepen there a night
Shall be broken er day light^
At nemyn in northwalis.
A litil ylond there is
That is called bardysey
Monks dwell there always
Men live so long in that hurst /
That the oldest deyed first /
Me^ say yt merlin there buried is
That highte also siluestris
There were merlyns tweyne
And prophesied beyne
One hite ambrose and merlyn
And was y gotten by gobelyn.
In demecia at carmerthyn.
Under king vortigerin
He told his prophecy
Even in snowdonye^
At head of the wat of coneway
In the side of mount eriri
Dynas embreys in walsshe
Ambrose hille in english /
King vortigere sat on /
The water side and was full of wone
Then ambrose merlin prophesied
to fore him right tho. Treuisa
What wit would wene.
Thate a fend might get a child
Sum men would mean
that he may no such werk welde
That fend that goth a night /
wymmen full often to gile
Iucubus is named by right.
And gyleth men otherwhyle
Succubus is that wight
God grant us none such vile.
Who that comes in her gyle
Wonder hap shall he smyle
With wonder deed
Both men and wymmen seed
Fendes wole kepe^
With craft and bring an heepe
So fendes wild
May make wymmen bear child /
Yet never in mind /
Was child of fendes kind
For withouten eye
There might no such child deye
Clergy makes mind
Death sleeth no fendes f^nde
But death slow merlin
Merlin was ergo no gobeblin /
Another merlin of albin land /
That now is named scotland^
And he had names two
Siluestris and calidonius also
Of that wode calidoni
For there he told his prephecie /
And heet siluestris as well
For when he was in batel
And saw above a grisly kind
And fill anon out of his mind
And made no more abood
But ran anon unto the wood^
Treuisa Siluestris is wood /
Other wild of mode
Other ellis /
That at wode he duelles
R. Siluestris merlyn
Told prophecy well and fyn
And prophesied well sure
Under king Arthure /
Openly and not so cloos
As merlyn ambros
There ben hills in snowdonye
That been wonderly hye
With heyght as great a way.
As a man may goo a day
And heet eriri on walsshe.
Snowy hills in english
In these hills there is
Leese ynowe for all beestes of walis
These hills on coppe beres
Two great fysshe weres /
Contained in that one ponde /
Meueth with ye wind an ylo^d
As though it did swymme
And neyheth to the brymme
So ye heerdes have great wonder
And wene yt the world meueth
In that other is perch and fysshe under /
Every one eyed is
So fares al^ well
In albania the mylwel /
In rutlond by tetingel
There is a lytil well
That flows not always /
As the sea twyes a day
But sometime it is dreye
And sometime full by the eye^
There is in norwallia
In mon that heet anglesia
A stone according well neyhe
As it were a man's thyhe /
How far ever that stone /
Be borne of any mon
On night it goth home his way
That he fond by assaye
Hughe therle of shrewsbury^
In time of the first harry /
For he would the soth find
That stone to anothir he ga^ bi^de
With great cheynes of iron /
And threw al y feren.
Y bounden at one heepe
In to a water deep
Yet a morrow that stone /
Was seen erly in mon /
A cherle held him self full sligh
And bond this stone to his thye
His thygh was roten or day /
And the stone went away
If men don lecherye
Neyhe that stone by
Swote comes of that stone
But child comes there none
There is a roche right wonderly.
The roche of heryng by country /
Though there cry any man born
And blow also with an horn
Noise there made though you abide
Thou shall here none in this side
There is another ylonde
Fast by mon at hand
Hermytes there ben ryue
If any of hem don strive
All the myse that may be get
Come and ete al their mete
Then seceth never that woo
Till the strife sece also
As men in this land /
Ben angry as in yrlond
So seyntes of this country /
Ben also wrecheful always.
Also in this land
In yrlond and in scotland /
Ben belles and staves
That in worship men haues /
And ben worshipped so then /
Of clerks and of lewed men
That dreden also /
To sweren on any of tho
Staf either belle
As it were the gospelle
At basyngwerke is a well
That sacer hete as men telle^
hit spri^geth so sore as me^ may see
What is cast in it throws a ye
Thereof springs a great stronde
It were ynowgh for all ye land
Seek at that place
Have both hele and grace
In the welmes after than ones
Ben found reed sperclid stones
In token of the blood reed
That the maid wenefrede
Shad at that pytte
when her throat was kytte
He that did that deed
Has sorrow on his seed
His children at al stoundes
Berken as welpes and hounds
For to they pray yt maid grace
Right at that well place
Either in shrowsbury street
There that maid rests sweet
De britannia Capitulum 39
AFter the Ilond of Occean now brytayn shall be descryued By cause of britayn all the trauayll of this storye was bygo^ne. The first point that shall be told shall
be of the names of the ylo^d / then of the stead and place of length and
bread / the thyrdd of the worthynes of the londe^ the fourth of merueylles and
wonders that been therinne / the fyfthe of the chyef party of the londe^ the
sixth of ylondes that been bisides that londe^ the seventh of the kings heyhe
wayes^ the viij of famous ryuers and stremes^ the ^ix^ of old cytees and
townes^ the tenthe of prouynces and shires / the.xj / of laws and of names of
laws / the ^xij of kyngedoms of bounds and of merkes between kyngdoms / the /
xiij / of bysshopriches and of bisshops sees / the.xiiij how many manner me^
have dwelled in that ylond / the fyftenth of langage of manners and of usage of
men of that land

De varia insule nuncupacione
First this land heyte albion / as it were the white land of white rokkes
about the clyues of the sea that were seen fro far. Afterward bruyte conquered
this land / And called it brytain after his own name. then saxons or
english men conquered this land and called it anglia that is england or it is
called anglia of a queen that owed this land that was named angela / and was a
noble dukes daughter of the saxons^ or as ysid seyth eth / 15 / Anglia has
that name as it were an angle and a corner of the world / or else as beda
says libro primo^ Saint gregory saw english children to selle at Rome. And
he acorded to the name of the land and said they ben sothly anglis. For her
face shyneth as angels / For the noblete of the land shone in the children
faces. Alfred The brytysshe Anglia is cleped the other world and for great
plente of al good the great charles called hit his own chamber / Solynus / The
edge of the fre^sshe clyf should be the end of the world if the ylonde of
brytayn ne were not^ which is worthy to have the name of another world / Al^o
This Ilond is called Insula^ For it is in sa^^ that is the sea and is beten of
with diverse course of waters with stremes and with wawes of the sea

De situ eius et dimensione. before libro secundo capitulo. 77 Capitulum 40
THis britayn is acounted a noble land. both in our storye^ and also in the
stories of greeks / and is set against Ge^^man^a gallia France and spain

questions and doubt whether it be even tide or dawynge / that is for the time
of the yere^ that the son goth not fer under the earth by night / But passes
by the north side and comes sone in to the eest again. And therefore in the
somer ben there days full long of xviij hours. And the nyghtes of six hours /
And after in the winter ben long nyghtes of / xviij: hours and short days of
vj Also in Armenia / Macedonia / Italia and in other lands of the same line
the lengest day and lengest night also is of xv hours / And the shortest day

men / there is the lengest day ^xij hours. In allexandria in egypt of xiij

named tile in all the six somer months is day^ And all the six winter

AS ffraunce passes britayn so Brytayn passes Irlond in fair weder and
noblete / but not in health / Beda libro primo For this ylond is best to bring

The land is plentiuous and the sea also. The land is noble copious and rich
of noble wells and Ryuers with plente of Fysshe^ There is great plente of small
fysshe of samo^ and of eels / W / de po^ li. 3o. So that the people in sum

drye^ but ever the older the color is the fayrer^ There ben also saltwelles and
hot wells. thereof rennen strem^s of hoote bathes departed in to diverse

De mirabilibus in ea stupendis Solynus^ Capitulum. 42
IN brytayn ben hoote wells. well arrayed and adressyd to the use of mankind.
maystresse of thylk wells is the great spyrite of minerua^ In here hows the
fire endures always that never changes in to asshes^ But there the fire
slaketh^ hit changes in to stony clottes Alf^ In Britayne ben many wonders.
Netheles four ben most wonderful / The first is at pecton there blows so
strong a wind out of the chynes of the earth that it casts up again clothes
that men cast in / The second is at stonhenge besides salesbury^ there ben
great stones and wonder huge and ben rered an heygh as it were yates^ So that
there semen yates set upon other yates / Netheles it is not known clerly ne
apperceyued how and wherefore they ben so arrered and so wonderfully honged / the
thyrdde ts at cherdhoke / there is a great holownes under earth. often many
men have walked therein and have seen Ryuers and stremes / But nowher can they
find none ende^ the fourth is that rain is seen raised upon hills and a none
y spronge about in the feldes^ Also there is a great ponde that conteyneth /
lx^ ylondes couenable for men to dwell in / that ponde is byclypped about with
/ vj / score roches / and upon eueri roche an egles nest / And.lx. Ryuers
rennen in to that ponde / and none of hem all rennen in to the sea but one /
there is a ponde closed about with a wall of tile and of stone / In that ponde
men wasshe and bathe well often and every man feleth the water hoote or cold
right as he will him self / there ben salt wells f^r from the sea. and ben salt
all the weke long unto saturday none / And fresshe fro saturday none unto
monday / the water of these wells when it is soden torneth in to small salt
fair and white / Also there is a ponde the water thereof has wonder wirchyng /
For though al an hooste stood by the ponde and turned their face thyderward /
the water would draw hem violently toward the ponde and wete al their clothes
so should horse be drawn in the same wise. And if the face be turned away fro
the water / the water noyeth not There is a well that no streme renneth fro
neither thereto / And yet four manner ffysshes be taken therein. that well is
but.xx / foot long and / xx / foot broad / And not deep but to the kne. and
closed with high banks on every side / In the countray about wynchestre is a
den or a cave out of that cave blows always a strong wynde^ so that noman may
endure to stond to fore that den or cave / there is also a pond that torneth
tree in to iron if it be therein a year / And so trees ben shapen in to
whestones. also there is in the top of an hill a buryels every man that comes
and meteth that buryel^ he shall find it even of his own length and mesure^
And if a pilgrim knele thereto / anon he shall be al fresshe and feel no grief of
werynes Gir in top Fast by the mynster of wynburney that is not fer fro bathe
is a wode that bears much fruit / if the trees of that wode fall in to
water or ground that is neyh and lie there al a year / the trees tornen in to
stones / Gir in itinere Under the cite of chestre renneth that river dee that
now departs england and wales / that River chau^geth every month his fordes
as men of the countray tellen^ and leueth often the chanel. But whether the
wat^r draw more toward england or toward wales / to what side that it be. that
year men of that side have the werse end and be ouersette. And men of that
otherside shall have better end and be at their above / when the water so
changes his course hit bodeth such happes / this River d^e renneth and comes
out of a lake that heet pymblemere / In that River is great plente of Samon.
netheles in the lake is never Samon founden^ W / de^ r / libro secundo Take heed how great light and brightness of goddis myldenes has be showed upon
english men. since they turned first to right bileue. So that of no men in one
prouynce ben founden so many hoole bodies of men after her death in lykenes of
euerlastyngnes that shall be after the day of dome as it well seems in these

steadfast for to trust on the fynal ary: sing of deed bodies for to last

De partibus brytannye principalibus Capitulum 34
AFter the first brutes time thr Ilonde of brytayn bygan for^ to have the
principal partyes^ that been beogria^ Cambria that is wales / And albania that
is now scotland^ Loegria had that name of locrinus that was brutes oldest sone
/ and heet Loegria as it were locrinus land / but now loegria is called
England / the bounds and merkes were thereof sometime the frenssh see both by
est and by southe / Beda libro primo capitulo visesimo And by north two arms
of the sea that breketh fer in to the land either against other. but they reche
not to gyders^ the est arm of thylk tweyn begins about a two lytil mile fro
the mynstre / of ebburcuring. in the west side of penulto^ in that arm is a
town that is called guydy. the weste arm of thylk tweyne has in the rightside
a strong cite that heet alcliud which in her langage is called clintstone / and
stands upon a river that is called Clynt also. R Sum men would mean that
loegria ends at humber / and stretches no ferther northward. the second
party of brytayn is called Albania that is scotland^ and has that name of
albanactus bruytes sone and stretches fro the forseyd two arms of the sea
northward unto the sea of norwaye. Netheles the south party of albania where
as pyctes dwelled sometime lies from the water of twede unto the scottysshe see
/ All that longed sometime to the kingdom of Northumberland. brenycorn / the
northside of northumberland fro the first time of english kings to that time
when kynadyus king of scotland that was alpinus sone did away the pyctes and so
joined that contray to the kingdom of scotland / the thyrdde party of brytayn
is wales. wallia. that heet Cambria also. And has that name cambria of camber
brutes sone / For he was prince of wales^ In the est s^de seuarn departed
sometime between england and wales / But now in the northside the River dee at
chestre and in the south the river that is named vaga at the castle of
strygelyn departs england. and wales^ Also king Offa for to have a
distinction for evermore between the kings of England and of wales made a
long dyche that stretches forth out of the southside by briston under the
hills of wales / northward and passes the Ryuers Seuarn and dee almost to the
heedes and unto the mouth of the River dee by yonde chestre fast by the castle
it renneth between cobehill and the mynstre of basyngwerke in to the see^ This
dyche is yet in many places seen In saint edwards time walsh men should not
pass that dyche with wepen upon a greet pain. and that was at earl beraldes
procuryng as it shall be said here after / but now in either sides both ayond
half and a this half the dyche and specially in the shyres of chestre of
shrousbury and of herford^ in many places ben english men and walsshmen
meddled to gyders

De Insulis britannye adiacentibus Capitulum 44
BRytayn has three ylondes that been neygh and longen thereto al without the
ylondes orcades / as it were answeryng to the three chyef parties of brytayn.
for the isle of wight ^ongeth and lies to loegria that is england / The Ilond
mon that is called anglesia also longs to wales^ And the ylond eubonia that
has two other names and is called menauia and man also^ which longs to
Scotland^ And all these three ylondes wight mon and man ben almost yliche
much And of the like quantite of the which / three al arewe now follows our
speech. Beda libro primo capitulo tercio Claudyus sent vaspasianus and
vaspasianus wan wight And wight stretches out of the est in to the west /
xxx. mile long. And out of the south in to the north.xij mile / And is in the
est side six mile fro the south clyf of brytayn^ and three mile in the weste
side / Beda libro quarto capitulo quinto / the mesure of this ylond as
english men guess is a thousand howsholdes and two honderd Gir in itinere^
Mon that is called anglesia also is departed from northwales by a short arm of
the sea as it were two mile brood^ In mon ben three honderd towns.lxiij. And
ben acompted for candredes / that been three hondredes / the Ilond is as it
were.xxx mile long and / xij / mile / cantredus is so much land as contained
an honderd towns. that name cantedrus is made one of two langages of brytysshe
and of yryssh. In praysyng of this ylond walsshe men ben wont to say a
proverb and an old sawe^ Mon main kembry / that is to say in englyssh mon
mother of wales / For when other lands lacken mete. that land is so good that
it seems that it would find corn ynough^ for all the men of wales. therefore
vyrgyls verses may be acordyng therto^ as much as guawes^ beestes long
Inneth dawes So much efte / brings cold dew in a nyyhte. In that arm of
the sea that departs this land and northwales is a swolow that draws
ships to it that saylleth by and swoloweth hem in right as does cilla and
caribdis that been two peryllous places in / the sea of mydde^erthe / therefore
men may not saylle by this swolow but slyly at full see^ R Of the marueylles
and wonders of the ylond mon thou shall find tofore in the chapter of wales.
Gir in itinere. The third ylond that is called both eubonia and menauia that
is man stondeth in the myddel between the yrysshe vlster and the scotyssh
Gallewaye as it were in the nauel of the sea Beda libro secundo capitulo nono
This ylond man conteyneth as it were two Ilondes / The first is southward the
more country and the better corn land / and conteyneth ix.C and lx
husholdes^ The second conteyneth the space of three honderd and moo as englisshe
men guess Gir in top / Sometime was stryf whether this ylond man should long to
Brytayn or to yrlonde / And for as much as venomous worms that were brought
thither lived there It was Iugged that the ylond man should long to brytayn. R.
In that Ilond is sortilege and wyccecraft used. For women there selle to
shipmen wind as it were closed under three knottes of threde / So that the more
wind he would have / the mo knottes he must undo. there often by day time men of
that land seen men that been deed to fore hond^ byheded or hoole and what death
they deide alyens setten their feet upon feet of the men of that land for to
see such sightes as the men of that don Beda li / 1 Scotts dwellid first in
this ylond / Thanatos that is tenet^ and is an ylond besides kente and has
that name thanatos of death of serpents. for there ben none / And the earth
thereof sleeth serpents y born in to other lands / There is a noble cornlond
and fruytful / hit is supposed that this ylond was halewed and blessed of saint
anstyn the first doctor of englyssh men For there he arrived first

De platris regalibus Ganfe Capitulum. 45
MOliuncius king of Brytons was the ^xxiij^ of hem and the first that yaf hem
law. he ordained that plowmen solowes gods temples and high weyes that leden
men to Cytes and towns should have the fredom of socour / so that every man
that went to any of the three for socour or for trespass that he had do should be
sauf for poursuete of all his enemies but afterward for the weyes were
uncertain and strif was had. therefore Belinus the king that was the forsaid
molyuncius sone for to put away all doubt and stryf made four high kings
w^yes priueleged with all priuelegys and fredo^ / and the ways stretche
through the ylo^d The first and grettest of the four ways is called Fosse / and
stretches out of the south in to the north and begins from the corner of
corn wayle and passes forth by deuenshyre by somersete / and forth besides
tetbury upon cotteswold beside couentre unto leycetre and so forth by wild
pleynes toward newerk and ends at lyncoln. the second chyef kyn^tes high way
is^ named wat^ingstrete and stretches thwert over fosse out of the southest in
to the north west^ and begyneth at dover / and passes by ye middel of ke^t
over temse biside london by west westmestre^ and so forth by seint albo^ in the
west side by donstable by stratford by toucetre by wedo^ by south lylleborn by
atheriston unto gilbertus hille that now is called wrekene^ And forth by seuarn
and passes besides wrokcetre / and then forth to stratton and so forth by
the myddel of wales unto cardykan and ends at yrysshe see the thyrdde way
is called Erimyngestrete and stretches out of the west northwest in to eeste
southeeste and begins in meneuia that is in saint david land in west wales
and stretches forth unto southampton^ The fourth is called Rykenyldestrete and
stretches forth by worcetre by wycombe by birmyngham by lychefeld by derby by
chestrefeld by york and forth unto tynmouthe

De famosis fluminibus Alfr Capitulum 46 /
Three famous Ryuers rennen through brytayn by the which three rivers merchants

northumberland. R / these name temse seems made one name of two names of two

falls in yse. therefore all the river fro the first head unto the eest see is
named tamyse or temse Tamise begins besides tetbury that is three mile by
north malmesbury / there temse springs of a well that renneth estward and

and esex westsex and mercia that is as it were a great dele of myddel england.
R / Seuarn is a / river of britain and is called habern in britons / and has

York is a great Cite in either side of the water of Owse. that seemed as fair
as Rome unto the time that the king William Conqueror had with brennyng and
