and ^^^kyng Mercurius with couetise of Richesse and marchandyse / bachus with
great drynkyng^ venus with love lewdly Lauerna with theft and Robberye /
Protheus with falshed and gyle then is pluto not. vnseruyd god of hell R
There babylon lore more might has truth the more

De shiris Anglie sieve prouyncijs / Capitulum 49
Take heed that England conteyneth.xxxij^ shyres and prouynces / that now ben
called Erldomis / reserved Cornewayl and the Ilondes Alfr These ben the names
of the Erldoms and Shyres^ Kent Southsex / Sortherey. Hampshire. barokshire
that has his name of a bare ook that is in the forest of wyndesore For at that
bare ooke men of that shyre were wont come to gyders and make their tretis and
there take counseyl and aduys Also wildshyre that heet sometime the prouynce of
semeran Somersete Dorsete / deuenshire that now is called deuonia in latin.
These.ix. southshires tamyse departs from the other dele of england which
were sometime governed and Rewled by the westsaxon law / Estsex Myddelsex^
Southe folk north folk hertfordshire. Huntyndonshyre. Northamptonshyre /
Cambryggeshyre / bedfordshyre / Buykynghamshyre Leycetre shyre Derby shyre /
notynghamshyre Lincolnshyre yorkshyre / Duramsihre^ Northumberhand Caerlelshyre
with Cumberlond Appelbisshyre with westmerlond lancasshyre that conteyneth five
litil shires / These fyftene north and eest shyres were sometime governed and
rewled by that law which is called denelawe / But Oxenforshire Warwikshire.
gloucestreshyre * wircetre shire Herdforshire shropshire staffordshire
Chestresire These viij middel and west shires were sometime governed and Rewled
by the law called mercia in latin and merchene law in englysshe^ It is to
wete that yorkshyre stretches from the river of humbre unto the River of
teyse. and yet in yorkshyre ben / xxij hondredis hundred and candred is al one.
candred is one word made of walsshe and prysshe And is to menyng a country
that conteyneth an honderd towns / And is also in englyssh called wepentak^
For sometime in the coming of a new lord. tenauntes were wont to yield up her
wepe^ instead of homage. dura^shire stretches from the river teise unto ye
river of tine / and for to speak proprely of Northumberla^d it stretches fro
the river Tyne unto the River of Twede that is in the beginning of Scotland /
then if the countray of Northumberland that was sometime from humbre unto
Twede be now acompted for one shire And for one erldom as it was somtyme^
Then ben in england but / xxxij shires but if the countray of Northumberland
be departed in to vj shires that been ever wikshire duramshire Northumberlond
carleylshire Appelbyshire and Lancasshire^ then ben in england xxxvj shires
without Cornuale and also without the ylondes King william conqueror made
all these prouynces and shires to be descryued and meten then were fonden
xxxvj shires and half a shyre / Towns L / ij / M / four score Parissh chirches
/ xlv M and ij / knights fees / lxxv^M Whereof men of Relygyon have xxviij
thousand.xv. knights fees / But now wodes ben hewn down and the land new
tylled and made much more than was at that time and many towns and vyllages
builded and so there ben many moo vyllages and towns now than were in that time
And where as a fore is wreton that cornuayll is not set among the shires of
england it may stand among them well ynowgh For it is neither in wales ne in
scotland but is in england And joins to deuensshire / And so may there ben
acompted in england xxxvij shires and an half with the other shires

De Legibus legumque vocabulis Capitulum 50
DVnwallo that heet Moliuncius also made first laws in britayne the which
laws were called moliuncius laws And were solompnly observed unto wiliam
conquerours time Molyuncius ordained among his laws / that Cytees Temples and
weyes that led men thereto and plowmen solowes should have priuelege and fredom
for to save all men that would flee there to for socour and refuge / Then
afterward marcya queen of britons that was gwytelynus wife. Of her the prouynce
had the name mercia. as sum men suppose. She made a law full of right of
wit and of reason / and was called merchene law / Gildas that wrote the
historyes of brytons turned these two laws out of briton speech in to latyn^
And afterward king Aluredus turned all out of latin in to saxon speech / and
was called merchene law / Also the same king Aluredus w^ote in englyssh and
put to another law that heet westsaxon law / Then^e afterward danes were
lords in this land / and so came forth the thyrdde law that heet dane law /
Of these three laws saint Edward / the confessor made one common law that yet
is called saint edwardes law / I hold it well don to write here and expowne
many terms of these lawes^ Myndebruche. hurtyng of honor and worship^ In
frensshe bleschur dhonour^ Burchbruch in frensshe / bleschur de court on de
cloys / Gritchbruch brekyng of pees^ Myskennyng chaungyng of speech in court /
Showing setting forth of marchandyse / In frensshe displeir de marchandyse^
Hamsokne^ or hamfare a rese made in hows / Forstallyng / wrong or let down in
the kings hye waye^ Frythsoken sewrte in defence^ Saka / for fait Soka Suit of
court / and thereof comes soken / Theme suit of bondmen^ Fyghtingtwyte.
Amersement for fightyng. Blodewyte. Mersement for shedyng of blood Flytwite.
amends for shedynge of blood. leyr wyte^ amends for lyeng by a bondewoman /
Gul^ewite amends for trespas^ Scot a gadryng to work of bailyes / hydage
tayllage for hydes of lands Danegheld tayllage yeuen to the danes that was of
every bonata terre that is every Ox land three pens / A weepentack and an
honderd is al one For the contre of C towns were woonte to give up wepen in
the coming of a lord. Lestage custom y chalengyd in chepyngys and fayres
stallage custom for stondynge in streets in feyre time

De Regnis regnorumque lymitibus Capitulum 51
THe kingdom of britayn stood without departing hool and al one kingdom to the
britons from the first bruyte unto Julius cezars time / And fro Julius cezars
time unto Seuerus time this land was under trybute to the Romans Netheles
kings they had of the same land from Seuerus unto the last prince gracyan
successors of brytayns faylled / And Romans reigned in brytayn Afterward the
Romans left of the Regnyng in Brytayn. by cause it was fer from Rome of for
great business that they had in other side Then Scotts and pyctes by
mysledyng of maximus the tyrant poursiewed brytayn and warred therein with
great strength of men of Arms long time unto the time that the Saxons come
at prayeng of the brytons against the pyctes and put out gurmund the yrysshe
king with his pyctes and the brytons also with her king that heet Carecticus
and drof hem out of England in to wales / And so the saxons were victours and
every prouynce after his strength made hem a king and so departed england in to
vij kyngdo^s Netheles afterward these vij kyngeddoms euerych after other come
all in to one kingdom al hool under the prince adelsto^ / netheles the danes
poursued this lo^d fro athelwulfis time that was a luredus fader unto the
third saint edwardes time about / C / lxx year and reigned therein continuelly
xxx year after the danes the / iij. saint Edward reigned therein xxiij year and a
lytil more / And after him haralt held the kingdom ix monethis And after hem
Normans have reigned unto this time But how long they shall regne he wot to whom
nothing is unknown R Of the for said seven kingdoms of her merkes meres and
bounds / when they began and how long they endured / here shall I somewhat
shortly tell Alf^ The first kingdom was the kingdom of kent that stretches
fro the eest Occean unto the River of Tamyse. there reigned the first hengistus
and began to regne by the acompting of dyonyse the year of our lord four / C /
lv^ That kingdom dured three honderd lxviij / year under ^xv / kings unto the
time that Baldrede was put out. And Egbert king of westsaxon^ joined that
kingdom to his own. the second kingdom was of southsaxon that had in the eest
side kent In the south the sea and the isle of wight. In the west hampshyre and
in the north sothery. There ella reigned first with his three sons / And began to
regne the year after the coming of the angles even / xxx / But that kingdom
within a short time passed in to other kyngdoms The thyrdde kingdom was of
eestsaxon^ and had in the est side the see^ In the weste the country of London^
In the southe Tamyse / In the north southfolk. The kings of this contreye
estsaxon fro the first Sabertes time unto the time of the danes were ten kings
which were subget somdel to other kings / Netheles oftest and lengest they
were under the kings of mercia and unto. that time that Egbert king of
westsaxon joined that kingdom to his own The fourth kingdom was of eest anglis
and contained Norfolk and Suffolk and had in the eest side and in the north the
see^ In the northwest cambrygeshyre^ In the west saint Edmundes dyche and
hertfordshyre. And in the southe Ests^x / This kingdom dured under / xij /
kings unto the time that King Edmunde was slain / And then the danes took
wrongfully both the kyngdoms of eest angles and of eestsaxon Afterward the
danes were put and driven away or made subgette And the elder king Edward
joined both the kyngdoms to his own / the fyfth kingdom was of westsaxon and
dured lengest of all these kyngdoms and had in the est side southsaxon. In the
north Tamyse. In the southe and weste the sea Oxcean^ In that kingdom reigned
Cerdrick with his sone kenrik and began to regne the year of our lord.v^C^xix /
And after the coming of anglis lxxj^ so seyth denis the other kyngdoms passyd
in to this kingdom. The sixte kingdom was of mercia and was grettest of all
The marks and the meres thereof were in the west side the River dee fast by
chestre and seuarn fast by shrowesbury unto bristowe / In the eest the est see^
In the south Tamyse unto London In the north the River humbre / And so westward
and dounward unto the River mersee unto the corner of wirhal there hu^bre
falls in to the west see / Penda wybbes sone reigned first in this kingdom
the year of our lord ^vj / C / xxvj / so seyth denis And fro the coming of
angles an / C.lxxv / year / This kingdom dured under xviij kings about two C
lxiij year unto the last colwulf / to the which colwulf the danes bitoke that
kingdom to keep when burdred the king was put out / But the elder Edward the
king put out the danes and joined the kingdom of mercia to his own kingdom /
netheles at beginning this kingdom of Mercia was departed in three In west
mercia In myddel mercia and est mercia / The seue nth kingdom was
northamhimbrorum that is the kingdom of northumberlond The meres and marks
thereof were by West and by est the sea of occean by south the river of humbre
and so dounward toward the west by thendes of the shires of Nothyngham and of
derby unto the River of mersee / And by north the scottysshe see that heete
forth in scottysshe werid in brytysshe^ the scotyssh see in english This
kingdom of northumberlond was first deled in two prouynces / that one was the
south side and heete deyra / and that other was the north side and heet
brenicia as it were two kyngdoms^ And the River departed these two kyngdoms
that tyme^ For the kingdom of deyra was fro the River of humber unto the River
of tine. The kingdom of brenycia was fro tyne to the scottysshe see^ And when
pyctes dwelled there as beda seyth libro terci^ capitulo secundo / that ninian
that holy man converted men of the south side / Ida the king reigned there first
and began to regne the rere of our lord / v / C / xlvij. so seyth dyonyse. In
deyra reigned the king elle the year of our lord.v.C.xlix^ These two kyngdoms
were other while as it is said departed between two kings and sometime al hool
under one king And dured as it were.xx english kings. three hundred and / xxj
/ year / At last osbrutus and elle were slain in the / ix^ year of her
kingdom / the danes slow hem^ And northumberlond was vode without king viij
year Then afterward the danes reigned in northumberlond / xxxvj year unto the
oonyng of the kingdom of adelston^ he made subget the kings danes scotyssh and
walssh / And reigned first al one in england and held the kingdom of england
all hoole and all one kingdom that was the year of our lord / viij / C.xxvij
That River of mersee was sometime the mark and mere between the kingdom of
mercia and the kingdom of northumberlond that may be showed in two manners ^
first by the proprete of this mersee that is as much to say as a see that is
a bound and a mere / For it departs one kingdom from another Also it is write
in Cronycks of Henry and of alfrede that king coward the elder fastened a castle
at mauncestre in northumberlond / But that cite mau^cestre is fro the River of
mersee scarsely three myle^

De episcopatibus et sedibus / Alfr Capitulum. 52
LVcius was the first king Cristend of the brytons in his time were three
Archibisshops sees in Brytayn / One was at London^ Another at york And the
thyrdde at caruske the cite of Legyo^s in glamorgan^ that cite now is called
carleon / to these Archibisshops sees were subget xxviij bisshops and were
called Flamynes to the archibisshops see of London was subgette C^^nual and al
myddel england unto humbre / To york al northumberlond from the low of humbre
with all Scotland To Caerleon all walls / there were in wales seven bisshops
and now ben but four^ Tho Seuarne departed england and wales / W de pon libro
primo. But in saxons time though saint gregorye had granted london the
pryuelege of tharchibisshops see^ Netheles saint Austyn that was sent in to
England by saint Gregory turned tharchebisshops see out of London in to
cau^terburye After saint Gregoryes day at prayer of king Athelbert and
Cytezeyns and burgesyes of canterbury. there tharchebisshops see has dured
unto now / Save that in the mean time Offa king of mercia was wroth with men of
caunterbury / and bynam hem that worship^ And worshipped adulph bishop of
lichfeld with tharchibisshops pal by assente of adrian the pope upon caas by
yeftes sent Netheles under kenulph the king it was restored to caunterbury
again. The worship of the sea of york has dured there always and dureth yet
though Scotland be withdraw fro his subjection by passing of time. Gir in iti
/ li / p: the archibisshops see was y turned out of caerleo^ in to meneuia that
is inthe west side of demecia upon the pryssh see in saint david's time under
king arthur from saint david's time unto sampsons time were in meneuia
Archebisshops. xxiij / aftward fill a pestylence in all wales of the yelow evil
that is called the Iau^dis / and then^e sa^pso^ tharchibisshop took with him
the palle and went in to Brytayn armonyca the lasbritayne and was there
bishop of dolensis / From that time unto the first harryes time. king of
England were at meneuia. which is called saint david's xxj bisshops all without
palle whether it were for uncunning or for pouerte / Netheles always fro that
time the bisshops / of wales were sacred of the bishop of meneuia of saint
dauyes / And the bishop of meneuia was sacred of the bisshops of wales as of
his suffrigans and made no profession ne subjection to none other church /
Other bisshops that come afterward were sacred at caunterbury by compellyng and
heest of the king. In token of that sacrynge and subjection bone face
archibisshop of caunterbury that was legate of the cross so^ge in every
cathedral chirch of wales sole^pnly^ amasse he was the first archebisshop of
canterbury that so did in wales. and that was don in the second Harryes tyme^
R But now ben but two primates in al^ England of Caunterbury and of york / To
the primate of caunterbury ben subget.xiij. bisshops in England and four in
wales The primate of york has but two Suffrigans in england that been the
bisshops of caerleyl and of durham Of all these sees and chaungyng of her
places I shall show you here folowyng^ Take heed in the beginning of holy
church in England bisshops ordained their sees in low places and simple that
were couenable for contemplacion for prayers and devotion / But in wiliam
conquerours time by dome of law canon it was ordained that bisshops should come
out of small tounes in to great cytees^ Therefore was the sea of dorchestre
changed to lyncoln / lychefeld to chestre: Tetford to norwiche. Shirborn to
salisbury wells to bathe^ Cornwayl to Ex^tre And Selesey to Chicestre. The
bishop of Rochestre has no paryssh but he is tharchebisshops chappellayn of
Caunterbury. Sith the Sea of caunterbury was first ordained by saint Austyn /
it changed yet never his place^ Chicestre has under him only southsex and the
isle of wight / And had his see. first in Selesey in the time of tharchebisshop
theodore. And the sea dured there three honderd ^xxxiij / year under.xx.
Bisshops fro the first wilfrede unto the last Stigande at commandment of
king william conqueror changed the sea from Selesey to chicestre.

De Episcopis occidentalibus. Willelmus Capitulum 53
Have mind that all the prouynce of westsaxon had always one bishop fro the
beginning unto theodoras time / By grant of king Islo king of westsaxon the
first byrinus ordained a see at dorchestre that is a simple town by southe
Oxenford beside wallyngford between the metynge to gyder of Tems and Tame when
birinus was deed kenwalcus the king ordained a See at wynchestre as his fader
had purposed. there Agilbert a frensshe man was first bishop of all the
prouynce of westsaxon / Fro that time the Cite and the Sea of Dorchestre
perteyned and longed to the prouynce of mercia

For that cite stondeth within Temse^ And Temse departs bitwene mercia and
westsaxon^ After that Agilbert was put out of wynchestre that tho highte
wynton There was there an englyssh bishop there that was called wyn O Sum men
suppose that the cite has the name of this wine and is called wynchestre as it
were wynes cite / At last he was pute out and after him come lentherius the
forseyd agelbertes neuew / After lentherius hedda a while was Bishop there
when he was deed theodorus tharche bishop ordeynd two bisshops to the Prouynce
of westsaxon Danyel at wynchestre to him were subgette two contreyes Sothery
and Southampshire^ Adelin / at shirborn to him were subgette six countrees /
Barkshire^ wiltshire / Somersete Dorsete shire / Deuenshire and cornuayl
Treuisa It seems by this that westsaxon contained sothery / Southampshire /
barkshire. wiltshire Somerseteshyre Dorsetshire deuenshire and Cornuayl.
Willelmus Afterward in elder Edwardes time to these two sees were ordained by
commaundment of Formosus the pope^ three other sees at wells for Somersete /
At. kryton for Deuenshyre / And at saint germayn for Cornuayle. Not full long
afterward the sixth see was set at Ramesbury for wytltshire / At last by
commandment of king wiliam conqueror all these sees save wynchestre were
turned and changed out of small towns in to great cytees For shirborn and
Ramesbury were turned in to Salesbury Now to that see is subget barkshire
wiltshire and dorsete. The sea of wells was turned to bathe / thereto now is
subget al Somersete. the sees of kyrton and of cornuayl were changed to exetre
/ thereto is subget / Deuenshire and cormuayl

De Orientalibus episcopis willelmus Capitulum 54
OIt is known that the eeste saxons always fro the beginning to now were
subget to the Bishop of London But the Prouynce of eeste Angles that
conteyneth Norfolk and suffolk had one Bishop at donwyck The Bishop heete
Felyx and was of burgoyn and was bishop xvij year After him thomas was bishop
five year / After him Boneface xvij / year / Then bysy afterward was ordained

After him unto egbertes time king of westsaxons an hundred / xliij / two
bisshops rewled that / prouynce. one at donwyck and another at elyngham /
Netheles after ludecans time king of mercia left and was only one see at
elyngham unto the / fyfth / year of wiliam conqueror when herfastus the /
xxiij bishop of the estrene changed his See to Tetford. And his successor

Read. the sea of ely that is nygh thereto the first king harry ordained the ix

De Episcopis merciorum^ Willelmus / Capitulum 55
HEre take heed that as the Kingdom of Mercia was always grettest for the time
so it was deled in moo Bisshopryches and specially by great heart of king Offa
/ which was forty year king of mercia. he changed tharchebisshops see fro
caunterbury to lychefeld by assent of Adryan the pope. then the prouynce of
mercia and of lyndefar in the first beginning of her cristendom in king
wulfrans time had one bishop at lychefeld the first bishop that was there
heet dwyna the second heet Celath / and were both Scotts After hem the
thyrdde Trumpher / the fourth germuannus. The fyfthe Chedde / but in Edelfredes

five bisshops in the province of Mercia And so he ordained bosel at wyrcetre^
cud wyn at lychefeld / the forseyd sexwulf at chestre^ Edelwyn at lindesey at
Cite Sydenia And he took eata monk of the Abbay of hilde at whytby^ and made
him bishop of dorchestre besides Oxenford Tho this dorchestre heet dorkyng.
And so the sea of that longed to west Saxon in saint byrynes time longed to
Mercia from theodorus the archebisshops time Also when Ethelred king of Mercia
had destroyed kent. This Bishop Sexwulf took pyctas bishop of Rochestre that
come out of kent and made him first bishop of herford^ At last when Sexwulf
was deed hedda was bishop of lychefeld after him and wylfred flemed out of

/ And so hedda held both the bisshopryches of lychfeld and of chestre. after

lyndeffar while his life dured

Capitulum 57
THe Archibisshop of caunterbury has under him ^xiij bisshops in englo^d^ and
^iiij / in wales / he has rochestr^ under him and that see has under him a

has under him somerseteshire allone. wyrcetre has under him gloucetreshire

constrayne to gad^e a Counseyl of Clergy /

The prymate of york is holden with his Suffrygans for to be there and for to

DA quot quando et quibus inhabita ta ^it gentibus Capitulum 58
BRitons dwelled first in this Ilond the.xviij year year of Hely the prophet
the xj year of Siluius postumus king of latyns / xliij year aftir the taking of
Troy to fore the buyldyng of Rome four honderd and xxxij year Beda libro
primo^ They come hither and took her course from armorik that now is that other
brytayn / they held long time the south contreyes of the ylond / Hit befell
afterward in vaspasianus time duke of Rome that the Pyctes shipped out of
Scicia in to Occean and were driven about with the wind and entered in to the
north costs of Irlond and fond there Scotts and prayed to have a place to
dwell in / and might none get / For Irlond as Scotts said might not
sustain both people Scotts sent the pyctes to the northsides of brytayn. And
behight hem help against the Brytons that were their enemies if they would arise

And took hem wives of her daughters upon such a condition if doubt fylle^
who should have right for to be king they should rather chese hem a king of
the mother side than of the faders side / of the women kyn rather than of the
men kind Ganfr In vaspasiane themperours time when marius aruiragus sone was
king of Britons / One Roderik king of pyctes came out of Scicia and* began to
destroy Scotland / then marius the king slew this Roderick. And yaf the
north party of Scotland that heet Cathenesia to the men that were come with
rotherik and were overcome by him for to dwell Inn / but these men had none
wives ne none might have of the nation of brytons. therefore they saylled in to
Irlond and took to their wives prysshmens daughters by that covenant that the
Mother blood should be put to fore in succession of heritage. Gir. c / 17.
Netheles syrinus super virgiliu^ seith that pyctes ben agatyrses that had sum
dwelling place about the waters of scicia / and they ben called pyctes of
peyntyng and smytyng of wounds that been seen on her bodies / For they had
much flewme and were often boxed and beat blood and had many wounds seen on
her body So that they seemed as men were peynted with wounds / therefore they
were called pyctes as peynted men These men and the goths ben al one people.
For when maximus the tyrant was went out of Brytayn in to France for to
occupye thempyre^ Then Gracianus and valentinianus that were brethren and
felaws of thempyre brought these Goths out of Scicia with great yeftes with
fflaterynge and fair byhestes in to the North own name In king edgards time
kynadyus Alpynus sone was duke and leder of the Scotts and warred in pycte
land and destroyed the pyctes he warred six sithes in Saxon and took all the
land that is bitwene twede and the scotyssh see. with wrong and with strength

De Incolarum Anguis Capitulum 59
AS it is known how many manner people ben in this Ilond there ben also many
langages and tongues. Netheles walsh men and scotts that been not meddled with
other nations keep neygh yet their first langage and speche^ but yet tho
scotts that were sometime confederate and dwelled with pyctes draw somewhat
after their speech / But the Flemynges that dwell in the westside of wales
have left her strange speech and speken like to saxons / also englysshmen
though they had fro the beginning three manner speches Southern northern and
myddel speech in the middel of the land as they come of three manner of people
of Germamania. Netheles by commyxtion and medlyng first with dan s and
afterward with normans In many things the countreye langage is appayred / ffor
sum use strange wlaffyng / chyteryng harryng garryng and grisbytyng / this
appayryng of the langage comes of two things / One is by cause that children
that gone to scole learn to speak first english / and than ben co^pellid to
constrew^ her lessons in Frenssh and that have been used syn the norm^ns come in
to England / Also gentilmens childeren ben learned and taught from their yongthe
to speak frenssh / And vplondyssh men will counterfete and likene hem self to
gentilmen and arn besy to sp^ke frensshe for to be more set by. Wherefore it is
said by a common prouerbe^ Jack would be a gentilman if he could speak frensshe.
Treuisa This manner was much used to fore the great deth^ But sith it is
somdele changed For sir Johan cornuayl a master of gramer changed the
techyng in gramer scole and construction of Frenssh in to english. and other
Scoolmaysters use the same way now in the year of our lord / M^iij / C^lx^v.
the / ix year of king Rychard the secund and leave all frenssh in scoles and use
al construction in englissh. where in they have auantage one way^ that is that
they learn the sonner their gramer And in another disauauntage / For now they
learn no ffrenssh ne can none / which is hurt for them that shall pass the sea / And also gentilmen have much left to teache their children to speak
frenssh R Hit seems a great wonder that Englyssmen have so great dyuersyte in
their own langage in sown and in spekyng of it / which is^ all in one ylond^
And the langage of Normandye is comen out of another land / and has one manner
soune among al men that speaks it in england For a man of Kente Southern /
western and northern men speken Frensshe al like in sown and speech. But they
can not speak their englyssh so Treuisa Netheles there is as many diverse manner
of Frensshe in the Royamme of France as is diverse english in the Royamme of
England R Also of the foresaid tongue which is departed in three is great wonder
/. For men of the este with the men of the west acorde better in sownyng of
their speech than men of the north with men of the south / Therefore it is that
men of mercij that been of myddel england as it were partyners with the e^des
understand bet^ the side la^gages northern and sothern than northern and
southern understand either other^ W / de p. li / 3^ All the langages of the
northu^bres and specially at york is so sharp slytyng frotyng and vnshape that
we sothern men may uneath understand that langage I suppose the cause be that
they be nygh to the alyens that speak straungely And also by cause that the
kings of england abide and dwell more in the south countreye than in the
north country. The cause why they abide more in the south country than in the
north country. is by cause that there is better corn* land more people moo
noble cytees. and moo prouffytable hauenes in the south country than in the
north

De gentis huius moribus Gir in itinere. Capitulum^ 60
FOr the manners and the doing of walssmen and of Scotts ben to fore somewhat
declared^ Now I purpose to tell and declare the manners and the conditions of
the medlid people of england / B^t the Flemyngys that been in the weste side of
wales ben now tornyd as they were english by cause they company with
englyssmen / And they be mighty and strong to fight And ben the most enemies
that walshmen have and use marchaundyse and clothyng / And ben full ready to put
hem self to auentures and to peril in the Sea and land by cause of great
wynnyng / And ben sometime ready to goo to the plowe / and sometime to deeds of
arms when place and time axeth It seems of these men a great wonder that in a
boon of a wethers right sholder when the fflesshe isw soden away and not roasted
they know what it have be don / is don and shall be don as it were by a spyryte
of prophecye and a wonderful craft They tell what is don in far countries
tokenes of pees or of war. the state of the Royamme / sleyng of men and
spousebreche such things they declare certainly of tokenes and signs that be
in such a sholdre boon R But thenglissmen that dwellen in england and ben
meddled in the ylond and ben fer fro the places that they spronge of first
tornen to contrary deeds lightly without entysyng of any other men by her own
assente / And so vnesy also full impatient of pees enemy of besynes and full of
slouthe W de pon^ / libro tercio / Seyth that when they have destroyed her
enemies al to ground. then they fight with hem self and sleeth each other as
a voyde^ and an empty stomak wircheth in hit self. R Netheles men of the south
ben esyer and more mylde / than men of the north / For they be more unstable.
more cruel and more vnesy. The myddel men ben somdele parteners with both /
Also they use hem to glotony more than other men and ben more cestlew in mete
and clothyng / me supposes that they took that vice of king hardekunt that
was a dane. For he heete set forth twyes doble mess at dinner and at soper
also these men ben spedeful on horse and a foot. able and ready to all manner
deeds of arms And ben wont to have vyctorye and maystrye in every fight where
no tr^son is walkyng. And ben curious and can well tell deeds and woundres that
they have seen. Also they goo in diverse lands uneath ben any men rycher in
her owen land / or more gracious in fer and in strange lands / They can
better win and get new than keep her owen heritage Therefore it is that they
be spradde so wide and wene that every land is their own. The men ben able to
al manner sleyght and wit But to fore the deed blondryng and hasty And more
wise after the deed And leueth of lightly what they have begone Pol / li / 6.
Therefore Eugenius the pope said that Englyssmen were able to do what ever
they would / and to be set and put to fore all other / ne were that light
wit lettyth. And as Hanybal said that the Romans might not be overcome /
but in her own country So englyssmen^ mow not be overcome in strange lands
but in her owen country they be lightly overcome R These men despysen her own
and praise other mennys / And uneath ben plesyd ner appayd with their own
astate^ what befalls and becomes other men. they will gladly take to hem
self therefore it is that a yeman arayeth him as a squyr / a squire as a knight
A knight as a duke / A duke as a kynge^ yet sum goo about and like to al
manner state and ben in no state. For they that will take every degree be of no
degree For in beryng outward they ben mynstrales and herowdes. In talking gre^e
speke^s / In etyng and drynkyng glotons In gaderyng of catel hucksters and
tauerners. In araaye tormentours / In wynnyngys Argy / In trauayl tantaly In
taking head dedaly. In beds Sardanapaly In chirches mamet^s^ In courts
chonder only in pryuelege of clergy and in prebendis they knowleche hem self
clerkys / Treuisa As. touching the terms of latin as argy tantali dedali
Sardanapali ye must understand hem as the poets feyned of hem / Argus was an
herd and kept beestes. he had an honderd eyes / and argus was also a ship a
shipman and a chapman And so Argus might see before and behind and on every
side Therefore he that is wise and ware and can see that he be not deceived may
be called argus^ And so the Cronyke seyth in plurel numero that Englyssmen ben
Argy / that is to say they see about where as wynnyng is / That other word
tantali the poet feyned that tantalus slow his own sone^ wherefore he is
dampened to perpetuel penaunce^ And he stands always in water up to the neither
lyppe. And has always Ripe apples and noble fruit hangyng down to the over
lyppe / but the fruit ner the water may not come within his mouth^ he is so
hold and stands between mete and drynk and may neither ete ne drynke^ and is
ever an hongred and a thyrst that woe is him a lyue^ by this manner lyknes of
tantalus they that do right naught / there as much thing is to do in every
side ben called tantali / It seems that it is to say in trauayl they be
tantali / For they do right naught thereto / the thyrdde word is dedali. take heed that dedalus was a subtyl and a slye man / And therefore by lykenes they
that been subtyl and slye ben called dedali / the fourth word is Sardanapali Ye
shall understand that Sardanapalus was king of assyryens and was full unchaste
and used him to lie softe^ And by a manner of lykenes of him they that live
unchastly ben y cleped Sardanapaly R But among all English men meddled to
gyders is so great chaungyng and dyuersyte of clothyng and of array and so many
manner and diverse shappes that well nyghe is there any man known by his
clothing and his Array of what someuer degree that he be. thereof prophesied an
holy anchor in king Egelfredes time in this manner Henricus libro sexto
Englyhssmen for as much as they use them to dronkelewnes / to treson and to
rychelesnes of gods hows / First by danes and then by Normans^ and at
thyrdde time by scotts that they hold most wretches and lest worth of all
other^ they shall be ouercome^ then the world shall be so unstable and so
diverse and varyable that the unstableness of thoughts shall be bitokened by
many manner dyuersitees of clothyng

Cao. pio. /
AFter that places and countrees be rekened and descryued of the world wide.
the order of the tale of the storye axeth that beryng and deeds of the world be
also descriued^ But every thing is for somewhat. and that is more^ Treuisa /
Here this auctoryte of the philosophre is to mean. that al thing that is
reasonable and kyndly ordained for another thing / as a mean for to come thereto
and for to save / It is ordeynyng for better thing and more noble than is that
thing that is so ordeynyng. therefore / eeryng^ and sowyng and dongyng of land^
is ordained for to have good corn / And good corn is better than all the other
deel Also medycyne is ordained for heel / and hele is better than the medycyne
/ Also mete and drynk and other things be ordained for the life / And the life
is better and more noble than the mete and drynk. and al other things that be
so ordained for the life R Than sith that the more world is made for the less
as holy write seyth / The more shall serve the lasse^ and now the more world is
descryued in our foresawes in the first book. than is it skillful somdele to
descryue the less world also. from the beginning of his forne dedes^ that it
might be know what manner thing it is. and how great / that is so little / and
does so greet deeds. in the more world that is so great and so huge / And
also the worcher and the maker of al things that has with him shaply resons
of al manner things. when he had made the more world than he made the less /
And thaugh he made him lord of the great world. yet he prynted on him the
likeness of the great world for a man and the world be like in three things /
In length and bread in kyndly disposicion and virtues worchyng

And first though the length of a man's body that is from the soole of the
foot to the top of the heede^ be such six as the bread that is from the one
side of the ribs to the other side and ten so much as the depnesse that is
from the rigge to the womb Netheles Before libro / vij / ca / 18 / seith that
as much space as is bitwene cinct. that is the point that is in the firmament
even ayenste him in the other side of the earth so much is out of the eest in
to the west and so it is in the body of a man that as much as is from the
soole of the foot to the top of the heed / so much is between his twey
longest fyngres ends and he stretche out his arms and hands a brood Also
Before the right capo 17. Seyth that the stature and the mesure of a child
when he is three year old is even half his mesure and his stature that he shall
have when he is of age. if he live so long / the second as we see in the world
so we see in a man / that (...) members and the parties helps and stands
eueryche other in ste^e and byne^meth his woo^ For the over lymmes governs
and yeueth. the neither lymmes bears and serves / the myddle receives and
deleth about the other lymmes / And in the either world if a limme is out of
his own place and entrede to another place / than in his own / anon is great
distourbaunce made as when the air is enclosed within the earth / than therth
quaketh / and when within the clouds than is greet thondryng Also in the body
of a man when the lymmes be writhed out of her own places / or if the humors
be apayrede. than is ache sickness and sorrow Also when the lymmes be well
arrayed and as they should be in shappe color and hew manner quantite
gretenesse and smalnesse meuyng and place than has the man good pees and
quyete and is in good hele and rest The contrary falls and the lymmes be
evil and not ryghtly arrayed / Therefore Plato yafe his dome and said such
ordenaunces and disposicion and shap as a man has in his kyndly members and
lymmes^ such kyndly manners and deeds he foloweth^ also as it is in the parties
of the great world that they be so ordained. and y set that the highest of
the neither kind touch the lowest of the high kynde^ As oystres and
shelfysshe that be as it were lowest in beestes kind passes / but litil the
perfection of life of trees and herbs. For they may not meeue hem but as c^lpes
of the Sea waggeth with the water else they cleuen to the earth / and may
neither see ne here / taste ne smelle but only feel / when they be towched And
the last of the earth touchethe lowest of the water^ And the over most of the
water touches the lowest of the eyer and so upward by degrees anon to the
ouermost heaven Also the highest in bodyly kind that may be cleped skylfully
man's body kyndly and parfytly disposed arecheth to the lowest of the next
ouerkynde that is man's soul that holds the lowest degree of spyrytes and
of goostes that have knowledge and vnderstandyng^ And therefore it is cleped
Oryson as it were the next narche in kind between bodyly and goostly thynges^
By the soul me gooth up from the lowest kind by degrees of knowleche and of
connyng anon to the ouermost knowleche and understanding And when the soul is
all cleene without erthly liking it recheth otherwhyle to holy spirits that
be nothing bodily also man has somewhat common with things that be parties of
the great world ffor gregory in an Omely says that a man has being with stones
living with trees / and herbs / felyng with beestes knowledge and understanding
with angelis. Also in me^nes body seems earth in flesh and boones / water in
blood and in other humors / eyer in the longes: fire in the heart: and is
called homo in latin and antropos in grue. and is as it were a tree turned vpso
dou^ and has an heed with here as it were a root and has arms and thyes as
it were bows Touching the third likeness that is virtuous worchynge we see as
gregory says in an Omelye of the aduent that the world was at beginning
thryuyng and strong for to bring forth childer as it were in youth / and was
full of heel and so fressh and grene and by great riches it was fatt / but now
it is abated with eld and as it were driven toward the death with often and many
diseases: So in a man's youth the body is thryuyng the breast is strong the
nolle is bold / the arms be full / But in his elde the stature boweth and
croketh and stonpeth a down / the bold nolle abateth the breast is driven often
with many sighs and soore^ the breath shorteth and in all the body might and
strength abateth And though there were none other sickness in old men for the
more dele ^^le is sickness Also as we see that in the more world be two
contrary moeuynges / One is kyndely^ by the which the planettes and nether
welkens meoue out of the west in to the est. That other is violent by the
which they be y rauesshed ayeinwarde with the moeuynge of the ouermooste welken
or firmamente out of the Eeste in to the weste So it fares in a man that the
flesh coueyteth ayenste the spyryte ^ and the spyryte against the flesh

For the nether knowleches and wits fight ayenste the reason And yet a man
has common worchyng and suffryng like to many other parties of the more world
For he is slow and heavy as the earth / and fleteth away as the water and
withdraws suddenly as the eyer / and heteth as the ffyre* changes as the moon / Fyghteth and sleeth as mars / coueteth as Marcurius: goth out of kind
as Jupiter / And is cruel as Saturnus Also before libro septimo^ capitulo

noccm^ Seyth that women be sometime turned in to men it is no magel tale but it

Smyrna He saw a maid turned in to a man / the same day that she should have been wedded / Also such one was brought to Rome to the Senators in time of
lasciuius crassus and cassius longinus consuls of Rome and by heste of
dyuynours that tok^ head of weder and of chittryng of birds it was born into a
wild yland. Also titus lyuius speaks of hens that were turned in to cokkes /
And auicenna libro / 8 / de animalibus speaks of an hen that had overcome a
cok in fightyng / and after the fightyng and the victory she rered up the
tail as a cok^ and had anon a spore growyng on the leg and a crest on the
head as it were a cok / Also capitulo ^5^ Trogus seith that in egypt be ^vij^
children born at one birthen / and thies days if two twynnes be borne it is
selde that the mother and the first child live long after the birth and namely
if the one be a knauechild and that other a mayde^ Also^ cao.^ 12. And sometime
a woman conceyueth twey children and is but a lytil time bitwene and so the
childer be afterward borne one after another and be parfihte ynowgh / as it was
of hercules and his brother hispycle / And so it ferde or happend of that woman
that bare two childer^ one like to her husbonde / and that other to the
co^pyner / and of that woman that in the vij / month after her birth in the
second month after she bare twey Children / sum women bear always. maid
children and some always knave children and some always chau^gen and beren sometime
a maid child and sometime a man child some be barayne / and conceive of no man
and some co^ceyue of so^me me^ and of some me^ co^ceyueth not. Also / ca / 13 /
So^me bear children like to hem self and some like to the fader and sum like
to no man. sum bear daughters like to the faders and sum like to hem self
Sum bear childer like to her forfaders Ensample is Nyceus the noble peyntour
at by sancm^ that was borne of a fair mother and went out of kind and had one
hand as a blew man Hugo capitulo malo^ Me says that woman's kind is such /
that she conceyueth children like to things that they see peynted and shape
for the worchyng of the soul while the body is in geetyng of a child se^deth
inward likeness and shape that she sees without and rauess^th the images thereof
as it were to his disposicion / and so they vsen in spain for to bring fair
horses and gentel and hold hem before the mares and in her sight while they
conceive / and they use also to peynt fair culuers or downs in places there
culuers were wont to dwell / And quintilianus defends and excuses a woman
that was accused of spousebreche for she had born ablue man^ And he leyed for
her that such an image was peynted in her bedchambre when she conceived that
child. and ypocras wrote of a woman that should be dampened to the death for she
had borne a fair child that was not like to her self / ne to the fader / but
ypocras made men assaye / And it was found that such an image was peynted in
the fader and mother hedcha^bre / while that child was conceived / and so the
mother was saved. Plius^ li 7 / c / 13. There for in a man be many diuersitees
for swyftnesse of thought and chaungyng of wit in the concepcion emprynteth
in many diverse likeness and shappes^ In other beestes wit is as it were not
chaungeable therefore among hem all the broad is like to the same kind

Capitulum. secundum
OF brodes that be wo^derly shapen me axeth if they come of adam and Noe /
So^me of hem hete. ciclopes and have. but on eye in the forheede / Sum have
both the shap of man and woman and ge^dreth to gider and geteth and co^ceyue
and beren childer as the course comes about / For ones he shall get child. and
he shall eftsoon co^ceyue and goo with child in his time as it goth about /
So^me women conceive at / v. year old^ and live not over eight year. some have
thies without hammes and be wonderly swifte and hete ciopodes for they lie
neuelyng and down right in the somer time and deffenden hem self with the
shadow of her feet from the hete of (...) son whereto we answer and say
that it needs not to trow that there be so many manner mishappen men as men
speken of^ Netheles reason as is y yeuen of wondre shappe children that be
among us such reason men may yeuen of diverse manner people that be wonderly
shapen / For god knows where and when it needs to make any manner thing /
he knows the fayrenesse of al creatures and with what likeness and
vnlykenesse of parties they be meddled to gyders Certainly in our time was a man
borne in the Este that had two bodies unto the myddel of the womb and bynethe
but one But yet for all that we shall trow that be come of Adam / Therefore such
as be wonderly shape owther they be nought^ owther they be no men / owther if
they be men without doubt they come of Adams kind Touching antipodes that men
speaks of and syngeth that they be men in the other side of the earth and her
feet toward ours and her heed yondward and treden hiderward / that may be
trowed by no reason / there is no story that makes us have knowledge / but only
by gessyng of mankind such a tale is found / Though the earth be round al
about and somdele hangyng within the holownesse of heaven / natheles the earth
is not bare in that side / For it is biclypped and closed within the water /
and though it were bare and not so closed^ yet follows not that men should
dwell there / R / But he would meene as marcianus seyth in his astrologye that
the sign capricornus the great makes somer to the antypodes and the cancer
the sign makes to them winter / And that is acompted. beyond the side of
ethyopia blewe men's land / there men tornen well nygh her fete toward men's
feet that dwell about the ylond tile. under the north sterre Treuisa. Here
take heed that the cercle that the son holds his course in by the year is
deled in twelve parties and every party thereof is cleped a sign and every
sign has a propre name / These be the names of the signs. The weder the bole
the twynnes / the crab the lion / the maid the balance. the* scorpion the
archer / the goot the stewe / the fysshe / also twelve months be in the year
and euerych month entered in to a sign as it falls for the month / and so
in march it enters in to the weder in aprile in to the boole / In may in to
the twins in June in to the crabbes and so forth arewe by months and signs
So that in december the son is in the Goote / than marcianus wol mean when he
sees that the goot makes somer to the antipodes that when the son is in the
goote than it is somer with hem But in december it is midwinter moneth^ and
when he sees that the crabbe makes hem winter he meeneth that when the son
is in the crabbe than it is winter with hem. that is June that is midsomer
month and thus it is declared what is to mean the goote makes hem somer and
the crab winter / ysid eth ^l / 11^ Sometime birthes be borne wo^delrly shapen
for to be boodyng and to kennyng of wonders that shall befalle. but than they
live not long^ as in excerses time. king of perse a mare foled a Fox and boded
that the kingdom should be undo / and in the greet king alisa^der in his time
was brought forth a be wo^derly shape^. for the over parties of him were
shape^ as the perties of a man but they were deed / and the nether parties were
shape^ as the parties of dius manner beestes and were alive and beto^ened sodayn
sleing of the king / for the wers perties lived longer than the better Treuisa
Wiliam wait of berkley saw a child with twey hedes and twey nekkes borne and
cristened at mese in Loreyn the year of our lord thousand three honderd.lvj /
that year the king of France was taken at battle of peyters / this child
had twey arms and twey legs as other childer have / and he had the thyrdde
leg growing out above the buttokkis behind and the thyrdde arm between the
twey shulders / Item Isid / li. 11 / capitulo tercio Sometime is grisly and
wonderfully chaungyng of shappes of men in to beestes and is do by words
other by wyccecrafte. so^me has and receives such chaungyng by the same
kind. sum by corrupcion passith and changes in to other kind and so of
calves roted comes bees and of horse roted comes thauers^ therefore ouide says
if thou craft have take arms holowe for the crabbe / Scorpio brings hail to
stynge with kroked^ tail. Au / li / 18^ c sexto. In the matier of wonderful
tornyng changyng and shapyng of men and women it is to hold that fendes and
evil men mow make no kind neither chaung that is made^ Nevertheless Almighty
god suffers likeness of things dyuersly for to seem / so that the fantasy
of a man that gedreth likeness of diverse things in thought and in dreamyng or
sweuenyng when the wits be let and take none head makes to seem likeness
of bodies that is not present also of images and of diverse likeness and
shappes of things that never were made^ and so men wakyng seems that they see
likeness and shap of diverse things and of beestes. as men seem slepyng and
metyng wonderful sweuenes / and seem sometime that they bear meny heavy birtho^s
but and they be birthons fendes bear hem / and so god that demeth rightfully
suffers mankind be often so begyled R Of this matier look within more plainly
after the batayl of Troy

Capitulum tercium
THough man as it is said be like and acorde to the world in two things that
be contained therin^ Netheles in many points of man's condition of his
prerogatyue and his worthynesse he is diverse and unlike to the world

For though man's body were made first of earth / yet it was so couenablie
and so acordyng to the soul that in man's body was euenesse of complexion
acordynge to lymmes rightfulnesse of stature / fayrenesse of shap / and so
should the body be afterward buxome to the soul withouten any rebellion and
bring forth children without any sin and live without any defaute of
strength and be translated and changed in to bliss of heaven withouten deyng
and death. also he should get and conceive children without shame and a woman
should bear children without sorrow and woo / and have mete and drynk without
sweet and trauayl steryng and moeuyng in lymmes withouten any mysfare / and to
all this paradyse was yeuen mankind for to^ dwell in / and woman for to be
man's felawe / paradyse to wonyng place / the tree of life for mete and al
creatures for solace and a^te last god him self for to be man's mede / But
allas that so noble a banyour fell^ so soon. that was erly brought forth / and
put in worship he knew not that he should be like to beestes when he did that
was forbode Fro that day forth the body that is corrupt by sin greueth the
soul The flesh coueyteth ayenste the soul and man's wits torn and
assente lightly to evil A man's oune meynal wits / be his own enemies / so
that al man's life is in temptacion while he lives here in earth. and the
disposipon of the soul rules meynteneth / helps and conforteth the body /
But ayeinward the wretched disposicion of the body distourbeth the soule^ Also
man is ever fayllyng and wayward he may not stydfastly abide / he falls
lightly but he man not lightly arise / Profyt of birth is sorrow and care in
living and man must needs deye Before libro septimo decimo capitulo tercio
decimo^ And thaugh oll other that be made have shelles ryndes skynnes. wolle
here / bristels feders wings owther skals / Man is born without any helyng or
keueryng nakede and bare / anon at his birth. he gynneth for to weep at
beginning like a be but his lymmes fayllen him and may not help him self
but he is febler than any other beeste / he can noon help / he may naught do
of him self but weep with all his might No be has life more brutyl and
vnseker / None has sickness more grievous no^n more lykyng to do otherwise
than he should. none is more cruel Also other beestes lone eueryche other of the
same kind and dwell to gyder and be not cruel / but to beestes of other kind
that be contrary to hem / But man torneth that manner doing up so down / and is
contrary to him self and cruel to other men / and if he may not reche for to
grieve other / then he becomes angry and cruel to him self R And yet to al
thees man has twey myshappes and that rightfully. one is of him self within /
so that he that threw away peace and rest warred within him / in his living he
has neither peace ne rest but war and strif within Another myshap man has
without forth. So that he that would naught be subget to god that is above him
now he feels his underlings rebel to hym^ so that the creatures that were
yeue^ man to solace of brutelnes to susteynyng of comfort to bear up feblenesse
to service and subjection to myron^ and showing of wonders / Now for the
most dele they flee man's sight and his felawship fro his company and
hates his handlyng and will naught of his lordship. and dredeth for to live and
dwell with him

Capitulum / 4
ADam was made of earth in the feld of damask the sixthe day of the world and
brought in to paradyce and sinned the same day and was put out after mydday /
and so he fille out of the state of Innocence. and of wealth in to the valey of
wretchedness and of woo^ Man in his beginning might take well sweet mete in
gods own hows But he desired that he should not and assayed that was forbode.
And fylle out of hye in to low out of light in to derknesse and slyme^ out of
his own la^d and country in to outlawyng / out of his house in to waylynge /
and trouble / Out of fruyts in to w^pyng and woo Out of praysinge in to dole
and sorow^ out of myrthe in to stryf / out of love in to hate. out of joy and
wealth in to pain and ^^ene / out of health and grace in to gilt and sin /
out of pees in to peyn out of homlynesse in to offense and wrath Methos This
Adam the xv^ year of his life bigate cayn that is co^unely called caym and his
sister Calmana Than / xv. year aftir that when adam was^ xxx / year old he gate
Abel and his sister delbora / but Abel was slain and his fader and mother made
dole and sorrow for him an honderd yere^ R^ As hebrews seyth / Adam begat
sees the year of his age an honderd and thryttye. And lived afterward.viij^C /
year / And so Adam lived in all nine honderd year and thyrtty Treuisa There were
three score and ten^ that turned holy writ out of hebrew in to grewe^ And

that is cleped also / Caryatharbe that is to mean the Cite of four that be
patriarchs that be buried there that be adam abraham^ ysac and Jacob Sees
gate enos when he was an honderd year old and fxue and lived after / viij C /
year / but the three score and ten seyen that seth was two honderd year and five
when he begat enos and lived afterward seven honderd year and fyftene^ But the
three score and ten seyen that Enos was nine score year and ten when he gate
caynan and lived afterward seven honderd year and fyftene. Me seyth specially
that Enos cleped first gods name. For upon caas he fond first. words of
prayeng^ Other as hebrews tellen. he first fond images to worship of god for
to wake the slouthe of man's mind in to god almighty. Caynan three score year
old and ten gate malaleel and lived afterward / viij / C year and fourtye^ But
the three score and ten puts an honderd year to fore the seuentye / and
withdraws an honderd afterward Malaleel five and sixty year old gate Iareth

honderd to fore v. and sixtye and withdraws an honderd afterward. Iareth an

/ In this the seuentye acordeth with other: Enoch five and sixty year old
bigate matusale and lived afterward three hon / derd year and held god
almyghtyes way and was translalated and brought in to paradyse / But the

epistle / Me troweth that^ Adam deyed in enokes* time / And as in caymes
childer lameth the seventh was werste^ (...) in sethes children enoch the
seventh from Adam was best

Matussale an honderd year old four score and seven gate lameth / and lyue^d
afterward seven honderd year and tweyne that was unto noes flode / lameth an
honderd year old four score and tweyn gate no^ / and lived afterward five
honderd year four score and ten

Capitulum 5
CAym Adams first son begat enoch / he gate Irad he gate manayel^ he gate
matusale he gate lameth. This lameth took ^wey wives ada Ada and sella and
gatte twey sons on Ada Iabel that was fader of hem that woned in tents and
in pauilons And tubal that was fader of organistres and of harpers

And lameth gate on Sella tubulcam that was a smyth worchyng with hamer and his
sister Noema she fond first weuyng craft Josephus Caym gadred riches
violently by strength / and made men be lechours and thieves and turned sympel
living of men to fyndyng of mesures and weyghtes / he ordained marks and
bounds of feldes and of lands. and bylde a cite and walled it / For he full
soore drad them that he had grieved Ysi libro quinto decimo capitulo secundo Men
were first naked and unarmed not syker against beestes^ nowther ayenste men to
defend and keep hem fro cold and fro heete / than by business of kind wit
/ they bethought them of buyldyng^ therefore they build them small cootes and
cabans and keuerd hem with small twiggis and with reed. that her life might be
the more sauf

Petrus capitulo visesimo septimo / Lameth the seven from Adam and most

first flokkes of beestes and marks to know one from another And departed

much in thaccorde of melodye^ but be was not fynder of the instruments of
musik For they were fond long afterward R Here wysemen tellen that thaugh
tubal used first music for his plesir while he was an herd and kept beestes
for all that was not he that fond firstt the reso^ne of acord in musik by
wightes but Pyctagoras fond that. thereof look within in the thyrdde book of
pytagoras Petrus visesimo septimo capitulo Lameth an Archer but somdele blind
had a yonglyng that led hem while he hunted for play and lykyng owther for
one of beestes skynnes For men ete no flessh before noes flood. And it happed
that he slough caym that loyterd among the busshes and wend that he had been a
wyld be / And for his leder warned him not He slow him also / And therefore
sith that caymes sin was punysshed seuenfold that is in the seventh
generation. For Lameth was the seventh from adam in that line / Lamethes sin
was punysshed seven and seuentye fold for seven and seuentye childer that come
of him were deed in noes flode / outher for many generacions were btywene
Lameth and Criste that paid ransom / Josephus No man shall trow that it is false / that is read of so long living of men that were sometime / for they
lived fair life and had couenable and clean mete and drink Also for blysful
virtues that they used and made hem besye about astrologye and Geometrye that
they might never lerne^ but if they lived six honderd year at lest in^ For
in so long time is the / great year of the sterres fulfilled Petrus Sethes
childer were good men unto the seventh generation / But afterward men mysused
men / and women mysused^ women Then Gods sons take mennis daughters: That
is to. say. Sethes sons took caymes douhters and begat geantes Petrus. 29
And it might be that Incubi such feudes that lie / by women in likeness of

answers and acordeth to the hugeness of body But after noes flood were other
geantes born in ebron and after were other in than a cite of egypt^ and thylke

Of hem come Golyas Josephus That time men wyste as Adam had said / that they

This ship was made somdele to the likeness of man's body in the which the

Capitulum sextum
At last when the water of the flode withdrewe noe went out of the ship the
/ xxvij^ day of the second month that is man^ Than our lord behete and
promised noe / that no such flode should be after that^ And in token of that
couenaunt^ he set his bow in the clouds that is the rain bow Petrus 329
The rain bow is token out of twey domes / Of the dome that was don by water
For me should not dread it. and of the dome that shall be by fuyre for me should
dread it Therefore the bow has twey colors / the utter is wattry for the dome
of watir that is a passed the ynner is fyry for the dome of fire shall be And
holy saints tellen that the rain bow shall not be seyn.xl. year before the day
of dome / Also they sey that it never appeared fro adam to noes flode Also no
rain bow was seen all that time now there flesh ne fyssh eten ne wyn dronken
/ For that time was as were springyng time / and tho was inow and plente of all
helthful things that was afterward changed through sin / But after the flode
mankind had leave to ete flesh and fyssh. that rather ete herbs and rotes
Noe lived after the flood three honderd year and fyftye / And he lived in all
nine honderd year and fyftye / and so deyed and left three sons a live Sem

Capitulum / 7
When men were departed and to shufte or skatred in to diverse lands and
eueryche followed his own lykyng and will while that it seemed that what that
was desired was ynow to no man. Mankind was departed against him self and the
stre^ger party bare down that other / and told more price of Fredo^ than of
sauacion and of heel / So that it was greet wonder of hem that had lever be
lost and spylt than be underlings and servants / And yet by loor of kind
better is be vnderlyng and servant than be put out of life. Therefore by goods
ordenannce it is do that sum men be kings and lords / and sum subgettis
and seruauntis. Isidorus libro 8 ca / 3 / Than men that came of Seem / Noes
first son had the south land from the rysynge of the son anon to the
Fenyces men that so heete These men that come of Sem occupied four honderd
countries and six under seven and twenty langages They that come of cham held
the land by the southe Occean unto the se^ Gadytan three honderd countries
four score and fourten under thrytty langages and tongues / Au. li / 6. They
that come of Iapheth held the lord from the hille that heete mons Taurus in

unto the brytyssh Occean that is the english see^ three honderd contrees under
fyften langages and tonges^ and left each land and people his name of the

changed Names as hem lyked as the grees / o wther for feyrenesse of writing /
Owther for liking of Reders outher for to make her own self the nobley of her

when we will meene that the Troyans be ferful we clepe hem Frigios And if we
will^ meene that they be gentel and Noble we call hem Dardano / If we will
meene that they be strong we call hem Troyans If hardy we clepe hem hectours.

1 The year before the buyldyng of the cite of rome a thousand and three hundred
nynus king of assiriens for couetise to make his lordship great bare out
armure and lived cruel life fyfty year in all asia in war and in battle / and
aroos out of the south and from the reed see and destroyed in the north upon
the sea that heete eusinu^ that stretches fro the river thanay to the ends of
hiberia and armenia / And so this king Nynus overcome men of Scicia barbaryca
that were yet no warriors but stille men and pesible and made hem know
strength and taught hem to live by mannee b^ode that lived before hand with
milk of beestes / And at last he slough Zoroastes king of battryans that
was synder of wytche craft but at last deyde while he besegied a cite that
was turned from him he was hitte with an arowe and so he was slain petrus 36
/ Nynus belus son when his fader was deed had assiria and the Cite Nynyue
and named it after his name And made that Cite Nyniue chyef of his kingdom and
enlarged the cite gretely by three iourneyes^ For nemproth had biforehand
founded that cite and slow also cham that heete zoroastes also king of battria
that wrote the seven sciences in fourten pilers in seven of brass and seven of
brand tyle for to save hem both ayenste fire and water / but Nynus brent his

honderd thousand verses of wytccherafte and democritus made that c^aft more
afterward in ypocras time Petrus 36 Of this nynus mawmetrye began in this manner
When belus was deed his son nynus for to have sum comfort of his sorrow made
an image of his fader and he did that image so great worship and reverence that
he spared al evil doers that fled to that image by ensample of this doing many
men made images to her lyef friends. And so by ensample of belus mawmett come
forth other mawmettis also of belus name come forth the comune names of
mawmettes in diverse langages and tongues For sum men call her mawmett beel.
sum Baal and some baalym. and sum gafe her mawmete a surname and cleped her
name Belphegor and sum belesebub Alexander in mytilog^ Idolatria mametrye Of
the bryngyng forth of mametrye come well nyghe the feynyng of Poetrye For when
Syrophanes of Egypt had an image of his son that was deed That image he
cleped ydolum that is likeness and shappe for likeness of sorrow when he had
made that image in mind of his son that image was gretely worshipped of his
servants / It was refute and socoure to mysdoers as he had y ordeygned

And while he sought help and remedy of sorrow / he found seed and
spryngyng of well more sorrow / for the old error in worship of mawmettes began
to sprede Netheles the same manner doing was. not ordained and comfermed of al
men^ For Philosophers worshipped oo god and yaue him many names for many manner
doings and worchynges / that he worcheth and lives for he yeueth life / felith
for he yeueth feeling Jupiter that is helper For he helps / Also Plato in the
book called Philosophus says: that Poets by cause of wynnyng and of favor
peynted reasons science and might that were granted to the use of living in
many manner shappes: and yaf to eueryche a propre name And so connyng of tillyng
of feldes he cleped cereres: Connyng of tyllyng of vynes he called bachus: and

paynyms cleped gods they were men: And as they bare hem in her life better or

Augustinus de ciuitate dei libro secundo capitulo vndecimo The poet with his
lyppe speaks of three manner of gods: For sum they clepe gods as mars and

full of mede all that sits about foundeth to taste of that horn the last day
of nouembre / And if they find than the horn full it bodeth a good corn year.
And if they fyndr it void or empty / than they make sorrow Crogus libro primo
When nynus was deed his wife Semyramys with her son nynus that heet nynyan
also reigned in this maner^ The woman durst not betake the kingdom to the young
child nowther she durst her self regne openly. Therefore she disguised her self
in the childs lyche the mother for the son a woman instead of the childe^
For either had a small voice and mean of stature Therefore they hid her arms
and her thyes with diverse helynges and her heed with a cap^ And for me should
not say that she had any thing with new manner clothynge^ she hight that her
people should go clothed in the sam^e array. and yet the people use the same
manner clothing Than this woman did many great deeds and when she had over come
the enemy of al enemyes^ than she knowleched what she was and how she had don
than that doing turned her to right greet worship for she overcome ethiopia
blew men land and Inde also And at last she desired her own sone and bade
him for to ligge by her / And he slow her. when he had reigned two and fou^^^
year But her son nynus held him appayed with the trauai^ of his fader and
moder^ and was afterward seld y seye among men and lived and wexe old among
women And his successors kings that come aftir him followed the ensample of
him and yaf answer to the people by messagiers that should goo between RThat
manner doing was used unto king Sardanapalis time

Iacob^ Capitulum duodecimum

This year apis the king argolicus sailled in to Egypt and dyed and was y

ox that was also white specled and tenderly nourysshed and worshipped Hugo

boole^ the Egipcians moeued and stynt upon the earth / but that boole vanysshed

Jupiter Therefore it was a great abhominacion among the egypcians to slay neet or

and began to ere and sow and have corn tylled the rinne Jacob an honderd year
old and seven and forty blessid his childer and yaf to every of them his

in to ebron and buried there in the double grave Petrus. It was the manner of
mysbyleued men for to keep a deed body nine days without oynement and make
sorrow for hem nine days and wasshe the bodies nine days for to wit whether
the soul were apassed or no Afterward they kept the bodies forty days
enoynted But it was the manner of Jews for to keep deed / bodies seven days
without oynement / and afterward thrytty days enoynted Augustinus libro

Ysidorus tercio decimo Also for me redeth that they made images of men goo and

and closed therinne a precious stone and cleped it a nail. ffor as the nail
is closed in the flessh so is such a stone closed in the / metal Hugo capitulo
Annulus Annulus is a ring seid of anus an ers. For sometime thieves and mansleers
when they were taken should bear an ape on her neck and hold her mouth at
apes ers. but this foul usage ceesed and thieves manslers when they were taken
should bear ringes of iron in her fyngers And therefore gentilmen for to have
dyuersite and distinction from such brybours made hem rings of gold or of

and fayrenesse / for in that finger is a vein that stretches to the heart But
Romans had rings of the comune tresory gentilmen had rings and other had
solidi that were hool and sound Free men of blood used rings of gold Fre men
that came of bond men used rings of silver / but bond men used rings of iron
Sometime it was a greet diffamacion for a man to use moo rings than one^

Moses Capitulum 13
AMram was caath son Caath was leuy son. this Amram sixty year old begat

Israel and make hem full grete^ Therefore it was commanded that the men childer
of Israel should be slain when they were born / Petrus / But yet for this the
people multiplied fast and pharao comanded the midwyues of egypt that they

egypcians but he was slyly brought to his own mother and she fed him And when

anon have slain the child / But there was a wyseman and said / that the

capitulo Grecia Augustinus libro octodecimo Jupiter reigned in the Ilond Creta

Allexandre in mith^ Very story says that Saturnus the fader and Jupiter the

there in a place and cleped the place Saturnia after his own name / and after
he cleped it lacium that is his hydyng place / there he taught boystous men to
bylde ere and sow. and set vynes / For before they lived by Ackornes and
dwelled under bows and twigs wouen to geder Also this ordained pannes of
brass / therefore the vplondysshe men hyeld him a god R And though poets mean
that Jupiter gelded Saturnus for he should not get childer to supplante him /
Netheles the history of Rome says that Saturnus gate pycus in Italie^
Allexander in mith Other mighty geantes founded to put out this Iupyter / this
Jupiter was full cruel and destroubled the pees after that his fader was put out
and over come the geantes with gynnes of werre / me feyned that be lightened out
geantes Petrus / Iosue er he dyed hyeld water on the earth before the people in
token of the covenant that was made between god and the people that was that
the people had chosen the sothfaste god Petrus: Mysbyleued men used to held out
and shede. the blood of a sow in token of covenant made Hugo capitulo Fedus
Fedus that is a covenant is said of Feda a sow that is slain as it were to
mean that is blood that breketh the covenant should in that manner be shadde /
Petrus / But the hebrews held out water in token that as the water is all
shadde and naught y left / so he that breketh the covenant should be deed and
al his kyn^ Also men in old time used to arere and enhaunce signs and tokens
that might long dure in mind of covenant of hem that come after ward / And
so sum men arered and enhaunced stones and huples of stones in mind of
couenauntes

Aioth Capitulum ^^

a greet sickness / that was so payneful and soore that he might not endure /
Therefore he threw him self in to a fire and brent him self R Claudyanus libro
