the geant rest him when he was weary

But in the thyrten deed he did on a corsette of dianier and dyed Here take heed that these twelve deeds that be acompted to hercules sowneth the story as
it is told so does the second of the lion and the elleuenth of the boor /
owther it perteneth only to coueryng of thewes / and than the tale is a fable^
but the menynge is full of truth and of sothnesse / So the thyrdde of the
Arpyes and the fourth of taking and the rauesshynge of the golden apples /
Owther it tokeneth and sowneth the storye y meddled with a fable / so does all
his other deeds of these twelve. Also here take heed / It seems that it is not
all one hercules that these twelve deeds be ascrybed to For saint Augustyne de
ciuitate dei li. octodecimo capitulo quarto decimo Seyth that it was another
hercules that these deeds be aretted vnto^ and another hercules that overcome
antheus the geant in wrastlynge / And also Boecius in fine quarti libri de
consolacione tells that same of Antheus among the twelve deeds of hercules /
Also saint Augustyne vbi supra eciam capitulo 19 / Seyth that there were many
hercules And also sampson for his wonder strength / was acounted hercules. And
Frigius dares in his book of the battle of Troy seyth that Jason that wan the
golden flees at Colchos had a surname and was callid Hercules Therefore ouidius
meth terciodecimo says Menia under fur^ and the Troyans under hercules / And
Ouidius octauo meth arretteth the sleyng of the boor of Archadia to meleandrus^
And also septimo meth he ascribes the chasyng of the Arpyes to Boreas sons
that highten Zoas and Calaius^ therefore many wise men tellen that hercules is
the surname of noble men and stalworth that passes other men greetely in
boldness and in strength. and so it seems all by kyndly menynge of that
name for hercules is said of heroes / that is a man and of cleos that is blis as
though hercules were to menyng a blysful man and glorious

Eusebius in Cronyca Aioth Capitulum / 18
IN Aioths time namely in greece fables were founden and me seyth that Isopus
found first fables for highte and enhaunce kyndly sothnesse^ for the pryuyte
of kind should not be despised / therefore kind of things and by diverse manner
of doing he feyned names and worchyng of gods Alcyn in mith And so he feyned
that after the flood men come of stones and of trees / but that was feyned for
the manner of dwelling of men in the old time / for sum went about as they
were beestes Augustinus libro octodecimo capitulo decimo tercio After Iosues
death unto the battle of Troy fables were feyned in grecia As that vlcanus in
great hete and brennyng of lechery with minerua gate Eruconius foted as a dragon
that is a fable and a poets feynyng and saw / But the soth meaning is that
in the Cite Athene was a temple of vlcanus and of minerua in that temple was a
child found byclypped about with a dragon / that bitokened that the child
shield be grete^ and for the child was found in her both temple / therefore
the child was cleped her both son / Also Tritholomus that was born of Fleyng
addres in to nedy lands at heste of Cerreres / and brought them whete it is
a fable^ Also of mynotaurus that a beest^ closed in laborintus ded^lus hows /
And when men went in to that house they were so begyled that they couth not
come out / Also of centaures that were meddled of mankind and of horse kind /
Also of Cerberus the hound of hell that had three heedes / Also of Frix^s and
his sister Elle that were borne of a wether by the air and flewen as foul*
Also of gorgon the strompet that she was heered with addres and turned in to
stones men that bihelde her Also of Bellerefront that he was born of a fleyng
horse with fethres and wings / his horse was called pegasus / Also of Amphion
that he plesed stones and drowe hem to him with swetnesse of his harpyng / Also
of dedalus the carpenter and his son ycarius that made hem wings of feathers
and fley as fowles^ Also of Antheus him slow hercules^ Antheus was the son
of the earth / therefore when he fell down he roos again with more strength
Ysidorus libro vndecimo / Also gereon the geant king of spayn that was slain
of hercules and was descryued in three lykenesses and shappes / It is a fable /
ffor there were three brethren so well acordyng to gedres that it seemed that
they had one soul / one wytt and one will Also the stro^pettes Gorgons
heered as serpents had one eye and turned in to stones men that bihelde them
it is a fable / But there were three sistres al of one fayrenesse. men that
bihelde them they made hem as still and as stydfaste as stones / Also the three
syrenes / that were half maidens half fowls and hadden wings and talentes as
hawks. and one of hem sang that other pyped and the third harped / and drowe
to hem ward Shipman that saylled in the sea in to ship wrake it is a fable /
But there were three hoores that brought men that used hem in to meschyef and
therefore me says that they brought hem in to shipbruche^ Also that me feyneth
that Scilla was a woman byclypped about with heedes of hou^des and with great
berkyng of hounds that is said / for the wawes of that see / Siculus that
flasshith and wasshith upon that rok that is called Scilla makes such manner
noise men that sailleth thereby be so aferd that they wene that the wawes berk
that wasshen on that rokke / So they fenne that the serpent ydra with nine
heedes^ and if one heed were smyten of / than grew up three for one / The sooth
tale is that ydra was sometime a place that wonderly and perilously cast up
water. and if oo water were stopped the water brake-vp in many places and weyes
Hercules saw that and destroyed the swolowe and closed all the weyes /
therefore me feyneth that he destroyed ydra the serpent. persid libro primo
capitulo trisesimo tercio / Fables be said of fando that is spekyng / not for
they be sothe in deed but feyned in spekyng Poets brought in fables for three
skylles^ for liking (...) (...) of talkyng and of fair spekyng. such be the
fables of plantus and of Terencius / and fables that be commonly told. Also for
health and enhauncyng of kind so me seyth that vlcanus halteth for the fire is
never even vlcanus is feyned god of fire So Chymera is feyned a beeste of three
manner shappe^ and kinds and bitokeneth the ages of mankind The first youth of
a man is cruel as a lion The second age of manhood is sharp of sight as a goot
/ owther stynketh by lechery as a goot* The thyrdde age is ^lde and boweth as a
dragon and wastes always and so the fable of ypocentaurus that was feyned
meddled af horse kind and of mankind bitokeneth the swyft passing of man's life
/ Also fables be feyned for derke fair and mystyal spekyng of thewes. As when
me speaks. and feyneth that things that can no reason speak to hem self that
by the tale that is feyned the soth betokenynge be remeoued to that that is
sothly don in dede^ So Orace speaks of the mouse and of the wessylle / And
ysopus and auenet of the Fox and of the wolf and in libro Iudicum of the trees
of lybanus and so speaks demostenes of wolves and hounds feyned for the
delyueraunce of the advocates and lawers R And that is that saint Austyn seyth
in his book de mendacio Fables he says though they have no sothnesse in
hemself^ Netheles they represente and enduce to man's mind sothnesse that
they bitokene and signefye. Augustinus libro tercio capitulo tercio By
auctoryte of the Romans it was affermed that the goddess venus was Eneas
moder^ and that god mars was Romulus fader / But I and so varro byliue it not /
the writer of the stories of Rome that says pryuely it were profitable to
Cyteseyns that strong men and orped trowed that they were bigeten of gods
though it were falls / That in that manner the mennis hertes should be the bolder
and have trust in the lignage of gods and adventure them ^ to the gretter
deeds and do myghtly with the moore boldness in trust of gracious end by
cause they hold them self of the kind of gods Allexander in mith^ Macrobius
super sompnium / Scip^onis Seyth that sum fables be feyned by cause of
lykyng^ such be of menandre and Terencius / and such long^th not to
philosophres And sum fables be feyned by cause / of prouffyt in excitinge and
comfort / in the which fables the matier that me speaks of owther the order
of telling of the thing that is feyned is feynyngly told that is to
understand / do falls is told by another falls / So it fares in esopus fabbes
and in anians fables also / and these fables be not pertynent ne long not to
philosophres Also sometime a soth saw is told by a feyned tale and such were
the feynynges of Esiodus and of Orpheus when they spak of diverse deeds of
kind of gods and such a tale is no fable but a tale like a fable And if
such a tale is told by likeness of foul thing and harlottry than it lengeth
not to philosophres neither to dyuynes / but such as be told by likeness of
fayrenesse and of honest perteyneth to philosophres / So plato feyned that a
knight that was called Er / aroos from death to live and told many things of
the everlasting life of man's soul R And Boece feyned that philosophye appeared
to him in the likeness of amayde / In this manner may a dyuyne use ensamples
manerly in his talkyng and spekyng Pet^us In Aiothis time the latter Appollo
that was laton^es son as the Greeks tell found up the A^te of Phisic and
made harpes R / Netheles ysidorus libro tercio eth Says that ^^rcurius
afterward in Gedeons time put seven strenges to the ha^p that was before
founden and he put to the strenges and streyned hem in this manner / The River
Nylus had be up and biflowed the land / and was ebbed in to the chanel again.
Than lay many beestes deed on the fe^des^ and among other lay a deed snayle /
when this snayle was rooted the senewes were streyn^d within the skin of the
snayles hows and sowned as the wy^de blewe thereon esyly / thereon and softly.
than mercurius took head thereto / and made an harp to the likeness thereof and
gaf it to Orpheus the harper Treuisa I read among the wondres of Inde that
snayles be there so greet and so huge that a man may be herbeured in a snayls
hows Petrus Also that time the forseyd mercurius fo^nde up an Instrument of
musick^ and called it Siringa and is made of reed and of pipes / and ^eete
Siringa by the name of that woman Syrynga that was cadmus wyf^ she went away
from her husbond for love of musik and of melodye / It is uncertain which
Mercurius this was^ whether Mercurius hermes or mercurius Trimegystus the
ph^losopher or the greet Mercurius /

For Josephus speaks of three of the which every was called Mercurius Ysidorus
libro quinto Also that time in grees was found up an Instrument of music
that heete ^horus Petrus Strabus says that that Instrument with twey pipes by
one pipe the eyer goth in / and by that other the sown goth out

Augustinus de ciuitate dei libro / 18. c. 13 / Delbora Capitulum / 19
DElbora that woman was a Prophetisse of the lignage of Effraym / This Delbora
with barache of the lignage of Neptalim ruled the people of Israel forty year
for to reken xx / year in the which Iabyn king of canaan pursued Israel. In

dei vbi supra / About that time dyed Denyse that heete also liber pater. that

at last perseus slough him His golden buryels is yet seen in thessalia
besides Appolyn delphicus in mount pernasus. Myda the rich king reigned that
time in frigia^ Of him poets feined many things. as it is written in mitholog
fulgencij et Alexandri. And Ilius Appolyns son bylde Ilium in Troy

Gedyon Capitulum 20
GEdion that heet Iheroboal was leder of Israel forty year for to reken / viij
/ year that Israel served madyanytes and Amalechites Josephus says that the
cite Tirus was buyld in Gedyons time about two honderd year and forty before

time. and gafe law to the men of Creta That time the strong man theseus Egeus
the kings son of Athene slough mynotaurus in the tournamente. therefore men
of Athene that were trybutarye before were quyttte and free of all trybute
Mynotaurus was a great man of stature. and there with all right mighty and
strong and full delyure in wrastlyng and was king of mynos Bocher / Therefore he
was cleped as it were mynoys taurus that is a bocher. About that time Theseu^
rauesshyd Eleyn and her twey brethere castor and pollux fett her and brought
her agayne^ And took theseus mother and chased theseus out of contray Also me

metal by craft and spyryte closed for to flee about^ Me says also that he made
images that mo^ued hem self / he was the first that departed feet of images a
twynne / for other men joined hem to gyders Ysidorus libro nono This dedalus
had a nenew called perdix and took him to his loer This perdyx was subtle and
connyng of craft and bythought him in his ymagynacion to have sum spedeful
manner of clyuynge of tymbre and took a plate of yren and fyled it and made it
tothed as the rigge boon of a fysshe and than it was a saw / Also this child
bythought him and made the first compass and wrought therewith Therefore his
master dedalus took greet envy to the child and threw him down of an high
tour and brake his neck / therefore Dedalus with his son ycarus at Creta
fleygh and come in to Scicilia and there he made first laborintus otherwise
called a mase Petru^^ ffor dedalus flewe away so swiftly after he had slain his
neuew me feyneth that he flewe with wings as a bird by the air Ysidorus libro
quincodecimo Laborintus is a manner building wonderly buyld / with dangerous
walles^ therein minotaurus was closed if any man went theder in without a clewe
of threde it were full hard to find away out they that opene the yat^s should
here dread full thondryng Hugo capitulo labor

Me gooth a down as it were by a honderd grees or steps there be also in
derknes wonder many diverse wyndynges and tournyngys / and such four be in
this world of such howses One in egypt another in Creta the third in the
ylande lempno and the fourth in ytalye and be so made that vnn^the they may
be destroyed while the world dureth Hugo capitulo Cilleo

When there fell a pestylence among men of Athene for the ^eth of ycarus and
of his daughter Erigen and maidens of Athene were compellyd as it were to
snarles and greues Than they had answer of Appolyn delphycus that the
pestilence might ceese if they sought besyly the bodies of ycarus and of his
daughter Erigen / Than they sought besyly / And when they had long sought
and might nowher find. for to show the devotion and will / that they had
for to seche for to be seen seche besyly in another Elemente that they might
not find in earth men of Athene henge up roopes in the Eyer and men tottred
thereon and moeueth hyder and thither. for they would be seen seche the bodies in
the eyer above the earth / and when men fell of the tottres and were hurt
soore it was ordained among hem that images like to the bodies should be set
in the tottres and meeue and tottre instead of hem that were fallen that game
is cleped ocillum in latin and is componed and made of tweyne of cilleo cilles
that is to meue and os oris that is a mouth for they that tottred so meneth
against men's mouths

Abymalech Thola / Capitulum 21
ABymalech gedeons son born of his concubine was leder in sichem after his
fader three year. And slough his own brethren three score and ten out take one
that were born of diverse wives / That time was the battle of athene between
the lapehites and centaurus / Palefatus libro de Incredibilibus says that
Centaures were noble horse men of thessalia that faught ayenste Thebees men of
thebe in Egypte^ Thola of the lygnage of Isachar was Judge in Israel three and
twenty year / In his fourth year medea went from her husbonde egeus king of
Athene in to the yland colchos there she was born Trogus 43 About that time
Faunus pycus son reigned. in ytalya in his time euandr^ came out of Archadia
and received and took feldes / and the hill mount palatyn / This Faunus had a
wife called Fatua and had often a spyryte of prophecye / therefore yet often they
that have a spyryt of prophecye be cleped fatui. Tho hercules. had slain
Gereon the geant king of spain and ladde his beestes through ytalye in token
of the vyctorye he lay by this Faunus daughter unlawfully and begat Latinus
that reigned afterward in ytalye / Orous li / p. About this year vesores king of
egypt warred first against scites yet first he sent messagers / and willed his
enemies to be subget to his law / and the scites answered / a dull king and
most rich moeueth battle against pore men and nedy namely while it is in
doubt what end the battle shall have / prouffyt comes thereof none but great
open harm and damage and not long after the deed acord with thanswer for they
compellyd the king of egypt for to flee and chaced and spoylled his host and
would have spoiled al egypt had they not be let by watres of the river nylus
/ than in the tornyng again they warred xv year in asia and made asia
tributarij. and her wives sent them word / that but they would come hoome /
they would have children by men of the contreyes about. The mean time among
the scytes twey ryall yonglynges by fraud and by deceyte of the greet werre
were put from home and took with hem greet multitude of people and strength
and werred in the countrees of pontus and capadocie and when they hadden do
greet destruction^ than they were kyld of men of the contrees about / than her
wives ^xyled and wydewes armed hem and took wreche of her husbandis death / and
when they had made pees by strength and by dedes^ of arms they took men of
other lands to lie by hem for to have childeren and slough her own men
childer and kept her maid childer and brent of her right breast. at last
tweyne of these wymen were queen's Mersepia and lampeto and departed her host
and kept and mayntened hem in batel either by her course. Than when they had
overcome a great dele of europa and many cytees of Asia they sent home the
better part of her host with proyes that they had taken / than enemies slough
marsepia the queen and the other women that were left there for to keep Asia /
And her daughter synope reigned after her mother death and gadred a singular joy
of virtue by everlasting chastyte. Men wondered so gretely of this woman that
when hercules had hest of his lord for to war against the queen he gadred all the great strength of the young men of grees and ordained nine long ships
and fell upon the women that were vnwarned for him was lever to stele upon hem
than come up on hem with a battle openly / than when the twey queen's that were
sistres were suddenly overcome hercules yaue menalippa to his sister Anthiopa
and wedded her sister ypolyta to his knight theseus and received the armure of
the queen in price of redemption / At last after Orthia the queen pentasilia
the queen was in the battle of troy and did many greet deeds against the
grekes^

Iair Capitulum 22
IAir of Galaad of the lignage of manasse was Judge of Israel two and twenty
year and had thyrty sons and made hem princes upon.xxx cytees and cleped the
cytees by his own name anoc Iayr that is to say Iayres towns R Sum tellith
that cartage was byld the third year of Iayr. but look in the first book / co.
Africa scilicet munidia. the xvj year of Iair mynoys of Egypt amended armure
ayenste dedalus in Scicilia and was kyld of Cotalus sonnes^ Ysidorus libro
primo. Carmentis nympha otherwise called Nichostrata king latyns mother fond
and brought latin lettres / Ysidorus libro nono The langage of latin was
departed in four The first was under Ianus and Saturnus and was cleped Priske^
/ and latin under king latin And other kings of tuskan / In that langage were
twelve tables of law wreton / Also Romayn that began after kings were made
subget and that langage used plantus and Tullius virgylius and caton / but myxt
langage encreaced after that thempyre increased and was huge After the death of
Iare Israel served the philystyns and ammonytes / xviij year that be acompted
to the years of Iepte that was duc afterward of. Israel

Iepte Capitulum 23
IEpte of galaad of the lygnage of gaad a common woman's son was Judge of
Israel six year / king latin ffamyus son began to regne in ytaly and reigned
there two and thyrty year. Of him the kings of ytaly hadden that name and were
called kings of latyns Ysidorus libro octauo. In this king latyns time was
Sibille Eretrea in her flowers and was callid Erofila and was borne at Babylon*
she warned the greeks that went to Troy that Troy should be destroyed and
that Omerus should write lesynges afterward There were ten Sybyls / and this is
the fyfth in nombre and is put before other The first Sibylla was of Perse the
second of Libia / the third was Delphica in Appolyns temple before the battle
of Troy omerus wrote many of her versis in his books / the.iiij was cimeria
of Italye / the / v / was critria of her is now our speech the vj / was samia
born in the yla^d samos. the vij / was cumana born in campania. she brought.ix
books of torquynus priscus king of romans in the which were written the domes
of rome / the / viij was elesponsia born in a field of troy / me redeth that
she was in king Sirus and in Salons time the / ix / was Frigia / me redeth that
she prophesied in anchisa. the tenth was tiburtina otherwise called albunea /
the books of hem all be worthy preysyng for they wrote much of Crist and also
of pains / R Netheles it seems that saint Augustyne^ li 18 / capitulo 16 /
Will meene that Sibilla Eritrea was in Romulus time and she wrote much of
Criste and that openly as it follows in these versis of hirs / Token of dome
the earth shall of sweet become wete / Out of heaven the king endless shall come to
syghte and that in flesh present for to deem the world. And so forth Sibilla
has many moo versis^ The heed lettres of these versis and of other as they be
written in latin speaks thus Ihesus Cristus gods son savior. Ysidorus
libro quarto Sibilla is a name of office and not of person and is said of Syos
that is god and of beele that is thought / And so Sibille is said as it were a
woman that has gods thought Therefore as a man that prophecyeth is cleped a
prophet / So a woman that prophecyeth is called a Sybylle / under these days
in king latyns time / was the sayllyng made that is called the sayllynge of
Argonantes / that saylynge was cause and occasion of the battle of troy and
began in this manner Trogus libro secundo After Neptunus the successor of
Erutonius the kingdom of Athene fell to Egeus that had geten his son
theseus on his first wyf^ And at last when that wife was deed / he wedded
Medea the kings daughter of Colchos and gate on her medus^ At last medea
dradde her stepsone theseus when he come to age. and took with her her son
medus and went home to her fader in to colchos* after egeus his son theseus
reigned in Athene / he went sometime with hercules and warred and overcome the
amasones^ After theseus his son demephon reigned and halp and assisted the
greeks against the troyans Trogus li / 42 / Than pelias king of poloponens that
is of thessalia dradde lest Jason the noble would war in his land. and put
him out^ Jason was esons son Eson was pelias own brother pelias brought Jason
in wit for to fetch the golden fle^s at colchos and hoped thereby that the
young man should be deed owther f^r long sayllyng in the sea. owther in battle
against strange nations Frigius dares^ Therefore Pelias made Argus ordeyne a well
fair ship couenable to his sayllyng and passage Petrus Of this name Argon
comes this name argonante / Argonante were stalworth young me^ gadred al about
for Iasons viage / than Jason saylled forth with these men and landed first in
frigia / tho laomedon reigned there. Trogus / But Jason was put out of frigia
and come in to colchos and overcome the king and slough his sone egealms and
took the golden flees and lad with him medea the kings dought and made her his
wyf^ netheles aftward he forsook her and put her away But afterward when king
Pelyas son was put out of thessalia Jason recounseylled and took ayene his
wife media with his stepsonne medus and gadred a strong multitude of young men
and went in to Colchos and restored orpedly his wives fader that was put out
of his kingdom and yaue him many cytees to his kingdom / in recompensacion
and amendment of the old wrong Frigius dares / Than Jason when he had
subduyed Colchos he had with him at his prayeng Hercules castor pollux peleus
of Scicia thelamon of Salymina and come in with five ships by night in to
Frigia and slough laomadon the king and destroyed Ilium in troy He rauesshed
hesiona the kings daughter and yaue her to his knight thelamon to wyue for he
was the first that entered in to Troy / there was taken a great proy and Jason
turned ayene with his men When pricimus laomadons oldest sone herd and wist of
all this / he strengthed Ilium that is troy with yates and with walls and began
for to Regne

Abessa / Capitulum 24
ABessa of Bethlem was Judge in Israel seven year in his second year priamus
king of Frigia that is king of Troy sent Anthenor to the greeks and said that
he would gladly for give all trespasses that they had do bifore^ if they would
send again his sister hesiona that they had rauesshyd / The greeks would not
priamus arrayed for the bataylle and made his oldest son hector leder of other
men / Alysaunder that heet paris also hectors brother assenteth herto and says
/ that when he hunted sometime in the wood called Ida / he slept and dremed
that mercurius brought before him Juno venus and mynerua for he should deem
which of hem were fairest and minerua biheete him wisdom / Juno worship and
venus behete him the fareyst wife of the world if he would deem that she were
the fairest / helenus the other brother prophesied the contrary and said that if
that alisander that heet paris took a wif of greece / the greeks would come and
destroy yliu^ that is troy^ that woman cassandra prophesied the same netheles
ships were arrayed and paris with Anthenor were sent in to greece and when the
men came in to the Island Citheria to the feste of Juno helena king menelaus
wife came for to see the fayrenes of Paris and paris rauesshyd her and took her
with him in to Troy Than was Priamus glad ynow wenyng thereby recover his sister
hesiona / Than menelaus king of lacedomonia made greet and grievous playnte to
his brother agamenon king of mescenes of the rauesshynge of his wife / and
gadred passing strong men Achylle Patroclus vlyxes Ajax Nestor with other
stalworth men seven and forty and had ships ready in the haven in nombre a
thousand and two honderd and had answer of Appolyn Delphicus / that Ilium
that is troy should be destroyed in the tenth year The greeks took up their
ankres and saylled on the sea and took great proyes and turned home ayene

In the mean time Agamenon sent messagers vlixes and Dyomedes to king pryam to
wytt if he would yield up heleyn. and send her home again Pryam bythought him
and had anon in mind the wrong of the Argonantes. the death of his fader
the rauesshynge of his sister / the despysyng of his messager Anthenor^
therefore he forsook pees / and ordained for the war

Than when the hooste was gadred on either side / Hector slough Protheselaus /
and slough and felled to the ground many men til that this Cosyn Esiona son
Ajax The lamomus knowleched kynrede between hem / and so let him of his rees
The mean time trewes was taken for two yere^ that they might burye her men that
were slain but after two year they received a strong batail in the which
batail^ hector slough.x / stalworth dukis and achilles on the other side slough
/ iiij. stalworth men and noble / and the battle dured four score days
continuelly in hard fyghtyng and strong. and after that was trewes taken for
three year and after that trewes they received and appointed to fight. and
slough many men on either side. And andromach hectors wife warned hector by her
dream that he should not that day wend in to the battle Netheles Hector went
to bataylle and was slain of achilles / And when Hector was buried were trewes
taken for an year And when Hectors mind day was holden. Achilles was there at
and loved right hertely policena king priamus daughter and axed to have her to
wife and withdrewe him from the bataylle^ and said that it was evil done to
destrouble al Europa for the rauesshynge of Eleyne. But at. last he went
forth at prayer of the Greeks and was wounded of Troylus that had slain
many Greeks. therefore he was angrye and wroth and slough Troylus and menon also
Than was Hecuba wonder wroth Priamus wife and bythought her of gyle and set
Achylles a day when he should come and fetch home his wife polixena that was
her own daughter. and when the day was comen alysandre otherwise called paris
slough Achilles gylefully. therefore they had answer of gods that the greeks
should have the vyctorye by achilles lignage Neoptholonius Achilles sone went
forth in to batayll^ in the which battle Paris and Ajax were wounded to death
either of other Then the seventh year of the siege came pantasilea queen of
Amosons in help and socour of the troyans and brake the siege of the Greeks
and brent many of their ships / Netheles she was slain of Neoptholomus that
she had wounded^ After that Antenor and eneas counseilled for to deliver
heleyne / and for to desire peace. Priamus took great indignacion of their
counseylle and said they should dye. if ever they were so wood to counseylle
that eftsoon / Therefore they took great indygnacion and sent Polidamas to the
greeks and proferd to bitray the cite for her own sauacion / The greeks
granted peace to these three to Anthenor eneas and polidamas / and to all their
retinue. and the cite was opened by night to the greeks / Than pryamus fled
to thautres of their gods and neoptholomus pursued him and slough him Eneas
hid polixena at his own fader Anchises at prayer of helene. andramach had
fredom granted to seek polixena and was long sought and at last found and
slain of neoptholomus at her fader tomb Eneas for he had hid polixena was y
hot to be a goo. The land was left to Anthenor / heleyn went home ayene with
menelaus This siege of troy dured ten year and six months and were slain of
the Troyans er the Cite was bytrayd six honderd thousand three score and sixtene
/ And when the cite was bytraid three score and echten thousand / were slain /
Than Eneas went out of country with four and twenty ships and with him
three thousand men and three honderd^ and with Anthenor three thousand with
Andromach and elenus two thousand

Aylon Abdon Capitulum 25
AYlon of the lygnage of Zabulon was Judge of Israel ten yere^ Netheles the
seventy acounten him not / and therefore Eusebius acounteth his years with the
years of Iosue of samuel and of saul for the scripture spekyth not of their
years / Netheles they set moo years than be founden by Josephus So that from
the going out of egypt unto Salamons temple were four honderd year and four
score Abdon that heet labdon also was Judge of Israel echt year in his third
year Troy was taken echt honderd year and four and forty after abraham's birth
three honderd year and forty after the going out of egypt the year of king
latin in ytaly / xxv^ before the byldyng of Rome four honderd year and two and
twenty Augustinus ^18 / capitulo ^16 After that Troy was destroyed^ yet while
king latin reigned in ytalye / the greeks that turned again and hadden in the
way many myshappes / For varro libro tercio de historia says that diomedes
were turned in to fowls and dyomedes was no more seen^ So that he was holden a
god / his temple is solemn in the Island dyomedia not fer fro mount Gargan in
Apulia / Me says that fowls be / and flee about this temple and serve
wonderly and spring water^ If the greeks or any of the kind of the Greeks
come thither / the birddes make hem good semblaunt and if any other come / they
wound hem with their greet bills / and for to conferme the same / varro
tellyth not a fable lesyng but sothnesse of story of that famous dyuyneresse
sorceresse and wytche / Cirte that transfourmed vlyxes felaws in to beestes /
And of the Archades that by lo^t swam over a p^ole and than were turned in to
wolves and lived with wild beestes^ and if they ete there no man's flesh
they should after nine year swymme home over the poole. and turn ayene in to
shap of mankind / He says also that demenetus when he had tasted of the
sacrifice of Archad was turned in to a wolf / and after nine year he was
restored ayene to his own shappe of mankind and used afterward geantes deeds
/ and had the maystrye in a tornyng of Olimpe Before libro sextodecimo
capitulo vysesimo secundo That men be transformed in to wolves / and often in to
her own shappe we trow it be falls / Netheles Auctours of Greece tellen that
Archades were led to a pool in the same land and henge her clothes on an
ooke and swam over the poole and in wilderness turned in to wolves and dwelled
nine year among wolves / And if they kept hem all that time and ete no man's
flessh^ they should swymme home again and take her own clothes and her own
shappe. and be nine year older than they were when they went out / but there is
no lesing so greet but it may be confermed Augustinus libro / 18 / capitulo.16
Than what shall we say to all this sayngys / Certeynly when we were in ytalye
we herd ynowe of women hostelers of that land that used to give chese that was
bywytched to men that trauaylled by the way and anon the men turned in to
beestes and bare heavy charges and hadden kyndly wit and reason / and when
they had done her service they turned ayene in to their own shappe / Also
epuleus in his book seyth that so it happed him self that he took such venym
and had his wit and reason and was made an ass R Willelmus de regibus libro
secundo Tellith such doing of tweyn wytches or encha^teresses / that dwellid in
the high wey to Romeward And if any gest come allone they turned him in to a
be and so come by them aminstrele that couth much mirth and they
transformed him to an ass and sold him to a rich man for a greet some of
money. netheles with such warnyng that he should never pass water and his
warden kept hem besily long time Netheles in passing of time he took less
head to his Ass and escaped to water and turned ayene to shap of mankind /
the warden of the Ass followed after and axed after his ass of every man that
he met / And he that had been an Ass. and was turned to a man ayene said
that he had been an ass and was bycome^ aman / and his warden led him to his
lord and the lord ledd them both to leon the pope and the old wytches were
co^uyct before the pope and knowleched the deed the pope douted of this thing
and petrus damianus a co^nyng man of letture confermed the manner doing by
ensample of Simon magus that turned Faustinus in to his own shappe and made
his own childer dread him full soore Augustinus vbi supra / It is to be bileuyd
that fendes may naught do but at gods suffrance and so they may make no
man kind neither transform ne chaungebodyes / Netheles it seems semtyme that
they change likeness and shap of things that God made and wrought^ So that
the fantasye of a man that changes in thought and in metyng of dreams by
diverse manner things and takes the likeness of bodies with a wonder swyftnesse
though no body be presente^ when the wits of the body be absente and let of
their worchynge and the image and lykenes that is in thought and in fantasy is
as it were emprynted in the likeness of so^me be and semyth to other me^nes
wits in the same likeness / And so a man may seem to him self such as he
seems in metyng of sweuenes and so him may seem that he bears berthens and
charges But and they be very berthens and charges fendes bear hem that men
may be so begyled For one presta^cius told that such an hap befelle his
own fader that he took such venym by these in his own hows and lay in a
bed as he were slepyng and no man might him wake but after many days he
awoke and told as it were a sweuen how him was bifalle for him thought that he
was made an horse and bare corn among other beestes to knights that were at
Rethica and it was found right as he told it was done in deed / He said also
that he saw a philosopher at home in his hows. which philosopher expowned to
him many secrets of platoes books which things he had boden him expoune
before and he would not and when me axed of the philosophre. why he would expowne
in an other mannys hows. that he had denied in his own: nay quod he / I did
not so but I met that I did

And in that manner by the image and likeness of fantasye it was showed to that
one waking what that other met in his sleep Therefore that the Orchades
turned in to wolves by wytchecraft of Cirta. me seems it might be in this
manner / Netheles if it were soth but for dyomedes felawes vanysshed suddenly
away and were never after found me troweth that wicked angels took wreeche on
hem and turned hem in to other fowls that were made and brought theder by
craft of men As it is known that an hynde was brought instead of ephigenia
Agamenons daughter and she was ladde away The fowls that at dyomedis temple
that spryngen water and flateren the greeks is by exciting of the devil to
bring men in wit to bileue diomede be made a god and so begyled in
worshipyng of falls gods R Look moore of this matter in the first book capitulo
hibernia / Giraldus in top Fendes and wicked men may not change kind but by
suffraunce of god / they may change likeness and shappe and let men's
wits and begyle men so that thyng^s seem not as they be but by strength of
fantasye and of wytche craft men have semyng by feyned shappes / But it is not
vnsytting that we trow that god as he makes things of naught so he changes
one in to an other for to take rightful wreche / owther for to show his
might or mercy. So he turned Lothes wife in to an image of salt and water in
to wine / owther change the likeness without and leave the kind unchanged
within^

Abdon Capitulum 26
AFter the destruction of Troy eneas with his fader anchises and his soune
ascamus with twelve ships come in to Scicile and there Anchises deyed / than
eneas would have sailled in to Italye but tempeste. droof him in to Affryca /
there he was right well byloued of dydo / the queen / But soon after he forsook
and left dido and came in to Italye R If it be soth that Trogus and papie and
other wise men written this queen dido build Cartage three score year and twelve
before the buyldyng of the cite of Rome^ that was buyld the fourth year of
Achaz king of Judah / Than is it truth that Eneas saw never dydo the queen of
cartage / For eneas was before and dyed three honderd year and more er cartage
was buyld^ And so means and writes saint Austyne primo libro confessionum in
fine / And seyth that wysemen deny that Eneas saw cartage Hugo Capitulo
Elissa / This Dido was called elyssa that is vyrago a manly woman for hap that
fell afterward for she slow her self ma^ly Trogus libro octodecimo At last
this Elyssa Pigmalyons daughter when she should have be compelled of the people
to take an husbond / she went in to a greet fire that she had / made and so she
slough her self manly and was long after worshipped for a goddess Mar Than

reigned in seven hills / these two faught and warred against latin king of
Latins and t^rnus king of Tuscan king latyns daughter husbonde / In that
battle pallas euandres son and turnus were slain R Netheles Trogus libro.43

geder^ took katayll against turnus for the gyleful marriage of ^^uyn / and latin
and turnus were both deed in that bataylle. And eneas afterward was king of
either kingdom of latyns and of Tuscans. And buyld a cite and called it the

son and heete first ascanius by the name of a river in ^^rigia that so heet
and was afterward called Ilus by the name of Ilus king of troy Hugo capitulo
Iulus Afterward when the king of mesenes was slain in a singler bataylle of
stalworth men than ascanyus was cleped Iulus for his ferst springyng of berde
that tho was first seen for the first spryngynge of berde is proprely called
Iulus and is a name of twey sillables by cause of meter R Here take heed that
but the years of Eneas regnyng be acounted within the year of king latin the
acomptyng of this story shall fail for the story says that king latin reigned
two and thyrtty year and specially while eneas when Troy was taken come in to
ytalye the xxv year of king latin as all historyes tellen^ Trogus / 43 li^
Ascanius eneas son began to regne among the latyns and regued.xxxviij /

buyld the cite alban a long upon the river Tiber That cite was heed of that

kings Albanes Reges Albani Eutrop / This Ascanius nonrysshed up full myldly his
brother siluius posthumius^ For he was born of his stepdame lauina after his
faders death and was called posthumus for he was born after that his fader was
buried and was called Syluius for he was nowrysshed in a wode A wode is Silua
in latin. By his name the kings of latyns were afterward called Syluyes

that saylled on the Sea Also that time orestes slough Pirrus of Egypt in

speak of his time old men discorden for sum say that he was an honderd year
sum an honderd year and forty Sum an honderd year and four score^ sum
two honderd year and forty after that Troy was destroyed and sum trow he
was before Troyes destruction Hiderto the book of Iuges liber Iudicum
accompteth three honderd year under twelve Iugges

Hely Samuel Capitulum 27
HEly the priest after Sampson was Judge in Israel / xl year so seyth ysidorus
libro quinto and Josephus libro sexto But the seventy sey that hely was over
the people twenty year In his time fell a greet honger in the land of Israel /
And the storye of Ruth that was of moab felle^ Hectors childer took Ilium that
is troy and put out Anthenores ofsprynge by help of helenuspriamus sone
siluius posthumus eneas and Ascanius his brother geten on his stepdame lauina
was the third king of latyns and began to regne and reigned nine and thyrtty
year in the which year Brutus Siluius son that was ascanius son occupied
bretayne as stories rehersen. It seems that historyes discorden that tell of
this brutus fader for thystorye of brytons says that this brute was siluius
son the which siluius was Ascanius son But thystory of Rome says that
Ascanius gate Julius of which came the meyny familia iulioru^ and makes no
mencio^ of Siluius then if this Julius had twey names and was cleped siluius
also that one of historyes fayllyth / for me says that this brute when he was
fyften year old slough his fader at huntyng and all historyes acorden that
Siluius posthumus was eneas son and not ascanius son and lived long after
vnslayne and reigned also than it is soth that this siluius posthumus was not
brutes fader but upon case for thystory of Rome seyth that ascanius after eneas
death norysshed up tendrely Siluius posthumus / therefore he is acompted his

and bitoke cornewayl to corneus and buyld a Cite and called it Trinouantuin as
it were new troy that cite now is called london and is upon Temse Brute bigate

and twenty year in the yland / The kings of Scicions failled when they had

ysrael twelve year so seyth Josephus libro octauo / Netheles the scripture
speaks not thereof from his time began the times of prophetees tempora

first company of clerks in queres for to singe and than me said that they
prophesied that is to meene they worshipped god besyly Afterward Samuel was Judge
in ysrael under Saul echten year / Lotrinus brutus eldest son began to regne
as it were upon the south see to the River of humbre and named that party of
the ylonde loegria that is england as it is said in the first book in the

after that he had reigned twenty year was slain also in battle that his wife

Saul Capitulum 28
SAul of the lignage of Beniamyn was the first king of Ebrewes and reigned

Petrus / For Saul reigned xviij year while that samuel lived and two year after

siluius is set the fourth and this eneas is set the fyfth but in this place
eneas is set the fourth / The xvij duc of Ath^ne Codrus melautus son began
to regne and reigned one and twenty year after his death kings of athene faylled
Augustinus libro octodecimo capitulo 14 The peloponens men of thessalia
rebelled against them of Athene. Than was answer yeuen of gods / that on
whether side the duc were slain that side should have the maystrye Therefore the
knights were charged over all thing to take good keep of king Codrus^
Netheles Codrus took a pore man's clothyng and a byrthen of Fagottes on his
neck and entered in to the strength of his enemies. and there was stryf arered
among the people and a knight slough hym^ that he had rather wounded with an
hook when it was known that coreus went away without bataylle and the Athenes
were delyuerd / Codrus had lever dye and his men have the maystrye than live
and his men be oue^come After his death the comonte was gouernyd by maystrys for
there was no law but lykyng of lordship unto the time that Salon the noble
maker of laws was chosen Judge Maddan Loctinus son by Gwendolena geten
reigned forty year among the britons and bigate mempricius and maulus / the
Amasons maken war in Asia saul and his childeren ben slain in the hill mount
Gelboe and so ends the third age of the world from the birth of Abraham to
the kingdom of dauyd Ysidorus libro quinto Seyth that the third age of the
world conteyneth nine honderd and eight and f^urty year by fourtene generacions
But either translacion says that the thyrdde age of the world conteyneth nine
honderd year and two and forty R This dyuersyte befalls for ysidorus says
that Samuel and Saul ruled the people forty year Netheles Josephus libro octauo
and the master of the stories acorden that Samuel reuled the people allone

Lybanus / unto the ysope that grows out of the walles^ Also he told much
philosophye of the kind of beestes / He found up also halsyng and coniurisons
for to slake sickness and other for to cast fendes out of men^ that they
combred / Also he found up figu^es and pryntes to be graven in precious stones
that should with the rotes of sum herbs be holden to the nose thrylles of men
that hadden fendes within hem and put out the fendes / This craft was much
used among the hebrews before the coming of crist Therefore Josephus libro
octauo says that he saw Elyazarus the coniurour in presence of Vaspas^an the
Prince helede men that hadden fendes with in hem / in this manner he put a
vessel with water to the man's nose and heet the fend / that he should
ouertorne the vessel when he went oute^ and so it was done / Also Salamon. to
find a spedeful craft for to cleanse and cleue stones / he enclosed a struction
bird in a glass and the struction brought a worm that heete Thamyr out of
wilderness and touched the glass about with the blood of that worm / and so
brak the glass and delyuerd his bird Than the first year of salamon was the
outgoing of that nation Ionica of Lacedemonea Omerus was in that passinge^
Ionica is a nation of greeks The fourth year of Salamon the second month that
was four honderd and four score year after the going out of Egypt salamon

chirch and the viij year the temple was hallowed and had in length an C cubits
and xx / in bread three score and in heyght xxx / In this temple was so much
gold that when the romans set it on fire there ran a streme of gold of

of Saba come for to here the wisdom of Salamon Petrus Me says this queue
saw a tree in the temple on the which tree / one should be an hanged / and by

Nempricius son was the sixth king of brytons and reigned sixty year / this man

Amasias Capitulum 31
AMasias Ioas sone reigned in judah xxix yer aft him the kingdom of Judah was
without king xiij year. Petrus. upon caas me says yt the kingdom was void so
long For amasias departed the kingdom while he was a live / and his son a

fader amasias was deed his son Ozias was but xvj year old when he began to
regne / R. These xiij year in the which me says that the kingdom of Judah was
without king sum stories acompteth hem not other acompte hem among the xxix

to be skylfully scars or mesurable that the trauaylle of knygthode be not

enherytaunce of lands should make hem al like mighty and strong Her

drynk^ He bade that childer of fourtene year he should not use hem in chepynge
ne in feyres / but in feldes unto they come to man's age. Nothing should be
sprad under them when they should sleep they should lyuewith out delicious mete
/ maide^s should be wedded without endowing or yeftes for to constrayne wedlok
the faster when no wedlock were bound with bridels of endowyng He ordained
that oldmen should be more worshipped than rich / he ordained no thing to be
holden of other men but as they would hold it hem self / And for his cite that
was out of good reule and out of good living should the rather come to rule and
receive the lawe^ he feyned that appolyn was fynder of this law / And for he
would that this law should last evermore / he bond the people by oath and made
hem hem swear not to change this law til he came ayene / And feyned him that
he would goo to Appolyn delphicus and axe counsel of him if ought should be

The fyftenth of Latyns Amilius procas younger son reigned three and forty year
but his years be acompted with his broders munitors years Munitor procas sone
was put out of his kingdom by his own brother amulius and lived in his own

no child was chosen to be a maid in the temple of the goddess vesca And the

But faustulus the heord espied this doing and took away the childer from the

feldes Than when the the childer come to age and hadden wytt and strength they

and brought him to munitor for he should punyssh him as a thef that had stolen
his beestes And when munitor took head of the shap of the child he aduysed him
long and bythought him how his daughter childer were laid sometime in the wode
Than in the mean time come fastulus the herd and brought with him Romulus
Then after when munitor knew that the childeren were his daughter sons he
and the childeren intended to slay his brother Amulius Eutr Faustulus the heorde
that kept the kings beestes fond twey lytil brethren leyde by the brynke of

her fayrenes and concupysce^ce of her disordinate lust she was called lupa in

gadred to hem many heerdes and thieves and slough amulus upon the River Alba and
restored her grauntsir munitor to his kingdom ayene Martinus^ Netheles whether
that woman was called lupa or no the old writing in marble and in other stones

a woluesse is lupa in latin Zacharias Ieroboams son regnede in israel sex

ysidorus and the seventy written iiij^ / C / and four and forty year After the

ends from the beginning of the kingdom of david to this taking of
Iheru^salem and of the Jews that is cleped the transmygracion This

days. by sextene generacions / Netheles matthew by cause of sum prive meaning
sets fourten generacions but ysidorus and the seue^ty tellen that this age
contained four honderd year four score and three And in case this discordyng of
years happeth for the common translacion says that Amon reigned two year and
sum seyne that he reigned xij year Therefore if the xiij year that the kingdom

Capitulum 3
Balthazar reigned in caldea and in Babyloyne in his first year daniel saw his
iiij sight of the iiij wyndes in the sea that is four angels of the four
beestes. Of the lion the bear the pardus and the boor that is of the four chief
kyngdoms of the world and of the ten horns that is of the other ten small
kyngedoms that sprang out of the fourth beeste^ and should be subdued of a
little horn that is Antecrist Petrus 163 This antecriste unworthy of the
lygnage of dan. shall be borne of the seed of fader and of mother in a derke place
of Babylone and after that he is conceyned an evil spyryte shall light in to his
moders womb and by virtue of him the child shall afterward be yned born and
waxen and be cleped the child of loss dr of lesyng And three of the first ten
horns be smyten of his face that is to say he shall slay first three kings of
thylk ten the king of Africa the king of Egypt and the king of ethyopia and
then the other seven kings shall yield them to that falls vyctour antecrist^ He
shall have wonder wit and conning for by wytchecrafte he shall worche wonders
and find tresour that is hidden He shall circumside him and clepe him self
messiah that is cast Jews shall fall to him and he shall build the temple
ayene and set his trone therinne / he shall torn men to him with dread with
yeftes and with wonder works that he shall worche / He shall slay Enoc and hely
he shall grieve god almyghties holy people that shall be bitaken unto his hand
unto the time and times and half a time that is unto a year and two years and
half a yere^

And Remigius seyth that Antecrist shall feyne him deed and arise again But
at last criste shall slay him owther by his own hecst or by service of saint
michael tharchangel And Ieronimus super danielem says that Antecrist shall be
slain in his own tente in the monut of Olyuete where crist ascended in to
heaven And Remygius says that crist shall not come unto the dome till Antecrist
be slain but men that shall be saved shall have fyf and forty days for to do
penau^ce^ Therefore take heed that though it be written in mathewe and in marc. 13
/ that no man knows that hour but the fader allone / yet gods son
knows itfor he is the same god that is the fader. But therefore it is said
that he knows it not for he makes not us know it that be his lymmes and
holy church her in earth It is not spedeful to us to know that day Austyn in
glosa says / The last day is unknown to us for we sholden bewar of all and
so we shulden live always as though we sholden be demed to day^ or to morrow
Trogus libro secundo About that time at Athene after the death of salon the wise

Anthyochus epyphanus come of one of the four horns for he come of Selencus

and warred in the kingdom and defowled the temple. The sixth sight of daniel
was when Balthazar with his concubynes drank of the vessel of the temple of

krought out of Iherusalem^ Balthazar saw an hand write before him on the wall

And the same year befelle the echt auision of danyel for the Angel gabryel

So that one weke contained seven year And he said short wekes For we should
understand years of the moon / and not of the son For a year of the moon is
shorter by xj days than an year of the son Treuisa A year of the son is
from a day of the year to the same another year but an year of the moon is from
pryme in a monethe of the year to^ the first prime in the same month of
another year and that will be enleuen days rather in the second year than in
the first year / Ensample when pryme goth by one than fallyth the pryme the
three and twenty day of January and the next year after it shall fall the xij
day of January. And that is enleuen days rather Than it sueth in thistory /
Than seventy wekes of years of the son makes four honderd year four score
and ten / Beda rekeneth this seventy wekes of years of the Moon from the twenty
year of Artaxzerses the king that year neomyas had leave and bylde the temple
unto the xviij year of Tiberius cezar / that year crist suffered death Affrycanns
history acordeth with bid touching the beginning but he ends the seventy
wekes in the xv year of Tiberius Caesar in that year crist was baptized.

Capitulum quartum
AFter the death of darius of media that was made assuerus either Astiages son
Cirus held the hole kingdom of the Este and set his see in percia though the
kingdom of Media were more worshipful for the men of Percia had auaunced him
to be king / This Cyrus was darius sister son and Astyages daughter son^
Trogus libro primo Astiages otherwise called assuerus had but one daughter and
he met in hes sleep that a vine sprange out of his daughters prive chose /
and byspradde al^ Asia Than dreeme reders expowned this swe^^ and said that
his daughter should have a child that should be lord of asia and put him out of
it Than the king drad and yaue his daughter to a simple knight that was pryuely
born for his daughter should bear no noble child / And also when his daughter
was with child he took her to him and when the. child was borne. he betoke it
to one Arpagus that was his secretary for he should slay the child. And he
trowed that the kingdom should sometime fall to the kings daughter / and
bitoke the child to an heerd that kept the kings beestes / and commanded him to
ley the child in a wood there to be devoured / And when the heerde had leyde
the child in the wood he told his wife thereof which was lyghter of child the
same time and she prayed that he would fette the child to her and she would
nowrysshe him and that he would leye her own son in the wood for him / And
when the herd came to the child he found a bytche yeuyng it sowke and kept it
from beestes and fowls Petrus 173 And when the child was brought to the herdes
wife / it made to her good semblaunt as though it had known her / and she named
the child spartatus that is a welpe in the langage of perse And when the child
was of age and strength and that he couth goo about and play with childer his
play feres called him Cyrus and made him her king in plays and he chastysede
soore them that were rebel to his heestes wherefore the fader of the child^e
were aggreued and compleyned to king Astyages on the heerdes son. than the
king sent after the child. and axed why he ferd so with the childer. he
answered boldly and said that he did so as a king should The king wondered that
the child was so bold and so stydfast and took head that the child had signs
and tokenes of a king / and he took the herd a side pryuely and learned the
soth all how it stood Netheles the dread of his neuew was aslaked for he trowed
that the meaning of his dreme reders was^ fulfilled in the kingdom of childer
Therefore to the same man Arpagus^ to whoome he had rather bytake the child
to slay he bytoke tho him to nouryssh and to feed / and told him that that
child was the herdes sone^ but he made arpagus privily ete his own child / for
he had broken his heeste and when he he ha d eten his child than he told him al
/ It befell that astiages made this Arpagus leder of his host for to werre
against his enemies of perse and the king left him self in media Than Arpagus
bythought him and had in mind of that evil deed that the king had done him
and conseyled thoost to chese cyrus and make him the king of Perses and than
they cleped hem Cyrus as they would mean though astyages strive this shall be
heir Trogus libro primo In the mean time Arpagus sent a letter to Cyrus that
he should have mind how he sauede him and lost h^s own child for love of him
Arpagus might not send this letter openly for the king. therefore he took out
the bowels of an hare and put the letter within the hare. and for the fraud
should not be known he sent it on a day as it were veneson And when the letter
was read. Cirus was warned in his sleep that the first man that he met erly
on the morrow he should take him with him on his wey / Than erly on morrow he
met one Sebar that was escaped out of prison and was borne in Perse / He
did of his gyues and ladde him with him to persipol there he gadred the people
and bade hem hew down a greet wode and made hem a greet feast a morrow / And
when he saw them mury and well at ease with mete and drink he axed hem whether
hem were lever the trauayll of the rather daye^ owther the feeste of that day
Than Cyrus said who that follows the medes he shall have the trauaylle of
yist^rdaye and they that follow me shall have such feestes / Than anon he
arrayed hem to battle against Astyages Petrus 173 / Than Astiages drad soore and
made his cosyn darius to be his son adoptiuus. and when the bataylls came to
geder and began to fight cyrus and perses began for to flee. than her wives and
her moders came fast against hem and showed hem her pryuee chooses and axed of
hem wol ye crepe in to your moders womb and be born ayene / than the men were
a shamed and turned suddenly ayene and fell on her enemies and hadden the
vyctory Cyrus bare him to astiages as his neuewe after the vyctory. and not as
his vyctor for be granted him the kingdom of hircans while he lived. and he
granted the kyngedome of medes to his ^ame darius as to his mother brother and
hoped that it should torn to him ayene Petrus 174 Cyrus when he had herd ysayas
prophecye that was wryton of him an honderd year and twenty bifore^ in this
manner to my crist whose right hand I have take etc / he delyuerd the Jews the
first year of his kingdom and made free nygh fyfty thousand men and restored
hem the holy vessels of gold / and of silver five thousand and three honderd and
yaue hem leave to goo again and bylde the temple in Iherusalem Aggeus me^ued
hem most thereto that was tho young and not yet a prophet and also Zacharias
the prophet meued him / that blessed salatiels son and cleped him Zorobabel
that is to say master of babylon But for many of hem in caldea and hadden
there possession and wives and children hem was the lother to goo thens and
abyden unto the thyrdde year of Cirus

Capitulum 5
DAnyel prayde. to god for the delyueranre of the people and darius king of
medes the first year of his kingdom purposed to deliver the people but he dyed
sone and he fulfilled it not^ Therefore Cyrus the first year of his kingdom
yafe the Jews the same leave but the people was slow therefore danyel prayed god
that as he had yeuen the king will to deliver the people that he would give the
people will for to wend homeward again Petrus 174 Than the third year of Cyrus
the Jews wenten under Zorobobabel the duk and under Johan the greet preeste
and this was the lxx year of the bondage and taking so seyth Josephus and
Ieroms gloss upon Ezechiel / that time was from the / xiij / year of Josias the
king to the thyrdde year of Cyrus though eusebius in his Cronyque by auctorite
of Zachary the prophet says that the second year of darius itapsis son was
the lxx year of this taking and bondage Netheles it may be determined in this
manner The second year of darius was lxx year of the fyfth age of the world and
of the destroyeng of the temple^ But the thyrdde year of Cyrus was the lxx year
of the first taking that was don the xiij year of Josias the king Than the
Jews went hoome again and leyde the fundament of the temple and the
Samarytans herd thereof and came to hem and asisted hem to build the temple for
they worshipped all one god and had understand moses books The Jews answered
and seyden though we worshipe one god^ netheles it falls not us to byld one
hows / Therefore the samaritans were wroth / and let her werk with suggestions
and with yeftes unto the second year of darius Itapsis son Orosius libro
primo In king Cyrus time Phalaris a tyrant of Scicilia punysshed men often
rightfully / though he were him self unrightful Than one Parilius a crafts
man of bras desired to plese the tyrant and made him a brazen boole with a door
in the riyhtsyde / where men that were damp^d should goo in to the boole for to
be tormented and when they were within and the door closed and fire made there
under the noise and cry of hem that were tormented should pass by diverse
wyndinges and tornynges so that it should seem grisely roryng of booles and of
beestes / and not man's gronyng But Phalaris the tyrant was well apayed with
the deed an^ wroth with the doer and made him first essaye the torment that he
had wickedly brought up to torment other men and punysshed the crafts man by
the craft that he had founden That year befelle that that me redeth of Cresus
the rich king of Liddus: For when Cyrus werred against the babilons Cresus king
of lyddes help the babylons but he was ouercomen and fled / And when the
Babylons were sessed Cyrus took Cresus and did by him great worship. and that
turned to either of them great profit For the strength that come out of
greece to werre against cyrus turned again for the curtosye that was done to
cresus This Cresus had a daughter that hight / Fanatica which had a spyryt
of prophecy / and ever counseylled her fader to leave the war / wherefore
cresus axed counseyll of gods that begyled him with a verse and a word of
double understanding Cyrus alym pass shall / And than kingdoms many lose
Therefore Cresus was rebel against Cyrus and was taken the thyrdde time Petrus 176
Cyrus smote Cresus besides the River Alim and brought the lyddes. that were
noble men of Arms by sleght to wrechednes and sleuth / For when they had
lost her horses and their armure he made hem to use tauernes pleyes iapes and
nyce crafts with common women and strompettis and evil living men / And in this
manner as it were showing love and good will he overcome by liking and lechery
hem that he might not overcome by bataylle / And so the kingdom of lyddes
faylled that had stand two honderd year and one and thyrtty Trogus libro primo
There had be noble kings of lyddes but none so gracious as Candalus that louede
his wife to much by cause of her beautee / and would speak of her and preyse
her to all manner men and at last he shewde her nakede to one Gygy that was
his own felawe / By that deed he made his felawe a spouse breker and his own
enemy And therefore he lost both his kingdom and his wife

Eutropius Capitulum 6
THe seventh and the last king of the Romans had three names Lucius
tarquinus and Superbus / He slough his wives fader Seruius tullius and reigned
five and twenty yere^ This found up first diuse manner torments among the
romans as bands boleyerdes plates battes prysons gyues cheynes out lawyng and
exylyng / he overcome the vultes and the gabyes and made pees with the tuscans
/ Augustinus de ca / li 2 ca 14^ At last he bylde a temple of Jupiter in the
hille carpelus and for they found a man's heed in that place while they^
dug they cleped that place capitolium / wherefore their prophets and dyuynes
told that that place should be heed of the world^ Titus lius / and augus de ci
li^ 1. ca 19^ Sometime while this tarquinus superbus besieged the Cite ardea
that was rebel to Rome / his son tarquinus sextus and lucrecias husbonde
tarquinus collatinus satte at soper and talkede of the chastyte of her wives /
let be quod collatinus^ and let their own deeds preyse our wives / therefore
as it were by assent they came by night to Rome and found lucrecia all one
waking about wol work and other men's wives were a sleep and sum about
gyglotrye^ wherefore Sixtus tarquinus waited his time and was lodged with
lucrecia in gestwyse^ and came upon her while she slepte with his sword drawn
to ligge by her maugre her teth And said but thou suffer me lie by the I shall
put a naked churl deed withthe in bed. and thou shall ligge deed with him also
/ Than when this sextus had done that deed the woman went her wey sorowfully /
and sent to her fader and husband and prayed them to come home out of the
host and informed them the mishappe that her was bifalle^ and they yaue feyth
and credence to her messagier and she took wreche of the deed and slough her
self before hem with a prive knyf that she bar^ R Wysemen here say that
lucrecia here slough not her self for no virtue but for shame and for anger for
neither man ne woman should be punysshed without gylt / neither gylt without
Judge / But for the romans coueyte most praysyng of men and worldly worshipe
This lucrecia had dread if she lived after that deed lest the people would wene
that she were assentyng to the deed / And therefore in token that she was sorry
thereof / in conseruynge her good loos and name and in a voydyng the despyte.
and in example of good women he would no longer live / Of this hap speaks a
dytour or retricion as saint austyn de ci li 1 ca 19 touches tweyn there were
and one brake spousage / Eutr. By cause of this deed the people gadred to geder
/ and put down and deposed his fader^ from his kingdom / and exyled him and

eneidis Euto. libro primo / Than Tarquinus gadred help on every side and warred

that he had no money to burye him with but as it was gadred among the people /

Capitulum 7
CIrus when he had won Asia^ he intended to war ayenste the Schites. there
thanurus the queen of / Shites and messagetes that be al one nation came
ayenste him / Though she might have withstand his enter in to her land and
all her enemies / and have holden hem of at passage of the River Arexes /
Netheles she wylfully suffered them enter to have the esyer fyghtyng within the
land that she knew Also for the River hehynde her enemies should let not them
escape by flight / Cyrus set his pauylon within her land with great plente of
mete and drynk and feyned him to flee^ and withdraw him as it were for dread
The Queen had sent her young son with the thriddele of her host against Cyrus.
and when he come to the deynteous mete and drink he was uncunning of chiualrye
and he and his men were rather ouercomen with dronkenesse. than with deeds of
Arms Than Cyrus came upon him and slough him. when the Queen herd thereof / she
wept not therefore / But for solace and comfort she desired to take wreche /
and begyled Cirus with such a manner gyle She as it were fleyng for her son
that was new wounded drough Cyrus in to a narow valeye between high hills and
slough Cyrus and two honderd thousand of his me^ of pers^ so that not one
escaped to bear home tidings The Queen bade smite of Cyrus heed and throw it
in a fflaket full of man's blood / and despised him in this manner / now fylle
thy self with the blood that have ever desired and thus Cyrus was deed after
that he had reigned nobly and ryally thrytty year and always done great deeds
Petrus 178

Capitulum 8
CAmbyses Cyrus son reigned after his fader / Esdras clepeth him artarxerses
and assuerus / Netheles in the story of judith he is called nabugodonosor In
this cambyses time bifell that is read in thystory of Judith / Trogus 189. And
no wonder though he were so cleped for his own fader Cyrus called him
nabugodonosor and while he was a live he made this cambises that was his own
son to regne twelve year among the Assyryes in nynyue. But at last when
his fader was deed^ he held the hole kingdom of the eest eight year This
cambises suffered not the temple of Iherusalem to be build during all his time
Also the first year of his hole kingdom he slough Arphaxath that would have
reigned in Media / while he would be worshipped instead of god of Israel as he
was ouerall Judith the wydowe slough Olyfernes the prince of his hooste in the
Siege of Bethulia the second year of his empire Than Cambyses the fyfth year of
his kingdom destroyed Egypt / He forsook the vsages thereof and destroyed the
temple and buyld Babylonia in egypt / And when he turned thens / he dyed in
Damask the viij year of his kingdom.

Valerius libro sexto This cambyses made stryke of the skin of a Judge for he
had yeuen falls Iuggement and made hem to sprede and to take / it about the
chair / there as the Judge should sytt in plee for to deem and made that Iugges
son Judge in that place instead of his fader / and made such versus to be
wryton upon the chair sitting on this see / Justice look thou stydfast be /
Keep hand and eke eeres from yeftes and from men's prayers / Take lantern
law / light under skyn to draw / Thou sittist in place yet^ where thy
fornfader was set / Trogus libro primo et Petrus decimo octauo

Capitulum 9
AFter Cambyses one hermeydes that was one of the seven wise men that Rewled
the kingdom of Perses wedded Cambises daughter and made it as though he would
not regne by the title of his wyf^ but as though he would have kept the
kingdom to one Mergus Cambyses brother. that yet was a young childe^ Netheles
cambyses had slain before this mergus within the temple and no man wist
thereof / but this wyseman hermeydes^ After seven months of his kingdom this
Hermeydes lyeng on his death bed and he had a fair yonglyng to brother
ordained him king / and said that that Ionglynge was Mergus Cyrus son and
Cambyses brother. Such hydyng of kings might lightly be done in Perse. For no
man goth in to the kings of Perse but men of meyne / One of the wysemen
began to have suspection of this doing and had a daughter among the
kings concubynes and charged his daughter pryuely^ that she should by night
grope the kings heed and take heed if he had eeres / And when it was known
by the wenche that the king had none eeres^ the vij. wise men conspyred to
geder and slough him / and so these two brethren reigned scarsely one yer /
tha^ these vij wise me^ treated bitwene hem self which of hem should wedde the
kings dough^ and be king of that kingdom than al they acorded that they should
erly a morrow come in to a place of the palyce before the temple yates and whose
horse neyde first he should be king by the showing of the gods / Than one of
hem darius I^apsis sone spak pryuely with the keeper of his horse and charged him
that he should make his horse assaylle a mare that night in the same place /
where they should come to geders a morrow So it was done and when^ the wysemen
came to geders on the morrow anon darius horse began to neye for he had mind of
the mare and so darius was made king and reigned six and thyrtty year

Capitulum 10
Darius reigned over an honderd and seven and twenty prouynces and Zorobabel
Salatyels son was right famylyer with him and had counseylled him er he
were king. that he should make his auowe to god of Isrl^ that if he were king
he should restore the temple of god and yield the holy vessels again Therefore
Zorobabel began boldly to bylde the temple and Zacharyas and aggeus the
prophets comforted him (...) thereto And said that god was wroth with hem by
cause gods hows was desolate and they dwelled in howses that were well bylde
and sayden that it was a token of gods wrath that they sewe much and gadred
lytil But the Princes of perse that weren beyond the River let the work of
the temple Therefore Zorobabel went to darius and had great worship of him and
slept in his own Chamber Josephus lib^o vndecimo The king put forth a
redels erly a morrow and axed of the three wardens of his body which quod he is
strengest of these thre^ king wine or woman^ And promised him yeftes that gaf
rediest answer The first said that the king is strengest of all for this skylle
for a man is above al beestes and the king is above men and men does al thing
that he commands

The second said that wine is strengest by this reason The king is not above
other men but by strength of his wit and wine ouercometh the strength of
mannys wit Zorobabel said a woman is strenger than either of the tweyne / and
women yeueth life and fedynge to kings and to hem that set vynes. and when
kings be comen to strength they Ieoparde their life for women and he told that
he saw a kings concubyne give the king buffettis And when she lough the
king lough and when she was wroth the king was wroth also Netheles he said
Truth is strenger than all these three For all these be they never so fair so
great and strong they shall pass and fail but sothnes and truth shall never dye
ne change but ever dure^ this sentence plesyd moore all men and the king
granted him the vessels of the temple / and lycenced him to goo and build the
temple and yaue him lettres of warrant that no man should let him Than the
second year of darius ytapsis the eicht month the werk men wrought for to
bylde the temple and fulfilled it the seventh year that was the six and forty
year of the kingdom of perses from the first year of Cyrus / when they had
leave to build the temple ^ And so it is sothe that is said in the gospel in
six and forty year this temple was bylde When the temple was byld it was
hallowed the twelve month that is in march And this is the second halowing of
the temple and was done in march Netheles the first halowiyng in Salamons time
was done in heruest The thyrdde was done in winter in Judas Machabeus time
Petrus 182 Also this year the fire that was taken away of the Altar the first
year of the taking in to bondage and hid in a pytte it was found brennyng /
Of the Shryne of the testament how and when the Jews came there to it is
uncertain

But if it be sothe that epyphanius that the shryne should not come out of the

It was usage and customme among the Romans that w^rriours should werre upon

mayntene and defend hem against the great

Capitulum 11
PIctagoras the philosopher dyed that time. Trogus li / 22 This was of the

the maystrye / Nay said Auallius but learn wise master that by nether way I
shall pay the that thou axist^ for yif it be demed against me than shall I not
pay by dome / and if it be demed against me than shall I not by covenant for I
have not the maystrye Than the Iugges saw that the cause was brygous as it
were an insoluble and continued the sentente of Iuggement to a long day So it

For on that one side was great sorrow to assoylle and in that otherside a cruel

Noes flode Netheles me redeth among the Greeks that Pyctagoras found the craft

Marian^ libro secundo It happed that Pyctagoras passed forth openly and herd

certain order of sown / For the sharp sown acorded to the great and made
the smythes to change hamers / but the same acorde of sownyng followed always
Than he took head that the hamers were of dyuse weight and bade him make greter
hamers And from hamers he tornede him to examyne strenges and streyned guttes^
and senewes of sheep and of beestes fastened to diverse weyghtes such weyghtes
as he founden in the hamer and had such song and acorde as the rather
acordynge of hamers made with swetnesse of kyndly sown of strenges Than when
he was connyng of so great pryuete he began to find nombres by the which
sownes acorde and so he spedde to make the craft of musik R Therefore Tullius de
tusculis question libro quarto speaks of him and says that Pyctagoras scolers
couth bring her mind out of strif of thoughte^ to rest by song and sown of
strenges Augustinus ep^ h contra Rut / When yonglynges were wyn dronken and
would break the yates of chaste women Pyctagoras bade pipers pipe a song made by
thendytyng of spondeus and when they did so / tho the bestyalyte of moeuyng of
lechery cessed by the sloth of the manner of tewnes^ Seneca libro tercio de
lira Pyctagoras with harp and strenges cessed the distourbance of wits R
Here wise men I tell that Pyctagoras passed sometime by a smythes hows and herd
a sweet sown and acordyng in the smytyng of four hamers upon an anueld and
therefore he let wey the hamers and found that one of the hamers weyed twey
so much as another / Another weyed other half so much as another And another
weyed so much as an other and the third dele of another^ As though the first
hamer were of vjl^^ / the second of twelve / the third of eycht^ the fourth of
nine / As this figure shows / When these acordes were founden Pyctagoras yaf
hem names and so that he cleped in nombre double. he clepede in sownes Dyapason
/ And that he clepeth in nombre other half he clepeth in sownes Dyapente. and
that that in nombre is called al and the third dele hete in sownes dyatesseron
/ and that that in nombres is called al and the eyghteth dele heete in tewnes
double dyapason as in melodye of one strenge if the stryng be streyned endlonge
upon the holownesse of a tree^ and departed even a two by a bridge set there
under in either party of the streng the sown shall be dyapason if the streng be
streyned and touched* And if the string be departed even in three and the
brygge set under / So that it depart between the twey deles and the thyrdde
than the longer dele of the stryng if it be touched shall give a sown called
dyatesseron. And if it be departed in nine and the brigge set under between
the last part and the other dele^ than the longer dele of the streng if it be
touched shall give a sown that hete tonus for nine conteyneth echt and the
eight part of eight as in this figure that follows

Ieronimus contra rufu^ Many of Pyctagoras disciples kept her maistres heestes

Incontynence and hastynesse out of all things Also all that friends have shall

sothnesse shall be worshipped that makes men be next god Ysidorus libro octauo
