Capitulum 12
THe name of philosophres had beginning of Pyctagoras / for old greeks called
him self sophistris that is wise / but Pyctagoras when me axed what man he was
/ he answered and said that he was a Philosopher that is a lover of wit and
of wysedom for to clepe him self a wyseman it would seem great boost and pride /
Afterward other philosophres hadden her names of her auctours And so they that
held pyctagoras loore / were called pyctogoraci^ And they that helden Platoes
loore were cleped platonici Pol^ libro primo Sum philosophres hadden names of
contrees and so they that helden pyctagoras lore were cleped Italya / For
Pyctagoras taught a great contre of Italye / that sometime was called the great
grecia / Other were called Ionyci / that hadden that name of the yonder greece /
their Auctor and prince was tales and millesius Ysidorus libro octauo Other had
names of standing and coming to geders as stoycy^ achademice peripatetici
Stoyci had that name of a porche of Athene called Stoa in the langage of greece
there in was peynted the great beryng and deeds of wisemen. and of strong The
first of hem was yeuen that all sin was like great and thus he meaned that
it were as great sin to stele straw as gold and to slay a knight as an horse
for the beast he said is not to blame but the man's will This Zenon^ said
that man's soul shall dye with the body. Treuisa I would a wyseman had seen
his water / and powered it in his throat though it were a galon^ Than it
follows in the storye he and his scolers said that they should not dure
withouten end and netheles they desired lif withouten end Achademici hadden
that name of platoes town beside a thene called achademia and was in point for
to fallen there plato was wont for to study This trowed al thing was
vncertaynly made / Archelaus brought up that sect but democritus made it more
But it must be granted that many things be unknown and hid fro man's
knowleche. So god will that many things pass the knowleche of man. And also
many things be that may be known by man's kyndly wit / Paripatetici have
that name of wandrynge and of walkyng* for Aristotle was her Auctour and was
wont to dispute wandryng and walkyng^ Augustinus de ciuitate dei libro octauo
There be three manner philosophres of kind and takes head of kind of things
such were^ tales Millesius Pyctagoras and they that held her loore / And
sum ethici that took head and taught the knowleche and conning of good
living and of thewes ^ Such was Socrates and they that held his loore / and
Plato specially and they that held his loore Therefore among all he is preysed
for a parfighte techer of Philosophi^ Ysidorus libro octauo capitulo sexto
Therefore he is a very phisosophre that has knoheleche of things that longs
to god and to man and holds al manner way of rightful living / But of al
manner of Philosophres they that were cleped dyuynes were reputed for most
excellent For they treated of god that is almighty. Netheles many of hem erred
in treatyng of god and of the world And many came to the knowleche of god
netheles they worshipped him not as god / but vanysshede away in her thoughtis
and said that they were wise and they were made fools. The errors of hem
brought in afterward many errors in holy church / Such a falls error is that
deed men shall not rise at the day of dome^ and that every martyr is even and
pere to god Augustinus de ciuitate dei libro octauo / capitulo decimo / They
that had right knowleche of god profyted much to the knowleche of truth and
such was plato that said that in god is cause of being / reason of
understanding and order of good living And therefore god is to us beginning of
kind so^hnes of loore and grace of lyf^ Also there were Philosophres that
trauaylled their wits to find and know cause of things and manner of
lyuyng^ netheles they were most preysed that knew god and where he is and
that he is cause of al things that is wrought and light of sothnesse and of
truth and well of grace / that we shall drink To this knowleche they come in
this manner / they trauaylled their wits to find the best of all that is god
They knew that / that is no body for a body may be fordone and corrupted for
it is made of contrary things Also they took head that god is no likeness /
that may be changed therefore he passed al bodies and al lykenesses The body is
seen without the likeness of the body is in thought within and that that is
in thought within / is no body but likeness of a body Than the likeness is
known by a thing that is nowther the likeness nowther the body and that that
is likeness is seen and demed whether it be fair owther foul / is better
than the thing that is so demed There is no fayrenesse of body whether it be
in state of body as in shap of length and bread owther in moeuynge as in song
but such as the inwytte of man demeth / and that might not be but if there were
a better likeness in the inwytte without swellyng of body and cryeng of man's
wis without length or space of the place and of tyme^ But that is man's
thought and kind in wit of man's soul and that is no body^ sith that the
likeness that is known thereby is no body But and our inwytte is no body should
god make that our in wit be a body / Also our inwytte is chaungeable and
moeuable / else should no man's wit know better than other^ of that he
felyth and knows neither he that is wyttyer better than he that is duller /
And yet^ the same wit amendeth and profyteth and demeth better after than
before / But what that is amended and apeyred is chaungeable Than philosophres
and dyuynes knewen well that no thing that is chaungeable may be but by him that
is a stydfaste and not chaungeable^ to him is none other being than living.
none other being than understanding none other being than be well Eutr and
Mariauns

Capitulum 13
THe people of Rome made strife as though they were mysledde by the Senators /

Capitulum 14
ARtaxerses Darius son was the fyfth king of Perses / and reigned twenty year
This wanne egypt that his fader had lost and put out arysted^ and warred five

aduysed hem long what it it should mean / ffor they saw no writing in the

For she shaued of the wax and than the lettres were seen and read. and so they
were warned of the war / For Artaxerses had made ready ixCM of fyghtyng men
/ so that it seemed that the host dried up the Ryuers for hem behooved so much

yren snowtes / ij / M / and / ijC. and three thousand of other ships well
arrayed so that the Ryuers semede scars for hem for to goo in and the sea seemed
skars for hem to sail in Than this great rowte that was not habyly arrayed to
fight neither free to goo forth and to renn^ / neither ready to flee come

leyden a down and slough of hem three days to geder Valerius libro sexto When

only be ouercomen but they shall be alayed with the multitude of Perses and
another spoke and said the king shall have no enemies to kyth on his strength
/ Yet another spoke and said the sea is skars for our shippes^ towns be
skars for our knights and feldes for our other me^. Then^e Damarachus answered
and said / here be so many me^ that they may not be ruled And what may not be
ruled may not long dure^ and so it befelle / For many that were naught rewled
were overcome of few that were well ruled Therefore when the king was ouersette
with them of Lacedomones / he said that he was begyled for he had so many men
and but few connyng in batell for to fight Valerius libro tercio In that
fighting one of the greeks said to his felawe the son is derked with arowes
and shot of Perses / thou say well said that other for we should better
fight in shadow than in hete of son /

Also me axed in great despyte of one that halted / why he came in to the
bataylle / And he answered and said It is my purpoos to abide and not to flee /
And that befalls well for an halt man Trogus libro secundo At last Leonyda

deyde wonder many for honger and many deed careyns lay in the feldes and

Artabanus Artaxerses the kings steward purposed to be king of Perse and ca^ in

Capitulum 16
THe Romans send messagiers and prayed men of Athene to send hem laws written
This were Salons laws they sent not in to lacedomonia to have ligurgus laws /
though his laws were best. For they had him suspecte as a liar for he had
said that he had taken laws of Appolyn The Romans gadred this Salons laws
in to ten tables and put afterward twey tables thereto Thereof come afterward
that famous law of the twelve tables as it is written in folio de origin Iuris
libro secundo in the gloss Ysidorus libro quinto. Moses gaf first law to the
hebrews Feroneus to the greeks Mercurius trimogestus to the Egypcians Salon to
men of athene / Ligurgus to the Lacedomones and numa pompilius to the Romans
Afterward the people of Rome might not ne would not suffer the stryf of the
maystres and Iugges and ordained ten men to write laws and they written laws
out of Salons books and turned the law of twelve tables out of grue in to
latin The first that would make books of law was the great pompeus the consul
but for dread of evil spekers he accomplysshed ne fulfilled it. than Julius
Cezar began to make books of laws / but he deyde to sone And so among the
Romans little and little laws were compyled / til Constantyne the great
ordeygned new laws. But Theodosius minor made a book of law that is called
Theodosius coode And soon after Iustinianus of well nyghe of two thousand
books and thyrtty thousand versus made / and restored the laws of digeste /
The power of consuls cessed in the cyte^ And then men were ordained rulers instead of the twey^ consuls but the second year after as saint austyn touches
de ci^ dei li primo ca / 19^ One of these ten men that highte appius claudius
had great desire and lust to enduce and meoue a knights daughter to lygge
by her and made falsely one of his servants challenge her for his bond woman /
and so Appius demed and Iugged her / And her own fader slough her and made
pleyn^e to the people of that falsheed / the people was tho in the hille algid
Than the ten men were put out of her office and trybunes and Edyles were put in
their stead Petrus 186 Neemias a man of hebrews king artaxerses butler came by
leave of his lord out of Babylon in to the Iewry / and ladde the people xij year
/ so that that the.v / year he began to restore the walls and the yates of
Iherusalem / and he ended his work in two year and four months and had so
great let in the building that half the people srode armed without the cite
for to defend the cite and the work for resing and slekkyng of strange
nations / and that other de^le of the people / armed bylde the wallis and leide
stones with one hand and held eueryche his sword in his other hand
Af^terward neemyas took heed that the Jews had no fire from heaven and cleansed
a pytte in the valeye of Iosephath where Ieremias had hid fire in the time of
taking into bondage and found the stokkes of the altar and brennyng coals and
fette water and he cast of that water on a faggotte of wode and thereof come
fire Than if thou wolt reken seventy wekes of years from the twenty year of
Artaxerses when neemias went down to build / Jerusalem unto criste that is
unto the eyghten year of Tiberius cezar / the which seventy wekes of years
danyel prophesied to be shorted upon gods people / thou might find seue^ty
wekes of years so that thou acompte a weke of years of the moon / and a year of
the moon is twelve months of the moon As it was vsede in moses law not the
year of the son now there of Embolisme^ And so seventy wekys of years from
this year unto crist makes four honderd years of the moon and four score and
ten without the months of Embolismes that makes four honderd year of the
son and three score and fyften

Treuisa. An year of the son is the full yere^ that men use now in England
and other lands. But the year of the moon is xij months of the moon. and a
month of the moon is fro change to change and so the year of the moon is
less by enleuen days than the full year and the month of embolis^me fallith
when xiij primes be in one year R The nombre of the wikes and years may be
proved in this manner For Beda libro de temporibus says that the kingdom of
Perses dured from this twenty year of Artaxerses to the sixth year of darius^
when darius was overcome of Alysaunder an honderd year and fyftene^ And than
the kingdom of greece dured unto Julius cezars time two honders four score and
tweyne years Than from the beginning of Julius cezar that reigned four year
and seven months to the / xviij / year of Tiberius Cezar was four score year
and eight / and so all these years amounte unto the nombre of four honderd lxxv
years of the son Orocius libro tercio Till a great dele of the day was passed
it seemed that the night dured / Also hayle stones fell and descended from the
clouds and beat the earth with very stones

Capitulum 18^
ARtaxerses the son of darius and of pera^itides had a surname^ Menuon and
the hebrews called him Assuerus / He was the xj king of pers and reigned forty
year from Inde to ethiopia^ over an honderd prouynces and xxvij / his trone was
in the Cite Susis / The Cite that here was called susis was called Egbatanis in
the book of Judith and was chyef cite of the elemytes / Josephus says that
danyel made there a wonder buryel for kynges^ So wonderful that it semede made
the same day that is to say the kings of media of perses and of Perchea were
wont to be buried in that buryel. This Artaxerses otherwise called Assuerus in
the third year of his kingdom made great revel and feste to his princes that
dured an honderd days three score and ten in that wonderful palais that me
redeth of in thistory of Alysaundre The pyllers of that palace were of silver
the keueryng like to the firmament chambred and having precious stones of
diverse colors to the likeness of the sterres After he lay with his people
seven days in the Orchard of liking / there was a vineyard with vynes of
seluer with branches of gold and clustres of precious stones The pauilons were
pighte upon pilers of silver of marble and of Iuory with roopes of white sylk
and of reed / There vasty the queen was rebel and would not come to the king /
therefore hester was chosen queen in her stead Democritus the philosopher dyed
that time Agellus speaks of him and says that he putt out his own eyes. and
that for three skylles The first for his sight let him of his holy thoughtes^
the second for he might not see women without great temptacion the thirdde
for that he saw shrewes often mysdo and deden evil deeds and that might he not
suffer but it grieved hein soore Tullius ep / 95 Democritus was wont to say
that the hestes of shrewes and the noyes of the womb ben in one place / what
have I to do therewith said he whether this noise sown upward or downward Pol^
libro septimo Socrates the philosopher four score year old and xix. drank
poison with stydfast semblaunt and dyed R Lest error befall in the name of
Socrates take heed for there were three Socrates One was Auctour of doing and of
deeds Cassiodorus in thistory called tripertita preyseth well this Socrates
Selencus theodoricus and Socrates made that story Another Socrates was of greece
a great philosopher and lawer

Of him libro primo Saturnalium is rehearsed that noble saw When he was prayed
of his felawes to put forth somewhat of his noble spekyng. he said as this
place axeth I spareno spech and the spech that I spare is not couenable / for
this place nouther for this time* Such a tale is told of Ipocras the
philosofre / the third Socrates was platoes maystrer of him is our speech at
this time Pol libro quarto capitulo sexto Socrates was reputed the wysest by
answer of Appolyn and without any withsayenge he passed the seven wysemen /
that were holden wysemen among the greeks and was acompted before hem with out
comparison not only in wit and conning but also in manner of good lyuing^
therefore tullius libro primo de tuscul^ qo^ seith that Socrates was Prince of
philosophye / and that he called philosophy from heaven unto earth and stuffed
cytees with philosophy. Augustinus de ciuitate dei libro octauo capitulo 14 A
spyryte followed Socrates and taught him things / Apulius libro suo 1 de di /
Socrates says and reherseth. that this spirit / used to warn Socrates to
leave of his doing when the doing should have no good end R Therefore calcidius
super librum thimei Me says that a spyryte folewed and / taught Socrates from
his first childhode not to compelle him to do ought but to forbede him to do
thing not spedeful^ and as in adremes It seems a man that he herith many
things not by very voys / but by sum token that followed thoffyce of man's
vois / So socrates thought while he was waking was comforted and taught by
warning of clear token of the spyryte Tullius de dio^^ libro primo / We have
learned of Socrates that was always tendaunt to a spyryt that was cleped demon
but he never moeued him to do deeds. but withdrewe him often fro doing of deeds
/ And therefore when he should be dampened to death he chees to deye in most
rightful maner^ but tho had he no token yeuen him of his god Valerius libro
primo capitulo septimo Socrates in his old age used harpyng and armonye of
strenges and said that it was better to use that craft late than learn it
never. he would also take heed to the Art of musik that art is right nedeful
said he / And so he hield him self ever pour to learn and rich to teche^ And
though he was wise and wytty ever he said that he could no good / Thereof came
the comune saw of Socrates I can not but that I can not / As Ieronimus
reherseth epistola 35 / Valerius li / 8 Socrates shamed not to take a rehed
between his thyes^ and play with his small childer Pol^ libro octauo It is
homely and necessary a wyseman other while to pleye / not to put away the use
of virtues / but to refresshe him self and make him moore strong to do
virtues of virtues Also Socrates was profitable in virtues that makes men like
god / For he was a man of good temprure as Agell says libro secundo / So that
well nygh al his lives time he lived in health without sickness / and also in
that moreyne time / that destroyed the Cite Athene Therefore Valerius libro
secundo Seyth that Socrates said that many men would live for to ete and.
drink / and that he would ete and drink for to live Also he was of great
suffrau^ce / therefore Seneca libro tercio de Ira says that Socrates walked in
the Cite and was evil smyten upon the heed. and he answered and said naught
else but he said It is evil for men that they wit not when they should goo
out with salettes on her heedes and when without Also when a young man spytte
in his face while he disputed of wrath / he answered and said I am not wroth
but I doubt whether I should be wroth or no

Also he was sometime wroth with a shrewed servant / that he had and said I
would beat the and I were not wroth Also he had a wife light of her body as who
says comyne and childer that were rebel and horelinges / and moore like to
the mother than to the fader And a servant that was always a shrewe always wroth
and grutchyng Netheles Socrates suffered always and was paciente Therefore Seneca
epistola 197 Seyth that Socrates was well nygh always in bataylle owther in
Tyrannyse^ owther in fredome harder than bataylle owther tyrannyse / Therefore
Ieronimus contra Ionium and also Epistola 33 seith that socrates had twey
shrewde wives that wolden always chide / and strive / And hadden often stryf for
him bitwene hem / the wynes were called Zantippa and Altipias / And on a time
he blamed hem by cause they stryue^ for him that was but a foul thing / and
said ye strive for a man with snatted nose with a balled fort^p with ^^ery
shulders and with crooked thyes.

And at last both the wives turned against him / and chidden him alto
scarthes by one assente^ and after great chiding and dispytous words they
threw on his heed their piss of four nyghtes pissynge out of a soler. And
he answered naught else but wypte his heed and said I wyste well that it
should rain of thondryng of words Agellus libro secundo et Pol libro / 5 One
axed of socrates why he chastysed not his wyf^ Zantippa that was so full of
chiding and of anger or else why he pute her not away from hyme And he said I
suffer such one at home to have use and customme that I may the moore
patiently suffer wrongs of other men Seneca de Ira capitulo tercio Token of
wrath in Socrates was low speech and few words He was true and trusty in
counseylle as Valerius libro octauo seyth that a young man axed counseyll of
Socrates whether he should wedde a wife or no. whether so thou do of these tweyn
seith he. thou shall forthynke full soore / For if thou wedde no wife. thou shall
have this disauauntages^ thou shall be allone / thou shall have no child a
strange man shall be / thine heyr / And if thou wedde a wife thou shall have
great business always / many manner playntes plee of doing despysyng chidyng
and stryf / of thy wives dame and vnsekernesse and dread of thy childers end
And Seneca epistola. 30 and Pol libro septimo One axed of Socrates why
pilgrimagis stood him to no prouffyte what wonder says Socrates / while thou
berist thy self always about with the / The same cause that greueth the makes
the goo from hoome^ what profyteth new land there the flyghte flees not the.
the disease of thought must be put away else shall no place the plese Also
Poli libro quinto capitulo sexto One axed of him who should get him best fame
/ Who that does best said he and speaks little Also poli libro septimo Plawes

no man shall envy the No thing is without envy but wrechednesse allone
Ysidorus eth libro secundo capitulo decimo quarto This Socrates ordained first

virtues and redynesse Augustinus de ciuitate dei libro octauo This Socrates
turned first al manner of philosophy to help of good living and of good

chyef Seneca epistola 107 Speaks of the cause and manner of socrates death / For

therefore he was dampened to prisonne^ where he should ete venym called fermacum
Augustinus de vera religione capitulo primo / Socrates ^ was hardyer than other

better than any crafty man's works / And therefore it is more worthy to take
worshipes that longs to god^ than mawmettes that were worshipped in temples R
Therefore an expositour upon boece de disciplina capitulo quarto / seyth / that
one of Socrates dtsciples accused him for he had made a book of one god and not

he was dampened the men of Athene were sorry and punysshed hem soore: that had

OThus otherwise called Artaxerses the xij king of pers / reigned xxv year / In

PLato the philosopher died wha^ he had lived lxxxx year / in so great
reverence that me doubted long after his death whether that he should be acompted
among the gods owther among half gods Plato was most excellent among

^iche for condition and time And dyogenes with his foul feet trade on his

They had low^ed their clothes / and slain all that they might take and so

Plato thought on fysshe and wondered and ete naught ne slepte For he made him

Capitulum 27
AFter Plato come aristotle a noble man of fame and of lore and of great wytt^
Netheles not so noble a speker as plato But he passed many men in thoffyce of
techynge and was connyng in craft of fair vtteraunce and showing to with sey
all other man's se^tences / he brought up the sect that is called
paripatetica^ For he used to dispute wandryng and walking while plato lived
aristotle gadred many disciples in to his heresye. he made books of al manner
philosophy and yaue certain hestes and rules in all manner philosophy Netheles
passing al other he brought logyk in to his right law / This is called the
philosophre as it were he that berith the price of philosophres^ So Rome is
called the cyte^ so maro / the poet and so Aristotle the philosophre Netheles
sum men trowed that he was a fendes son / for he was swyper and swyfte and
clear of wit and desired great worship / for by many manner sleyghtes^ he
used to win and took worship before all other men / Alexander de natura
Aristotle among other taught eloquence fair and noble speech as it is
specially seen in his comentes homeris / and in dyte of troy the which he
bytoke Alysaunder and in his dyalogus of poets and in his tretice of
rethorique Aristotle xviij year old was sent in to Athenes and learned there of
Socrates three year. And when Socrates was deed he was with plato xx^ year till
plato dyed / and had so great favor of plato that plato called Aristotle's hows
/ the redyng hows / and would often say go we to the reders hows And when
Aristotle was absente Plato would cry understanding is away. the audience is
deef / he lived after platoes death xxiiij year / Sometime techyng Alisaunder
sometime wending about with him in to many lands sometime making books sometime
techyng disciples and so he lived in all lxiij year He made Alysaunder build
ayene the Cite stagerik that philip had destroyed and beten down Therefore the
men of that Cite haloweth a fest day in worship of Aristotle and that feste is
called Aristotileya and the month that this feste is hallowed in^ they clepe it
stagerites Aristotle dyed in calcide and was brought in to stagerik. when
alysander went against the perses aristotle was besy about philosophye and made
an historye of two honderd and fyfty laws Aristotle put to many things of
philosophye and to ethyk. that is the science of thewes He put that parfyt
welthe / is not in wordly richesse Also to philosophye he put the fyfth being
Treuisa In libris de celo et mundo and in other books also Aristotle clepeth
the welken or firmamente that is above the four elements the fyfth body Than
it follows in the storye that he withdrewe nothing of diuynyte. He made
problemes me dycynale of phisik and of kind in four score books / And
problemes of perspectyue and of methaphisik Treuisa A problem is a question
that is hard to assoylle and also an hard redels is also cleped a problem
Perspectyf is a science that specially longs to the sight that science
techeth how a thing is seen and is less owther more than it seems / owther
even as much as it seems even or crooked and right as it is or other wise
shapen than it seems Than it follows in thistorye^ he made statutes to

end of plees between the greeks He left after him his son nychomachus / and
his daughter pitharda and full many disciples among the which theofrastus was
of great name He made the book de nupcijs of spousayls Aristotle made a
thousand books and loved to follow truth. and not forsake thing that was
openly known / Auicenna preyseth him well libro tercio methapharo suo / And
raby moses li^ 1 / capitulo 4 and agellus li / 8 capitulo tercio and Johan in
suo policrato li / septimo / This is he that meoued archademia more with
strength of resons than it was moeued with strong blastes of wind for through
his besynes the Achademici that were left after. plato moeued doubts well
nygh of al things Also plynius libro suo seyth / That the great Alysaundre
burnt in couetyse of knowleche of the kind of beestes and sent to Aristotle

fowls wyld and tame and all that be taken with haukyng owther with huntyng and
had al manner beestes in keeping in hyues in lays in fysshe weres and pondes /
ffor he would know all thing that is brought forth in kind Aristotle examyned
al hem besyly and made about a fyfty volumes of the kind of beestes Therefore
plinius de naturis recu^ libro secundo / seyth that sommen tellen that
Aristotle made his books so shortly and so hard for envy and for vein
glory Other say that he made his bookis in that manner to use of studie^tes as
the science axeth for science is about thing that is good and hard to know
Treuisa Here take heed that here al thing that has life and felyng is cleped
a be Than it follows in thystory / aristotle when he should dye bad that his
subtle books should be buried with him in his grave / For they that come after
him should have no proufyt thereof / But I wot not by what virtue of kind
owther of craft that I say not by wondre of wytchecraft that sepulcre has
so appropred there to that place that is about it that noman may come now
in to that place /

Sum men say that antecrist shall know that place and look and see the books
that he there hid / but who dar trow / things that be in doubt and uncertain
/ Of the death of Arystotle gg. Nauzauzenus in his tretice upon that word of
the apostel The wisdom of this is folly before god And said that in greece at a
place called the black brygge^ the sea ebbith and flows as it were at ones in
the same place And Aristotle came and would know the cause why and bihelde it
and took heed long time / and for he could not find the cause why^ for great
indignacion he spoke to the water and said / For I may not comprehend and
take the thou shall take me and so he fell in to the water and dreint him self
Treuisa It is wonder that gregorius Nauze^zenus tellith so mad a magyl tale
of so worthy a prince of philosophres as Aristotle's was / why tells he not
how Aristotle declares the matier of ebbynge and flowynge of the sea. secundo
meth / why tellyth he not why it is wreton in the book of the appel how
Aristotle's dyed and held an Appel in his hand and had comfort of the
sinelle and taught his scolers how they should live and come to god and be
with god withouten end

And at last his hand began to quake and the apple f^lle down from his
hand and his face wax al pale and so Aristotle yield up the ghost and dyed
Than it follows in thystorye Aristotle's successor was theofrastus and had
that name for his noble spekyng of god so says the master of thistoryes
supli. math This theofrastus made a book de nupcijs of wedlok and called the

anguysshe of wedded men Ieronimus talks much of that book against Ioninianus
And this Theofrastus made another book of friendship and puts and prefers

accused kind for it yafe longer life to other beestes than to mankind There it
is said that is spedeful that friends love well / and not assaye hem that they
love / Also it is written there that loving men have blind domes

Eutropius Capitulum 25
THe Romans ordained a bataille against the Sampnytes that be between campania
and Apulia and have armoure of gold and of silver The cause of bataylle was the
land of campania that is best land and most pleyne The chyef Cite thereof is
capna and is peer to Rome and to cartage in gretenesse and in plente Than
lucius papirius dictatour or orator of Rome was sent against the Sampnytes and
he t^rnede ayene to rome and bade quintus Fabius master of the horsemen that he
should not fight while he were a way. netheles Quintus saw and found occasion
and faughte and spedde well and skomfyte the Sampnytes / And by cause thereof the
dictator dampened him for he had foughten against his heest in his absence
Netheles he was delyuerd and saved by great favor of knights of the people.
And so great stryf was arered against papirius that he was in ^opardy of his
life But afterward in a place called furcule ca^deus. the sa^pnytes had the
Romans closed in narow ways and streyte and overcome hem with so great shame
that hem was lever keep hem a live to shame and to shenship. than slay hem so
closed and made hem cast of her armor and her clothee / and goo on a long
rewe under the hille side and had of hem a condition the which condition if
the Romans had holden they had be^ deed owther bond men to the sampnytes
Titus liuius

The duc and the leder of the sampnytes called poncius had ord^^gned his
host besides Furcule candynes where the Romans should pass That place is
closed with hills on either side and has a plain in the myddel between high
lands with streyte enter and strayte out going Poncius had sent sum of his
knights before clothed as heordes that kepen beestes and that they should
answer the host of Romans that would pass and axe after the sampnytes where
they were and the knights to answer that the sampnytes were passed to besiege
a cite called lucrecia that was comfedred with the romans / and when the
Romans herd that anon they went swyftly in to the valey of furcule as it were
for to speed hem to socour the Cite that was besieged / but in the mean time
the sampnytes knights and other hew down trees and stopped the enter and the
outegoynge of the valey and went in to the tops of the hills and so the
Romans were compellyd by meschyef to axe pees of the Sampnytes owther a
battle of knights Than poncius the duc answered and said now the battle is
done and granted pees upon this condition that the Romans should yield up
her clothyng and her armor and goo al naked sauf her preu^e members in a long
rewe under the hille side and yielded up pleggys three hond^rd horsemen of the
Romans T Entr The year that followed after by heest of the Senators the
dictator ^^cius papirius scomfyted the Sampnytes Orocius libro tercio After
that vyctory there fell so great pestylence in Rome of death and of lyghtnyng

books of Sibylle the wise and took counseylle and sent in to Epydauru a cite
of greece for to have a mawmette the image of Esculapius^ he is feyned god of
medycyne and shows him to his worshippers in the likeness of a serpent Item
Orocius Wives of Rome brennyng in wode love toward her own husbands made as

wenche that knew that doing warned the Senators thereof than the wives were
compellid to drink of the same and by the vyolent poison of that drynk many of
them fell down suddenly deed. and two hundred wives and seventy that were
mays^^s of the doing were dampened to the death / About that time Guytelynus
Gurguncius son reigned in Brytayn^ his wife marcia was right connyng and could
many manner crafts she made the law called marcene law. R Look more hereof in

Capitulum 26
ARsanius otherwise called artaxerses othus sone was xiij year king of Perse
and reigned four year In his first year Iadus bishop of Jews prospred Philip
king of macedonia was deed by trayson of one pansania Trogus libro nono This
philip was moore besy about deeds of Arms than about feestes and yaue him
moore to win richesse than to keep it And for all that he robbed always yet he
was ever nedy and loved mercy and falseheed both like well and was untrusty in
his speech / and would behote more than he would perform He couth feyne him
gracious and well apayed when he was wroth and wroth when he were well apayed He
used to make wrath between parties and get thank on either side Trogus libro
septimo This when he had first ouercomen the men of athenes he let the
prysonners goo by his good will than he wedded olimpyada Neoptholomeus the
kings daughter of the moloses and bigate on her the great Alysaunder These yaue
an assaute to the cite mathona and there his right eye was smyton out with the
struck of an arowe / but for that wound he was never the slower to fight ne
wrother with his enemy / but at last men yield up the Cite and than he was
mylde and merciable to hem al Trogus libro octauo This philip was enemy to
men's fredome he nourysshed firyfe in Cytees and helped the less aie^st the
more and brought both in to thraldo^ the victor and him that was overcome / so
he made to him.ij / brether kings of tracia subget that put her querele in
his arbytracion to deem rightly bitwene hem to make final pees He made subget
to him the Bardanes and other nations by such manner fraud He made his wives
brother Alysaunder a yonglynge of / xx. year old to use f^rnicacion always /
for he would have him afterward the moore bound to him and to his service
Trogus libro 14 Philip sometime werred against the Shi^es and scomfyted hem more
with gyle and fraud than with virtue and strength He had with him on a time
twenty thousand childer of women and of beestes with twenty thousand noble
mares for to do what it were in macedoyne as it were to have sum manner new
men to dwell therein And on a time he turned from the tebans men of thebes in
greece that warned him passage / and was wounded in his thigh wo^derly soore so
that through his thye his horse was slain that he rode on Netheles he scomfyted
hem solempnely but that day for the vyctory he seemed never the gladder of chere
to his own men / ne the more stierne to hem that were over come but he sent
again the prysonners and restored ayene three honderd wysemen that were put out
Al these wise men when five of hem were accused of the trespass said that they
al were even peers in doing of that deed Yet philip arrayed an host of two
honderd thousand footmen and fyften thousand horsemen to werre in the Reame of
pers and made one Attalus duc and leder of that hooste this dukes sister
Olympiada was philippes wife and afterward put away and forsake / Therefore when
Philip sat at feste of spousayle without wardcorpses Pansania a noble young
man slough him right there The cause thereof was this^ Atthalus had dispitefully
scorned this pa^sania and done him greet vylenye first pryuely and after
openly in a great feste and revel and he complained often to Philip of the
despite that atthalus had done him and had none ame^des^ therefore he turned his
wrath and was wroth with philippe and slough him in that manner for vengeance of
that deed Olimpiada philippes wife and alysaunder philippes son were had in
suspection and not holden all gyltles of that deed Olimpiada for that she was
forsaken^ and Alysaunder for the despyte in that was done to his mother And
specially for philip often repreued his sone alysander for his mother was so
forsaken and was often in point to rese on him with his sword And therefore
Alysander exiled. dwelled a while with his uncle in epyrus Treuisa This land
is tracia and was sometime the land of Epyrotes / It follows in thystory he
hanged afterward pansania and crowned olympyada with gold and burnt aftward
her body upon her husbands body / Treuisa / Who that knows this cronyque a
right knows that it was used sometime in diverse lands to brenne noble bodies
when they were deed and keep the asks sole^pnely in reverent place It follows
in thystory he hanged cleopatra Atthalus sister This philip was sometime warned
and saved him self from the vyolence of a chariot Therefore he undid all the
charyottes and chares that were in his kingdom Also he avoided and withdrough
him from that place called chariot in boecia / and come not therinne Netheles
he escaped not pansanias sword in the hilt of that sword was engraven a
chariot Pol libro sexto capitulo sexto While philip ordained his hooste he

Capitulum 27
THe great Alysaunder when his fader was dede^ bygan to regne after his fader
in macedonia in his xx. year of age and reigned but xij year and sex months /
He was gretter than his fader both in vices and in virtues / Netheles his fader
was the wyser man of counseylle / but the son was the gretter man of heart
The fader would often keep secret and overcome his own wrath^ the son used
not to seche love nowther the manner of wreche / either loved well wine and were
both good deynkers The fader would slay but his enemies and the son would slay
both his enemies and his friends The fader would be loved but the son had
lever be drad. they were of one believe / the fader yaue him to skillful largenes
of yeftes / and the son yaue him to lechery Vynceu^ libro quinto The year of
othus king of pers xv of philip king of macedoine xij and of nectanabus king
of egypt xvij. othus occupied egypt and put out nectanabus^ If this
nectanabus drad werre and bataylle he would not array and gadre his hoost^
neither ordeyne gynnes of werre but he would go secretly in to a pryuate place
and take with him a basine of clear water and make ships and men of wax to
the likeness of a ship in the sea so that it should seem that all tho meoued
and were alive Also he would take a yerde of fyrre holowe / within as a pype and
he would speak in the holownesse of that yerde and clepe gods above and
bynethe and so he would found to drown his ship of wax in the basen / And
so it should byfalle that by drenchyng of the wax and of the tapres that were
brennynge his enemies should drenche in the sea / He herd tell on a time that
Indes perthes medes Arabes and other nations also had conspyred to rise against
him and he brake on laughyng and went to do his craft that he used / and he
knew by that that he should be overcome but if flight might help him^ Anon he
bade shave his heed. and took all the precious riches that he had and came in
to macedonia and said that he was a astronomer / and philip the king was thoo
out of countray / and occupied in werre and nectanabus by his enchauntement
and his fantastic feynyng gate such love of the Queen Olimpias. that he lay
by her in likeness of Jupiter horned and bygate the great alysander / Than
when the queen. was with child many fowls flow about philip that was tho
occupied in werre But among other fowls an hen leyde an egg in philippes
lap and when that egg was smyten of his lap to the ground a dragon lepte out
of the shelle and crept all about and while he would have cropen in to the
shelle that he came out of. he dyed anon / Than Antiphon a noble dyuynoure
was demanded what that should signefye and he answered and said that philip
should have a sone borne that should goo about all the world but he should dye er
he came ayene For a dragon is a ryall be and an egg has the shap of the
world Afterward when Olimpias was trauelyng of child were herd and seen earth
quakynge lyghtnyng and thonder Quintus curcius Al that day sat twey egles upon
the coppe of the hows that boded and sygnefyed twey great empyres of europa and
asia Vyncen^ The child is born and named Alysaundre with fair heier and fair
eyes one yelowe another black Ieronimus epistola 85 Alysaundre might not leave
the manners and the vices and the lechery of his master leonydes. in the which
he was enfe^t while he was a child and used hem when he was lord of the world
/ And therefore his fader philip put away leonydes and made Aristotle to be
Alysaundres master Seneca Alysaunder put that leonydes afterward to lions to
be deuouted

Vincen^ When Alysaunder was twellif year old he had great liking and joy
to be in hooste among men of Arms / and to lepe on horse and used him self
right knyghtly On a day when Philip was absente. Alysaundre prayed Nectanabus

Alysaunder is to blame for it warned not the this change. there thou lyeste

were a vile shame / for a christian man to believe this false saw of a wytche. For
from every myshap that man is shape / in this world to fall in / god may him
save if it be his will Than it follows in the story nectanabus said I know
well by this craft that mine own son should slay me / what said Alysaunder

/ that time philip took great thought who should be his heir and king after him

Alysander herd tell hereof of philippes horse called Bucyfall right perilous

Gir in top^ In an homely and special company and myrthe alisandre herd a sweet

to likyng than to hardynesse. to ease than to cheualrye / to lechery than to

Capitulum 28
THe xiiij king of pers darius Arsanius son / began to regne the second year
of alysander and reigned six year Trogus libro 11 Than Alysaunder slough his

brain and not in feet and trust in the vyctory and not in the flight In

That time Alisaunder axed of one dyonydes a thief of the sea that was taken^

Capitulum 29
AFter this Alysaunder took the clothyng and the dyademe of the king of pers
as thaugh he would pass in to the manner and usage of macedonia And for it should
not seem that all one he trespassed in that doyng^ he. bade his friends also
use long clothes of gold / Also he deled the times and stempnes of the nyghtes
among company of strompettes and put to noble mete and drynk lest fasting
destroyed lechery he highted his meels with diverse plays and had no mind
that great Richesse is lost by such manner doing and not get ne won.
Therefore men began to have indygnacion of him for he forsook the usage and the
manners of his forfaders / He let knights wedde women that were taken
prysonners / for they should take and suffer more easily the trauaylle of
chiualrye and think the less of their own country / he held that macedonia
should be strenger / if young knights come after old faders and used deeds of
knights with in the bounds of their own birth / And should be the more stal
worth afterward if they pyght her tents as it were in her own cradels / Also
Alysaunder ordained fedyng for children hers^ and armor for the yonglynges
hire and wages for the faders / and if the faders dyed the sons should receive
the wages of the faders and so her childhode should be as it were knyghthode and
cheualrye / than when the parties were chased Alysaunder way cruel among his
own men and hated most if any of his men with said him of any manner dede^
There he slough one permenion an old man that was next the king and permenyons
son phil^ta also / for they told him that he ouertourned and destroyed the
manners and the vsages of the countray and of his fornfaders Than Alysaunder
drad lest tidings of that deed should come in to macedonia. he made it as he
would send sum of his friends in to macedonia to. tell there tidings of the
vyctoryes and of the great deeds that he had do and bade that men should write
lettres all that would tidings send and made the messagers bring him the
lettres pryuately for he would know al men's will that would lettres send
owther for he would reward hem that were true owther send hem that were falls
in to far lands Pol^ Alysander was often dronken and than he was cruel among
his meyny / And so it happed on a time that he yaue dome against one the
grettest of his palace that his heed should of / And he appeled anon right^ But
for me used to appele from the less to the more. the tyrant that was wine
drunk turned in to more wodenesse and said from whom and to whom appellyst
thou / I appelle said he from Alysaunder the drunk to alysaunder the sober /
By that answer Alysaunder abated his wrath and put of the sentence and dome /
and fully foryaue him the trespass Trogus Than he subdued the people that dwelled
at foot of the hille cancasus and bylde the cite Alexandria upon the river

in a litel while / than take heed and bewar that thou fall not with the tree
while thou take to the the bows Often the lion is mete to small beestes and
to fowls and rust destroyed yren / there is no thing so strong and stydfast
that may not be brought in to peril and that by a feeble thing and well litel
worth / What cyleth the at us / we came never in thy land we may serve no man
and we keep not to regne And thou have joy to pursue thieves and thou art every
nations thef What need hastow to riches that makes the the more nedy to desire
moore riches To the vyctory is cause of bataylle / no man suffers gladly an

take fro no man his own If thou be a man think what thou art / thou might
have friends of hem that thou have not grieved / and them that thou have

Alisandres trusty friends was speech of the deeds of philip the kyngis fader
There Alysaundre began to booste and make him self more worthy than his fader

Solinus After this Alisander came to the hills of caspy there the childer of

Capitulum 30
When Alysaunder had goone about the last clyff of occea^ he arrayed him to
werre in the Ilond Bragmans / They sent him such a letter King we have herd
of thy bataylles / and of thy vyctoryes / but what shall suffice the who^ all
the world suffiseth not. richesse we have none for the which me should werre on
us. Al our good is comune to us all / Mete is our riches / Vile clothyng and
sckars we have instead of gold and great array Our women be not arrayed for to
plese For great array is acompted charge among us and not highness and
fayrenesse Our women desire no more fayrenesse than they have of kind Our dry
dyches and dens stands us in double stead / instead of our herberowe
while we live and instead of our graves when we be dede^ If we have sometime a
king / It is not for to do right^ but for honest of kind / We have among us
neither domes ne plee^ for we do not thing that needs redress by plee owther
by dome^ we desire no more than reason of kind axeth^ we hold needful that we
know is mesurable and not to much / Euenesse of pouert makes us all ryche^
our people has one law and does nothing against the law of kind we use no
trauayll that slhod make us covetous we shone and forsake foul sleuthe and
lechery we do no thing that nedith punysshyng / It is unlawful to us to
wound the hills with culture and with share. we use no gloteny ne outrage of
mete and drink and therefore we be not seek / we dwell in dry dyches heaven
fyndeth us keueryng and earth fyndeth us bedding We be no werriours we make pees
with good living and not with strength Also no fader follows thoffyce of his
sons death

Committatur exequias
We seche no plays and Iapes for it is right lyking to us to behold the
firmament and the sterres of heaven / we be men of simple speche^ It it commune
to us all not to lie / god of al is our god for he has lykyng in words and in
beedes by a manner likeness of love / He is a word spyryte and thought and is
not plesid with wordly Richesse but with holy works and thankynges of his
grace Rn^o allexandri If it be as thou say dindimus bragmans allone be
acompted in the nombre and tale of mankind they be without vices and riches.
they acompte wrongefull all the deeds that we doo^ they acompte grievous the
benefyce that god has granted to the help of mankind. help and service of
crafts they acompte sinful and at last they destroy the laws of living.
than either they sey / that they be goddes^ or that they han envy to god and
by cause thereof they blame the fairest of creatures Respo^sio dindimi We be not
at home in this world but from home as gestes / we come not to dwell here but
to wend hens. we be not alayde with charge of sins / but without such
manner charges / We draw nyghe our own hows and hye fast homeward / we say
not that we be gods we have none envy to god / But we sey that we wol not
mysuse goodness of god almighty. We say not that al thing is semely that is
lawful / god has put the use of things in man's fredome than he that
leueth the wors and follows the better / is not god but he is made gods
frende^ When the swellynge of wealth has bolned up pride than ye forgete that
ye be men and seyn that god rekketh not of mankind / ye bylde temples to your
self in the which ye sheden blood Therefore I call you. wood for ye wit not
what ye do and if ye despise god wyttyngly than ye holden in the sin
sacrylege Epistola Allexandri Thou call thy self a man of welthe for thou
dwell there no man may come to the / ye praise the living and doing of
your scarsete but by the same skylle they be in welthe that be in perpetuel
prysonne. for they have no use of riches. but they be with out riches right
as ye be^ law of kind does to you as prison does to hem That ye tille
neither gardyns ne feldes that makes defawte of ire that kind voucheth not
sauf to give you / that yet live by roots / so ye must needs for ye may not
sail in to other lands to get you other lyuelode Sometime beestes lived by
roots right as ye do therefore it is good to live in good rule and in plente
and not in strayte skarste and meschyef Else blyndenesse and pouerte should be
noble virtues allone Blyndenesse for he sees not what he coueyteth / and
pouerte for he has not what he desires That your women ben not lykyngly
arrayed I grant for ye have neither connyng ne where with That ye have no great
flesshely liking it is no wonder for that makes your great need and meschyef
and foul sight and nakedness / that ye have no laws and domes men and study
in no l^ttrure and axen neither grauntmercy / therinne ye acorde with fysshes
and vnskylful beestes / Man's soul in diverse time for diverse happes of causes
is able to diverse manner of doing / diverse manner of sowles torn and change
with the chau^gynge of heaven and be wyttede in a cl^er day and dull wytted and
heavy when the day is dym and clowdy / Also the reason of wits as it may be
in many manner wise so it is chaungeable and not only by dyuersyte of other
things but also by dyuersite of ages Therefore childhode is myld and young men be
wild and old men be soft and wexen feeble Also all the wits ben plesed with
things that long to her own felyng Treuisa / Ye may know how the wits han
lykyng in things that longs to her own feeling if ye take heed how the
sight has lykyng in fair hew and color the heryng in sweet voys and sown /
the nose in sweet odor and smelles / the mouth in sweet taste and savor / the
gropyng in hot and cold dry and wete nessh and hard but nesshe is known by
many wits / for it is known both by gropyng and by sight. Than it follows
in thystorye The elements yeueth us matier of wits and of all that we feel.
the stature of the body of mankind is made of the elements meddled ^o geder.
for every should make good for his own party and give us special help and
subsydye by his own dispensacion. than if thou wolt not use the benefyce /
that we have by thelementes the which benefyces ben seeds. fysshes and fowls
and many other Thou shall be accused of pride / for thou forsakest yeftes /
either for envy for they be yeuen of him that is better than thou Responsio
dindimi / Ye moeue werres and bataylles and werre outward against men^ for ye
have not ouercomen your enemies within / but we bragmans had overcome the ynner
bataylles of our own membrys and rest sikerly and have no bataylles outward /
We beholden the firmamente and the sterres of heaven and her fowls song we be
heled and fed with leaves and fruit of trees^ we drink water and sing songs
in worship of god / and take heed and think of the life that is coming We be
apayed with few words and be sone stylle and hold our pees / Ye say what
should be do but ye do it not Your wit and wisdom is in your lyppes. ye be
hongry and thyrsty after gold^ you needs hows and servants. ye coueyte
reverence and worship / water quenches our kind thirst Gold heeleth not your
wounds nowther withdraws / ne refreyneth your couetise but makes it moore
Therefore it is openly known that the thyrste and hongre of gold / comes of
kyndely need. when it were ones had it would sometime quench such honger and
thyrst One calamus fled from us to you^ we despised him and ye worship him
Than Alysaunder sent one Onesicritus to dindimus that lay in a wode upon leaves
of trees with these words Alysaunder the great god Jupiters son and lord of
the world chargith and commands that without delay thou come to him and
if thou come he would give the many great yeftes and if thou come not / thou
shall thy head and thy life for goo Dindimus lay still and answered him in this
manner Sothfaste god yeueth men light and does no man wrong / He auoydeth
manslaughter / and arereth no stryf ne werre But Alysander shall dye than he is
no god. What he promyseth to me is not nedeful to me^ Me needs no such
thynges^ I goo freely wheder me lyketh^ If Alysaunder smite of my heed and slay
me / he may not slay my soul The gronyng of hem that suffren wrong is
beginning of pain and tourmentes of hem that does the wrong Say than to
Alysander that I dread not my death / if he wol ought of mine let him come to
me Than Alysaunder left of all pomp and boste and came to dyndimus fete^ and
dindimus to him said. why distourbest thou our peace What desire / we have no
thing. and what we have is not nedeful to the We worship god and love men. we
rek not of gold / we despise death / Ye love gold and hate men and despise god
Than Alysaunder said teache thou me wit and wysedom that thou have received.
of god as it is said Than dyndimus answered and seyde. thou haste not whereon to
do. such a yefte / for thy soul is full of couetyse / than how shall I
suffyce to the. to whom all the world suffyseth not / god has made the lytil
/ and though thou desire all the world / It needs the to have at last as
little land as thou see me lie on owther thy self sit on / If thou learn
this wisdom of me al thou shall have / though thou desire naught / for
couetise is mother of pouert God is my friend / I have heaven for my roof. the
earth instead of my bed. the River fyndeth me drink / and the wode is my mete
borde^ flesh of beestys roteth not within my guts / I am not buryels of
deed bodies / I live as I am made / I know gods pryuytees. for god will that
I be pertener of his works / Than whether seyst thou is more ^ightful to
mysbede men owther to defend hem and do hem right to shede and to shyfte
owther to keep and to save. If thou slay me I goo to god and thou may not
escape his hand / Than destroy thou not that god has wrought and made Than
Alysaunder said thou come of god and lyuest in a place of pees and reste^ I
live in great dread and effray / mine oune wardeyns I dread I dread mote my
friends than mine enemies I may not leave hem ne trust to other A day I grieve men
and I am grieved at night and dread full soore if I slay him that I dread than am
I sorry and full of woo And if I be easy and soft than I am despised. and if I
would dwell with the in valeys and in dennys I might not endure^ when these
tales were told. Alysaunder proffered to dindymus gold silver clothes breed and
oil And dindimus said to him may thou make the briddes that here singe the
better for gold and silver and if thou may not / why wolt thou make me wors
than the briddes^ and make me receive thing that may not stand me in steed
/ but of a free man make me bond but for I would not grieve the to swyth this
oil I wolle receive And when dindimus had said so he threw the oil in a
fire of wode and sang an ympne to god almighty / And alysaunder saw that and
went his way

Capitulum 31
AFter this Alysaundre about the enleuenth year of his kingdom passed by the

were an honderd foot high. Alysaunder said that it rone often in that place.
nay said the preeste and said that there came never rain ne byrd ne wild
be / but the trees had wept in the eclyps of the son and of the moon
Petrus 197 Prestes took of the apples of these trees and lived five honderd year
and when the beam of the son touched the tree of the son^e owther the beam
of the moon the tree of the moon. than anon the tree would shake and give

Also in I say about the incarnacion of criste. they found six names of god

and hem self at last When the cite was destroyed hanybal left his brother

Among the capenes it seemed that twey mones were risen among the falistes it

There was so hard fighting that the fighting men wist not of the earth

would not assente that cartage should be destroyed for he would that the outrage
should be chasede by dread

Capitulum 37
THolomeus euergetes reigned in Egypt nine and twenty year and the young Scipio
was twyes made consul and overcome the numantanes and made hem subget in a well
strong battle in spayn / the Romans said that they escaped and had not the

was sometime so strong that it might not be overcome and by what cause it was
aftward overcome and destroyed Petrus 22 Tryphon desired for to regne and cast

first friendship with simon And than he pursued tryphon that flygh by the sea
side in to Antyochia / But at last he brake covenant of friendship that was

he should werre in the Iewry but he was put abak and overcome Simon renewyd
friendship with the sparciates that been the lacedomones and sent the Romans a
shield of gold of a thousand mnas Treuisa Mua is a manner of other manner money
and weyeth sixty cicles Ciclus is a full ounce among the hebrews and among
Greeks and Latyns^ Cyclus is a quarter of an ounce. So in holy books of hebrewe
ciclus is y take for an ounce and in hethen menus books Ciclus is y take for a
quarter of an ounce Than it follows in the storye Such friendship was made
bitwene the jews and the romans that lucius consul of Rome wrote to kyngdoms
of the est lands chargyng that they should not grieve the Jews / Attalus king
of asia made the people of Rome cyres of his kingdom Petrus 2^5 / That year one

Sequitul capitulum 38
THolomeus Sother the son of cleopatra reigned in egypt seuenten year Marcus
tullius Cithero is born in the vulcene kind Valerius He kept beestes in his
youth and ruled thempyre of Rome in his elde / It is wonder that he despised
lettres / and was him self a plentuous well of lettres This was a noble speker
in all manner tongues of wit and of wysedom and chyef speker with tongue. he
assoylled al doutes clerely^ at will and cleansed and enorned al Rethoryke Me
axed him sometime how he come to the fair spekyng that he had / noble facunde
said he is a great gift of god almyghty^ Who that knew how he should have fair
manner of spekyng He wrote all the gestes of Troy subtylly as it might be
closed in a note sha^e Pol libro quinto capitulo sexto Cithero would sometime bye
an hows in the palace and had no money and borrowed of one scilla / but he was
wryed er the bargayne was made^ Than Cythero was moeued and denied all that he
had received and said that ^e would bye none hows. And if I bye an hows said
he / I shall knowleche the sothe of that ye put to me / and afterward when he
had bought the hows it was putt against him / Ye be unwise seyde he if ye know
not that buyers forsake if they wole ought bye and make it as though they would
no thing there of to have the b^tter chepe and so what he might not deny /
he turned it to bourde and to laughyng and not to blame and to trespasse^ He
had always that manner doing that as often as any foul deed was put against him
that he might not deny / he would put it of with a merry answer Ieronimus ad
nepoc Me said sometime of one to tullius in this manner / Demostenes by nam the

often medycynes of treacle / by the which remedies he put of the peril of venym
in his yougth / so that he might not dye by venym when he would have dyed by
venym in his elde Than after venym he drad Ire and feyned that he would goo an
hunting / so that in seven year he came never in cite ne in small town / so
that all that time he had never hows over head / but walked and lay by night in
hills and in montaynes and there he trauaylled often wild beestes / and took
hem with swyfte rennynge and fought with hem^ sometime for to make his body
stydfast by use in trauayl for tendure

Also when he come to rulyng of kingdom. He chastysed the Scites that might
not be overcome before by sleyght of wit He occupied pontus and macedonia Also
he went pryuely out of his kingdom and took with him sum of his frendes^
and passed in to Asia and went about in Asia and espied the places and
countrees of that land and came again than in to his own kingdom and found
a little sone that Laodyce that was both his wife and his own sister / had
brought forch by a copyner while he was absente in other lands Therefore the wife
ordeygned venym for metridas when he come home^ but he was warned by a wenche
that served his wife / and took wreche of the doers of that falls deed Than when
winter was comen / he would not be in festes but in the field stryuynge on his
horse in rennyng or in great deeds of strength and made his host to use such
trauaylle and deeds for to make hem conning by use stalworth and stydfaste
eftsoon when they should fight

Than he werred in Galacia and despised the manase of the Romans Metridas
second wife shaar her heed for love of her husband and used her for to ride
for to help what she might / if her husband fell in any peril / and for to be
with him always / her husband was overcome of pompeus and fled and she sewed
him always among full cruel nations Giraldus As often as highest consuls sylla and
Pompeus overcome metridas^ so often he seemed the more mighty and strong for he
occupied babyloyne and asia and peased the Scites and made subget capadocia and
Armenia and made his own kingdom stretche streyht unto Inde / and come to
ephesus and slough all the Romans in one day that were in Asia / Than he sent
Archelaus that was the duc before him in to greece with an honderd thousand
fyghtyng men that gate him al greece / At last he was holden of his own son
farnaces and drank venym by his good will for he would have dyed / but it
grieved him not / Therefore a knight of the galls that he had grieved was prayed
for to slay him and slough him anon / After his death Pompeus made Tigranes
king of Siria and burnt with fire the temple of Jerusalem /

Capitulum 43
When Julius caesar was slain Octauianus of Rome xviij year of age was sent
with twey co^suls for to pursue marcus Antonius. that was than demed open enemy
to the comente / for he made insurrection against the Senators and against hem /

Than Octauianus came to Rome in his xx year of age / and took the dygnyte and

owther for For he had the vyctory in that month of Antonius and of cleopatra
This augustus was the sone of one Actia Julius sister daughter Eutropius libro

Capitulum 44
ANtonius put from him his wife Cleopatra cesars sister / and wedded the queen
of egypt and yaue her Arabia By couetyse that women have she desired to regne
in Rome / and by her counseyll and comfort Antonius moeued a civil bataylle
against octauianus and was overcome at actia in greece Petrus visesimo octauo
Herodes was not at that battle / for that time Antonius had sent him again
to the king of Arabye at prayer of cleopatra. so that he should have his
kingdom that were overcome whether it ever were Eutropius libro septimo
Antonius when he was overcome at Actiu^ / he sledde in to Egypt / there he
slough him self ffor he had none hope of help ne of socour Cleopatra made her
gay and met with Augustus entendynge to meoue him to lechery / But she might
not speed and was put in ward and escaped away and leyd her self in the grave
by her husband Antonius and dyed by the venym of a naddre that she took with
her / Afterward Egipte fell to thempyre Petrus 78. After this augustus enlarged
herodes kingdom for he had wytly provided for him what him neded while he was

not keep fles^he long without appayryng / but virgyl by his wit ordained

of herbs so that five honderd year the flesh was found fressh and of good

Incipit Liber quartus
OCtauianus Augustus bygan to regne in march / In the beginning of his xlij
year in the year of herodes / xxxj / in the thyrdde year of the Olimpias nine
score and ten after the buyldyng of the Cite of Rome / vij C / year and five
after the concepcion of Johan baptist the sixth month the xxv day of march in
a frydaye the tenth day of the moon the twelve indiction at nazareth in galylee
crist was conceived of the virgin marie Joseph's spouse Treuisa The greeks used
sometime turnemences deeds of might and of strength at foot of the h^lmons
olimpus ones in five year and named such deeds and plays olimpias And also
the first five year of such plays they named the first olimpias And the
second five year of such deeds and plays the second olimpias And the third
five year the thyrdde olimpias / and so forth of al other And for crist was
conceived in the twelfthe indiction that is the menyng in twelve year of the
indiction. therefore take heed that the indiction is the time of fyften year for
when the Romans had won many provinces and lands they had of eueryche
land that they had won three manner trybute in fyften year and clepyd the xv
year indiction and the first / v / year of the indiction the Romans had
brass to trybute for to make armor and the second / v / year they had
silver for to pay knights and the thirdde and the last five year of indiccion
they had gold to the tresory of rome / Petrus / Criste was conceived full man in
soul and in flesh so that the shappe of his lymmes and of his body might
not be seen with man's eye and so ends the / v^ age of ye world as it were
the age often grieved with care and with woe from the transmigracio^ of jews unto
crist that is from march before bre^ning of the temple that was don in harvest
unto march in ye xlij year of augustus under xiiij gnacio^s and and co^teyneth

begins from crist the age is not certain of generacio^s nowther of years
but it shall be ended as it were by death the last age of all the world So^me wol
mean that the sixthe age of the world bigan at the incarnacion of crist by the
which incarnacio^ criste vysyted us and came down from heaven / Sum acounten
the sixth age of the world from the birth of crist. and for that auctoryte of

acounte from the cristnyng of crist for the virtue that was yeue^ unto the water
to bring forth children goostly when the circumsicion bygan to cease. So^me
acou^te from cristes passion for thanne was opened the yate of paradyse Than
the years from the beginning of the world that was the xiiij day of Apryl in
the which day the world began unto the incarnacion of crist were five
thousand and two honderd year so seith orocius / But the common calculyng seyth
five thousand and C year four score and sixtene / Marcius seyth five thousasand
an / C year and nine / the first Adam sinned in a friday and dyed in the same
friday after nine honderd year and xxx. and in such a friday the second Adam
that is crist took flesh and blood and ended his fasting and suffered death
for mankind / and in the same hour of the friday that adam was put out of
paradyse right in such an hour the thief was brought in paradise / Marianus
libro secundo^ It is naught against this that holy church holds that the
first adam was made of earth in the ix day before apryl. and crist conceyuid
the vij day to fore Apryl ffor the night of the ix / day before the first day
of apryl that come after the day that ada^ was made ynne is now made by cristes
passion the night of the viij / day of april that goth before the day / ffor
the / viij / day before april of his first party is made the ix day before
april and of his last party that is the night in the which crist was holden
and buffeted and scorned. is made the vij day a fore apryll / than it follows
that crist suffered the ix day / the viij / day and the vij^ day before Apryl.
that may be showed by another reason / For every year the letter of the day
changes in the calendar / for there is one lettre more than / lij / wekys. It
is no wonder though the friday that was in the beginning of the world the
nynethe day before Apryll When Adam was made fylle after so many years the

loore of greet men Auctoryte of holy Church. and certain essaye of
calcalers 3 But as saint Austyne says above / Against reason no sobre man demeth
no Christian man demeth ayenste holy writ / no possible man demeth against
holy church Also here take heed that saint Austyn says that criste lay in
the heart of the earth three days and three nyghtes / but not all fulle and

hours / So that he lay in his grave in the last end of the first day for
to acounte the first day of four and twenty hours with the night that was to
the ffrydaye that criste deyd ynne. And crist lay in his grave holy all the
second day and in the first party of the thyrdde day And so saint austyn
says that yche of these three days had his night So that the night passed a
fore the day / thereby it seems that the master of the stories should not be

Lucas and beda Thanne marie aroos after that she had conceived and come in to

bethlem. and than the viij day after he was circumcided in a sunday / the xij

seventh day before apryll that was the friday in the which criste was conceived
to the night of the sunday in which crist was borne / were to honderd days
three score and sixtene the which nombre of days makes nine months of the moon and six days / So that every month be of thyrtty days as men acounted
in old time These nine months and six days ben assigned to women that goth
with child as yet were ten months though not all women goo with child to
this sixte day / As yet was sothe of saint Johan baptiste and of saint mary
that had one day less than crist in the mother womb R And for of the coming
to gyders of years of criste and of kings the begynnyngys and the ends ben
uncertain and full often fall great doutes in acountynge of years. And also of
the years of our lord / what year he was baptysed^ what year crist suffered death
Auctors speken dyuersly / therefore for to put away al manner doubt take heed by
bedas loore libro de temporibus. that the Romans before numa pompilius time
bygan the year in march as the hebrews don But from numaes time that put two
months to the year Ianyuere and feueryere / the Romans bygynne the year in
the beginning of Ianyuere / Holy church in the west lands folowith them in
the common calendar and in the year that is most used

But the greeks that brought up olimpias begynnen the year from the shortest
day of the winter But the hebrews beginne^ the year in march when the day and
the night ben like long / for that time the world was first made But the
Egypcians bygynnen the year from heruest Men of the eeste lands as Arabes and
caldeis begynnen the year after the gadrynge of wine and corn and of fruit
when the tethenges ben brought in to the temple in the beginning of october
when the day and the night ben y like long in heruest time as yet seems
^zechielis vision theer he speaks of the fourth month and the fyfthe day of
the month among them october was the first month and Ianyuere the fourth R
/ It is said that diverse men have diverse beginning of years and yet over
that comes diverse years by some hap that there falls and begins in
diverse times of the year that we most use as yet is of years of kingis that
begynnen to regne in diverse time of the year that we most use yet we acounte
the years of our lord in twey manner wise / other by his birth or by his age.
And also while crist was born in the end of the year that we use by the son
/ he had of the first year of his birth but seven days from the natyuy^e to
years day But the first year of his age of twelve months by his course from
the five and twenty day of december to the same day twelve months is
fulfilled the second year of his birth And so in the first year of his age he
fulfilled almost two year of his birth / And the second year of his birth is
the first year of his age therefore yet is that the years of the birth of our
lord by the course of the son be nygh four and thyrtty year and an half and
the years of his age nyghe three and thyrtty year and an half and he was
baptized in his / xxx / year of age and the xxxj year of his birth for to
acounte that year with the last party that was almoost an half year It is
sothe that criste prechid four year and specially three year and an half by the
Gospel of saint Iohan^ And so crist suffered death in the xxxiij year of his age
and in the xxxiiij year of his birth R Than in the two and forty year of
Octauianus in the which year crist was born bygan in march and ends in
march Therefore that year bygan in the thirdde year of Olimpias nine score and
fourten and ends in the fourth year of the same olimpias in the month of
march And for the wisdom of our lord ordained his birth there the greeks
begynnen the year with the olimpias / therefore the years of our lord bygynne
and end with ^he Olimpias But the years of kings and of Emperors begin and
end certainly but right selde^ therefore it is hard to acounte them with
olimpias owther with years of our lord for they begin often in one year of
the olimpias and end in another Than the kingdom of Augustus is acounted in
march And crist begins his first year of his birth in the end of augustus
two and forty year / than the xlij year of Augustus bigynneth in the first
year of the age of criste and the xliij year of Augustus in the second of the
age of crist and is xliiij year in the thyrdde and so forth

When our lord was born a well of oil sprang by yo^de Tiber out of the
tavern emeritoria and ran al a day and a cercle was seen about the son
Treuisa Knights of Rome after sixty year left deeds of arms and were called
knights of the cheualrye emerytoria and spend what they had in a tavern

The image of gold fell down that Romulus had set in his paleys and said hit

the children death he was sompned by amandemente of caesar for to come to Rome

Aristobolus For there were three herodes of great name for her evil dedes^ take heed that the first was herodes Ascolemta / And had that name of the cite
Ascalon for he fulbylte that cite. And in this herodes time Criste was born and
the children were s^ayne The second hete herodes Antipas and was the first
herodes son In his time Johan baptist was byheded and Crist suffered death The
thirdde hete herodes agrippa Aristobolus sone / Aristobolus was the first
herodes sonne^ This herodes Agrippa slow James and prysonned peter / Therefore
ben versus made Ascalonita sleth children and Antipas I^han b^ptist^ Agrippa
slow James and prisonned peter / The fryste herodes when he saw that his

and fonded to put his eldest son antipater before them both while they treted
of their fader is death they were put away and went to caesar for to plain of
the wrong that their fader had do them The mean time the three kingis come to
Jerusalem and come not ageine to herodes by the same wey^ / Herodes trowed that
they had begiled him and ^orn^d again ashamed / therefore he withdrowe his will
/ and slow not the children for to do hem to death / But f^r the citacion of
caesar / he went to Rome and come by tharses And burnt her ships for the

after the birthe of c^^ste he come from Rome and was acorded with his sones^
And therefore he was the bolder / And held the more sure the kingdom and slow
all the children of bethlem about the age of crist that he wyste was then xij
month old unto two year old and with ynne that is to menynge from the
children of two year old to the children of one night old Among the which
one of his own children was slain that was parauenture take to norysshyng But
methodius says that. that was done by gods own dome and his ordenaunce for
he that had be refte so many men / their children should be by refte of his
own children all so / For his sons Aristobolus and alysaundre were efte
suspecte For they had byhote mede to their. faders barbour^ for to kytte her
