Capitulum tercium
THis Augustus was so loved among strange nations / that the scites and the
Iuwes that knew not a fore hand the name of the Romans sent him messagers
and gifts And many kings bylde cytees in worship of him and called the cytees
cesareas Also kings went out of her own lands clothed as lords of Rome
And would run by his chaare^ And at last he hatid so werre and stryf that
he would never werre ayenste man without a rightful cause And he says that it
was the doing of a proud booster and of a light wytted man for to break surte
in stryf and disease of the people for couetyse of worship and of laureal leaves
without any fruit Also he said that no werre should be meued without cause
and great profyt lest great boost wonnen by little profit fair as a golden
fisshoke / the lesyng thereof may be quyt by no wynnyng of taking of fysshe.
he was also mylde to the cytezeyns / And true to his friends / Selde he would
receive friendship / and to hold friendship he was true and stydfast / he was
kunnyng in art and science And specially in fair spekyng. he was so besye
that no day should him escape / that he would read write or declare
rightwysenesse Ysidorus libro primo He brought up first this lettir X Me wrote
therefore / C / R / S / And he fond it up skylfully for the figure / thereof is
like the cross of crist that was born in his time Eutropius He echid the cite
of Rome with fair howses and had joy to say I fond a cite of brande tile and
I leeue a cite of marbel^ He was fair in all his body but his eyes were fairest
of al But so great and so fair a man was not al with out vices and synne^
For he was angry and might not suffer wretheful and pryuely enuyous and openly
disseyuable coueytouse of lordship and player at the dyces^ and though he were
a great eter and drynker of wine yet he absteyned him from sleep and vsyd
lechery / so that name and fame was counted thereof among the common people For
he was wont to lie between twelve such that would lightly assente to sin
and between twelve maidens also and he did away his wife Scribonia. and wedded
one linia as it were by grant and assente of her husband His sons were
tiberius and drusus and though he were a gret^ lecherour / yet he took great
wrech of lechery / Seneca^ The romans saw that this was so fair and would
have made him a god / but he forsook hit and would not assente And axed thereof
counseylle of sibilla tibur^ina and after the fasting of three days she answered
him in this manner / Token of dome earth shall wax wete by swote. out of heaven
shall come the king that last shall ever And so forth of many versis that be
not ^ere wreton

When Cynnas t^^son was know / Caesar wakyd all that night thanne his wife linia

S^tur An old man that was in peril of dome came to Augustus and prayed him of

he used for to say allas al is lost trauayl and c^ste^ But at^e last the

and bought the chough derrer than any of all the other Also a greek that was a

endytynge of praysyng and gave to the greek that had preysed him / the greek

that he never should dye. the man was like god in bataylle was noman more

run to lepe and to use of castyng / And he made his daughters use them to
wolle craft to spynne on a distaf and to make bread for they should if them
neded live by craft

Capitulum quartum
Tiberius was augustus stepsone. and wedded his daughter and biga^ to regne in
the month of september in the which month Augustus was deed and tiberius
reigned three and twenty year and somewhat of days Eutropius This first governed
the empire with great sobrenesse So that when sum men counseylled him to take
great tribute of prouynces and lands He answerde and said it falls for a
good shepherde to shere his sheep and not for to swolewe them / this was first
wise and ready ynow and gracious in Arms A man of great cunning of letture and
of castyng ever awaytynge and aspyeynge and what he nold / he made hit as
though he would To them that he loved he made it as though he were wroth And to
them that he hated he seemed goodly / he would y^ue better answer and counseyl
suddenly and without auisemente / than with great auisement He sent^ for sum
kings and made them come to him by flateryng^ and sent them never again This
was called Tiberius nere^ but mynstrals called him a faier name Tiberius mero
for he was often wine drunk Also this by cause of sum lettres that pilat
sent him would have be worshipped as god al mighty / But the Senators said
nay / and therefore he exyled many of the elder men and chees him counseyllours
and left uneath tweyne of them in good heel eer be were Emperor / he was
wise and ready in Arms But afterward he werryd by messagers Pol libro te^cio
capitulo quarto He was gre^^ly to blame in many of his deeds but against chydyng
he was s^ydfaste and said that men's tongues and hertes should be (...) in the

change procuratours that he had made ones in prouynces and in lands Me axed
why that he did soo^ he answered and said that in that doing he spared the
people for ever the less time quoth he procurators have lo^dship over the
people they ben the more grievous And preued that by ensample of one that was
wounded and set i^ the son and would not do away the flies that sat on
his wounds / thanne come one of his friends and drove away the flies for he
w^n^e that the seek man might not suffer for feeble Thou have done evil quoth
the s^ke man for the flies that thou have drive away were full and therefore they
ete well the less / But now comen hongry flies and wole byte full soore / So
new officers greue^ wors the people that is under them / Ysid li / 6 / ca. 16 /
Me s^yth that in tiberius time a craftis man had fond up a craft of t^mpryng

again and bend it and bowyd it as it were tyn / than the emperor learned of
this crafts man that there was none other man alive that so could tempre glass
And bad smite of the craftis man's head / for if that craft were known / gold
and other precious metal should be of no prys Ouidius naso the poet dyed in the

he had often (...) in plays and in stryf* Therefore the romans demed that
pylatus was profitable to the empire to hastyse froward men and stern and

/ that would with good will over them no Judge receive another suffer among

with fayer byhestes therefore he had a name of that ylond and was called poncius
pilatus / Herodes Antippas had joy of his wykkednesse and sent messagers and
gifts and drowe him to him and made him prince vnderr him in the Iewry But
pilatus at last gadred much money and went to Rome vnwetyng herodes for to
receive the office of tiberius / that he held of herodes And by cause thereof
they were enemies herodes and pilatus to the time of cristes passion when

was the emperor had an hard sickness and herd tell that at Jerusalem was a
leche that heled seek men only with a wor^e There for tiberius sent one
volucianus to herodes / that he should send him that leche Pilatus had xiij
days auisement to give his answer / for Ihs was before hand nailed to the
cross The forseid volucianus took a queyntau^ce and knowlech^ of a nobel woman
that heet veronica So that he brought her to Rome to the emperor with her
lynen clothe in the which clothe she had the printe and the lykenes of our

the emperor wist that pylatus had dampened crist / pylatus was take by
amaundement of the empe^our and brought to rome before the emperor and had / on
him cristes own kyrtel that was without semes and was callid tunica

and the iij time. but no word might be said yt him should grieve while he had on

that kyrtill was take of him and than he was put in prison and there^ he slow
him self with his own hand Of pylatus death look within in gayus last yere^
Petrus / That time were three sects of jews in the Iewry severed and departed
from the common living of other men The sects were Phariseis saduceyes and
essays that heete Assideyes also the phariseies wered and vsid hard clothing
and scarsite of mete and of drink. they determined moses law by her
ordenaunce and statutes. They bare scrowes in her forheede and in her lift
arms and called the scrowes philaterna In the scrowes were the teen
commandments wrete in mind of the law Also they had large he^mes / bound
with thorns that prycked them as they w^nte in their weye They withsayd never
their souereyns Also they hoped in a rysynge of bodies from death to live / the
saduceyes denied the arysing of bodies from death to life and said that they
noon angels were / they trowyd that the souls dyed with the bodyes^ They
heelde only moses five books And for they were to cruel and not compeynable
among them self / they called them self saduceyes that is rightful / the
esseyes lived well nygh in all points as men of relygyon and forsook wedlok. but
it were fulselde^ for they trowyd that no woman was true to her husbond^ her
clothis were clean alwey they had no certain cite before the son rysyng /
they spak no thing that was unlawful they worshipped the son when he did
arise / they spak not at their mete. they hated oaths as it were for swerynge /
they took noman to their sect but by the essay of one year if they took any of
her cite with sin / they put him away for to ete gras as beestes done in
penance to his lives end / though ten of them sat to geders none of them
would speak a word without l^ue of the nine / they would not spete in the
myddel of the company^ another in the right side They held the saturday so
holy that they would that day dress no mete another tend fire another set a
vessel out of one place to another / And also they would not cacke in the
saturday Josephus libro secundo Other days they would dygge the earth without
thwytel / and make hem a pytt and let fall here clothis about them and hele al
about when they would cacke for me should wene that they did wrong to the son
beme and when they had cacked they would fyl the pytte again with the same
earth that they had dug up of the same pyt / these leued longest of al men
for they lived starsly and deed no surfeet of mete and of drink / They trowyd
that all the souls were made at beginning and put in bodies when it were
time And sum of them would tell what was to come for they forsook flesshely
lykyn ge as it were an evil doing And despised riches Here land and what they
had was common among them all / They bargayned not among them but^ every had
freely of other what him neded they rought not of none oynementes / They
changed never hosen and shoon another clothyng but wha^ they were y tore other
spente / they held hospytalyte / they had one manner mete / they prayed before
mete and after / In her house was never herd cry another noise None of them
should not give without ordenaunce of the common spencis / they held al their
laws strenger tha^ any other he that should be received to abide among them /
after his year of essaye he should swear to keep faith to god / rightwysenesse
to men and obedyence to princes And if it happed him sometime to be above and
over other he should not mysuse his power and his might in damage and wrong of
subgettes but he should chastyse liars with all his might / To here dome should
come no less than an honderd persons the dome of hem should stand stydfast
and not be changed

Capitulum quintum
FRom the fyften year of tiberius to the first year of Adam for to acoun^e
bakwarde were five thousand years so seith eusebeus and so many years make lx*
year of grace and so by his tale the sixtene year of tiberius was the beginning
of the year of grace sixty and one / But the seventy say that from Adam to the
xv year of tiberius ^ere five thousand two honderd and xxv Bu^ the hebrews
tellen five thousand. therefore sum men wol mean that that year began the
sixth thousand for than the circumsicion seesid and cristendom bygan Other
begin from thincarnacion of crist Also that year Johan began to preche and
baptize and baptized crist the sixth day of Ianeuere the day of the showing of
our lord / And that day twelve month he turned water in to win Petrus Therefore
in old books that day is called the day of shewynges in the plurel nombre for
that day fill many diverse shewynges and had diverse names for in the same day
in diverse years were do three great shewinges the first hete epyphania and is a
name made of epy that is a booue and phanos that is showing a^^t were a
showing made from a booue as it were a ste^^^ the second hete theophania / and
that name is made of theos that is god and phanos that is showing as it were
showing made of god in baptising of crist by a douue^ The thyrdde hete
bethphania and that is made of bethe that is house and of phanos that is
showing as it were a showing made in an hows by tornyng of water in to wine R
And some men meene that that day two year was the miracle do of the five loves
and two fysshes and heete fagephania that name is made of fagyn that is ete and
phanos that is showing / for that miracle was do in fedynge of men Also that
second year as Luke and Ierom says Crist bygan the thyrtty year of age so
seyth the gospel Jesus was beginning as it were xxx year Crisostimus marianus /
And common meenyng of holy church. and Eusebius in historia ecclesiastica /
Meneth that than crist byga^ his one and thyrtty year hool and as much as was
from the natiuite to the passion time / thanne crist* the monday next after
his baptym was ladde in to wilderness by the spyryt / and bygan his fasting
and fastyd forty days And ended his fasting in a frydaye the xv day of
feuyre / that day he ouercam the devil that temptid him / in the which day the
devil had overcome and supplanted Adam the first man Than the next ester
after as true loore tells he drofe and chacid sellers and buyers out of the
temple / In the same year after he called and chees his disciples Andreu Petyr
Philip Nathanael The next year after he turned water in to wine in a xij day
And after that beda tellyth Crist and his disciples baptized in the Iewery /
And the next ester after Johan was enprysonned Also in a holy feeste crist
heled in a saturday one that had the palsy eight and thyrtty year And after
that in the same year he went up in the hill there he chees the twelve Apostles
and sent them for to preche And so it seems that three gospelers that tell
the doing of crist / after the prisonyng of johan baptist leueth untold almoost
the doing of one year before the prisonyng / but johan the evangelist speaks
less of other things and tells the doing and deeds how ihus turned water in
to wine nichodemus come to ihs by night and how ihs drofe out the sellers of
the temple / after that at third ester John was biheded wha^ he had be
prysoned al a yere^ at iiij Eester crist suffered death / Petrus C / 11. The xj
book ecclesiast^^e history tellith that Johan was byheded at macheronta a
castle of Arabia / His body was buried at sebasten that is Samaria His heed
was buried at Jerusalem bysides Herodes howse^ for dreede leest he would arise
from deth^ to live if the head were buried with the body

Mysbyleuyd men divided his bones and threw them abroad in Iulianus Apostatas
time for they had envy to the myraclis that he wrought / And they gadryd
again the bones to gyders and and burnt them and wynnewyd the asks away with
the wind / that doing sum men now acounteth as it were the second
martyrdom of the deed man / they wist not what they did In the feast of his
natyuyte while they gadryd his bones to geders and burnt them as ferforth as
they might And while mysbyleuyd men gadryd Iohans boones men of Jerusalem were
meddled among them and took with them a greet dele of the bones among the
which dele of the bones was the fyngre that Johan showed crist with Afterward
saint tecla brought that fyngre unto Alps Alps ben hye hills in Lombardy
side That finger is now in moris mynyster. as it is said but the bones were
sent to Athanasius bishop of Alysaundre In marcianus the princes time Johan
warnyd two monkys of his heed and told where it lay The monks were of the
lands and were come to Jerusalem for to bydde and pray Nevertheless the heed
was long lost by vnkunnynge and was leyde in a den in fenicia^ till that Johan
efte told where his head lay to marc^llus the Abbot that dwelled in the same
den / and than afterward the feast of the bihedyng byga^ to be holden in the
same cite the same day yt the head was fou^de^ and take up of the earth Other
tellith that it is not the feast of the decollacio^ of byhedyng but of the
collection of the gadrynge of the boones that was rather do and of the brennyng
Thanne theodosius the emperor brought the head to constantinople And thens it
was brought in to ffraunce and is often showed to pylgryms at Amyens

Capitulum sextum
CRiste suffered death seven days before apryl / cassyodorus seyth^ that day
was a greet Eclips of the son / So that none such was a fore hond nowther
after / so that the ste^^es were seen in heaven and earth schakyng In Bythinya

seems that veins and clyftes that now ben seen in quareis and in roches and

steven / philip Procorus Nychamor Timor permenas and nycholas^ Nycholas^ stood
not as he should but he made his wife common to all that would have her Eusebius
in historia ecclesiastica libro tercio This nycholas had a fair wife and was

though sum folowyd diverse lechery / yet nycholas did yet in despysyng of

and namely for his sons and daughters lived chaste to her lives end and also
^e him self took none other wife after his first wife R Of this James take heed

sone ^ur lords brother for he was most like to our lord in holiness and in

deed And there for men trowyd that ruben was suddenly deed Than Pilatus gave to
Judas al Rubens catel and he gave cyborea to be Judas wife Than in a day ciborea
made great moan before Judas of her wrechyd and sorrowful life / how she had put

how she was married against her will And so it was known that Judas had

Sequitar Capitulum septimum
GAyus Tiberius neuew of his brother germayn was called galygula for he was born
in the hooste^ He had the name of a knights leg harneysed that heete
galygula This was Emperor after Tiberius and reigned as it were four year and
nine months and was an idle disposed man And cleansed all the shame of Tiberius
/ And made men call him god of heaven and of earth / therefore he made his image
set in the temple of Jerusalem. he lay by his own sistres and gate a
daughter on that one And lay by that daughter afterward And at last he
exyled his sustres that he had lay by This the first year of his Empire
delyuerd herodes Agrippa out of prysonne and made ^im king of the Iewry
Tiberius had prisoned herodes agrippa^ the second year of his kingdom he
exyled herodes Antippa^ And herodyas that had lived in spouse brech with
herodes antipa and herodes agrippa accused them The earth swolowyd the wenche
that tombled But gayus the third year of his empire exyled Pilatus Justice of
the Iewry and sent him in to v^en that is in the royalme of france in despyte
of his king for he was born there The Jews accused pylatus that he slow me^
gyltles and that he had set images of men of strange nations in the temple
ayenste the will of Jews Also that he had take money of the holy tresory and
made a water condyte to his own house Also that he had take the stole of
prysthode in to his own hows and would not delyuere hit but for huyre to the
prince of priests in the holy days / Than be was put in prison and borewyd a
knyfe for to pare an Appel and slew him self there with and with his own hand
/ and was bound to a great stone and thrown in to tiber / than ylle spyrites
made joy with him that ylle was also and made pestylence and great rysynge of
water and great thondrynge about that place Therefore the romans drowe him out
of tiber and threw him in to rone at vien^ that place was tho granted the
plase of corsinge And also hit hete vigenia as it were via that is a way and
of Iehenne that is the valey of children of depnesse But there fill a
pestylence also and the men of the place buried him at bosane / And there also
men of the countraye were effrayed and did that body in a pytte that is
byclipped al about with hills There is yet hard grysely bear and noise In
historia ecclesiastica it is read that the Iuwes accused pilatus to tiberyus
and that pilatus was bore to lugduns in france R And that either story may be
sauede without with saying for to understand that he was born in to lugduns
after the accusacion of the Jews and that after volusianus was come again from
Jerusalem / he called him out of the exylynge for to have harder dampnacion
Eusebius and beda withness^th that Pilatus slew him self with his own hand

Capitulum Octauum
Claudius the ^ame of gayus and of drusus when Gayus was slain was made
emperor by sleyhte and help of herod Agrippa and bygan to regne in lammesse
month and reigned as it were fyften year The deeds of this be s^lde in mind
but that he made the Bryto^s subget for he gave him always to mete and drink
and lechery out of mesure And cast him to make a law to excuse all that
behind let go a blaste / for sometime he spared it to much and fell in great
peril Josephus libro visesimo This claudius had three wives / the first hete
pet^na and he gate on her a daughter that hete Antompde / petina deyd and he
wedded messalina / And gate on her a sone that hete britannicus and a daughter
that heet octauia / his / third wife hete Agrippa germanicus daughter and she
had a sone that heete nero Claudius wedded his daughter octauia to this nero
and for love that Claudius had to this Agrippina / he slew hi^ wif messalina
and when she was slain claudius in triclinio sittyng at mete used for to speak
as though he were out of mind and axed why his lady messelina would not come
Agrippina drad lest B^tannicus the sone of messalina should regne after his
fader And therefore she poysened claudius for her son nero should be Emperour^
And nero quyt his mother that triacle when he was Emperour^ For he poisoned
brytannicus and slew his mother and his own wife octauia R Of the forseyd
messalina speaks iuuenalis satiricus and says that ^he was so lecherous that
first she did her pryuely to the pryue harlattes place and / afterward she
put her forth openly and went thens not fulfylde of the manner doing but weary
of trauaylle and also she exyted noble wives to the same manner of doing Beda
libro primo capitulo quarto That year was the great honger in (...) that Agabus
the prophet had prophesied in Actibus Apostolorum Petrus 81 While this hongre
was strong in every place of Siria and in the Iewry most / helene the queen
of adyabenes come to Jerusalem and bought corn al about for to sustain nedy
christian me^ at Jerusalem / and at las^ she made two vnryels and heete burye
therinne her body and her sons body the buryels been yet seen / therefore
many ben disseyued and trowith that there is the buryels of helene /
constantyns moder^ for me^ read of her that she come to Jerusalem and highte
the cite in many things Also that year powle come to Jerusalem to talk with
peter of the gospel. Also that year the fyftene day of Iuyll the Apostles were
departed in to all the world about Than peter come to rome and sent marcial to
lymonica and appollinaris to raven and marcus in to egypt This marcus of
leuyes kind was peter's sone by baptym and his disciple and come to Rome with

approved and took it to be rudde in chirches Thanne marcus was sent in to
Aquileya there he converted much folk At last he was sent to Alexandria in

C three score and seven he was translated and brought from alexandria in to
venys / this kyt of his tho^be sometime lest he should be made priest other
bishop but goddis ordenau^ce had the maystry and auctoryte of peter that made
him bishop of Allexandria Beda libro primo capitulo quinto King guiderius
reigned among the brytons and warned the romans trybute / therefore claudius
caesar come and conquered brytayne as it were without bataylle and great noise
of grutchyng was arered in brytayn as it seems for her men that fled were not
restored again He come in to an Ilond there Julius caesar durst never come
another other man after him Also the ylondes orchades that been beyond brytayn
in the sea of occean / he made subget to the empire of Rome and turned again

And this hamo deyde before hamoes haven that was so called by his name that is

guiderius brother to his grace and brought his daughter genuyssa from Rome and
married her to king Aruiragus And for he would make the place of the marriage
solemn he called it claudyocestria by his own name R Claudyocestra hete
caertleon in brytyssh speech that is claudius cite / But after that it was
called glocestre and glouernia also And had that name of the duc of demecia
that hete glora Me says that claudius caesar gate him there at gloucestre Than
claudius sent legyons of knights in to Irlond^ But he turned again to Rome
and aruiragus withdrowe him and would not be under the romans Therefore
vaspasianus a duc of Rome was sent and made the king of the kingdom and the

Rome Herodes Agrippa when he had grieved sum of the holy chirche^ he come in
to cesarea for to make pleyes in worship of caesar And there to let him self be
called god / therefore an Angel smote him and his body swal and he said to his
friends / Lo I that was called god / now I am right fully bounden with bonds
of death and so he dyed Peter ca 60 This herodes Agrippa was Aristobolus sone /
Aristobolus was the sone of the great herodes ascolonita and his suster was
herodias her oldest eam^ herodes Antipas the foresaid Aristobolus brother This
herodes agrippa was a man of great heart a great w^rriour and fre of gifts but
he was pour He come to Rome while Tiberius caesar liuede for to geete another
tetrarchia that is an other fourth deele / of the kingdom of Jews and had
great friendship of drusus tiberius cesars son and obleged him self for much
debt for to win the will of the Romans But drusus was hastly deed and
therefore tiberius caesar was sorry that he did al drusus servants out of his
presence lest drusus death come to his mind by syghte of his servants
Therefore hi^ happyd that herodes Agrippa went again to the Iewry / as it were
a man without comfort and for shame and for need and for meschyef he closed
him self in a toure that he might dye for hongre but at prayer of his suster
herodyas he was releued by herodes Antippa But herodes antippa repreued him in
a time for the good that he had do him / and herodes agrippa had indignacion
thereof and went to tiberius caesar and gate grace of him at last and leefte
with gayus Germanicus sone / In a time he sat with gayus in his chaar and
wyssched that tiberius the oldman and vnnesy were deed that gayus might be
emperor The charyoter herd that and warned the emperor And therefore Agrippa
was prysoned six months unto the death of tiberius caesar. While this Agrippa
was in prisonne one of his prysonners that was kunnynge in dyuynynge warned
hym^ that he should be sone delyuerd out of prysonne and be a king so that
his friends should have envy to his welthe. this dyuynour dyuyned so while he
saw an owl sit upon the tree that Agrippa lened to And said that as soon as
he saw efte such a manner bird sit above him he should dye the fyfthe day
after / When tiberius was deed gayus delyuerd Agrippa and gave him two
tetrarchyes of philip and of lisania and crowned and called him king / Therefore
his suster herodyas was wroth and had great indignacion for her husbonde
herodes Antippas that was retrarcha had not get him the na^me of king and she
excited her husbond herodes Antippa that he should goo to gayus and beye the
name of a king but gayus was warned before hand by lettres of Agrippa and put
herodes to lugduns in france And for herodyas was Agrippaes suster / she had
choes where she would goo again other follow her husbond / And she chees to be
exyled with her husbonde and said that she would not leave her husbonde in his
meschyef that she had followed in his bonechefe And so the third tetrarchia was
take from herodes Antippa and give to herodes agripp^ At last gayus was
slain when there was stryf between the senators and knights and the people of
Rome^ For the senators drad the cruelte of the emperor and the disauauntage
of the comynte. And the people dradde the couetyse of the consuls / thanne by
sleyght of Agrippa claudius was made emperor and anon he gave herodes agrippa
the fourth tetrarchia that is Judea And so herodes agrippa was made great and
went again in to Iewry And afterward there he slow James and prysonned
peter Than he made plays at cesarea as it is said before hand and swal and was
ete with worms and deyde / And left after him two other lygnages and an half
beyond flume Jordan his sone herodes agrippa was not callid herodes but only
agrippa To him christian men fled afterward out of Iewry when the cite should be
take and destroyed / Saint mary our lords mother deyd the yrre of her age three
score and three for in the birth of her sone she was fourtene year old and
leued with her sone three and thyrtty year Afterward sixtene year as sum men
wol mean and so she was take hens when she was sixty winter old and more /
for men say that the apostles preached after crist in the Iewry and in the
countries about full twelve year. Philip the apostel was nailed to the cross in
the cite Iherapolis the year of his age three score and eyghten^ Lasarus the
first bishop of cipris deyde in his second death and had four and twenty year
between his two dethis Felix procurator of the Iewry was sent by claudius
before this felix / powle was accused and appeled for his offense to the
emperor / that time were many falls prophets Egesippus libro secundo Also that
time were many shrewyd swerd men in Jerusalem and were meddled among the people
and slew many men so subtily and so pryuely that no man could them aspye / so
the dread of them that lived was more grievous / than the meschief of them that
were deed Therefore many men went in to wilderness for to have refute and
socour Claudius died at Rome in his own palis. the year of his age three score
and four as it were in the month of march for his wife Agrippina slew him
with venym for to put of his sone brytannicus and to make her own son Nero
emperor

Capitulum 9
NEro the sone of domicius and of Agrippina gayus suster had wedded claudius
daughter and bygan to regne and reigned almoost fourten year / this was most
curyous and crafty to work with Iustrumentes of music. so that he had joy
and likyng to be openly called prince of harpers Also he had great likynge in
the swetnesse of his voys that absteyned him and spared al manner mete and
drink that was not good for the voys and not only he did that but also he
used often c^isteryes and vomytes when Nero bigan to singe / no man was so
hardy to goo out of the theater er he had made end of his song And he was al
ruled and lad by ledyng and counseyll of mynstrals / And for he was most
covetous of al emperors / he used so to say / he that is above all has need
to all but yet it grieved him not to give mynstrals all that he had And he gave
them all the Worshippes ^f the cite of Rome Suetoniu^ He wered no cloth twyes.
he used shosoles of silver / he fysshed with nettis of gold / the nettis were
draw with ropis of reed silk Also for this be would see the likeness of
troy when it was set a fire he set a great dele of Rome a fire that burnt
seven nyghtes and seven days / And he began to cry and singe the gestes of
troy Orocius Also he was so lecherous that he would be w^sshe with hot
oynementes and cold Also he wedded a man for to be his wife and he bycame
another man's wife Also he let kerue his own moders womb for he would see
the place that he was conceived ynne Martinus Phisiciens blamed him for he had
defowled his own mother And he answered and said / but ye make me goo with
child ye shall be deed euerychone tha^ they made him swelle with drynkes and
made him vnwytyng drink a frogge And at last after much woe and sorrow / he
delyuerd him and cast up a frogge / But the phisicians said that the child
was born before his time / And therefore it was so vnthryuyngly and so euel
schape. But nero made this frogge be kept in a tour to his own lives end
Therefore sum men wenen that lateran has that name of the frogge that loted
there for latere a latin is lotye and be hid other unknow in english and
rana in latin A frogge in english Also nero made him an heaven of an honderd
foot hye and bored and thyrlyd with many small hooles / and it was born up with
four score pylers and ten of marbel stone he leete fall water thereupon / that
dropyd down as it were rain that falls from heaven He made also a lamp
brennyng be drawn in to that heaven by day that yede a down westward as it
were the son And he made a myrrour set with precious stones that shone by
night as it were the moon But al these were by gods ordenaunce so suddenly
distroied so to rusched and to broke that thereof was never gobet found another
cromme Also he made a carre with iiij whelis be draw upon that heaven so that
noise was herd as it were the noise of a great thonder but god almighty sent
a great wind that threw the cart in to the River Eutropius Nero slew many
noble men and linia octauians wif his own mother Agrippina and his fader suster
and his wife And Seneca the philosopher of cordij be^ Lucanus came was neroes
master / and axed couenable reward for that he had be neroes master / and he
had choys in which bow of a tree he would be an hanged Seneca axed why ^e
had deserved that manner death Than Nero made one to scarmuch about seneca^s
heed with a bryghte sword and saw that he was wonder sore aferd And said as
sore as thou art aferd of this sword As sore I am aferd of the And yet I am as
sore aferd of the as I was sometime while I was a child And therefore while thou
art thou alive I may not be without dread but ever in great drede^ therefore
Seneca chees what man death he would take and chees to be late blood in a bath
and to dye in that man / and as it were by a forbedinge he had that name seneca
/ for seneca a latin is he that sleeth him self in englyssh / this seneca had
two brethren one of them hete julius gallo and was the best declamator of al /
he slow him self with his oun hand / the other brother hete mela lucanus the
poets fader also this lucanus when he had made his book of the harm and
damage of strif and discord bitwene cyteseins and thereby he brought nero to
acorde and mildenes yet by heest of nero he was slain in bleding by kittyng of
his veins as it is sayd^ Pol / li. 8^ Some ben bold and hardy to despise this
seneca and for to ground him upon the auctorite of quintilianus but me seems
that they doubt for he was worthy to be homely with poul and ierom rekeneth him
among holy seintes this seneca had noble wit to learn and to teache and had
great studiyng and great knowlech of things and well nigh al mat of study of
wit and of science he had and wrote resons of poetry and nigh al manner
philosophy and in euy doing he was good and true keeper of virtues and enemy of
vices and of synnes^ so that it seemed that he made worlds of gold and gods
acorde with ma^kinde / also he made books de beneficijs de cleme^cia
declamaco^es tragedias de na^libus q^stio^ibus and de tuscula^is / de casibus
fortuitis. Ierous de viris illustribus / paul appeled to the emperor and was

/ bisshops that were ^elpers to tech the feith of holy chirch / linus was one

percius satiricus and poet dyed / R / There were mo poets than satirices.

/ Isid li 8 ca / 7 / The office of a poet is for to tell thyngis that been

howses and Maumettes heyer than other bodies so they trowid that gods should

Capitulum 10
GAlba Seruius reigned after Nero vij months y chosen of spaynerdys and Galls

Also david was lever take in se ipso wreche than live and see the people

He is feerful that will not dye when it nedith It is a woman's stalworthnesse

Capitulum 12
TItus reigned after his fader as it were three year This was most noble speker
of g^^e and of latin and wrote causes in latin and poesyes and gestes in grue^
they that were conuicte of conspyracio^ against him were as homely afterward
with him as a fore Pol libro tercio capitulo 14 This was so fre of heart that
he purgyd and cleansed the couetyse of his fader so that he was called the love
and the liking of mankynde^ Also he had always that manner that no man that
come to him yede from him without speed or hope of speed Therefore men of his
hows axyd him why he would byhote more than he might perform There should no
man said he go ^lynge and sorry from the answer of a prince / Ones at a soper
he bythought him of that saw and bithought him also that he that day gave no
gift in help of any man and was sorry and said Alas my friends this day I have
lost In the time of his death he was born in a lyter and looked up in to heaven
and said that he nedid not to think of none of al his deeds but only one / but
what deed it was noman wyste. About that time dyed Iulyanus bishop of
cenomannens Me says that he was simon leprosus the mesel that crist heeled and
he received crist in his hows and lodged him after the assencio^ of our lordr
he was bishop of cenomannens ordained by the Apostles or by here disciples And
he was a noble man of vertues^ And rered three men from death to life. Sum men
would mean that this is he that men that trauayleth by the way prays to for
good lodging for crist was was herberuhd in his hows But it seems more
sothely that it is the other Iulianus that vnwyttynge slew both his own
fader and mother Of him it is certain wreten in this manner Iulianus was young
man and went an huntyng and chaced an heart and the heart turned his face to
him and said thou chacest me and thou shall slay both thyn own fader and mother
Than Julian drad sore and for to beware that / that meschyef should not befalle
Julian forsook and left all that he had and put him self to a great prince in
fer land and bare him well and nobly under that prince both in battle and at
home in his palais And bare him so that he was made a knight and wedded one
castellana a wydowe that his lord gave him to wife Than his fader and his mother
sought Julian in every land And it happed at last that they came to Iulians
own castle and when Iulians wife had talked with them / she knew well that they
were her husbands fader and mother and received them goodly and leyd them for
to rest in her husbondes bed and went her self to church at morrow erly and
left them both a bed Julian came erly home and fond them sleep both to
gyders in his own bed And trowyd that another man had lay there by his wife /
and stikked them both thorugh out and went out and met with his wife* And than
he knew that he had slain both his own fader and mother. as the heart had
said that he should Fare well my leave suster quoth he for I shall never rest
er. I wete if god wole take my penance and forgive my sin. God forbede said
she that I should forsake the in this manner in woe and in sorrow and have be
pertinet with the in joy and in welthe / Than they went forth to gyders and
made an hospytal by a river where men passed often and were in great peril there
/ they halpe men that passed and socoured pour men Long after in frost time
Iulyan was w^ry and rest him about mydnyght and herd a voys cryeng and
pray^ng of help over the passage Julian aroos and fette over the pour man that
was ney deed for cold and brought him in to his hows and made fire and set
him thereby / but for all the fire the man was never the h^tter / than Julian
did him in his own bed and hilled him with clothis / And withynne a little
while th^s man that seemed so cold and a vile mesel was white and fair and
styed up in to the air and spak to his host Julian and said / Julian / Julian
Our lord Ihesu crist sent the word by me that he has received thy penance
And sone afterward both Julian and his wife went al to our lord to endels rest

Capitulum 12
DOmicianus vaspasianus sone reigned fyften year and five months. his wife hete
first Augusta and first he hyte to call him self god and lord This forbade
geldynge of men and plantynge of vynes in the cite of Rome that exyled many of
the senators and put mathematicos and philosophres out of the cite of Rome and
bylde a temple of Rome without any timber. that temple hete pantheon and was
bylde in worship of all gods / there is now the church of our lady that
hete sancta maria rotunda that is saint mary the rounde^ Sometime this had the
vyctorye of Germans and of danes / and was so proud therefore that he would
suffer none image set in worship of him / but it were of clean gold Treuisa
Ma thematic^s is he / that has the science that tretith as it were of length
and of bread and tell thurugh such length and bread be none body^ that men
may grope and feel and so it fares often of arsmetrike and geometrye Pol This
man was unprofitable in every deed and did no thing manly as a man should but
that he bare only the name of the empire But for he would hyde the lewydnesse
of his wit and of his body under the name of a prince. he ordained him every
day a pryuy ydelnesse / and used him to catch flies and stykked them with a
sharp poyntel / so that in a time one axed if any man were there ynne with the
emperor nay said his cha^berlyn metellus-th^re is not a fly. left with the
emperor / This gave two months of the year new names and callid september
germanicus and october d^micianus Anacletus of the nation of Athene was pope
nine year in Clementes stead when clement was exyl^d / eusebius called him
cletus but he ouerlepe him in his cronyke / Damasus the pepe writes to Ierom
the cronyke of bisshopes of Rome and withsayd that saw and said that cletus
was a romayne and anacletus a greek also in many other things eusebius cronik
varyeth from chronicles of other men This Anacletus ordained that priests should
be worshipped before other men and not trauayled ne grieved Eutropius Cornelia the
cheef maid of the temple of the goddess vesta was conuicte in lechery and
buryed^ quyck a live Anaristus after cletus was pope ten year / this ordained
seven dekens that should k^pe the bishop while he preached lest enemies of
trowth would bear him wrong on hand and say that he err^d And also for they
should not lightly be herd nor he despised When d^micianus was slain of his
own men and dispytously born forth among thieves Nerua the mylde prince.
regne^ after him one yere^ and vndyde the deeds of domicianus / And all they
that were exyled were reconsiled and come home again And so Johan the
evangelist come home again to ephesym out of the isle of pathmos Coiyllus
marius sone was norysshed at Rome from his childehode / and reigned in brytayn
and paid trybute to the romans and ladde his life in pees R So^me men suppose
that he build the cite of colchestre which is chyef cite of estsaxon

Capitulum 13
VVlpius crinitus traianus was born in spain and was emperor nyneten yere^
among his friends he was free of heart and besy in deeds of Arms and esy in
gouernynge of cyteseyns and mighty in reuelyng of cytees and towns. He
chastysed the danes Scytes Sarmates hiberes. Colches and Arabes. he ordained a
nau^y in the reed see for to werre in Inde / He made him self every man's
felawe and vysyted often his friends for he would be salewed of hem and wete how
they ferde. he grieved no man he did no thing wrongfully for to have the more
esche^es but be made his servants rich that them neded to greu^ no man / his
friends blamed him for he was so common to a^le manner men / he answered and
said / I will be such an emperour^ to other men as I would they were to me if
they were emperour^ R Helymandus says that in a time traianus was lepte to
horse for to goo to batayl for the comynte / And there come a wydowe weeping and
took him by the foot and prayed him that he would do her right and justice of
hem that had slain her son / I shall do the right said the emperor when I
come again. what said she if thou never come again Thanne sayd^ the emperor
my successors shall do the right / what pro^yt said she shall be to the if
another man do me good^ thou art dettour to me / and thou shall resseyue as
thou deseruest by thin own deeds. And so it is fraud for to yield not that is
du^^ when it may be yolden Thy successor shall fare well if he bear him well and
do as he should Traianus was meued by these words and light down of his horse
and did the wydowe right and Justice And therefore he was worthy to have an
image in rome Also on a time Traianus sone rode on a wild horse and slough a
wydowes son And therefore traianus yaue his own son to the wydowe for her
son And by cause of this gre^e right wysenes it seems that saint gregory wan
his soul out of hell Creuisa So might a man wene that were wors than wode or
out of right believe When euariscus was martrid. Alexander come after him and
was pope ten year. he ordeygned holy water to be blessed with salt and to be
spryngt in christian menni^ houses. he put in to the mass / Qui pridie quam
pa^eretur / And so forth unto these words hoc est etc Also he ordained that
water should be meddled with the wyn in the chalyce for to bytokene the onyng of
crist and of holy chir^he / And he ordained that the oost should be of therf
bread and ^f little quantite / and seyde the scarser this oost be the better it
is Simon that hete symeon also cleo^has sone / the less James successor was
nailed to the cross in the church of Jerusalem. And all men (...) that so
old a man of six score year might suffer that passion Ignacius bishop of
antyochia Iohans disciple was brought to Rome and thrown to wild beestes^
And while he was tormented he cried alwey besyly Jesus / Then after his death
his heart was hewn in to small gobeites And in every gobbet was fou^den jesus
wreton with lettres of gold / the second plinius nonocomensis a pleter and a
writer of stories was in his flowres^ he was master to traianus the emperor /
and refreyned him in many things and in especial that he should not persecute
ne grieve christian men Also this not withstondynge the knyghthode and chiualrye
that he vsede alway^ yet he wrote seven and thyrtty books of the storye of
kind in the which he descryueth clerly the world and all that is therinne^ At
last he went for to search and enquere the cause of the grauel that is in the sea stronde which is alayed with heepes of grauel as it is sayde^ After the
passion of Alysaundre the pope sixtus was pope almoost enleuen year / he
ordained that trisagium that is sanctus / sanctus sanctus should be song at
mass And that the corporas should not be of sylke nether sendel but clean lynen
clothe not dyed and that no woman should handle no towelles of the auter And
though men read that Alysander suffered death in adrians time ^ yet then was
not Adrian Emperor / but perauentur consul or prefect. In this trayanus time
placidas master of knights went on huntyng and met with an heart having
bitwene his horns the crucifix which said to him that he his wife and his
children should suffer much woe and sorrow And after this he was crystend and
his wife and his children / and he had a new name and was named eustace
Cassiodorus This Traianus deyde in the flux in Selencia the year of his age /
lxiij His bones were in a golden vrne or pot and buried in the market place
under a piler that he had made of an honderd and four and forty foot high^
Loos and mind of him is so spronge that yet in our time men pray in plesyng
of princes / More gracious mo^e thou be than (...) was Augustus / and better
than traianus*

Capitulum 14
ADrianus helius Traianus cosyn was Emperor one and twenty year and ten
months / he was connyng in the langage of grue and of latin and made in
Athenes a lybrarye of wonder manner werke^ He was conning of music of physic
of payntyng of grauyng of meltyng and of castyng of brass / and of other
metal^ When books of our believe were wreton by one quadratus the disciple of
thappostlis and by one (...) of athenes^ Adrianus bad and commanded by his
lettres (...) christian men should not be dampened without trespass put against hem
and proved / he made many laws / but he had great envy to the noble loos
and renomme of traianus^ So that he forsook the prouynces that traianus had
wo^ne^ as siria / mesopotania and Armenia / and purposed to have left dacia^
but his friends caused him to change his thought / Also this Adrianus overcome
the Jews that were eftsoon yet rebel and chaced hem out of ierl^m And put
therinne men of other nations and since that time the place where crist suffered
his passion is within the north walls of the cite of Ierl^m / which was to
fore that time without the walls / In this Adrianus time the philosopher
secundus was flouryng which put him self to silence and would not speak to his
lives end. And the cause of his scilence was this / he had (...) and study^d
at scole of Athenes and herd of the vnstydfastnes of women And therefore in a
time when he come home and was unknown of his friends / he thought tassaye and
prove the vnstydfastnes of his own moder^ and yaue to a wenche ^er servant
yeft^s and she brought him pryuel^^ by night unto his moders bed Then his
mother bygan to (...) him and comfort him for to have to do with her / nay
mother said he it is not sitting to me to defowle that place from which I came
of / why / said she / who art thou. I am said he secundus thy son / And when
his mother herd that she deyde forthwith for shame and sorrow / Then he saw
and understood that his mother was deed by his defaul^e in speaking and
t^llynge what he was unto her and made great doole and sorrow / and auowed
never to speak after / and so he never spak after but lived as a d^mbe man to
his lives end / And held his auowe unto his lives ende^ so that he would not
sp^ke for man^ce ne for fair bihe^tes and yet he was brought to fore Adrian
th^mperour^ but speak would he never as it is wreton in ^he questions that he
wrote in his scylence time / the lefforus the pope was a greek after sixtus
passion he was pope xj year. he ordained the lent (...) be fasted to fore
cester. And that noman should sing mass to fore the hour of vndern - and that
men should singe three masses with gloria in excelsis on crystemas day. That year
Eustace that to fore was called Placidas was martred and his wife and children
That time the three maidens fides spes and caritas and her mother sapiencia were
martred at rome ^ Adrian the emperor deyde in campania in the dropecye ^ That
time Aquila of the ylond pontus was flourysshynge^ He was the second after
seventy that turned holy wryt out of hebrew in to grue After the passion of
Thelefferus Igynus a greek philosopher of Athenes was pope four yere^ he
ordained the clergy to be rewled in order and in degree Also he ordained that
no Archibisshop should condemn his suffrygan but in sight and in heeryng of
other suffrigans and bisshops of the same prouynce

Capitulum 15
ANtonius pius with his sons Aurelius and lucius was Emperor two and twenty
year / he had such a name that in all his kingdom he withhelde the caucions of
his dettour and foryaue the dettis. And therefore he was called the fader of the
countreye. And m^ said that he would say often in this manner Me is lever by the
ensample of Scipion save one cyteseyn than overcome a thousand enemies ^ His
daughter faustina saw sword men fight and cast so great love to one of them
that she was seek for loue^ And she told it to her own husbond Marcus
Antonius / Then by counseyll of phisiciens of caldea that sword man was
slain and faustynas body enoynted with his blood And so the sorrow cesed^
Also many men of strange nations did of her armure / and put the causes of
her stryf upon Antonius and were ready for to stand to his ordenaunce and dome
/ Ieronimus de viris. In his time policarpus bishop of ephesim that was
disciple to Johan theuangelyst come to rome and converted many men out of
their heresye / And was afterward burnt in his own church. After Iginus pius
was pope fyften year. At his prayer hermes wrote that book that is cleped
pastor / therinne it is wreton that esterday should not be hold but on a
sunday by bidding of the Aungele that showed him in the clothing of a
fyssher / About this ^yme Tro^tus pompeus of the nation of spain was in his
floure^ / He wrote the stories of all the world from Nynus time king of Assiria
unto the time of the hoole lordshippe of Emperors in xliiij books / his
disciple Justinius abredged those books This Justinius was a pleder and a writer
of historyes. Also this justinius wrote the book de cristiana religione to
antonius pius And thereby he made him the more goodly After pius Anitetus was
pope as it were ten year / he badde that clerks should be shaven round about
and have no long locks Galyen the phisicien that was born at pergamus was in
his flowers at Rome^ he expowned ypocras books and not only them but he made
many volumes of his own Me says that for reasonable abstinence that he used he
lived honderd and forty year / he ete never ne drank his fylle nether ete raw
fruit. He had always a sweet smellyng breath / he deyde for age and for non^
other evil That time hirmeus episcopus lugdium was flourynge he expowned many
books of holy wryt And ptholomeus a connyng man of the science of mathematyke
was in his flowers he made more of astronomye than was made to fore his time.
This man was of strange wacche and of little mete and had a sweet breath. he
made many b^okes that been named Almagestus perspectiua and in Iudicijs
quadripertitum and centilogum Among his prouerbis tweyne ben famous and noble
he is heyghest among men that retcheth never / who has the world in hand. and
other men ben not amended by him that is not amended by other men

Capitulum 16
MArcus Antonius verus and lucius comodus the sons of Antonius pius regneden
after thryr fader eyghten year These tweyne were both joined by kynred^ and
affynyte though they were not both born of one womb / For marcus Antonius had
wedded Antonius pius daughter / And lucius comodus had wedded marcus Antonius
doughter^ and so by these tweyne the Romans begone to have twey emperors
This marcus was never proud for none hap that might befalle to him he was so
stydfast and so sad that from his childhode he changed never his semblaunt for
sorrow ne for ioye^ also after the bataill that he did against the germans
sclaues and sar^^tes he had spent all that was in the tresory and had naught
for to give unto his knights / yet him was lever leye to wedde his vessels of
silver and of gold and tharaye of his wife / than grieve prouynces lands and the
senators Therefore when the vyctorye was won he recouerd all that and much
more and paid the pryse of the valewe to hem that would yield ayene that they
had bought other received to wedde / And was not wroth to hem that would not
yield again that they had bought or received to wedde / he relesed many
^^^butes to prouynces and lands. the tables of the dettes that men o wyd him
he burnt in the myddel of the cite Cruel laws he attemperid with new
ordenaunces and constitucions^ In his time egesippus flouryd the writer of
stories and of destroyenge of ierl^m / his book was wreton in grue and Ambrose
turned it in to latyn^ Tho was the maid praxedis flouryng after that she had
buried many martires she prayde our lord that she might pass after hem and
her boon was herd / In this Emperors time wa^ (...) great pestylence and death
that the host of rome was nygh destroyed / so in a time the emperor fought
against the quades and his men fayleden well nygh for drink and god almighty
sent hem rain fro heue^^ but the contrary befyl wha^ lightnynge fered the
germans and sarmates / Gaufr / About the first year of this marcus lucius
coyllus son bygan to regne in Brytayne / Gaufr and alfr / he sent lettres to
elentherius the pope for to resseyue crystendome / and his bone was graunted^
and britons held and kept hoolly that faith and believe unto dyoclysian
themperours time / After Anitetus sother was pope nine year / he ordained that
a menchon or nonne should not handle the towayllis of the auter neither do
ensence in the sence^ but she shall bear a veyle on her heed / also he ordained
that no wife should be holden lawful but she were blessed of a priest. After
sother elenthe^^u^ was pope xv yere^ he ordained that christian men should not
Forsake ne forbere no mete. that is skillful and reasonable for mankind / and
that no man should be degraded ne put out of his state and of his degree but he
were lawfully accused to fore hond / and he said that our saueour wyste well
that Judas was a thief and his traytoure^ but for he was not accused he was not
put down / but all that he did in the mean time among thappostlis for the
state of his dygnyte it was allowed and stood ferme and stable / also this pope
at prayeng of lucius king of brytons sent forganus and damianus that
crystned the king and the people and made bisshopes and Archebisshops instead
of flamynes and A^cheflamynes that mysbyleuyd men hadden in steed of
Archibisshops and bisshops / And this crystendome dured in brytayne ij^C year
and sixtene unto dyoclisians time when saint albon was martred

Capitulum 17
AFter marcus lucius comodus was emperor? thyrten year / This comodus was
unprofitable to all things and yaue him al to lechery and harlotrye / he made
to slay many senators and christian men and cleped the monethe of septembre
after his own name. Also he was deffamed by the shrewdnes of his wif and fought
in Amphiteatre with short swerd men in the hows of the gods vesta / he was
strangled at last and dyede with so great wrath and de^pyte that he was
demed enemy of mankind / Tree uisa / Amphiteatrum is an high round place for to
se about / Then it follows in the sto^^ that be sent philip the noble
burgeys of Rome in to egypt This philippes daughter eugenia with twry sons
prothus and Iacinc^us went a way in a mannys wede vnwetyng her fader that was
not in the believe and she was cristned and was called eugenius and made a monk
/ And when the Abbot was deed / Eugenius was made Abbot in his stede^ At last
a woman that hete melencia cast a lecherous eye upon Eugenius and would have had
eugenius to lie by her^ And by cause eugenius would not assente / melencia
diffamed eugenius and said that eugenius would have leyn by her by strength
against her will. wherefore eugenius was take and brought to her own fader philip
/ then she kytte and slytte her clothes and showed that she was his own
daughter eugenia / and shewede that there were prothus and iacinctus y gelded.
when her fader saw that he was cristned with all his meyne / And melencia that
had her deffamed was suddenly burnt with a stroke of lightnynge: After
elentherius victor was pope ten year. Anon he sent lettres to theophilus of
Allexandria and to all the brethren that were there that they should gadre a
counseyl for to ordeyne the very holding of esterday / Marianus li^ 1. ca 2.
ffor after that the apostles were deed unto that time as cristemas day is
hold the vij day to fore ^anyuer upon that day ever it fell. so all the men
of gallia held the esterday the vij day to fore april upon what day of the
weke someuer it be fell as it was first bygonne and take for to be hold
Eusebius in his storye tellith that men of the eest lands held esterdaye the
fourten day of the moon upon what day it ever fylle in the month of march In
this counseyl and sinode was pope victor and narcisus patriarch of Jerusalem
and hireneus bishop of lugdium / there it was ordained that esterday should be
holden the first sunday after the xiiij day of the moon of the first month
that is march / (...) esterweke should dure unto the xxj day of the same moan
so (...) thylk day be acompted in the ester weke / Theophilus of cesarea halpe
much in this ordenaunce. Theodocius of ephesym was that time holden a noble
man he was the thyrdde that turned holy wryt out of hebrew in to grue / after
comodus hilius pertinax was Emperor six months Him sl^we Julian a connyng
man of the law and so he took thempyre by strength but he was slain of one
seuerus anon after the seven month

Capitulum 18
AFter Iulianus Seuerus of Affryca of the countray that heyghte tripolis was
Emperor sixten year / this was made emperor and no mo of Affryca first this
was an eschetour and steygh up by diverse offices and dygnytees unto he was
emperor / He was right skars and stern of kind / he overcome the parthes and
the arabes. and therefore he was called perthicus and arabicus / he made a wall
in brytayne that stretches six score mile and tweyne unto the sea / and he
deyde at york Beda libro 1 This seuerus governed the comynte myghtly / and with
great trauayl^ And at last he went in to brytayne and made a wall of turues
and not of stones as sum men wene and departed brytayne by that wall / he dalf
up turns of the ground and made up an high wall / so that to fore the wall is
the dyche that the turues were doluen out / thereupon ben pyght strong poles
and stakes of tree / he strengthed often that wall with many toures and deyde
afterward at york and left after him twey sons basianus and geta / But geta
was Iuged for a common enemy and put to death / basianus was callid antonius and
had the kingdom / Gaufr Lucius king of brito^s dei^e without children and was
buried at gloucetre / then fyl stryf among the britons and the power of the
romayns^ therefore seuerus the senator with two legions was se^te in to brytayn
/ he made a wall at cost of the comynte between deira. and albania that been
the north side of england and Scotland He made the wall against fulgencius king
of pyctes and fought afterward at york and was slain and buried there and left
after him two sons / one hete geta. his mother was of Rome. that other heet
bassianus and his mother was of brytayne. Therefore was great fyghtyng between the
two brethren and geta was slain and bassianus had the kingdom Gaufr The
brytons chose bassianus for his mother was bryton / but the romans chese geta
by cause his mother was a romayn / and so they fought and geta was slain R But
eutropius says in the story of rome! that geta was slain at cite edessa when
he fought against the parthes

But gaufr / in the story of brytons says that geta was slain of one caransius
a tyrant that frayed with him / Symachus was tho in his floures^ ^e was the
fourth that translated holy writ out of hebrew in to grue he was of the
samarytes and turned unto the Jews law and was^ made proselitus that is when
he is turned fro another law to the Jews law / Eusebius libro sexto / That
time was narcisus flowryng bishop of Ierl^m It is wreton that he was a right
true Judge and stydfast and would not bend but always hold the troth and give
true sentences / therefore three men that were culpable in hem self feyned a blame
and accused the bishop and brought forth hem self for wytnes / the first
prayed that the fire of hell must brenne him but it were sothe that he said /
the second prayed that the kings evil must de^troye him but if it were sothe
that he said. the thyrdde prayde that he must lose both his eyes but it were
sothe that be said / But the great eye of gods ordenaunce brent the first
witness as he had prayde and all his hows therto^ And destroyed the second
wytnes by the kings evil / the thyrdde saw how his felawes sped and dr^d full
sore and knowleched h^s trespass to sore all the people and wept so many teres
and so often for that sin and trespass that he lost both his eyes / After the
passion of vyctor Zephirinus was pope ix year. he ordained that every christian
man of xii year old and above should every yer ones receive the sacrament and
be hoseled on esterday / He made many omelyes and epistles and so of his
making is the legende on childermasse day and begins Zelus quotendat and so
forth and also of the decollacioon of seint john /

Eusebius libro sexto Saint leonydes Or^gn^s fader was martrid at alexandria
the first day of march his son origenes a child of xviij year that hight
adamancius also cast for to follow thensample of his fader / but by
thordenau^ce of god and besynes of his mother the child was kept to full great
prouffyt of many men / for she hid the childs clothes that night that he
would have goon out on the morrow. therefore the child wrote a letter to his
fader how he was holden at hoome by sleyht of his mother and prayde his fader
that he would be stydfaste and hold forth that he had bygonne. while this was
a little child he axed often questions of his fader / and axyd how holy write
was give to us by thinspiracion of the holy gost^ and what of gods counseyll
is hid in holy wryt in symplenes of spekyng and of words / Hit is said that
often when the child was a sleep the fader would vnhele the childs breast and
worshipe it a^ it were gods temple and kiss it full swetely and say that well
was him that gate ever such a child Then when the fader was martryd the
child was of eyghten year age as a fore is said / when his fadris catel was
taken be thescheters / he and his mother that was wydowe and his eight brethren
were left in great pouert and meschyef Than at Alexandria he held a gramer
scole for to have lyuelode for him and his But ever among he turned men to
christian feyth and halpe and socoured hem that were poursiewed and brought in
meschyef and conforted hem that were lad to death for the faith of holy chirche^
he vsid much waking and fastynge^ he followed the sayng of the gospel that
counseylleth that me should not have two kyrtels ne care for the day that comes
to morrow / So that if le knew any that kept of her own catell to live by he
refused hem and would not have hem in his loore / he went many year without
hosen or shoe^ / Alwey he spared wyn but if it were for helping of the stomak
In his yougth he did one deed that seemed of vnparfight wit but it was a
token of a full believe and of parfyght chastity as the gospel says / sum ben
ghelded that ghelde hem self / for the kingdom of god Therefore not only by
cause of chastyte but also for he should preche to men and to women pryuely

Mame^ Alysander themperours mother desired to here orygenes speak and stute
after him that he should come to her out of alexandria unto antiochia This
orygenes without other had seven young men and seven maidens that wrote
diverse books and matters as he yaue hem to (...) by his own mouth he wrot^ ^o
much that Ierom knowlechyd that had red of orygenes books four thousand
volumes without epistles that he had written Hit was a proverb of him. Such
was his loore such was his life / he slepte upon no bed / he tasted nether
flessh ne wyn / Giraldus Orygenes was neygh the grettest of holy wryt^^^ if he
not erred in so much speech / And as all the latin (...) folowen ennius so
all expositours folowen orygenes Also in hi^ manner he translated the bible in
to grue Also he fonded to amend the translacions of other doctours^ of Aquila
/ of symachus and theodocion And there they had more than was in hebrew he made
a sign that heyght ^belus / and is shappn endlong like a rod / And there
they had^e less than was in hebrew or spak derkly^ he made a sign that is
called Asteristus and is shape like a s^^^re Ieronimus epistola 41 There
orygenes said well. noma^ said better and there he said evil no man said werse
And when he passyd well nygh all other doctors in his other books. he passyd
him self super cantica canticorum / he spoke a thousand tretys in church and
made exposicions without nombre and called hem themos / if any that follow him
put error ayenste us he may take heed that the great homerus slepte sometime /
for in a long work it is lawfu^l to sleep sometime / we shall not follow his
vytes if we may not follow his virtues Therefore if one of his books be defowled
which book heyg^te peryarchon. whe^^nne he understands evil of the fader
and worse of the sone and worst of the holy goost^ And there he said that cast
will sometime thurgh^ his great mercy save the angels that fill down fro heaven
And he leyth for him that verse of the saw^^r / god shall not be wroth for
evermore / nether manace without end Shall all his books for this be
destroyed / he him self orygenes in a pystle that he wrote to fabyan the pope
of Rome makes sorrow for he had wreton such things / And put the cause of
that fo^e upon one Ambrose that put forth his books that be had wreton priueli
and made him common er he had corrected and amended them My friends said he
have done me this^ If I hold my pees / I shall be holden gylty And if I answer
I shall be holden an enemy / either condition is hard / but of the tweyne I
shall chese the lighter / About this time the fyfth translacion was founden in
a town at Ierycho That translacion is callid vulgata the Auctor (...) is
unknow It semeth^ that the common sauter that we use is taken of that
translacion though we follow Ieroms translacians in other books of holy wryt
But Damasus the pope made the church of rome follow Ierom also in the sawter

Sequitur Capitulum 19
BAssianus Antonius seuerus son reigned after his fader seven year. this was
callid marcus aurelius and carakalla also for a manner clothyng that he gave at
Rome And therefore bathes that he made at Rome ben called caracalane This was a
right evil man and sharper of manners than his fader and he was vnsuffrable of
lechery R So that he took his own stepdame Iuliana and wedded her to wife Of
the place and manner of his dyeng auctours discorden as it is said to fore hand
Gaufr and Alfr While this bassianus reigned one caransius that come^h of the
lowest blood of brytons was a noble man of cou^ceyl and of hand ^he gate of
the senators the keeping of the costs of Brytayne^ for that time frensshemen
and saxons werryd thereupon but when (...) had gotten his axyng he did more
harm and damage than proff^t to the comynte For he byhete to the britons that
he would (...) and chase the Romans out of the ylond if they would make him
king Then he slough bassianus and (...) the kingdom seven year For the
pyctes that fulgencius the ^nc bassianus moders brother had brought out of

Capitulum 21

^risten man of al themperours / and was ^^istend of saint poncius the martir^

Capitulum 22
ORosius says that decius was Emperoroure three year ^ud three months / But

Capitulum primum
MArcianus wedded theodocius suster and was Emperor seven yere^ In his first
time was the cou^ceyl calcidonense made against entices and dioscorus as it is
said to fore hond At last this marcianus was slain at constantinople by
conspyracye of his own men

And the hunes and wandels destroieden the cytres of gallia that stood upon the
ryn / that time vortigerus reigned in britayne. and then fyl so greet plente
of corn and fruit that none such plente was seen in none time there to fore.
And with that plente lechery and pestilence of al evil doing bigan to encrece
cruelnesse and wrath / not only in seculer men^ but also in the flock of our
lord and in the herdes and governors of the flok of our lord were both strong
and great: so that every man turned his spear against the true man / as it were
ayenste the traitors of brytayn / and they yaue hem to dronkenes / fyghtyng
staf and enuye^ then suddenly fyl so great pestylence on the men of evil
living / that they that were left a live might v^meth burye them that were
deed / but they that were left a live / were not sone amended thereby. therefore a
gretter vengeance came afterward For vortigerus and his cou^seyl took hem to
read and sent after paynyms of saxon and prayed hem to come fro byyond the sea
to do hem help and socour / It is unknown that it was gods oune deed. for
harm should fall upon wicked men / Gaufr / and alfr. Vortigerus drad the
pictes that he had grieved to fore hond and in the other side he drad the
coming of aurelius ambrose / for he had herd that he had made ready his
ships for to pass the sea / therefore be coueluded to send for the saxons
that were noble men of war and strong in batayl / Beda li^1 / Then the
saxons strong men of arms and having no place to dwell in. were prayed of the
brytons for to come in three long ships that they call obylas in to brytayn.
and resseyue a place to dwell in in the est side thereof in the ylond thanet
beside kente as it were to fight for the contray / but it was more for to fight
and war against the country / W / de. regibus / Well nygh all the land that
lies northward over the sea occean of britayn is called germania. for it
brings forth so much folk / germania comes of germinare that is for to borge
and bring forth

Therefore as water bows ben kutte and hewe^ of trees for the fatnes of the earth
should suffice to the lif of the other dele of the tree So men of Germania releue
that land that is her mode^ by putting out of men that been strong to
fight. lest they should (...) overcome with to many children if they should
all a^yde at (...) me. But for to couere the envy of doing / they say that
they (...) sent out by lotte / therefore it is that men of that land makes him
strength of need for to challenge strange lands to dwell (...) / when they

And as they came of woden^ So well nygh all the kings lygnage of strange
nacious come of this woden And for as much as the saxons held him tho for a

and the sixth day friday in worship of his wife frea Thus they did by

Capitulum 2
VAlentinianus augustus his time is acounted to the course of theodocius and of
martinianus Eutcopius. He dradde the fortune of Aecius and patricius. and made

that ^e spared brennynge and manslaughter and took prisoners and Riches of the

bishop of the cite nola when that he had spente all that he had in raunsons of

AFter marcianus leo reigned xvij year In his first year vortimerus vortigerus

Capitulum tercium
TEno the emperor reigned after leo seuenten yere^ In his time deyde childericus
the fourth king of frenshem^n / and after him his sone clodenus lewys reigned
thyrtty year / This in the fyften year of his kingdom while he ladde his hooste
/ and should fight against a great nombre of Almains / he looked in to heaven and
said lord Ihesu crist whom my wife worshipeth if thou give me this day the
vyctorye I shall be crystned in thy name The Almayns fled and he and his two
susters and three thousand of his men were crystned on an esterday of saint
Remigius bishop of Raynes^ And for they had no crysma. Lo a down brought hem
in his bylle a vyole with crysma / and the Bishop enoynted the king therewith
That vyole is kept in the chirch of raynes / and with that crysma the kings
ben enoynted. sone after this while the king went to a batail against one
aladericus that warryd in guyan Remigius took him a flaket full of holywyn and
promised him vyctory and said / Goo forth as long as this wyn dureth / Then
the king drank and his servants and the wyn failed in no place Then he
occupied guyan and passed the river of leyr and tu^one / and in saint martins
church he herd that verse of the sauter / Precinxisti me domine virtute ad
bellum^ that is lord thou have byclypped me with virtue and strength to
bataylle Therefore the king was glad with all and arayde him for to pass the
forde of the River vincenna / but the water began hugely to arise. And an hynde
appiered suddenly and passed the water to fore the king and shewde him the forde
/ Then the king made the kingdom of france stretche unto the hye hills of
Aragon that been called montes pireni Therefore the emperor anastasius herd of
his name and sent him a crown of gold rychely besette with precious stones
with a kyrtell and a gyrdel^ And fro that time he was assigned to be consul and
Augustus for the common prouffyt of thempyre And he was clothed in a consuls
gown / And from that time the empire of Rome that was sometime translated to
constantinople bygan to wax less and less from day to daye^ And the kingdom
of france bygan to sprede and wexe more and more When Gisericus king of
wandels was deed his elder son homericus reigned in Affryca eight year by
sleyght of strange nations. this began first to do myldly with christian men /
But at end he commanded to put fyry plates to the breasts of holy maidens /
by cause they should knowleche that bisshops and clerks had leyn by them /
Also he put a great multitude of christian men in a strayt prison for they should
let fall vryne and foul ordure each upon other / and so it seemed that the
stenche thereof passed all that other pain About that time saint medarde and
