double bataille and saved uneath his oune bounds / But when he was older he
brought all the kings that were nygh him under his yok out take the kings of
northumberlond. then he wedded a Frenssh woman that hete berta / and by
ensample of one letardus a Bishop that come with berta^ He was much exyted
for to leave and forsake his wild manners / At last he herd saint Austyn
preche the loore of holy faders and forsook his cursyd laws and made good
laws in the langage of the land. in the which laws he promised mede to good
men and peynes to evil men and wicked / And deyde the year after that he had
received the feyth of boly church one and twenty / Martinus After pelagius the
third Johan was pope thyrten yere^ that time prescianus the gramaryen of
cesarea was in his flowers at constantinople / he made noble books not only of
gramer but also he descryued all the world in a book that he called
Cosmagraphia / Of him it is said as Hugucio capitulo / edo edes Tells that
he become apostata and forsook the feyth for love of his disciple Iulianus /
Also that time one Arator a subdedene of Rome and a wonder poet made the book
Actus Apostolorum all in versis of six fete. And saint Brendan Abbot of
Irlonde was in his flowers that time. Of him ben many wondres radde. and
specially of his purgatory that is in the west side of I^lond Also that time
seynte Steuens boones were brought to Rome and leyde by saint laurence in the
same place / Thereof speken Cronyckes of Rome and legendes of holy saints and
tell that when saint Steuens boones were brought thither / saint laurence
boones turned on his side. and had leyn up right always to fore hond^ but
then he turned him so for to give place and stead to his felawe saint stephen

Capitulum septimum
AFter iustinianus the second justinius reigned enleuen year That man despised
pour men and spoylled the senators and yaue him to couetyse so that he made
cofres of iron for to put in his tresour / And fyl at last in to pelagius
heresye and lost reason and good mynde^ but he ordained one tiberius a mylde
man to govern thempyre Beda libro tercio capitulo tercio In this princes
first year one columba preeste and abbot come out of yrlond for to preche to
the north pictes that were departed from the southe by hye hills and downs /
for the southe pyctes were converted to fore hand by ninianus the bishop of
the nation of Brytons and he was sent thither therefore But he was first taught
right well at Rome^ his see was at candida casa. that is the white hows there he
lies and rests / And then that see perteyned to men of brenicia / Marianus
libro secundo / Badius a mighty king reigned among them tho / Beda vbi supra /
Then Columba come to the north pictes and received of hem the ylond hij that
was as it were of five meynes to bylde there an abbay that was heed of all
thabbayes that be bylded / So that ylond uses always to have him that is abbot
and preeste to rule and to govern hem^ So that all the ppouynce and the
Bisshopes also ben subgette to that Abbote and preeste in a manner order that
is not used elleswhere^ And that by ensample of her first Doctor Columba that
was not Bishop but preeste and monk After his coming two and thyrtty year he
deyde and was buried there and left after him noble disciples / But they were
in doubt of the eester term and followed the cycles an honderd year and fyfty
unto the year of grace seven honderd and fyften

Then came to them one egbertus a priest af English nation that had been
long exyled in yrlonde^ It was no wonder for the decretes of synodes of the
holding of the Eester tide come not yet to hem^ for they were set f^r as it
were out and over the Roundenes of the world Paulus libro secundo Narses
patricius was sent. of Justinius in to Italye and slough Totila king of goths
and restored the state of thempire but the Romans had so great envy to him
/ so that they sent to justinius and said it was better to the Romans for to
serve the greeks than the goths / Here narses patricius was emperor. Therefore
thempecaur was meued and put his prefect longinus in narses patricius stead /
and the empress sophia augusta sent to narses a dispytous scorn that he
should return in to constantinople and that he should with his wenchis and
with wymens wit find cost and woollen thredes / Me says that he answered
thereto and said that he would warpe such a web to the empress that she never
should have it to her lives end / then he went in to naples in Campania /
and sent the longobardes word that they should leave the pour feldes of
pannonia and come in to the Rich lands of ytaly and so they did The
longobardes came in to ytaly the morrow after eester day / the year of our lord
five honderd lxviij Then was the kingdom of ytaly vnyoked and delyuerd of
the yock of constantinople^ And the Romans were afterward rewled by patrycies
/ R. There Albuinus king of Longobardes assailed ytaly / Fyry hoostes were seen
in heaven that cast onte man's blood as it were lyghtnynge / therefore gregory
speaks in an Omelye / Also in Ligurgia were wonder tokenes y seen in houses in
doors and in clothes / and if any man would wesshe hem away^ they were the more
seen / And after a yer in men's channels at nether end sprange out as it were
akehornes / and after that came a brennynge fever and slough men in the space of
three dayes^ therefore men fled and left not at home but hou^des^ No tylyer
of the land were left in the feldes ne in vyneyerdes the places of pasture
were turned to buryels and sepulcres / Day and night men herd in thayer / now
trompes now grutchyng as it were of an host that passed / but stappes nether
forowes were none seen. Paulus. li / 5 / The longobardes have that name of
their long berdes^ they use to shave of their here of her heed fro the molde
to the nolle / but to fore they had locks hanging down to the mouthe^ they
used large clothes and long and specially lynen clothes as english saxons
were wont to use with broad laces wouen with diverse colors / they used hye
shoon up to the kne y slit to fore and lacede with thwonges^ her hosen tylled
to the hamme and y teyd with layners al about The first year of her coming
her king Albuinus besyeged the Cite papye three year and took it at last and
occupied al Italye / reseruyd Rome Paulus libro secundo. when the king albuinus
roode in at est yate of the cite of papye / the horse that he sat on fylle
down under him in the myddel of the yate^ and might not be raised though he
were prycked with spores unto the time that the king had revoked and releced
an harde^ auowe that he had made. he had made his auow that all the people
that would not yield hem should be slain with swerdes / Then Albuinus reigned
in ytaly three year and six months and deyde at last by treson of his wife
in this manner This Albuinus dwelled in pannonia sometime and overcome the
gespydes^ and also their king and made him a cup of the kings skulle for to
drink of / that manner cup is called Scala among hem and pathera a latin
Also he wedded Rosamunda the same kings daughter. that he had sleyn And at
cite verona in ytaly at a great feste he made his wife Rosamunda to drink of
that cup whether she would or noo^ and prayed her to drink with her fader^ And
she had great indignacion thereof and awayted her time when the king was out
and laid her self pryuely in the bed of a damoysel That a Duke of the Kings
loved specially / the Duc came to that bed / and supposed that she had been
the Damysel * and lay by her Then she spak to the duc and said wost thou
not what thou have done / Sekerly thou have do such a deed now that thou
shall slay my husbonde Albuinus the king. or thou shall be slain with his
sword and so he slow the king For Rosamunda in an under tide bond so fast
the kings sword / that tho slepte^ that it might not be drawn out of the
scaberde by cause the king should not mow help him self / when that other came
to slay him Then when the king was slain the sleer fled and went with the
queen to Rauenna. and after that they had dwelled there a while / Rosamunda
saw a right fair young man that was prefecte of the cyte^ and loved him out
of wit and by cause thereof she yaue her husbond venym for to drink / and anon
the duke felt the strength of the venym / and drough out his swerd and made
his wife drink that other dele / and so they deyde both^ but sum men tell
that when Rosamunda was slain One parideus that wist of the first treson come
out of Raue^na in to constantinople and slough on leon in presence of
the emperor in common spectacle^ where men stood for to byholde pleyes and ne we
thynges^ But for he should not cast ayenste the / Cite / The Emperor made to
put out both his eyes. but sone after he took two knyues pryuely in his
sleues / and feyned that a secret cou^ceyll for to tell to the emperor / And
the emperor sent him two pat^ricies that were preuy with him / and the
forsayde perydeus slough hem both at one stroke / In that second year of
Justinius ethelbertus king of kente yaue a bataylle to ceaulinus king of
westsaxon and his brother cutha / but they chaced him and slow two of his dukes
of wyl^aldoun^ And that was the first battle that was between the Saxons That
year cutwulf king ceaulinus brother fought strongly against the Brytons at
Bedford and took fro them four cytees lygauburgh / Eglesburgh Besington and
euesham and deide the same year That time deyde saint german bishop of paris a
noble man and full of miracles When he bygan to wax s^ke he saw on the wall
ayenste his bed thus wreton / Four days to fore maye^ and thereby he knew
that he should dye on such a day and so did / and was buried in the meadows
bysyde paris Chilperitus the seventh king of France deyde al so that same
time After him his sone Lotharius reigned four and fyfty yere^ The Poet
fortunatus of ytalye a clear man of wit and sharp of connyng soft and sweet
of speech wrote saint martyns life in iiij books in meter and versis of six
fete / and was afterward Bishop of turon / In this Justinius seventh year was
fulfilled the great cycle of the eester time / that conteyneth five honderde
year and two and thyrtty from crystes passion. so says marianus 560 But fro
the beginning of the world five thousand lxv year as sum men suppose

Capitulum Octauum
Tiberius constantinus was Emperor seven year / This was myldest of all men
and yaue the tresour of the palace to pour men / therefore his wife blamed him
often. And men say that he answered her in this manner / I trust in our lord
that money shall not fail us at our need if we put our tresour in heaven Then
he passed in a day besides themperours palace at constantinople / and saw a
cross graven in the pauiment of marbelstone And him seemed that he was not
worthy to trede upon it with his fete and specially upon that that should be
prynted in the forhedes of mankind And took up that stone / And saw another
grave in the same wyse^ and then he saw the thyrdde in the same wise grau^
and took it up and found there under tresour without end / Pope Johan deyde /
On his tomb it is wreton in meter in this man Bynam worshipe thought and word
Johan besyly thought / with will to plese god. that all thing has wroughte
After him the first benet was pope four year / he brought many thousands of
mesures of whete in ships out of Egypt / and delyuerd the cite of Rome fro
the meschyef of honger while king Albuynus besieged that cite. Therefore they
wrote in his tomb in meter in this manner / Fader benet thou benet thou live
greten mind / Title of virtues fayrenes and gretene sorrow Marianus. That year
Ceaulinus king of westsaxons overcome the Brytons and took of hem the famous
cite gloucetre su^cetre^ and bathan cestre. Also that year saint maurus deyde
the year of his age lxxij / he bare his maystres saint benettes stole on his
neck as long as his life lasted After benet pelagius was pope ten year

Capitulum nonum
MAuricius was emperor one and twenty year a good christian man of believe He
ouercam the perses and the Armenyes^ but at last he discorded fro saint
gregory. so that he spak much evil of him and founded to do him to death / And
then was seen a man in Rome clothed in monks wede with a sword y draw in
his hand that cryede in to all the cite in this manner Mauricius shall be slain
The emperor herd this and amended him of his evil deeds and prayde god that
he would withdraw that dome Our lord showed him self to mauricius in his sleep
and said / wylt thou that I spare the here. either after this life Lord said
he thou love wretches that been here in meschyef / yield me here as thy will
is Then when mauricius was in the eest lands and founded for to forbede his
knights theft and robberye and yaue hem not wages as he was wont to do /
therefore the knights were moeuyd and made one foca Emperor against him and
Foca slaugh mauricius and his three sons whiles he fled in an ylond Marianus
libro secundo That year ceaulinus and his son cutha fought ayenste the
Brytous at Fechaulege but cutha was slain there and ceaulinus had the byctorye
Beda libro primo Elle king of deyra deyde the one and thyrtty year of his
regne / And Idas sone ethelbertus reigned fine year both in deyra and brenicia
That year were born in france three brethren / Ado / Bado and dado / Dado
heete Audoenus also / Afterward he forsook chyualrye^ and was made bishop of
Roan Paulus libro quarto About this time gu^tranus king of france went an
huntyng in to a wode / and his men were disperpled hither and thither on every
side / And the king wexe wonderly slepy and leyde him self to sleep / and
slepte in ones lap that was most preuy with him / Then crepte out of the
kings mouth a little be and would have passed a little lake that there was fast
by^ the secretarye in who^ lap the king slept saw that and drow out his swerd
and leyde it over the lake and that little be passed thereupon in to that
other side and went in to a cave of an hille and abode there a while and came
again the same way upon the swerd in to the kings mouth After a while the
king awoke and told his secretarye that he had y met a wonder sweuen^ and
told that he met that he passed an iron brydge^ and fond great tresour in
an hille

Then his secretarye told him what he had seen and done then they tweine
went to gyder and dug greet tresour in that cave of that hille / Of sum
of that tresour the king made a great covering as it were a shryne and cast
for to send it to Ierusalem^ but he was let of that purpose. and did hit
over the body of saint marcel the marter in the cite cabyllona Beda libro primo
The holy fader Columbanus with saint gallus and other noble disciples come out
of Irlond in to burgoyn and bylded there the abbay luxonium by leave of
theodericus the king / but he was driven thennes by brunmylda the queen and
come in to Almayn / and builded many abbayes that yet ben famous there and
resseyne but yrysshe men to monks. there columbanus left gallus and came in
to ytalye and build the Abbay bonum / That year fill so great rain that tyber
wesshe the Walls ol Rome / and cast up a great multitude of serpents and one
great dragon^ and the stenche of hem slew many men in the cite Also there come
a pestilence of evil in the channels of men at neder end / that pestylence
slow pelagius the pope. that pestylence was so wood that it slow men in the
weye / at mete at playeng and in talking and often slow men with gal^ynge and
snesynge / thereof it comes that men use to say when they fnese. god help the
and when he gapeth to make a cross to fore his mouth / For this pestylence
saint gregory tharchedeken of Rome ordained seven manner letanyes to be said on
saint marcus day For he set in the first the clergy^ in the second abbotes and
monks in the third abbesses with their menchons / in the fourth children in
the fyfthe lewdmen^ In the sixthe wydowes and the seventh wives Beda libro
primo capitulo visesimo tercio Gregory was pope thyrten year six months and
ten days / he made many noble beokes / thereof quadraginta due omelie / omelie
super eua^gelia dominicalia moralia super Job / Omelye super principiu^ et
finem ezechielis Registrum pastorale dyalogorum and builded an abbaye in his
own hows Also in all the chirches of Rome he ordained fasting every day in the
lent for foryefnes of sins Also he mae all the heedes and lynmes of
maumettes y cut of. and in the canon of the mass he putto / Dies que nostros
in tua pace disponas and so forth Also he was the first of all popes that
called him self and wrote in bulles^ Seruus seruorum dei / that is servant of
the servants of god* Also he ordained in the Synod and counceyll at Rome.
that the mynystres of the auter sbolde take heed to prechyng and not to
syngyng. and said that while me axith a sweet wys in holy seruyse / Couenable
life is set a part and the syngar with his manners pricketh the people / though
he plese hem with his voys / And though saint gregorye were most holy yet he
had bachiters and enemies that would have burnt his books after his death / but
his deken pers had sworn upon the book and by peril of his soul and wytnes
of his owen death that his books were endyted by inspiracion of the holy ghost
That year Ceaulinus king of westlaxon and oryda were slain. after him
calfritus the sone of his brother cuthulphus reigned strongly fyu^ year / after
him his brother colwulfus reigned xiiij year. Beda li / ^ / ca. 5. Ethelfridus
was ethelricus sone and Ethelricus was ydas son This ethelfridus bygan to
regne over the northumbres and reigned nobly four and twenty year This was right
strong and desired great worshipe and destroyed the Brytons more than all the
Angles princes and made hem tributaryes. he had by his wife Acta king else
daughter seven sons and one daughter that hete ebba Tweyne of his sons
highte Oswaldns and oswyns Beda libro tercio capitulo tercio Columba deyde this
time that was abbot and buyred in his abbaye in the ylonde hij Beda libro
quinto / ca. 9 He had a name made of acella and columba and was called
Colunkillus Beda libro primo capitulo visesimo tercio Also that year the great
gregory sent Austyn the Monk to preche the word of god to englysshmen / And
Austyn was aferd and drad in the wey and turned again to saint gregory / And
gregory comforted him and sent him with lettres to the bishop are latensis
that he should help austyn in what that him neded^ The tenoure of thylke
lettres and of other lettres that were sent to the king of kente and also
answers that saint gregore gafe to Austyns questions ben wreton in Registro
gregorij and in beda Paulus libro quinto Also that year the longobardes by
night assailed seint benettes abbay in the mount cassinus / but the monks
fled to Rome and took with hem the book of the holy rule and a weight of
bread for the iourneye and a mesure of wyn that here euinia^ Of this meschyef
benette warued hem before hand and prayde god and had it granted uneath that
men of that place should be sauf / In the River nylus at ylonde delta. the
host of Rome saw mermyns in lykenes of men and wymen that were so seen from
the morrow unto the euentyde That year Austyn came a land in the eest side of
kente in the ylond ^ thanet So^me men call that ylond den^e / there he came a
land with forty felaws and sum men interpretours to be with hem out of the
land of france by counseyll of gregory^ Saint Austyn sent these
interpretours to kyn ge ethelbertus the year of his kingdom six and thyrtty and
said they were come out of Rome for hele and sauacion of the king and of his
Royamme The king herd this / and had herd to fore hand of the same of christian
feyth^ For he had to his wife a christian queen that was a Frenssh woman And
had resseyued her of her fader and mother upon that condition that she should
use and keep christian feyth / Then after somewhat of days the king come in to
that ylond-but he spoke with hem without the hows under the welken / In that
doing he used the mysbyleue of mysbyleuyd men and in his coming they areysed
up the baner of the cross with a crucifixe y peynted on a table and song the
letanye and preached the wrod of life Then the king spak to hem and said It
is fair that ye promise / but for as much as it is new I may not yet assente
And by cause ye ben come fro far for my sake we shall spare you and find
such things as shall be nedeful to your lyflode

And we shall grant you l^ne also to turn of our men to your feith as many
as ye may / When they herd this^ they went with procession to the cite and
song alleluya and said Lord we pray the in all thy mercy that thy wrath be
take fro this cite And so they went in to the Cite Dorobernia that is
Caunterbury / And ladde their life as holy faders did in the beginning of
holy church. in fasting / in waking in bedes byddyng ande in prechynge of
gods word and song masses and crystned in the eest side of the cite in
tholde chirch of saint martyn unto the time that the king was converted and a
great dele of his people The king was converted and yaue his doctor a place
for the bisshops see at crystes church with many possessions and builded
thabbay of saint peter and paul in the eeste side of the cite. Austyn and his
successors and also the kings of kente were wont to be buried there Beda li /
26 ca / 2 / In the mean time Austyn went to tharchebisshop Arelatensis and was
sacred Archebisshop of him / Saint grego^e was certefyed thereof and sent to
Austyn moo helpers / Mellitus. Iustus and paulinus and books and relyquyes of
holy saints and answers to saint Austyns questions / Such were tha^swers as
the church of Rome uses of al goods that fall^e that tho goods should be
deled on four parties / One to the bisshoppe. and his meyne to find hem
herbegerye and such as they need / The second to the clergy / the thyrdde to
pour men^ the fourth to the amendment of chirches To hem that lyuen in common
/ all thing is common. And what there leueth shall be spended in deeds of mercy
^ To the second that is axyd while the feyth is al one / why ben there so many
diverse vsages in chirches / herto it is answerde in this manner / what thou
knowest^ is most plesynge to god almighty gadre thou to gyders and make that
to be used in chirches of Englonde^ Things ben not loved for the place / but
the places ben louyd for good things Colwulfus the son of cutha ceaulinus
brother reigned in westsaxon fourtene year That time in the subarbis of
constantinople come forth gree^^ meruaylles and wondres / for one child was
bore with four feet and another with two nolles and moldes That year saint Iue
the bisshoy that was born in perce deyde in England Beda libro primo That year
Austin by commandment of gregory made two archebisshops one at London and
another at york / In the mean time by help of ethelbertus gadred hisshops and
doctors of brytons to gyder in a place called Anstyns oc. that is Austyns
strength / that place is in the march of the wiccies and of the west saxons /
And there he charged hem that they should preche gods word to the Angles
with him. And also that they should amend sum other errors among hem self
and specially of thusage of the eester time / And they withsayd openly til it
were showed by an open token which party should be holden / then was a
blind man brought forth of the nation of Angles that was heled and had his
sight by the prayer of austyn^ for brytons failed in that deed / When the
brytons saw that the blind man had his sight they knowleched that saint
Austyns way was true / But they said they might not forsake their old vsages
without assente of hem that used the same Then be gadred a synod / thereto
came seven bisshops of britons with the wysest men of that famous abbaye of
bangor But first they had a counseyll of an heremyte that they should assente
to austyn if they fond hem meke and mylde as Crystes disciple should be / And
that they might know if Austyn would arise against hem when they come in to the
synode^ Austyn satte stylle in the bisshops chayer and roose not. therefore they
forsook him in great wrath Then saint Austyn seyde assente me specially in
three things / if ye wole not assente to me in the other Assente to me and
hold the eester day in dew time and give ye crystendome in the manner of the
church of Rome and preche ye gods word to the Angles / and that other dele
I suffer you to amend anonge your self / but they would not thereof Then saint
Austyn by inspiracion warned hem and said / that they that would not resseyue
pees of her brethren should ress^yue of hem war and wreche and afterward at
gods own dome. Hit was fulfilled by Ethelfridus king of northumberlond when
the people and the monks of Bangor were slain at chestre

Capitulum decimum
AFter that mauricius was slain Focas reigned eight yere^ Ethelfridus king of
northumberlond fought ayenste Edan king of Scotts at dexsastan and had a
solemn victory / but theobaldus the kings brother was slain and the hooste
of all that be ladde Beda libro secundo. Also that year the holy fader saint
austyn in a mydwynter day when he had cristned ten thousand Englysshmen in
the weste River that is called swale besides york / he knew that he should
deye and ordained him a successor one laurence / while he was alive him self
for the state of holy church in Englond^ that was yet rude and boystous / And
that he did by ensample of saint peter that made clement his helper and his
successor / Also he ordained mellitus bishop of estsaxons / The River thamyse
departs between hem and kente / her chyef Cite was london in the which
Ethelbertus king of kente builded saint paulus church / for to be cathedral
church and the bisshops see R Another cronyke seyth that sebertus king of
eest angles made paulus church in lond^n / and he made Iustus bishop in kente
at cite dornbres that now is called Rochestre. And had first the name of one
rufe / and is bywest dorobernia that is caunterbury three and twenty mile / In
the which cite of Rochestre king ethelbertus let bylde a chirch of saint
Andrew Also the great gregory deyde that year After him gaminianus was pope two
year / he ordained that the hours of the day should be rongen to at chi^ches^
And he sp^k evil of gregory^ for he had made to great cost on pour men
Therefore saint gregory app^ered to him thryes and blamed hym^ And ^tte fourth
time by cause he would not amend he smote him on the head / and then he a
woke and yielded up the ghost Also that year in wales saint dauyd deyde that
hete dewy also^ he was bishop of mene^ia that now is called saint dauyes
About that year deyde saint Johan the Amener patriarch of Alexandria / ones to
him in his prayers appiered the fairest maid that might be crowned with olyue
and called her self mercy and promised him that he should speed well / if he
would take her to his spouse. And fro that day forward Johan was the more
merciable. So that all pour men he called his lords Therefore it is that saint
Iohans hospitalers call pour men lords / Also this Johan had all the pour
men's na^es of his cite written in a book Also he used twyes a weke to sytte
all day to fore the church door for to a^orde men that were in stryf^ In a
time he had seten there al day / and saw no man pleyne then he groned and
said / who is me wretch for this da^ / was I not worthy to do no good deed.
yes said the dekene / this day thou sholdest be glad and and make great
joy. for now men ben made right as Angels without strif Also on a time while
the gospel was a reding the people went out of the church for to talk and
tell tales / and he went out also and sat among hem and said where the
sheep be / there the herd shall be / then goo ye in to the church and I shall
goo with you / or if ye abide here I shall abide with you

And after that he taught hem for to stand at Church in the mass time ^ And
Johan in his prayers was often herd as it were speaking with god almighty and
saying so so / Lord Ihesu^ thou yeuest largely and I dele forth / look who shall
have the maystrye After Saminianus the thyrdde Bonefacius was pope eight

couetise when riches is more loved than god almighty / the thyrdde is the fire

fendes threw on him a man that they termented in fire / And therewith furseus
sholder and his cheke were burnt / Anon furseus knew that man / and knew
that he had resseyued his cloth when he deyde / the angel that lad furseus
threw that cloth in to the fire / and the fend said throw not away that
which thou have to fore hond approuyd / For thou have received the goods of
synful men / so thou shall be partener of their pains. nay said the angel he
received it not for couetyse but for sauacion of his soul / and then the
fire ceced / and the angel said to furseus what thou have set a fire that
has burnt the / then furseus was brought to his body again. the same mark
and tokene that he had felt in his soul / he bare alwey after seen on his
sholder and cheke Afterward as often as furseus told this tale though he were
right thynne clothed in the myddel of the cold winter. he should sweet for
dread / At last furseus left that abbaye to his brother fullanus and he
went with another brother vulcanus and lived heremytes life al one year / then
that prouynce was anon destroyed by rennyng and reyses of strangers and he
sailed in to France and deyde there after many great deeds of virtue and was
buried at perma. After honorius Seuerinus was pope one yere^ In his time the
Jews were conuertyd and turned to christian feyth Heraclius the emperor after his
noble vyctoryes erryd out of the feyth and that by cou^seil of Cirus patriarch
of Allexandria and of Sergius patriarch of constantinople And Eraclius deyde in
the droposye / and was shende with the heresye of the Iacobytes that were they
that mysunderstode saint Iame thappostle /

Capitulum / 14
About that time lived machamet the false prophet duke and leder of Sarasyns
and of turkes^ his story is brought in this manner / But steven of caunterbury
and girald of cambria helpen much in this matter. Sometime while thempyre of
rome was in great might and strength. Crystendome was nyghe wydder and more
than thempyre of Rome was in great might and is no wonder. for crystendom was
so encreced that it contained Europa and many prouynces of Asia and well nygh
al affryca within his merkes and bounds. At last by d^scorde and stryf of
christian men between hem self / It was do that that Agarenes wexe strong / the
agarenes have three names and ben called agarenes Ismalytes and saracenes / of
her empire prophesied methodius the martyr and said that christian relygyon
should ^aue little without thendes of Europa Also after that error of Sarasyns
had infecte al affryca. hit defouled also a great dele of spain And but gods
grace and mercy had helped / it would have infecte and shente al ffraunce with
spain Then after the great gregoryes time the empire of Rome that stretched
sometime from th^ccean of brytayne unto the ends of perse was so destroyed
with tyrauntrye and civil bataylles that it was not of power to defend it
self against enemies / then the cruel paynym host of perce bygan to occupye
many prouynces of the lordship of Rome and of men of christian feyth in the est
lands / Then as the great fly follows the trace of the malshawe. so after
other woo comes pestylence of the ismalytes that was more grievous and
destroyed neygh the christian men that were left in the eest lands by ledyng of
the prince machomete in heraclius themperours time Then in the fyfth bonefas
time while heraclius regnede about the year of our lord six honderd and
twenty. machamete the false prophet and witch begyled the ysmalytes and
agarenes in this manner. a famous clerk was at court of Rome and might not
speed at his will and p^ssed the sea and plesed many men and had hem at his
assente / Among the which he promised machomete that he would make him prince
of h^s people if he would do as he said / then this clerk fed up a douue
and made him fe^che his mete in machome^s ere. for there he put the co^ne that
the douue should ete / And of that same the douue would often feed him self
then in a day this clerk gadred the people to geder and promised them that he
would make him their prince whom the holy ghost would show in lykenes of a douue
and let anon his douue flee. And the douue as he was wont sat upon
machomets sholderes and put his bylle in machamets ere / And therefore machamet
was chosen prince and leder of the people. This that is said is the common tale^
but what now follows is more allowed and approu^d^ A monk that hete sergius
was put out of the company of monks that he was among for he was fall in to
nestorius errour^ he came in to Arabia and put him self to machomete and
informed him though it be radde that this sergius was archedeken of Antiochia
or patriarch of Ierusalem^ then machomet faderles and moderles was in his
emes keeping in his childhode and worshipped maumetrye somewhat of time with his
country men of Arabia / and he yaue him self specially to worshipe venus / And
therefore it is that yet the saraseyns holden the friday holy as the Jews don
the saturday and we the sunday After that machomet come to age and was sharp
of wit and went. in to many lands by cause of marchandyse and was often in
company of Jews and of christian men and learned the maners^ vsages and custommes
of both the laws of christian men and of the jews / And couth both wytchecraft
and nygromancy / and was a wonder fell man and fer casting and had noble
faconde and fair speech / th^nne he come to the lady of the prouynte Corozonia
/ the lady hete cadygan / And with sum spyces that he brought with
wytchecraft and fair words he made the lady so mad and so nyse that she
worshipped him as the grettest prophet of god almyghty^ or as it were messiah
tha^t the Jews abyden / and she desired him to husbond / It is the usage of
that prouynce to be ruled also by women Then he wedded the wedewe that was
queen and so he was made lord of that prouynce / then he drew to him the
Arabes and occupied the est empire unto Allexandria against heraclius the emperor
/ Then he took the manner of speaking of true prophets as though god had
spoke in him and spoke in this manner in his books that he made / Our lord
spak to his prophet and said. for so the books that he feyned gylefully
should be byleuyd as though they were made by auctoryte of god almighty

Then not only his own men but also men of fer lands fylle to him and bowed
to him in every side. he had great liking to have gretter lordship And as it
were for to bring men in to good manner living and as it were by commandment
of god almighty he assoylled the nations that dwelled nygh him and did by
craft and by gyle that he might not do by deeds of Arms Therefore when Egypt
Libia arabia and Siria were subgett by cause he would seem the more holy^ he
drew the people that were subget to his false law and made hem to forsake the
vsages and laws of their fornfaders / And he forbadde the paynems maumetrye
and he granted circumsicion to the Jews as they had vsed^ and feyned of his
own self sum new laws and alleged wytnes of either testament The sarasyns
call that law his law yet unto this time And he bade the sarasyns circumcide
hem as the Jews don / and forbad hem that would follow him etyng of swynyssh
flessh / And machomet would tell the cause why he forbade them the swynyssh
flessh and said that swyne come of camels dirt after noes flood and therefore
clean men should eschew it as mete that is unclean. And as it were to acorde
with Christian men in the manner of crystnynge / he ordained often wasshing of
lymmes in water as it were for clensing of sins And for to bring the people
that was so begyled the faster to snarle / what he knew that was most
playsanut to man's lykyng he ordained that for law / And so he ordained that
a man should have as many wives and concubynes as he might sustene with his
catel / Also that a man might have wives of his oun kynrede unto the nombre of
four. and that a man might four sithes forsake his wife and take her again /
and also that he might have as many concubynes as he would of wymmen / that
were bought prisoners^ And also that he might selle hem but if he had brought
any of hem with child- And ordained hem to use sobrenes of mete and drynk /
and forbad him drynkyng of wyn / but it were in certain solemn days in the
yere^ And for he would somdele varye fro the Jews that worshipped god westward
/ and fro christian men that worshipped god eestward / he taught his people to
worshipe god south ward with often knelynges^ for in the south is plente of
light / he ordained hem to worshipe the goddess venus and to hold the day
thereof solemn and ^ holy. that is friday / he bade worshipe one almighty god
creator and maker of all things and said that moses and Johan were
Prophets and that Christ was gretter and grettest of all prophets and that he
was born of the maid marie by virtue of god without man's seed as he says
in his book that hete Alkaron. netheles he meddled sum falls sawes with soth
sawes / And said that criste was afterward born up to heaven and not slayne^
For he says that Judas the traitor sought christ in a den and changed in
to the lykenes of christ / and so he was take and nailed to the cross instead
of crist Also he bade that the men of his law should every year if they might
goo in to gods hows that is in matha for to bydde her bedes / and when they
were comen thither they should ben clothed in one manner clothing / and they
should throw out stones through hooles of the walles^ as it were for to stone
the devil / and said that Abraham made that hows for his childeren ismaelytes
/ for they should there bydde their bedes / Also by machomets law ^e that were
take with a woman in spousebreche should be stoned to death / and if he deed
fornicacion with a sengle woman he should have four score lasshes / A thief the
first time and the second time should be beete^ and the thyrdde time he
should lose his hondes / and the fou^th time he should lose his feet / And he
seyth that who that holds all this and other heestes of his law god almighty
promised him paradys / the orcharde of plesyre and liking. there is no
distemprure ne pain that is any manner of gryef but al manner of welthe and of
liking / there is lykyng mete for to ete and clothes to were and maidens
tembrace fair shall serve them there / the Angels ben so great and so huge
that from that one eye to that other is the space of a day iourneye^ and to
them that hold ne keep not his lawe^ he promyseth hem fire and pain of hell
without end / And also in his book that is called alcoranum he prayseth all
the faders of tholde testament. and specially moses and Johan the baptist^
Christ and machomete Also there he preyseth all that that believe in god and do
rightwysenes / but it is not there red what is the right feyth. ne what men ben
of right believe. ne what men ben of mysbyleue Also there is wreton that five
books come fro heaven for the informacion of mankind / the sawter / moses
books / the books of prophets and machometes Alcaron / In that Alcoron it is
wreton that god almighty would rule and led mankind in to the way of
sauacion^ and after abraham he yaue to the childeren of Israel a law by which
law they should know God and worshipe him / But for they told not of his law
god gaf the gospel to other men / And also they mysused the law / And the
Arabes that came of Abraham by ysmael were mo men and gretter people than the
Jews that come of Abraham. by Isaac. And the Arabes that were left were left
without law / therefore out of the consistorye of gods rightwysenes come a
decree that a prophet of her own people should be sent to the ysmaelytes with
a law / the which prophet and law the sarasyns should follow as the Jews
followed moyses^ and christian men Christ And therefore the Sarasyns hold them self
better than Jews and Christian men for they hold holy their law / And Jews
and Christian men often trespacen against their own law / For to bring this
about / machomet norysshed and fed a fair camel in a pryue place / so that
the camel had no mete but of his own hand / And machomet waited his time and
henge that cursed book Alcaron about the camels neck. in that book were the
foresaid laws wreton And machomet let go the foresaid camel in to the feldes
with the book about to fore day light / Then the camel as it was no wonder
bygan to lepe and to sterte and made great joy for he was at large and fled
every man and would come nyghe no man's honde-Speche of this wonder sprange
once in feldes and towns and the people gadred thither out of every side. But
when machomete was comen the beast saw him a fer that yaf him alweye mete and
ran to him anon right^ and bowed to him and lykked his hondes as he was taught.
then the people cried and said in this deed is showed the holiness of gods
prophet / And they prayde him that he would undo the book with his holy
hondes / and when the book was opened / Lo says machomet Here is your law not
wreton with man's ynke but with angels hondes and sent fro heaven for to be
bolden ever without any. end In the book ye ben taught how ye shall worshipe
god / and how greet mede ye shall hope to resseyue of him for keeping of this
law / The day that this was don in is every year made solemn and holy /
and is called the fest of the camel / and they fast a month to fore that
feste in this manner Every day of that month fro the first light of the day
when men may know bitwene white and blac unto the going dou^ of the son /
they fast and ete not ne drink / ne delen with their wives / but ben alwey in
her prayers but after the going down of the son unto the dawynge again
they ete drink and lie by their wives / but seek men and feeble ben not holden
so for to fast. This machomet displesyd often his wife for he had the falling
evil / and in that evil he fill often to the ground / But he plesyd her and
other that had r^sseyued his law in this manner and said that he fill to ground
for the words of seint mychel tharchangel that spak with him so often For a
flesshliman he said may not suffer an angels words but if he fall / he hated
wyn dronkenes as Rybawdrye / and harlottrye / by cause of heete of the country
he would have it spared^ But in a night he was drunk and fylle down in the
streete^ And there swyn ete him which he reputed unclean beestes Therefore they
that hold his laws spare wyn and swynes flessh In the first point it seems
that they follow the Jews / In the second point it seems that they follow
the philosophye of their master Also after the death of machomet that cursed
sect encreced so fast that it caused so mighty men of perce to draw to that
cursed law of the Arabes Also that sect has infecte unto this time al
africa and a great dele of spain as gernarde. And tharchebisshop turpinus
tellith that machometes image of latone that he made with his own hondes /
stondeth in the Sea stronde and has his face toward the south. In that image
machometus by wytchecraft closed a legyon of fendes. A cryste^ man that comes
there is lightly perysshed. But a sarasyn goth alwey hoole and sound / A bird
that comes there dies anon The image holds a mace in his right hand And
that mace shall first fallen when a king shall be born in gallia that shall
renew al spain with christian laws / And when the mace shall fall / then the
sarasyns shall flee a^nd leave their tresorye / The famous norye of this cursed
sect Saladinus duc of turks the strong hamer of christian men about the year
of our lord enleuen honderd four score and ten he herd that christian men used
many messes of mete at one mele and said that christian men were not worthy to
have the holy land Also he was fell and slyhe for to praise his own secte^
and to blame and despise our law. and that is known by this ensample On a
time were two white monks brought to fore him that thieves of turks had take.
And he knew by her strange clothing that they were philosophres and christian
men. And he axyd by one that knew both langages of hem what they were and of
what condition and profession and they said that they were monks and had don
their profession to saint Benettes rule. Then he axyd besyly many points of
that rule. And specially among other. he axed if they should by her rule ete
flessh or drink wyn / Then answered they and said that they had at al time
somewhat of wyn for to drink. but flessh should they none ete / but it were for
sekenes or great need / then the tyrant badde that they should have more
large keeping and have two young fair wymmen to serve hem / and badde that they
should ete flessh and drink water / And so they ete flesh and drunk water^
and took ensample by saint Job / and made covenant with their eyes that they
would not think of fylthe and of sin and were alwey besy in their prayers /
Then Saladynus was waar thereof and took from hem the flesh and the water
and bad hem serve with fysshe and wyn / And he badde so do to that intent that
Salamon moeueth and says / give ye wyn to hem that been in great sorrow that
they may drink and foryete their sorrow and her need / When he had thus done
he cast to begyle by symplenes these two monks / For he would if they might
there bysette challenge and blame upon the Relygion / then the Monks drunk
wyn and wexe merry and glad and forgate what they should have in mind and fylle
to and lay by the wommen Thennne on the morrow when the wyn was defyed^ they
thought on their trespaas and began for to weep full soore. the tiraunt saw hem
weep and said why be ye more soory than ye were wont to be. For we have
sinned grievously said they and were overcome with wyn^ Then he said / while
ye ete flesh and drank water ye held forth your purpose redyly ynowgh / But
when ye were overcome with wyn without flessh ye brake your rule and your
purpose / Therefore it is known that Benett the Auctour of your rule was unwise
for to forbede you etyng of flesh that distourbled not a man's wit and
granted you to drink wyn that roteth up the strength of reason as ye have
assayed now by new assaye / Then he that made our law machomet that forbad
us wine that distourbeth man's wit and granted us the use of flessh was
wyser than your Benet^ But what be your remedies and clensyng of this sin
now that ye have broken your rule and your purpose. Penance said they and
satisfaction by ordenaunce of our ^elder fader / Then said he mow ye not be
cleansed among us / Goo ye to your own and be cleansed in your own manner wise
/ and so he let hem go This man was full of old pestylence of sleyght and
wyles / And what the wyly shrewe / might not have saueour in^ he began to
despise / For he would blame the holy man saint Benet / Of the which saint
Benet the great gregory says that he wrote the Rule of monks full of wit and
of wisdom / and open and clear in words. For it was a wise deed to withdraw
fro hem that go to holy chyualrye. liking of metes that withdraws the soul
from holiness of deeds and of thoughts / and by thappostles lore he granted
hem a little what of wyn for to strength somewhat the feblenesse of the flessh
and granted hem but little. for it should not grieve the sharpnes of the soul

Beda libro tercio capitulo secundo That year king Oswald king of

Treuisa It is soth that cursed men hate good men and her good deeds / And so

Then it follows in the story also that year king oswy hade slay king

/ then the king and the Bisshops were both well plesed and sat to gyder

Then it happed soon after that the king was slain as it is said / And

Capitulum 17
About that time deyde Aydanus and Finanus bisshops of Northumberlonde / And
Colmannus a Scot come after hem to be Bishop three year / In his time come
Agilbertus Bishop of westsaxons in to the countries of Northumberlond And
ordained wylfrydus that was tho Abbotte of Rypon and made him priest at
prayers of king oswyns That time was a greet question made and meuyd of the
Eesterdaye that was not that time holden lawfully of scotts and of brytons but
it was suffryd at reverence of colu^ba of aidanus of fimanus and of other holy
faders / Therefore was a counseyl made in thabbay of Hilda. there in that one
side came colmannus the bishop and hylda thabbesse^ and alleggyd for them that
her predecessors were worthy men and holy and held the Eester tide from the
fourtenth day of the moon unto the xx day of the mone^ And specially seint John
the euangelyst held so the cestirtyde in Asia / In that otherside ayenste hem
came Egylbertus Bisshoppe of westsaxons James that was sometime Paulinus priest
the Archibisshop of York and wilfridus abbot of Rypon and Alfridus the kings
son / And Wilfridus disputed for hem and aledged for hem that the manner and
the usage of al holy church of Greeks of ytaly of Rome Of gallia and of
France / should be set to fore the manner customme and usage of a corner of the
world that knew not the decrees of synodes as it is no wonder^ namely while
saint Johan the euangelyst in the beginning of holy church that was tho young
and tender held thordenaunce of moses law in many things and followed tho
the Jews as it is wreton of poule that he circumcided thymothe and offered
oostes in the temple and share his heed with Aqnyla and priscilla at Corynthy
And that was profitable to nothing but for to put of the sklau^dre of the Jews
/ And also saint Johan by the usage of that law byganne to hold the eester
tide the fourtenth day of the first month and rought not whether it fill on a
saturday or in another day of the weke / And peter thappostle that was primate
of holy church and had power to bind and unbind. he abode the four tenth
day of the moon when the moon were at full as saint john did and bygan to
hold the eester tide at eve the next sunday after the full of the moon and the
euenes of the day and the night and held that tide to the one and twenty day
of the moon / And if the fourtenthday fill on a sunday he held not there the
Eester day. For that sunday was of the rather year and not of the new year
that should tho begin / king oswy herd this and said. ^ith that ye tell
that so many and great pryueleges and power be granted to saint peter I dar
not withsaye so great an vssher and porter / lest he close heuene yate against
me when I should come to heuene / When this was said the multitude assented /
But Ced Bishop of the eeste was there present and held him corrected from
that time forward / But colmannus that was tho bishop of northumberlond was
tho wroth and went thennes in to the country of scotts for to find the
eester time without fail there ben rewles ynowe in the ordynal of the kalendre
and it is nedeful to set it here / But the error that holy church suffers
in the calendar that we. use is so encreced that the styntyng of the son and
the euenes of the day and night and thentryng of the son in to signs ben
passed backward by twelve days in our calendar now about the year of our lord
a thousand / iij / C and twenty / And therefore but our calendar that we use /
be amended by withdrawing of the days that been put in to lepe year / to a
certain time or in sum other manner wise. if the time of grace dure to
eyghten thousand yere^ eesterday shall fall about the shortest day of all the
year by our calendar / And if the sixthe age of world dure two so longe^ the
feeste of the birth of saint Johan baptist shall fall in the shortest day of
the year. And the feeste of the birth of our lord in the lengest day of the
year The cause of this error is declared in tholomeus book. in Almagestis
tholomei Treuisa Here take heed that twyes in the year falls the styntyng of
the son and so does the euenees of the day and of the night that is called
in latin equinoxium. the stynting in winter of the son is when the day is
shortest and eke in somer when the day is lengest / the euennes of the day
and night is ones in lent and again in harvest time / when the day and night
ben lyche long / And for we speak of the sons entringe in to signs ye shall
understand that every month ones the son passed out of one sign in to
another / And for we speak of the month of the moon. the month of the moon is
from change to change / or from pryme to pryme Also the first month of the moon is here called the time of the moon / when it is full when the day and
night ben lyche long in march or next after / For in such a time the world
was first made Willelmus de pontificibus libro tercio / then Colmannus
bishop of northumberlond was conuycte by wylfridus of mysholdynge of the
esterday and was wroth and went to the Scotts as it is before said / And the
same wilfridus was chosen Archebisshop of york by procuring of Alfridus that
was the kings son. And was sent in to France for to be sacred / For deus
dedit tharchebisshop of Caunterbury was deed that should have sacred him here
in England That time kenwalcus king of westsaxons deled his prouynce in two
bisshopryches Therefore egilbertus was wroth and went again in to france
there he was born and other things as it is said in the same book^ Capitulo
15. Paulus libro / 6 About that time Constantyn the emperor would deliver
ytalye of the hondes of the longobardes and came to Tarent in ytalye and axed
there of an holy man that was solytarie / whether he might overcome the
longobardes or no / he answerde that / it might not yet be do. For by cause
of an abbaye that is founded in Ytalye in worship of saint Johan baptist /
saint Johan prays alweye for the longobardes / But the time shall come when
that Oratory shall be despised and unworthy persons shall dwell therinne. And
then the longobardes shall first be perisshed-Themperour rought not thereof and
went forth against the longobardes but he spedde not. But le spoylled Rome not
withstondynge that vitalianus the pope prayed him for to leave / And this

/ In his time saint Benettes body was translated with the body of his suster

Capitulum 18.

/ for it is said that he was crystned of Sergius / that is to understand that

changed as it happeth in confermacion of children And though he were of

About that time Egbertus the Monk. that we spoke of tofore hond that escaped
the moreyn by prayers and auowes had sailed about brytayn and cast for to
convert the men of germania. but deeds and warning of heaven let him. For
the ship that he had ordained for that journey was to broke with a sodein
tempest of weder / And tho one of his brethren was warned by a vision and spak
to egbertus and said. that he must whether he would or no return to saint
columbaes abbaye again / For their plowes yede not a right / therefore he sent
wyllebrordus with / xij. felawes in to the countries of germania^ And he
turned much folk to the feythe by help of the older pupinus duk of Frensshe
men that had won the hither fryselond / And at last by auctorite of the
pope gregory he was made bishop of vtrecht and ruled that bisshopryche well and
nobly well a forty year Offorus deyde Bishop of wiccies that had men of the
bisshoprich of wircestre and Egwinus was bishop after him that sone afterward
bylded the abbaye of euesham by assente of Etheldredus / when theodericus king
of France was deed whom pupinus Vetulus had myldly suffrid to regne with him
/ he made his son Clodoneus king / pupinus vetulus hete pupinus breuis also
That year the men of Caunterbury made pees with Iue king of the westsaxons and
yaf three thousand pound for the death of mul cedwalles brother. Iustinianus Caesar
was priued of the joy of his kingdom for gylt and mysbyleue and went exyled
in to pontus Leo patricius refte him his nose and his tongue and exyled him in
to Cersona

Item capitulo duodecimo That time nactanus king of pictes sent messagers to

as we now hol^de The second Ius^inianus sent his host for to take Philipicus

fader Childebertus / and reigned enleuen year by suffraunce of pypinus vetalus /
that yet ruled the kings hows After Constantinus the second gregory was pope

of westsaxons and colredus king of mercia foughten at wodenesburgh so sharply.
and either of hem bare him self so ungraciously. that it was not known /
whether of them had worse spedde The third theodosius was Emperor one year
and was goodly and benygne. and overcome his predecessor Anastasius and made
him a priest But after one year this theodosius was putt down and made a clerk
by his successor the thyrdde leo the strong / In his time come many sarasyns
and besyeged Constantinople three year. It seems that Johan damascenus was that
time in his flowers and was brought in to Perce There were lettres wreton of
his enemies and thrown forth and found and openly read / In which lettres
was contained his conspyracye ayenste the prince. Then his right hand was
smyten of / for he should never ward write / but he prayed fast to our lady that
he served bysyly and his hand was restored to him ageyn R It it is not to
suppose that this Johan is Johan theremyte that is set in the book of faders
/ soon after hillarion and warned theodosius the emperor of other vyctoryes
It is another Johan that was in the thyrdde theodosius time in greece and
afterward in Perce and made many noble books in both philosophye. That Johan
theremyte was long time to fore the great gregory^ And this Johan damascenus
was long time after the great gregorye

That is known by that^ that this Johan damascenus in his books of diuynyte
aledgeth the great gregoryes noble and great miracle of the drlyueraunce of
Traianus^ that may not be understand of gregory nazauzenus^ for he was about
constantinople and about pontus and uneath come ever at Rome / But mind of
that miracle of the delyueraunce of Traianus at sepulcre of thappostles in
the cite of Rome by the great Gregory pope is holden every year as holy church
makes mind / In tretynge of deeds that helps hem that been deed / Johan
damascene alleges that miracle

Capitulum 23
THe thyrdde leo with his sone Constantyn was Emperor five and twenty year /
In his first year deyde pipinus Vetulus after that he had governed the kings
hows eight and twenty year / After him come charles that was bygoten on a
Concubyne and heete tutides and marcellus also / And had such names of

and sixty thousand of sarasyns / Also he fought against the saxons and against
the bauar^es Also against hendo a duc of guyen and against Raufredus duc of angeo
Also this charles for besynes of wars and bataylles that fill upon him bytoke

/ That Bisshopryche is now called wyrcetre. In a time Egwinus bythought him of

Capitulum 24.
LEo the emperor left thenemyes of thempyre and warryd ayeynste fygnres and
images of saints / Pope gregorye and Germanus of Constantinople withstode him
manly as the old use and customme would that is allowed and approved by holy
church and said that it is worthy and medefull to do hem the affection of
worship / For we worshipe in hem but god / And often by the fight of such images
men worshipe god and holy saints God a^one shall be principally worshipped and
after him Creatures shall be worshipped in worship of him Beda libro quinto
capitulo visesimo quarto That year deyde wyhtredus king of Caunterbury and

/ the which relyques were sometime translated to sardina for fere of strange
enemies / And he made hem to be borne to the cite of gene / and thens to papye
/ that hete sometime titinum / Willelmus de Regibus libro primo King Iue bytoke

said that he was the first of kings that granted to saint peter of every hows
of his kyngedome a penny / that long time of englysshemen was called Rome skott
/ but in latin it is called petres penny / The kings wife ethelburga yaue him
occasion to take that pylgremage / and that in this man / she had often
cou^ceyled her husbond to forsake the riches of this world / and specially in
the last years of his life / but she sped not / therefore at last she fonded to
overcome him with gyle / And in a time when they had leye to gyder in the
Ryal cite / and departed thens / then after three days the governor of the
cite defowled the palace with all the fylthe that he might find with dunge and
fylth of beestes and of mukhilles / And where the king had leyn and slepte /
he leyde a sow with her pigges that late had farwed / All this he did by
assente and commandment of the queen / then the queen prayed her husbond
with flaterynge and desired him to come to that place / there he had be The
king granted and came thither / and saw that place that sometime was like to
Sardanapalus pleasure and lust / then so disarayd and defowled / when she
saw this occasion / she spak to the king and said / I pray you my lord /
where ben now the curteyns / and all the rich arraye of halles and chambres
/ Where is now the plesaunt seruyse of them that were wont to flatre you /
where is the liking and plesaunt seruyse of glotonye and lecherye / Be they
not al passyd So my Lord shall our flesh pass and fall aweye / that is
now norysshed in gold and in rich array / here with her husbond was overcome
/ and after his noble bataylles and vyctoryes / and great prays that he had
taken / he bytoke his kingdom to his neuewe / and went to Rome / He came not
openly thedyr in syghte as a king / but he share his heed / and clothed him as
a pour man / and wexe old among beggars / But the queen Ethelburga went to
the Abbay of berkynge there her suster had be abbess / And she was afterward
made abbess of the same maidens and made a blessed end / and passed to rest

Here lacks and fails conning and speech to wondre at full / that a man
that was so without use of scole made so many noble volumes in so sobre words

at Rome / though^ some men would wene that he went to Rome to be there present

exposicion / Regna ruent Rome / Ferro / Flamma / fame que / that is to say /
Kyngdoms of Rome shall fall by Iron / fire and honger / Willelmus de Regibus
libro primo But by Pope Sergius pystle that was sent to abbot colfrydus it is
known that beda was sent after and prayed for to come to Rome / for tassoylle
questions that there were meuyd / Here take heed / how worthy the court of

assoylle the questions that there were meuyd / And also how worthy we shall
hold him by the manner of his living and of his techynge / he might not be
vycious that spent so his wit and thought in expownynge of holy writ /
But his clennesse was seen much at his last end / For seven wekes

he spared not the trauaylle of letture and of books / But every day among

^eche / he trauaylled besyly in bedes bidding and thankyng god of al / The

have of him mind / And he yaue to many of his servants things that he had

tellith that he is now at durham with saint Cuthbert / and with him was buried
well nygh all the knowleche unto the conquest of deeds of england and neygh all
the connyng of lettres For after that time after lewd came more lewd. As the
shamely verses that were wreton on his tomb bear great wytnes of uncunning /
tho versus be unworthy to be written on so worthy a man's tomb / these ben the
verses / Beda the priest rests here y buried in the flesshe^ Christ grant
his soul to be glad in heaven forever / Grant him to drink the well of
wisdom that he has now. Desired besily alwey right with love great About
that time ricoldus duc of Frysons was turned by the prechyng of of saint
wulfranus the bishop and would be crystned. And put his one foot in the

Capitulum 25
THe fyfth constantinus after his fader leo was Emperor three and thyrtty year
/ This as his fader used took images out of church in every place and set
hem a fire / Etheldredus king of westsaxons deyde the fourtenth year of his

governed his subgettis hard and euyl^ And turned the laws at his own will
And slough the noble Earl cumbranus evil and wyckedly / for he had spoke to him
of his evil berynge and deeds But at last for he would not be amended. he was

kyngis hows of France / Under hildericus the sone of theodericus^ for he was

and amended hit in two states / for he was a man of great heart and of great
wit / and took strongly head that as it is great pride to coueyte and desire
ought that is not rightful. so is it great lewdnes and wrechedines to

Capitulum 26
THan pipinus was deed the frensshemen departed the kingdom between his two
sons charles and charleman. but charleman deyde after two year and then
charles had all the kingdom and governed it nobly after that time six and
forty year Then charlemans wife and children fled to desiderius king of
longobardes and prayed him of help and socoure with out any need for noman
compelled hem thereto But charles first overcome duc hunald and wangyen and made
it subget / and at te prayer of pope adryan he bysieged desiderius king of
ytaly in the cite of papye / for he was rebel against the church of Rome / as
his brother astulphus had been / Charles took him in the Cite of papye and exyled
him and made his own sone pipinus king of ytaly in his stead / In that batayl
deyde amicus and amelius crystes knightes^ and his herty frendes^ Of hem ben
red wonderful deeds At last charles chastysed the saxons and the sclaues
and took many of hem and sent hem in to diverse places of france / So that the
saxons forsook their mawmetrye and were made one people Saxons and Frensshmen^
There after Charles went in to spayn and wanne the dales lands and countries
about the hills montes pireni^ But he was assoylled in the wey with
busshementis of Gascoyns. so that they slough the vtterde^le of his host.
there olyuer chyef sewer of the kings bord^ and rouland Earl of the palace
were slain and many other peers of Frau^ce^ De libro turpini In a day when
trewes were granted on either side / Aigolandus a strong prince of spain came
to charles for to be crystned / And saw all that were at b^rde rially clothed
and delyciously fedde^ And saw a fer thyrten (...) men sytte on the ground
and have broken mete and simple with out any board. And he axyd what they
were. and it was answered him that these thyrten ben gods messagers and pray
for us and bring to mind the nombre of crystes disciples / As I see said
Aigolandus your law is naught rightful that suffers gods messagers be thus
evil seruyd^ He seruith evil his lord that so resseyued his servants / And
so he was lewdly offended and despised crystendom and went home again / But
charles worshipped afterward pour men the more Treuisa Aigolandus was a lewd
ghost and lewdely meuid as the devil him taught and blinded him that he couth
not know that men should be served as her state axyd / Gir de p. ca. 17 Here
after charles wanne gallia narbonensis and made subget capnanes. and
be^neuentanes the danes and the sueues that were confedered to hem / And he
did that al at one journey / kings of brytons of angles of perte and of
scotts of greece worshipeden him with yeftes And as Turpyn tharchebisshop
tells Charles was fair and welfaryng of body and stern of face^ His body was
eight foot on length / his face a span and an half^ and his berde was a foot
longe^ he cleef a two with his sword a knight armed at one stroke / he would
esyly with his hondes fold and bend four horse shone at ones^ he would heue a
stondyng knight armed from the ground with his one hand / he would ete an
hare all hoole or tweyne hens / or a goos at one mele / and he would drink
a litell wyn watered / he was so scarce of drink that seelde he would drink
but thries at his soper This Charles was gracious and mylde to pour men and to
chirches / Over the Ryn at magounce he made a bridge of five honderd paas^ as
frensshmen don / as so ne as he might for youth he taught his sons to ride
and hunte. to do deeds of arms and to learn scyences of scole / he ordained
his daughters to werche* wolle work with spyudle and with dystaf and ordained
hem to use such works for they should not wexe slow by ydlenes / he held him
not a paid with his country speech / he couthe better understand the langage
of g^ue than speak it / in loore of gramer peter of pyse was his master / and
in other sciences of clergy alcuinus albinus an englysshman was his master /
Charles fonded to write lettres / therefore he bare a payr table^ for to write
ynne. but it profyteth right little / for that trauaylle was bygonne to late^
he would be at church erly and late and at hours that were said by night / he
ordeygned and assigned great alms to pour men that were in f^r lands in
egypt and in Africa. he had alweye a reda^ at mete. and had great delight in
saint Austyns books and specially in his books de ciuitate dei. In somer time
after mete in the vndertyde he would take somewhat of apples and drink ones
thereto / and do of his clothes and goo to bed as it were by night and sleep
two houres^ By night he would four sythes or five awake and arise and lie down
and sleep / thryes he came to Rome and alyght of his ho^s a mile a this half the
cite and yede afote in to all the cite and kyssed all the pylers of chirches^
he delyuerd the holy land and come again to Constantinople and forsook all
the precious and great yeftes that Constantin the emperor proffered reserved
relyques of holy saints / he receiuyd a great party of our lords cross and a
party of the crown of thorns that there in his syghte that byganne to
blosme^ and bear flowers. and one of crystes nails / our lady smok and saint
symeons Arm / and brought these relyquyes with him to saint marye church at
Aquisgranum that he had founded and lies buried there / he fonded as many
abbayes as ben lettres in the A / B / C. In every of thylke abbayes by the
order of the fondacion thereof. he set and pyghte a letter of gold of the
weight of an honderd pond tournoys / Of this man Charle^ it is wonder that he
would uneath marye any of his daughters while he was a live / out take his
oldest dought^r the which he married to the king of greece that hete constantin
/ Charles said that he might not be without company of his daughters /
Therefore though he were gracious in other deeds / In that point against fortune
he was to blame / and though there were great speech thereof among the people. he
made it as though he knew it not^ And as none suspection were of that folly
deed. therefore sum men wene that that was the sin that he would never shryue
him of with his mouthe^ but uneath at last by writing to saint gyles Also
this charles or he deyde deled his catel in three parties. one party he
assigned to pour men / Another to chirches^ And yet the third he departed in
four partyes^ one there of he kept for to hold his myndeday / that other to
every days use / the thyrdde to his sons and neuewes and the fourth to his
servants that were of his household / he sat ones at meet. and his master
alcuinus sat to fore him. then he axyd his master how great difference and
space was between a scot and a sot / but the bread of a metebord said his
master R. For to bring stories to acorde that seems out of acord speaking
of thempyre and of the kingdom of charles / Take heed that this charles while
he was young was enoynted king of the second pope steven / the year of our lord
seven honderd.Liiij. while his fader pipinus was a live and reigned with his
fader. and under him xv year unto his faders death / then after his faders
death that deyde the year of our lord seven honderd and eight and sixty year /
he reigned with his brother charleman two year. his brother deyde the year of our
lord seven honderd and / lxx / Charles held the kingdom al hool fourten year
/ to the year of our lord seven honderd four score and four That year he went
first to Rome to be crouned emperor of Adrian the pope And there after he was
Emperor sixten year to the year of our lord eight honderd When the fourth pope
leo confermed charles again Emperor. there after he was emperor fourten year
And deyde the year of his age two and seventy / that was the year of our lord
eight honderd and xiiij Then after sum men tell in stories that he reigned
in all six and forty year / that shall be vnderstonden from his fadres death to
his own death / / But who that wole see more of charles life must look the
books of his master Alcuinus or turpyn tharchebisshops books That day that
Charles deyde at vyan in France Turpyn was in his bedes and saw a company of
blac knights wend toward Akon for to take charles soule^ and he coniured the
last of hem that he should come ageyn when he had don and tell hem what they
did and how they spedde Then the fend went and come again And Turpyn axyd
of him what they had do / we have quod the fend weyed charles soul / but
thylke James of spain that was byheded / leyde so many stones and teres in
the weight and balaunce that charles good deeds had the maystrye and weyed more
than his evil deeds / And we have right naught brought with us ageyne^ Charles
said the fend used to bylde many chirches in worship of seint Iame. After that
Constantyn that had assoylled the poperych and take it with strength was put
out. Pope stephen was pope four-yere. Anon he gadred a synod and revoked all that was do by his predecessor out take crystenynge and crysme / and what
that was ordained to sauacion that deyen

Capitulum 27.
AFter Steven the first Adryan was pope four and twenty year / First this
gadryd the second counceyl at Constantinople of three honderd faders and fyfty /
he made another counceyll in the Cite of Rome with three honderd and fyfty
faders / king charles was present there / Then him was granted right in
the election of the pope and of the ordeynyng of the popes see /

The northumbres putt out their king Aluredus and took ethelbertus that hete
Etheldredus also the son of mollus^ and made him their king / he reigned over
hem five year / The fourth leo the son of the fyfth Constantyn reigned in
greece four year / He burnt in thirst for great couetyse^ he took of a church
a crown that was ryally set with carbuncle stones / and set it on his
heed and was take with a sudden fever and deyde / That year / offa king of
mercia spoylled lamberd Archebisshop of canterbury of his dygnyte / of prymate

by assente of the pope adryan The sixth Constantin the son of the fourth leo

and stryf between the son and mother. And the mother took the son and put him
in prison and so she reigned alone five year. At last the son had help and
counseyl of the Armenyes and came out of prysonne and poursued cruelly his
mother and her helpers Then afterward the son for his great cruel^es was
take by commandment and strength of the mother / and his eyes were put out
in so evil m^ner that he deyde sone afterward and so Iren reigned again five
year. But nichoforus patricius that had great worship of Iren. roos ageynste
her and took the crown against the peples will. and took of her the tresour of
thempyre with an oath made to be harmeles^ and exiled her and so exyled she
deyde / the first year of this Constantin in a deed man's grave at
Constantinople was found a plate of gold. in which plate was wreton in this

and Iren / sone efte me. thou shall see. Mari li. secundo. That year kenulphus

out her king ethelbertus that heete etheldredus also / and made Aswolf king

three honderd and fyfty bisshops in adryans time / In that synod against
thoppinion of greeks it is said that the holy ghost comes of the fader and of

cast for to put kinehard out of his kingdom the brother of his predecessor

there Clyto came with four score felawes / and and bysette the king al aboute^
But when the king was awaked he defended manly him self / but he was slain

After kenulphus brightricus of Cerdicus blood was king of westsaxons fyften
yere^ Anon by help of king offa whose daughter he had wedded be put out
Egbertus the son of Alemundus the under king that was the sone of offa that

offa married his daughter Ethelburga to Brightricus king of westsaxons / Of her

household men of her husbonde / then on a time she yaue venym to a yonglyng
that was homly with the king and slough both the king and the yonglynge /

riches / And in a time the king and his sone stood in a chamber / and the

sholdest have had my son / But for thou have forsake me / thou shall not have
me nermy son / thou must leave the pride of the world / and goo in to an
abbay / there a lewd man lay by her / and she was put out and deyde in

/ Henricus / libro quarto / That year was seen a wonder sign of the Cross on

Capitulum 28 /
Offa deyde king of mercia / his son Egsercus reigned after him one year /
And after him a mylde man kenulphus cutbertus sone was king / he gate on his
wife queen Alfritha quen drida / burgenilda / and saint kenelme / Willelmus de

degree / and was a greet man / his virtues passyd his fame / At home he was
devout and mylde / In bataylle he was strong and had often the vyctorye /
After Offa he took wrath against kentysshmen and werryd strongly in her land /
And took their king Egbert that hete pren by his surname / and lad him with
him y bound in to mercia / But sone after he was mylded by mercy of manheede

bisshops and ten dukes / For that deed all the church sowned for joy / and the

the dygnyte of prymate to athelardus bishop of caunterbury and deyde at

Constantinople the son withdrewe his light seuenten days / and was not seen

out of king Constantyns eyes / Alfredus Also that year that was the tenth year
of bryghtrycus were fyry dragons seen in england fleyng by the air / After

that assaylled first northumberlond / and then lyndeseye But at that time the
danes were overcome and fled to her ships After adryanus the fourth leo was

with the letany and was take and his eyes put out and his tongue kyt of / But

with him to Rome / Then wreche was take of the popes enemies / and the pope

and confermed him that was to fore crowned / Nychoforus patricius exyled Irene
themperyce of grece^ and assaylled and took thempyre with wyles and with

The body of saint wythburgh the maid was founden hoole and sound in the town
of durham / there as it was buried after / lv year / wythburgh was the daughter
of king anna / and the suster of sexburga / that year charles was crowned
emperor of leo the pope / Sith that time thempyre passyd fro the Greeks to the
Frensshemen / and to the germans that been Almayns

Giraldus de / p / capitulo septimo / For this passinge of thempire / the
greeks though they fail in hem self / and strive more with venym than with
virtue / more with craft than with strength of batayl / and of mars that is
called god of battle / yet they have so great envy to the latyns / that they
have withdraw hem out of the subjection and obedyence of the church of Rome
/ And therefore when the popes of Rome charged hem often to be obedyent and to
come again to the unity of holy church / They used to write again in this
manner / Ye have withdrawn you from us / and we withdraw us fro you /
Willelmus de regibus libro primo / Et de pontificibus libro tercio /
Bryghtrycus king of westsaxons / deyde y poisoned by the venym of his wife /
After him Egbertus the son of Alcmundus the under king that was the sone of

chaced of bryghtrycus and fled in to france / and came ageyn and taught what he

ordained knights delyuere men and strong and swyper / And made wepen to be
born in time of pees / In a time bernulphus king of mercia scorned his doing

hampton / there was unlike nombre and array of knights / for against an honderd
of Egbertus knights that were paal / and lene came a thousand that were rody
and fat / and were sooner stuffed with swote than with blood / But when the
battle was done / Egbertus oned the kyngdoms of mercia / of kente and of
northumberlond to his kingdom and took chestre upon the brytons / For the
Brytons held chestre unto that time / then he called the lords to gyder at
wynchestre and was crowned king of al brytayne / there he ordained and
commanded that all the saxons and Iutes should be called Angles fro that day
forward / and that brytayne should be called anglia Brytayne conteyneth england
wales and Scotland / R / That year that king bryghtrycus deyde / as marianus
says / Ethelmundus king of mercia went out of his own land unto the forde
of chymerforde / and fought against weoftan duc of wylton In that bataylle the
dukes were slain in either side / and the wylton men had the victory / But
