in Ethelmundus side and was slain there / his body was first buried at white
a^bbay and afterward at derby / in the north chirch that is builded in his name
/ there god shows for him many tokens and myraales / and the northumbres

englisshman that hete alcuinus also a connyng man of Clergy passyd over the sea in to France / and enlumyned that land with light of his techyng / and
ordained there orysons and office of mass for feryal days / And he brought to
paris study that the greeks had sometime changed to Rome / After beda and

turone to govern by thabbots right / for the monks there were fallen in to

his soul / four monks mete / about this time seint gylys thabbott of the

/ Among the Greeks mychel a mylde man was made emperor / In his third year

water / Many men suppose that this hap fylle at prayer of ryculfus the
bishop for manslaughter and robberye / that was often by night don upon that
bridge / But other men suppose that it fill by sum adventure and none otherwise

Capitulum 29
LOwys the mylde Charles oldest son was Emperor after his fader six and

Capitulum 30
AFter kenelm his eme on his faders side colwulfus reigned in mercia / but after

Another is for as they change her names / so should they change her living /

Capitulum 32 /

But marianus tellyth this of lotharius and not of lowys Etheldredus the thyrdde

penance / then the king come / and the pope axyd of him / if he had holden

Capitulum 33
THe thyrdde lowys reigned in France after his fader the secunde lowys four
year Willelmus de Regibus libro secunde This year the hooste of danes left
este england and come with their dukes hungar and hubba / toward redynge in
westsaxons / there the third day after their coming the two dukes of danes
went out for to take prays and were slain at engelfeld / there after the
fourth day the two brethren kings of westsaxons met to gyder and made a
great slaughter of the danes. At last the danes brake out of the tour and
slough Ethelwulfus duc of barrokshyre / and compellyd thenglysshme^ to wend a
bak / For that shame Englysshmen were meuyd and arrayed a battle the fourth
day there after upon Asshdoun / There Aluredus was drive for great need to
come to the bataylle to fore his brother the king that herd a mass that time
/ The which kings prayers to god that day was much worth / For though the
danes had taken the hither place of the hille / Christian men come from the foot
of the hylle upward ayenste hem / and slough osryk king of danes and five of
his dukes / and many thousands of enemies / and chaced the other al a day unto
Redynge / But the fourtenth day after at basynge the danes yaf a battle / and
again two months there after at merton and had the vyctorye / In the mean
time the kings of mercia / of northumberlond and of eest angles had no will
to suffer the lordship of westsaxons / therefore hem was lever sustain the
enemies and favor hem in the syege than help her own country men that
trauayled for the land / Therefore it was that the enemies encrecyd and had the
maystrye / and men of the land were over come / and bare down and made doole
and sorrow / the next year there after / / After many batayls etheldredus king
of westsaxons deydr eight days to fore may and was buried at Wynburn / After
Adryan the eygth Johan was pope twelve year / In a time this dwelled with lowys
balbus king of France al a year / and was prysoned of the Romans / for he
would not favor charles Also this pope yaue to ansegysus bishop of Senons
the great gregoryes heed and pope leos Armefor to do hem in his church / In
the time of this pope / the fyfthe Synod of Constantinople was made of three
honderd / lxxiij / bisshops / Also in his time Sarasyns pryked in ytaly / and
destroyed saint benets abbay in mount cassyn then the second time

Incipit Liber sextus
Capitulum primum /
ALuredus the fourth brother of birth / was ever holden behind while his
brethren reigned / But he had after hem the hoole kyngedome of westsaxons nine
and twenty year / And ruled it nobly / but with great trauail

Here take heed of his beginning of his forth going / and of his last end /
For Aluredus was fair of shappe / and more loved of fader and mother than his
other brethren / and dwelled in his faders court to the year of his age
twelve / and was not yet lettred / yet after that the child learned right well
/ and held saxon poesy^ in mind / He passed other men in craft of hunting /
and was a subtle master of buildynge and of other works / he gadred psalms
and orysons to gyder in a little book / and called the book manuel that is an
hand book / he had that book with him alwey / He was but a simple Gramaryon
/ for that time was not one techer of gramer in all his kingdom / Therefore by
counseyl of neotus the abbott / whom he vysyted right often / he was the first
that ordained common scole at oxenford of diverse arts and seyences / and
procured fredome and pryueleges in many articles to that Cite / he suffered
noman to take degree or order / to what manner dygnyte of holy church / but he
were well lettred / he turned the best laws in to englyssh tongue / At last
he auentred him to translate the sawter in to English / But he translated
uneath the first part before his death / when he come to age and would stable
his heart and his thought in gods heestes / the lechery of his flessh greuyd
him and let him of^e time / therefore to put awey temptacion of flesshely
liking / he went and vysyted often temples of holy saints erly and late / and
at cokkes crowyng and prayed god that he would chastyse his flessh with such a
sickness that he should not be unprofitable to worldly deeds / and that he
might the more freely serve god almighty / At gods ordenaunce he had many year
the evil called Fycus At lastehe was out of hoope to be heeled and went in
to Cornewayle to to saint suerons church / there saint neotus rests / owther
for to ceese owther for to change it R But sum men say that saint modwenna
/ the yrysshe maid heled him of that evil / At last when he had his will
/ a wors evil took him in his wedded time / and grieved him well more from his
twenty year / to his five and forty year / his queen ethelswyda bare him / ij
/ sons / Edward the elder / and egelward / And three daughters Elfleda lady of
mercia / ethelgota a menchon and elf^yda and he made hem all learn gramer and
other fre arts and scyences / Than aluredus yeuer of alms herer of masses /
sought besyly loore of art and of craftees that he knew not and sent after
saint gyrmbald the monk a connyng man of letture and of song and prayde him to
come to him out of france in to england / Also he sent for Johan monk of
saint david abbaye in meuenia to come to him out of wales to teache him clergy
/ he exyted and comforted the lords of his land to learn letture a^nd clergy
/ so that they should set their children to scole / and if they had no childer
/ they should grant her bond men fredome / and set hem to scole / if they
had good wit and were able to learn / he inquired and ^spyed besyly the
doing and deeds of his officers and servants / and namely of Iugges and of
domesmen / And if he might understand that they erryd or did amysse / whether
it were for uncunning or for couetise / he put them out of office / Also he
made Werfredus Bishop of worsetre translate in to Saxon speech gregoryes
books dyalogus Will / de Regibus libro primo / He departed in three all that
he might spend / and yet he departed the first part in three / For the twey
parties of the kings ministres were at home for to ordeyne for homly things /
In the thyrdde month every party and company of his howsholde should serve
before him / he assygned the second part of this first part to diverse werkmen
that gadred out of every side / The third pa^te he deled to comers and
strangers / Than the second chyef part of that he might spend / he departed
in four / The first part thereof he yaue to pour men / and nedy / the second^
to foundynge of abbayes / the third to scolers of oxenford that were gadred and
should be gadred there / and the fourth part to amendyng of chirches / and for
he would weye his own lif a right he departed in three the four and twenty
hours of the day and night / and spend eight thereof in writing and redynge
and byddyng of bedes / eight about his bodyly needs / and eight about needs of
the kingdom / And to depart these hours redyly / h^ set a candel in his
chapel of four and twenty parties and should be warned by them that were
ordained therefore / as often as any of thylke four and twenty were spente /
After the month of his kingdom he fought with the danes at wyl^ton with great
harm of both the hoostes / For englissmen were destroyed with eight batayllis
in one year and were much febled / therefore engli^shm^n made that year pees
with the danes on the coneuaunt / that they should wend from hem / and so they
did / for that year they dwellid at london / and the next year after at
lindesaye / And the merces made pees with the danes also at that time / but in
the third year the danes brake the pees / and went out of lind^seye to
R^^yndon Charles the elder the third lowes brother took the weye to Rome when
his brother was deed / and was crowned Emperor of pope Johan and reigned two
year / For whiles he ordained at papye for the comune prouffyt of the Empire /
he herd of the coming of charlemayne / that was his own broders son And
his heart byganne to fall for dread / and went toward France / and deide
among the great hills / called the Alps / After him his son lowys balbus
reigned two year / After him Charles the younger that was called grossus / that
is great / the sone of the third lowys reigned ten year / That year the danes
lef^e lindeseye and came to Rependon / there they put out burdredus king of
mercia / and bitoke the kingdom to one Colwulfus / that was Burdredus servant
upon such a condition / that they should have the kingdom ayene when they
would / But after three year they departed sum of the kingdom bitwene hem /
and sum they left to colwulfus / and this Colwulfus was the last king of
mercia / After his death Aluredus joined london first / and Colwulfus part to
his own kingdom / Also that year the danes came often to Rependon / and the men
of hamburgh that is five mile fro Rependon were wonder soore aferd and took the
body of saint werburgh the maid that had long time ley buried there / and
was alwey hool and sou^de / unto that time and translated her to chestre as to
a seker place / Also that year king Aluredus made pees with the danes and they
slough the kings horsemen al in one night Therefore the king was meoued and
chaced hem unto chestre / And the danes delyuerd and yaue efte pledges and
dwelled a year there / Henricus libro quinto / That year Rollo the dane came
first in to normandye and reigned there forty year / Willelmus de Regibus libro
/ 2 / First one hastynges and than Rollo noricus / that is a dane that had no
country of his own / but by heste of the king / he ^xyted mysdo^^s that
coneyted other men's gods and catayls and brought hem in great hoope of
great wynnyng and led hem with him and warryd on land and on see from brittyssh
occean unto the sea called mare tirenum / that is the sea that stretches to
ytaly / then he come to Carnotum / there the Cy^eseyns trust not on her
walls nowther on her strength / but they took our lady smock that charles the
balled had brought with other relyques out of constantinople and set the
smock upon a pynacle / as it were a baner / the enemies scorned the smock /
ands hotten there at and were smyten with blyndenes / but Roll escaped and
occupied Rothomage the year of our lord eight honderd / lxxvij / that was one
year before the death of charles the balled / his son Lowys overcome the
normans but he put hem not oute^ And Charles simplex otherwise called Grossus /
this lowys brother and neuew to charles the balled was often ouersette in
batayllis with Rollo / and took counseyl at last / and acorded with Rollo^
so that he should be cristened and knowledge that he held n^oma^dye and
Armorica / that is little britayne of the king of France as of the chyef lord
/ when that was do men that stood by counseylled rollo that he should kiss
the kings feet that yafe him such a yefte / But he had indignacion and was
to proud to fall down on his knees / but took up the kings foot to his
mouth so that he threw the king upright / For that hap normans began to
laugh and the frensshmen wax right wroth / Rollo excusyd him of that boystous
deed / and alleged the manner and usage of his countreye Thanne Rollo went
ayene to Rotomage / and ordained for his catell and things / and deyde sone
thereafter /

Capitulum secundum /
LOwys balbus reigned in France two year / In his first year the danes sailed
from warham toward ^xcestre / and lost ^^x score ships in a tempeste of the sea / But sum of the danes occupied the Royal Cite Chypenham and the
countreye about / and chaced awey many englysshemen / owther made them subgette
/ In the meschyef of that time king aluredus with few men led uncertain and
vnnesy life in the wode countries of Somersete / For he had right naught to
live by / but what he might win by prays / owther with huntyng / owther
with fyss^yng^ / On a time while his felawes were a fysshynge / and he
comforted his uncertain and vnstidfast life with comfort of ^okes / A pilgrim
came to him and axed alms in gods name / The king lift up his hands to
heaven and said I thank god that vysyted his poor man this day / by a pore man
That he wol vouchsauf this day to axe of me that he has yeuen me / and restore
again with encreace / that he axeth of me / Anon the king called his
servant that had but one looff and little what of wine / and had him give
the half thereof / to the poor man / The poor man thanked him and vanysshed
suddenly away / and no step was seen of his going in the nesshe more / And
also all that was yeuen him / was founden hoole an^ sound / And they that
were a ffysshynge brought great plentye of ffysshe / Then when the king
was slepynge / one appeared to him in a Bisshops wede / and charged him that he
should love god / and keep ryghtwysenesse and be merciable against pore men / and
worship^ priests / And said moore to / mine Aluredus Christ knows thy
conscience / and thy will and puts an end of thy sorrow and care for to
morrow strong helpers shall be with the / By help of hem thou shall overcome
thine enemies / who art thou said the king / I am Cutberth said he / thy
pilgrim that yisterdaye was here with the / to whom thou yaue breed and wyn /
I am besy for the and for thine / have mind hereof / when it is well with the
/ But how he made mind of his pilgrim by the fredom and possession of the
church of durham / it is now seen / Willelmus de regibus libro / 2

Than Aluredus came out of prysonne / and put him to a peril of great fraud
and gyle / For he went in to the king of Danes pauylons and tents / in
myustralles weed / and espied all that he would / and come again to ethelynge
and declared to his felawe the slewthe of his enemies / Then be fylle suddenly
on his enemies / and slough moo of hem than me would trow / For the day after
came to him the men of wyl^shir / of So merse^te / and of Hampshyre / By help
of hem / he build a tour at Ethlynge / that is to say in English that now
is used the ylelande of noble men / Out of that tour ^e ^eesed often his
enemies and overcome hem / and namely besyde^ Selwode that is a great wode in
English that now is used / So that he received hostages and pledgis the best
that he wold^ ch^ese / And Guttrun king of Danes was Crysten^d / and twenty of
the grettest that were with him the which king Alfredus received of the cold
water / and yaue him a name / and called him Adelstan / Therefore to king
Guttrun that we call Gurmundus were yeuen the prouynces of Eest Angles / and
of northumberlonde for to dwell ynne / But for the blewe man changes not
lightly his skin / This Guttrun destroyed the lands with tyranny / / and
with pride enleuen year / and dyede the twellyfth year / The other Danys that
would not be Christian went in to France / That place that hete Ethlyng or
Ethelyngeseye is not an Ilelande of the sea / but it stands in water marreys
and moors / so that me may not come there to but by ship owther by boot /
The place conteyneth uneath the space of twey days journey of earth in breed
/ and yet there ben wild beestes / and veneson / Charles the younger otherwise
called Grossus / that is great was the thyrdde Lowys son / and reigned in
France after his came lowys balbus / ten year / he went out of Almayne and
occupied ytaly five days and came to Rome and was sacred emperor of pope Iahan
/ In his time byganne the Erldomme of Flaundrys / For that time Flaundrys was
not of great name / but it was ruled by the kings Forsters of France /

Also this Charles put fro him his wife / for it seemed that she was to pryue
with the bishop of Versell / Therefore the king of France knowleched openly
that he himself had never leyne by her flessbely / And she was glad of her
maydenhode / and and went in to an Abbaye when she was forsaken / At last
/ the tenthe year of his kingdom / this Charles went out of France in to
ytaly / and was poisoned of a Jew called Sedechias / and dyed at hills
Alps / Ranulphus It seems that this is that Charles that married his daughter
Gilla that he had by his rather wife / to duc Rollo / and granted with her
the ducheryes of normandye and of little Brytayne

Willelmus de pontificibus libro secundo /

Also that year dyede Du^bertus Bishop of Wynchestre / And king Aluredus made
Dunewolfus Bishop in his stead / that be found in the wood in his hydynge
time kepyng^ beestes / But when he knew his good will after g^e^t^ age / he
put him to scole to learn lettrure / and clergy / That year the king
aluredus amended the cite of Septon / that is shaftesbury / as a greet stone
wytnessyth / that there in the Chapter hows of Nonnes lies above earth After
Johan / martyn was pope one year / He relessyd to the Scole of Saxons al manner
trybute at prayer of king Aluredus / Also he sen^te to Aluredus a great
part of the holy cross / After marty^ agapitus was pope one year / the which
year the danes came ou^^ of France / and besyeged Rochestre / and build a tour
ayenst^ the yates of the cyt^ / But the Cyteseyns defended the Cite til^ that
Aluredus come and took all the horses of Danes / and compellyd hem to flee /
Then the danes went in to France ayene / and the king sent his navy full
of men of arms out of kente in to Eest england / and took sixten ships of
danes / But in the coming again the kings nauye was ouercome^ / Treuisa /
Eeste Engelonde / conteyneth Northfolke / and Southfolke / Look more hereof in
the first book capitulo iji / It follows in the storye / that year the danes
rowed in the water of Seyne and besyeged paris a year all hoole / That year
Aluredus reparayled london / and bytoke it to the k^pynge of Etheldredus Earl
of mercia / Than the Englysshmen that were disparpled yaf hem self to the king
Aluredus /

That time the king sent his alms to Rome and to Inde and build twey
Abbayes one of men at Ethelyngesley and another of women at Shaftesbury and
made his doughte^ Etholgof Abbes there / After Agapytus / the thyrdde Adryan^
was pope one year / After him Basilius one year / After him Stephen six year /

Capitulum 3 /
CHarles Grossus was poysonned of a Jew as it is said before / and wexed
strongly seek / Therefore Arnulphus the son of his brother Charleman was chosen
king / But when Charles was deed / were ordained five kings / But the
Empire lest with Arnulphus / and he was crowned at last of Formosus the
pope / and he beat down the norma^s and the danes that had werrid in france
xl / year / Aatte last he was hard holden with a strong sickness / and might
not be heled ne saved with no manner medycyne / that he was destroyed and eten
with lyse right to the death / Franco Archebisshop of Rothomage Crystened Rollo
/ And king Guttrun is deed

Willelmus de Regibus libro secundo For reses of normans and of the danes /
saint ma^tyus body was translate from Turon to saint Germayns church at
Altissiodor / and many were there miracles done / And the monks of Turon and
of Altissiodore pleted for thofferyng / And for the saint should deem whether
of hem had right of thofferyng / they brought forth a leper that was heled in
that one side of his body / that was to ward saint martyn / and the other
part of his body left foul and not heled / Than for me should wene that
that was happyly byfalle / they turned the other foul side toward saint
martyn / and anon it was heled also /

Than the monks of Turon had at the offering till the werre was seeced and
than they had her own saint hoome again to her own hows / This befell not
in this manner / for no power of saint germayne / but he spared and did his
gheste reverence in his own hows / Henricus libro quinto / That year came four
hoostes of danes against Aluredus / one in northu^mberlonde / another in
Eestenglonde that conteyneth Norffolk / and southfolk / the thyrdde at Excestre
/ the fourth at Chestre / but at chestre the danes were so besyeged / that
they ete her horses for honger / Three scottysmen dusblay mahbon / and malmmyn
desired to lead pylgryms life and took with hem lyueloode for one weke / and
took Akarabum / that is a ^oote made but of twey huydes and an half and went
therinne wonderly without sail without rother and oore / and al manner tacle
of

Shipcraft and came on land at Cornewayle after seven days / and come to king
Aluredus / After steven fo rmosus was pope five year / Sometime for dread of
pope Johan / he left his bisshopryche of portune / but for when he was called
/ he would not come ageyn / he was cursyd / At last he come to the pope Johan
/ and was degraded unto the state of a lewd man / Also he was made swear that
he should never turn ayene to hi^ bisshopryche nowther come in to the cite of
Rome / But at last he was restored again by pope martyn that was pope
Iohannis successor / Plegmundus Archebisshop of Caunterbury that was a noble
man of Clergy received the palle of formosus / the pope / and ordained seven
Bisshops to chirches of england in one day / That year king Aluredus chaced the
danes furste out of Kente / of excestre / and of Chichestre /

Henricus libro quinto / The danes that were at Chestre were besyeged three
days / And were compellyd by honger to leave the Cite / Than they spoylled
Northwales / and went so about by Northumberlonde in to Eest England / there
her wives and their Ships were / They entryd in to the River luys / and
build a castle there fast by / But the Londoners by help of the king
destroyed that castle / and departed that River in three channels or stremes /
So that Danes might not bring out their Ships / and dwelled at bridge
upon Seua^n fast by wales / and build there a strong castle / And so these
three year / England was hard bysette with three manner of sorrow / with war
of the Danes / Moreyue of men / and pestylence of beestes / After Formosus
Bonefas was pope fyften days / After him the sixth steven one year and three
months / there after he left the papacye / and was made monk / This was
sometime made Bishop of Angum by Pope Formosus / But afterward when he was
pope he pursued so Formosus that not only he withsayde his doing and his deeds
/ But also he let take up Formosus / when he was deed / out of the earth
/ and made men bring him in to the plain Consistorye clothed as a pope / And
than he made men unclothe him / and take of him that manner clothing / and
clothe him as a lewd man / and kytte of twey fyngars of his right hand and
cast him in to Tyber / After this Steven Romanus was pope four months /
Lowys Arnulphus son reigned in France twelve year / But he had never the
Crown of the Empire / And in him was the end of the Empire* / towchynge
Charles ofsprynge /? In his time were five Popes Theodorus / Johan / Benette /
Leo / and Crystofor / Of hem Theodorus the second / though he were Pope / but
one monethe / yet he aroos against pope Steuens doing / and wi^hsayd his deeds /
and confermed the deeds of Pope Fromosus / The nynth Johan was pope two year /
he made a counseyll at Rauenna / and dampened pope steuenes deeds and fought
against the Romans Willelmus de re / libro secundo / This year deyd king
Aluredus and was first buried in the cathedral chirch at wynchestre / but for
the madness and rauynge of the chanons that said / that spyryts of kings
taken the careyn / and walk about by night from hows to hows / His son
Edward took the faders body and did it in the new Abbaye / This and such
other lewd tales Englysshmen holden by a mysbyleue that has full long dured
/ and borrowed it of mysbyleuyd men / That they trow not that after a man's
death the body walks and goth about by menyng of the fend / Thereof spekyth
Vyrgyl / and said / when death comes what semyng shappes flees about /
Ranulphus / In praysynge of this king Henricus libro primo writes versus in
this manner / Kyndly noblesse / of goodness / yeueth to the worshipe / And
goodness travail / mighty werryour Aluredus / And travail name / to the
without any end / Joy with woo meddled / he had in every time / Alweye
thine hoope was meddled with greet dread / Though he were now down / he arayd
bataylle a morrow / if he were vyctor / he dradde the bataylle a morrow / After
trauaylle of life / of regnynge both / His very rest / be with Christ
without end / Marianus libro secundo /

Capitulum 4 /
EDward the elder by his surname reigned after his fader four and twenty year /
he was lower than his fader in worshiy of lettrure and higher than he in wordly
joy / and worship / For he build new Cytees / and repaired citees that
were apayred / And spradde the ends of his kingdom wydder than did his fader
/ He made the kings of Scotts of Cumbres and of walsshmen to yield hem to him
/ He wanne Essex / Northumberlonde and mercia with strength out of the hands
of the danes / and had al mercia after the death of his suster Elfleda / On
his first wife Egwyna he gate his oldest soune Edelstan / On queen Edgyna he
gate Edredus and Edwynus and seven daughters / he married one of hem to Otho the
Emperor / and another to Charles / king of weste France / and the thyrdde to
Sythyrycus duc of northumberlond

Willelmus de Regibus libro secundo / On his third wife Ethelswyda / he bygate
Edmonde / and Edrede / Either of hem reigned after her brother ethelstan / he
bygate also two daughters / Saint Edburgh that was sacred^ to God / and restyth
at wynchestre / And Edgyna the fair that was married to lowys king of guyan /
Also this made his sons learn lettrure / and he made his daughters first
learn lettrure / And after that he made hem use the nylde and the dystaf /
Willelmus de pontificibus libro secundo / Of this maid Edburga it is read /
that when she was three year old / her fader would wit and essay whether she
would turn to God / owther to the world / and leyde in that one side of his
chamber many ^ay^ I^wels and diverse and greet Riches / And on that other side
chalyce and gospels / Than in another place he p^tt besauntes broches and
rings / thanne the noryce brought forth the child And the child was boden
chese / and take what she would / and she crepte on hand and on foot / and
took the gospel / Than the fader kyssed the child / and said goo thither as god
clepe^^ the / sewe him with a gracious foot that ledeth the And so there after
she was made nonne / kings blood never made her torn aweywarde / But she
would take the shoes of her sustres pryuely bx night and wasshe hem / and
smere hem / and bring hem pryuely again / that sygnefyed mekenes /

After Johan the fourth Benette was pope three year. Also that year saint
Gyrmbald the Confessor that was king Aluredus techer dyed at wynchestre / That
year plegmundus the Archebisshop of the Cite of dorob^rnia / that is
Caunterbury / ordained seven bisshops to the chirches of England / Five to the
land of guyseyes / that be westsaxons / one at wynchestre / one at Cornewayle
/ one at Shirburn / one at wells / one at kyrton / Also among the southsaxons
one / And in mercia one at Dorkyngam that is Dorchestre besides Oxenford. /

For formosus the pope had yeuen his course to king Edward and to Englysshmen
by cause of scarsete of Bisshops in her land that had be bisshoples seven
year to geder /

That year breed failed in Irlonde / For worms that were twey tothed / and
like to wontes fylle down fro heuene / and ete the breed corn / But the
worms were done aweye by prayenge and fasting /. Clyto Ethelwoldus king
edwardes ^ames son / roo^ or rebellyd against the king and occupied the cite
of wynburn besides bath and said that he would have the maystrye owther dye
there / But he rauesshyd and took with him a nonne of thabbaye of wynburn and
went thens to the danes of northumberlond and prayde hem of help / But the
king pursued him so strongly that he forsook England / and fled in to France
/ But the king brought with him the nonne ageyn / and restored her to her
abbay / But the same year Ethelwulfus come again with ships in great array /
and took with him the danes that dwelled in eeste england and assailed and
destroyed all that he might find unto Crekanford / that is cryklade / then he
passed temse / and spoylled and robbed the land Bradenestok / and so he went
ayene to eestenglond / that conteyneth northfolk / and southfolk / as it is
said before often time The king followed after and destroyed and spoylled the
land of his enemies from the River ous to the bounds of saint edmundes land
/ And badde his men that none of hem should abide behind / but the kentysshmen
forgendryd the kings heest / and abode there / and were slain nygh all of the
danes / many were slain on either side / But clyto ethelwoldus was slain
among his enemies / than the danes saw that king Edward might not be
overcome and made pees with him / After bene^ he fyfthe leo was pope twey
months / For his pressed crystofor prysonned him and took the papasye so / by
maystry / but he was cast out after the fourth month / the fourth Sergius
putt out crystofor / and was pope there after seven year / Sometime he was deken
cardynal / and reprouyd of Formosus the pope / and went to Frensshmen / by
help of hem he prisoned crystofer that gate the poperyche / and held it by
strength / and than he him self occupied the poperyche / and in wreche of his
puttyng / he made men take up Formosus the pope out of his grave / and smite
of his heed / and threw the body in to Tyber / But at last fysshers found
the body and brought it to saint peter's church and the images of holy saints
did that body great reverence and worship in his coming That year the cite
Caerleon that is legec^stria that now is callid chestre / after that it was
destroyed by the danes / it was restored again by help of etheldredus duc of
mercia and of his wife e^fleda / that cite than was closed about with new
walls / and made nyghe such two as it was before So that the castle was
sometime by the water / without the walls is now in the town within the walls
/ Ranulphus / King edward buyld a castle at herford / That time was thabbay of
cluny founded of wyliam the mylde prince of burgoyn / the first abbot of that
place was saint odo the second mayclus / Wi / de p / li / 4 / Seyth that first
the monks of that place were rich in the world / and and of clear Relygyon in
god / That time etheldredus duc of mercia / and his wife elfleda translated ^
the bones of saint oswald the king from bardeny to gloucestre / there they
buyld an abbay in worship of saint peter

Capitulum quintum
COnradus after lowys was made prince among the almayns / But for he was not
emperor in ytaly / he is not rekened among emperors / ne he is not enhaunced
with sacryng and blessings / but he reigned seven year / In this year bygan
thempyre to pass from frensshmen to the Almayns / For lowys predecessor of
this might not defend the Romans ayenste the Longobardes / thempyre passyd
from the Frensshmen / And so were twey Emperors / one in Almayne and another
in ytaly / unto the first otho that was Emperor of both / That year in the
prouynce of stafford at toten hale the Englysshmen overcome the danes and
afterward at wodenysfelde / king edward slough of the danes twey kings / twey
earls / and many thousands of danes of northumberlond / Etheldredus duc and
leder under king of mercia deyde / and his wife elfleda king Edwardes suster
regn^d nobly long time in all mercia / out take london and ox^nford / the
which the king held to him selfward / she build many cytees and towns and
amended many one / that be brymmesbury bridge upon seuarn / thomworth besides
lychefelde / stafford / warwyk sheresbury / watrisbury / Edysbury in the forest
beside Chestre / that now is al destroyed / Also she bylde a Cite with a Castle
in the north ends of mercia upon the River merce that than was named Runcofan
/ But now it is called Runcorn / Willelmus de regibus libro secundo This strong
vyrago Elfleda favor of cyteseyn^ and dread of enemies halpe much the king /
her brother in yeuyng of counseyl and buyldyng of Cytees / when she had ones
assayed the woe and the sorrow only of one child / that she bare / she hated
the enbracyng of a man after for evermore / And took witness of god and said
/ that it was not semely to a kings daughter to use flesshely liking where
such sorrow should come after / The ^er thieves of danes that went out of
england in to France about nynten year before / come again in to England /
and sailed about Cornewayle and come in to Seuarn see / and took prays / and
teke a bryttyssh bishop in Irchenfelde / the which Bishop king edward
raunsoned for forty pound / and chaced the enemies in to yrlond / and made a
castle at mouth of the water of auene and other Castles at Bokyngham in
either side of the River ouse / and made subget the danes that dwelled at
betford and at northhampton and her king Turketillus / Anastasius was pope two
year / After him lando was pope fine months / That year the hungaryes that be
by the River of danubins / destroyed ytaly / The tenth Johan was pope fourten
year / This was pope Sergius son and Bishop of Raven / By his help
Albericus the markys put the sauasyns out of ytalye / At last fyl stryf and
discord between hem and the pope put the markys out of the cite / therefore he
was wroth and brought the hungaryes that had destroyed ytalye / therefore the
markys was ^slayn but the pope was straungled of the markys knights / That
year deyde Rollo the first duc of normandye after the fourtenth year of his
duchery / his sone wiliam longa spata was duc after him five and twenty year /
Elfleda queen of mercia took prays in the land of brytons at brechnok / and
took the kings wif of wales and ren^wed legecestre that is chestre / king
edward bylde the Cytees of Toucetre and of wygmore and destroyed the castle
that the danes had made at Temesforde / Elfleda took the cite of derby upon the
dan^s / her four mynystres were slain / Harry the sone of duc Otho of saxo^
reigned eyght^n year over the almayns / but not in ytaly / and therefore he is not
aco^pted among the emperors / this overcome the hungaryes and turned to the
feyth the duc of normandy / wiliam longa spata / longa spata is a long sword
in english / Will / de Regibus libro secundo / That year deyde elfleda eygten
days before Iulij / five year before the death of her brother king edward / And
she was buried in gloucestre in saint peter's church that she and her husbo^d
had bylde upon king oswaldes boones / that they had brought thither from
bardeny / But the danes destroyed that church / and aldredus bishop both of
york and of worcestre reparayled another that is now the chyef abbay of the
cite / king Edward took the power of mercia from elswyna the daughter of
Elfleda / and led her with him in to westsaxon R In praysyng of this elfleda
/ Henricu^ libro quinto / O Elflede mighty o maid men's dread / vyctryce of
kind well worthy the name of a man And the well bryghter / now kind has made
a maid / go^dnes has the maid to have the name of a man / kind techeth the
to change nothing but the name / mighty king and queen victoryes to arraye /
Cesars tryumphes were not so much worthy / Nobler than Caesar / maid vyrago
Fare well / when king Edward herd the death of his suster / he made subget to
him thom worth and snotyngham that now is nothyngham / there he byld a new
cite in the south side right against the old cite / and set a brygge upon
trente between the twey cyte^s / there after in the same year twey kings yield
hem freely to hym^ / that were the kings of Scotlonde / of danes / and of wales
/ That year king Edward buyld a cite at thylwal / that is in the north ends
of mers^a by the water of mersee / and there he set keeping of knights /
Than he passed the water of mersee / and restored the Cite of manchestre / that
is in the south ends of northumberlond / king Edward dyed at faryndon twelve
mile by west oxenford and was buried at wynchestre in the new abbay /

Capitulum sextum
EDelstan king edwardes oldest son was made king at kyngeston besides
london in southrey / ^e reigned sixten year In his first year the noble child
dunstan was borne in the coutreye of glastenbury / Al his life to his ending
day he shone by virtues and by miracles / Alfredus / King Edelstan married his
sus^er to sithricus king of the danes of northumberlonde / Sythrycus dyed sone
after / and the king put out Sythrycus son / and joined that kingdom to
his own / Than by bataylle he made subgett ho^lus king of brytons / and
Constantyn king o^ the Scotts and received him when they were yolden / King
Ethelstan made this Constantyn king of Scotlond / Than Constantyn said / It
is more worship to make a king / than to be a king / Willelmus de Regibus
libro secundo / Also king ethelstan married his other suster to Otho the
Emperor and receyuyd of him horses and other precious stones / and a manner
vessel of stone called Onychynus / that was clear and bright / and let not
the passing of light / nowther of syghte and it was made subtylly by grauynge
craft that it seemed verily that corn growing therynne waued hyder and thither
/ as long corn does in feldes / and that vynes bourgened / and images of men
meoued / Also he received of him the great Constantynes sword / In that sword
the owners name was read in lettres of gold / in the hylte thereof in great
plates of gold was stykked on of the four iron nails that christ was nailed
with to the roode / he received of him the great charles spear / ever when
Charles shoke that spear / he had the maystrye / Me says that spear opened
Crystes own side / and saint moris baner / that baner Charles used against the
sarasyns / Also he received a part of the holy cross and sum of the thorned
crown / King ethelstan ordained sum of the Relyques to the abbay of
malmesbury / Mar / The sixth leo was pope four year and / vij / months / Odo
is made bishop of wylton / Willelmus de pontificibus libro secundo / Frystan
Bishop of wynchestre deyde / and Birstan was Bishop after him / Of this
Byrstan it is read that he sange as it were every day for all Christian sowles /
Than he went on a night about a church yerde and said salmes for all christian
sowles / and when he had al said he said Requiescant in pace / And he herd a
voys of a great host answer / out of graves / and said Amen / Odo Bishop of
wynchestre is made archebisshop of Dorobernia that is Caunterbury. Than Steven
was pope seven year / Odo Bishop of wynchestre is deed / After him elphegus
the balled was bishop of wynchestre / that man was a prophet and nygh of
saint dunstans kyn / Willel / de pontificibus libro secundo / On asshe
wonesdaye as the manner is / he put hem that should do open penance out of
church / and charged other men that they should in thylke days fast / and be
chaste and spare liking of their wives / Among hem al one spoke and said /
Sir I may not at this time leave both my feste and my wife / But the wife that I
have put awey for the time / I shall sone take her ageyn / Wretch said the
bishop thou make me soory thou know not what is for the ordained against
the morewe / Than on the morn he was founden deed in his bed / also on a time
this ethelphegus made three monks priests dunstan Ethelwold and ethelstan /
And when the service was done / he spak to hem and said / This day before
god I have set mine hand upon three men / Tweyne of hem shall be bisshops /
but the third shall make a wretchid end / Than ethelstan was the more homely
by cause of kynrade and spoke and said / Shall I be a bishop thou shall have no
part in this order said elphegus / nowther thou shall bear long this clothing
/ For Constantyn king of Scotts had broken covenant / King ethelstan
arayd him toward Scotland and inthe wey he went on pylgremage to saint Johan of
beuerley / and leyd his knyf to wedde upon saint Iohans auter / and said if he
come again with the vyctory be should raunsonne his knyf with a worthy prys
After the vyctory when he come again / he prayed god that he would through the
prayer of seint johan of beuerley show some open toke^ / by which token they
that be and shall be may know that the Scotts by right should be subget to
englisshmen / Thanne the king with his sword smote on a great stone fast by
the Castle of dunbar / In that stone yet to this day is seen of that stroke a
chynne of an elne long / Than the king came ageyn and raunsonned his kynf with
worthy doing / the enleuenth Johan was pope one year / After him the seventh
leo was pope three year and six months Lowys the sone of charles the simple
and of king edwardes daughter reigned in France after his fader in westfraunce
nynten year / Willelmus de r / libro secundo / He was on a time pursued of one
Isenbardus / and axed help of the lords of his land / and they yaf him none
answer / Than hughe a simple knight of Earl Robberts of mount desire / took
wylfully the bataylle for his lord and slough him withynne lystes that would
needs fight therefore sone ater when the king was feeble / he made this hugh his
heyr / and so ceesed the ofsprynge of charles / owther for his wife was barayne
/ owther for he lyuede but a short time / than this hugh wedded king Edwardes
other daughter The first Otho the son of the first harry / was the first
Emperor of duchemen / and reigned seven and tthyrty year / On an eester time he
made a great feste to his princes and lords / And er they were all served a
princes son took a mess of the board as a child should / and the kings sewer
smote the child with a staf / the childs master saw that / and slough the
sewer anon / than the emperor would have dampened him without audyence / he
threw down the emperor to the earth / and straungeled him al most / the
Emperor was uneath delyuerd out of the chyldes maystres hands / but when he
bade save the chlides masters life / and cried and said that he him self was to
blame / for he had not spared him for so great a feste / That year Anlaf a
paynym king of Irlond and of many ylondes Syhtricus son by exytynge of his
wives fader that was Constantyn king of Scotland / Anlaf entered in to the
mouth of the river of humbre with a strong nanye / king Edelstan and his
brother Edmond met him at Brymford / Willelmus de Regibus libro secundo /
When the hoostes were gadryd Anlaf bythought him of a queyn^ gyle / and took an
harp in his hand / and came to ethelstanes tenth / in harpers arraye / There
at mete time he espied all that he would / and had money for his harpynge
He had the money against his heart / and buried it pryuely under him in the earth
/ That was espied of one that had be sometime a soudyour with anlaf / and he
warned ethelstan / when Anlaf was a goo / The king blamed him for he warned
him no rather / he answerde and said O king the same feyth that I owe now to
the I yaf to Anlaf sometime / Therefore if I had broken that feyth to him thou
would wene that I would do the same to the another time / But now take heed
to my counseylle / Remeoue thy tent fro this place / that when he comes
unwisely he may fail of his purpos / than thou may overcome him with great
sobrenes / This was do / and Anlaf came hastily by night and in the wey he
slough a Bishop that remeoued his tente / and his meyny / and passed forth and
fylle on the kings tente / But the king was waked with so great noise and
his swerd fylle forth of his skaberd / and he cried to god and to saint Aldelm
And at prayer of odo the Archebisshop that was than with the king / the
king fond his swerd fallen in to his scaberd ayene That sword is yet kept
in the kings tresorye / that sword is keruyng on that one side / and
reyceueth in no place neither gold ne silver / By that yefte of god the king
was then helped / and chaced his enemies all that dawynge and al day on the
morrow / there the king Constantyn was slain / and five other small kings and
twelve dukes / and well nygh all the gadrynge of strange nations / here after
he chaced the north brytons at herford / so that they should pay him every year
twenty pound of gold and and three honderd pound of silver / and five and twenty
honderd heed of neete / tha^n he took to his subjection Cornugallia / and
amended excetre / In praysynge of him / one made this dyte / Kings blood
brought forth a full noble knight / Bright precious stone / tho byshone our
derk so bright / Great Ethelstanus hight of land path to the right / Noble
worthynes the sothe forsake ne might / After leo the third martyn was pope three
year and six months / Also that year Ethelstan dyed at gloucet^e and had no
child / and was buried at madulf / Marianus

Capitulum 7
THan Athelstans brother Edmundus biganne to regne in his twenty year of age /
and reigned about seven year / and bygate on his queen Elgina twey sons /
Edwyn and Edgar the pesyble / Willelmus de Regibus libro secundo / In this
Edwyns time the northumbres rebellyd and sent for Anlaf out of Irlond / But
king Edmund overcome him / And Reynold gurmundus son / and outlawed hem and
took northumberbond to his own lordship / And beat down Combreland that was
rebel and yaf it to malcolyn king of Scotland / So that he should help him
in every place where he were / R ^ It seems that in this iourneye / king
Edmond took with him the boones of Colfrydus the abbot / and of hylda thabbesse
/ and brought hem to glastenbury / Alfrydus says / and marianus also / that
the king in the seventh year of his kingdom would deliver his sewer out of
his enemies hands / and was slain of hem right there at pulkerchirche But
Willelmus de Regibus libro secundo / says that the king was at a feste at
Pulker church / on saint austyns day and he saw one leof / a thief / that he
had exyled for his trespass / sit there at mete among other men / And the
king lepte over the board / and took the thief by the hee^ / and threw him to
ground / and the thief gloton with his knyf rent out the kings bowels /
Than the thief between the hands of hem that made noise and cry / wounded and
slough many men / and was alto bakked of knights and of other men After martyn
the second Agapitus was pope six year / That year lowys the king of France /
the son of Charles made william longa spa^a be slain gylefully the second duc
of normandye the son of Rollo Therefore the lords of normandy* were wroth and
took the king and held him in Rothomage / till that he had promised and sworn
that he should yield normandy to Rychard duc wili^ms son / And that ^uer
after that time / in every speech / when the king and the duc spak to gyder
/ the duc should be gyrde with a sword / and the king should neither ^ere
sword ne knyf / After this ducwyliams young son Rychard was duc / And yet
while this Rychard was young / he was called richard the old / and without
dread / for he dradde never / he was duc of normandye two and fyfty year / and
come to his duchery by hard trauaylle and great / and on his wife gunnora a
dane / he bygate five sons and twey daughters / The first was called Emma /
and was the flour of normandy / Her fader married her to Etheldredus king of
England / This duc Rychard used to bydde his bedes in every church / that he
come by / and namely without / if he might not come in to the church / On a
night he came in to a church allone / and found a Corpse ly^ ther^ on a bear /
and no man therewith / while he hade his bedes / be laid his gloves on a deske /
and forgate hem there / and went on his weye / Then the deed man aroos with
a great noise / and spr^d his arms in the church door ayenste the duc / The
duc made the sign of the cross in his forheede with his thombe / and coniured
the deed man that he should rest. But al for naught / for it would not be /
Than the duc with his sword smote the corpse in twey / and by thought him when
he was out / that he had forgeten his gloves / Than he turned ayene and fett
his gloves / Afterward he ordained in all his land / that about a deed corpse
should be a watch all the night long / It happeth that a monk of saint
Ando^nus of Rothomage would on a night go to his lemman / and fill down of a
bridge in to a water / and was drowned / Than for his soul was stryf between
an Aungel and a fend / And either of hem put the cause upon duc Rycharde^
dome / And he yaue such a dome / that the soul should be restored ayene to
the body / and the body should be set on the bridge / of the which he had
fallen^ And if he went than to do that sin / he should be dampened / and
else he should be saved / when this was do the monk fled to church /
The duc went on the morrow to the same church / and fond the monks clothes
yet al wete / and told thabbot of the place / that deed that was bifalle
When the duc / and Gunnora had long lived in dishonest^ life / the people
spak much therof^ And the duc by counseyll of the people wedded her at last
/ Than the first night after the wedding / when they come to bed / whether
it were in game or in ernest / gunnora turned her bakke and her buttoks toward
the duc as she had never before done / me axyd of her why she did so / for
now first said she I may do what / me lyketh / Also this duc wax seek upon a
time / and made him a great chyste and filled it full of whete and deled it to
pour men energy friday to his lives end / Henr / Edmond king of England took
and wan out of the danes hands that were paynyms five noble cytees / lyncoln
/ notingham / derby / stafford and legecestre. he took fro hem these Cytees in
that they were paynyms / and caused these cytees to be of right believe / For he
received anlaf of the cold water / Anlaf was cristened more by strength than by
preching of gods word / Also ordained and made ordenaunces / and amended
what should be amended by counseyll of dunstan / and made the abbay of
glastenbury / noble in cataylle / and in monks / R / As it is said before at
last he dyed at pulkerchirche and was buried at glastenbury Marianus libro
secundo

Capitulum Octauum /
EDredus was euoynted at kyngeston of odo tharchebisshop and reigned after his
brother edmond ten year / For Edmondes sons edwyn and edgar were yet of young
age and to young for to regne / this edredus in the first year of his kingdom
beet down strongly the northumbres that were rebels / therefore the scotts
dradde him and yield them to him / after agapitus the / xij / john was pope
viij / year / his fader alberycus was mighty in the cite of Rome and he made
the noble men of the cite to swear that they should make his son octauianus
pope when agapytus were deed / and so they did / and changed his name / and
named him johan / he was an hu^ter and a lecherous man / so that he held
wymen with him openly Therefore some of the cardynals wrote to otho the e^perour
of saxons / and prayed him that he would come to rome and help to do aweye the
sklaunder of holy church / the pope was war thereof and kytt of the nose of the
counseyllour and the hand of the writer that wrote that let / than he was often
warned by the emperor / and by the clergy that he should amend him self / and
for he would not he was deposed and leo was made pope in his stead / but when
the emperor was gone benett was made pope / therefore the emperor came again and
besyeged Rome till they yield benet to him and restored leo ageyn / Lowys the
king of westfraunce is deed / the sone of charles the simple After him his sone
lotharius was king xxxvij / year and dyed without children / he pursued Rychard
duc of normandye as his fader had pursued wiliam his fader / Mar / But at last
edredus for the untruth of the northumbres / he destroyed her land and brent
thabbay of Rypon with fire / when the king went thens home ward / an host
brake out of york / and did great harm on the last party of the kings host
/ therefore the king was wroth / and thought to destroy al northu^berlond / but
the northumbres did awey hircus that was their king and plesyd the king with /
yefces / king Edredus bygan to be soore seek / and sent for his goostly fader
dunstan / and he came with greet speed / and as he came in the weye a voys spak
to him clearly / and said / now restyth king edredus in pees / At that voys the
horse that dunstan sat on fylle down and dyed without hurtynge of him that
sat above / Dunstan byryed the king at wynchestre / in the old abbay / After
this king that dyed without issue / edwynus was king edmundus oldest sone / and
was enoynted king of england in the Royal town kyngeston be side london of Odo
tharchebisshop / the first day of his sacrynge he fill in to an unlawful
lechery / therefore dunstan myssayed him and blamed him therefore / and therefore he
exiled dunstan and many monks / and took fro hem what they had / he putt
out the monks of malmesbury / and yaue the abbaye to his clerks / At last
the merces and the northumbres put this edwyn out of his kyngedom for his evil
living / and made his brother Edgar king when he was sixten year old / in
edgards beginning saint dunstan herd angels sing in this manner / pees to the
land of englysshmen in the childs time that now is born / and in dunstans time
/ and so it was than made that the river of temse departed the twey kings
lands / edwyn reigned four year / and dyed at last / and was buried at
wynchestre / but his soul was delyuerd out of hell at prayer of saint du^stan
and translated to the souls that do penance in the wey of sauacio^ / Treuisa
/ Here take heed criste^ me^ of the understanding for the words be perillously
set / therefore have mind now of twey manner of helles / in that one were ada^
abraham / isaac and jacob / and other holy forfaders that dyed before christ /
in to that hell crist descended after his passion / and brought with him thens
holy faders that there were / the other hell is a place for them that be and
shall be dampened for eumore^ who that comes in that hell shall never after be
sauid ne come out fro pain / but as me seyth in comune speech / that a thef
that is delyuerd from hangyng and from the galowes though he come not there if
he be delyuerd out of her power that would led him to the galows and hang him
thrrupon / So in sum manner understanding / he that is delyuerd out of the
fendes power that would bring him to hell / is delyuerd out of hell though he
come not there / So means the prophet in the sawter / and seith thou have
delyuerd my soul out of the lower hell / Willelmus de re / li / 2 / And as
the same land beryth evil herbs and good / and the netylle sometime grows
next* the rose / so of the same mylde Edmond come edwyn the worst and edgar the
best /

Capitulum nonum
EDgar young of sixtene year old was made king and / reigned after his brother a
sixten year / in the twellifth year of him in Atha^mannes cite that is bathe
the fyftenthe day of may on a wytsonday he was enoynted king of the holy
bishops dunstan and oswald / anon he reconcyled dunston and made him of
thabbot of glastenbury bishop of wyrcetre / he connexyd the kingdoms that
were denyded and made thereof but one kingdom / he bare down wykked men and
chastysed them that were rebel / he loved well good men and sobre / he repaired
and amended chirches / In many places he did awey clerks that lived in outrage
and put there monks / Treuisa / In that / save reverence of edgar / he was
lewdly meoued while there were other clerks / tha^t lived well ynowe / Than it
follows in the story / he byld more than forty abbayes / among the which he
made rich glastenbury / abyndon burgh / thorney ramesey wylton and wynchestre
/ but at wynchestre in the new abbay that now is called hyda for an hap that
there bifel / he was the first that put in monks instead of clerks / for
clerks fled the travail of the quere and spend the catail of holy church in
other places at her own will / and vycars in her stead full little for to live by
/ and when they would not be amended by king edgar nowther by bishop ethelwold
nouther by tharchebisshop du^stan / the king yaf the proue^des of these clerks
to the forseid vicars / but the vicars were wors than the rather when they were
made persons / and lived more in outrage tha^ the rather did / than the king
was aggreued / and by thasse^t of the xiij / pope john he put out the clerks
and put in monks / W / vbi su / In his time was no thief taken open ne pryuy /
that he ne had his pain / Also this king cast to destroy the wyld beestes
that desire blood / therefore he made ludwallus that was king of wales / to
bear him certain year a trybute of three honderd wolves / And when he had paid
this three year to gyder / in the fourth year might never a wolf be founden /
Item / W / Though this edgar were small and little / of stature / he would
overcome every man were he never so strong that would with him fight / On a time
at a feste where Iouglers showed hem self most / me says that kynadus king
of scotts said in his game / that it seemed wonder that so many prouynces and
lands were subgette to so a little man as Edgar was / A mynstral herd that
word / and told the king / and he told not his men / but he aroos from the
feste / there kynadus was / and had kynadus to him as it were for a great
counseylle and ^ad him far in to a wode / and took him one of twey swerdes
that he brought with him / and spak to kynadus and said / now thou have leave
to kythe thy strength / and essay whether of us tweyne shall be subget to other
for now we be here alone / It is a foul thing for a king to ^angle much at
fest / and not to fight in battle / kynadus was abashed and fill down to
edgards feet / and prayed him of foryeuenesse / of that simple word that he
had said in his game / Every somer after he would gader ships to geder / and
depart hem in four / and set them in the four parts of England / Then
with the west nauey he would sail in to the north country / with the north
nauey / he would sail in to the eest country / and with the eest nauey he would
seylle in to the south country / And with the southe naueye in to the weste
country / In that doing he was a mylde espy / for the thieves should not grieve
in water ne in land / In winter time he would ride about in the land / and
inquire and espy the domes and the deeds of his mynystres / he would take
cruel wreche of hem that trespassed ayenste the law At al time he was a
prouffytable counseyllour for the ^omonte / But he favored the danes unwisely
in their axynge / For uneath was there one street in england but danes dwelled
therein with Englysshmen / That was suffryd with a good heart / but thereof come
a right grievous end / for the danes were great drynkers by kind and left
with englysshmen that one doing that is known and dureth alwey / so that now
the doing of englysshmen does pryiudyce to all the world in emptynge of cups
/ Therefore king edgar made styke nails in the cups / and marked so the Cups
for they should drynk by mesure unto the nails / W / de / r / et de / p / li /
2 / Than this edgar on his wife egelfleda / the white by her he bygate his
oldest son Edward. that was afterward Edward king and martyr / Than on
alfritha the dukes daughter of deue^shyre he gate edmond that dyed before his
fader / and Egelredus that reigned after saint edward / and on saint wylfrytha /
he bigate saint edyth the maid / this wylfrytha was not verily a menchon / as
the comune saw madly means / but for deed of king Edgar that desired her
unlawfully / she took nonnes clothing / and so she was brought to the kings
bed / And for the king lay by that woman that was holden and seemed a nonne / he
was blamed of seint dunstan / and did penance seven year / Also when she
had a child / she forsook flesshely lykyng and man's company and lived
relygyously / and is holden a saint in the abbay of wylton so it is said / Also
of her daughter edyth / it is said that while she was a menchon at wylton /
she used often gayer clothes than her profession axed / and she was therefore
blamed of saint ethelwold and she answered nowther vncouenably ne full cu^tously
/ Gods dome said she that may not fail / is plesed only with conscience /
therefore I trow that as clean a soul may be under these clothes / that be
arrayed with gold / as under thy slyt forour skynnes / On a time while dunstan
hallowed a church / he saw this maid croyse often her own forheede with her
right thombe / Dunstan was glad thereof and said I pray god / that that
thombe may never rotte / And anon at mass Dunstan bygan to weep and said /
Anon after six wekes this fay^^rose shall well wydre / and so it befelle / For
after when her body was taken up of the earth / it was founden al roten /
and turned to powder / out take the thombe / and her womb with the pryuy
chose bynethe. Dunstan had thereof greet wonder / and thought much therynne
/ and why it might be / Then she appeared to him and told him the cause / and
said wonder the not / though I be hoole and sound in the nether parts of my
body / for I was never gylty of outrage of mete and drynk / nowther of
flesshely liking / Also of this holy maid it is red / that while king
cauntus loved little saints of england ones in a whitsontyde at wilton at a
feste he made open mowes and scorned saint edyth and seid that he would never
trow that of edgards children that was lecherous / and a great tyrant should
be a saint / Ednotus tharchebisshop withsaid / that tho was there present / and
opened anon the grave of the maid / then she arrered her self up to the
girdel stead / so that it seemed as though she would have resed on the rebel king
/ for that deed the king was astonyed and fill down to the ground as though he
were in a swoun / and drough breath at last / and was ashamed and glad / that
he was saved / and intended to do worthy penance

Capitulum / 10 /
About that time dyed odo tharchebisshop of Caunterbury This was of the nation
of danes / but he did alweye his wildenes at last / and seruid king edward the
elder in chiualry And not long after he took the to^sur of clerk / and was made
bishop of wynchestre / he had made king ethelsta^ his friend by the coming of
the sword that was lost in the scaubert again / So that he was made
archebisshop of caunterbury / and for that he would take that dignite the more
holily / for all his predecessors had be monks he passed the sea and took
monks wede at floriacio beside aurelian / Treuisa / Odo was lewdly meoued
therefore to make him a monk for christ ne none of al his apostles was never monck
ne friar / Than it follows in the story / Odo come again and was nyghe the
king / and went at last with king Edredus in to Northumberlond / and
brouht with him to Caunterbury the holy axes of saint wylfryde the bishop /
thereof is yet contynuel stryf bitwene them of york / and of caunterbury whether
has the more wilfrides bones / that was buried in the church of rypon / by
these forsaid bones owther the bones of the less wylfride that was saint john's
pressed and his successor / in the sea of york / Also this Odo suspended king
Edwynus of crystendome for he was to feruente in lecherye and out of al good
fame / Therefore Edwynus took wreche in all the monks of England / For in all
england was no man that him durst wythstande out take odo / and dunstan / For
as Seneca says / a Cok is most mighty on his own dung hylle / Also on a time
Od^es temple was vnheebed And all that time / that the heelynge was in making
/ and the temple in heelynge / he heeled it so with his bedes / that there
fylle no drop of rain in all the place about / and yet that time was so
great tempeste / and rain of water / that is seemed that all the world should go
to giders / Also on another time when he sacred saint du^stan bishop of
wyrcetre / he did so thordre of the service as though he had sacred
tharchebisshop of caunterbury / and when his clerkys blamed him therefore / I
wot sons said Odo what the holy ghost worchith on me / and in the true before
bodyng lakked no sobre feyth^ though elsinus bishop of wynchestre ever among
founded to have that see / for when odo was deed / this elsinus ordained him
advocates / and groped her hands / and gate slyly a mau^dement of the king /
and was put in at canterbury And the first day that he was in there / he
spared not but he cast out of his wodenes that he had long kept in his heart /
and put with his feet on saint odoes tomb / and despised his soul and spoke /
to him in this manner / thou worste old man / thy soul is a goo late ynow /
thou have made a place to a bett than thou were / what I have long desired /
now I have maugre thy teth / therefore I can the full evil thank at this time /
but when that day was a goo / and this blower of wodenes was brought to his
bed / he saw the shap of saint odo blame him and despise him / and manace
that he should dye / But he wend that he had be scorned of a fleing fantesye
/ and spared not therefore / But he went toward rome to receive the palle of the
pope / and passed by the hills alps and was fro^en in a cold snow / and in
his horse bowels that we re opened to have sum hete / he wrapped his feet with
which he spurned saint odoes tomb / and dyed so there / After him
bryghtlynus bishop of wynchestre was archebisshop of caunterbury / and for he
was not suffisaunt to so great a charge / he went again to wynchestre by
comaundeme^t of the king / and Dunstan bishop of london and of wyrcetre was
made archebisshop of caunterbury / and went to rome / and received the palle
of the pope Johan He come again and gate of the king. that oswalde that was
Odoes brother son should be bishop of worcetre /

Willelmus de pontificibus libro primo

Dunstan was first abbott of glastenbury / he was alwey full of virtues / and
made him besy to torn king edgards heart / to deeds of sauacion / and to make
the kings living to be a myrroure and ensample to all his subgettis / And if
the king trespassed he studied him fast to amend / and so he made him do
penance seven year for unlawful lyggyng by a menchon / by that ensample he
chastysed the comonte / and made knights do as they should / and fered the^es
and refreyned hem / Thordre of monks was thryfty that time / For it had
relygyous rulers clear of science and of clergy / And so between thacorde of
the good living of the king / and of the Archebisshop / clerks had choys /
whether they would amen^e her life / or bid her benefyce fare well / and leave
wonynge places to better than they were / For so should be no moore discord
/ between the fayrenesse of the house and the living of hem that dwelled theryn
/ Than the foldes answerde to the tillers of plente of corn / and of fruit /
Every groan shone with hurton trees / and other trees full of fruit / The
Elementys were clear and liking / uneath there was any dystemperance of weder
/ pestylences and enemies both were fer that time / About that time in
Gaskoyne was a woman departed and divided from the nauel upward / and had
twey hedes and twey breestes / so that sometime one slepte / owther ete when
that other did nowther / and they lived so to gydre long time / and dyed
both at ones / After the twellyfthe Johan the fyfth Benet was pope three
months / Nychoforus king of greece was an old man / and drad lest his own
sons would put him out of his kingdom / and demed that his sons should be
ghelded / But the queen cou^seylled one Johan / that he should slay the king
and regne / and so it was done / After Benet the eyghtenth leo was pope a year
and four months / For the malice of the Romans that made of hem self
unlawfully popes / he ordained that no popes should be ordained without assent
of the Emperor / After him the thyrtenth Johan was pope as it were eight year
/ At last he was taken of the prefecte of the Cite and exyled / But the
emperor restored him again / and slough his enemies / After Johan the sixth
Benet was pope one year and six months / After him / the eight Bone face was
pope three year / he might not abide at Rome / but he spoil led saint peter's
church / and went to Constantinople / and come ayene to Rome with great pomp
and booste / And when he might not have his purpoos be took the Cardynal
Johan / and put out both his eyes / and dyed sone after / Willelmus de pont
libro secundo / When Askatyllus Archebisshop of york was deed / saint oswald
bishop of wyrcitre received the the archebisshoprych / and governed both that
/ and the bisshoprich of wyrtetre / Besides the cathedrale church of saint
Peter at wircetre / he build another church of our lady that he might there be
the more homely with the monks / and there by he had great love of the people
/ There clerks of the next church when they saw that / had lever be monks
than so despised and forsaken / When oswald was stalled at york / he brought
lettred men in to country / For the countraye should not be defrauded / and be
without such goodness / without the which goodness / other goodness
seems but a vanyte / Albo monk of floriacio was one of thylk lettred men /
without much f^uyte of clergy / that he brought in to England / he descryued
and wrote the life of saint Edmunde the king and martyr / at prayer of saint
dunstan / This Albo turned home afterward / and was made Abbot / Than on a time
in a celle in gascoyne called Alereul and longed to his abbay / he would have
used the strength of Relygyon / but the eruelte of Gascoyns would not suffer
it and kytte his throat and so he dyed / and oswald lived five year after /
and kneled down on a time to wessh pore men's fete / and said gloria patri /
and dyed right so / Willelmus de regibus libro secundo / King Edgar in the
twellyfthe year of his kingdom was enoynted king / and sacred at bathe and
sailed about north Brytayne / and come a land at legyon that now is called
Chestre / Eight under kings come ayenste him / with the which kings he went
in a boot on a day on the River dee / and took the helm in his hand / and
was steres man and the other kings were set to row with oores / and so he
come rowing to saint Iohans church / and come rowing with a great pomp and
boost to his own palace / and me says / that he said thennethat any of his
successors might be ioyeful and glad / when he had so great pomp and
worship /

Capitulum 11
EDgar Emperor flower and fayrenesse of England dyed the fyftenth day of
Iuyll the year of his life seven and thirty / and of his kingdom with his
brother and after one and twenty / and was buried at glastenbury / he is no
less worthy to be in mind to englysshmen / than cyrus to the perses outher
Romulus to the Romans / owther Alysaunder to the greeks / owther charles to
frensshmen / Willelmus vbi supra / At glastenbury the year of our^ lord a
thousand and two and fyfty when abbot aylward had dygged vnworshipfully
edgards grave / the body was founden hoole and sound and so full of flessh
that it might not enter in to the new cheste / Also fressh blood was seen drop
out of the fressh body / and so that body was put in to a shryn that he had
yeuen to that church / and set upon the auter with saint Apolynarys heed /
and other relykes of saint vyncente / that the same king had brought for
great prys / and yeuen to that hows / but that nyce Abbot wax wood / and
went out of church / and brake his neck and dy^^ / Ranulphus / The Bryttyssh
storye tellyth in saint eltutus life that when king edgar destroyed the
country of glomm^rgan for the rebelnesse of the people / saint eltutus belle
was taken awey / and hanged about an horse neck / therefore in vndertyde while
king edgar lay on his bed to rest him / one appeared to him / and smote him on
the breast with a spear / than when the king was waken / he bade restore ayene
all that was taken / But the king dyed after nine days / In praysynge of him
one said in this manner / Henricus libro / 5 Helper punyssher of tresp^as and
yeuer of worship / king Edgar is ago to the kingdom of heaven / This other
salamon laws fader wey to the pees / Noble in batayls than more noble he was
Temples to the good monks / to the monk temples yaue he feldes / Al wrong /
this put awey / so this yafe place to the right / Willelmus de regibus libro
secundo / But sum men founden to put venym to the joy and goodness of
Edgar / and tellen that he was cruel in his beginning to Cyteseyns and
lecherous to maidens / As in this manner one ethelwold an Earl was prive with
him / and on a time he charged this Earl / that he should goo to elfrytha
orgarus daughter Earl of deuenshyre that was a wonder fair maid and counseyle
her and bring her for to be wedded to the king / if it were so that the
fayrenesse of her were acordynge to the loos and to the fame / The earl went
his wey and took the maid to his own use / and come a^geyne to the king and
a^lledged for him and for his side as he trowed would help and said that that
wenche was but of comune fayrenesse and shap / such as me says al day not
couenable to be a kyngys wife / But on a time tale tellers / warned the king how
gylefully that ethelwolde had served him / than the king droof out one
nail with another / and took wreche of a gyle with a wyle / and made good face
to therle and semblaunt and set him a day as it were in his game / when he
would visyte that woman / For so dredefull a game / therle was all comf^rtles
and nygh deed for fear / and ran home before / and prayed his wife / that she
would help for to save him / and that as much as she might / she should make
her self foul and unseemly in the kings sight with clothing and foul array /
But what / she durst not / but she did the countrary / and took a myrrour and
kembed her / and arrayed her body / and her heed / as gay / and as fair as
she couth / and left no thing that should make her fair and liking / to a
man's syghte / Then when the king saw the woman / he began to brenne in
her love / and made it as though^ he were not wroth / and had the earl with
him for to hunte in the wood of werwelley that now is called hoote wood /
There the king smote him through with a shafte / there the king ax^d of therles
baste sone how him lyked such hunting / and me says that he answered and
said / lord king what plesyd the shall not dysplese me / By that word he meked
so the kings heart that was to swollen for wrath / that no thing was lever
afterward to the king than the son of therle that was slain / Afterward for
clensynge of this deed / this Elfrytha build an abbay of nonnes at warwell /
Ranulphus / But more verily for the sl^ynge of her stepsone / Edward that she
made be slain / for her own son egelredus should regne / Willelmus vbi
supra To this ensample of cruelnes they tell another of lecherye / and say /
that he took a maid that was sacred to god / out of an abbay and lay by her
/ Also that he was on a tym^ by night at Andeuer not fer from wynchestre / and
badde bring to his bed a dukes daughter that was a well fair maid / But the
mode^ of that maid would not that her daughter should so be defowled and had
a bound servant that was a fair maid smothe and liking / and sent her to
the kings bed / A morrow when the dawynge byganne to spring / the woman
byganne to rise / Then me axed of her why she hyed / for to do my work said
she / as I am wont every day. Than for that nyghtes iourneye she axed fredome
for her mede / For she that was assenting to the kings lykyng should no more
be under in boundage to cruel lords / Anon the king byganne to laugh and made
that boundewoman lady of lords / But how it ever be of such deeds / it is
sothe / that he clensyd him of such deeds by very penance / After Boneface
the seventh / the seventh Benet was pope / viij / year and six months / the

duchemen ten year / and six months / The seventh year of his kingdom / he

made a great feste to the lords of ytaly / at the grees of the church of Rome
/ And while they were at mete / he made men of Arms byclyppe hem pryuely
about / and meoued a pleynte at last of brekyng of the pees / and bade hem
take him the names written of hem that were gylty / and made hem be byheded
