Capitulum 12
Young Edward by help of dunsta^n / and of other Bisshops was made king ayenste
the will of sum other lords / Specially ayenste the will of his stepdame
elfrytha / that fonded to make her own sone egelredus king a child of seven
year old That she might so regne under the childs name / This edward reigned
as it were four year There a^fter waned the grace of the kingdom / For in the
fyrmamente was seen stella Cometa / that is a sterre with a bright shynynge
creest / that bodeth alwey pestilence in the prouynce / owther chaungynge of
the kingdom / And long thereafter fell bareynesse of feldes / honger of men /
and death of beestes / And Alferus prince of mercia favored Elfritha the queen
with all that he might / and put out monks that edgar had ordained / and
brought ynne Clerks with concubynes / But dunstan and the earl of eeste
england withstode hem manly / For the clerks that were sometime put out /
rered stryf ageyn / and said that it were a wretchyd shame / that a new coming
should put old landesman of her place / That is not plesing to god that granted
the place to the old woner / nowther a good man aloweth it not that may dread
that me would do to him self as he sees that me does to other / Herfor was a
solemn counseyle made at wynchestre / there the image of rode spak out of
the wall / and said that dunstans wey was good and true / but yet cesed not the
hertes of unskillful men / therefore was made a counseylle at Ryal street of
Calue / there the king was absente / for he was yet of tender age / and there
sat in an high hows the senators of England / There dunstan was strongly
despised and chydde / Then the gystes and the beams of the sober al to brake
/ and the soler fylle down / and sum were deed / and sum hurt and maimed
for evermore / so all that there wree were deed owther hurt full soore / out
take dunstan alone that escaped graciously and wisely / that miracle brought
forth silence to hem that intended afterward to have mayntened that qua^ele /
The young Edward came from huntyng weary and a thurst / and his stepdame yaue him
drink / and the mean time / he was stykked with a swerde^ Then he byganne
to prykke his horse with all that he might thennes for to flee / Then his one
foot slode out of the styrope / and he was to draw by that other foot al
about the feldes / and thwert over weyes and al be bloded and at Cornisgate be
yaue the signs and tokens of death / than he was buried vnworthly three year at
warham / there god wrought for him many miracles and great / For there great
light come down fro heaven / and the haltman received his going aryght / the
dembe man received his spoche / the deef his herynge / and the blind his sight
/ there all manner seek men took the state of health / By that rumor she that
slough him was meoued and came rydyng on a beeste that might not come nyghe the
place / for no betynge / ne for no cryeng / the beeste was often changed but
it was al for naught / therefore what she might not done in her own person /
she did by another / For her mynyster Elferus that had sometime put out
monks in mercia and brought Clerks in her stead / he took edwardes body and
buried it solempny at Septon that is shaftesbury / R In time afterward sum
of his body was translated to leof monaster besides herforde and sum to
Abyndon / The place at shaftesbury / there his longes yet qnaue all fressh and
sound is called Edwardestow / W / vbi supra For this slaughter Elfrytha build
twey Abbayes of women not for fro Salesbury / One at ambrysbury and another at
werwel / she did awey the pomp of the world / and did long time hard
penance at warwell / and used alwey the here / and fasting and chastysed her
body that was full fair sometime / Ande always as she might she croysed her
forheede and breast and lies buried there / But the foresaid Elferus escaped not
all manner wreche for he was eten all with lyse after one year after the buryng
of the forsayde martyr / About that time was fulbertus in prosperyte bishop
of Carnot an excellent man in our lady love / Among his other noble works he
made in praysyng of our lady the response styrps yesse / and solemn iusticie /
and this ym^ne Chorus noue Jerusalem / On a time he was seek at yate of death
and our lady appeared to him and axyd of him / whereof he dradde / my lady said
he / I trust in thy mercy / but I dread full soore thine own sons dome /
dread the nothing said she / and for to make the / the more seker herafter. I
shall now make the al hoole / and anon she took her breast out of her bosomme
and dropped on his face three drops of precious lycour of milk / and went
forth her wey / he was hoole forthwith and did that sweet lycour of heaven in a
vessel of silver / and had keep* it in mind /

Willelmus de regibus libro secundo

Capitulum 13
EGelredus edgards son bygoten on his second wife Elfrytha was made king
after his elder brother Edward at kyngeston / he was a fair knight and a lovely
/ Eight and thyrty year he besyeged the kingdom more verily than ruled it /
For the course of his life was cruel / and ungracious in the beginning / wretched
in the myddel / and foul in the end / For while saint dunstan baptized him /
he defowled the fontston with the fruit of his womb / therefore dunstan said by
god and by his moderthys shall be unkind / And in the day of his crownynge he
told^ this prophecye / For thou come to the kingdom by the death of thy broder^
in whose death Englysshmen conspyred with the wykked woman thy mother / they shall
not be without blood and sword er there come people of an unknown tongue / and
bring hem in to the last thraldom / this trespaas shall not be cleansed without
long vengeance / when this egelredus was a child of ten year old / and
herd tell that his brother edward was so slain / he meoued so his wode mother
with weeping and with yellyng that she beat him almost to death / with tapers /
for he shad naught else at hand / therefore he hated tapers al his life time /
Also on Ethelgyna Earl egbertus daughter he bygate Edmund Ir^nsyde by hi^
surname / and edwyn and ethelstan and one daughter called edgyna / Afterward on
emma of normandy he bygate Alfredus and Edward / Half a night a cloud was seen
in all England now blody now fyry / than it changed by diverse colors and
beams / and went awey in the dawning / That year southha^pton and the isle of
Tanet besides kente / and saint petrocus abbaye in Cornewayle / and the
prouynce of chestre were destroyed by thieves of danes / the cite of london was
burnt with fire of the same Cite / Saint ethelwold bishop of wynchestre is
deed / he was born at wynchestre / and norysshed up under du^stan at
glastenbury and made monk / And he was made abbot at abyngdon in king Edredus
time / And he was made bishop at wynchestre in Edgars time / there he made an
abbaye of nonnes / and translated saint swythynes body out of the earth / After
him saint alphegus abbot of bathe was bishop / And afterward Archebisshop of
Caunterbury / and was slain of the danes / Of him Inner more we shall speak /
This thyrdde otho the second Othoes son reigned among duchemen after his
fader eyghten year / This had a wonder surname and was called otho the wondres
of the world / Mirabilia mundi / and he was crowned at Rome of the fyfthe pope
gregory / And though these three othones were emperors arewe as it were by
kind heritage / yet afterward it was ordained that the Emperor should be
chosen / by thoffycers of the empire / tho officers be seven / Of hem ben
versus made / Maguntmensis / treuerensis / Coloniensis / Qu^l^b^t imperij fit
can cellarius horum / Eciam palatinus dapyfer / dnx portitorensis / Marchio
prepositus camere pyncerna boemns / Hij statuunt dominum per secula summum /
these be to mean Bishop meynse / magunce Treuer and Colonia / these three /
Euerychone of this is made right chaunceler of thempyre / Earl palatinus sewer
duc of Oustryche beryth the swerd / marquys is chamberleyn^ butiler king is of
beam / this chosen to men all the lord highest for ever / the thyrdde otho
had a wife that would have had an husbond man to lygge by her / but the man
would not assent to anon try / than he was thretend that his heed should be
smyte^ of / without any dome / but er he dyed he bad his wife that she should
after his death prove him gyltles by the doing of ho^r brennyng yren The day
came when the emperor said that he would do right / to the faderles and
moderles childer and to wydues / This wyduc came and brought with her her
husbands heed / and axed what death he were worthy that had slain a man
wrongfully / He is worthy to leese his heed said the emperor / thou art that
man said the wydue / and that I shall prove anon by the dome of fire and
brennyng yren / when the dome was done / the emperor yaue him self to the woman
/ for she should punysshe him as she would / but at prayeng of bisshops /
first of ten days were grou^ted / and than of eight / and than of seven / and
at last of six In the which days the emperor examyned the cause at
full and burnt his own wife / and for his raunsonne he yaue to the wydue four
castle towns in the Bysshopryche of Brynensis / that yet have the names and be
cleped by the first days / ten / eight seven and six The fourtenthe johan was
pope eight months After him the fyftenth johan four months / After him the
sixtenth johan was pope ten year Willelmus vbi supra / King Egelredus for stryf
that was between him and the Bishop of Rouchestre besyeged the cite of
Rouchestre / Dunstan send to him that he should leave his wodenesse / a^nd that

dunstan ended his life full of virtues and of wondres / as descryued osbertus

dunstan hyghted the images of appostles and martirs with the stole of a preeste
/ An harp that henge upon the wall was herd make swetely melodye without
man's hand / the melodye was the note of this anteme of the martres / Gaudent
in celis anime sanctorum / that is to say holy men's souls make joy in
heaven / Also he tellyth thkt dunstan couth many crafts / and wrought with his
hands / and made on a time a chalis by gold smythes craft in a celle fast by

fantasyes of diverse liking / Dunstan in his spyryte was war thereof / and

dunstan was slepy and herd angels sing full swetely / Kyryeleyson /
Xprysteleyson / the melodye of that note / and armonye / is yet famous among
english men / and used on that kyrye / kyrye rex splendens / than when

the iiij / year / xxiiij / M / l^i / the / v / year / xxx / M / l^ / at last
xl M / l^i till all the money failed / than the danes bygan ayene to rob and

yet so cesed not harm / But as the hedes of Idra when sum enemies were awey
come up other enemies / and destroyed the countraye. The Capytayns presence is
much worth to be known in werre and in bataylle / so is hardynesse use and
loore of deeds of Arms / these failed that time among englysshmen / For if the
host were any time gadryd if Ships were made / no thing spedde a right /
For our men were not chasted / they yaue them to theft and to robbery / For
they were not comforted / they would lightly flee / Our ships were destroyed
with great tempest / One wylnotus that the king had exyled occupied the
ships that were left and drenched hem owther burnt hem / If the lords come
to counseyll any time / they were not of one assent But they treated more of
discord and strife that was among hem self than of the comune profyt / and if
any good counseyll and profitable were yeuen / anon their enemies should wit
For without the forsaide Elfrycus one Edrycus / that the king had made
lord of mercia a right falls traitor and slye that couth well feyne him self
true friend though he were falls

He espied the kings counsel as he were true and trusty and warned the
enemies thereof / as a falls gybeful traitor / In the mean time / mescheue / and
hunger encreaced fast / Enemies might go freely fyfty mile / and take prays and
led to her shippis Then they paid more trybute to the danes / the king had
such a condition that he would lightly dyssheryte englysshmen / and feyne
trespaas for to have her money and her good / he was so froward to his wife
emma. that she selde come in his bed / he walowed in lechery with strompettis
/ and with comune wymmen /

Capitulum 14
LOtharius lowys son was king of westfraunce / and dyed without childer /
In him the great charles ofspryng lost the kingdom / Sum men say that this
lotharius had children that reigned not after him / By help of Rychard duc of
Normandye / that was sometime gretely greuyd by lotharius / Lotharius sons
were taken / and the great hugh capette was made king of france / and reigned
nine year / this hugh Capett was the sone of duc hugh / whose suster duc rychard
had spoused

Saint oswald archebisshop of york / and of worcetre also / dyed and was
buried at wyrcetre / The / v / gregorius was pope as it were three year / this
was before called brunus / and was othoes themperours kynnesman / At his
instaunce he was chosen pope / But afterward when the emperor was absente one
Crescencius prefecte of the cite took one placentinus a rich man of money /
and put him in the poperyche / and called him the seventh Johan / But the

changed to durham / And saint Cuthbertus body was translated thither / the
which body / ardulphus led about with him sometime / The first Rychard the
third duc of Normandy is deed / After him his son the second Rychard was duc
/ xxviij / year / For his great goodness he was called the good Rychard / he
was devout in gods service / and wise and ready to the world ward / Curtoys
and large of yeftes / On his first wife he bygate three sons / Rychard Robert
and Wiliam / and three daughters On his second wife he gate wyliam and Robert /
archebisshop of rothomage / One of these second rychardes knights stale a spone
/ and leyd it to wedde among other things / The duc espied it and none other
man / and let quyte out all the knights weddes / the knight espied that the
spone was so espied / and was so ashamed that he fled pryuely awey / The king
went after the knight that fled / and brought him ayene and made him rich /
and loved him afterward right well / One master Bernard herd the dukes loos /
and would be known to him / And bythought him on every side how he might best
do for to come thereto / he come at last with a bow and an arowe to a
wyndowe of the castle / there the duc was wont to stand / And walked hyder
and thither as though he would have shot to the duc / the duc was war thereof /
and espied what the cause was / and loved him right well / After the seventh
Johan was put out the second syluester was pope four year and twey months /
W / v / su / This hete first gerebertus by his name / and was of the nacio^ of

to pyctagoras double wey / he was caught with noye of his order with couetyse
of worship / and left his habyte on a night / and fled in to hyspals / that is
syuyl le grannt a cyto of spain for to learn subtyle and curyous arts and
scyences / there as christian men have Tolet / Sarasyns have hyspals / there
gerebertus learned and passed tholomeus in astronomye and Alca^drius in the
space between the sterres and Julius fermicus in desteny / there he learned what
sygnefyed song / and flyghte of fowls what the curyosite of kind may take
that Carsong I leave / But he drank thereof that he passed all other / he was the
first that took Agabus of Sarasyns / and yaue rules therynnne / that may
uneath be understood of the connyngest men of that craft / which crafts
men ben cleped Abacyste / Gerebertus was at In with one that was most conning
philosophre / that was bound with promyses and with yeftes / Gerebertus had
wryton and copyed all this philosophres books / except one that contained all
the pryuyte of the craft / For that book might he not geete by no manner of
sleyght / But the philosophre was otherwhyle dronken^ And so Gerebertus waited
his time / and took the book / that was under the philosophres heed and
fled aweye therwyth / Then he awoke. and pursued Gerebertus by craft of
the stere^s / in the which craft he was parfyht ynowe /

By that same craft he that fled was ware of the peril / and dressyd him
under a treen bridge that was there next and henge there by the arms / so
that he touched neither earth ne water / and so by that craft he was begyled
that sought him right besyly / and withdrough him and turned home ayene /
Then this gerebertus came to the sea / and called forth the fend and behete
him homage if he would bear him over the sea / and save him fro him that pursued
him / and so it was done / Than he come agey^ in to France / and held open
scole / and had with him Constantin thabbot of saint mayimin besides aurelyans
/ To him he made and yaue a rule of Abacus / Also he told the skylle and reason
of the dyameter above macrobius / Treuisa / The dyameter is of a figure owther
of a shap the lengest even line that is divided therynne / take who that may /
Than it follows in the storye / Gerebertus had s^olers Robert the son of
hugh Capette king of france / and otho / Otho the emperors son / But robert
was afterward king of france / and made this gerebertus Archebisshop of
remensis / yet in that church is mind of his lore for there is an orloge made
by craft of hand / and water organs that sowneth by eyr and water / there by
strength of hoot^ water the wind brekyth out and fylleth the holownes of the
Organs / and then by shaply draughtes the brazen pypes send out sweet cry
and noise of melodye / thereafter Otho was Emperor and made Gerebertus bishop
of Rauenna / and sone there after pope / Marianus / Of that hap is a verse made
/ Scandit ad / R / Gerebertus / ab / R / post papa vygens / in / R / That is
Gerebertus passyth up to / R. out of R / and is thereafter pope in his flowers
in R / R / He passed out of Remence to Rauenna / and the third time to Rome /
Willelmus de Regibus / Favor of the fend droof forth his fortune / for by
help of the fend / and by craft of nygromancye he fond tresour that was hyd
of old time / in that field called Campus Marcius / besides rome was an image
that time that held straight out the finger / of his right hand / the which
finger some men call lyk pot / that is the finger next the thombe / and on the
images heed it was wreton / smite her / men of old time wend and trowed
tresour there to find / and brake so^what of the image with many hard strokes /
gerebertus blamed hem therefore / and eue^ at midday wha^ the son was highest /
he took head where the shadow of that finger fill on the ground and pight there a
stake and at night he took with him his cha^berlayn alone that bare with him
light and opened the earth there as the stake was pyght and went in and saw
the^e a kings hows of gold and knights of gold playng with dyses of gold /
and king and queen of metal sitting at board and served with mete set on
the board / servants standing before hem / and cups of great wight and
price / In the ynner place of the ho^s a carboncle stone shoone clearly / and
did awey all the derknesse of the night. On the other side stood a yonglynge
with a bow bente / But among al these no thing might be touched though it
might be seen / if any man went ner to handle any thing her of / it seemed
that all the images would on him rese / Gerebertus was war thereof and absteyned
him and withstode his couetyse / and desire / but the chamberlayn absteyned not
at full / for he took a knyf that lay on the boorde / Anon as he had taken
the knyf / all images bygan to grutche / and to arise / and the child lowsed /
and shot and hytte the carboncle stone with a reode / and made all the hows
full of derknesse / So that but if he hadd leyd down the knyf as his lord
bade him / both should have paid the pain So it is read that Joseph dalf
with his fader much tresour in to the earth / And hircanus took up three
thousand talentes of king david's grave / for to break up the syege of Jerusalem
/ Also it is a comune feign that this gerebertus by certain craft of the
sterres / did ghete an head that spak not / but when me axyd of him and said
naught but soth / That head warned gerebertus that he should be pope / and that
he should never dye er he ^ad song a mass in Ierl^m / but he was not ware that
in Rome was a church that hete ierl^m / there the pope singith mass three
sondayes in the year in the stacion time / In that church he arayd him to
mass on one of these sondayes / and was taken with strength of sickness / and
lay seek in his bed / and counseylled with his image / and knew that he was
begyl^ed and was war of his oundeth / he sent for the cardyuals and knowleched
his evil deeds / and wept full soore / And as it were a wood man for sorrow of
his sins / he made men kytte him self lymmele^ and throw out his lymmes /
and said let him have thoffyce of the lymmes that axyd homage of hem and let
the spyryte go to god that made it of of naught / Mar / Than he bade do the
stoke of the body upon a cart and burye it where the beestes would abide / and
^o it was done Than the beestes steynte at saint iohans the l^ran and he is
buried there in token that his sins were foryeuen / his grave bodethe and
warns if the pope shall sone dye / And that by sterynge and rustlyng of the
bones that be therynne / and by swetynge of the tomb as it is yet there wreton
in lettres of latin /

Capitulum 15
HVgh Capett king of west France dyed after that he had reigned ix / year / his
sone Robert was king after him / that he had bygoten on the elder edwardes
daughter king of england This robert reigned about thyrtty year / in his time a
^elygyous pilgrim came out of ierl^m in to Scicilia / and lerued of one that
was closed that deed / me^^es souls for dyus sins and trespaces be tormented

of christian men and namely of monks of cluny / Therefore odyl^ abbot of cluny
when he was war thereof / he ordained to have mind and memory for hem that been
deed / And that the morrow after al halowe day / That manner of usage and doing
/ passed afterward in to all the world / Also this robert was a connyng man of
science / and would in high^ festes of saints in sum abbay of his kingdom /

day he had left his host about a castle / that he beseged and bare a coope

nobis gracia / that is the grace of the holy ghost be with us / Also he made

Also that year deuelyng a cite of an Archebisshops see of Irlond was destroyed

me^ of that country / but this Iuo appeared to a simple man and informed him of

ramesey for they should go yfere and take up his body out of the earth / when

the^pire / the same shall be understood of Conrades and othones emperors that

/ This year Elphegus bishop of wynchestre was made Archebisshop of Caunterbury

Capitulum 16
About saint matheus feste the danes beseged Caunterbery and the twenty day
of the syege the cite was taken / and set on fire / and that by tresonne of
Almarus the Deken / that saint Elphegus had before saved from death / Thabbot

despised with many manner pains / Therefore gods wrath fell upon the people /
that slough so men / that sorrow of her bowels slough and destroyed of hem /
now by / x / now by / xx / and so a great nombre / than the danes were warned

abide therewith / for on ester eue^ they gaf the bishop chois whether he would
pay three thousand pond owther leese his life / he forsook at her profre / and
prayde mekely his christian men / and forbade them hyghly that none of hem should
pay for his ransom / therefore the danes were wroth and kene and the next
saturday after the danes were wine dronken / and ledd out the bishop and
slough him with stones and with rotheren bones / That saterdaye fell twelve
days before maij / when the bishop was deed he was not buried til on the morn

Than the next day after his body was brought to london / and buried

of danes he was brought all hoole in body to his own church / W / de / r /
li / 2 / After that this Alphegus had taken monks habyte at dirhust / he lived
as an Anchor at bathe / and gadred there monks afterward and as it fallyth often
in agreete college / these monks drough hem all to evil manner of doing /
For vnwyttyng the fader sum of hem made festes by night in outrage and in
drinking to the day light / But the banyour of this evil doing / fyl deed

war thereof by noys that he herd / and come to the wyndow and saw twey fendes
beat that body / and the wretch axed help Nay said the fendes / thou were
not obedyent to god / so we shall not be obedye^te to the / On a time saint
andrew / appeared to dunstan and by counsel of saint andrew alphegus was made

would begyle his wardeyns and stand in the water to the gyrdel stead / and
worship god and pray him to the day light / When he had be bishop of
wynchestre two and twenty year / he was made Archebisshop of Caunterbury against
his will / But as he went to Rome for the palle / he was robbed in a street of
all that he had / therefore god took wreche of that street / so that the
street wax on fire / than the men of that street knowheched her trespaas and
restored again all that was his / Than they saw that the fire was quenched

saw that sight that he should go to his successor the / xx / johan / and pray
him to do alms deed for him of the money that was in such a cheste / For all
that was deled for him before / stood him in no stead / For it was of theft
and robberye / so it was don and than that bishop went in to an Abbay / This
year twey days before october the sea ouerflowed and passed the clyues and
d^^ynt many men and towns / Henricus libro sexto / Suanus king of danes
sailed about eestenglond that conteyneth northfolk / and southfolk / and come
with his nauey in to humbre / and passed forth by the river Trente to geynil
burgh^ than the men that dwelled by / the north watlyng street swar / fewte to
him and bytoke him pledgys / and he bitoke his nauey and these pledgys to his
sone canutus / while he went to destroy south mercia / and slough the men and
kept the women to flesshely liking of him / and his men / Than he took
oxenford and wynchestre / but as he went toward london and sought no bridge he
lost many of his men in the River of Temse. But by presence of king Egelredus
he was put of at london and went and wanne westsaxon / the londoners went and
saw that / and sent him pledges / than the king was abashed and sent his
wife Emma to her brother the second Rychard duc of normandy / and sent with her
his twey sons and the bishop of l^ndon / In the mean time hyder and thither
at wight he held so his mydwynter tide. At last he was without cataylle

in the myddel of his own knights / at town of geynisburgh a^nd cried in

canutus saw that and did myldly with saint edmond and made a dyche about

hem afterward they should pay therefore much money and have hem ayene The
collectours of trybute that were full cruel in other places of england there be
mylde and easy and soft pl^tynges on this half saint edmondes dyche /

Capitulum 17 /
When Suanus was deed the danes made his sone canutus king / But the
englysshmen sent in to normandy to king Egelredus / and promised if he would
be more goodly to hem than he was wont / hem were lever to put aweye Canutus
and take him to king / he assented to the profre / and sent his son^ edward
before for to stable the pees / thereafter about lent time / the king come with
great speed / and droof canutus out of lyndesey / Then canutus took him to
read for fo flee at Sandwyche in kente / he made kytte of hands and noses of
all the English pledgys that were delyuerd to his fader sometime / and falled
ayene in to deumarche / and come ayene the next year after / This year Canutus
sailed about eestenglond and took prays in the southe country / The noble
knight edmund yrensyde came manly against him / But edmond withdrough him when he
was ware of Edricus treason / Edrycus yaue him / and his to canutus /

The westsaxons saw that / and delyuerd him pledgys / and did the same /
King egelredus dyed at london eight days before maij / and was buried in
paul's church / After his death bisshops abbotes and lords of the land
forsook his issue / and progenye / and knouleched at Southampton / that
Canutus should be her king / and he swear that he would be to hem a true lord
both to god ward and to the world / But the londoners and many of the lords
made her king edmund yrensyde / And anon he made the westsaxons subgette /
sum for dread / and sum by her own good will / In the mean time canutus
bysieged london / but be was put of there / and he fought with edmonde in
dorsette besides gyllyngham and was ouercomen there / Thereafter after the
myddel of the somer Edmond with a greet host fought more sharply with canutus

fought so strongly that either hooste / withdrough hem from other for / pure
werynesse / Alfred / and marianus / But the morrow Edmond had overcome the
danes / ne had the false Edrycus showed a knights head that was most like to
king edmond / Edrycus showed that heed and said / flee englysshmen / loo here
is the heed of Edmond your king / but when edmonde was ware thereof / be leyde
one more sharply and faster and fought unto night / By night canutus went to
london ward / But Edmonde followed after / and saved the cite and passed temse
/ the third time / and overcome the danes at brentford / Than duc Edrycus swar
fewte to king Edmond / yet the fyfthe time when the danes robbed and reued and
took prays / edmond overcome hem at okeford in kente and chaced hem unto the
yland of shepeheye / Then while Edward turned in to westsaxon Canutus took
prays in mercia / therefore edmond met him upon asshdon / there was strong
fighting on either side / Duc Edrycus saw the danes downward / and fled as
a traitor should / so that many noble men were slain on edmondes side / there
was slain the bishop of lincoln and the Abbot of Ramesey that were come to
pray for the knight / Than by counseyll of Edrycus pees was made between the
kings / and pledgys taken on either side / At Durhurst upon the brynk of
Seuarn / the pees was made in this manner / One of the knights stood up in the
myddel of the host / and said alwey we dye / no man has the vyctorye / Edmond
may not be overcome for his greece strength / Canutus may not be overcome for
favor of fortune / But what shall be the fruit of this contynuel stryf / but
when the knights he slain on either side / than the dukes compellyd by need
shall acord^ owther certeynly they shall fight without knights alone / either
with other / Than why do they not now one of these tweyne / If they acord why
is not the kingdom now more suffycient for hem tweyne / that was sometime ynowe
for five / If her couetyse of lordship is so great that either has
indygnacion to take and have part with other / owther to be under / than late
hem fight alone / that wol be lords alone / lest if al men fight al men be
slain / and so should leave no knights under the heestes of dukes / nowther to
defend the king ayenste strange alyenes / Then the dukes with her hoostes
come to geder at yland of olneye besides Gloucestre / there all men cried
owther they should acorde / or fight a^ one / Than both the kings come to
geder in middel of the yla^d and the people stood / and beheld on either side /
The kings fought first on horse / and than on foot / There canutus espied that
Edmonde might not be overcome and acorded to be partyner of the kingdom / and
they threw awey her wepens and kyssed either other Then al men wondered / and
were ioyeful thereof / when this was done the traitor Edrycus desired to make
him self leeue Canutus / And at oxenford when edmonde was at pryny to cleanse
his womb / as need of kind axeth / Edrycus was pryuely hid under the place
/ and stykked the king upward / that sat on the sege / And than edrycus
went to canutus and said hayle king aloone / When the king knew how it
stood / he said to Edrycus / For thou trowest to plese me with such manner
service / and have slain the best body of the world / I shall arerethyn head
above all the lords of england / Than anon Edrycus heed was smyten of / and
set above the highest yate of london /

R But sum stories say / and specially marianus / that Edmond dyed not in
that manner / But after that the acorde was made / and stabled between the
kings / and the kyngd^me deled between hem tweyn / Edmond dyed at london

death / Canutus yaue mercia to the false Edrycus / and exyled edmundes brother /
by his counseylle and did many other deeds / and that might not stand / if he
had beheded Edrycus before /

Capitulum 18 /
CAnutus the dane was made king alone when edmond was deed / and reigned about
nynten year / he deled the king of England in four / and assygned westsaxon to
him self / Eeste england that conteyneth northfolk / and Southfolk to therle
turkyllus / Mercia to the false Edricus / and northumberlond to hyricius / Than
he made a counseylle at london and axed of the lords / if any mention was made
in thacord between him and edmond / that edmundes brethren owther his childer
should be kings after his death / They answerde full falsely and flateryngly and
said nay / Also they swar that they would in all wise put of edmondes kynne /
They trowed thereby to be greet with the king afterword / Therefore sum of
them were slain by gods rightful dome / and sum banysshed and exyled and
put out of the land / By counseylle of Edrycus / the king exyled edmondes
brother that was cleped king of churles / But he was afterward gylefully
reconcyled and slain by / tresonne of his oun men / but king canutus drad /
and was ashamed to sle edmo^ds sons edmond and Edward / and by counseyll of

god and sent hem forther to Salamon king of hongary to save her life / And
edmond wedded that kings daughter / and dyed sone after without children /
But Edward wedded Agath / henry the emperors daughter / and bygate on her
Margarete that was afterward queen of Sco^lande / and Crystyne a nonne / and
Edgar adelyng / Henricus libro sexto / This name adelyng is made of twey saxon
words / Ade^ that is noble / and lyng that is an image / than adelynge is as
it were a noble image / Therefore the westsaxons have in a proverb / of great
despyte / vnderlyng / that is he that is put out of honest / owther an image
that goth bakwarde / The holy king edward was afterward in purpo^s to make
this Edgar heyr of England / but he dradde goodwynes sons / and the shrewdnes
of his own men / and made wiliam norman his sone adoptinus / Willelmus de
regibus libro secundo / In the month of Iuyll king Canutus wedded Emma the
queen / for he would be the more sure of England / and bygate on her a son
called hardeknutus / After that at london the false Edrycus despised the
benefyce that him was yeuen / and the king bade slay him right there in his
own palace / and bade throw the body besides the walls in to Temse / In that
he was war / that Edrycus should not bytraye him by fraud and by treasonne / he
exyled sum other lords / But he loved Earl leofrycus alwey afterward /
After this^ he made a parliament at oxenforde / there Englysshmen and danes were
acorded for to hold king edgars laws / Henricus libro sexto / That year
Canutus went in to denmarck / and had with him Englysshmen against the
wandales that werred upon him / The night before the battle duc goodwyn and
englysshmen come vnwar upon the enemies and dysparpled hem / and chaced hem
vnwyttyng the king / therefore the king did englissh men great worship from that
time forward / and come ayene that year in to England This year Alduinus
bishop of lyndeffarn was deed / Than the sea was wide about three year / and
there was made a synod for the election of the bishop / there come Edmonde
the priest and said in his game / why chese ye not me / Some took not his game
in game / but they ordeygned for to fast three days for the same cause For
they would wit saint cuthbertus will Then when the priest was at mass
a voys sowned twyes out of saint Cuthberts tomb / and said that Edmond should
be his bishop / Also this year fell that wonder in Saxon in saint magnus the
martirs church / There fyften men / and three women led a dance in the
chircheyerde on a crystemas night And the priest of the church was wroth /
and prayed of wreche / and said in this manner / God grant by the prayer of
saint magne the martyr that ye be so dyseaced / and led in this manner the
dance all the year long / and so it was done / For when that year was
passed the same cristemasse a twellyf month they led the dance in snow up
to the sides / and had nowther ete ne drunk / nowther slepte till they were
delyuerd by the prayer of saint Cuthbert bishop of Colon / when they were
drawn up of the earth / they leyde hem self before the altar / then sum
of hem dyed anon / and sum were kept alive / and showed on them self the
great deeds of god / One of thilk women was the same priests daughter / that
prayed this wreche / Her oune brother would have drawn her out of the dau^ce /
but she brayde to him her arm / and led forth the dance never the latter with
the other all that year / Willelmus do pontificibus libro primo / About this
time bryghtwold monk of Glastenbury that was afterward the first bishop of
wylton / was in his co^templacion / and thought on the kings lygnage of
Englyssh men / that lygnage was than nygh^ al destroyed / And so this monk
fill on sleep / and saw saint peter the apostle held by the hand edward /
Egelredus son in normandye that was then exyled out of england / and he
saw petre sacre this Edward and made him king and showed at full / how holy
this Edward should be / and how he should regne three and twenty year / Also this
monk axyd and made question of Edwardes ofsprynge and who should be kings
afterward / Peter answerde and said / the kingdom of Englysshmen is gods
kingdom / and after this god shall ordeyne and puruey / Henricus libro sexto /
About this time an holy man warned englysshmen / that a lord that they
thought not on / should come out of France / and gbrine hem right low / and
told other things as it is said in the end of the first book / Willelmus de
Re / libro secundo This year egelnotus Archebisshop of Caunterbury plesed king
Canutus in goodness by auctoryte of hoolynesse / And f^red him in his excess
/ and brought saint elphegus body out of london to his own church / There
after as he came from Rome at Papye / he bought saint anstyns the doctors arm
for an Cl^i of silver / and a talente of gold / he sent that arm to couentre
for love of leof^ycus / This year dyed the first henry Emperor of Almayne /
After him the first Conradus reigned / xv / year / He ordained that who so ever
brake the law of the land should leese his heed / Then the first that
trespa^ed against thordena u^ce was Earl lupoldus / Then he d^adde full soore /
and fled in to wilderness / he and his wife / On a time Conradus come thither
for to hunte / and herd slepynge in his bed a wys that spoke to him twyes and
said / the earl heremytes child. that now is born newly / shall wedde thy
daughter / and shall be thine heyr / Therefore he had indignacion and commanded
to bring the childs heart / But the messagers dradde god and threw the
child a live in a wood / And brought to the king the heart of an hare / Sone
after it happed that one duc harry passed therforth / and herd the child weep
/ and sent him to norysshynge to his own wife / that was bareyn / and named
him harry by his own name When the chykde come to age / Conradus the king
beheld him often time / and bythoughte him full often that he was warned sometime
/ and kept the child with him / But he that was holden the childs fader
withsayde it alwey / The Emperor by him self bythought him full often / how he
might destroy this child / Therefore he sent this child to themperyce / with
lettres wreton in this manner / when the lettres were read / the child
should dye the same day / the child was lodged on a night with a priest / that
read the childs lettres / when the child was a sleep / and for this word
should dye / the priest wrote should wedde our douhter / and so it was done /
And though the emperor was evil apaid therefore he bythought him that the child
was a gentil earls sone and took it the lyghtlyer / And build an abbaye in the
place of wilderness there the child was borne / The Abbaye is called vrsania
/

Capitulum 19 /
ALso this year dyed the second Richard / the fourth duc of normandy / After
him his sone the third rychard was duc of normandy^ After one year of the
ducherye / his younger brother Robert slough him / with venym / and was duk after
him / But after the vij year of his duchery / he was sorry for his broders death
and went on pilgremage / barfote to Jerusalem and dyed in Bithinia / Of him it
is seyde / that he was mighti and polytique / in battle / large and free of
yeftes and of mete and drink / On a time it happed at a great fest that
knights offered at mass / but one of hem offered not / The duc trowed therefore
that he had not that he might offer / and bad give him an C / pound / he leyd
hem holy upon the altar / Me axed him why he did so / for hit was yeuen me
for to offer said the knight / The duc herd that and yaf him a another hundred
pound to his own use / On a another time the same duc pleyed at chesse / and
him was yeuen a golden Just / wonderly feyre arrayed with perles and with
precious stones / and he yaf hit anon to the clerk that pleyed with him at
chesse / and the clerk dyed anon / Phiscians told the cause and said / that
right as the heart closes for great sorrow and is cause of death but the heart be
the sooner opened / Also for great Joy the heart opens and is cause of death /
But it be the sooner closed / Also on a time one brought to Duc Robert twey well
fair knyues / and anon he badde give him an hundred pound / And while he told
the money / were tweye gentill horses yeuen to the Duc / The Duc yaf hem anon to
him that yaf him the knyues / When he had received all this he sped him fast
his way / lest some let might have fallen In the mean time the duc was yeue^
acup of seluer that was a ^essel to bear in fruit / Than he was sought that
brought the knyues and might not be founden / Than the Duc made great moon and
said / that he had received a simple reward that brought him the knyues / Me
seyde of this Robert / that all that me yafe him / but hit were such a yefte
that should be eten / he would give it to him / that yafe him the first
worshipful yefte that day / willelmus de Re / libro 2 / This Robert on a time
passed by phalesya a cite of normandye. and saw a ma^den called Arlett by her
name a skynners daughter dau^ce among other / and had her to his bed at night
and held her somdele long time instead of his wife / and bygat on her wilia^
the conqueror / a sweue^ that his mother met signefyed how great he should be /
for she met that her bowels were sprad in to al england and normandy / Also
when the child was born it happed that he touched the ground and took both his
hands full of the powder of the pame^t and co^streyned his ^andes and held
fast the powder / therefore the mydwyf told that the child should be a king the
first night that this mayd^ arlett was brought to the dukes bed / she to rent
her owen smok fro the chynne to the feet / The duc axed whi she did so / It is
neither skyll ne curtesye said she that the hemme of my smok that has
byclipped my feet / should be turned toward my lords mouth Than duc Robert went
to Ierl^m and had to geder all the lords of his land at Fiseanum and made hem
swear feuty to his son william that was tho vij year old and ordained erl^
Gilbert the childs tutor and ordained the tutor to be maynteyned by the king
of France / they held their obeisance to the child til duc robert was deed /
But when they herd of duc Robertus death / every of them took head to him self
and rought not of the child / At last this Gilbert was slain of one Rauf
that was the chyldes uncle / There was fightyng and man slaughter the country
was foul faren with / with strif that men had among hem self / but william
was young in arms / and one Guye a Bourgyon / was cause and maker of all that
strif / and treson the which Gye was williams kynnesman of the second
Richardes daughter But william took him and did him to death / And Odo the
kings brother of France come against willyam / but willyam / had the maystrye
and chased Odo / and made him fle^ / henry the king of France herd thereof and
came with a great multitude and was despitously and foully chased / But
mediators went bitwene and made peace / And the kings men of france were
delivered that were taken prisoners. / Here take great head that wylliam faught
often with the king of France / but never suddenly as our men do now a days /
But the day of battle should be set / and he had ever the victory / Than
when the king of France was ded / he took manly the lands of Normandy thaugh
the lands were long time absolute / that by the count of canouic / and litil
bretayn / that king charles had yeuen to rollo with his daughter gilla / this
will^m wan it manly / harold an english^ man was in that battle asit shall be
said with in / Duc whert went to Ierl^m and passed by borgoyne / there as he
went out of the yate / the porter smot him with a staf / anon he thanked god
and forbad his men and charged that none of hem should tak wreche of that deed
for I am said he well worthy to have more harm I love said he this stroke more
than al Rothomage / Than he came for to take the cross of the pope / and did
his noble palle about the image of the great Constantyne and scorned there
with the Romans that would namely ones a year give their lord a clothe Also he
made to shoe his mule with gold that he rode on / and forbade al his men that
they should not take up the shoes / when they were fallen / Also he came by
the emperor of constantinople and while he spak with the emperor he saw no
benche in all the house and sat him down upon his own pall in the manner of his
oune countrey^ and his knights did the same / And as the duc bad they left
their pallys there / when they arysen / and said that they should not take awey
her benches / the duc was prayed of the emperor to take money for his cost by
the wey and he answered and said that he would in pylgremage live by his own /
But when he came again he would do the emperors will / than the king forbade
that no man should selle him fuel to sethe his mete therewith / than the duc
bought notes and sethed his mete there with / the king wondered of the dukes
manhede / and made benches in his court afterward instead of the foresaid
palles / herafter the duc eueled so in the weye that he might neither goo ne
ride / therefore he hired pour sarasyns that should bear him by day / in a
litere on her shulders / and charged a norman that went again in to Normandye
/ that to the normans that would axe tidings of the duc / he should tell that he
had seen fendes bear the duc to heaven ward / he called the sarsynes fendes /
and the holy land heaven / Than hit was used that no christian man should come
within the holy Cite with out great hyre / Than many men herd of this dukes
coming and came to him and prayed him of help and he swear by the heart of his
womb / that while he had one penny / he would be the last that should enter /
That noble Sarsyn the lord of the cite herd thereof and had also herd of this
Dukes other manly deeds / and forbad anon that nothing should be taken of him
nowther of any man that come in his company and charged and commanded also to
give to the duc all the offryng of a day / He received the offryng and yaf hit
anon to pore men and dyed sone after in Bithinia as it is before said

Capitulum 20
AFter Benet. the xx John was pope ix year / Al^o this time Maryanus the Scotte
was / born / by his labor / this cronyk is much enhaunced / Maryanus / The
Norganes that is to sey men of norewey forsook eft their holy king olauus for
his symplenesse / and took canutus in his stead / and he was cursidly slain /
the fourth year after / Robert king of France is deed / his son hugh was
king after him / Also that year canutus went out of denmark / to Rome / and
yaue large gifts to saint peter / and made there the scole of Saxons free of
al manner trybute / and yaf large Alms / and great in his coming again toward
england / and paid great raunsonne for passage of pylgryms in many places /
And purchaced that the weyes were opened that were closed and procured the pope
to relece the price and the payment that prymates of his kingdom were wont to
give and pay for to have the palle / Of all these deeds they sent a letter to
the lords of England and and charged hem that they should before his coming
amend all trespaces and defautes / ^ After Johan the nynth Benette was pope
eight year / but this benet was put out of the poperyche and another that
was called Syluestre was put in his stead / But this Siluester was put out
and Benet was restored again But yet this benet was efte put out ageyn / and
Johan Arche pretour of saint John's place that is callid ante portam latinam was
made pope / Inner more this Johan is called the sixth gregory / This benet for
he was boystous of lettrure / when he had the poperyche / he ordained
another pope for thoffy^e of holy church / That manner of doing dysplesyd many
men / Therefore the third was brought ynne / that should do thoffyce for hem both
And so one stroofe against tweyne / and tweyne ayenste one for the poperyche /
Then henry the emperor that had wedded conradus daughter / and was his
successor put out these popes / and brought in by strength the bishop of
ramberge that was called the second clement / Of him this henry was crowned /
also this henry compellyd the romans to swear that they should never ch^se
pope without his assent / But this Benet after his death appeared to a man in the
likeness of a wonder shape^ beeste / with an ass tail and with a beeres
heed and seid that he apeyred so right as he was while he was alive / This
year dyed robert duc of normandy in his pylgremage / after him his young sone
wiliam was duc / of the which wiliam it is said ^^fore / Mar / This year
canutus a little before he dyed one suan^^ king over the norganes / this suanus
was holden the sone of canutus and of Elgyna of hampton / Sum men said that
this elgyna might conceive no child by the king and therefore she took this
suanus when he was new borne / of a priests wife and leyde her self down /
as it were in childebedde / and the child by her / and begyled king canutus /
and brought him in wit that it was sothe / Canutus made his son and Emme
sone hardeknutus king over the danes / king canutus dyed at Septon that is
shaftesbury / and is buried at wynchestre in the old abbay / Henricus libro
sexto / Me spekyth of three great deeds that he did / the first that he married
his daughter to the emperor Conradus. The second that he went nobly to Rome /
and come again and brought with him a greet dele of our lords cross / the
third that he set his seet on the sea stronde while the sea was flowyng and
commanded and charged the sea should not comme upon his land and that the sea
should not wete his lords clothes / But the sea came up as it was wont by his
own kind / and wette the kings thyes / Than the king starte awey and said
/ Al men shall wit and know / that the power and might of kings / is vain
and vanyte / and that none is worthy to have the name of king but he that has
al thing subgette to his laws / And this king canutus never bare crown upon
his heed after that time / but he set the crown upon the crucifyx heed /
at wynchestre / when Canutus was deed / than was made great stryf at oxenford
/ who should be king and his successor / For leofrycus consul of chestre /
and other lords of the northsyde of temse / and the londoners also took harold
harefote that was holden the son of Canutus and of Elgyna hampton / and made
him king / though Goodwyn made him besy for Canutus / Marianus / Sum men
sayen that this harolt was a souters son / and falsely anon he was born
brought to the bed of this Elgyna / and leyde by her as thouh she had born
him and brought him forth / Right as suanus was leyd by her sometime / but
herald was made king and took fro Emma all the kings riches / and put her out
of England / But the earl of flaundres receyuyd her worshipfully / and did her
great favor / Ethelnotus archebisshop of Caunterbury dyed / and seven days
after him dyed ethelricus bishop of winchestre / he had besily praid god yt he
him self should not long live after ethelnotus Than edsius heraldes chapelayn
was made archebisshop of caunterbury / and stygandus heraldes other priest was
made bishop of wynchestre / Thereafter he took the sea of canterbury
wrongfully after edsius / This herald dyed at london after the fourth year of
his kingdom / and was buried at wynchestre / when he was deed / the lords of
the land sent for hardeknutus / king of Denmark / that dwelled than in
flaundres with his mother /

Capitulum xij /
HArdecnutus come in to england / and reigned three year / But he did right
naught that he was worthy to be praised fore / for anon he sent alfrycus
archebisshop of york with goodwyn to london / and made take up king heraldes
body / out of the earth / and for wreche of the wrongs that herald had done
to his mother / he made smite of heraldes head that was deed before / and throw
the body in to temse / but afterward fysshers found the body / and buried it
couenably / Also hardecuntus made to pay to every rower of his nauey eight marc
of silver of the tribute of thempyre of england / And put all the rule and
governance of his kingdom upon the wit and counseyll of Goodwyn / and of
his own mother / when this king put all themperial trybute upon English men
/ tweyne of the kings mynystres that were asse^tynge to that deed were slain
at wyrcetre / therefore that Cite was destroyed / and set on fire / Willelmus
de re / li / 2 / Also this king married his fairest sister gunnylda to harry
the emperor / gunnylda was the daughter of Canutus and of Emma / and was before
wowed of many greet wowers in her faders time / When she had be long time
with her husband / she was accused of spouse brekynge / Than her nory that she
had brought with her out of England put him to fight in that quarele
with him that had told that falls tale / though that tale teller was as great
as a geaunt / they fought to gyder / and gun nyldas nory carf the false pelours
hamme / and had him down^ and so by virtue of god he had the maystrye / than
gunnylda began to hep and dance for joy / and forsook her husband for ever
more / and would never after come in his bed for no man's prayer / but she
took the holy veil and bycam a nonne / Hen / li / 6 / and mar / In this
heraldes time elfrede / and edward the sons of king egelredus and of emma
after that they had long dwellid in norma^dye they took with hem many knights
of normandy and come to speak with her mother at wynchestre / Than goodwyn cast
to mary his daughter to edward / as to the sympler and younger of the tweyn and
supposed that the elder brother would despise such a marriage / and goodwyn
warned the lords of England / and said that it was not seker that any man
should bring in to the land / so many me^ of Strange / and gileful nation /
and therefore they that were comin must pay the pain / For of. the normans /
that were brought forth / he slough alwey ix / and kept the tenthe / and yet
him thought that the tythyng were to many lefte^ and tythed efte the tythynge^
/ In this manner he fastened the ends of guts to stakes that were arered and
pyght in the ground / and led the lodyes about the stakes till the last
ends of the guts come out / Elfreduc was sent to Ely after his blyndynesse
but few days / When emma herd that she sent her sone Edward hastyly in
normandy / There after Goodwyn was blamed of hardecuntus the king and of other
lords for these deeds / Then he swear that he did never such deeds / But
as he was compellyd by strength of king harald / when Conradus the first was
deed / the second harry that had wedded his daughter was emperor after him /
Of him be wondres read both before and after in this book^ he reigned xvij /
year / he put al mynstrals out of his court / and yaue to pore men all that he
was wont to give to mynstrals before / W / de re / li / 2 / Also he had a
sister that was a nonne / and loved her so much that he might not suffer her
out of his company / On a time a clerk of the court had layne by her al night
unto the morrow tide / and the earth was heled al with snow / they took hem to
read / And the clerk made her to bear him on her bakk out of the court / the
king aroos to pysse / and saw that doing / and held his pees till a
bisshopryche was void / and then he yaue the clerk that bisshopryche / and
said look that thou never after this ride more upon a woman's rydge / Thereafter
voyded an abbaye of menchons / and he yaue it to his sister / and said take
this / and look thou never bear clerk more ridyng on thy bak / they were thus
espied / and absteyned afterward / Also on a time this emperor went upon a
sunday that is callid quinquagesima pryuatly for to bear a mass in a chapel
besides a forest^ There served right a foul priest / therefore the king
bythought and wondered in his heart / why god that is so fair would suffer so
foul a creature come nyghe / and handle his sacramentis / when the verse of
the tracte was songen / S^itote quonia^ dominus ipse est deus / that is wit ye
that our lord is god / the priest looked on the emperor / as it were bla^mynge
the defaute of his clerc / and said Ipse fecit nos / et non ipsi nos / that is
he made us / and not we our self / The Emperor was meoued by that saw / and
made that priest a Bishop sone after / This priest made the place and the gree
honest with good manner of living / For a rich man had lad awey a no^ne and he
departed him from her / and restored the nonne to her abbay again / And
afterward this rich man fylle in to sin / and cursed him with all that come
in his company / and then he dwelled in his own orcharde to his last
sickness / and then he prayde the bishop that he would him assoylle / the
bishop answerde / and said / if that cursyd man wol leave that cursed woman /
he shall be assoyled / and if he wol not this day a twelve month the same hour
when I shall dye / he shall dye and answer for his deeds before the highest god
/ and so it was done / For they dyed both the same day a twellyf month / the
same king had in his chapel a clerk / that had great conning in scripture /
and a fair wys / but the clerk was lecherous / the Emperor bade him on a day
read the gospel / and he would not / for he had defouled him self with a
strompette the night to fore / then the Emperor said / owther read the
gospel owther forsake my land / Anon he trussed his fardels / and arayd him
for to goo / The Emperor had charged his servants that they should go
after him privately / and if he would be a goo / they should bring him again
When that was done the king said to him I am glad of thy goodness / that
thou draddest more god than the losing of thine own country / and the wrath
of heaven more than my manace / therefore forsake the wood love that thou vsyst
/ and I shall make the a bishop / Also while this harry was young in Conradus
hows / he took of one a pype of silver / such as children use for to play
with / and he promised that clerk a bisshopryche for that pype / when he were
Emperor / At last he was emperor / and the clerk axyd and had that was
promised him / Sone after the emperor was smyten with a grievous sickness / so
that three days he felt no thing / nowther tasted mete ne drink / At
last by prayers of good men / that stood about him / he caught breath / and
sent for the clerk that was so auau^ced / and deposed him by dome of
counseylle / and knouleched / that he was al tho three days tormented with
fendes / that cast on him wonder hoote brennyng lie / through the same pype / In
comparyson of that lie our fire is as it were temperatly warm / But there come
a yonglyng with a golden chalis full of water / and quenched the same heete with
spryngyng of water He said that saint laurence was that yonglyng / Saint
laurences church was al to fall for elde and feblenesse / and defawte of
help / And the emperor had amended the church / and yeuen thereto a chalys /
Mar / In this henryes time was great stryf in the church of Rome / for three
men were chosen popes at ones / And a priest called gracianus yaue money / and
had the poperyche / but this harry came to Rome to cesse that stryf / Gracianus
proffered him a crown of gold / but for all that he was conuycte of Symony / and
deposed / and another made pope / Also in this Emperors time pallas body the
Geaunt was founden at Rome hole and sound without rotyng with a chyn of a
wou^de-of four foot long and an half / his body in length passed the heyght
of the walls of Rome / At his heed was a lantern brennynge that might not be
quenchyd with blast neither with moisture / er the eyer ca^ in at a little hole
/ that / was made under the leite / On his to^be were these two versus wreto^ /
Pallas euandres son / whom with his spear turnus / That knight did to death
in his wise lies here / Willelmus de Regibus libro 1 / I trow not that these
versus were made in latin when that geaunt was buried / though Ca^rmentus
euandres mother had found before lettres of latin / But I trow rather / that
they were afterward made of Ennio / owther of sum other poet / But in time
after that the body was bysprongen with water / it roted as other bodies do /
and the senewes were fallen and the skin also

Capitulum / 22
AFter Benet the sixte gregory was pope about four year / and was called
gracianus before / Willelmus de Regibus This man of great relygyon and
sternesse had a battle sometime with henry the emperor Also this found the
state of the papacye of rome so to fall that uneath he had ought to him
self and the cardynals for to live by / but few towns nyghe the Cite / and
the offryng of christian men The remenaunt was taken awey owther occupied by
thieves so ferforth that the offrynges were taken awey from the aulters under
naked swerdes outher robbed in the high streets and weyes / therefore all
prouynces left of and took not the wey to Rome / because of thieves in the wey /
and of other thieves in saint peter's church / Gregory saw this and treated
with them first soft / and with fair speech / but when he saw that helpyd not
/ he cursyd all them that did so / and departed hem from the body of holy church / and all that were assenting to them that so did / when the pope
saw that / that halp not but it brought him self in to peril of death / he
wrote to the emperor that he should help holy church / that was in point to
fall / the emperor excused him by the war of wandalia / and prayed the pope /
that he would in his stead / and at his cost put to his hand / therefore the pope
yaue the dome / that the yren of cuttynge must be vsid and gat him armor and
horsemen on every side / that drofe awey first owther slough the thieves that
robbed the offrynges of saint peter's church / than the pope gate again the
land that he had lost long time / Then the quyrytes that were wont to
live by theft and robberye cleped the pope ablodsheder and a man sleer / And
said he was not worthy to do thoffyce of the altar / So that many of the
cardynals were assenting to that meouynge / and demed that the pope should not
be buried in holy church / In his last sickness he was ware thereof / and
called the cardynals before him / and he spak to hem in this man My brethren
me wondreth gretely / that ye deem your bishop so rabbyshly I have lived so
that I have spe^te what I had in your prouffyte / For your delyueraunce I have
forgendryd / and rouht not of the fame of this world / therefore if other men
make such tales on me / ye should stylle thoppynyons of fools in a better
manner meaning / thieves had taken aweye your lyflode that I might not
suffer / therefore I werryd with the thieves / therefore sith every man's deed
shall be demed by thentente of him that does the deed / as the gospel sayth^ If
thine eye be simple / that is if thine entente be ryghtfull / all the body shall
be bright and clear / that is the gaderyng of thy works / Sometime I yafe alms
to the pour men / and he showed my benefeite to the thef and to the robber /
therefore he was robbed and slain / Shall I be blamed / for I ydue alms to the
pilgrim / through which he had his death / god it forbede for it was couetyse
of the thief / that did that cursed deed / and not my larges and fredome / Also
in the law the same is blamed and punysshed and praised for diverse intent For
the thef that sleeth in hydels. is punisshed and the knight is preysed that
sleeth his enemy in bataylle / for the first sleeth the man for couetyse / and
the second for the sauacion of the country Also the first pope Adryan was
sometime preysed / for he granted to charles the inuestiture of prelates / now
be our Bisshopes preysed for they do the contrary / and taken fro princes such
manner power / Then for sum manner causes it was resonably granted / that
is now resonably warned and denied / For than charles soul was not enfecte
with couetyse / and the court of rome was fer from the ellysers / and the
prince was nyghe and fastby that would right naught do by couetyce / but now
couetyce of princes has shente al / In this manner may my cause be taken
toward either side / and be apeyred owther helped / but ye sey it is not a
bisshops office to shede blood / nowther to make it to be shed / I grant /
netheles it fallyth to him / if he sue the innocente in peryle / to help and
socoure him with his tongue / and with hand / For ezechyel accused the priests
for they wythstode not ne made a wall for gods hows / Twey persons be
ordained to destroy vices in gods church / One that whetteth the speech
another that bears the sword / I take witness of god and of you / that I
armed the tongue against thenemyes of holy church / as long as I might profyt
/ And him to whom it befalls to worche with the sword / I prayede thryes by
messagers / and by lettres that he would come and chastyse such manner thieves /
and he wrote again that he was occupied in the war of wandalia / and prayed
that I would at my travail / and his cost dystourbe the thieves / what should I
do than when he had put his office upon me / and I saw the sleynge of
cyteseyns / the damage of pylgryms and the meschyef of the pope and of the
Cardynals / And he that spares the thief / yeueth cause and occasion why the
ryghtful man and innocent is slain / but one caas ye sey that it falls not
for a priest to shede man's blood / I grant but if he defowle him self that
bears down the wykl^ed man and saves the man that is innocente and ryghtful
/ and they be blessed that keep ryghtfull dome / and ryghtwysenes / Phynees and
mathathyas be praised for they stykked hem through / that trespast / but we shall
less suffer our very holy things to be defowled / than they her mysteries
/ that were but shadow in comparison of ours. and zachary the bishop put king
osias out / For he would cense and without dread he would have kyld him nadd he
had goon his weye / and he did him good / the which it seemed that I slough /
for the longer that the wicked man lives / the more he deseruyth of blame and
pain / therefore he that shorteth the life of such one / lassyth his blame and
his pain / and so he does for him and yeueth him a benefyce / Treuisa / Here
ware of the deuyls argument and of gyle / For be a man never so evil / yet he
may amend while he is a live / and so did Paul and mary magdalene and many
other and so christ means in the gospel in the ensample of whete and of
cockle that sum men call darnel^ Than it follows in the storye / Then the
pope said that I no wther ye be begyled in this doing / take my body when I
am deed / and set it before the church doors with out and do that the
doors be fast loken and bars / and if the doors open not by gods grace and
his virtue / do with my body what ye wol / when it was done that the pope
desired / there came a whyrl wind / and brake up the doors and the bars / and
shufte the body anon / to the Inner wall of the church / When this miracle
was seen the cardynals and the people buried him in saint peter's church / Also
this year at a fest of a spousayle at lambehyth besides london / while king
hardecnutus was hool glad and mury / and stood and drank / be fylle suddenly
down and wexe dombe. and dyed the eight day of Iunij / and was buried with his
fader at wynchestre / Henricus libro sexto / Me seith he was so large and so
free of heart that he would make array kings messes four sythes a day / ffor him
was lever that ghestes should leave releef than axe more mete / willelmus de re
Me sent in to normandy / that edward should come and be crowned king and
pledgys were yeuen so that he should bring with him but few normans / then
helped Edwardes side / leofrycus. Earl of chestre. Goodwyn duc of westsaxons
and lyuyngus Bishop of wyrcetre / R But marianus says that king hardecnutus
had sent before for his brother edward and made him abide with him in his
own court / Willelmus de re / and marianus

Capitulum 23
THan edward come in to england and was crowned king at westmynstre of edsius
the archebisshop of Caunterbury and reigned about four and twenty year / This
king wedded Godytha / Goodwyns daughter / and by ladde her by such craft so
that he put her not from his bed / nowther lay by her flesshely / whether he
did it for hate of her meyny / owther for love of chastyte / I know not for
certain / but that solemn doing is told of him / that he lived alwey
without gylt of woman / This king worshipped not his own mother at full / no
wther shamed her openly / but by counseyll of goodwyn he took of her all the
precious things and Jewels that she had / Owther for she had be to hard
with him sometime / owther for she would give him right naught / Also he had
to him out of normandy sum that were with him famylyer there / for they
should be rewarded / Among the which he took one Robert gemeticus a mo^k and
made him first bishop of london and than Archebisshop of Caunterbury / The
king was simple and did so much by this Robertes counsel that he awaited
his time. and outlawed his wives fader goodwyn and his sons also / and took
fro his oune mother all that she had / and closed her in thabbaye. of werwel for
suspection that she was to homely with the Bishop of wynchestre / and
prysonned the bishop alwyn / But emma was easyly kept / and somdele at her
large. and wrote to the Bisshops of England / in the which she had trust of
friendship / And said that hit grieved her more the despyte that the bishop had
than her own shame / and said that she was ready by gods own dome and by
thassay of fire hoote iron / that the bishop was wrongefully defamed / Then
the bisshops come to geder to the king and should have had of the king all that
they prayed / ne had be Robert tharchebisshop of Caunterbury spoke against hem
/ My brethren bisshops said Robert / how dar ye defend her that is a wild
be / and not a woman / she has defamed her own son the king / and
nempned her lecherous lemman gods own crist / But be it / that the woman
would purge the bishop / But who shall purge the woman that is accused that was
assentyng to the death of her son Egelredus and procured venym to the
poysenynge of Edward / But be it that she had auctoryte and power upon the
condition of proprete of kind of male owther female / Yet if she would goo
barfote for her self four steps / and for the bishop five steps
continuelly upon nine solow shares brennyng and fire hoote / Then if she
escape harmeles over all these steps / he shall be quytte / and assoyled of
this challenge / Anon the day of thassay of this purgacion was appointed / till
that day come the king and all the lords were there / out take Robert all one
/ but the night before the day of this purgaco^n / the woman was in her prayers
at wynchester at saint Swythytes tomb / and was comforted there / Than on the
morrow her eyes were hid / and she passed the fire in hot solowe shares /
and escaped harmeles / Than the king began to groan and axed mercy and was
disciplyned of either bishop / and of his mother also and than he restored to
his mother all that he had taken fro her before / Then Queen Emma yaf saint
Swithyne ix manners and the bishop yafe other ix because of the ix solow shares
that Emma had over passed / But Robert bishop of Caunterburye fled in to
normandye / Marianus / Elfword bishop of london that was sometime abbot of
euessham / wax vnsuffisaunt for elde feebleness and sickness to govern and rule
so great a bisshopriche and would have be abbot of Euesham ayene / but the
brether of the place would not assente / Than he took with him books and other
things that he owther his successors had yeuen to the abbey of Euesham / and
went him to thabbey of Ramesay / there he dyed sone after / and was buried there
/ After him came Robert / I^em Marianus / king edward gadred a strong nauey in
the haven of sandewiche / ayenste harolde harfager king of the Noreganes / that
arrayed him for to com and werr in England but by the betaylle that Suanus
king of Danes / yafe him / all that purpos was let / Me says that in a
another time king edward lough at mess / as he was not wont / they that were
present wondered / and axed why hit was / The Noreganes and the danes said the
king / were accorded for to come and werre in England / But when they all were
arrayed forto sail one profred hem a bolle with meede for to drink and prayed
hem in a dispitous name / but if they would drink / Than came bolle after bolle
and dronkenesse turned into Ianglyng and Ianglyng into stryf and strif into
fyghtyng and so they be departed and to shufte a twynne / And I hope that in my
time shall non aliens werre in my land / After grego the x benet was pope /
about two year / he had bought the poperiche. and therefore harry the emperor put
him out and brought in the second Clement that dyed after one year and poppo
was pope after him two months This poppo was cleped the second damasius when
he was deed the ix leo was pope v year / The foresaid harrold king of Noreganes
was sent to Olauus his brother on the mother side / He chased Swanus king of
denmarche / and made denmarche subgiet to him self / king Swanus that was so
put out / axed help of the king of england / And earl Godwyn was assentyng /
But other lords counseled Nay / But king har^old dyed and Suanus recovered
Denmarche again / This year lyuyngus the bishop of wirceter dyed and Aldredus
was bishop after him / This Aldredus had be first / monk at wynchester and
than abbot of tauestok / Great snow fille in the west contreyes of England /
So that hit brake great trees of the woods and dured from the first day of
Ianuar to saint patriques day After that fell great pestilence of men / and
death of beestes and lightnyng forscalded corns / This year was a bateyle
bitwene henri king of France and the lords of Normandy / For they would not
receive william to be duc / when they were ouercom / Duc william outlawed some of
hem / and heng some of hem by the throtes / About that time erlewynus a knight
of Normandy forsook the worldly cheualrye and byld an abbey at beccum in
Normandy that yet is called Becherlewyn / Him shamed naught abbot and ruler /
to bear ston and mortar to the work and bake bread and do other works of
clennes and of honest / God sent him the twey lanterns of the world / to his
help and counseyl lanfranke and Ancelme / twey men of great clergy and
lettrure / Either of hem was pryour in that place / one after another and
afterward Archebisshop of caunterbury / Marianus This year pope leo and Swanus
king of danes^ went with harry the emperor against baldwyn Earl of Flaundres /
And Edward the king of england kept the sea with his Nauey til the emperor had
all his will / Also this ix pope leo had a wemme in his conscience for the
emperor had made him pope somdele by mastrye / therefore he resygned the
poperiche but than he was laufully chosen pope again / Also this year the
thieves of Irland came in to seuarn see with help of Griffyn king of wales and
took many prays about the river vaga / In the mean time swanus / Godwynes
eldest sone / that had sometime leyne by Edgyna / the Abbess of leofmonaster /
and cast for to wedde her and forsook his wife therefore he came to England / If
he might have grace / to make his peace with the king / But in his coming / he
slough Earl Beornus that was his Cosyn that was about to make his peace with
the king / Than he fled in to flaundres til he was reconcyled by help of
Aldredus the Archebisshop of york and of worcetre / Marianus /

Capitulum 24
King Edward dyscharged englysshmen / of a grievous tribute that his fader
Egelredus had made pay to the soudyours of denmarck / and had tho dured forty
year / This year dyed Edsius Archebisshop of caunterbury / And king edward yafe
the Archebisshopryche to his famylyer Robert that he had made Bishop of london
/ Here after in the month of September Eustacius Earl of Boloyn come a land
at dover / he hadd wedded goda king edwardes syster^ his knights sought him
in Innes unwisely / and slough one of the Cyteseyns / and the Cyteseyns slough
one of his knights / Willelmus de regibus libro secundo / and marianus At
last was strong fighting / so that the cyteseyns slough twenty men of the
earls company. and wounded so many that me couth not tell how many were
wounded / the Earl escaped uneath with one felawe / and came to the king at
gloucestre and meoued the king grievously against Englysshmen / Than goodwyn earl
of kent was sompned to court and y charged that he should with his hooste take
wreche of the wrong that was done to therle / he saw that alyenes were allowed
with the king and would help to save the Cyteseyns / and his country men and
answerde and said that it were reason that the wardeyns of the castle of dover
should be sompned / and if they couthe excuse them self they should be harmeles
/ and else do therles pleasure with her bodies and catel / The king seemed that
Goodwyn set little by his heste / therefore the lords of the land were called
to geder at Gloucetre and specially leofrycus Earl of mercia and syward Earl of
northumberlond for to withstonde Goodwyn Earl of kente / and his eldest son
Suanus and harold also / For goodwyn had gadred a great host at beuersto^ of
his countees of kente of southrey and of westsaxon and suanus of his ^^untees
of Barokshire of Oxenford shire / and of Gloucestre shire / And harold of his
countees of eestsex / of eeste england and of Huntyngton shyre / Than goodwyn
was enpeched for he had gadred so great an host / he answerde and said that it
was do for to cesse the walsshmen / But the walsshmen made the blame turn
ayenste his own head. Than what little accord that ever was procured / there
was assygned a counsayll at london for the same deed / So that Goodwyn and
Harold should come to court all unarmed with twelve men / and no mo that they
should bytake to the king the knights service that was dew to hem in all
england / They said that they might not without weddes and pledgys come to
the counsel of trechours and of gyleful men / And that they might not
without peril and shame pass by the weye with so few naked men / and
unarmed / In the mean time goodwyns knights withdrewe them sum and sum /
for dread of the kings hooste / Then it was openly cried by the kings
cryours that Goodwyn should come to the court in manner as it is said / owther
wide out of England within five days / Therefore goodwyn and his three sons
Swanus and Tosty and gurth sailed by the Island of thorney in to Flaundres to
therle baldwyn / For Suanus had spoused his daughter Iudytha / But harold and
leofwynus sailed out by brystow in to Irlond / Algarus leofrycus son took
and had haraldes count and ruled it nobley and delyuerd it up to harald with
good will / when Herald was comen again and axyd it again when harold was
turned to his faders countees / Therefore king edward in plain parlemente
