outlawed goodwyn and his three sons / And put his own wife Godytha the queen
in to the abbay of warwe^le without worshipe with one maid and no moo / And
so the fader and the sons were outlawed two year fulle / and took prays in
the marches of england and gadred great strength and purposed slyly for to
fight with the king / But lords went between / and so peace was made after
two year / and the queen was brought again / So that wylnotus Goodwyns son
/ and hacun Swanus son were pledgys leyde to wedde for surete of the pees /
Anon king Edward sent hem to keeping to wylliam duc of normandye / During
the outelawynge Duc Wylliam of normandye come with a great multitude in to
England / and had many greet yeftes / and went again in to Normandy / And
Queen Emma the kings mother dyed / and was buried at wynchestre / Also marianus
the Scot the year of his age five and twenty forsook the world and went in
pylgremage and was shoren monk at Coloyn a Cite of Almayn in the Abbay of
Scotts /

Willelmus de Pon / li / 1 and marianus / This year Godwyn and al his sons
were acorded with king edward / out take his eldest son swanus that was sorry
for the death of his Cosyne berinus and went out of flaundres barfoote to
Jerusalem / and went out of Jerusalem to licia and dyed for cold that he had
taken / here after the normans that were the kings cou^seyllours had yeuen him
evil counsel and were exyled / and specially Robert archebisshop of
caunterbury / that had ludder blown his trompe against goodwyn and englisshmen
in that cause / This robert dradde him and would beware of peril * and went
to Rome and came again with lettres of the pope / and dyed in his abbay called
gemmeticum / After him Stygandus was archebisshop / he had left the
bysshopryche of Shyrborn / and took by strength the bisshoprich of wynchestre
/ This man used feyres of holy church things / and was a lewed man / and so
were nygh all the bisshops of England that time / but this was a mighty man by
money and by flateryng / therefore he was never worthy to have the palle fro Rome
though there be great sale that does many maystries / W / de p / li / 2 Than was
openly song in weyes / that he was not worthy a bisshopryche that could use
the brag and the boost of this world / the use of wodenesse^ the courage of
glotony / the array of clothing / the fare of knights / and the gaderynge of
horsemen / and thynk right little of profyt of souls / If me told hem that a
Bishop should be allowed by his holiness and his clergy and not by couetyce of
money they would answer by this meter / Nunc aliud tempus / alij pro tempore
mores / that is now is other time / and other manners used for the time / And so
they planed the sharpness of the doing with lyghtnesse of the answer /
Marianus That time in Irlande a clerk barbosus was a man of great and wonder
Relygyon / so that he held a great scole of clerks of lewdmen and of wenches
/ and forshaar the wenches in the same sect and manner of his scolers / he was
put out of Irlond Willelmus de pontificibus libro secundo / About that time
dyed saint Alfwold the last Bishop of Shirborn / he was first monk at
wynchestre / and then he was made Bishop / He used breed and water among
all the greet festes / that were made in England after the coming of the
danes / This man was devout at all points to our lady and saint Cuthbert /
After his death no man might grieve his see / but he were punysshed / For he
should be so fered with blac images in his sleep that he should starte / Also on
a time was stryf between him and goodwyn the earl and might not be alayed at
day of acorde that was set / Than the bishop was wroth and said in his
going awey / by saint mary my lady he shall fare right evil / and after that
hour goodwyn had never rest of gnawyng of his bowels till he hadd the bisshops
blessyng / On a time this bishop went to Durham and he did a deed that seemed
of great hardynesse / For he turned awey the helyng of the body and spoke to
saint Cuthbert as it were to his own friend / and leyd there the yefte of love
/ and went forth his wey

Capitulum 25
AFter leo the second vyctor was pope two year and six months / He made a
synod at florence in ytalye / and set a down many Bisshops for Symonye and
fornycacion / Marianus / This year Syward the noble duc of northumberlond by
commandment of king Edward bare down Scotland with an host of horsemen and
with great gadrynge and chaced the king and took malcolyn the king of Combres
sons and made him king of Scotland / but in that bataylle Sywardes son was
slain / when his fader wyste that he was deed of a wound that he had
received before in his body / and not behind / though the fader was sorry /
for the sons death / yet he was glad that his son was so herty and so
hardy / That year dyed Wulsius bishop of lychefeld and leofwynus abbot of
Couentre was Bishop after him / Also that year at wyndsor the morrow after
Eester day / earl goodwyn sat at kings board / and it happed that one of
the childer that served the king came in with the kings cup and stombled with
his one foot and kept him self with that other / so that he shed naught of the
drink / Goodwyn saw that and lough and said / now that one brother has
helped that other / Anon the king answerde thereto and said / So my brother
Aluredus would have helped me / ner goodwyn had be / the earl understood there by
that he had spoken more than enough / and understood the king meaned the
bytraynge of his brother / And said to the king Sir as I see it is told to the
/ that I should be about to slay thy brother and to bytraye the / so mot I
sauely swolowe this morsel that I hold in my hand. as I am gyliles of such
deeds / And he was choked anon / At kyngys commandment harold drough him
fro under the board and he was buried at wynchestre / R / But Marianus says /
that godwyn sat at te mete by the king at wynchestre and was suddenly take with
a sickness on eester monday / and dyed the thursday in the eester weke / than
godwyns Erldome was yeuen to harold / And haraldes Erldome to Algarus the son
of Earl leofrycus / This year king edward sent aldredus bishop of wircetre to
the second henry the emperor / prayeng that he would send lettres to hungary and
send thens in to England his Cosynne Edward the sone of Edmond Irensyde / The
king had ordained to make him his heyr in england / but the thyrdde year
after he come in to england and dyede at london / long time rather than the
king / This Edward was the fader of margaret queen of Scotland / and of Edgar
adelyng / But margret had by malcolyn / Dauyd the king of Scotland and molde
the queen of of England / Marianus / This year king edward outlawed Algarus the
son of leofrycus withouten gylte / Anon he was prayed and associate to
gryffyn king of wales and destroyed the prouynce of herford and took herford*
and set the mynster a fire and slough seven chanons / But earl harald pursued
hem that fled and restored herford again and walled it about / and made her
pees that were outlawed with the king / Item / Mar / Also this year Syward the
noble duc of northumberlond dyed at york on the flyx and was buried in the
mynster galmaicho that he had build / but er he dyed he made arm him / and
sat vpryght and said / thus it seems a knight for to dye and not lyggynge
faint as an Ox / And for his son waltyf was young and lay in his cradel /
his Erldome was yeuen to Tosty heraldes brother that was theraboute ten year /
Item / Mar / and W / Also that year herman of Flaundres that was sometime king
Edwardes priest / and than bishop of wylton and Ramesbury was at disease for
defaute of catayll and prayed the king and had it almost granted for to ordeyne
his see in the abbay of malmesbury / but the lords of the land would not
assente / Therefore herman was wroth and left the bisshopryche and went over see
and took monks habytes at saint Bertines and lived so three year and Aldredus
bishop of wyrcetre ruled herma^s bisshoprich in the men^ time / But as it
fallyth often that they that take relygyon in such hasty and sudden reeses have
no stydfast will and devotion / For it withdraws and slaketh at last /
After three year herman come in to england again / The man that was wont al
his life time to have ^ykyng service and plesynge at his will thought full heavy
and elenge to leave it in his age / Also it come to his ere that Goodwyn was
deed / that him had wythstande / And also that the Bishop of Shirborn was
deed and he had long time thought to oone and join that bisshopryche to his
own by old promysses of the queen / He held long time these Bysshopryc^es so
joined with three countrees that longed thereto unto the nynth year of wyliam
conqueror / when he passed from Shyrborn to Salesbury / Willelmus de regibus
Also that year the king was at / a feste and Harold and Tosty pleyed before him
/ and harold drough his brother by the heeres / harder than game would and threw
him to the ground and had weryed him with his hands ne he had be the rather
delyuerd out of his claws / when the king saw that he said that great
stryf should be after between tho twey brethren / and that one of hem should
slay that other / Earl Goodwyns first wife was king Canutus sister / on her
Goodwyn gate on a sone that rode on an horse unwisely / and spurred him and the
horse threw him in to Temse / and so he was dreynt / The mother was smyten with
lyghtnynge and dyed / and it was no wonder for s^e took fair wenches and set
hem to hoerdom for she would gadre the more riches / After her death Goodwyn
wedded another wife and bygate on her syx sons / Suanns / harold / Tostius /
Wilynotus / Surth and loofrycus / how they spedde / it is wret^n before and
after in this Cronyk / Willelmus de Regibus libro secundo / About this time a
woman at barcley used evil crafts and was at a fest on a day / Than a crow
that she had lykyngly fed and norysshed creked ludder than he was wont The
wom n herd that and the knyf fill down of her hand / and her face wex / al
pale / than she byganne te sygh and groan and said this day is my solow comen
to the last sorrow / When that was said came in a messagyer that said to the
woman that her son was deed and al her meyny / leyde and fallen and deed also
/ The woman lay seek anon / and sent for her chylder that she had a live a
monk and a Nonne / when the monk and the nonne were comen she spak to hem
in this manner / I am a woman that have used evil craft and evil living / In
vein I hoped to be saved by your bedes and prayers / but now I pray you that
ye wol releue my torments and pains / for of the soul the dome is yeuen / On
caas ye may keep my body / if it be sewed in hertes leder / lay it in a trowh
of stone and heled it with a lydde of leed fast bound / and barred with yren
/ and byndeth it fast with three yren cheynes / make ye forty sing psalms by
night and as many masses by days. And if I lie so three nyghtes / the fourth
day burye the body in earth / But al for naught / for twey the first nyghtes
while the psalms were in syngyng fendes brake up the doors / and twey the
vttermest cheynes and that wonder lightly / The third night about cocks
crowyng the place al to shoke and one with a grysely face that was high of
stature brake up the doors / and heete the body that it should arise / I may
not said the body for strong bands / thou shall be unbound said he / but to
thine own harm / and anon all that let was to broken and he took her out
of the church / and set her upon a blac horse that neyhed before the doors
and so she went awey with loud cries that were herd four mile thennes /
Though this be wonderful / who that has read the fourth book af Gregoryes
dyalog shall not deem that it might not be trowed / Therefore it is wreton that
fendes cast out a wicked man that was buried in a church / and so it ferd of
Charles marcellus as it is said (...)

Capitulum 26
THe thyrdde henry the second henryes son reigned among Duche men about fyfty
year / Sometime he dystourbed holy church / ayenste pope Hyllebrande / and he
would if he might have put in another pope / but he was ceesed and went to
the holy land with the Dukes Godefr^de / and Beamund as it shall be said Inner
more / After Victor the nynth stephen Abbot of mount Cassyn was pope eyghte
months / he came in by strength and resygned the Papacye afterward /
Agelrycus Bishop of Durham left his own bisshopryche / by his own good
will / and went in to thabbaye of bourgh / there he was norysshed and lived /
xij / year in peace and quyete / His brother Agelwyn was bishop after him / Mar
/ Also this year the noble earl leofrycus the son of leoswynus duc of mercia
dyed in his own town Bromley the last day of Nouembre / and was buried at
Couentre in thabbay that he had bylde / Sometime by counseyl of god and of his
own wife God gyna / that worshipped much our lady. he amended and made rich
thabbayes of leonen besides herford / of wenlok / of wyrcetre / and of euesham
/ and of twey chirches of chestre / one of saint johan and another of saint
werburgh / while he was on live his wit and his redynes stood in greet stead
to the land of Englysshmen / R Also at abusy prayer of his wife he made his
town of couentre fre of al manner toll / out take the toll of horses / For to
have that fredome granted his wife godgyna the countess rode naked through the
myddel of the town in a morning not keueryd / but with her own here / After
the death of leofrycus his son algarus had therldome of mercia / but the same
year he was conuycte of treason and outlawed / But of gryffyn king of wales he
was received as he had been before and reconcyled / W / de re / A young Cyteseyn
of Rome lucianus by his name a rich man of cataylle and of gold a man of great
kynne / He wedded a wife Eugenya / because thereof he made a great feast and
went in to the field after mete with other men to dyscharge his stomak / And
this new wedded man for he would play at balle / did his spousyng ring on
the finger of an image / that was there fast by / And when he had played and
was hoote / he drough him first out of the game / and went to fette ageyn his
ryng / but he found the images ring y^lyght in to the palm of the hand /
Then he bygan to wrynge and wrast long time / but he couth not wreste of the
ryng nowther wreth ne break / nowther right up the finger / than he went
stylly aweye for his felawes should not wit thereof lest they would scorn him /
while he were there / owther take awey the ring when he were thennes /
Then he came thither with his servants when it was derk night and found the
finger even straight and the ryng awey and had great wonder / when it was
time he araid him to bed with his wife and felt a dym thing and sad walowe
between him and his wife / And that spoke to him and said. lie by me / and dele
with me* / For thou have spoused me this day / I am the Goddess Venus /
Then he was soore afered / and woke all the night / And so it ferde as it
were every night / Then his wife pleyned and charged him that he should warn
his fader and his mother / And so he did / Then his fader and his mother
warned pal^mbus the priest of the suburbs that was the grettest Nygromancer
that was that time a live / he received greet mede / and yaue the young man a
letter that he should take to him that he met last at night coming against him
with a chaar in the metyng of twey weyes / the young man stood in the metyng of
twey weyes at night and saw a woman sytte on a mule arrayed as a strompet /
and her here abroad with a chaplet of gold / on her head and a rod of gold in
her hand / Then he took this letter to him that came last rydyng / when the
letter was read the principale fend hafe up both hands to heaven and said /
Almighty god how long shall the wickedness of palumbes the priest dure / Anon
his knights come to venus to have the ring / but she wrenched and blenched
and stroof long time / But at last the knights wrest of her the ryng and
took it to the young man ayene and so he had his will and Joy of his love /
that he had long desired / but palumbus herd the fend cry of him in to
heaven and kytte of his own lymmes and knowleched al his tres^aas to the pope
in presence and heryng of the people / Marianus Aldredus bishop of wyrcetre
made saint wulstan pryour of wyrceter by leave of the king / and yaue the
bisshopryche of wylton to herman that was comen ayene from beyond see / and
aldredus went over see / and forth by hungary on pylgremage to Ierl^m Me
redyth of no bishop of england that so did before that time / At Coloyn in
Almayne twey abbeyes of Scotts were burnt with their own fire / One patronus
a monk that was there closed warned hem of that brennyng long time before /
But when the fire was comen / he would out in no manner wise / but there he
was burnt for love of martyrdom / Treuisa. / In that doing patronus the monk
seemed a lewd ghost that couth not know the cause and circumstances of very
martirdo^ For there is no very martyrdom / but it be for mayntenynge of
troth / owther for the feyth and wythstandyng of wrong and of sin / but god
grant if it be his will / that patronus be not dampened for his blind
devotion / Than it follows in thystorye / About that time in the prouynce of
Apulea was found an image of marble with an heed of brass / and had a
garland / in which garland it was wryton / The first day of maij at son
rysyng / I shall have an heed of gold / A Sarasyn that the duc of the
longobardes had taken prysonner understood what it meaned and come the first
day of maij / and took head of the shadow of the image in length and in bread
/ and found under the shadow wonder greet tresoure / and paid for his
raunsonne / Willelmus de Regibus /

Capitulum 27
When Benet was putt out / the second nycolaus was pope about two year / In
his time holy church in France was gretely destroyed by berengarius
Archedeken of Toreyn / he said that the ooste in the altar is not very
crystes body / but it is a figure thereof / Ayenste him the pope made a
counseylle at versel in ytaly of an honderd bisshops and thirtene / in the
which counsayll berengarius withsayde his error as it is said in decrees de
consecracione diui / 2^ Ego berengarius / But after the popes death his heresy
byganne ef^e to spring / Than hyltebrandus the pope determined and yaue the
dome against his fauctours / To his errors answered lanfrank^ pryour of becceus
in his book called liber sintillarum / And specially wymund that was a monk
of normandye / and afterward bishop of Auersan in Apulya / that was tho the
most proufyte / So that Berengarius amended his life at last / so that
sum men held him an holy saint / he expowned the Apocalypse and used mekenes
and alms deed and voyded the syghte of women / and used simple mete and cloth
/ and that by thappostles loore / Hyldebertus Bishop of Cenonia in his versus
praised him most in this manner / Of him now wondering / shall wondre the world
evermore This berengarius that dyed / shall dye no more / And than thus After
death with him / life bid I in even rest / No better be my lot / I pray than
is his lot / Loo here me may see / how the noble Bishop passyd in manner of
praysyng / But the Rethoryke with his fair speech brekyth out oftyme in that
manner / therefore the poet says / Rich speech shedyth out often well fair
reed flowers But among all this take heed / that though berengarius amended
his sentence. yet he might not amend all that he had apeyred with his loore in
diverse lands / Such it is to a peyr other men by word owther by evil ensample
that when his own sin is awey yet noyeth it and greueth other men's
sins / Me says that the noble bishop of Carnotens / Fulbertus spak there of
in his latter sickness / For when he saw Berengarius come to him among
other men / Does him awey said the Bishop for I see a fend follow him that
apeyreth the eyer all about / Also this Berengarius when he dyed on a
twellifth day / had mind how many wretches he apeyred / by his evil loore
when he was a young man / And said / this day I hope that Christ wol show
him to me / in the day of his own showing / outher for my penance toward
bliss / owther for other that I have apeyred by mine evil loore toward pain /
About this time Mananus the scot was closed in the abbay Fuldence and was
there ten year / when kynsius Archebisshop of york was deed / Aldredus bishop
of wyrcetre was archebisshop after him / and went t^ Rome with Tostius Earl of
northumberlond for to receive the palle / but he was found blame worthy in his
answer / and he was pryued of al manner worship / and as he went homeward he
was robbed of all that he had / Therefore tostius therle went ageyn to Rome and
entreated so the pope by skylles that he alleged / that the pope yaue
Aldredus the Archebisshopryche / Tostius said that nations of fer lands should
set right little by the popes cu^s / while it was so scorned of thieves that
dwelled there nygh. therefore owther aldredus should have his catayll restored /
owther it would seem that he was robbed by fraud of the pope / Also the king
of england shall here thereof and withdraw the tribute of saint peter / It is
evil do said therle that Aldredus shall goo home worshiples and be robbed of all that he had / And so Aldredus had the pall and went in to england and made
wulstan the pryour bishop of / wyrcetre / No man would gladly of Stygandus the
archebisshop of caunterbury receive the yefte of bisshopryche nowther wiliam
conqueror when he was come would receive the blessyng of him / After nycol
the second Alysaunder was pope enleuen year and was chosen by the Cardynals /
and defended him manly ayenste one Candulus tha^ the ytalyens had chosen pope /
They said that no man should be chosen pope but if he were of the paradys of
ytaly born / Herald duc of westsaxon by commandment of king Edward went in
to wales with few horsemen after crystemasse and set king gryffyns palace on
fire / at Ruthlan and his ships also / But Gryffyn fled and escaped / After
that about the Rogacion time he went about Brystow with a great naueye / and
sailed nyghe al about wales and his brother Tostius Earl of northumberland
met him with an hooste of horsemen and destroyed so the countrees of wales /
that the walsshmen delyuerd pledgys and paid trybute as they were wont / and
outlawed and put out her king gryffyn and slough him at last about the
fyfth day of August / and sent his heed to harold therle / After that king
edward granted the land of wales to Gryffyns twey brethren that swear to him
feute / Henricus libro septimo / This year harold went toward normandy to
speak with his brother wylynotus and with his broders son hacun / that were in
pledge with duc wyliam^ But he was driven with tempeste in to the prouynce of
ponntyf / The duc of that land took him / and sent him to duc wiliam / Me
says that there harold er he might escape swear that he would wedde duc wiliams
daughter and that he should keep for him England when king Edward were deed /
And so he had his neuewe with him and came in to england ageyn / R / But his
brother wylynotus left in duc wyliams ward alwey yet while he reigned / Henricus
vbi supra / Also that year in king edwardes co^^t at^ wyndsor Tostius was
agreued and wroth and went thens to herford / there Harold had arayd a feste
for the king / there Tostius to hakked his brother servants and souced her
lymmes / and sent word to the king that if he would come to his feste he should
have salt mete ynow / The northumbres herd thereof and put out her duc
Tostius and slough his servants also and they brake his tresory and made him
flee in to Flaundres / Willelmus de Regibus / But the king herd thereof and
sent harold to take wreche of the wrong that was of his brother / they alleyed
that they were freely born and freely nourysshed / and that they might not suffer
the cruelnes of dukes / Also that they had learned of her soueraynes / to
mayntene fredome owther else take the death / Also that they should lightly be
ladde by an esy duc / Then harold seemed that it were more wisdom to favor
the country / than to take heed to the syngler prouffyte of his brother / and
sent that his host should come ayene / and went to the king and procured that
malcherus should be her earl / All this grieved Tostius / and therefore he went
in to flaundres with his wife and his childer and was there unto the kings death
/

Capitulum 28
King edward sat at mete at westmynster on an Eesterday And while other men
ete besyly / he fill in a thought and lough while other men ete / Me axyd him
in chamber after mete what him ayled so to laugh / For seven slepers said he
in mount Selyon besides ephesum in the less asia had there slept two honderd
year on the right side and turned hem on the lift side in my laughyng time /
and they shall so lygge on the lift side three score year and fourtene / That
time shall come among mankind that hard saw that Christ menaceth in the
Gospel / Men shall arise ayenste men and so forth / For the Sarasyns shall arise
against christian men and christian men against Sarasyns / And also the king told
how the seven slepers weren arrayed / and so tellyth none other storye / Anon
the kings mynystres sent to nycete the emperor of Constantinople to espy the
soth of this saw / he received them goodly / and sent forther to the Bishop
of ephesye. that he should show the array of the seven slepers to the messagers
of England / And so it was found as the king had said / And sone after the
Sarasyns and turks arysen and occupied Siria / the less Asia and Jerusalem /
The thyrdde Henry the emperor dyed sone after / and henry king of France was
poisoned and dyed / Seven days before maij a sterre with a bright blasyng
crest was seen in all the world wide / and was so seen seven days continuelly /
Olyuer monk of malmesbury grett that sterre / and spak thereto in this manner /
Thou art comen now Thou art come doole and sorrow / to well many moders / It is
long sith I see the / but now I see the more dredeful and grysely / Thou
menacest destroyenge of this country / This Olyuer was tho a c^nnynge man of
lettrure. and a man of greet age / but in his yongthe by great hardynes / he
founded for to fl^e as a byrd with whynges I not by what manner craft he
fethred his fete / and his hands for he would flee in dedalus wise / and so he
took a fable instead of a sothe saw / and so he stood on an hye toure and
took the wind and flough the space of a furlonge and more / But he was aferd
of the great strength of the wind and of the whyrle wind / and on caas of
his own folly deed / and fill down so that he was lame in his thyes term of his
life / Also this year when Childermas day was hallowed at westmynstre king
Edward began to be seek in his last sickness / he saw a syghte and told it
to hem that stood about him / Twey men of Relygyon said the king come to me /
that I knew sometime in normandy and sayden that god hem had sent to warn me
hereof / For the rather dukes bisshops and abbotes of England be not gods
servants but the deuyls / god has taken this kingdom in to the enemies hand
for a twelve months and a day / and fendes shall walk and hurl about in all
this land / I prayed and by sought that they must by my warnyng do penance /
and be delyuerd by ensample of the men of nynyue / Nay said they for nowther
shall be / for these men shall not do worthy penance / nowther god shall have
mercy of hem / Than I said / when may be hope and trust of foryeuenes / they
answered and said / when a grene tree is hewn down / and a party thereof
kytte from the stok / and leyde three teme length fro the stok / There stood tho
Stygandus the Archebisshop and said that the old man raued and doted as old
men do / and was out of his wit and spak folly and vanyte / But afterward
England felt the soth and the truth of his prophecye / when it was in
subjection and destroyed with alyens and men of strange lands / Than king
Edward dyed at westmestre on a twellyfth even / when he had reigned three
and twenty year / and seven months / and was buried at westmynstre / R /
Aluredus of Ryual deseryued clearly king Edwardes life / and sent it to
laurence abbot of westmynster / And he sent that life that was so descryued
forth to the second henry / Willelmus de Regibus vbi supra / Anon Harold
occupied the kingdom and held it about nine months But sum intended to
make Edgar Adelyng king / Edgar Adelynge was the son of Edward the which
Edward was the son of edmond Irensyde / But for the child was insuffysaunt
to so great charge / Earl harold that was feller of wit Rycher in the purs /
and strenger of knights / occupied the kingdom by an ungracious hap / R.
But marianus says that king edward ordained before his death that Harold should
be king after him and that the lords made him king anon / Item Marianus /
This was sacred of Aldredus the Archebisshop of york / and byganne to destroy
evil laws and to make good laws and ryghtfull to defend holy church / To
worshipe good men / to punysshe evil doers and to save and to defend the
land But his brother Tostius herd thereof. and that he was king / and came with
syxty ships out of flaundres / and took paymentis and trybute of the isle of
wight / and took prays in kente on the sea costs / but he dradde the arraye
of his brother harold / and went by the sea in to lyndeseye / and burnt there
towns and slough men til that he was driven thens by edwyn and Morkar dukes of
mercia and of northumberlonde / Than he went to malcolyn king of Scotland and
was with him all the somer time / In the mean time the king of the norganes /
harold harfage Olauus brother came with three honderd ships in to the mouth of
the River Tyne / then Tostius came to him with his strength as they were
acorded before / King harold was warned thereof / and ordained thither great
strength / but er he was come^ / the twey brethren that we spoke of rather
Edwyn and morkar had stalworthly foughten and were overcome at last / and
there were delyuerd pl^dgys on either side an honderd and fyfty / After this the
fyfth day king harold came to stemesford bridge and had a strong battle and
hard fyghtyng / but he slough the king of norganes and his own brother Tostius
/ but he made Olauus the kings brother of norganes and paul duc of the ilondes
Orcades / swear to him and took pledgys of hem and let hem goo hoome again /
but one of the norganes bare him so there / that he is worthy to have a name
for evermore / For he stood al one upon the bridge of Stemesford and slough moo
than forty englysshmen with his own axe and let the passage of all the
english hooste / till it was none of the day / till an Englissh man took a
boot and came under the bridge and stykked the norgan thur^h an hoole with his
spear / For that hap harold was proud / and would not part with his knights
the prays that were taken there / therefore many of the lords and of the
comonte were wroth and a grieved and forsook him / when he went to the
battle of hastyng against wylliam / Willelmus de Regibus libro secundo

Capitulum 29
When harold was set up in the kingdom and thought not on the couenauntes
that were made between him and wylliam / he held him self dyscharged of the
oath. for wylliams daughter that he had spoused was deed within age of wedlok /
And also for wylliam was occupied with werres in Islands that were nyghe him /
But william warned him of covenant broken / and meddled menaces with prayers /
Harold said that a nyce folly covenant should not be holden / and namly the
byhest of other men's kingdom without comune assente of all the Senators /
There a lewd oath should be broke namely sith it was compellyd to be sworen for
need in a nedeful time / In the mean time wylliam arrayed all that neded for the
journey and gate the assente of the lords of his land / and purchaced favor
of Alysaunder the pope with a baner that was to him sent / these were the
causes why duc william axed and challenged England against harald / the death of
Aluredus that was his cosyn the sone of emma on aluredus he had procured his
death / the second the e^ylyng of Robert Archebisshop of Caunterbury^ The
thyrdde cause for king edward had promised duc wiliam that he should be king
after him if he dyed without childer / and harold was sworn to fulfill that
commandment / Henricus libro sexto / The lords of normandye counseyled among
hem self what were best to do of this iourneye / and wylliam that was the
dukes sewer the son of osbert counsayled to leave and forsake the journey both
for scarcete of fyghtyng men / and for strength / hardynesse and stiernesse
and cruelte of his enemies / the other lords were glad hereof and put her
answer and her words upon this wylliams mouth / and as he would say / when he
come before the duc / he said that he was ready to the iourneye / and all the
other lords / than might not the lords withdraw hem for shame / Willelmus de
Regibus libro tercio / When duc William and his men were long tarried in saint
waleryes hauene^ for the wind was against hem / the people grutched and said
that it was a wod^nes to challenge by strength other men's land / and namely
while god stroof against hem / and god must grant hem good wind / if they
should seyle / Duc william made bring out saint waleryus holy body and set
him there out for to have wind / Anon lykyng wind filled the seyles / than
duc william came toward England after mychelmasse day / and landed at hastynge
in a place called Peuenesey / In his going out of his ship / he slode with
his one foot and styked in the sand / and the knight that was next cried to
him anon / and said / now Sir Earl / thou hold England / thou shall right
newely be king / than he charged that they should take no prays and said that
he must spare things that should be his own / and he left so fyften days /
harald came from the werre of the norganes / and herd tidings hereof / and hyed
well fast / and had but few knight^s about him for he had lost many stalworth
men in the rather bataylle / and he had not sent for more help / and though he
had men were wroth and would have withdraw hem for they should have no prays
at battle of norganes / but harold sent forth espyes to awayte and see the
nombre and the strength of his enemies / duc wylliam took these espyes and
led hem about his tents and pauylons and fed hem ryally and sent hem to
Harold again / than they told to harold tidings / and said that all that were
in duc williams host / were priests for they had both the chekes and both
the lyppes shaven / Englysshmen used that time the here of her ouerlyppes
shed and not shore / Nay said harald they be no priests but they be strong
knights / Than said gurth heraldes youngest brother / why wolt thou vnwar fight
with so many orped men / we swear him never none oath / Than is it better that
thou that art sworn to him withdraw the for a time and let us that be not
sworn fight for the countray / and if we have the maystrye well it be / and if
we be overcome the cause and the querele is sauf to the / yet duc william sent
a monk to Harold and proffered him three weyes / owther that he should leave the
kingdom o wther hold the kingdom of duc william / and regne under him owther
they tweyne should fight either with other in that quarele in syghte of both
the hoostes / namely while king Edward was deed that had granted him
england if he dyed without heyr / and by cou^seylle and assente of Stygandus
tharchebisshop and of therles goodwyn and Syward / In token thereof Goodwyns
son and his neuewe were sent to duc william / But Harolde would not assente
to the monks message / but said the cause should be dereyned by dynte of
sword and prayde god only that he should deem between them tweyne / Than the
hoostes of either side came to the place of the bataylle on saint Calyxt the
pope the fourtenth day of October on a saturday in the place where thabbaye of
bataylle is build / as we be informed / the night before the bataylle
Englysshemen yafe hem to song and to drynk and waked al night / Erly on the
morrow foot men with her axes made a greet strength of sheldes. and set hem
to geder and had the maystrye. ne had be that the normans feyned to flee /
king Harold stood on his fete by his baner with his twey brethren. That baner
was afterward sent to the pope / The normans the night before the bataylle
shrofe hem of their sins and were houseld erly in the morning / Footmen and
archers were set in the bataylle and than knights with wings on either side
/ Duc william comforted his men to the battle and was waare that his haberion
was turned in and out and amended that hap^e with a bourde and said the
strength of an erldome shall turn in to a kingdom / But er that the Shiltrons
come to geders one of the normans called Taylefer cast his swerd and play^d
before the hoostes and slough a banyour of Englysshmen that came against him and
did efte the same of another / Also he slough the thyrdd and was slain him
self / Then anon the Shyltrons smote to geders with Roulandes song that was
bygonne on the normans side / The bataylle endured from vndern of the day to
euensong time / And neither party would wythdrawe / but the dukes archers had
their forth / than the duc made a token to his men that they should feyne to
flee / and by that wyle engl^sshmen were begyled and dysarayed hem as it were
to pursue and so to reese on her enemies / but when englysshmen were so out
of array / the normans arrayed hem efte / and turned again vp^on the english
men that were out of array and chaced hem on every side / At last harold was
smyten with an arowe and lost his one eye / and was hurt on the brain and
fill down in that place / And one of the knights smote him in the thyghe
while he lay there / And therefore wylliam put that knight out of cheualrye /
for he had done an uncunning deed / That day lost wyllia^ three the best horses
that he had / and were stykked under him / but he bare him so that no blood
came out of his body / when the vyctorye was done wylliam buried his men that
were slain / and granted his enemies to do the same / who that would and
sent haraldes body to haraldes mother without any mede as she had prayed and
she buried him at waltham in thabbay of chanons that harold had founded / R /
But gyraldus Cambrensis in his book called Itinerarius would mean that harold
had many wounds and lost his lift eye with the stroke of an arowe / and was
overcome and escaped to the countray of Chestre^ and lived there hoolyly as me
troweth an Ankers life in saint James selle fast by saint john's church / and
made a gracious end / And that was known by his last confession and the
commune fame acordeth in that cite to that saw / Also Aluredus Ryuallensys in
saint edwardes life / ca / 26 / in the end there he says that Harold either
dyed wretchedly owther he escaped and was preserved to do worthy penance / R
/ Thanwhan king haraldes death was known therles of northumberlonde and of
mercia / Edwyn and marcarus that had withdrawn hem self from harold for
streytnesse of places. owther more verily for wrath that the prays were not
deled at bataylle of norganes / they come to london and and took her sister
Agytha haraldes wife and sent her to Chestre And they and aldredus
tharchebisshop of york and the londoners promised that they would make edgar
adelyng king and fight for him / but for the dread of wylliam encreaced / they
withdrew hem and fulfilled not that they had promised / And all this with other
noble me^ come to wylliam and yafe him pledgys / and swear him fewte and did
him surete

Explicit liber sextus
Incipit Liber septimus
Capitulum primum
When william came to london and was crowned at westmynstre of aldredus
archebisshop of york and wyded stygandus archebisshop of Caunterbury / and was
y crowned in a mydwynter day / that fill that ^ere on a monday / W / de / pon /
But the next lent thereafter ^e went in to normandy / and left his brother
Bishop of bayon to keep england / and had with hym^ the gentilmen / and namely
the earls edwyn and markarus and edgard adelyng / and most specially stygandus
tharchebisshop / though he wythstode in that with all that he might / he ladde
him with him / as it were for to do him worship / but his mening was specially
for no treson should be done in his absence in england by auctoryte of
stygandus Among all other it is hard for to tell / how greet worship he
did to stygandus for he would arise and come against him with procession and
that with great boost and array / but all that was closed and hyd in that doing
/ come out afterward clear enough / when the popes legate come in to england /
and made a counseyll by thasse^t of the king / and stygandus was deposed and
set a down / and prayed besyly the king of his grace / the king excused him
self with fair words as he couthe well enough / and said that he might not
do ayenste the popes heste / And so he held stygandus in boondes at
wynchestre term of his life / Alfr / Herafter against winter king will^iam came
in to england and put a trybute upon english men gretter than they might
bear / and bes^eged excetre that was rebelle against him and brake the cite /
Gytha the countess that was sometime goodwyns wife forsook the cite and sailed
in to flau^dres W / d re / li / 3 / In this syege the town wall fylle down as
it were for the nones / and so the enemies come in for one of the cyteseyns
stood upon the wall and did down his breche and defowled the eyer with the
foul noise of his neither end / Also that year the lords of northu^berlond
drad the cruelnes of william and took with them edgar adelyng and his mother
agath and his twey systres margret and crystia^ and sailed to malcolyn king of
scotland / R / But somme^ wol mean that this edgar sygh that the things of
englysshme^ were distourbed in euy side / and took a ship and cast for to sail
with his mother and his twey systres in to his own country there he was y bore
/ But there come great tempest and drofe him in to Scotland / By occasion
thereof it was that malcolyn king of Scotland wedde edgars sister margret / and
gate on her six sons and twey doughtes / three of his sons were kings
after the fader / Edgar Alysaunder and david / Mold malcolyns daughter was
married to the first henry king of England / of him come mold themperyce / the
other daughter mary was married to eustas earl of ^oloyne / of her come mold /
that was married to king steven / Also that year king william made a strong
castle at snotyngham that now is called notyngha^ and another at lyncoln and
tweyne at york / Also that year mold the queen came out of normandy in to
england and was crowned of aldredus / harald and Canutus the sons of suanus
king of denmarche come a land in the mouth of humber with two honderd ships
/ Edgar adelyng yaf him self to hem / Aldredus the archebisshop was so soory
for her coming that he deyde for sorrow the / xj / day of September / The eight
day thereafter the normans that kept castles dradde / lest the houses of the
subarbes should help the danes to fylle the dyches / and therefore they set hem
a fire / but the light aroos to hye / and burnt the cite of york / with the
mynster of saint peter / But er the fire were done came the strength of the
danes and slough by assente of the cyteseyns more than three thousand normans /
Than king wylliam was wroth and destroyde so that prouynce that for great
honger men ete horses flessh / hou^des flessh / cattes flessh / and man's
flesh / Also that land that lies between york and durham was nine year
without tylyer and wonyer / out take only saint Ioones land of beuley. for there
fill a wreche upon one of the kings knights for his horse neck was to broke
and his face turned bacword / Also that time was brent saint bedas abbay that
was in girmu^ upon the brynk of the river wyre / That year malcolyn destroyed
so northu^berlond that he slew all the old me^ and feeble / and made the strong
boonde for reverence / so that uneath any was hows in scotland without an
english boonde man other woman / king william by counsayll of some me^ made
search all the abbayes of england and took all the money in to his own tresour
/ W / d / p / li / 1 / Sone there after in the vtas of ester was made a
counseyll at wynchestre by ass^nt of the second pope alysander / there were twey
cardynals present / In that counseyll stygandus tharchebisshop was degraded for
three skylles / first by cause he had holden wrongfully the bisshopriche of
wynchestre and the Archebisshopriche of Caunterbury while Robert the
Archebisshoppe was a live / and used the pal that was there left without leave
of the court of Rome / For he had received the pal of pope benette that was
acursyd of the church of Rome / And though stygandus sought besyly fre^dshippe
of the king the king excused him self swetely as he well couthe by the popes
commandment and cast stygandus in to bonds at wynchestre to his lives end
/ and yaue him every day a little what of enchetes / to live by / Stygandus was
kyndely so hard that he would take right naught of his own / and swore by at
halowen that he had not a penny / but that oath was preued untrue by a little
key that henge about his neck / when he was deed / For by that keye was
found great riches in many places under earth / Also in that counseyll were
set down many bisshops and abbotes / namely by procuring of king wylliam
for he would bring in normans in their stead / Sum men trowyd that he did so
for he would be the more seker of the kingdom / Also in that counseyl saint
wulstan bishop of wyrcetre axyd besyly sum possessions of his bisshopryche
that were with hold by Aldredus Archebisshop of york and y fall in to the
kings hondes after aldredus death / But for the church of york was dombe that
time / for the sea was void / It was demed that that cause should be stylle and
not y touched at that time / herafter at wyndsor in a whitsonday king william
yaf tharchebisshoprich of york unto thomas chanon of baiocens / Wd / p / li /
1 / Herafter the king had lanfrank abbot of cadomenence out of normandy / this
lanfrank was of the nation of ytaly and was most connyng of holy wryt and of
syngler lettrure and most ready in gouernyng of things / In our lady day the
assumpcion the king made him archebisshop of caunterbury / R / Of his thewes
and of his noble deeds it is wreton Innermo^e / about his death time / W / d / p
/ li / 1 / Thomas that was y chose archebisshop of york^ came to this lanfrank
for to be sacred as the usage would. lanfrank axyd of him an oath and his
profession y write of his obedyence / Thomas answered and said / that he would
never do that but if he herd there for auctoryte y write / other skillful reasons
and byndyng^ by the which it were know that he should so do without any
preiudyce of his chirch / he said so more for lewdnes of wit than of rebelnes
/ and pride of heart / as he that was a new man and begyled by flateryng words
/ and knew not the custom and vsages of england And lanfrank declared and
preued resonably / that his axynge was reasonable and ryghtful / but yet thomas
would not assente but wthsayde hit and went his weye vnsacred / the king herd
thereof and was wroth and trowyd that lanfrank would have great things
wrongfully / and he trusted more in his conning / than in good feyth and
reason / But he answered thereto in presence of the king / and esed the kyngys
heart / therefore by commandment of the king / thomas was compellyd for to come
again / and came again and wrote his profession of obedyence and rad it / In
that profession he byhete without any condition that he should be obedyente in all that longs to the worship of god and Christian feyth / and so he was sacred
and went forth his weye Not long thereafter lanfrank axyd and took profession
of all the bisshops of england that were sacred of other men before hond

Capitulum secundum
THe Earls of mercia / of northumberlonde edwyn and Markar went pryuely out
of the court / For king william had cast to put hem in bonds / And so they
were rebel somewhat of time / but it stood hem but little instead / edwyn went
toward the king of Scotland / and was slain in the wey of his men / But markar
and Egylwyn Bishop of durham went in to the isle of Ely / there the king
stopped the out going in the eest side / and made a bridge of twey mile in the
west side / Than they were aferd that were closed withynne / and yield hem to
the king / And the king sent the Bishop to the Abbay of Abyndon to be there
in ward / there this Bishop deyde for honger / for he would not ete for sorrow
/ Willelmus de pontificibus libro tercio / Walkerus of lotharynge was bishop
after him / And Edytha that had be king edwardes wife saw him brought to
wynchestre for to be sacred and said here we have a fair martyr By
coniecturynge of the cruel men of northumberlonde she was meoued to tell what
should afterward byfall she saw him whytely of here / rody of face / and huge
of body and of stature / W / de p / li / 4 / This year deyde walter bishop of
herforde / of him it is said that he lou ed hugely / I not by what mysshappe a
shipster of that Cite / But she wist not thereof / and in caas thowh she had
wist she would have set little thereby / In the mean time yet the bishop
thought that nothing is more ungracious than a loving old man / and withstode
as he might for reverence of his own state / but in a time by fraud of the
devil she came in to the Bisshops chamber in caas for to shape the chamberleyns
lynnen clothes Servants that knew and wist the Bisshops pryu^te went out
for the nones At last. ethe Bishop after vnsyttyng words would have take
the woman with strength The woman styked the Bishop bynethe his pryuy membrys
with the sheres that she had in hand and so the Bishop dyed After him
robert lotharyngus was bishop there / he was connyng of al manner arts and
scyences / specially he conth skylle in aba^^ that is a table to make by
diverse fygures and shappes / ^e knew the course of the moon and of the other
sterres and planetes That time Marianus Scott and monk was closed at magounce
in Almayne / In his long solytarye being / he serched cronykes and storyees /
and was waar first other alone of denis exyguus dyscord against the sothnesse of
the gospel in acountyng of cycles and of years / And marianus acounted all the
years from the beginning of the world and put two and twenty year that lakked
of the foresaid cycles and years and made a great book of Cronykes the which
book this robert defloured solempnly and take out the best / so that it
seems that that defloracion is now more worthy than all the great volume and
long / Wyllelmus de pon / tificibus / libro primo / Also this lanfrank
archebisshop of Caunterbury / and thomas Archebisshop of york went to Rome y
fere for to have the pal / But lanfrank received the palles / one of Worship /
and anthoer of love / for lanfrank had such grace to pope Alexander / that
both his felawes that come with him to Rome thomas of york / and Remigyus of
dorchestre that were right fully y pryued of her croyses and rings / he
restored hem to their office again / For the first was a priests son / And
while the second was monk of ffyscam / he halpe duk wyllyam in many things /
to his wendyng to England / So that the duc byhete him by covenant a
Bisshopryche if he had the vyctorye and that was preued upon him before the
pope / and therefore he was set a down / in the presence of the pope / Thomas
of york meoued a cause of the challenge of the prymate of Dorobernia that is
caunterbury / and of subjection that should long to him of three Bisshopryches
/ of Lyncolne / of wyrcetre and of lychefeld

And said that the Sees of Caunterbury and of york were far atwene / and
that another of him by Gregoryes constitucion should be subgette to other / but
that the one of he^ is more worthy than the other / for he is of elder^ time /
Then lamfrank declared skylfully that that constitucion of gregory makes no
mention of Caunterbury / but of york and of london Than the pope demede that
that cause should be termyned to fore the king and the Bisshops in england /
And though lanfrank held thomas y bound by the professyon that thomas had
made before him byforehonde / yet him was lever trauayll for his successors
than let that challenge abide to him to strive therefore afterward / This year
the year of our lord a thousand three score and twelve at wyndsore before king
wylliam and the clergy that cause was treated / and there Bedas story was
shewde and thereby it was showed that from the first Austyns time / to Bedas
last time about an honderd year and forty / the Archebisshopryche of
Caunterbury had prymacye over all the land of Brytayne / and of Irlonde also
/ And also that he hadd hold cou^sayls fast by york / and cleped thereto the
bisshops of york and made bisshops and punysshed sum bisshops of york for her
trespaas / and set down many / and put hem out of the dygnyte / Herto
were rehearsed pryueleges that were granted upon this manner of doing / Against
all this thomas aleyde the pystle in the which pope Gregory demed that the
chirches of york and of london should be even peers and neither subget to other
/ Than lamfrank answered and said I am not bishop of london nowther the
question is not meoued of the church of london / Then thomas that had many
fauctours and much folk / gadred with him answered and said that Gregory had
granted to Austyn al one to have under him all the bisshops of england and
that the bisshops of london and of york should be good friends / and love well
either other / and he that were first ordained should be first worshipped / and
though Austyn had changed the Archebisshops see from london in to kente yef
gregory would that Austyns successors should be above the bisshops of york /
he would lightly have set in his epistle such manner words / I grant to
the Austyn and to thyn successors / But for he would not that it should stretche
to austyns successors / therefore he made no mention of his successors /
Lanfrank answerde herto and said / if that auctoryte was granted to Austyn
alone and not to his successors it was a simple yefte that the pope yaue
Austyn that was pryue with him / and namely while Austyn ordained no
Archebisshop of york while he was a live / and also there was no bishop at
york / that should be ordained by austyn / Also pryuelege of popes confermeth
this dygnyte to Austyns successors of caunterbury / and demed that it is skyle
and right that all the chirches of England should take loore of living of
that place for of the well of that place they had the leeme of believe / But
for thou say that gregory might if he would have confermed with a word to
austyns successors that he had granted to saint Austyn / That is soth but
that does no preiudyce to the sea of Caunterbury / For when christ said to
peter / I shall give to the the keys of the kingdom of heuene / he might also
have said / if he would I grant the same power to thy success^urs / And though
he said not so yet he bynymeth Peter's successors nothing of reverence /
another of autoryte / But they had lawfully the dispensacion of office of
holy church / what makes that but the virtue of god that spryngeth by Christ
of peter in to his successors / Also if thou kanst know between falls and
soth^ what has strength in all / has strength in the party / and what
strength in the more / has strength in the less / The church of Rome is as
it were al of all chirches and other chirches both as it were parties thereof /
And as for to take heed in one manner wise / man is the kind of his syngulers /
but in every syngler man is the kind of al mankind / So for to take heed in
sum manner wise the church and the sea of Rome is as it were the kind and
conteyneth al in comparyson to other chirches / and yet in every church
regneth the full holiness of Christian feyth / The church of Rome is grettest of
al chirches / and what has strength in that church shall have strength in
less chirches / So that in every church the power of the first shall spring
in to al his successors / but ought be namely and specially out take /
Therefore as Criste said to all the Bisshops of Rome that he said to peter /
So Gregory said to all Austyns successors / what he said to Austyn / Hereof
follows that as Caunterbury is subget to Rome for he takes the feyth of Rome
So shall york be subgette to Caunterbury / that sent thither prechours to
preche hem the feyth / But for thou say that Gregory would that austyn should
have his see at london. hit may not stand / who would trow that so noble a
disciple as Austyn was would wythstonde / nd do against his maystres will /
that was so noble a maystre and do ayenste holy decrees / But though it were
so that Austyn as thou say passed from london / what is that to me that am
not bishop of london / therefore yef this stryf is ceesed and pees made for a
time / yef thou desyrest to plede / I shall not be from the dome / but I shall
defend mine office / and my right / By these reasons thomas was overcome and
granted gladly that the yonder brynke of humber should be the beginning of his
dyocesy / Also it was demed that there afterward in things that longs to
worship of god and to the feyth of holy church the archebisshop of york should
he subget to the Archebisshop of Caunterbury / So that if tharchebisshop of
Caunterbury would make a counseyl in any place of england the Archebisshop of
york should be there at with the bisshops of his prouynce and he shall be
obedyente to his lawful heestes / If the Archebisshop of Caunterbury is deed /
the Archebisshop of york shall come to Caunterbury with bisshops of the foresaid
church / and sacre the primate that is chosen / And if tharchebisshop of york
is deed his successor shall come co the archebisshop of Caunterbury where he
wol assygne in england and be sacred of him / And he shall make him an oath
with profession and obedyence / Than lanfranck hopped for joy and took all this
wreton for that new doing should not slide out of mind and his successors
should be begyled of the knowleche thereof / but he bare him so that he lost
naught that another passed in speaking / For it is hated a man to make him self
curious in his own praysynge / Than lanfranck sent a pystle to pope
alysaunder that contained all this doing with the profession of thomas the
Archebisshop of york / This year king wylliam went in to Scotland with a
great nauey and an hooste of horsemen / And made king malcolyn subget / and
king malcolyn bycame his lyege man / and swore him hommage and feute
Sygebertus bishop of magounce went to saint James a pylgremage / but in his
coming again he was made monk of cluny / than shi^pmen would have bought his
Bisshopryche / he saw that / and went again to his bisshopriche as his abbot
bad him

This year Edgar Adelynge went to king wylliam in to normandy and was acord
with him

Capitulum tercium
HIltebrande that was the seventh pope gregory was sometime pryour of cluny /
and than Archedeken of Rome / and than he was made pope enleuen year / he made
a synod and forbede clerks that were sacred wives / and forbode that they
should have no wives another dwell with women / but with such as the synod
nycena and holy laws suffryth / But for priests dispreysed his punyschyngis
/ the pope badde that men should not here a priests mass / that held openly
and comunely a concubyne ayenste the popes ordenaunce / In a time this was a
Cardynal and the popes messagyer in to France and made hard process ayenste
prelates that were made by Symonye / Than one bishop that was sharply defamed
by Symonye change with mede the witness that him had accused / The legate was
waare thereof and said before all the counseyll / now man's doom is awey
that faylyth often / let us bring gods own dome that faylyth never more /
Since that the grace of a Bisshopryche is the yeft of holy ghost / he that
byeth a bisshopryche does against the holy ghost / than thou bishop have not
do against the holy ghost / Say openly here in the counsaylle gloria patri et
filio et spiritui sancto / that is the joy to the fader and to the son / and
to the holy ghost / he byganne and essayed often / but he might never say the
holy ghost / But he said it pleynly when he was put out of the bisshopryche
/ Also while this pope song his first mass in a myd winter night at saint
marye at presepe domini / one Cresce^cius the son of the prefecte of the cite
took him and put him in prisonne / but anon the Romans brake the tour and
delyuerd the pope / Also in a counseylle of three honderd bisshops / this pope
cursed the thyrdde henry the emperor and assoylled al men of her oath that owht
him hommage and feute / For he cast many things against the state of holy
church / And afterward though the emperor stood long time barfote upon snow
and yse uneath he was assoylled / But afterward besyeged Rome and meded the
cyteseyns and prysonned the pope / and took one wybertus bishop of Raven and
made him pope / and cleped him Clemente / But Robert duc of Apulea herd thereof
and delyuerd the pope / Roger the earl of herforde / by whose counsel king
william had made search all thabbayes of England for to have great tresour /
this earl married his sister to rauf earl of eestenglond that conteyneth
northfolke / against the kings heeste / And made there conspyracye against the
king / and made Earl walref asse^t thereto bygyle^ but he went anon to
lanfrank / and took his penance / and went then in to normandy to the king
and warned him of the treasonne / and put him wylfully in the kings grace /
the king came again in to England and outlawed some and chaced Earl Rauf and
prysonned waltef and made afterward smote of his heed wyckedly besides
wynchestre / In time that came afterward by thordenaunce of god / his body was
beryed afterward in the abbaye of crowlond / of him wytnessyth lanfrank that
he was very repentaunt of his sins and said that well were him if he might
come to waltefs rest after his end day In lanfrancus time was made a
counseyll at london in saint paul's church / that doing had be long time left
of in England / First there was ordained how bisshops should sytte in
counseyll and in Synod / the second that the bisshops see should pass out of
small towns in to gretter towns and so the Sea of Selfey passed to chychester
of kyrton to excetre / of wells to bathe / Of shirburn to sabesbury / of
dorchestre to lyncolne / Of lychefeld to chestre in bishop peter's time / But
his successor robert passed from chestre to couentre / Willelmus de
pontificibus libro 2 / This year deyde hyrmanus the first bishop of Salesbury
/ of the which it is wreton to fore hond / After him the kings chau^celer
osmundus was bishop four and twenty year / he builded there a new church and
brought thither noble clerks and connyng of clergy and of song / so that
this bishop him self shoned not to wryete and ^ymne and bind books / Also he
made the ordynal of the service of holy church / and cleped it the
consuetudynarie / now well nigh al england wales and yrlond. uses that ordynal
/ Also he endyted saint adelins life / This year Robert courthchose king
williams oldest son / for he myht not have normandye that his fader had
assigned him sometime / therefore by help of the king of France he took prays
in normandye and did his fader much woo / So that his fader was wounded and
unhorsed and began for to cry / Robert herd his fadere bois / and alighte
down of his horse. and horsed his fader ageine^ Willelmus de pontificibus libro
tercio / The northumbres slew walkerus bishop of durham / William that was
sometime abbot of cariles was bishop after him / This william brought first
monks at durham / he was mighty in the world / and had his mouth at his
will / and had great trust therinne / and favored afterward parties / Somdele
against king william the read / Therefore he fled out of england and came
again to his own Bisshopryche after two year and made him full besy to have
the kings love again / so that he followed the kings will in his ye and nay
in all manner wise / and specially in that strife that was between the king and
ancelm / and hoped thereby to geete the kyngys grace other to be archebisshop
after ancelm / But he failed of either / for there fylle stryf between him and
the king / and he was at gloucestre to defend his cause / This was the first
that did the pryour of durham that benefet that he should be deen and
archedeken in all that bisshoprych / waryng earl of shrowesbury made twey
abbayes / one in the subarbes of shrowesbury and another at wenlok in worship
of saint mylburgh / Willelmus de Regibus While a mighty man sat at a fest Myes
byset him suddenly al about / and though he were brouhgt in to the high see it
halp him not / for the myes syewed him in the sea upon ryndes of pome garuat
and were adreynt of the shipme^ Nothing that god has wrought is al without
wit / another thing without remedy / Than the man was brought ayene to land
and myes al to haaled him / Me says that the same hap byfyl a prince of
polonia that a leopard had y beat / Also such an hap is told of a prince
that might by no manner craft keep and save him self fro lyese in no manner
wise / Henricus lib / sexto / This year was a cursyd stryf between monks of
glastenbury and the vnthriuyng abbot thursta^ that king wylliam had brought
theder out of the abbay of cadony and made him abbot of glastenbury that couth
no manner wit of Redynesse / Among his other lewdness and folly he despised
gregoryes song and office / and byganne to compelle the monks for to use the
song of one william monk of fyscamen / Willelmus de pontificibus li 1 / He
wasted and spended the chirches gooddes and catailsin lechery-and chalengyd
cruelly the order and service of the monks and withdrewe therewith their mete
and their drynk Thereof came chiding and strif of words discord and of wits
and of thoughts / For lucanus says fasting folk can no dread / Than after
chiding and strif me took wepne / And the abbot with his men of arms fille
armed on the monks and slough tweyne at hye auter / and wounded eighten and
shot arowes to images and schrines of the church / the monks as they were
drive to by need defended hem self as well as they might in every side with
forms and stoles and candelstikkes and wounded sum of the knights / This
cause was meoued before the king / and the Abbot was changed and turned to his
own abbaye in normandy But the monks were to scatred about by the kings
heest by diverse byisshopryches and abbayes / But after king wyllia^s death this
thurstan bought the Abbaye of glastenbury of king william the reed for five
honderd pound and so he went about somewhat of years by the possessions of the
abbay and deyde fer from him / This year king wiliam had of every huyde of
land six scyllynges of silver / Also pope hyltebrand lay in his deed bed
and cleped to him the cardynals that he loved most / and knowleched that he
had made wrath a^nd stryf between the Emperor and the other christian men /
Therefore he vndede the bounds of the peynes that were set and deyde

Capitulum quartum /
AFter hyltebrand the third vyctor was pope one year and five months /
Sometime he hight desiderius Abbot of mount Cassin / he was poisoned with venym
that was done in his chalys / that year canutus king of de^mark by help of his
wives fader Robert of flaundres arrayed him for to come in to england with a
greet nauey^ but king wylliam herd thereof and gadred a great host and come
in to england out of normandy / But his enemies were let and he held his
court at gloucestre / there he yaf Bisshopryches to his three priests / to
morice he yafe the Bisshopryche of london / To william the bisshopryche of
Tedford / To robert the bisshoprych^ of chestre / but he changed the sea to
couentre Willelmus de pontificibus libro quarto / He rasede of one beme of that
chirch five honderd mark of silver for to fill the kings hand and for to
begyle the occupacion of the pope / earl leofrycus had made that place rich
of gold and of silver of relykes and other precious stones / And so this
Robert robbed his own church / and was gylty to make good therefore in his life
owther with his cataill after his death if any man were that him would accuse /
also he fed the monks of that place with simple mete and drink and suffryd
them not to learn but simple lettrure / lest liking mete and drink and
gretter lettrure would make the monks stout and proud against the bishop /
Netheles at lychefelde he byganne many greet buyldynges. About that time
bygan thordre of the chartrus in calabria in the bisshoprich of grannopolytan
by one bruno that was y bore at Coloyn of the nation of Duche men and chanon of
Reins in Champayne in France and master of the scoles / he forsook the
world and founded the heremytage of chartrus about saint ioones fest and
ruled it syx year / At last he came to Rome by heeste of the second pope
urban that had be sometime his scoler / there he halpe the pope gretely in
dygnyte of holy church / But when he might not suffer the stryf and the
manners of the court / he forsook the court and the Archebisshoprych of Rysens
/ to the which he was chose by heeste of the pope / And went to the
heremytage that was called the tour in Calabria / and ended there his life /
That manner heremytes that be cleped Cellystes also for they woneth in celles
and lyuen under a pryour and passen not the nombre of twelve in clerks / but
it be for sum worthy person / but they take leude men anon to the nombre of
twenty / every in his own celle in simple days y served by him self byddeth
his bedes / slepyth and etyth / Each of them has one loof for his bread for
all the weke / they ete never flessh ne blood / they were never lynen cloth
another stamyn but the here next the flesh and a boue a kyrtell of woollen and
a pylche / they have thryttene celles / and every celle is departed a four and
to set within for the oratory the dortour the fraytour / and the werk house
there they does her works / but they join all to gyders / On sondayes and
other high days they come to church and to a common board and etyn y fere /
and talken y fere of goostly tales / they say their service after saint benets
rule / An apostata that breketh his order they take him never again / King
wylliam made descryue al england / For he would wit and know how much land
each of his barons had / how many knights fees how many teme land / how
many towns and men and how many beestes / the land was grieved with many
meschyefs and happes that fyl for that deed / That descrypcion was written al in
one volume / and y do in the kings lyberarye at wynchestre / Also this year
Edgar Adelyng went in to Apulea with great strength by love of king wylliam
and his sister Crystyne went in to the abbay of Romsee / After vyctor the
second urban was pope thyrtene year / First this was a monk of cluny and
archedeken of rome / and hete Odo Thereafter he was Bishop hostyence and pope
at last / Another pope that hete clemente that was in the poperyche with
wrong did this urban much woo and teene. This clemente was sometime bishop of
Rauenna / That year in england was greet^ death of beestes and dystemperyng of
the eyer by the which many men deyd in fevers and for honger / In the same
time grysely fire destroyed the pryncipal cytees of England and saint Paul's
church / and a great dele of london / Alfr / That year the danes in a church
slew her king Ca^^tus / Willelmus de Regibus libro tercio / This king wylliam
lay a bed at Roen Rothomage in the last end of his life the king of France
scorned him in this manner / king william of England lies now as wymmen don a
chyldebed and takes him to sleuthe he bourded so / For king wylliam had
slaked his great womb with a drink that he had drunk / the king was
displesyd with this scorn / and said I shall offer him a thousand candels
when I shall goo to church of child / And not long thereafter in a lamesse
month when the corns were in feldes Fruit on trees / and grapes on the
vynes / he set a fuyr the west side of France and the Cite medant and our
lady church / In that church he burnt a woman that was closed and trowyd not
but she should fle in such a manner need / In that hete he took an evil that
might not be heeled other else when his horse lepe over the dyche he brake
the entrayls of his fat womb / than leches warned him that he should dye /
than he ordained normandy to his eldest son Robert And England to wylliam the
reed. And the mother possessions and tresour / To henry clerk and made delyuere
his prisonners that he had in bounds / that were the Earls marcarus Rogyer /
wilnotus / haraldes son / his brother odo bishop of bayon / And so he deyde
the year of his kingdom one and twenty the tenthe month the year of his
duchery two and fyfty / the year of his life nine and fyfty / the year of our
lord a thousand four score and seven the eight day of december / and he was
buried in thabbay of cadony that he had founded / there me might see sorrow
that he that was so dredeful and so worshipful in europa might not be buried
without challenge / For there a knight forbede openly his beryeng and seyde
that ground was his own / and y take of him with strength / therefore his son
henry yaf the knight an honderd pound for to ceese for there were none of king
williams sons / for his eldest son Robert warred than in the countray / and
william the reed was sailed in to england / But at Wynchestre he took his
faders tresorye and yafe much for his faders mind / Henricus libro quinto /
This william conqueror was a wise man and gyleful rich and couetouse glorious
and loved well great loos fair speker with gods seruaunces and stern to him
that would him withstonde / In the prouynce of hampton in the new forest in the
space of thyrtty mile / he threw down chirches and towns and did there wyld
beestes / So that who took there a wild be should lose his ^ne eye / and
who that took a woman by strength should lose his genetoryes^ W / dear / li / 3
/ King wylliam was of skillful stature to great and fat of body stern of face
/ bar of forheede / great of strength in brawne and arms / so that uneath
any man myyhte bend his bow / but he would on his horse stretche forth his
senewys and bend it easyly enough upon his one foete / he had skillful strength
and yaue him self to much to huntyng / so that he threw down chirches and
town^s to make wodes / he made great feestes and reueles in the high fe^^^tes
of the year / he held his mydwynter tide at gloucestre / his eester at
wynchestre / whitsontyde at westmynstre / when he was in England / but he
passyd and ouerdyde in gaderyng money of the people / other to wythstonde his
enemies / other to make him a greet name / other to ceese his couetyse / it
is^ a common tale that when this william was young he distourbed his came
malgerus Archebisshop of Rotomage of his bisshopryche / for he forge^dryd
gods service and yaue him self to huntyng and to festes / but more verily /
for the bishop had acursid duc william and mold his wife and his cosyn / for
they were unlawfully y wedded to giders But for that trespaas duc William
bylded an abbaye of men / and mold another of wyme^ at cadony / R / Also
william bylded twey abbayes in england one at bermu^deseye fast by london / and
another at bataylle in southsex / there he had fought / Hen / li / 7 / When
this william was king uneath was there a lord in england an englysshman / but
englisshmen were made boonde / so that it was shame and despyte to be cleped an
englysshman / To bear down and to destroy englysshman god had ordained cruel
and stern / that be of such kind that when they have boren down their
enemies than they bear down their self /

Capitulum 5
WYlliam the reed was crowned king the day of saint Cosma and damian / him
halp wulstan Bishop of wyrcetre / and the Archebisshop lanfrank that had him
norysshed / and made knight / This william reigned thyrten year a month la^sse
/ Robert the eldest sone was that time in almayne / and hadd gadred a great
host against the fader. and herd hereof and came again in to normandye / and
leyde half normandy / out take castles to wedde to his brother henry for to
wage an host against his brother william and came at last a land at hampton /
Than the king sent him messagers that said in this manner / Thy brother william
clepeth him self not king / but vnderkyng to regne under the / and by help of
the that art gretter than he / and better and rather y bore / if it is thy
will / he bathnot mystake as his own that he has take for a time by cause
ofthyn absence. but by cause he is now crowned he prays that he may regne
under the and pay to the every year three thousand marc / and he that over
leueth shall have the worship of other / Robert waggng his heed assentyd anon
and left his host and went again in to normandy / and had right naught but
fair byhestes / well nygh all the noble men of england would have made robert king
out take lanfra^k and wulstan / That time fell a cruel and grysely tempest in
england / for after winter in the beginning of spryngyng time king williams
eame Odo bishop of bayocens that was before delyuerd onte of the first king
williams prysonne came in to england / to him was yeuen the Erldom of kente He
saw that it yede not al to his deuyse in the land / as it did sometime in the
first king wylliams time / and was wroth therefore / and forsook the king and
enfected many other with the same grutchyng / and namely the bishop of durham
/ The earl of northu^berlond / and rogyer of mount gomeryk / Earl of
shrowesbury / Than this odo wasted and destroyed the kings rentes and enchetes
/ And lanfrank the Archebisshops lands / for he was by his counseyll cast in
the first king williams bounds / for the first king william pleined sometime of
his brother that he would forsake him Take him quod lanfrank and bind him that
he grieve the not I say not the bishop but the earl of kente. That time Rogyer
Earl of shrowesbury with his walsshmen destroyed the ends of England anon to
wyrcetre / But by the prayer and curs of seint wulstan / they were so y febled
and blente that he and his men were chaced of a little nombre of men of castles
of the same Bisshops meyne / King wylliam saw that the normans were nygh all
conspyred against him / Than he plesyd englysshmen with be hestes of bett laws
and fre hu^ting in his own wodes / In the same manner he awelded roger earl of
shrowsbury and ano^ he fill on them that him hadd forsake and occupied odoes
castles in kent / and took odo and made him forswere england / and besieged
and took the cite of rochestre there the noble men were gadred / Also that year
saint nycolas body was brought to the cite barrus in apulea when turks
destroyed the cite mirrea / four and twenty knights of barrus went thither and
brought to her own cite saint nycolas bones swimming in oil / Also that year
pope urban had with him ancelm abbot of becko / and made a cou^seil at
cleremou^t in gallia that is in france. there it was ordeygned that the hours
of our lady should be said every day / and fulle service of her the saturday.
King william corru^ped the wardeyns with money and when so^me of robertes
castles in normandye and let the king of france / that be should not fauer
his brother robert / and so normandy was long vnstidfast / now fauouryng that
one brother / and now the other til that robert had chynon and king williams some
castle in saint nycolas mount and resed upon either brother now upon the one and
now upon the other / there in a day king william went out of his tente on war
and fyl on many enemies with few men / But his horse was slain under him / and
he was long draw and haled by the foot / But his haberione was so good that it
saved him that he was not hurt / the knight that had throw him down set his
hond to his sword for to sle the king / leave fool quoth king william I am
king of england / all the host drad when they herd that voys / and brought
the king another horse / he axyd who threw him down / I quoth the knight that
