had do the deed / I wend not to throw down a king but a knight / Per vultum
de luca quod the king / thou shall be me the lever after this / Than when hen^y
was so beseged of both his brethere^. that him locked water / he sent to his
brother robert that was the more benign man and said that it was an evil deed
for to werne water that is common to al men / and beestes / and that it were
more lauful to fight with strength of knights than with vyolens of the eleme^s
/ than he granted him water / king william herd thereof and scorned that deed
and said / so thou have learned robert to overcome thyn enemies and to give hem
drink / Thou tellest great price of water quod robert / tellest thou more
price of water than of our brother / would thou suffer him to deye for defaute
of water / where shall we have another brother if we leese him / For this answer
the king vndyde the werre / and had both his brethren with him in to england /

Capitulum sextum /
THis year dyed lanfrank Archebisshop of Caunterbury / the fourth day of Iuyn
after that he had be archebisshop / xviij year / And than the sea was void
four year / W / de p / li / p / This lanfrank of the nation of lombardes was a
noble man of lettrure / he had y give al his yought to free arts and
scyences and spente his elde al in holy books / he was connyng thereof / and
despised the smokyng and schyllyng speech of mysbyleuyd men And of al thabbayes
of normandy he chose becco^ and was y capped by the pouert and relygyo^ of that
place / there he was monk under abbot herlewing / and was a man that couth do
no great works to get his lyuelode therewith / therefore he held open scole of
art to releue the nedy place by fredome of his scolers / the loos of his
praysynge and of his worship sprang out among wykked men / so that they had
great envy to the good man and to the priests of the cou^tray meoued so
william duc of normandye that he comau^ded to put out lanfrank out of
normandy for his vnnesynesse W / li / 2 / By cause hereof duc williams preeste
was holden a man of great science before the coming of lanfrank / And he came in
a day to lanfrank scole with greet brag and boost / than by his first
speech lanfrank was waar that the man couth well nygh^ right naught / and took
him a thing with lettres for to speed / And so he overcome the wyldenes of the
man by cunning of ytaly / therefore he was wroth / and made duc willya^ put
lanfrank out of al normandy / But occasion to have grace of the duc was for
lanfrank went to the dukes court / and his horse halted and made the duc laugh
/ The duc took head of courtosye of lanfra^cks answer and of the fayrenesse of
his face / and made him pryour of becco / abbot of caen and afterward
archebisshop of Caunterbury / W / de / pon / li / 1 / This man was so famous of
lore that Pope alysaunder aroos worshipfully against him when he came to rome and
said that he did not to the archebisshop that worship / but to his clergy /
therefore the pope axyd that / sith that he had do / what was worshipful
la^ffra^k should do what was rightful that is that he should fall down to the
feet of saint peter's vyker / when he had do so / the pope by cause of him
restored his felawes bisshops that come with him to their state croyses and
Rings that were before y preued as it is said before / Also this lanfra^k
tretid and byladde king wylliam conqueror by an holy craft / not with
grymchydynge / but sometime an ernest and sometime in good myrthe / King william
was stern and dradde no man and ruled both temporalyte and spiritualyte at his
own will / he took no man fro the pope in his land but he come and plesyd him
/ he suffered no counseyll made in his own country without his own leave / Also
he would no thing suffer to be ordained in such a counseyll but as he would
assente / Also no lord of his land should be punysshed but at his own heest /
Sometime lanfrank took money for to spare the more the trespass of his subget /
That did he not for light the charge of sin / but for to get the more grace
of the king / The need why it most be do excused somewhat the kings deed in
gadryng of money / For with great money one may make peace / in the land that
is won thith deeds of arms and with strength / And though it be little
acounted among men to rauysshe of men of the land and give to enemies / yet
before god I hold it right naught / Then king wylliams deeds in comparyson
of deeds of kings. that now ben be worthy to be preched for ensample of free
and lordely heart / That was said trespaas of presu^pcion / Lanfrank suffryd
it ageynste his will / And when ^e saw his time he would speak plesauntly
and warned him and wythsayde him in skillful manner / Lanfrank had filled his
wit with all virtues and specially in / alms deeds / he passed other
men in words and in deeds / and vsyd often that word of holy writ yeueth
alms and al thing is clean to you / And though c^uetyse be a special vice
to lombardes he put that gleymyng fer from his person / so that he spence on
pore men mete and drynk and cloth / he shamed him not to gyrde him self high
and feed and serve pore men and make pore stolers strive and dispute / and
when they had done either should goo glad aweye / the vyctor for he had
the maystrye / and he that was overcome for comfort and solace of shame / he
advanced namely the place of monks and of clerkis / he brouht manly a^en
possessions that were alyened / Sharpnes of wit and dunsta^s favor comforted
him often / for as often as he was thoughtful for such doings and abode with the
sentence / Saint dunsta^ would come to lanfrank when he was a sleep / and warn
him of all the sleyghte of his adversaries / and teache the weyes how he should
escape / Also in a time lanfrank was seek and him s^med that dunstan warstled
with him and delyuerd him of his sickness and made him al hoole / And as it is
take out of saint Dunstans life / lanfrank was so mylde and so fair of speech
in herynge of shryfte that when the shryfte were do he would kiss their
hondes that were y shryue to him / and say these have made me holy this day
/ Also in his time the monks of Caunterbury as well nyghe al other monks in
england were not vnlyk to seculer men save that they left not their chastyte /
but they vsyd haukynge / and huntyng and playeng at dees and great drynkers
also / So that thou would wene that they were consuls rather than monks for
they had so many servants of so great arraye / lanfrank suffryd their
outrage a space of time / but he fered hit awey with the staf of couenable
sternesse / The wise master of souls knew and wist well the customme is the
second from kind / And he knew also that sudden chaungyng of manner and
thewes greueth thoughts and wits / there for otherwhiles emonge he put awey
somewhat of such manner doyngis with fair speech and soft / and whette the
ruyde souls to good with the whestone of virtues / So that they forsook the
branches of shrewdness and evil manners of living and desired the kind course
of virtues and of thewys by their own good will / therefore yet they have the
holy man in mind and greet devotion to god and fair speech to ghestes and
charity among them self / this lanfrank let never man go fro him ^lenge or
sorry / if he saw any man discomforted he would besyly axe and wit the cause
and give comfort and medicyn / he would freely profre penyes to young childeren
/ he ordained to monks what them neded in every side / so that they should
not lack of what that them neded / and out of rule they should not blenche /
that time spra^ge envy among bisshops that would put out monks of their places
/ and bring in seculer clerks / auctor of that doing was walk linus bishop
of winchestre a good man in other deeds / though he were bade in that doing and
brought thereto by cou^seyl of bacbitres Also he had co^utid king william to the
same intent / but la^fra^k herd thereof and destroyed the castes of the mighty
me^ as who destroys attercops nestes / so they that comen afterward should not
be hardy to begin that doing ne none other like / he made that pope alisander
forbode it by his writing / he restored thabbay of rochestre from the no^bre of
four clerks to the no^bre of fifty monks that had enough to live by. his
wit is y wist that he translated gundulphus monk of cadony to the bisshoprych
of rochestre as I trow by the election of god / For this gundulphus learned
holy writ of lanfrank at cadony while his master took heed to other things
he and his felawe walter with the third held on hand the book of the
gospels / and said now essaye we be turnynge of the leaves which of us shall be
abbott and which shall be Bishop / than gundulphus fond this place true
servant wise and ready that our lord ordeyneth over his meyne / but walter
fond this place gods servant and true enter in to the Joy of thy lord /
The third felaw fond I not what hard word that grieved him soore / and though
I have herd it / I foryete it gladly for it is a gentil heart to make no game
and scorn of other men's woo / then they made joy of that hap / and
lanfrank axyd what they had of murthe / and when he knew how it stood / he
told them without doubt that gundulphus should be a bishop and walter an
abbot / and that the thyrdde should torn to the slidyng of the world / as it
fylle afterward / the soth was preued / for gu^dulphus was bishop of Rochester
/ and walter abbot of euesham / and the third passed in vein / when lanfrank
acorded not in manners with king wylliam the reed / he lay at last seek of
the feuer^ and was shryuen and houseled and drank a medecinale drank and so he
yield up the ghost as he had desired / he knowleched that he had prayde god
that he might deye in the fevers or in the flux / for these euyls dystourbith
not the mind nowther lets the speech

Capitulum 7
THis year when the counseyll was made in the cite turon in gallia / in france
pope urban exyted nygh all the west lands to socour of the holy land / therefore
the third henry emperor Reymund earl of saint Gyles and beamund of apulca took
the cross and passed the sea of myddel earth at that place that is called
saint georges arm and had with hem two honderd thousand of Cryste^ men / and
so the holy land was won at that time and crystes spear was found by
reuelacion of saint andrew that was showed to a clerk / with hem went Robert
duc of normandy and therefore he made acorde with his brother king william the
reed and leyde to him normandy to wedde for ten thousand pound / But be
cause thereof king wyllia^ took a grievous trybute of englisshmen so that
prelates melted their vessel / and lords spoylde their subgettes / Malcolyn
king of Scotland took prays in northumberlond / therefore king william and his
brother Robert went in to Scotland / his nauey was nygh al adreynt and his
host marryd with ^old and with honger. Malcolyn came against him with adelyng
and made pees by medyacion / So that malcolyn should be obedyente to king
william / as he was sometime to his fader / and king william should give him
every year twelve mark of gold and he should yield him twelve cytees / in
england / but sone there after the king failed and Robert took with him edgar
and went again in to normandy / This year the fyfte day of October a great
struck of lyghtnyng smote the church toure at wynchecom be and thyrled the
wall and threw the crucifyxe head down to the earth and brake the right
thygh and threw down our lady image that stood by the roode / thereafter came a
stynkynge smoke that filled all the church / and dured till the monks had
goo a procession about all the places and offices of the abbay with holy water and relykes of holy saints and with the Letanye

Also at london a whyrle wind threw down six honderd houses or moo / and
many chirches thereto / and slew two men in seint marye church at bow / and
lift up six reftres of the church / and stroke them so deep in the
ground / that uneath the sixte part of hem was seen above the earth / Also a
whyrlwynde threw down the heelyng of the church of Salesbury / the fyfth day
after that osmundus had hallowed that church / Willelmus de pon / libro quarto
/ Remigius the Bishop that translated the sea from Dorchestre to lyncolne /
cast for to halowe the church that he had newely build / But thomas bishop
of york wythstode him and said / that that place was of his parysshe / And
king wylliam for money that Remigius had yeuen pryuely commanded nyghe all
the bisshops of England that they should come to that dedycacion the fyftenth
day of may / but twey days before that day of the dedycacion Remygyus dyed by
gods preuy doom / Robert Bishop of herford aloone would not come to the
halowyng of that church / for he knew by certain sight of the steres that that
church should not be hallowed in Remygius time / This Remygius seemed nygh a
wonder forbodyng for his body was so little / but he overcome kind and showed
outeward a noble heart and wit / So that gracious and noble virtue come of
that litel body / After this Remigius Robert bloet was Bishop a full lecherous
man / he fulfilled ryally the halowyng of that church / Atlast at wodestok he
went from the king and deyde and his bowels were take out of his body and
beryed in the abbay of euesham that he had founded / the other dele was
buried at lyncolne / there it was well know that the wardeyns of the place
were often dysesed with shadows by night / till that the place was clensyd
with holy prayers and be dys / That year king william went in to
northumberlonde / and repaired the cite of lugubalia / that now is called
caercol and made a Castle therynne / that cite had been destroyed from the
coming of the danes two honderd year / And sone thereafter at gloucestre the
king was take with a great sickness and byhete that he would amend his life
by counseyll of the lords / Henricus libro sexto And he yaf that year the
Archebisshopryche to Ancelm / but he might not take thereof but as the king would
/ er the tribute was paid that the king had set / Also he said that the
Bisshopriche of lyncolne longed to the Sea of york / till that Robert bloet had
give the king five thousand marc / Also this year deyde Rogyer earl of
shrowesbury / when he lay seek he made him mo^k for to have sum socoure by
assente of countess Adelysa / for he had sent Reynald pryour of shrowesbury
to cluny for to have saint Hughe / the abbots kyrtel to were it about him /
Treuisa A wyseman would mean that earl Rogyer had as much mede of that he was
monk / as malkyn of her maydenhode / that no man would have and not adeel
more / Then it follows in the story / after Rogyer his son hugh was earl /
Also that year was great reyne and flodes / And soon thereafter so great fro^t
that one might over all led carts and waynes over waters and ryuers / And
when the frost byganne to. thawe and to melte it brake nygh all the bridges in
every side / Rees king of wales was slain in fighting fast by brechnok / and
so ceesed the kingdom of wales / Malcolin king of Scotts come to gloucestre
against king william on a saint barnabas day / to acorde with him / But they
departed in wrath / for king william would that malcolin should be demed in his
court where ever it were in England / But malcolin would not but in the marches
of both the kingdoms there it was wont / but that year upon saint bricius
day malcolin and his eldest son edward and many other were slain in
northumberlond of Earl Robartes knights / margrete queen of Scotts that loved
and worshipped god with her might / took so great sorrow that she fill seek as
she had prayed god and deyde the third day thereafter / when she was deed /
the Scotts made dunwald malcolyns brother king / But duncan malcolyns son by
help of king wylliam put out dunwalde and took the kyngd^me of Scotland /
Willelmus de pontificibus / it was told this malc^lyn in a time that one of
the lords of his land had conspyred to bring him to death / he badde him be
stylle that told him that tale and he held it preuy with him self till the
traitor was comen / At last the traytoure came to the king to awayte his
time to do that cursed deed / the king bad erly in a morning that all the
hunters should come with their hounds / While they were an hunting the king
went with this traytoure to a brood pleyne / that was bysette with thykk wode
al about as a garland / In the myddel of that place was a little toote as it
were an hylle / these tweyne stood alone on that toote / loo said the king / I
and thou ben here alone / each well y horsed and wepened^ and each well arrayed
/ Now is no man that sees us that might help other let / if thou might and
if thou darrest do now as thou had thought / I can not see when it might
be better another more freely done / if thou have ordained venym that is the
doing of wymmen and not of knights / if thou desyrest my wife so may spouse
brekers / if thou castest to stele upon me with (...) that is a thieves doing
and not a knights / Therefore do (...) and as a knight should / that thy tresonne
he without shame of cowardyse for without falsheede may it not be / Anon he
fylle down to the kings feet and swore tha he would thereafter be true to the
king to his lives end and promised him pledgys which he would cheese / And
so the traitor was made true and went again to his felawes when he saw
his time / Also this year Ancelm abbot of barro came out of normandy in to
England at request of hugh earl of chestre for three causes / one because he
should releue abbayes that he had before founded in england of grievous
trybute that the abbayes paid to the king / the second for to visyte earl hugh
that was sore seek that time / The thyrdde by cause he should found an abbaye
at chestre / In that place he assygned his preeste Rychard first abbot and
changed seculer chanons in to monks But in the coming again thennes he was
made Archebisshop of Caunterbury /

Capitulum 8
THis year England and Normandye were grieved with a grievous trybute and with
moreyn of men / so that earth tylyenge ceesed / and thereafter come great honger
and walsshe men forsook the yok of thraldom and of subjection and took prays
in the shyres of Chestre / of shrowesbury and of herford and took the castle of
meuema / That time the Scotts slew their king duncanus and made dunwald efte
king / Sterres were seen (...) down from the sky as it were fyghtyng to
geders / King William came out of normandy and sent an host in to wales /
there he lost many horses and men / than the king saw that the walshmen
might not be overcome for streytnesse of diverse places / and for thykke wodes
/ therefore the king made strong castles in places by the sea side and hewed
down a great dele of the wodes / and thereafter he beete down many walshmen /
Wulstan Bishop of wyrcetre deyde the eyghtenth day of January / Willelmus de
pon / li / tercio / This wulstan in the hour of his dyyeng appeared to his well
byloued friend Robert bishop of he^ford in the town of Cryklade and chargyd
him that he should array for his beryeng / and efte the thyrtenth day thereafter
he appeared to ^ym and warned that he should amend him of the negligence of him
self and of his also / And said that he should not long in his chayr sytte /
And soon thereafter Robert deyde / Also this wulstan wol^de suffer no man
when he was deed to take of him his ryng that he had first when he was
sacred bishop / he had often sa^de while he was a live that he would never
leave that ryng / Also he said often to egnlysshmen / It is gods chastysynge
that ye suffer / Englysshmen answered him and said that the norma^s were wors
than ever were englysshmen / god almighty quod he uses well the wykkednesse of
hem in you and by hem that be unworthy he takyth wreche of hem that have
trespaced and a gylt

So god by his good will the fend by his evil will tormentyth evil men in
hell and is tormented with them also / Ensample may be yeuen / thou art wroth
and smytest a man with a staf / of the brekyng of the staf thou rechest but
little / Willelmus de pontificibus likro quarto / Wulstan was borne in warwyk
shyre. and learned lettrure and office of holy church in the abbaye osburgh /
At last he was made preeste and song a long mass / and heelde him apayed
with only the offrynge of christian men / and he was holden a clean maid / he
did no outrage in drink / Flessh / he ete sometime / but he f^rsoke etynge of
flessh / by cause of this hap / In a day when he should goo for to plede /
him seemed that he should first sing his mass / and than took sum mete to
releue with his need / Then a goos was leyd to the fire / and he smelled the
roasted flessh / while he was at mass and was let of his devotion by the
smell of the flessh and so he strof long time and might not torn awey his
thought at this will / therefore he swore on the holy sacrament that he had on
hond / that he would never ete such manner mete after that time / and said his
mass and ete and went forth to the ple as he must / At last his devotion
encreaced and he auowed chastyte / and forsook the world by ensample of his
forfaders that hadd auowed chastyte before his death time / and in the abbay of
wyrcetre there his fader had served before that time / he was made monk /
there he went upward by all the offices of the house / He was ever besy in
fasting waking and in bedes / he was wo^t to lay his head on a form of the
church / there he badde his beedes and slepte there / he lay before the
altar in a night / in his bedes / and there came a fend in a man's likeness
/ and warstled with him / whether he would or no. and cast him thryes to the
ground / therefore he had afterward great penance in an evil that is called
yleos and greueth fast by the reins / the fend came to him in a servants
likeness of the court. as often as wulstan saw that servant afterward he
wexyd al pale for dread / he would not light down from his horse for no
brekyng of brydges / but he would ride surely enough upon the high brinkes of
the bridge^ though it were right strayte / At last when the forsayde aldredus
was translated to the bisshoprych of york wulstan was chosen Bishop of
wyrcetre specially by the procuryng of aldredus that hoped to blind his
rebberye by the symplenesse of wulstan / but he had more help of virtue than
of lettrure / and defended manly the right of his church / But he was not so
lewd of lettrure as he was holden / for he couth what him neded for to kunne /
out take fables of poets / and wyly and Sly Sylogismes / that he would not on
cas / vouche sauf for to learn / wulstan would not assente to his own election
/ Then one wulsius an holy man had be forty year closed / blamed him
sharply for he would not assente / Also he was warned of god that he should
assente to the election / In his consecracion were two legates of the court of
Rome / and though he made profession to Stygandus the Archebisshop / he took
his consecracion and his sacryng of aldredus the Archebisshop of york / but for
to avoid chalenges that might fall afterward / Aldredus made protestacion
that he chalengyd no right of subjection in wulsta^ after that time / though he
had be his monk before that time / Than wulstan was made bishop and spared
both mete and drink in his halle all the hours after mete / as the usage was
of englisshmen / he would sytte by him and frote his palms and feyne to drink
as his time come and comforted him that would drink / but he did that more for
usage of the countraye / than for any liking that he had therynne / and he
left not of the boost of the normans but he had knights about him where he
would we^de He said his mass every day and the sauter also / and memoryes and
minds of famous saints departed a seuene by the seuene hours of the day / As
often as he was at wyrcetre he would sing the hye mass / and said that he
would not leave that office for to resygne the bisshopriche / he would be at
collacio^ of monks / and made the general confession with other / and yaue the
beneson / and goo in to his chamber / when he rode on his horse he would say his
sawter / and beneson that englissh men makyth on the cup. he spared it not
at kings board / if need droof him to plede in any manner time / he would
bydde crstes curs to al evil arbytrours and moyens / but to all the good he
would bydde crystes blessing / he used furs of simple price / and rought but
little of wh^t manner skynnes / but be vsid more skynnes of lamb than of other
beestes / and if one had counseyled him sometime that he should use skynnes of
cattes / he answered in his game and said / I herd sing in the church of
gods lamb and not of gods catte / therefore I love better the heete of the
lamb than I do the beete of a catte / In a time his monks went in the more
church that he had builded / and he saw that the old church was destroyed
that saint oswald had bylded and wept full soore teres / He was in fair manner
wythsayd of that deed / and it was said unto him that he should rather be glad
that his church had so great worship in his time / And also as the houses
were more / so were the moo of monks / He answered and said I mean al other
wise than ye do / we wreches destroy the works of holy saints for to get
us a great name and praysyng of men In that time they used not to build / no
hostful buyldynges / But they used to offer them self to god under that roof
what it ever ewre / and and to draw their subgettis to their own ensamples /
but we do the contrary and gader stones to hepe and retche not of souls In a
time he made a sermon of the pees to the people / and many men turn to love
and to pees / But one there was that would not be acorded in no wise / another
for reasonne another for skyll another for prayeng of the bishop / he stood
before the bishop / and the bishop said to him / It is y wryt^n that men of
pees ben blessed / Than they that been not men of pees be wr^tches and the
deuyls children / Than till thou amend the / I betake the to him that has the
as his own child / And anon as he was made the enemies manciple / he byganne
to lygge and to foam / to grysbyte and to grynde with his teth / and to cast
his head about Wulstan heeled him again / but he would not of peace / Than the
fend had him efte and the third time till he had foryeuen all manner trespaas
/ In a time lanfrank put against wul-stan of lettrure / And the archebisshop
of york Aldredus chalengyd of him lawful subjection / and he went out of the
palace / and said the hour of none that he had behind and came again boldly
/ and answered and had the mastrye / One Alwyn that leuyd as an anchor at
maluerne hills had great will to take the weye to the holy land and told
his counseyll to Bishop wulsta^n / the bishop answered nay / and said leave of
Alwyn with thy good will / trow thou me / thou would have great wonder if
thou wist / what god thinks to do by the / he did by his read / and went
thennes^ and gadred thyrtty monks in the same place / A shipman that hight
Sewulphus shroof him to wulsta^ often of the same sins / than the bishop
said I see well that ese makes a thief / therefore I counseyll the that thou be
a monk / He would not for it was an hard life / Go quoth the bishop / whether
thou wolt or no thou shall be a monk / and so it happed afterward / In a time
wulstan groped the heed of one nycol that was his own nory / that byganne to
wexe balled right in his yongthe / wulstan said to him / I trow son that
thou shall be balled in short time / Than said he / fader why kepyst thou not
my here and make it abide. Sone quod the bishop trow thou me / the other dele
of thy here shall abide while I am alive / and it happed that the same weke the
bishop deyde / That here of Nycols heed fill awey and lofte not on his heed
but the bare skyn After wulstans death when all the church was a fire / there
fell neither ysel nor spark another soote upon wulstans grave / and so it ferde
of the matte that was under him / when he badde his bedes / Of him it is said
that king william the conqueror would have pryued for vnsuffysaunt lettrure /
And also for he couth no Frenssh and cast in that manner to bring in sum nor
man's in his stead / Then wulstan took his cross / and pyghte it in the hard
stone at saint edward the kings feet that lay there in his grave / he pyght
so the cross / that no man it might take out of the stone er he took it him
self at the kings heeste / While he pyght there the cross / he said to king
william a better man than thou art / betoke it to me / and I take it to him
again / take it awey now if thou might /

Capitulum 9
THis year was the going to Jerusalem / in the which journey was beamund / and
Robert duc of normandy / By cause of that iourneye Robert leyde normandy to
wedde to his brother william for ten thousand pound of silver / Thereafter twelve
days before Iuyl Christian men took the cite Acon / and in the month of october
stella cometa that is a sterre with a bryghte blasyng creest was seen fyften
days / and many men saw the sign of the cross brennyng in heaven / That time
saint steuens heed was brought to Cadony in normandy and that with many great
miracles / Among that hight Odo brought thither that holy heed / Henricus
libro septimo / There fill stryf between king William / and ancelm the
archebisshop for Ancelm most make no synodes another correct trespaas / Also
the king chalengyd the inuestiture of prelates and pylled and shaued the people
with trybute / and specially to spend about the toure of london / and about
the great hall of westmynstre / Also the kings meyne grieved the people over all
where they went /

Willelmus de Regibus libro quarto / And yet herto the rote and norysshyng of
couetyse of Ranulph that was sometime the first king williams priest and his
chapellayne was made thus his procuratour in every place / If this Ranulph
should gadre the kings trybute / he would take such two as reasonn would / He
pylled the rich / and bare down the pore / and dysperagid herytages and took
hem in to the kings hand / therefore the king bourded in a time and said that
he was a man alone / for he couth so torn his wit that he rought of no
man's wreche while he might plese his ^orde at full / By his doing holy
dignytees were sold / and sone thereafter he bought the bisshopryche of durham
for a thousand pound / That time they used strowtyng locks and long blasyng
clothes / gay sporres and sharp / tho men yede tryppyng showing the sides /
Ancelm would amend all this and had no help of his suffragans / and therefore he
went out of england / but by heste of the king in his going in a haven of ke^t
he was pylled and robbed and faren with as it were a thief / His males were
serched / his bouges and his trussyng coffers and all that he had / Then
ancelm went to pope urban in great counsel at barus in apulea / he declared
clerly against thoppynyon of the greeks that tellyn that the holy ghost comes
of the fader and not of the son / Willelmus de pontificibus libro secundo
That time Raf bishop of Chichestre spared not the king another the bisshops
that hold ageynste ancelm / but he spak for Ancelm and wythsayde the king to
his own face / and dradde right naught / he showed forth his cross and his
ring and cesed never nether slaked the great doing of his wit / er ancelm in
his going had brought his cause to a good end / And also this would he not
assente that the king should take tribute of prestes that vsyd fornycacion / but
in all his dyocesy the service of holy church was suspendyd and the church
doors were stopped with thorns / the king was awelded by grymnesse of that
deed So that he granted to him aloone the trybute of his priests / Also he
aleyde that the church that is destroyed and burnt should not be pylled and
robbed with trybutes. but it should be releued and helped with fre yeftes / And
the king that had take from al chirches / he yaue gladly to raufes church
many great yeftes / This Rauf spared not to blame mysdoers for her sins and
if his blamyng halp but little / he would destroy the sin wyttyly / with game
and with myrth^ he would go about his dyocyse thryes a year / but he pylled
not his subgettis by might or by maystry / but what they would freely give him
he took it with good will / Hereof would I not speak at this time nether that it
should be acounted a miracle now in our age to find in a bishop besinesse of
prechyng and reasonable receiuyng / Willelmus de re / li / 4 Will / de regibus
libro quarto / In a time when king william went an huntyng / there came a
messager and said that Cenemonia was besyeged^ Anon the king turned his horse
heed and took the wey straight to the sea / the lords counseylled him to
gader an host / I shall see quoth he who will follow me / and went so to the sea well nyghe alone / The weder was derke and the wind was against him / but
he would needs sail over / and shipmen cou^seylled him for to abide the wind
and the weder / I herd never of a king said he that was adreynde / but take
up your ankers / and array you for to sail / and ye shall see that the eleme^tes
make hem ready to my service / So he passed the sea / and they that besyeged
Cenomania herd of his coming and brake the syege / Helyas the master of that
treson was take and brought before the king and the king spak gamely to him and
said master now I have the yet is by hap quoth he that thou have take me /
I wot what I would do might I ones escape / The king was wroth and said go
thy wey and flee / I grant the to do what thou may and if thou ouercomest
me / I shall acorde with the / For the king did such deeds / that if it might
stand with the feyth of holy church / ye would wene / that Julius cesars soul
were passed and come^ in to this king as I trow sometime that euforbins soul
passed in to pyctagoras / Hen. li / 4 / This year at fynchamstede in
barrockshyre a well was y see well blood fyften days / And al a night heaven
was seen brennyng a fire / Also this year hugh and hughe earls of shrowesbury
and of chestre took the ylande mon that hight Anglesye also / and slew
walsshmen that were therein and of many they cut of their genetoryes / and
put out her eyes / Among the which they took a priest that hight kynredus
and drew him out of the church and put out his one eye / and kytte of his
genetoryes and his tongue / But by miracle of god he had his speech afterward
the third day /

That time the great king of the norganes the son of Olanus took with him
harald that was sometime king haraldes son / and took the ylandes orcades and
menanies / and thennes in to mon / there the twey forsayde earls were. the earl
of shrowesbury went against him and was smite with an arow right in to the eye
and deyde the eight day after that he had kydde his wodenesse of the foresaid
preeste / and he was beryed at shrowesbury / / W / de p li / 2 About that time
Robert losang that had be sometime abbot of ramsey and was then bishop of
tedford was a great nory for symony for he had bought the bisshopryche of the
king / but afterward he was sorry and bywepte the vnskylful rest of his yongth
and took the wey to Rome and come home again and changed and tornyd his see
from Tedford to norwiche / And he founded a solempnel abbaye with his own
catell and not with the catel of his bisshopryche / But at Tedford he ordained
monks of cluny that were rich in the world and clear of relygion to god ward
And so herbart was amended by double saw of warning / that one was of his
predecessor herfast / and was this / not this but barabas / And the other was
his own and was this / friend whereto art thou come / He herd this and wept
and said / I come in an evil manner / but by gods grace / I shall goo out in
good manner / and had often in mind the word of Ierom that said we erryde in
our yongth / amend we us in our elde / Henricus libro quarto / Than king
william came out of normandy / and when he saw first the great halle of
westmynstre / he said that it was to little by the half / and therefore he had
cast to ordeyne it for his chamber /

Capitulum 10 /
About this time began thordre of white monks in burgoyne in the dyocyse of
Cabyloneus / that order is cleped order Cystersiensis in latin and bygan in
this manner / W / de r / li / 2 One steven hardyng of the nation of england monk
of shyrburn from his childholde went in to scotland and afterward in to
france / there he learned lyberal scyences and took the pryckes of the love of
god and went to Rome at last with one of his scole feres No greef might
depart them tweyne / No thing them let that they nold every day say the
sauter / It sprange in his wit as it came forth afterward / For he came in to
burgoyne and in to molys in the great new abbaye / he threw awey the here /
there he took lightly the points of the rule that he had seen before / And
when he saw other put forth to be holden and kept that he had never seen
/ another herd in saint benets rule / he inquired the skylle and the reason
thereof soberly as a monk should and said / the higher worcher made al thing by
reason and gouneth al thing that he made by reason / by reason the elementis have
their being and the sterres also meoueth by reason and kepyn their course by
reason / And so should our kind stand by reason and falls of the reason by
sleuthe and uncunning and is y cleped ageyn by law to reason / and also by saint
benets rule / in the which rule is somewhat contained of the which I am not of
power to conceive the reasonne / but yet I hold that it be resonne to assente
to auctoryte / For the auctorytees of holy scripture ben alone though it seem
sometime / that they discord and god does nothing without reasonne / how shall
I than trow that holy father that folowyd cast ordained ought without
reasonne / As though we should give feyth to all^ one auctoryte and naught to
reason / Than of that ye do show so^me auctoryte other reason / and shows
ensample of saint benets rule / if ye mow not / it is al ydel that ye make
profession / that is so noble and despise to follow the lore thereof / the
sentence of this speech passed from one to other and meoued many on lest / they
had run in veyn other should run in veyn / than it was demed that the
superfluyte of the rule should be take awey and only the marouh should be hold /
thabbot made him besy to make all assente / but it is hard to wreche up on
thoughts that is roted in of long time / Only eyghten monks and abbot hardyng
left that abbay and said that the clennes of the rule might not be holden in
place there riches were gadred and there plente of mete and deynk stoffed the
soul and the wit that should withstand / than they went to cisterus a place
that was to fore hond full of wode and of lands / but now there is a famous
abbay / the which abbay is hugely aduau^ced by help of the bishop of yve^ /
and afterward by help of the pepe^ R / Theraft the year of our lord a / M^ an C
/ and xxxv / one walt espek brout that order of white monks in to england /
and made at Ryual an abbay of thordre of Cysteraus that is thordre of white
monks W / de regibus li / quarto / These ben the obseruauntes that semyn hard
in that order / they shall were no manner furs another lynen cloth another woollen
that is small and soft as stamyn another breche / but in the wey one of hem shall
have on him twey curtels and a coule / though it be winter but if they wol they
may have less in sum manner time / they sleep clothed and gyrde and after
mateyns they go never to bed ageyn^ they dispose so the hour and time that
before lauds the day light begins to spring / anon after lauds they sing
prime / after that they go to ha^dwork that they do by day they make an end
thereof without candel light / none of hem shall be from hours another from
co^plyn / but if he be seek / after complin ye selerer and ye hosteler go
stilly out and serve the ghestes / thabbot does not him self / but nygh as he
grants to other monks / he is oueral present with his flok / but only at
mete and that by cause of ghestes / and then he is served but only with twey
messes / none of hem eteth blood another flessh but if he be seek / from the
thyrtenth day of September to the eester tide / they ete but ones a. day out
take the sunday / they go never out of their cloystre / but by cause of
hondwerk / they speak in no place but to their pryour or the abbot / they
put no gybletes to the hours of gods service out take placebo and dirige
for the deed / they use Ambros office and have charge of ghestes and of seek
men / First this abbot of molyce held streytely these ordenaunces and
compellyd other to hold hem also / but in time that come afterward the man
thought^ that he had be lykyngly nourysshed and sum of the monke^ knew well
his lust and lykyng / and procoured lettres of the pope of reuokyng by the
which lettres this abbot was brought again to his first abbay and all the
monks with him out take eight and made alberyk her abbot and hardyng her
pryour / But thereafter this steven hardyng was abbot there and bylded sixten
abbayes / and byganne the seuententh / That order encreced so that time / that
the monks of Cysteus were espied / of al monks the myrour of hem that were
goodly besy and repreef / and chastyng of sleuth / here they be clepyd ostrum
of the slow oostru^ hight tanu in frensshe

Capitulum 11
AFter vrba^ the second pascalis was pope eyghtene year and five months / In
his thyrtenth year he was prysonned / and his cardynals also / by the fourth
henry the Emperor that assaylled Rome / and the pope might not be delyuerd er
he had sworn fewte to henry the Emperor and byhight him the inuestiture and
prelates with the cross and with the ryng / and also that he should never curse
the emperor / and hereof he wrote him a pryuelege in this manner I enbrace and
take al holy writ the old testamente and the new law and the prophetys
the gospels / and the holy pystels / all the general counsel and decrees of
Bisshopes of Rome what they held / I hold / And what they dampne / I dampne
also / And namely that pryuelege that is more verily a pryuelege that is an
evil law that was sometime granted to henry we dampne it without end / W /
de p / li / 3 When william bishop of durham was deed the king yaf the
bisshopryche to one walter that had be the elder williams priest / and his
chapellayn / the king yaf him the bisshopryche for a thousand pound / Evil
doers that fled to saint cuthberts church / this drew hem out of church
and made monks sytte with him specially in his halle at mete and served hem
with mete that was forbode / and ordained wymmen to serve hem with her here
sprad byhynde that seemed wowyng gyglotes in clothyng face and se^blaunt / there
uneath escaped any that he was undertake / For if he turned awey his eye he
was clepyd an ypocryte and if be were assentyng or according with the myrthe he
was cleped a nyse man and a fool / but this is worthy to be gretely preysed
for by his procuryng saint Cuthberts body was take onte of the grave and
clothed in new clothing / and king of waldes ^eede was founden between his
arms / Osmund bishop of Salesbury deyed / Also this year the sea floode
sprange up by temse / and drowned many towns / the devil was seen and spak
with many me^ of the kyngys malice and of his hasty death / Willelmus de Regibus
/ libro quarto / The king was warned thereof and set little thereby / Also this
year hugh abbot of cluny sygh in his suenene king william brought before god
almighty and y dampened / Hugh the Abbot t^lde that to ancelm that was so ^xyled
/ Also this met that he was y let blood and bledde blood that dymmed the
sun / therefore he cried often saint mary and saint mary^ and awoke of his
sleep and badde bring light / and commanded that the chamberlayus should with
him abide / than the thyrdde day of August / the year of our lord enl^uen
honderd / and his kingdom thyrtene / and his age four and forty / in the
new forest he was shot of one walter tyrel that was his own meyneal that
would have shot to an heart and so the king deyd and few men wept for
sorrow / walter tyrel escaped and no man him pursued / and so the king was
laid in an horse bear and ladde to wynchestre / and his blood dropped down in
the weye as he was ladde / and he was buried within the toure of the
bisshopryche / That toure fyl down withynne a year thereafter / this man took
upon him great deeds and cast to do well gretter if the destyne of his life
had be escaped to make thereof a good end / Before the next day of his death
one axyd him where be would hold his myd wynters tide / at peyters quoth he /
For the earl of that place arayeth him for to wend to Jerusalem and would
borow money of him and lay his land to wedde / he would suffer no counseylle
of Bisshops should be made / he sold dygnytees of holy church in diverse manner
wise and held sum in his own hand / For on the day of his death he held
three bisshopryches in his hands caunterbury wynchester and Salesbury / and
twelve abbayes also And sum he let to ferme also^ He desired to be every
man's heir / he werned the trybute to rome for stryf that was in the church
of Rome between pope Urban and wybert the Antypope / Henricuslibro septimo /

And though he were light of deeds he was stable and stydfaste of works / so
that if he byhyght any man good other evil / he might be full syker of that he
had by hight / And though he was most coueytous of money / yet he did one
deed that is worthy to be kept in mind / For in a time an abbot was deed in
england / and twey monks gadryd a great sum of money / and went to the
king either to supplante other / to geete the Abbots office / and the thyrdde
went with hem in that entente to bring him home mekely that should be abbot /
These tweyne stood before the king / and the one behyghte more than that other
/ and the thyrdde stood stylle and spak never a word / And the king axyd him
what he would give / nothing said he / For I wol neither give neither promysse
/ Come nere quoth the king / for thou art worthy and none other to take so
holy a charge /

The other deeds that longs to king williams life look hem within Ancelms life

Capitulum 12
King wyllia^ the read used le^mans alwey and deyde without children / and his
younger brother henry was king after him / And waschose at wynchestre the fyfthe
day of August / and crowned at ^ westmynstre of morys bishop of london for
Ancelm was not there / this was get in wedlok the thyrdde year of his faders
kingdom / He spente his first yougthe in lyberal arts and scyences / His
brother wylliam had grieved him in a time and his fader conforted him in this
manner / Son weep thou not for thou shall be a king / Than in the last year
of his faders kingdom / and in the / xix / year of his age he was made knit of
his own fader and went with his own fader in to normandy and was at his
faders dyeng / Sone thereafter as it is said by fore / and his other brethren
were goon every in his side as it happed him at that time / therefore he had his
faders blessyng and his moders heritage and tresoure and drad the pride of his
br^theren but little / he bowyd him alweye to his brother robert for myldenesse
of heart / but robert groned alwey and trowyd lightly tale tellers^ and also
Robert spente in his knights soudyou^^ three thousand pound that were byquethe
henry in his fad^^^ testamente / Then henry was made king most by the help
of henry Earl of warwyk that was before his meyneal / He made holy church
free / but he held the forestes in his own hand / he held edwardes law with
the amendyng thereof he yaue the grievous pencions / he put out of his court the
men that used wimmens manner and restored ageyn in his court candel light / by
night that was left of in his faders time. and closed ranulph bishop of
durham in the toure of london and reconcyled ancelm archebisshop of caunterbury
that was so exiled / he chasted the false mesures of merchants and brought
forth the length of his own arm / he would fight more gladly with counseyl
than with swerd / he would ete to staunche his honger and not for gloteny / he
would never drink but he were a thirst / In him self and in his meyne alweye
he hated outrage of mete and of drink / After great stryf that was between him
and ancelm the archebisshop / he resigned to god and to saint peter the
inuestiture of prelates that was ^^ne by seculer hand / At last was made a
counseyl of bisshops at london / and strompettes were put awey and remeoued and
he wedded mold the daughter of malcolyn king of Scotland / Ancelm crowned her
queen upon a saint martyns day / Willelmus de p / li / tercio / This year deyd
thomas archebisshop of york and gyralde was archebisshop after him a lecherous
man a wytche and evil doer as the fame tellyth / For under his pyle when he
deyde in an erber was found a book of curyous crafts / the book hight Julius
frumeus / In that book he radde pryuely in the under tides / therefore uneath
the clerks of his church would suffer him be buried under heuene without holy church / Willelmus de re / li / 5 / In the mean time Earl Robert the kings
brother herd of the death of king william the reed / and came again out of
the holy land in to apulea and thennes in to normandy and arrayed him to wend
in to england / Than it was known / and many of the lords feigned sum small
occasions and withdrew hem privily and openly from king henry and clepyd him
godryche godfader and sent pryuely for earl Robert / And herto Rauf bishop of
durham that had been before prysonned / gate a roope and escaped out of the
toure of london / and went in to normandy and encouraged duc Robert ayenste
king henry / Will de regibus libro quarto This Robert was king william the
conquerours eldest son a little man of body with a fat womb / In his first
knyghthode he vsyd his faders manners / but afterward by heete of his young blood
and counsel of fools prycked him and he founded to have normandy while his
fader was alive / and when his fader warned it him / he went awey for wreche
and made often restes upon the countray. First his fader scorned him but
afterward he swore by the resurection of Christ and said Robert schort boot my
son shall be a noble man / For else had robert not that should he blamed / For
he was curtoys and fair of face of shap and of speech / mighty of strength and
sad of counseyl / but at last his fader was so wroth with him that he pryued
him of the heritage of england and left him uneath ther^dom of normandy / he
did many great deeds in the holy land / and was so wonderful in every place
that he might never be unhorsed by christian man another by paynym / Also at
Jerusalem in an ester even he stood among other men and abode the fyere that
was wont to come from heuene and tend sum man's taper / Than his taper was
y tend by doing and virtue of god / Therefore al men chose him king of
Ierusalem^ But when he herd of the death of his brother william king of
england / he refused the kingdom of Jerusalem / not by cause of reverence but
for dread of trauaylle or couetyse of the kingdom of England / Therefore him
happed never well thereafter in battle / Also in the coming again from
Jerusalem he wedded the daughter of william de auersana in Apulea a fair woman
of shap and lost her by an evil after few years / yet was said that he was
begyled by counsel of a mydwyf that kytte her breasts for great plente of
mylk that ran of her breasts when she had child / but she had a sone
tha thight william noble man of wit / Robert took great money for that marriage
and wasted it sone thereafter / Than he gadryd a great hooste in every side and
came in to england for to reave his brother henry the kingdom / and londed at
portesmouth but by mean of the wysest men of the kingdom pees was made upon
such a condition that Robert should have every year three thousand marc / and
whether of hem lived longest should be others heyr / if he deyde without heyr
male / but the next year after Robert came in to england / and at request of
molde the queen he forya^ that pension of three thousand marc / Then Robert
went again and was little y told of among the normans / so that the normans
prayed king henry to come against Robert / The king c^m and bynam him al
normandy little and little / Rone / Cane and faleys in the which cytees Robert
went burethely up and down Therefore they of ca^e were wroth and prayed king
henry for to come to them and closed their yates against Robert / Then Robert
fled to Rone with one squire alone and prayed help of the king of France /
and of the Earl of Flaundres / but Robert was helpeles for them and founded to
give his brother a battle and was overcome and taken and kept in ward seven
year to his lives end / and deyd in the castle of Cardef and. was buried at
Gloucestre

Capitulum 13
THis year Robert de Bolysme roos against king Henry / This Robert was the
grettest of the sons of Rogyer de mount Gomeryk earl of shrowesbury / Robert
strengthed his castles of shrowesbury of brugges of Arundel of tykenhyl / And
encouraged many walsshmen against the king / But within forty days the king
wan and took al these strengthes and overcome the walsshmen with yeftes and
fair byheestes / And compellyd this Earl Robert to forswere england / and he
sailed in to normandy / and sone thereafter william Earl of mortom in normandy
and of Cornewayle in England sailed to Robert in to normandy / For the king had
warned him the erldome of kente / These tweyne fautours werryd and did great
harm in normandy / King henry herd thereof and bynam the earl of mortom all
that he had in england and sailed thereafter in to normandy / and made it
subgette not without shedyng of blood / And prysoned the twey foresaid Earls
to their lives end that were men full of gyle and stryf and of wyles / than
king henry left^ great pees in normandy and came again in to england and made
sharp laws ayenste falls men and thieves / in the which laws is contained
lost and lesyng of eyes of pryny stones of fustes and of hondes / Than he made
subgette the Scotts the walsshmen / the britons of beyond see / and lowys
king of France / Than king henry lay in normandy and pope Calyxtus came nygh
to normandy among other causes for to have king henry sharply at answer for the
prysonnement of his brother Robert pilgrim of Jerusalem / But he had semely
answers and ceesed of that cause / Al manner arguing may be bond toward other
side by the facunde of the pleder the which facunde is with presents
specially lyghted / And for no pomp and boost should fail / the king made the
young sons of the earl of mellent appose the cardynals that were tho present /
and embryge him. and smar^e him with s^tyl sophyms / therefore the Cardynals
shamed not to knowleche / that there was more wit and cunnyng of clergy in
the west lands than they had herd of speak / Hugh earl of chestre king
wylliam the conquerours neuewe in his systres side deyde / and his son
Rychard a child of seven year old was Earl after him / Ancelm made a counsel
at london and put down many abbotes and forbade setting of dygnytees to ferme
/ and demed that Sodomytes should be acursyd every sunday / but afte^ward he
vndide that doing for pupplycacion of vice / that was norysshynge of more
hardynes to wicked hert^s to do such deeds / Also he forbede priests wives /
strif fill between the king and ancelm by cause that he would not sacre the
prelates that had take inuestiture of lewd men's hands / namely because that
the pope had forbode hit upon pain of cursynge / but giralde Archebisshop of
of york sacred such prelates / therefore ancelm was meoued and went to the pope
/ The countray of flaundris was destroyed with castyng up the grauel of the sea
/ therefore the flemynges yede about long time and had no place to dwell in /
therefore they prayed and had y granted of king henry a place for to dwell in
fast by twede in the eest side of england / but in the enleuenth year they were
turned in to west wales / For the mysbyleue of sum prelates / Saint
Cuthberts body was founden hoole and sou^de the year after his beri^ng / CCCC
and xiiij year / and between his arms saint Oswaldes heed was founden al
hoole and sound / The seuenthe day of Iuyn were seen four white cercles
about the son / That year the first weke of lenten on the friday at even was
an uncouth sterre seen schyne between the souche and the west and schoone so
every day in the same hour five and twenty days / Also a great beam was seen
come against that sterre out of the eest side / thereafter in cene thoursday
that sum me^ clopyn chere thoursdaye were seen twey full mones a little before
day one in the eest and another in the west / That year was a gasely stryf
between the fader henry emperor and his own son henry / so that the son
prysonned the fader / That year king henry came to becco / and ancelm was
acorded with him / and sent thennes in to england /

Capitulum 14 /
THis year the fourth henry the son of the thyrdde henry began to be
emperor among duche men / and reigned nynte^ year / he cast his own fader in
bounds in the which his fader de^d Also he took and prysonned pope paschal and
the cardynals as it is said before / therefore men trowyd that he deyde without
children though he had wedded mold when she was but five year old Henryes
daughter king of england / At last he reputed and resygned up the ryghtes of
holy church freely to pope calyx^ / and so as the sothe oppynyon tellyth ^e
exyled him self by his own fre will vnwyttyng his wife and deyd at chestre /
Ancelm made a counseylle at london and there it was ordeygned by assente of the
king that never after that time the king should not another other lewd person
make inuestiture with croos other with ryng

That time gyrald archebisshop of york / put his hondes between the hondes of
Ancelm Archebisshop of caunterbury / and did him obedyence. Than the tenth day
of August at london Ancelm sacred five bisshops in one day / the bishop of
wynchestre / Of salesbury of excetre / of herford and of glamorgan / That
happed not after plegyndus time This year king henry ordained that thieves should
be hanged and that falls money and falls seel makers should l^se their eyes and
her pryuy stones / and that penyes and half penyes should be round / Philip
king of france deyed / and his son lowys was king after him / Girald
archebisshop of york deyd and thomas the neuewe of the elder thomas was
archebisshop after him seven year / king henry made a bisshops see at Ely and
ordained there henry that had be bishop of bangor And for in that doing he
took a great dele of the bisshopryche of lyncoln / and gaf Cambryggeshire to
the sea of ely / therefore he yaf the bishop of lyncoln his own ryal town of
spaldyng That year dyed saint hugh abbot of cluny in the eester weke / After
that our lady and saint peter and saint hillarye had apeyred to him Willelmus
de pontificibus libro primo / / That year dyed ancelm Archebisshop of
Caunterbury / And the next day after that fill the Cene thoursday / he was
enoynt with bawme that god sent down from heuene / And so he was beryed / And
than the sea of Caunterbury was void full five year / And in the mean time holy
church good was spente in the kings use / And when the king was meoued to
help the church that so was hedles as it were a wydowe / he would put it of
with a meke answer / and say that his fader and his brother had made
Archebisshops the best men that they could find / and that he would not goo
out of kind / but he would make archebisshop the best man that he might find
/ Such answer seemed full of law and of right / but the great so^me of money
that was ar^red of the archebisshoprych^ plesyd the kyngis herte^ though emerus
monk of Caunterbury had write and descryued saint ancelms life at full / yet by
the help of william malmesbury somewhat mot be said of so noble a man / Than
ancelm was born in the Cite August fast by the hills that hight Alps / and
was lettred and chaste of his childehode and had his fader^ wrethe and might
plese him in no manner wise / wherefore he fled awey fer from his fader and came
to becco in normandy / And was favored under la^fra^k priour of becco / and
was made monk there in his six and twenty year / After three year lanfrank
pryour of becco was translated to the abbaye of Cadony / And ancelm was made
pryour under abbotte herlewyn / Then Ancelm yaf him to penance and to
fasting and to techyng of children namely fyften year and would say full often that
him was lever to be in hell without sin than in heaven with sin / he made
many books of clergy in the which our believe that other men make hem besy to win with aucterite / he strengthed with reasons and arguments that may not
be assoylled / So that he passyd not only her works that were before him^ but
also be gadred her works al in to one hepe / Also ly wit and pacyence he
overcome the malice of his enemies / After the fyftenthe year of his priory
herlewin Abbot of becco deide and ancelm was made abbot in his stead and held
him five year out of england / though his coming were nedeful for many manner
causes lest that it should be demed that he converted the archebisshopryche of
caunterbury that wided tho by lanfranks death But at last for three manner
causes he was compellyd for to come in to england as it is said before / That
time in ^nglonde was Robberye under king william the reed and pr^scripcions /
and exylynges and taking in to the kings hand / For it were esyer to by waill
the Empire of one man alone than be under new lords that comen one after
other / Among all this was great silence among the bisshops / The ryghtful
dome was choked within the conscience of hem that might not other durst not
spek^ for dread of one man / For what prouffyt is hit for to speak there thou
shall arere wreth / and win no proufyt / then was hope for to escape all this meschyef if the banyonr ancelm that was first common child were made
archebisshop / King William put of all that was well said to him with swellyng
wreth other with myrthe and curtosye of speech / he suffryd do no bedes for
him / another for the state of holy church / but he said pray ye what ye wol
/ I shall do what me lyketh / At last he was take with a great sickness and
sent for Ancelm / and by assent of bisshops he ordained that he should be
Archebisshop and he wythsayde it / and alayde for him in this manner / if a
young sheep that is Ancelm shall be coupled and yocked to a wild boole that is
william the reed / for they draw not al like / the solouh of holy church
shall not goo a right / But Ancelm took the inuestiture and was sacred / but he
recovered of his sickness and was wors after than before / his friends
cou^seylled him to good / and he used to answer and say / per vultum de luca
/ god shall never have me good / for the harm that he does me / Also this king
was a Rauenour in gadryng and a great waster in spendyng / he fered despytously
every man that proferyd him ought / but the yefte were great and acordyng to
his own heart / So in a time saint ancelm proffered the king five honderd pound
/ and he would not take it / Than Ancelm deled it to pore men / diverse wondres
were seen in to al england / for at shrowesbury was a great earth shaking / and
a^ notyngham from the erly morrow tide to under of the day / The River of
Trente was so fordryed that men might goo therouer dry foot / And stella
cometa that is a sterre with bright bemyng creste was seen three hoole wekes in
the month of Iuyn /

Than was an hard winter / strong honger. death of men / pestylence of beestes
and fyghtyng of fowls that fought to geders / king henry builded the abbay of
hyde without the walls of wynchestre that was before within the cite / This
year the fourth henry emperor of almayne / wedded molde king henryes daughter
at magounce the syxth day of Ianuar /

Capitulum 15
THe fyftenthe day of October fylle great defaute of watre in England / so that
horse and men might wade between temse bridge and the toure of london that
dureth a day and a night / Willelmus de pontificibus libro tercio / This year
was a counseyl at wyndesore and the king ordained faricius abbotte of abyndon
to the sea of Caunterbury / but the charge of that deed come to the examynynge
of bisshops / and they put before him Raaf bishop of Rochestre / Also that
year one thurstan was chose archebisshop of york / the king charged him often
that he should do lawful subjection to rauf Archebisshop of Canterbury / but
him was lever leave the dignyte than be obedyente to the Archebisshop of
Caunterbury / But whaune he was pryued and had no service as he was wont / he
was agreued and for thought that deed full soore / and folowyd the king over see
/ there by procuring of thurstynes clerks / pope pascal sent a letter to the
king for to restore thurstan ageyn / when he was efte come to the sea of york
yet he had scorn to do lawful obedyence to the Archebisshop of Caunterbury /
than the old stryf was renewed ageyn / first there the pope promised to the
king of england and to Raaf Archebisshop of Caunterbury that he would nothing
ordeyne against the dygnyte of holy church of Caunterbury / Willelmus libro
secundo / But it seemed that he granted a pryuelege in this manner / Of all the
autentyk grauntes that your church has y granted of our predecessors / we
wol nothing wythdrawe. but will that it stand and be kept without any wemme
/ Here if the pope has said your church has these. dygnytees and these he
had assoylled the plee and the stryf / but now he leueth / the stryf al
vnassoylled / So the gyleful speak of Romans can torn him self to the
walls of pleders / So that him lyketh he would suspende in veyn and leave hit
in doubt / and spares net the cost and trauayll of other men while he casts
for his own prouffyte and advantage / therefore when the kings messagers were
goo / the pope was bowyd other for favor other for yeftes more gylefully than
so great a man should and forsook the rule of old time and sacred thurstan
and yaf him the pal / Willelmus de pontifici^us libro tercio King henry had
great indignacion thereof and forbede thurstan his land / but he was aferd by
the popes lettres / in the which it was contained / the king should take
thurstan owther be acursyd and suspended by the dygnyte of the office of
Caunterbury^ Willelmus de pontificibus libro primo / King henryes first wife was
deed / Than he wedded the dukes daughter of lotharyngia / In the day of the
weddyng Raaf Archebisshop of Caunterbury that was wrethful and acombred with
the palesey and sygh the bishop of Salesbury reuested to do the solempnyte of
that weddyng / and made him leave of that deed / and ordained the bishop of
wynchestre to do that office / than the next day thereafter he saw king henry
crowned against his conscience / and went to him and said / thou art
vnryghtfully crouned / therefore thou shall leave thy croune other I shall leave the
mass / Fader quoth the king / amend thou that is mysdoo / Than Raaf spared
uneath for prayers of lords / but he had smyten down the crown of the
kyngis heed He was a steadfast man of good living of lettrure and of fair
speech without suspection of any trespaas that was known / but that he vsyd
more laughyng and playeng than it seemed his state and his age / and he was nygh
cleped a Iaper / the winter was hard / so that many brydges in england were
broke in thawynge of the yse / In the month of may came so many flies / and
flyed about in the land of Jerusalem that they ete and destroyed vynes trees
and corn / And when they had do her journey a day sum fly and sum
yede on her fete to her herb row at even / In ytaly was an earth shaking that
dured forty days / so that many houses were thrown down / and a great town
was meoued and heue fer out of one place in to another / Pope pascal deyd /
Johan gaytanus was pope after him / This was the rather popes chaunceler and
was cleped the second gelasius and was pope a year and an half / Henry the
emperor herd that his pryuelege of the inuestiture of prelates was with
cleped and went to Rome to take more grievous wreche of pope paschal and herd
of pope paschalis death / And* put one morys burdyn in to the poperyche / This
morys was bishop of bache^ / and the emperor cleped this moris the seventh
gregory / For dread of the emperor pope gelasius left Rome / and sailed to
give and went thens on his feet to cluny / and deyd there / the Cardynals than
there took Gy / Archebisshop of vyen / and made him pope / and cleped him the
second kalyxte. R / Also this year dyed florencius monk of wyrcetre / by his
study and trauayll this story is gretely y hight / Great stryf was between the
kings of England and of france and henry king of England overcome the king of
france ryally in battle / Willelmus de p^. libro quinto / Here after king
henry married his eldest sone william to ful^oes daughter duke of angeo / Than
was pees made between the kings / For this william held normandy of the king
of France / and did him homage / For that land by grant of his fader king
henry / For the king was so great / that he would not do homage to the king of
france for normandy / Than king henry made his fre men of england and of
normandy to do homage to his son william / than men hoped thereby that king
edwardes profecye should be fulfilled in this william / In that prophecye it was
said that when the tree that is kytte comes to the stok again and spryngeth
/ than shall be hope of remedy / but that was blende by chaungyng of the hap
of mankind / For after that the king had dwelled three year in normandy / this
william was adreynt / Also that time this Earl Fulco went to Jerusalem and
bytoke the erldom of angeo to the king of england to keep to the prouffyte of
his son in law if he come not again /

Capitulum 16 /
THe second calyxt was pope five year and five months / ^e gadred strength
in every side and took and prysonned morys the foresaid antipope and made first
set him upon a camel and turn his face toward the camels tail / And so he
rode / and held the tail in his hand instead of a brydel and roode before
the pope / Willelmus de regibus libro quinto ^ About th^s time began thordre
premostracensis / that is the order of white chanons and bygan in the dyocesy
laudunensy^ under the fader nothbert of the nation of Coloyn / About this time
deyd mold queen of england / First she was learned lettrure and was nourysshed
among menchons / at wynchestre / for to put of unworthy marriage / that her
fader proffered her often time / she bare the veyle of holy auowe / therefore king
henry would have her to wife / that doing fylle in great desputyson / and ancelm
wythstode that marriage till it was preued by lawful witness that she took the
veyl for to put of wowers and for none other cause / This had twey children at
one byrthen a son and a daughter / and cessed of children beryng / than she
dwelled at westmynstre and was found as a queen by the kings will / But she
were the here under the ryal array and yede barfote to church in the lent
time and was not squaymes to wesshe seek me^nes fete and grope soore botches
with her hondes and kiss the seek men and set to hem a mete board and serve
hem / Also she loved much gods seruyse / therefore she spente much on clerks
that couth well singe / therefore famous men of scole come to her with versus and
with song as it were out of al lands / Also she spente largely in comers
that came of every side / Desire of praysynge is so kyndely pyghte in men's
hertes / that uneath any man though he be of good Conscience hold him apayd
with the fruit of his good works / but yet he has liking that the people
know of his good deeds / by cause of such deeds she pyled her plowe men / but
that may be wist by the counseylle of her mynystres

Willelmus de Regibus libro quinto / The syxthe day before december at harfleet
In normandy up goo the ankers / and the king sailed graciously in to england /
His son william would sail after him / and was adreynte and many noble men
not fer from land. / The kings son Rychard bastard was among hem and nota
the contesse of Percy / and Rychard Earl of Chestre and his wife that was the
kings niece / and the Archedeken of Herford / and other in the nombre of an
honderd and forty / Of hem all escaped none but one chorle bochour that
swamme al night upon a broken maste / and came to the clyue in the morrow tide
/ and told all the geste / how it was byfalle / All these went by night in
to a new ship with dronken shipmen / and fylle anon upon a rock not fer from
the land / and the ship to cleef / And william the kings sone was do in a boat in the which he might have be saved well enough / but when he. came to the
clyf he herd his sister weep and cry / than he turned ageyn and took her in
to his bote / Than other men starte in to that boot / and ouerlode it and
drowned the boat and all that was therynne out take the foresaid chorle / But it
was wonder that great tresoure was founden fast by the clyues in the morrow /
and none of the deed bodies were found / but they were al eten of the ffysshes
of the sea / Henr / libro septimo / And it was said that nygh al these were
sodomytes / William / And also this william the kings eldest son had manaced
Englyssh men that if ever he were lord over hem / he would make hem draw as oxen
at plowe / R / Also Rychard earl of Chestre had manaced that when he were
^^me out of normandy / he would destroy the monks of Chestre that his fader
had ordained there / W / de re / li / 5 Herafter fulco earl of Angeo / whoos
daughter william that was drowned had wedded come out of the holy land and
married his other daughter to Robert short hooses son / and yaf with her the
Erldome of Cenomannia / For king henry withhelde his dower in England /
Herafter / Henry married his daughter mold to the fourth henry Emperor of
Almayne / This year king henry made a greet park at Wodestode / When
Rychard Earl of Chestre was drowned / the first Ranulph de mescheues / the sone
of the first hughe was earl eight year after him / Raaf Archebisshop of
Caunterbury dyed and william Canonicus was Archebisshop after him / About this
time began the order of the templers / These were gadred of the Releef of the
hospytalers / and ordeygned hem a place in the porche of the temple of
Jerusalem / therefore they be cleped knights of the temple / these were
sustained by the Relief of the hospytalers both in mete and in armure / and
wax so rich that it seemed that the daughter passed and wyryed the mother /
At last for vile apostasye and despysyng of Christ / they were destroyed in
the fyfth pope Clements tyme^ the year of our lord a thousand three honderd and
twelve / Henricus libro septimo / Johan Cardynal of Rome came in to England and
made a grievous process against priests concubynes and said that it is a foul^
sin and a great to arise from a strompettes side to sacre crystes body / but
the same day after that he had song mass he was taken with a strompet at even
/ thing that was openly y know might not be forsake / Hit most needs be
known if this dysplesyth any man / I reed him hold his peace / and be stylle
lest it would be demed that he follow Johan in words / and in deeds / After
kalixt the second honorius was pope five year / The fourth henry the Emperor
of almayn is deed / and some men tellyn that he is buried at spyre with his
forfaders with such writing on his tomb / Here lies the son and the fader
and the grauntsyr and the faders grauntsyre. R / But it seems / that Gyrald in
his book itinerario wallie has the more soth understanding / there he says
that this henry after that he had emprysoned his flesshely fader / and his
goostly fader the pope / and the Cardynals also / him repented at last and
went awey vnwytyng his wife mold of England / and exyled him self by his good
will / and lived at Chestre ten year as an heremyte / and by cause he would not
be known the while he was alive / he cleped him self godestal that is gods
clepyng / when the emperor was so pryuely goone / mold the Emperyce came
again to her fader king henry in to normandy / there she was soon married to
geffroy plantagenet Earl of Angeo / and hadd by him the second henry that after
him was king of England /

Capitulum 17 /
When the fourth Henry was goo Lotharius duke of Saxon was made Emperor /
At london was made a counseylle / and it was granted to king henry / that he
should do right of priests fornycaryes / and of her concubynes But he did not
else but took money in every syde^ That year in presence of the king the
lords of England swore / that they would keep the kingdom to his daughter
molde the emperyce / if she lived after his day / and if he deyde without
other children / Saint mathys the Apostles body was founden in the Cite Treuer
/ the which body Agricius the archebisshop had brought thither out of
Constantinople in the elder Constantynes time / and he had that body of the
yefte of Helene the queen / After Honorius the Second Innocencius was pope
thyrtene year and seuene months / Peter leonis that hight Anacletus also
assaylled the Poperyche / and so fylle greet strife in holy Church / This
Anacletus was chosen of the less deele and party / and chaced Innocencius
out of the cite / And spoiled the chirches of Rome and meded the Romans with
the money of the chirches / But Innocencius and the Cardynals woned with the
king of France / and made a counseyll at Rome and in his coming again he
crowned lotharius duc of Saxon / and sacred him Emperor / By his help he
chaced Rogyer duck of Sycilya and of Apul^a that was rebel to this Innocencius
the pope / when the first Ranulph Earl of Chestre was deed / his son the
second Ranulph Gercious by his surname was Earl after him five and twenty year
/

The Earl of Flaundres deyd / and Henry king of England by the assent of the
king of France had the Erldome after him by right of blood and of kynrede
/ Mold the emperyce was soon forsake of her husbond Geffroy / and went to her
fader in to normandy / there the king saw three wondre syghtes / Fyrsts he saw
in his sleep many clerks assaylle him with toles and axe of him debt / Efte
he saw a Route of men of Arms that would refe on him with all manner wepen /
the third time he saw a great company of prelates manace him with their
croyses And at every time the king start up of his bed and caught his sword
and cried help / as though he would slay sum men / but he might no man find
/ Also a phisician grymbald by his name saw all these syghtes / and told hem
to the king erly in the morrow / And as danyel had sometime chargyd
Nabugodonosor / So he chargyd the king that he should do alms deeds in
remedy of his sins / Then the king went in to England and was sore
trobled with tempest in the sea / and made his auowe that he would relece the
danes trybute for seven year / and that he would vysyte saint edmund / and do
and use ryghtwysenesse / In France was so great drought / that Ryuers and
wells were fordryed / Also fyere come in to the chynes of the earth that might
not be quenched another with wete another with cold / another with doing of craft
/ This year at kerdef dyed the kings brother Robert that was sometime Earl of
normandy and was beryed at gloucetre before the hye Auter / William the son
of nychellus founded the pryorye of norton in the prouynce of chestre / Also
thabbay of Cumbremer was founded in the same prouynce / And henry short mantel
is born the son of the Emperyce / King Henry deyd in normandy / Of him one
moeued in meter in this manner / King henry deyd fayrenesse sometime now deol of
the world / Gods now wepyn for her god that is now deed / marcurius the
less. in speech / heart strong as appollo / Jupiter in hest and mars in
strength / greueth England in childhode and kingdom right of this godde was
high in shynyng for derk now falls a down This land with his king / normand
with his duke well with awey / This land nouryssheth the child / that other now
lesyth the man / Henr / li / 8 / When king henry was deed men demed of him and
spoke freely / what they would as they do of other men when they be deed /
Sum said that he passed other men in three things in wit / in spech and in
