fortune of batayl / Other said that he was overcome with three vices / with
couetyse with cruelnesse / and with lust of lecherye / Also the kings bowels
were draw out of his body / and his brain taken out of his heed / and the
body salted with much salt / and for to avoid the stenche that had infecte
many men it was at last closed in a boole skyn / and yet might not the noyful
odor be let / But he that took out the brain of the heed deyd of the
stenche / he had eten of a lamprey while he was old and feeble and he loved it
alwey though it grieved him evermore / The kings body was brought in to england
and beryed in the abbaye of Redynge that he had founded out of the ground /
Henricus libro septimo / In this kings time one Simon the son of Robert
bishop of lyncolne was in his flowers deen in the same church / he was sharp
of wit / clear of speech / fair of face / and of shap and gracious with all
/ young of age and wise and ready / as an old man / but he was spytted with the
vice of pride / In him of his pride sprang envy of envy. wreth of wreth /
stryf and bakbytynge / he spoke in a time of him self and said / I am set
among me^ of court as salt among quyck elys / he took heed of one proprete of
that saw and was not war of that other / For als salt among eles greueth full
sore^ So he grieved men of the court with bacbytyng and evil speech But at last
when salt is destroyed by moisture of the el^s / So was he by hate of all men /
For at last he had the kings wrethe and was prysonned and escaped aweye by a
gonge / and was flemed and deyde so exyled /

When the first king henry was deed / steven Earl of boloyn was king after him
/ This steven was the earl of blesens son / king henryes neuewe in his
susters side / and he reigned seuentene year a noble man and hardy / but against
his oath that he had made to the emperyce he was crouned at london on a saint
Steuens day of william archebisshop of Caunterbury that was swore to the
Emperyce also / Therefore this william leued not over one year / Also all the
great that were sworen to steven made a wrechyd end / Also men said that in
the day of his crownement the sacrament of crystes body was brought to the king
and it vanysshed awey suddenly / king steven was crowned and swore before the
lords at oxenford / that he would not hold in his hand the prelacyes that
voyded / and also that he would foryeue the dane gylt and that he would emplede
no man for his own wodes / Also for he drad the coming of the emperyce he
granted every lord leave to bylde a Castle other a strength upon his own
ground / and sone thereafter he took to acorde david king of Scotts / that had
before by gyle taken the castle caerlel / and the castle upon tyne and he yaue
him huntyng in england and had hommage / and sent to the Emperyce / than king
steven took excetre and william Archebisshop of Caunterbury deyd / and theobald
abbot of becco was Archebisshop after him / Lotharius Emperor of almayne deyd
/ and Conradus was Emperor after him fyftene year of Almayns and of Romans /
And though he took not the Beneson of the pope / yet at prechyng of Abbot
bernard he took the holy land in pope eugenius time and did many great deeds
/ Gir / d / p / ca / 19 / That time theobald the mylde earl of Campania was in
his flowers / he would myldely vysyte pour men and lepres / One praised him in
meter passyngly in this manner / This fellow Earl this was that mylde man
theobaldus / Heaven makes joy / that him has / and sorrowful is the world /
that him leueth / I may call him man / him dar I not clepe God / Death preueth
him man his own life him preueth good / Above man / under God / more than man
/ less than God / I not what manner thing is between the weyne / /

David king of Scotland came the thyrdde time in to England and destroyed the
land anon to the River of theyse in the mouth of the prouynce of york / and
brende / and slew and slytte wymmen with child / thurstan the archebisshop
came pryuely against him with the kings knights / and chaced him and slew / x
/ M of his men and took many prays and gret^ / king steven took the Castle of
bedford that was ageynste him / and herafter he went in to scotland / and did
there few deeds at his own will / and came home ageyn / but in his coming
homeward / he took alysaunder bishop of lyncolne and put him in bounds /
til that he had give him the castle of newerk / Also ^e chaced nygellus bishop
of hely / and Roger bishop of salesbury that had do him much good / he
took him and put him in prison and held him there till that he had give him
two castles of the vyse and of shirburn / And for this Roger was a greet
bylder of houses and of Castles / he bycam seek and deyd for sorrow / After
that he left in his castles of money as it were a forty thousand marc /
that was spente in the kings use / and not to gods service / For with that
money the king bought to his sone Eustace / Constaunce the kings sister of
France / Thurstan the Archebisshop of york was a great foundour of abbayes of
hagustald of Founteynes / and of eight other / and took the habyte of monk /
and pountfret / and deyd in good elde / After two year his body was founden
hoole and sound smellyng full sweet / That time the king took the Castles of
Gloucestre of herford / of webbely of Brystow / of Dudely / and of shrowesbury
/ Robert Earl of gloucestre king Henryes bastard son herd thereof and sent
for his sister molde the Emperyce that dwelled at Angeo / and prayed her to come
in to england and byhyght her help against king steven /

Henricus libro 9 Than in the month of Iuyll Robert and mold came first to
portesmouth and thennes to Bristow / and did men of the Countray great harm
and dommage Than the king besyeged the castle of wallyngford / and herd hereof
and left the syege and went ageynste them and besyeged lyncolne soon after
that time / Than about Candelmasse Ranulph Earl of Chestre and Robert earl of
gloucestre came with many walsshmen to break the kings syege /

And when they were uneath passyd a reedy mareys. and had arrayed the
sheltrons / The Earl of Chestre spoke to his men in this manner and said I
thank you and pray you besyly that I that am cause of your peril mot be
the first that shall enter in to the peril / Earl Robert answerde him / and
sayde^ It is not unworthy that thou axyst the dygnyte of the first stroke both
for noblesse of blood and for virtue of strength in the which thou passyst
other men / But the kings falls ^the and his wodenesse meoueth men to war /
and to fight / But we may not torn again by the wey that we come / Than we
must have here the maystry other be overcome / he that has none other socour
must needs flee to bold deeds of arms and manhood of strength / but take heed against hem and what manner me^ ye must feyght / Robert earl of mellent
stondyth against you / he is crafty of fraud and of gyle and has wyckednes in
his heart / treason and gyle in his mouth and sleuthe in his deeds / there
comes also the earl of Albemarl / he is devout to bachus and not known of
mars / he smellyth of the wyn and vsyth no war / Treuisa Po^tes feyneth a
god of wyn and clepyn him bachus / and another of batayl and clepyn him mars
and so forth to speak / he that is a good drynker is devout to bachus / and he
that is not worth in battle is unknown to mars / Than he tellyth forth his
tale in the story in this manner / There stondeth Simon of hampton / his deeds
ben but words his yefte is but a by hest when is word is said he has done
his deed / / when he has behyght he has yeuen his yeftes / In this great
heete king steue^ herd alysaunder the bisshops mass and the tayre that the
king offered brake in the Bisshops hand / and the cheyne brake and the box fyl
there gods body was in / that was a token of the kings fayllyng / than the
king went forth and baldwyn the earl had the words to comfort men for to
fight / and he spoke to other men in this manner / Men that must fight must
know three things / the ryghtfulnes of the cause lest men should fall in
peril of soul / The quantite of the company that they be not boren down with
to many enemies / And the effect of might and of strength lest men lene upon
feeble help / and fall to the ground touching these three points / I trow
that we be spedde / But take heed ferthermore What manner enemies we have / Loo
Roberts counsel that vsyth great menace and does little in deed / in mouth he
is a lion and in heart an haar / he is clear of speech and derke by vncunnyng /
Also there stondeth therle of chestre a man of unreasonable hardynesse ready and
pressed to conspyracy / and vnstydfast to fulfill in deed / hasty of heart and
unware of peryls / he casts full great deeds and essayeth deeds that he may
not awelde / what he begins fresshely / he forsakes i^ feyntly / as a woman
unhappy and ungracious in every place and is alwey overcome other chaced / he
has with him flemed men and sculkers about the walsshe men ever the more ben
of hem / the wors they ben in fighting / But er he had made end of the words
come the cry of the enemies the noise of the trompes and the gruntng of horses
/ and the sheltrons smytyn to geders and forth goon tharowes / The king was
take and brought to the emperyce and was kept in bounds at brystow from
candelmasse to the holy rode day in heruest / therefore the emperyce wexeth swyth
proud / and occupied surcetre and than wynchester / there they came against her
with procession and that alowyd the popes legate / than she went to wylton /
to Oxenford to Redyng and to saint albon and in every place all men took her
with good will out take kentyssh men alone / But theobaldus the Archebisshop
came specially ageynste her / Than she came to london to trete of the state of
the land / there the queen of England king Steuens wife prayed the emperyce that
the king might be delyuerd out of bonds upon that condition that the king
should yield up the kingdom to the emperyce and somwher become a monk other be
a pilgrim to his lives end / But the emperyce would not here this bone / Also
the cyteseyns of london prayed her that they might use saint edwardes laws /
and not the laws of her fader king henry / for they were full hard / But she
would not assente / therefore the people was meoued and ordained for to take her /
she was ware thereof and left al her store of household and fled to oxenford /
and there she abode her knights that were al y shed or dyuyded / then she
took with her her own came david king of scotland and strength of knights /
and went to wynchestre / there she besyeged strongly the bisshops toure there
the kings brother was / At last came the queen with william I prens and the
emperyce was so aferd that she was born to gloucestre in an horse bear as it
were a deed body / her brother earl Robert was take and put in prison in the
mean time / than the queen on that one side was besy for the king / and the
emperyce in that other side for her own brother / and such delyueraunce was y
procured and ordained that the king should be restored again to the kingdom
and the Earl to his lordship / and both should make pees in the kingdom as
they had dystourbed it / But the earl would not assente / than all the year was
in the land Robbyng and reuyng / manslaughter and sellyng of Rich men / than
about holy Rode day in heruest the king was delyuerd and besyeged the
emperyce in the cite of Oxenford from mychelmesse to mydwynter and destroyed
all that was without At last fill a great honger and the Emperyce was couerd
in white and byspronge with snow and escaped over Temse that was froren and
hylled with snow and came to walingford / Therefore the men of the syege were
begyled and y blend with the blasyng of the snow / And so the cite of
oxenford was yolden to the king / About this time one master arnold preached
at rome against rich men and ageynste superfluyte that men vsen / therefore
many men pursued him / at last he was taken and hangyd for wreth of clerks /
Also that time deyd Johannes de temporibus that had lived three honderd year
three score and one / and had be squire with the great charles /

Capitulum 19
AFter the second Innocencius the second celestynus was pope five months /
after him lucius enleuen months / The thyrdde eugenius was pope eight year
and five months / This was first saint bernardes disciple and afterward
Abbotte of saint anastasy besides Rome. and came unware to saint Cesarius
church and was chocen by the Cardynals / but for dread of the Senators he was
sacred without the cite / This sygned lowys king of France with cross and made
a counseyll at Reme in France. Also to him saint bernard the Abbot wrote the
books de considere / Henricus libro nono Ranulph Consul of Chestre came to
walyngford with many knights / and was acorded with the king / But soon
thereafter he was gylefully taken in the parliament of northampton and might not
be delyuerd er he had yolden up the castle of lyncolne / That time the
walsshmen destroyed the prouynce of Chestre / but at wycumalba^ they were kylde
/ Soon thereafter king steven was crowned at lyncolne / and so happed no king
before / Also that year conradus the emperor lowys king of France the Earl of
flaundres and many other that had take the cross to the holy land / chesed
the land weye and not the water weye / And passed by hongary and were bytrayd
by fraud of the emperor of Constantinople / For many of them tasted mele
medlyd with lyme / and deyde and many other were deed by sword and honger /
For robbyng and reuyng and lechery / Giraldus de p / capitulo 18 Loys king of
France come homeward out of the holy land / and wexed seek for long
continence and defaute of women as leches said / and leches and prelates
counsayled him to take a wenche^ by cause he was so fer from the queen / Me is
lever deye said he chaste than live in spousebrekyng / and so he put all in
gods hand and was hoole anon / In a time a clerk came to him / and brought
to him a^ pryuelege of the pope that he should in every cathedral church of
his Reme have the first Benefyce that voyded with the fruit and prouffytes in
the mean time / Anon he threw the lettres in to the fire / and said that him
was lever brenne such lettres than have his soul tormented in hell / the
same prince fasted every frydaye to bread and water / and men counseylled him
to feed an honderd pour men on the friday and leave that fasting / We would
gladly feed so many pour men other more / but our fasting will we not break /
For all without the prouffyte that it does to the soul / hit profyteth much
to the body also / we do every weke so much and so many superfluytees in to
the body / that the purgacion and rest of one day helpyth much to put of
superfluyte / and also to make the sharper appetyte / When this lowys was deed
a vercifyour wrote on his tomb in short style a writing y hight with fair
spech of rethorik and turned his speech as it were to his sone phelip / and
showed him his fader that lay beryed there / and said / Nunc super tu qui
superes successorum honoris / Degener es si degeneris a laud prioris / that is
to say thou ouerlyuest this that art above successor of worship / thou art
unkind / if thou ghost out of kind of the praysyng of thy forfader / About
that time deyd master hughe de saint vyctor monk and pryour of saint vyctor
besides paris a parfyght man of lettrure and of Relygyon / Of him it is said
that when he was seek in his death evil / and might hold no mete another
drink he axyd besyly and prayed to give him gods body / his brethren would
ceese his cryeng and brought him an oubleye that was not sacred / he knew hit
in his spyryte and said god foryeue it you brethren why wol ye begyle me this
is not my lord / Anon they brought an obley that was sacred / he saw it and
might not hold and hened up his hands and said I pray that the son goo up
to the fader. and the spyrite to god that made him of naught / And so he yield
up the ghost / and our lords body vanysshed out of sight / R / But sum men
wol mean that this hughe might not hold for he was castyng aweye / and therefore
his brethren would not bring him the very sacrament / And he prayed hem
specially that they would set the sacrament upon his side / and when they
had so done the seek man's side opened and the sacrament went in by hit
self / This made many good books de sacramentis de Archa noe / de institucione
nouiciorum / de arra anime / de studio sapiencie / dydascalycon and de laud
crucis / he made a book also / Fr^st and yse was so strong that horses might
pass over temse / This year master gracianus de Tuscia / monk of Bononia was
borne / He compyled and gadred the book of decrees so says hugh / 296 / forma
/ His brother germayne master peers lombard Bishop of paris compyled and made
the four books of sentence^ and gloosed the sauter and poules pystles also

Capitulum 20
AFter Conradus the first frederyk was Emperor of Almayns and of Romans seven
and thyrtty year / After pope adryans death that him had crowned this was a
grievous enemy to pope alysau ndre / for in preiudyce of him / he held with
four falls popes each after other / Also by cause that the pope was fled to
the king of France / he fought ageynste the king of France with great
strength of boemes and of danes but he was put of by help of rychard king of
England / Than the year of our lord enleuen honderd three score and tweyne he
came to mylan that was the highest walled of any town / and destroyed it down
to the ground / At last after that this had do the pope many greues / he drad
the rebelnesse of the lombardes / And prayed foryeuenesse of the pope / and took
the cross in his flessh to the holy land as it were in amendment of his
sins / And he was drowned in a little river besides armenye / and beryed at
Tyrus / And his son a noble yonglyng deyde at the siege of tholomayda that is
Aron and nygh al^l the noble of christian men deyde that time / After Eugenius
Anastasius was pope as it were two year / That year deyd saint bernard abbot of
cleruaulx that was borne in burgoyne in the Castle of Founteyns He was a noble
knights son and was first fed with his own moders mylk and afterward
norysshed with greter metes Than the year of our lord enleuen honderd and
twelve after the beginning of the order Cistersiensis that is the order of
white monks fyftene / of his own age two and twenty / He entered with thyrtty
felawes in to Cystercy / and after the fyfte year of his conversation he was
ordained abbot of Clereuaus / There he used waking passing the usage of
mankind / he said that he lost no time more than when he slepte / he
lykened sleep to death / uneath that he might suffer him that routed and
aferde foul in his sleep / he went to mete as it were to tormente for great
abstynence that he used / he had lost his taste and savor of mete and of
drink / So that he would take oil instead of wyn and blood instead of
botter / he would say that hyin sauoured water for hit keled his mouth and his
Iowes all that he learned of Scripture / he drank hit in wodes and in feldes in
his medytacions and and beedes / he knowleched none other maystres that he
had butokes and beches / In his clothyng was pouert without any fylth He
said that clothing is Judge and witness of heart and thought of negligence
other of pride and vein glory / that proverb he had often in his mouth and
alwey in his heart al men wo^dryth of him that does that as none other does /
To the ^ouyce that should come to the Relygyon / he would say if ye hye to
that is within / leueth here without the bodies that ye brought of the world /
the spyryte shall enter / the flesh does no prouffyte As often as. men prayed
him to be Bishop he said that he was not his own / but that he was ordained
to service of other men / Alwey he was found other bidding other redyng /
other writing other in medytacions other prechyng and techyng his brethren /
The year of our lord enleuen honderd and three and fyfty / when his death
neyghed he bytoke his brethren three points to keep / and said that he had
kept hem in his wise al his life tyme^ and said / I would no man sklaundre /
but if any sklaunder were arise / I ceesed it what I might / I trow mine own
wit less than other me^nes dome / if I were grieved I axed no wreche of him
that had grieved me / Bernard wrote many noble books and specially of the
incarnacion of christ / and did many miracles / and builded three score Abbayes
/ and passed out of this world to our lord of heuene / Also that year deyd
the Second Ranulph that hight Gercious by his surname / he was the fourth Earl
of Chestre / after the conquest / his son second hughe was lord after him in
that Ducherye nine and twenty and did many great deeds / Also that year deyd
king steven in kente in the abbaye of Feuersham that he builded up of the
ground / In this steuens time a knight that hight owen went in to the
purgatory of the second patryk abbot and not bishop / he came again and
dwelled in the needs of the Abbaye of ludene of white monks in Irlond and told
of joy and of pains that he had seen as it is said before in the first
capitulo / 34 / of the wondres of Irlond

Capitulum 21
When steven was deed / the second henry was king / This henry was the first
henryes neuewe / the eldeste son of his daughter the Emperyce / and of
geffroy plantegeneti Earl of angeo. his manners and his deeds his virtues and
his vices gyrald Cambrensis in his dystinctions descryueth and says in this
manner / Dredeful it is to allegge against him that may put out of land / and
to descryue him with many words / that may exyle a man with a word / that
were a gracious thing and passing our wit and our strength to tell out the
soth in all his deeds and offend the princes heart in no manner point / This
henry was somewhat redyssh with large face and breast / and yelowe eyes and a dym
voys / and flesshy of body / and took but scarcely of mete and of drink / and
for to allege the fatness / he trauaylled his body with business / with
hunting with stondyng / with wandryng / he was of mean stature / Renable of
speech / and well y lettred / noble and orped in knygthode / and wise in
counseyll and in battle / and drad doutful desteny / more manly and curtoys to
a knight when he was deed than when he was alive / he showed more sorrow for
men when they were deed than love while they were alive / No man was more
goodly than he in meschyef And when he had efte seurte / no man was more
stern than he / he was cruel to them that were not chasted / and sometime
mylde to his subgettis / hard to his famylers and free herted to strangers /
large in yeftes outward and skars in pryuyte / Whom he hated other loved ones
uneath he would turn to the contrary / he would wylfully pass his own word
/ slow in all manner answer / and loved well pees and quyete / he bare down
gentilmen and sold and tarried ryghtwysenesse / vnstydfast of feyth /
chaungeable and gyleful of word open spousebreker / the hamer of holy church
alwey unkind to god / He norysshed strif among his sons with all business
and hoped to have peace alone by stryf of his children / if men axyd of al his
great deeds the world should rather fail than we should make an end / lauds
may ceese to a bold heart but vyctoryes can not ceesse tryumphes / and praysyng
shall not fail but the matter of wynnyng of worship may fail / he was pereles
and passing in chyualry in werre and in lechery / he pesed myghtly the lands
of his herytages / and wanne Irlond myghtly by strength / he took william king
of Scotland and joined the kingdom of Scotland to his own From the southe
occean to the north Islands of Orcades he closed all the lands as it were under
one principate / And spradde so nobly his Empire and made it full wide / After
Julius Caesar men read of noman that so happed by yonde the sea without
normandy / Gyan / Angeo / and Chynon in toureyne that fill to him by the right
of his fader and also peytow and gascoyne anon to mou^tes pyrenes the hills
of spain that fill to him by marriage / He made subget to his lordship aluerne
and other lands / He vsyd for to say that all the world is little enough for
a man that is strong and mighty / The kings of spain for to ceesse stryf put
her querel upon this kings dome / many of his deeds that were al against the
pees he brought to end at his own will as it were by warnyng of gracious ^ur
and by a chosen worcher of fortune / but many things happyd him as it were
ungraciously to his own meekness / if he would be repentaunt and else for he
should be tormented in his own flessh / the cruel bochour / First he took
wrongfully Elyanor the queen from her lord lowys king of france and wedded
her in deed / though he might not by the law and his own fader geffroy forbad
him and said that he should not touch her for he had lay by her him self while
he was the kings steward of France / Netheles this henry gate on her three
daughters and syx noble sons / The first daughter mold he married to the duk
of Saxon / The second Elyanor to the king of spain and the thyrdde Johan to
william king of Scicil. Also his twey sons were hastily take from him and he
was worthyly distourbed and grieved by the other four to his lives end / he
reigned nygh five and thyrtty year and so he had thyrtty year y give him to
wordly bless / and lykyng to suffraunce of Conversation and to assay of
devotion / and the years that were over the thyrtty year / were yeuen him to
greef and to wreche as to an evil man and unkind / For in the second year of
these five year the strength vanysshed aweye that he had ordained about the
sendyng of his son Johan in to Irlond / and the third he that lost never
thing lost aluerne against the king of France / the fourth year he lost bytu
rycam / the fyfth year the cytees Cenoma^nea and Turon and many castles thereto
and him self also / This king used to have in his speech of Tr^iys Relygyous
bisshops and lad hem with him beyond the sea in deeds of arms / and did more
by counseylle of hem than by counseyll of knights / and that he did for twey
skylles / First for his court should seem the more ryal and noble to messagers
and legates / that come thereto / the second skylle for alweye he assayed
rather pees than wepen and armor / therefore he made such medyatours with
puttyng to of money / Also for he had sometime yeuen dygnytees of holy church
to unworthy persons for to win his fame again / he made baldwyn the white
monk Archebisshop of Caunterbury / and hugh pryour of the chartherous bishop
of lyncolne / he had these tweyne as it were alwey to Conseyl / For every man
that redyth in book should have the less wondre of the ungracious issue / and
end of this king and of his sons / Men shall take heed of this kings
beginning / and whereof he come both in fader and in mother side. Also of the
Condition of his lif / on whom he gate his sons / Geffroey plantagenet come
of the children of a countess of Angeo that was spoused only for fayrenesse of
body / She would selde come at church / and than uneath she would abide the
secreet of the mass / The Earl her husbond took heed and was waar of that
doing and ordained four knights to hold her in church / and she threw awey
her mantel that she was holden by / and left there her twey sons under the
right side of the mantel / and with her twey other sons that she had than
under the lift side of her mantel / she fleuh out at church wyndow in sight
of all men / and was never seen after that time / / Afterward Richard king of
england told often this tale and said that it was no wonder though they that
come of such kind grened every other / as they that come of the deuel / and
should goo to the devil / Also in a time king henry sent a clerk to his
son gaufred earl of britain for to reform and make full pees and the son
answered the clerk in this manner / Why art thou come to dysheryte me of my
kind birth know thou not that it longed to us proprely by kind and it is
pyghte on us by kind of fornforfaders that none of us should love other than
trauayll thou not in ydel to put awey kind also this king henryes mother was
wedded to this geffrey living her rather husbonde that was a pilgrim and lived
as an heremyte / and this king henry come of hem tweyne in this latter marriage
/ Also of henry while he was a child nourysshed in the kings court of France
/ saint bernard the abbot prophesied and said in presence of the king / of the
devil he come / and to the devil he shall / and moeued thereby both the
tyrauntrye of his fader geffrey that gelded the bishop of sagre and his own
cruelnesse that slew saint thomas of Caunterbury / and yet his fader geffrey
had lay by this Elyanor that his son this henry wedded afterward / Also this
Elyanors fader earl of Peytowe rauysshed his own shyrreues wife and wedded her
lyuyng^ her husbond / In a time an holy man blamed him for that deed and it
auailed not / than the good man prayed that never child that come of him should
bring forth gracious fruit / It happed in a time at wynchestre in this king
henryes chamber that was dyuersly y peinted / that one place was left
vnpaynted by the kings beeste / there the king badde afterward peynte an Egle
with four birds the three birds cratched and torent the fader with bills and
with claws but the fourth bird besyed him strongly to cratche out the faders
eyes / Men axyd him what this should meene / these four birds quoth the king
be my four sons that wol not ceesse to poursue me unto the death / And namely
this last Johan whom I love now most shall most sharply awayte and cast for my
death /

Capitulum 22
AFter anastasius the fourth Adryan a man of english nation was pope four
year / the common fame tellyth that this was the abbots bond man of saint albon
in england and that he prayed sometime that he might be monk in that abbay and
was put of and forsake / but he yaf him to clergy and to good thewes and was
made bishop alban^ses / In a time he was made legate to wormacia / and
converted that prouynce to the right believe At last he was^ ma^de pope / and
for the woundynge of one Cardynal he enterdyted all the cite of Rome / He cursed
william king of Scicile and compellyd him to submytte him to his grace / This
was the first pope that dwelled with the Cardynals in the old cite / The king
of Scotland dyed and neyghe all the lords of Englonde^ In the month of
October the sign of the cross was seen in the moon / Saint James the Apostles
hond is brought to the abbay of Redyng / That year king henry ladde first an
host in to wales and made a strong Castle at Rutland and founded the abbaye
of basyng werk / After Adryan the thyrdde alysaunder was pope two and twenty
year / he overcome four falls popes that Frederyck the Emperor had set up /
Also this acorded Frederyk and emanuel of Constantinople / and the king of
Scicile and socured thomas of Caunterbury when he was exyled Henry this
kings eldest son wedded the kings daughter of France At Gloucestre Jews
nailed a child to the roode / Theobald the Archebisshop dyed and thomas of
london the kings chau^celer was sacred Archebisshop the second day of Iuyn / /

And the thyrdde year thereafter he went out of England / and came again the
seventh year of his experlyng / and was martred / Four famous men descryued
his life and his deeds as it is written in his life / About that year abbot
Ioachyn was in his flowers in Calabria / he wrote the exposicion upon the
Apocalypsis / and upon the books of prophets / Also he warned Frederyk the
Emperor and other kings that went to the holy land that they should not
profit there but a little at that time / for the time of the delyueraunce was
not yet come / Men seyn also of this Ioachyn that he descryued as it were by
prophecye / the manners and deeds of nombre of al popes that should be in holy church / But there he wrote against the maystre of sentence / his opinion was
repreued as it is written in the beginning of decretals by the nynth gregory /
The twellifth day before october about prime were seen three cercles in heaven
and twey sons That year aroos the stryf between the king and thomas / That
time was master pyers comestor in his flowers in france he wrote a storye of
either testamente that hight historia Scolastica / He wrote allegorias upon
either testamente that is a book of goostly understanding / Also he made a
noble book of Sermons and made afterward his Allegorias in a book of me^re and
cleped the book Auroica / Raaf Bishop of Coloyn brought the bodies of the
three kings to coloyne out of melan that was destroyed by Frederyk / These
bodies were first brought out of Perse to Constantinople and than by pope
Sergius they were brought to Melan / This year was thomas of Caunterbury
martred / Of him one says in this manner / Anno milleno Centeno / Septuageno
Anglorum primas corruit ense thomas / / That is to menynge / The year of our
lord enleuen honderd and seventy / thomas deyde / by a sword prymate of
english men / Another says in this manner / quis moritur / presul / cur / pro
grege / qualiter ense / Quando / natali / quo loco / ara dei / In English who
dies / a Bishop / why / for the flock / how / with a sword / when / at
mydwynter / in what place / at gods altar Another says in this manner / Pro
Crysti sponsa / Crysti sub tempope Crysti / In templo Crysti verus amator obijt
/ That is to menynge / For Crystes spouse in Crystes time / In Crystes temple
crystes true lover dies / Giraldus / After his death the kings fortune
began to withdraw / for the year after the king went in to Irlond that he
had myghtely won and made there counseyls in many places by the popes will /
and namely at cassil / there was not the primate of arnach for febelnesse of
his body / This prymate ladde with him a white cow alwey about / and was
sustained only by the milk of that white cow / he reformed all that yland with
all his might / specially in three points in rulynge of thoffyce of holy church / in the true payeng of tethyng to holy church and in lawful usage
of wedlok / than it was there ordained that men dyed that should make their
testamente in presence of their neyghbours^ and if the man that dies has wife
and children / he should first cast what he owes / and his dettys to other me^
/ and to servants for their hyre and the other deele of his meobles should be
deled in three / The one party should be ordained to his children / the other
party to his wife / and the thyrdde to bring him in earth and for to do for
his soul / if he be without wife or without children / his catell should be
deled in tweyne / When the king come out of Irlond he byganne to have
reuelacions and specially by cause that he should amend his life / first in the
Castle of cardef in wales the sunday next after eester day when the king had
herd mass / and went to his horse / there stand a pale man with round
tonsour lene and long barfoote in a white kyrtel he spak to the king in duche
speech in this manner and said / Good old king And than he told forth his tale
in this manner / Christ greteth the and his mother myld and Johan baptist and
peter and commands hyghly that no chepynges be holden another seruyle works /
done on the Sunday in the lands of thy lordshipe out take doing that nedith
to the usage of dyghtynge of meet / if thou do as I tell / all that thou
begynnest / thou shall bring to a gracious ende^ the king spoke Frensshe to
the knight that held his brydel and said / Axe of this chorle if he has y
dremed all this that he tellyth / And he expowned it in English / Then the
man spoke in the forsayde tongue / and said / whether I have met this tale or
no / take thou heed what day it is to day / For but if thou do as I tell
and amend thy life / thou shall here such tidings within this year that thou
shall be soory therefore to thy lives ende^ The man vanysshed when this was
said / and within the three years the kings sons henry Gaufred and Rychard
turned to the king of France against their own fader / The king of Scotland
the Earl of Chestre / and the Earl of leycetre raised against the king / And
the king had many warnynges / but he set little thereby / For the second time
an Irysshe man warned him and told him tokenes that were most pryuy / the
thyrdde time a knight of lyndeseye Phelyp of Chestreby passed the Frensshe see
/ and come to the king in normandye / and expowned him there seven artycles
that he should amend / and if he did he should regne worshipfully seven year /
and he should win the holy cross and his enemies / and else he should shamely
dye in the fourth year / Three the first were the Artycles that he had swore
in his crownynge that he should hold / One was of the mayntenyng of holy church
The other of ryghtful laws / the thyrdde that he should no man dampne without
dome / The fourth that he should restore again herytages that he had byn^me
/ the fyfthe that he should do right without meede / the syxthe that he
should pay the wages of his servants / The seventh that he should do the
Jews out of England and leave hem some what of money to wend out of the
land / But the king was not amended / Therefore aroos ageynste him three
strong men and mighty his own three sons with the king of France / But
when king henry had vysyted mekely thomas the martiris tomb / William
king of Scotland and the twey Earls of Chestre and of lyncoln were taken at
Alnewyk / This meschyef dured two year and was uneath ceessed / and he
acounted the ce^ssyng thereof to his own strength / and not to gods mercy /
And he that had prysonned his wife Elyanor the queen and was pryuely a spouche
breker / and lived now openly in spousebrekyng and is not ashamed to mysuse the
wenche Rosamund / To this fair wenche the king made at wodestoke a chamber of
wonder craft slyly made by dedalus work / lest the Queen should find and
take Rosamund / but the wenche dyed soon / and is beryed in the chapyter hows
at Godestow besides Oxenford with such writing upon her tomb / Hic Iacet in
tumba / r^samundi / non rosa munda^ Non redolet / sed olet / que redele^e sole^
/ That is to say / Here lies in tomb the Rose of the world / not a clean
rose / It smellyth not sweet but it stynkyth that was wo^t to smelle full sweet
/ This wenche had a little Coffre scarsely of twey foot long made by a wonder
craft that is yet seen there / Therein it semyth that geauntes fyghtyn /
beestes startlyn / fowls fleyn / and Fysshes leepe without any man's
moeuynge /

Capitulum 23
ALso this year at york the twellyfth day before september william king of
Scotland by assente of lords and prelates of his land did hommage to henry
king of England / Also this king william seyth in his lettres patente that he
and his successors and men of Scotland should do hommage legeance and fewte to
the kings of England / as often as they be thereto required / In token of this
subgettion the king of Scotland offered his hat and his sadel upon saint
Peter's Altar / in the church of york that be yet there kept unto this day /
And yet herto the lords of Scotland swore that if the king of Scotland would
withdraw him in any time from that feyth / they would rise ageynste him and be
against him alweye / till that he were turned again / Pope Gregory in diverse
wrytynges that he sent to the kings of england and of scotland charged
heyhely / that this composicion should be stydfastly hold / And for the
declaracion of this subgection / the king of Scotland and his prelates come to
northampton to king henryes parliament / And thereafter he came to king henry in
to normandy Also this year by assente of the king the Covent of Caunterbury
cheese Rychard pryour of dover to be Archebisshop / In the enleuenth year of
his bisshopryche our lord appeared to him and said / thou have wasted the
goods of my church / and I shall rote the out of the earth / then he was
aferd and deyd the eight day thereafter / the charge of the trauayl of the
taking of the cross that henry the kyn^e had y take sometime beyond the sea
and swore afterward ^yfore two cardynals that he would poursue it after three
year / when three year were passed / he sent to Rome for to have longer delay
in ydel of his gyleful doing / And that by such a feyned color that he should
make three abbayes in england And so he did in this manner of Seculer chanons
of waltham he made chanons reguler and did awey menchons of Ambresbury and
brought thither other menchons from beyond the Sea / and restored symply the
chartrous at wytha^ besides salesbury / Also he had taken sometime the keeping
of the kings daughter of france for he should mary her to his son rychard of
peytow / But after the death of Rosamund he lay by this maid / therefore his
son Rychard refused the marriage / therefore the king cast to wedde this
wenche / and therefore he prayed huguncio the cardynal for to come and make
dyuorse between him and elyanor the queen / for he hoped so to have the more
help and favor of frensshe men to dyssheryte his own sons / Afterward fill
war between him and the king of France for Castle Raph^ and king henry axyd
this wenche to wedde her to his son Johan / And axyd with her the erldoms of
Peytow and of Angeo / but the king of France assentid not to this axynge. but
he sent the lettres to Rychard by cause he should hem see / Therefore aroos a
grisely wreth between the fader and his own son / Grysly thundryng was herd
in a mydwynter night at andeuer In hamptshyre a preeste was smyten to death with
lyghtnynge in the myddel of the people / and none other man was touched / and
swyne were seen among hem run up and down / Tempest of hayel slew fowls
beestes and men in a ma^deleyn night / Gir / 16 This time that was in our time
king arthures body was fou^den that was acou^ted as it were fantastyk / and
brought as it were a fer at an end and a fable of Brytons feyned / that he
should eft^ come and be king / at glast^nbury between two pylers that were
arered of stone sometime in the holy church high by wonder tokenes and
warnynges / this Arthures body was found beryed and marked in an holow oak
deep in the earth / and than he was take up and translated worshypfully in to
the church and y l^yde honestly in a tomb of marbelstone / there was founden
a croys of leede / and a stone thereupon / and lettres y write within in the
cross turned toward the stone / the which lettres I radde and handled in
this manner form / Hic iacet sepultus inclitus Rex Arthurus cum wennenera vxor
sua secunda in Insula Aualona That is here lies beryed the noble king Arthur
with his second wife wennener in aualon / The bones were leyd in the grave / so
that the twey deles of the grave toward the heed contained the man's bones /
and the thyrdde dele toward the feet contained the woman's boones / there the
yelow tresses of the woman's here was founden hoole and sound with Fresshe
color and hew as ^t had sometime / but a monk touched it coueytously with his
han^e / and anon it fill all in to powder / This king hen^y had herd
sometime of a bryton that knew stories and was a synger of gestes that king
Arthures body should be founden (...) an holow oak about fyftene foot deep in
the earth / He was beryed so deep lest he were lightly found of the Saxons
that were his enemies / And therefore lett^^s were written and graven within
toward the stone / to be Judge and witness of the sothnesse and truth / And
also have mind that Arthures schyn bone that was then showed was l^nger by
three inches than the leg / and the knee of the lengest man that was than
found / Also the space of his forheede between his twey eyeen was a spanne
broad. Also in his heed were seen wemmes of ten wou^des / and it seemed that
they come al in to one wemme out ta^e the wemme of one wound / Jerusalem was
take and destroyed of the Sarasyns / After Alysaunder the thyrdde lucins was
pope a year and four months / That year dyed hughe Earl of Chestre at l^^k /
his son the thyrdde Ranulph was Earl after him fyfty year / Also that year
deyde henry that was the kings eldest sone / of him one said in this manner /
Omnis honoris honor decor et decus vrbis and orbis That is worship of all
worship fayrenesse and worshipe of the Cite and of the world wide / Milicia
splendour gloria lumen apex that is shynynge and bliss light and heed of
Chyualrye Julius ingenio / virtutibus hector / achylles viribas / Augustus
moribus / ore paris / that is julius in wit / hector in virtues ^^ Achilles
in strength / Augustus in thewes / Paris in mouth /

Capitulum 24
THis year when Rychard Archebisshop of Caunterbury was deed / baldwyn
bishop of wyrcetre was Archebisshop after by assente of the king and of all
the bisshops / but the monks of Caunterbur^ withsayde it with all that they
might / Of him it is said that he ete never Flesh from the first day that
he was made ^hyte monk to his lives end / In a time by the wey an old lene
womman met him and axyd if it were sothe that he ete no manner flessh / It is
sothe quoth he / It is false said she / For thou have ete my flesh un to the
bones / For I had but one cow that I was sustened by / and thy deenes have
bynome me that cow / he answered and said truly by the grace of god thou shall
have as good a cow as she was / The four^^ year of his bisshopryche fyl stryf
between him and the Conu^^ of Caunterbury / for new houses and chirches that
were buyld fast by the monks walls / in the which church he had ordained
seculer clerks and ordained hem prouendres of the monks chirches / that he
was compellyd to take awey the byldyng / and they were translated to lambhythe
fast by london before westmynstre The year of our lord enleuen honderd four
score and eyghte / thi^ baudwyn had the office of the legacy of the cross and
went in to wales and song in every cathedral church of wales a mass in
pontificalibus / and that was never seen before that time / After lucius the
third urban was pope as it were two year / he deyd for sorrow that Jerusalem
was take of the sarasyns / That time came heraclius patriarch of Jerusalem in to
England to king henry and prayed him help against the saraseyns in the name of
all the Christian men of the eest lands / and proffered the keys of the holy
Cite / and of our^ lords grave with the kings baner and lettres of lucius the
pope that cou^seylyd and chargyd him that he should take that journey / and made
mind of the oath that he had made / but the king put over his answer till he
came at london / and by the prechyng of the patryark and of baldwyn the
Archebisshop many took the cross to the holy land But henry answered and
said that he might not forsake and leave his lands / without ward and keeping
another set him to the pray to the Robberye of Frensshmen / But he would give
largely of his to them that would thither wend / king says the patriark / It
is naught that thou do / we seek and axe a prince and not money / Neygh every
land of the world sendyth us money / but no man sends us a prince / Than we
axe a man that needs money and not money that nedyth a man / And so the
patriarck^ went his wey / and his hope was lost and the king folowid him un to
the sea / For he would with fair words as he well couthe plese the patriark
that was grieved but the patriark spoke to the king and said / hederto thou
have reigned gloryously / but herafter he would forsake the that thou ^ast
forsake / Think and have mind what our lord has yeuen the and what thou have
yolden him again / how thou were falls to the king of France and slow saint
thomas and now thou forsakest the defense and protection of christian men / The
king was wroth with these words The Patriark saw that and proffered him his
heed and his nek and said do by me right as thou dydest by saint thomas^ For
me is as leef be slain of the in England as of Sarasyns in siria / for thou
art wors than any sarasyn / though all my men said the king were one body and
spoke with one mouth / they durst not speak to me such words / No wonder
said the Patriarch for they love thyn and not the / this people folowyth pray
and not a man / than the king said I may not wend out of my lands For mine
own sons would arise against me / when I were absente / No wonder said the
patryark for of the devil they come and to the devil they shall / This year the
king sent his sone Johan in to Irlonde / but he did little prouffyt there and
come home again / This year the first day of may sarasyns took Jerusalem and
bare awey the holy cross / and slew the master of chyualrye of the temple
and many noble men / when that was wist among christian men / many took the
cross to the holy land in all the world wide / Among the which Rychard of
peytow king henryes sone took the cross also. And for the same cause baldwyn
the Archebisshop went in to wales as it is touchid before hand / In his
Company was girald Cambrensis archedeken of landaf that descryued the manners of
walsshe men in his book that is called Itinerarius as he had before descryued
the state and the manners of Irisshe men in his book / that highte Topographia
/ when he was sent with Johan king Henryes son in to Irlond / After urban
the eight gregory was pope four months / He sent many lettres and pystles
for socour of the holy land / After him the thyrdde clemente was pope three
year / This year at dunstaple in england many men saw our lord Ihesu Christ in
the eyr honge on the cross / Also this year ^^ng henry made Ranulph earl of
Chestre knight and yaf him (...) wife constance the contesse of brytayne the
wydowe of his sone gaufred with all little brytayne / and the erldome of
Rychemond / the kings of England and of France and Rychard earl of peytow and
many other noble men to the nombre of an honderd thousand and four score
thousand took the cross on^ saint Gregoryes day / that year Frederyk the
emperor went acursed to the holy land / and ladde his hooste by
Constantinople / but for great hete he bathed him in a river in armenye that is
called gula Sathane that is Sathanas throat / and there Frederik was drowned /
other as some men tellyn his horse stombled and fell in to the water and so he
was drowned and beryed at Tyrus / his eldest son was deed in the same
iourneye / and his other son the fyfthe henry was Emperor of Almayne after
him and reigned eight year / and wanne Apulea and Scicilia / and was acursed of
Pope Celestinus / For Rychard king of England was take when he come from the
holy land / and holden in the Emperors prysonne and might not be delyuerd
without a great sum of money / And the emperor dyed in the same cursyng /
and might not be beryed without assente of king Rychard / Also that year fill
stryf between the twey kings of england and of France / and all the money
was wasted that was arered of dymes for the iourneye and going to Jerusalem /
For at Cite Cenomanna the king of France and Rychard earl of Peytow come
against the king of England / and king henry made set the subarbes a fuyer
for a cautel / by cause his enemies should have no socour therein / but the
strength of the wind droof the layte of the fire in to the cite and burnt up
all the cyte^ and compellyd king henry to goo out of the Cite / And the king
in his going from the cite spoke such words / and said for thou have bynome
me this day the cite that I most love in this world I shall quyte the / For
after this time I shall benyme the thing that should most plese the in me that
is mine heart / At last at Turon he was take with a fever and desired to have
pees with the king of France in such manner that he would gladly put him self
in the king of France grace / saving his own worship and the crown and his
Royamme / But all for naught for he might geete no pees / but if he would
without any condition put him in the kings grace / And it was well worthy /
for he granted not to thomas this word saving the worship of god and the
dygnyte of his ordee and the Fredom of holy church / Than king henry deyd in
the Castle Cynon^us / and all that were about him yaue hem so to Robberye
and to brybrye that the kings body lay naked long time / til that a child
coueryd the nether parties of his body with a short cloak / Than hit seemed that
his surname was fulfilled that he had of his childhode / henry short cloak
that hight short ma^tel beyond the sea / For this was the first that brought
short clookes out of Angeo in to england / Also they that were there as he
was deed told that all the while that his son stood by his faders body / the
faders both nosetherles bledde dropes of blood / Eight days before this kings
death fysshes leepe out of a ponde in normandy and fought strongly to gyders
with so greet noise that men of the contraye about come thither out of every
side for to see the wonder and found uneath any fysshe alive

Capitulum 24
King henry is deed at Fontreuerard / And his son Rychard was king after him
and reigned ten year / Steven of Caunterbury descryued clearly his manners and
his deeds And by cause this storye should not mysse the noble deeds of so great
a duke / I have studied to take the flowers of steuens book / This king
ordained redyly his things beyond the Sea / and came in to England for to be
crowned / In his coming prisones were opened and he was crowned at london of
Baldwyn Archebisshop of Canterbury the third day of September the which day
is acounted an evil day by the vein believe and usage of mysbyleuyd men / and
is clepyd in the calendar Dies Egypciaca / and dies mala an evil day as it
were a day of bodynge of evil happes to the Jews for the Jews of England had
evil hap that day / Many Jews came to this solempnyte lest the welthe that
they had under the old king should be withdraw in the new kings time /
But the king heet and commanded that the I^wes should not come in to the
church / while he were crowned nowther in to the palace while he were at mete
/ But while the king was at mete / sum of the Jews pressed among other / and
come within the palace gate / and one of hem was smyten with a man's fyste /
Than the Rabyssh people wend that the king had so commanded / and up with
staves battes and stones / and laid on the Jews and made them to flee / Hereof
sprang lykyng things in to all the Cite / as though the king had commaund^d to
dystroye the Jews / and the people resxny and cryeng brake up the houses there
the Jews were fled for dread / and burnt and spoylled and took what they
might / and would not leave for the kings sendyng / The outrage of* so great
wodenesse if it were suffered should pass many cruel deeds and blemysshed much
the kings beginning / But for the great multitude of hem that were gylty he
must let pass what he might naught take of full wreche / At last the Jews
had pees granted / And anon the king ^eueth dygnytees that auoydeth / And all
without that his brother Johan had of his faders yefte in Irlond and in
normandy. he yaf him the prouynces of Cornewail Of Deuenshyre / of notyngham
and of lancastre / Also he yafe him the earls daughter of Gloucestre to wife
that was his Cosyn in the third degree with all her faders lordship / The
lordship of the fourth dele that was yeuen him made him unkind and untrue and
desire the hoole kingdom / The king committed the governance of the Royame to
the Bishop of Durham / that should more skylfully and semely occupye him self
in gods service than in the kings service / For the Gospel says that no
man may serve twey lords at full as he should / though the Bishop would to dele
him self for to plese either king of heaven and of earth / Certainly the king of
heaven aloweth not service that is so deled For he would be seruid with all the
might of the soul / And what if the Bishop that is but half yeuen to Gods
service does not his office as he should / but ordained unworthy and recheles
persons in his steed for he would serve ho^ily in the palais other in the
feire and court / For in none half man makith God at full of the acountes of
an erthely prince / Also the king for to have the more large spence toward
Jerusalem he resigned the Castles of Berwick and Rokesburgh to the king fo
Scotland for ten thousand pound / Also he begiled the old man the rich
bishop of durham and made him bye his own prouynce for a greet sum of
money / therefore the king said often in his game / I am a wonder crafty man /
For I have made a new earl of an old bishop by such manner wyle and speech he
empted many man's purses and bags / and sold dygnytees and lordshipes that
longed to the king as though he thought never for to come again / In a time
his friends that were homely with him blamed him therefore and he answered and
said I would selle london and I might find a chapman that might well pay /
many men bought with the better will / For they trowed that the king would
never come again / he had take power of the pope that he might byneme the
cross whom that he would / and thereby he gate many thousand pound / than
the king as it seemed betoke rechelesly the gouernyng of the kingdom to his
chaunceler bishop of hely / and sayl^ed in to Normandy before mydwynter tide /
That time at dunstaple the sign of the cross was seen in heuene / and soon
thereafter the sh^p of the cross was seen forsake the baner and pass somewhat
of space therfrom / Tell who that will what it might mean / For I have learned
to tell this wonder and not to descryue what hit should mean / Than the kings
of England and of France after that they had made suerte between hem tweyne
they dwelled at Turon in France for to abide somer to wend in the wey to the
holy land not only for holy entente and for cause of the feyth / But for
desire of her own welthe and hope of great hap and fortune / but the
ryghtwysenesse of God aloweth not such manner doing / but semely god ordeineth
that outrageous pride of mysbyleuyd men should be alayd in that manner / Also
without the meschyef that Jews suffryd in her body and catel at lyncolne and
at lynne / yet at york after a long siege and great meschyef and woo / Raby
master of Jews forkytte the veins of four honderd Jews and of his own
veins also and his veins throat Also at stau^ford Jews were beten / slain
and pylled / And one Iohne most hardy of Christian men come to Northampton with
many great prays / there the hostiler slow him pryuely by night for couetyse
of money that he had brought / And threw the body by night without the cite
and fled aweye as a thief should / Than old wives met and there were seen
wonder falls sightes of falls tokenes / and the sely men bare on hand / that it
was for the holiness of that man that they held a very martyr and worshipped
the sepulcre of the deed man with solemn watches / and yeftes / But wise men
lough hem to scorn / but clerks of the places were well apayd therewith / for
they had prouffyte thereby / this was told to the bishop / and anon he forbad
the doing of simple men upon pain of cursyng and the great boost of coueyto^s
me^ and her falls martyr / in the mean time while king rychard was absent
william bishop of hely the kings chau^celer procuratour of the Reme the popes
legate in england made for money he held low the clergy / and spoke by the
kings power / and bare down the common people and showed auctoryte of the pope
of Rome / and roode with a thousand horses / he grieved abbayes with paymentes
and with gifts / and made his allies the grettest of the land / Either
prymates see he held low enough / at his own will / For Baldwyn
tharchebisshop of Caunterbuy dyed at Troys before the coming of the king fro
the holy land and the kings brother geffrey elect of york / he had let ten
year that he was not sacred / And also geffrey landed at Dover / and he bynam
his cateyt and drew him out of saint martyns abbaye and put him in the kings
toure / And made a counseyll at westmynstre as the kings procuratour / and the
popes legate There his fautour hughe nouaunt bishop of Chestre put forth a
playnt that the monks of Couentre had shadde his blood right before the high
altar / Therefore william bishop of hely demed that monks should be put awey
from Couentre / and that clerks should be brought thither that lives by
prouendes by occasion her of this hughe that was gyleful of wit / shameless
and hardy in evil deeds cunning in lettrure and fair speech / and had alweye
made debate and strif bitwene the priour and the Covent of Couentre / now with
strength of men of Arms he put out the monks as passing evil doers / and
gilty of hughes tr^spaas / and sent anon to the court of Rome men of answer
full informed with lettres of bisshops witnessyng that the monks had forsake
Cristes chiualrye and were fall to wordly liking / therefore he prayed the pope
of free ordenaunce of that Abbay^ / The pope abode six months with the
sentence for to abide if any man would come and speak for the monks / but
defaute of spences let the monks and made that the bishop had al his will
/ the monks come uneath at last when they had long wept the wrong of her
violent out puttinge. But the bisshops might and power had the maistrye by
money and slight and many years the monks were disparpled / and what they
had was ordained to prouendes of clerks and they lived porely* and gate their
lyflode as they might / therefore when this bishop hughe was seek at becco in
normandy on a good friday / and might noman find that would set him penance
as it is said / Than he said / and I deem my self to lie in the pain of
purgatory for mine evil deeds un to the day of dome /

Capitulum 26*
AFter Clement the thyrdde Celestinus was Pope six yer^ and eight months /
the second day of his consecracion he crowned the fyfth henry Emperor
Frederycks son / In this manner / First before the grees of the church of
Rome he took ^n oath of this henry that he should defend and mayntene holy
chirch and the ryghtes of holy chirches / and if ought were bynome o^ saint
peter's lands he should restore it again / with all his myg^t Then he saate in
his chayr / and held the Emperors crown with his feet and the emperor
bowyd down his heed / and the pope leete fall the crown upon the Emperors
heed / and smote it of again of the Emperors heed anon with his feet / in
token that the pope has power to make the emperor and to set him down if
he be worthy / The Cardynals stood by and took up the crown and set it upon
the Emperors heed again / While the king was absent the foresaid wylliam de
longchamp Bishop of hely pryued hugh bishop of durham of all manner worship /
and greuyd the Bishop of wynchestre / and wrethyd neygh all / In the mean
time / many were arayd for to pass the sea to have and axe remedy of the
king and help ageynste the common tyraunte / but he was waare th^rof and come
before all other / and had al his will and come again er other men come to the
king / but other men had lettres also such as they would and one of hem that
was bishop of lyncolne came again and pursued william bishop of hely un to
lyncolne / There was set a day to answer in the castle of tykhylle / there
when the bishop of durham was come / this william spoke to him and said / /
I take the bishop not a bishop / but I chaunceler take the Castellan till
that thou give pledges to yield up the kings Castles / The fame of this evil
man william fulfilled al england / So that the great grutchyd against him and
the small cursed well fast / The kings brother Johan was wroth for the taking of
his brother Geffrey earl of york / and gadred great strength of his own
prouynce and of walsshemen with many bisshops / and chaced this william from
wyndesore to the toure of london / and from thennes to dover / there this
william dradd left he should not freely pass the sea and took a woman's cloth
above his own clothyng and coueryd his head and the most part of his face
with kercheues and wymples and walked on the clyf / and bare on his lift arm a
web of lynne^ cloth as it were to sellyng and bare a mete yerde in his right
hand / for he would slyly escape and pass by that craft and not be espied /
But by cause he couth not selle and undo his cloth as a woman should he was take
by his pryuy me^bris and despytously espied / but at last he passed the sea /
and the bishop of Rothomage had the reulyng of the Royamme by commandment
of the king that was than in Scicilia / Also the bishop of bathe was choce
Archebisshop / but he was sone deed / and yet william bishop of hely purchaced
a well strong maundement of Celestinus the pope / and had the same Auctoryte
and power that he had rather as it were for amendemence of the kingdom of
england / and for to wythsto^de Johan that would byneme his brother the kingdom
while he was absent But in all this he was begyled for he conspyred and was
assenting to Johan other for yeftes other for fair byhestes / And yet al for
naught for though he showed at dover the great warau^t of his legacye / yet the
queen Elyanor and the Archebisshops of Rothomage and of york / and many other
compellyd him for to sail again. then after that they had abide spryngynge
time at Turon the kings of Frannce and of England went / the one by water and
the other by land and come to Scicilia / There the king of France let pass
the trespaas of his men unpunished and was cleped a lamb / but the king of
England l^te no trespaas unpunished / therefore he was cleped a lion / Also
king Rychard fought with griffons in Calabria / and in Scicilia / and had the
maystrye / He made a Castle of tree to be ladde about and he rered that
Castle against the cite of messa^ and cleped that Castle mategryffons / with
that castle afterward he took the cite of Acres / Also there his mother brought
him a fair maid of speech and of shap Berengaria that was the kings daughter
of nauarn / and king rychard wedded her to wife / Than the king of france went
forth in to siria / and the king of England abode somewhat after that he was
goon / but in that abydyng he was not ydel^ but he sent forth vytayls and made
engyns Than he went out of Scicile and come in to Cypres and bythouht him that
tweyne of the kings ships were broke with tempest of the sea and spoylled by
men of Cypres / therefore king rychard chaced the king of the land that would not
do amends / from Cite to Cite till that the king yielded him to king Rychard
/ And the king yield him self upon covenant that he should not be put in
bounds of yren / king Rychard granted him / but he put him in bounds of
silver and dwelled there twey months / and had the land at his will / than
he went to acres and took in the sea one of the soudans greet ships lade
with greet riches / and bulgyd and thyrled it in the nether side / when he
come to akres fyl stryf between him and the king of France in this manner / by
covenant that was made between him at Turon / The king of France chalengyd
half that was won in Cypres / king rychard ayene said and said that the
covenant was made of the wynnyng of the holy land and against the sarasyns /
Also there was another cause of stryf for the king would lene nothing to therle
of champayn that was than full nedy and in great meschyefs / but he would lay
champayne to the king to wedde / than the earl said / I have done that I
should do herafter / I shall do that me nedyth / Mine own lord takyth me not
but for of mine / therefore I shall goo to him that is more ready to give than to
take / Than he came to king rychard / and was rich y nough / Also king Rychard
favored guy king of Jerusalem ageynste Conradus markys king of Tyrus that the
king of france favored on that other side / But they came to the si^ge of
acres that was besyeged two year and al their trauayll lost / For the engyns
that were brought against the cite were brent with Grekysshe fire that no
water might quench another other Element / Also the Christian host waxed less
and less somdele by sekenes and somdele for other defautes and meschyefs /
Also it was to deled in parties for the stryf that was between guy and the
markys / Also sum great of our side had received money and mede of the
Soudan

Capitulum 27
THan the year of our lord enleuen honderd four score and ten / the enleuenth
day of Iuyl / the thyrtenth day after the coming of king Richard / the cite
thelomayda was take that is called acres / In that taking the duk of austrych
folowyd king rychard for he would on caas challenge part of the prays that were
take / but I can not tell whether by hap other by the kings will the duk of
austryche baner was trodden in the feen / Therefore the duk was wroth and turned
home again for to take afterward gretter wreche of king rychard / Than all that there was won was departed between the kings of england and of France
/ and the king of France sold his prisoners and the king of england henge his
own prysonners / Herfor and for other such deeds the king of France byganne
for to strive / and had great envy to the name that king rychard had and said
that the eyer was dystempered and went home again and swore that he would do
no damage to king rychard before his coming out of the holy land / than he
had good wind and sailed in to ytaly / and came to the pope and prayed to be
assoylled of an oath that he had made against his will / but the pope would not
asse^t Than Conradus the markys was slain of twey thieves in his own Cite
Tyrus / And the king of france founded for to put that cursed deed upon king
Rychard / and made a counseyll at Paris / and there he said that he would be
wroken upon king rychard / but the wisest men cou^seyled him to leave his purpos
/ and take none hasty wreche / and said / though it were soth that was bore
king richard on hand / yet men should not hastly and vnskylfully worche but men
should abide by cause of honest till he were come home ageyn / for it was
known that he was in pylgremage for crystes sake / Also if he would when he
were come home purge him of that men bare him on hand other make good for the
trespaas / than it shall be well enough / and else it is ryghtful to axe wreche
and that in skylfull time / and if this counseyl plese you not / axe cou^seyl
of the pope / the king ceessed for a time / but he cast a cruel doing and blody
for the kingdom of England / For the king of France sent messagers for to
have to his wife the kings suster of denmark upon such a covenant that he
should have granted with her all the right that the danes had sometime in
England and nauey and strength for one year to help win that right

That condicyon was denied for the Wandales that were against him in the other
side / but the king had with the wenche ten thousand marc of silver / But after
the first night of the weddyng / the king forsook her and put her awey
unseemly other by cause her breath stank / other for he fond her not maid /
That time in the eeste lands was greet defaulte of spence and also king
Rychard was wyckedly defamed that he was untrue to the king of France and had
done him wrong. and also that he had hired thieves to slay conradus the markys
and that he had conspyred with the soudan to bytraye the holy land / and that
it was therefore that king rychard would not go to for to take the holy cite /
therefore king rychard arrayed him hom ward Also for the more dele of the
cryste^ host was destroyed with sword / with sickness with honger and with
hard trauayll / In that doing take heed that the high wysedom of god that
ret^^^th but little as it seems of the wordly heel and sauacion of his
servants while he makes hem come wisely by meschyefs and sorrow to fulfill
the cite of heaven / I tell it for they that passed so there sped more graciously
than they that come home ageyn to her foul manner of living of old time / so
christ our king uses well the evil deeds of mankind while he takyth the erthly
Jerusalem in to the hands of enemies for the sin of hem that dwelled
th^rynne and bryngyth forth wisely large wynnyng of high Jerusalem of heaven /
for the defaulte / and shame of our time the holy Cite mot be defouled of
mysbyleuyd men un to that time / that god knowyth alone / For without any
doubt when time comes the holy land shall cast out evil me^ that dwell
therein as it did sometime and on caas with well less strength / for gods owe^
stre^gthe should be more known in that man deed / So among the machabeys one
said it is but little maystrye to god almighty to overcome many men with the
might and strength of few men and that was showed and declared when one
pursued a thousand and tweyne chaced ten thousand / And gedeon did aweye the
greet multitude / and had the vyctorye of a greet multitude with three
honderd men that laped water in to their own mouths / But Christian men shall
not assaye god and start forth rabbyschly and unwisely few against many
enemies / as who says we have a good lord and a mighty / For god wo^ that his
servants trust so on him that they be not recheles and neglyge^t but worche
wisely /

Capitulum 28
THan trewes were take for three year between king richard and the soudan / and
hubert bishop of Salesbury yede to the sepulcre for him self / and for the
king and offered there an holy oyst / and came thennes and sailed with the king
to Cypres / Thennes the king sent forth to Scicile twey queen's / his wife /
and his suster neygh with al^ his meyne / and he might not well endure in the
soft see / but he sailed with a strong wind toward the countray of hystria
with few men / and was driven til that he came between Aquila and venyse / and
there he houed and bleynt hider and thither / and hyd him somewhat of time and men
made great purueaunce of vytayls for him / and so he was aspyed and take of the
dukes men of Austryche / when that was known the king of france made Johan
king Rychardes brother to torn lightly against king rychard / a^nd exyted also
the emperor of almayn against king rychard / than the emperor made covenant with
the duk of austryche for to have the thyrdde part of the prouffyte and wynnyng
that come of king rychard and had king rychard in to his own ward / yet while
king rychard bare the cross and the sign of our lord / And the emperor put
hyin in a place that is called Tryuallis / there arystotle seith it were good a
man to sle his own fader / but about palmsonday the emperor brought forth king
rychard to give his answer before many lords of the emperors land / and he
came forth with so glad chere and answered to all thing that was put against
him / that the Emperor was bowed not only to mercy / but also for to do him
great reverence and worship / than came to the king that was so holden william
bishop of hely that was put out of england for his great extorcio^s and
outrages / he came to the king for to espy what will the king had to him ward /
and when he might not begyle the king with gyle of blind flateryng he had
evil trust to him self and turned again to France with hoope of grace / But
Hubert bishop of Salesbury come out of Scicile to the king and was sent in
to england for gouernyng of the Royame and also for to speed the kings
raunsone when he was comen in to england he was chosen archebisshop by assente
of the monks of Caunterbury and of the Bisshops / and no wonder / He took the
pal and and was stalled / and took anon the habyte of Chanon at Marton / and
was not grievous to the monks of Caunterbury / but the sharpness of baldwyn
had somewhat unwisely grieved them before / Though this baldwyn was a good man
and holy in other deeds / yet he founded to torn the right and the prerogatyf
of the election of the Archebisshop from the monks of Caunterbury / by cause
thereof fast by the monks church by favor of the king he byganne to bylde a
place and great housyng not without shedyng of blood for to have there
prouendes for seculer chanons / and for bisshops suffrygans should come thither
for to trete therewith clerks of the election of the archebisshop and for to do
awey the monks / but in the other side the monks appellyd to the pope and
compellyd to ceesse the work that was begone / and after baldwyns death they
threw it down straight to the ground / In that doing it is wonder of so
greet a man / that was first archedeken and than white monk / and than abbot
/ and than bishop of wyrcetre and than Archebisshop that ^e would bring men
of more wnparfyghte life / seculer chanons instead of men of more parfyht life /
For sometime holy princes and bisshops in england would not have to many of such
manner clerks / and give them choice / whether they would leave their benefyce
other change their life and goo in to Relygyon / Treuisa / It seems that
baldwyn was well aduysed that christ was head of holy church / and his apostles
heyghe bisshops / and none of them all was never monk another freer / and so it
might seem that he knew well that other clerks were more parfyht than eu was
monk other freer / but for it is said that the clerk^s had^^ choys whether
they would leave their benefice or go in to Relygion / of that choys it might
seem great wonder / for it semyth thereby that they should leave their benefyce /
how it ever were / for if they yede in to relygyon they should leave their
benefyce / and if they yede not in to relygyon they must leave the benefyce by
the rule of relygyon / other they speak other wise of relygyo^ than al men in
common spech^ wol mean and so it seems more wonder of that wonder than of his
menynge / but men would wonder that baldwyn that was a mo^k would not flater with
monks but held other clerks more holy than monks / sith he knew the degree
of eu either. than it folowith in the story / after the woe and tene that king
rychard had in prison in almayn a year and three months / he was delyuerd in
the month of Ianuar for an / C / thousand pound of silver / and left with
the emperor pledges / the Bishop of Rothomage and of bathe for sum of the
money that was not yet paid / And for to pay that sum of money all the woll of
white monks and of chano^s was take / and also rings of prelates vessels
croyses and chalyces were take and gold of seuentene shrynes y shave and molten
and no pryuelege of person another of holy church another fredom was spared /
the king dwelled two months full at swynne in Fl^aundres other to abide the
wind other for to array what him neded / There the emperors men had almost
take him eftsoon / for the Emperor thought tha^t he had latte goo the king
as phaaro forthought sometime that he had let go the children of Israel / But
in the month of march the king came a land at Sandwyche / and dwelled a while
at london and went and took the strengest castle that his brother Johan had
The Castles of nothyngham and of tykkehylle / and put the wardeyns thereof in
prysonne / and by counseyl^ and dome of l^ordes he pryned his brother John of al
manner worship / For he held him untrue and unkind / And heelde his eester at
hampton / And so at wynchester when the meschyef of his taking was wyped of /
he was newely crowned as a new king the fyfthe year of his kingdom / After
the solempnite of that crownyng the king axyd again all that was before
lygh^ty yeuen or grievously sol^de / and he acounted for the sort all the
fruit that was take in the mean time and spared for no covenant another for
charter / another for deed / another for instrumente / And so he dwelled a while
and sailed in to france for to werre against the king of France / than the
kings fought and either sped dyuersly / And trewes were granted for one year
/ and that was prouffytable for king Rychard for to gader both riches and
strength / though hit would not stand with reason of honest / Johan king
Rychardes brother that turned to the king of france against his own brother for
he had right naught / he might do right naught / therefore he was forsake of
the king of France / But by help of his mother Elyanor he came mekely ageyn to
king richard and was afterward his true knight / for use of ong knights as it
were to make him al to fight in a batayl / that time tornementes that were
left of long time were made and used again not withstondyng the popes
forbedyng

Capitulum 29
About that time one steven procurator of Angeo that had wisely y bore him in
the second king henryes time / and in this king Richardes time also / he
supposed tha^t the king that was tender of body should be overcome with long wey
