and peril that he should never come again / other if he come again it should
be uneath / therefore he bygan rabbysshly to pass his warraunt in absence of
the king / than one that was homely with him conseylled him to axe of a
nygromancer / whether king Rychard should come again or no / the nygromancer
ladde steven in to a privy place and showed him a brazen heed in the which
was a spyrite closed / Axe of this what thou wolt quoth the nygromancer but
few and shortly / For he answered not to great ianglyng / Shall I ever see king
Richard quoth steven / nay quoth the spyryte / how long shall mine office dure
quoth steven / To thy lives end quoth the spyryte / where shall I dye quoth
steven in pluma quoth the spyryte / Than might he axe no more but he went from
his prophet and forbad his men and badde them that they should bring no
fetheres nyghe him in no manner wise / and that by cause that a fether is pluma
in latin / Thereafter he byganne to worche the more boldly and grieved his
subgettis full soore / and namely a noble man that fled sometime in to his
own castle by cause steven pursued him / This man aspyed when steven was
Recheles in the syege and took him and al to hakked him / That Castle was
called pluma / And so the cautel of the gyleful spyryt was known / And so it
fell of gerebertus the false pope as it is said before

Ranulphus And so it bef^ll of one alberycus earl of north thumberlond that was
a mighty man with all and heelde hyin not apayd with his own state / but he
counseyled with a fend / that told him that he should have grecia that is greece
/ Therefore he went eftward and came in to greece / When the Greeks herd tell
that he should regne over them they took of hem all that he bad / And put him
out of their land / But afterward somewhat of years this was weary of
trauaylle and of woo and came to king henry in to normandy / and had of him a
noble wydowe to wife / And when the preeste should wedde them / he axyd of the
woman and said / dame grecia have thou will to this man^ Then Albericus
knew the gyle and the fraud of the false spyryt that arered his own coueytous
heart in to vein hope / when king Rychard had made ready to pay to the duc of
austryche twenty thousand ponde that was behind of Raunson / the pledges that
king rychard had left with him come suddenly and told that the tyrant was
ouertorned by wreche of gods dome and his land before his death was grieved
with many great meschyefs / For Cytees were suddenly burnt / and the River
dannbyus passed the brynkes and did great harm fer about / Seeds that were
sowe^ fordryed in the earth / Also this duke was acursyd of the Pope / for the
taking of king Rychard and scorned the cursyng / Also on a saint steuens day he
roode to the feeldes and hurt so his foot that it most be kytte of / And he
without hope of life saw that he must dye / and in presence of the lords of
his land he prayed to be assoylled of the sentence that he was in bounden / The
clergy answered and said that it might not be / but he would swear to stand to
holy chirches ordenaunce touching the wrong that he had done to king Richard /
the duc swore and delyuerd king Rychardes pledges anon after his oath / Than
the king amended his life / and had also another warnyng for to amend his life /
For a man of Cenomania went to saint James for great devotion and came home
again sauf and sound / Thereafter he had a greet devotion to wend and went
to the holy land to see our lords grave / As he went by the wey upon caas
aloone He saw one with a dredeful face and was aferd full soore / and blessed
him self welfast with the sign of the cross in every side Than the other as
it were despysyng the sign of the cross seid / thou mit not defend the / in
that manner but thou shall be mine / and if thou wolt fall down to the ground
and worshipe me / I shall make the Rich / now quoth the man it seems that
thou art contrary and of the other side / take thou thyn own / crystes own
yefte is enough for me / I worship him aloone / wolt thou nylt quoth he / thou
most have somewhat of mine / And threw anon upon the man's heed as it were a
thynne mantel / that burnt the here of his heed and made the skyn of his head
al black / the man was soore aferd and cried to saint James Saint Iame came
anon and arouted the fend and axed what he was and whereof he served / I am a
fend quoth he and grieve mankind / I let the Christian kings in the iourneye
in the eest lands / I took king Rychard prisoner by my servant the duc of
austrich After that king richard was deliud I beset him al about and namely
about his chamber and his tresour that he gadred besyly / when these words
were said the fend vanisshed awey and the man was comforted and left his
weye that he had mente and turned home again to Cenomannea and told king
rychard what he had seen and herd / and showed him his heed that was swelled
and scalded / than the king amended his own life and his manners / About that
time Hubert archebisshop of Caunterbury was lieutenant ^ of the pope and of the
king in england / The Archebisshop of york was deed. and hubert made a
greet counseyll at york /

Capitulum 30 /
About that time were tweyn that founded as it were to do the kings prouffyte
al by one entente but by dyners causes of doing / For the Abbot Cadonencis
warned the king of the fraud of his officers / therefore he would that their
outrage should be chasted that men of the contrayes might live in pees / But
william with the long berd warned the king of the outrage of rich men that
spared their own Richesse and pylled pore men / Then this abbot had a
warrau^t and came to london in the month of Februar and made sum to come
before him / the officers of countrayes and of prouynces to yield full ac^untes
/ But death him let so that he saw not eesterdaye / Men sayn that this
william was borne at london / and had (...) of his long berde that he used /
and was cleped william with the long berde / He used that long berde because
that he would seem the more worthy / and semely in speech and gaderyng of many
me^ He was sharp of wit and somewhat y lettred and over mesure a great speker
and by a manner kyndly Rabbysshnesse of wit and of thewes. he would geete him a
great name and cast him to do new deeds and byganne to here great doing and
deeds / Also his wreched and shamely deeds ageynste his own brother was sign
and token of his wodenesse in his other deeds / For he accused his own brother
of treson to the king / for he yaf him no more large spence of solace and cost
than he was wont / His brother was a bourgeys of london / and had found him to
Scole / He was scorned of the prince for that deed / and yet by favor of
sum men he had place among the great of london / Also among the people he
blamed venymously the pryue deeds and outrage of rich men that mysferde with
pour men and so he excited hugely^ the mean men to love and desire fredome
out of mesure So that he socyed many to him as though they were bywytched
right with wytchecraft / For there he had tendaunt to his heestes five
honderd thousand and two thousand men of london / as it were to the common
puruyour of al / when he had so many fautours as he that would stand for the
pore people and for the kings prouffyt he would in every gaderyng and counseyll
with stand gentylmen and say that by her fraud the king lost many great
enchetes / they grutchyd against him therefore / and he sailed to the king and
said him / that Rich men did him greet wrong by cause he was true to him /
Then he came again and byganne to worche with fraud as he was wont more
besyly and more trustly / and comforted his fautours as it were by favor of
the king. Noise and tidings of this conspyracy spra^ge out and hubert
Archebisshop of Caunterbury that had the rule of the Royamme herd thereof /
and sent for the people / and rehearsed how it was told / and for to put of all
evil suspection / he prayed well fair and axed pledges / The people was plesyd
with his fair speech and yaf and delyuerd him pledgys / but this william held
forth as he had bygonne and had much folk about him and went with great
boost and array and made openly Conuentycles and counseyls and gadrynge of m^n
and cleped him self the savior of poor men / and made great boost and brag
and said that the frowardness and outrage of mighty men should be alayd / and
that in a short time / And he took a teme of holy writ and byganne to preche
in this manner / Haurietis aquas in gaudio de fontibus saluatoris / that is
draw up water with joy of the wells of the sau eour / I am said he the
saueour of pore men / ye be pore men and have essayed the hard hands of Rich
men / now draw ye and laue up water of heelefull lore up of my wells / and
that for joy for the time of your vysytacion is come / I shall quoth he depart
and dyuyde watres from watres / the people is water / than shall I dyuyde and
depart the people that is true and meek from the people that is fal^ and
proud / I shall depart good men from evil men as light from derknesse / than
by counceyll of lords this hubert sent for william for he should stand and
answer to that m^n should put against him / he come at that time as he was
somned / but he had so much people about him that he that had sent for him was
aferd and the softer in his doing and put o^ the dome for that time Afterward
oportunyte was aspyed by two burgeys of london / when he might be found
aloone without people about him and men of arms were sent for to take him /
But william with his axe slew one of the bourgeys that had espied him / Anon
william with few of his men and with his concubyne that would never from him
went in to a church / that was there fast by that is saint mary chirch at
bow / there he would not defend him as it were in a church but as it were in a
Castle with strength and hoped in veyn that his people would come and deliver
him / The people was soory for the peril that he was Inn / and is no wonder
but by cause of the pledgys that they had yeuen him / and for dread of the
knights that they saw armed they came not to his delyueraunce / than william
was boden come out but he would not / than he was compellyd by fire and smoke
to come out maugre his teeth / when he came out the bourgeys son / that he
had slain forkytte his womb with a knyf / but by d^me of the court when he
was taken he was first drawn with horses and than he was hanged with nine
felawes that would never leave him / but fautours defamed the Archebisshop as a
mansle^r and not only that but alfo for to wype awey the shame of their own
conspyracye and for to preue that they that dampened william were wicked men and
evil doers / By craft and by fraud and gyle they fonded to make william to
have the name and worship of a martyr Also men seyn that a priest of williams
kyn leyde the cheyne that william was with bounden under a man's head that was
seek of the fevers and preched openly that the man was hool anon / Right this
sprang out among the people / and the people came pryuely by night and took
aweye his gybet and pared awey little and little the earth that was by bled with
his blood / And made a great dyche and kept the earth as it were holy relyques
to hele with seek men / Name and tidings hereof sprang wel^ wide and great
company both of slye men and of fools came to the place and woke there by night
/ Alwey came theder greet multitude of lewdmen and of fools / and as much
worship as they did the deed man so much vylonye they put upon him that him
had dampened / This error had so his forth when it was bygon that it would
have by witched wise me^ and ready and they redyly take h^ede to the doing that
they knew of this willia^s deeds / for he slew a man a little before his taking
/ and that is enough for a wise man to know that he should not be worshipped as
a martyr / and yet his last confession that he made when he should dye / should
sham^ all that worshipped him / for a martyr. Many counseylled him to be shreuen
mekely of his sins / and to worship god / he shroof him / though it were
laate and knowleched that he had defouled saint mary church and lay there by a
woman while he was therynne / Also by cause his men come not at his will to
delyuere him / he forsook mary sone and called the devil to help and prayed that
he would deliver him Williams fautours denied all this and said that it was
falsely feyned / also the vanyte of this tale fill down sone and dured but a
while and alayde the stryf / For sothnesse is steadfast and is str e^ger in long
time / but falsenesse feyned vanysshed awey in short time / Than hubert the
Archebisshop ruler of the Royamme cursed that priest and set men of Arms to
keep that place / by cause men should not come thither a pylgremage / And so the
sleyght that was feynyd fill awey in short time / And thoppynyon of the people
byganne for to rest

Capitulum 31
THat time one Fulco an holy priest in Gallia came to king Rychard and said
king / to the I say in the name of god almighty that thou marye soon thyn
three evil doughters^ lest sum worse hap the befall / thou lie ypocryte
quoth the king for daughter have I none / yes said he / thou have pride
Couetyse and lechery / The king had lords to geders and said I ye^e my pride
to the templers and hospytalers / my couetyse to white monks / and my lechery
to prelates of holy church / They that saw this Fulco took and put him in
bounds / but he might not be bounden / This year deyd Rees prince of wales /
Of him one said in this manner / O bliss of battle child of chyualrye Defense
of contraye worship of arms / Arm of strenght hand of largeness / eye of
reason / bryghtnesse of honest / beryng in breast Hectors prowess / Achilles
scharpnesse / Nestors sobrenesse / Tydeus hardynesse / Sampsons strength /
hectors worthynesse / Eurialius swyftnesse / vlyxes fair speech / Salamons
wisdom / Ajax hardynesse / O clothing of naked / the hungryes mete /
fulfyllyng al men's bone / that him would ought bydde / O fair in speech /
felawe in service / honneste of deed and sobre in word / glad of semblaunt and
love in face / goodly to every man and ryghtfull to all / The noble dyademe of
fairenes of wales is now fallen / that is Rees is deed / al wales groneth /
Rees is deed / the name is not lost but bliss passes / The bliss of wales
passes / rees is deed worship of the world goth awey / Res al praysynge
slakyth / wales lives in gronyng / Rees is deed / Rees is awey / the enemy is
here / for Rees is not here / Now wales helpyth not it self / Rees is deed
and y take awey / But his noble name is not deed for it is alwey new in the
world wide / This place holdyth great worshipe if the birth is byholde / if men
axe what is the end / It is ashes and powder / here he is hyd / but he is
vnhylled for nam^ dureth evermore / And suffers not the noble duc be hyd of
speech / his prowess passed his manners / his wit passed his prowess / his
fair speech passed his wit / his good thewes passed his feyr speech

AFter Celestinus the third innocent that was called lot^arius also was pope
eight year and five monethes^ This was a lettred man and made the books de
miseria humane condicionis and speculum miss and many constitucions / he
dampened Abbot Ioachyms book that he had made ageynste Pyers lombard master of
sentence / he dampened also amary Carnotensis with his heretyk loore Also that
year when the Emperor was deed / the princes of almayn discorded for sum
chose otho and sum phelip the fifth henryes brother / but phelip was
traytourly slain / and otho was crowned of Pope innocent in france / he
fought anon with the Romans / by cause they had don him no worship / And
than he byname frederyk the kingdom of apulea ageynste the popes will / and
therefore he was acursed of the Pope / than the fourth year of his regne the
princes of Almayne made Frederyk Emperor / and he had worshipfully the victory
of otho / this last year of king richard one wydomarus vycecounte of lemonke in
brytayne the less / the king ofenglondes own man fond greet tresoure of
gold and silver in his own ground / and sent a greet dele of the tresour to
king Rychard / and he refused it and said that he should have all by the
right of his lordship / and the other withsayd him / Than the king besyeged
the vycecountes castle that is called Calux / and trowed that the tresour was
therein / the mynystres of the Castle come out to the king and proffered him the
castle with all that was therein saving their life and lyme and armor / But the
king would not / but had them goo again and defend them self with all the
strength that they couth and might / Then on on a day the king and the duc of
brabant went about for to espy the feblenesse of the Castle / and one
bertrand guedon an al balastrer hit the king in the arm with a dart / therefore
the king had that the Castle should be take in all wise and al men that were
therinne should be hanged out take him that. him had wounded and so it was
done / the shafte was take out / but the iron abode withynne and veins and
senewes were forkytte / and the nynthe day after when the king should dye /
he sent for him that him had wounded and spoke to him and said / what did I
ever to the that thou haste wounded me to death / thou slew quoth he my fader
and my twey brethren and now thou would have slain me also / therefore it
plesyth me what pain I ever suffer / so that thou be deed / than the king
commanded that he should goo free / and yaf him an honderd schyllynges sterlyng
/ But after the kings death the duck of brabant made him he flayn al quyk /
and hanged / than king rychard dyed the syxth day of apryl and his body was
deled in three and beryed in three places / therefore one said in meter in this
manner / vyscera carleolum corpus fons seruat ebardy / et cor Rothomagum magne
Rycarde tuum / In terra diuiditur vnus quia plus fuit vno / Non superest vno /
gracia tanta viro / that is thy bowels ben at carl^el Thy body at font ebrard.
and thyn heart at Roon thou great Rychard / he is departed in three for he was
more than one and so great grace is not in one man alive / Another metriour
said in this manner / Christ tui calicis predo fit preda calucis / Ere breui
denis / qui tulit era crucis / Hic Richard iaces / sed mors si cederet armis
Victa timore tui cederet armis tuis / that is Christ the thief of the chalys is
caluxes pray / For short metal thou throwyst him down that took the metal of
the croys / Here thou lie Rychard / but if death would spare for wepe^ overcome
with dread of the he would void thy wepen / Treuisa / Here king rychard is
cleped Caluxes pray for he was slain at a Castle that was called calux

Capitulum 32
King Rychard deyd without children / and his brother Johan without land was
king after him / Anon he occupied king rychardes tresour at chynon and sent
hubert the Archebisshop to ordeyne things in england / but thomas of thorney
bytoke angeo to Artur duk of Brytayne the son of the elder brother geffrey /
there come to geders the lords of Angeo of Cenomannia and of Chynon in Tureyn
/ And held with Artur as the manner is of the land / there the elder brother
son shall be eyer if the eldest son dies without son / Constans Geffr^ys
love countess of brytayne betoke the ward of her son Arthur and his
heritage to the king of France / but Johan ouertourned soon Cenomannea / for
he held with Arthur / Than at Eester at Roen Johan was gyrd with the sword of
the ducherye of Brytayne / And on holy thursday at westmynstre he was crowned
king of England of hubert Archebisshop of Caunterbury / That day Johan made
hubert his own chauncel^r / Hubert was to proud of that offyce^ and afterward
one spoke to him and said Sire thou sholdest not be proud of the yok of
thraldom / Of^e we have herd of an Archebisshop made of a chaunceler / but
never a chaunceler made of an Archebisshop / herafter about saint John's feste
the natyuyte king Johan sailed in to normandy There were trew^s y take between
the kings of England and of France / and assured with oath and with writing /
So that whether of hem brake first that pees his men should be assoylled of his
hommage and fewte and torn to the other king / But afterward king Johan would
slay his own neuewe Arthur^ then the king of France occupied many lands
beyond the sea / Also this year the earl of Flaundres bycam king John's lege
man / And the king of France made Arthur knight / and took of him hommage for
the lands of Angeo / of Cenomannea / of Peytow and of toreyn / Of little
britayne and of normandy Also this year was made dyuorse sole^pnly between king
John and his wife the earls daughter of gloucetre by cause of kynred in the
thyrdde degree / And by counseyl of the king of France king Johan wedded
Isabel the daughter of engolosym / and gate on her henry and Rychard duk of
cornewayle and three daughters / and took anon tribute of every teme land in
england three schyllynges / and went again in to normandy / That time the
third Ranulph earl of Chestre on caas by ensample of the king left his wife
Constance countess of brytayne that he had w^dded sometime by counseylle of
henry / and wedded one Clemencia Rauffes daughter of Feneger / therefore he dyed
without childeren as sum men wenen / Men trowyn that this year bygan the
lordship of Tartres / Thise m^n dwelled under the hills of Inde that was
preter John's sone and went to robbyng and reuing and took prays of other
nacion^ / Also that year Frensshe men took Constantinople / and made there
Emperor baldwyn Earl of Flaundres / Men of the country about long time
thereafter might uneath leave that that cite was take / and that for old
prophecye that said that that Cite might not be take but by an angel / but the
enemies entered in to the cite by a place of the wall there an Angel was peynted
/ and so the men of the contraye knew at last that they were begyled by
double entendment of an angel / The second Frederyk was Emperor three and
thyrty year / This was crowned of Pope honorius / first he favored holy church as it were his own mother. but afterward he spoylled holy church as
it were his stepdame / therefore Pope Honorius cursed him and assoylled men of
his fey and feute / The nynthe pope gregory renewed the same sentence / this
frederyk took his own son henry king of almayne and slew him in prison /
Also the prelates that the nynth Gregory had sent for to come to a general
counseyll he made them to be take / And while he was so acursed he went to
the holy land and left there more desolacion and discomforte than consolacion
and comfort / At last he was set down of the fourth pope innocent / and
while he be syeged a cite of ytalye he lost his tresour / and the popes legate
chaced him in to Apulea / and there he eueled and dyed / About this year fill
so great reyn thonder / and hayl / that hay^ stones fill down from heaven as
great eggs y meddled with reyn / And destroyed vynes and corns / Men were
shende and fowls were seyn flee in the eyer and bear fuyer coals in their
bylles and set houses a fire / Also this year at london dyed saint hugh
bishop of lyncolne but he was beryed at lyncolne / To his beryeng came the
popes legate and three Archebisshops of Caunterbury of deuelyn and of Ragne and
thyrten bisshops and twey kings of England and of Scotland that was so comen
thither for to swear feute upon the hubert archebisshops cross and for to do^
hommage to king Johan. That day a woman had her sight that had be seven year
blind / and a purskeruer in kyttyng of purses was lame in his hands till that
he was delyuerd by prayeng of the Clergy of the people / This hughe was of the
nation of beyond the sea / he was made pryour of the chartrous at wycham /
besides Salesbury and then he was made bishop of lyncolne / When he was
stalled at lyncolne by the Archedeken men axyd an horse other a Cow for his
stallyng / And he said he were lever forsake the bisshoprich than give any
manner things for such a doing / Wild fowls would fetch mete at his hond /

This year eustace abbot of flaye came in to england for to preche gods word
/ and did many miracles among the other miracles he blessed the well of wy
bysydes Caunterbury / and seek men that dronk thereof had their heel / For a
woman that had a fend within her drank thereof and cast up twey black todes /
that turned anon in to hounds and then in to great Asses / and flyed up in
to the eye and left foul foores after hem / This eustace by his prechyng made
many man leave vserye and Chepynge and feyres on the sunday / He made that
light should brenne alweye in chirches before gods body / and that lords at
board should have alms dysshes / At last sum prelates had envy to this
Eustace and said / thou have no leave to set thyn hook on other men's ripe
/ there is much corn quoth he / and few werkmen. and so he went in to
Normandye /

Also this year in the prouynce of york in the month of December were seen
five mones in heuene / one in the Eeste / Another in the west / The thyrdde in
the south. the fourth in the north / And the fyfthe in the myddel of heuene /
And yede six sythes about the other mones / as it were in an hour / and
vanysshed awey at last /

Capitulum 33
AT lammesse at the castle of myrabel king Johan took and slew his neuew Arthur
and prysonned his sister elyanor at Brystowe to her lives end / therefore as it
were for felonye / the king of france occupied normandy brytayn peytow / angeo
/ and Cenomannea / This year that was the syxth year of the thyrdde Innocencius
began thordre of friar prechours in the countray of tholons under the duc
dominik / but it myht not be confermed before the first year of honorius /
than fylle a sharp winter and grysly / and dured from Ieres day to the
annunciacion / Also king Johan married his baast daughter to lewelyn prince of
wales / and yaf with her the castle and all the lordship of Ellesmer in the
march of wales / this year when hubert archebisshop of Caunterbury was deed
fill great stryf in the ehirche of Caunterbury / For some chose the suppryour /
and sum the bishop of norwyche / by the kings heeste / but Innocencius the
pope vndyd either election and sacred steven of langton / Hounds and maistynes
ben slain in all the forestes of england / Gir In southe wales in morgons land
a knight appeared to one master moris in his sleep that was wont to play
with him / and to make versus either with other now beginning and eft endyng /
So that either should end others verse / In that apperyng the knyht spoke to
maystre morys and said / Master morys I wole that thou end this verse /
Destruet hoc reguum Rex regum / But end thou it quoth morys for thou have
almoost made a full verse / As I see quoth the knight / thou art old and slow /
Therefore end in this manner / Destruet hoc regnu^ rex regum duplici plaga That
is king of kings shall destroy this Royamme with double meschyefs / Also this
year was henry borne king John's oldest sone y get on ysabel / he gate on her
this henry and rychard Earl of Cornewayle and three daughters / Isabel the
emperyce and Elyanor that was first married to william marchal Earl of Penbroke
and afte^ward to simon de montford earl of leycetre that gate on her six
children / Also the third Jane was married to the king of Scotland / This year
bygan the enterdytyng of England that dured seven year contynuelly / For king
Johan refused and would in no wise take Steven of langton Archebisshop of
Caunterbury / that was confermed by the Pope^ Also king Johan chased the
monks of canterbury and took their goods in his own hand / therefore the
pope assoylled king Iohans men of his hommage and fewte / and wrote to the
kings next Johan that they should arryse against John Heretics that hight
albygensis come in to england / and some of them were brent alive / Sarasyns
came out of affryca with three thousand men of arms al without / lx / M /
Lauendres / and occupied a great dele of spain / therefore Innocencius the pope
sent messagers to diverse nations for help and socour of the holy lands /
for the sarasyns had bylded strengthes in the hylle mount Tabor for to werre
ageynste Acres / Also this year saint Fraunceys bygan the order of friar
menours bysides assyse / The king of France with a great host occupied the
clyues of normandy against king Johan / The popes legate pandulphus came in to
england and spoke to king Johan and chargyd hyghely / that he should be buxom
and obedyente to the church of Rome / the king saw peril in every side by
the king of France and also by lords of his own lands / that had by
writing turned hem self to the king of France / than the king oblegyd al his
kingdom of england and Irlond also for him and his heyers to pope Innocencius
and his lauful successors for ever / so that after that time he and his heirs
should be feodaryes to the church of Rome / and pay every year seven honderd
mark / for england and two honderd mark for Irlond / So that if he or any of
his heirs failed of this condition other of the payemente he should fall of
the right of the kingdom / herafter pandulphus went forth and compellyd the
king of France to wend out of normandye Steven tharchebisshop / and they
that were exyled with him came in to england and assoylled the king and his
fautours in the church of wynchestre / but he made hem swear that they should
restore all that was wrongfully taken / About that time king John caused to
hang and draw an holy man that hight pyers of ponfret / for he had warned him
of many myshappes that him should fall for his cruelnes and for his fornycacion.
Also for he had warned him that he should regne but / xiiij / year / and he
reigned almoost xviij / year / but he knew not in that doing that he reigned
freely but xiiij year / but he reigned three year not freely for thylke thr^ year
he was trybutary to the pope / christ appeared twyes to this pyers at york and
ones at ponntfret and taught him many things that he told afterward to
bisshops and people that were of evil life / Also in a time he lay three days
and three nyghtes as he were in swonyng and was rauysshed and saw the Joys and
peynes of good men and of evil / On saint andrews even king John took the
Castle of Rouchestre / there many gentilmen were conspyred ageynste him / Also
lowys that was the kings brother of France came in to england at prayer of
the lords and had hommage and fewte of Frensshe men and English / and of
the king of scotland at london / But the Popes legate Gna^^ was than in
england / and cursed lowys and his fautours / nethe less lowy^ took wynchestre
and besyeged dover and wyndesore^ Pope Innocencius deyd / and the thyrdde
honorius was pope after him ten year and eight months / In his first year he
confermed the order of friar prechours / For the third Innocencius was loath to
conferme that order / king john deyd at newerk of the flux on saint Calyxtes
day the pope / the seuententh year of his kingdom in the syxth month / but he
was ^oweld in the Abbaye of white chanons at Croghton / and beryed at wyrcetre
in the middel of the quere of monks / R / But the common fame tellyth that he
swore there at meet that the loof that was than there worth an half penny /
should be worth twelve pens within that year if he might live / A monk of that
house herd that / and made him drink of venym and shroof him and was houseled
and drank to the king as it were his tastour / and so the king / and he deyd
both attones

Capitulum 34 /
ANon upon saint symons day and Jude king John's sone henry a child of ix year
old was made king / he was helped by strength and wit of the Popes legate of
the bishop of wynchestre / of therles of penbroke / and of chestre / for
ranulph earl of chestre had than take lyncoln against lowy^ and slain there many
frenssh men Than lowis saw that his party was febled and took money and yielded
up the strengthes that he had hold / and was assoilled of the popes legate /
and went again in france / Lewyd men that held with lowys were not
disheryted but clerks as the trespass wa^ great were pryued of her benefyces /
other sent to the court of rome for to be assoylled / Ranulph earl of chestre
went to ierl^m after that he was acorded with lewelyn prync^ of wales / and
damyeta was taken of christian men / This year first the abbotes of blac order
come to geders at oxenford for to tr^te of thordre / king henry began the new
werk at westmestre / and ranulph earl of chestre came out of the holy land
and bylded the castles of charteley and of beston and thabbay of delacresse of
the white order / for the costs of these castles / he took tollage of and in
all his la^d / Also this year seint thomas of caunterbury the martyr was
translated by Steven the Archebisshop during the solempnyte he fond hey and
prouende to al men that would axe hit in the wey between london and Caunterbury
/ Also in the day of the translacion he made wyn to run in pypes contynuelly
in diverse places of the Cite / and so the cost that steven made in thi^
solempnite / his fourth successor bonefacius paid it uneath / Alysander king
of scotland wedded Ione king henryes sister / On saint luk the eua^gelystes
day came a wind out of the north side / that brake down houses orchardes and
wodes / belhous / and belfrayes / Also fyry drago^s and evil spirits were seen
fle about in the whyrlwynde / At ox^ford in the counseyl of bisshops was one
taken that had in his body wounds as our lord Christ had y nailed to the
cross / This said that he was Ihesus / but by dome of holy church he was
take to be punysshed and at abburbury he was nailed to the cross / David an
earl of Scotland had a son Johan that wedded lewelins daughter prince of
wales as it were for final acorde between him and lewelyn and his eme Ranulph
Earl of chestre / Johan king of Jerusalem came in to Engl^and for socour of the
holy land / the lords of england granted king henry ^he wards of heirs
and of her ^andes and that was beginning of much harm in england / and sone
thereafter king henry took the fyftenth penny in all england / This year first
come friar menours in to england two year before saint Fraunceys death / After
honorius the nynthe gregory was Pope fourten year / this strengthed the
sentence of cursyng against Frederyk the Emperor / Therefore the Emperor took
many prelates and two Cardynals that we^ to the counseyle / This Pope made
brother Raymund to compyl^ five books of decretales that were gadred of many
constitucio^s pystles and decretales / Also in a time this Pope was besyeged of
the emperor in the cite of Rome / and he saw that the romans had taken mede
of the emperor / than he took in his hands the hedes of thappostles petir and
paul^ / and made a processio^ from seint john's chirch the lateran to seint
peter's chirch and so he awelded the hertes of the romamayns / therefore
the emperor was aferd and went thens a far wey / Steven tharchebisshop deyd he
quoted the bible at paris and marked the capytres / and endited king rychardes
lif / and left after him many good books that he had made / the great deen of
london may richard of wethershed was archebisshop after him / also thi^ year
deid william of alune a lettred man / first he was chau^celer and than bishop
of paris / and left after him many books that he had made de sacramentis Cur
deus homo / de fide et de legibus / and de vniuso corporali and spu^ali /
gregory took the dyme ^f holy church / while the Bishop o^ london said his
mass in saint paul's church fyl so great thycknesse of clouds derknesse of
the son / with thundryng and lyghtnyng and stenche that no man might suffer /
so that the people went out of the church / and left the bishop there with
his seruaunte^ aloone / This year king henry granted englysshmen many Fredoms
/ but he took of hem the fyftenth dele of her goods / and catail for to win
lands beyond the sea that the king of france had occupied in king henryes
time / and so he sailed over see with gret^ strength and dyd^ little prouffyte /
william de brewes was blamed for lewillyns wife prince of wales / and prysoned
and hanged / therefore fyl great stryf bitwene the king and lew^lyn / Ranulph
earl of chestre. of lyncoln and of huntyngdon deyd at walyngford and was beryed
at Chestre in the chapter of monks with his for faders / his sistres son
Johan scot was earl after him / This ranulph dyed without children / and had
four sustres / the eldeste of hem mold was married to dauyd an earl of scotland
/ of him ca^ John scot / the second sister mablye was married to therle of
aru^del / the thyrdde agnes to therle of derby william de Ferraus / the fourth
hawys was married to therle of wynchestre robert quynycy / king henry made the
hospytal of saint Johan without eest yate at oxenford and laid the first stone
/ when rychard archebisshop of caunterbury was deed / saint edmond of abendon
was archebisshop after him that was at that time tresorer of salesbury. he dyed
beyond the sea the eyghtenth year of his bisshoprych and was bury^d at
pou^tney in burgoyn / and the seventh year thereafter he was translated by
favor of the fourth innocent the pope

Capitulum 35
FRederik the emperor wedded ysabel king henryes sust / that year jews were
brought before the king at westmestre / for they had hyd a child al a year at
norwich / and after that they had circumcyded him they cast for to nail him to
the cross / king henry wedded the earls daughter of prouynce / John scot earl
of Chestre and of huntyngdon deyd without children at dere^hal^ the seventh day
of Iuyn and was beryed at chestre / but because that this lands had
prerogatyues of realte / his erldo^ fill in to the kings hond and his systres
that were his eyres had other lands / therefore in co^pe^sacion by cause that so
feyr a lordship should not be deled between dystanes of women / this Johan had
four systres / one of hem margaret was wedded to aleyn of galwey and bore the
maid deuergoyl / This maid was wedded to John bayllol / and bare John baillol
/ king of scotland / the other sister Isabel was married to robert de bruys /
the third sister would dyed without children / the fourth sister alda was married
to henry de hastyngys / Also this year Octobonus the legate came in to england /
and ordained many good ordenau^ces for the prouffyte of holy church / while
he passed through Oxenford was great fyghtyng between the scolers and some of his
meyne / so that one of his men was slain / and he hym^self octobonus was
besyeged in the belfray at osenay till euensonge time / and might uneath be
delyuerd by many of the kings mynystres that came thider from abyndon / than he
was brought at walyngford and cursed the mysdoers and suspended the study of
oxenford til that the abbot and chanons of osenay and maystres regentes of
oxenford came barfote and bare legged and vngird through london to the legate and
had foryeuenes uneath / that year a falls clerk feyned him self mad / and espied
the pryuyte of the kings court / and came by a wyndowe in to the kings chamber
at wodstock for to slay the king / but by the cry of an holy woman he was
taken and drawn at Couentre / Edward king henryes eldest son is borne at
westmynstre / him cristned octoban the legate and confermed edmond archebisshop
/ This year the kings of Tartres when they had overcome the eest lands they
departed hem in twey companyes / that one party thereof destroyed so hu^gary and
pannonia that men of the cou^tray ete the flessh of their own children / and
many scrapyd of the powder of an hill and ete it as it were mele / After the
nynth gregory the fourth Celestinus was pope one month / and the sea was void
one year / And after him the fourth innocent was pope enleuen year and syx
months / Our saueours crown of thorns wa^ brought in to France /
Octobonus went out of england and was take in the sea of the emperors men /
At Chestre king henry entered in to wales / and david the prince came to him at
ruthla^d / that year dyed seint edmond at po^teny and bonefas was archebisshop
after him / this edmond was born at abendon besides oxe^ford / and had an holy
fader and mother / his faders name was edward rych^ by his surname / by asse^t
of his wif he lad relygyous life at euesha^ / his moders name was mablye / she
used the here and an haberion / and fought in her flesh against the fflesshe
/ Edmond was born cleene of al wem of childhode on saint edmondes day the king
and martyr / and lay all that day from the morrow tide to even as though he were
a swowne / So that they that were there would have buried him if his mother had
not withsayd him / he was cleped edmond that is gracyous and clean / for he was
borne on a saint edmondes day / And also while his mother was with child with
him / she went a pylgremage / and badde her bedes at saint edmondes tomb /
and there she was first ware that the child was alive / From his first
childhode this used his wit to the study of goodness by occupacion of
goostly / living / For good usage and customme should afterward have the
maystrye / and void al wicked deeds / though he were shynyng with all the
flowers of virtues / yet he chose the clennes that makyth man be next god / In
token thereof he made his auowe to our lady by his moders counseyl / he used
the here and fasted every friday with bread and water / and used every sunday
and holy day to say all the sauter er he would dyne / In his childhode he learned
his gramer and was so dysesed with the head ache that he had no hope to speed
afterward in lore / his mother spak to him and said sone I trow that the lewd
and unseemly tonsour that thou use is cause of thy woo / Than afterward he
used tonsoure of a clerk / and was hool of all that woo / In a time he walked by
him self in a meede / besides oxenford / and a fair child appeared to him and
said / hayl my leef / I wonder that thou know me not. and namely while I am
alwey by thy side in scole and in other places / therefore what thou see in my
forheede written / prente it every night in thine own forhede / The wrytinge
was Ihesus Nazarenus Rex Iudeorum / that is Ihus of Nazareth kyng^ of Jews /
Thereafter he learned alwey to have our lords passion in his mind / Ones for
besynes of a lesson that he must read he forgate it / Then when the day
byganne to spring the old enemy bond fast his hondes / by cause that he should
not bless him self / and he prayed in his heart / and the enemy fyl down from
him between the bed and the wall / and he coniuryd him by the shedyng of
gods blood that he should tell wherewith he might be most y chasted / with
that thou have now nempned quoth the fend / Another time he had foryete to
say this oryson / O beata et intemerata / And saint Johan the ewangelyst
appeared to him in his sleep / and manaced him to smite with a pawmer And for
holy wrytt says that he that rectheth not of the small fallyth awey little /
and litel / and he would every day shryue him and cleanse him of venyal sins /
by entysyng of the old enemy his hoostes daughter not only with signs and
bekkes / but also with words auentred her to tempte saint Edmond for to do
amysse and would not cesse / er she came to the holy man's chamber and was
strypte and scourged and so she putt of her utchyng and when the enemy might
not speed by the wenche he auentred by the wife to assaylle him / but edmond
would not take her yeftes without leave of the husbond / and put her of so
ashamed / and though he was not infra sacros / he was a master of Art / and
used to here a mass / and say his hours every day / er he would read / and
was prouffytable to his scolers / for he taught hem here mass also / when he
took money of his scolers he leyde it in a wyndowe and said powder to powder /
and ashes to ashes / but the money was often take awey / with his felaws in
game other else pryuel^y with thieves / when he radde arithmetryk / his mother
that was deed appeared to him in his sleep and axyd of him and said what
fygures be these that thou studiest yune / and he answerred such and such /
than she peynted three cerkles in her right hand as though she would mean the
fader and son and holy ghost and said / Son study thou in these fygures
after this time / Selde he sat in church but he bad his bedes other standing
other knelyng / For he was a noble precheour / a sharp arguer and a mylde
lyster. For he was auysed and took heed of falace / and was waare and wise in
assoylynge of questions / and did great prouffyte in redyng For greet
abstynence his here fill aweye from his berde and heed / so that his lyppes
seemed y cloue / he used alwey great mete and left flesh on mondaye and
wonesdaye / and also in septuagesima that is all the lent from time that
Alleluya is closed / he would taste no Flesh the day before that he would
singe his mass / and so often it happed that he ete no Flesh in a month al
hoole / he ete but selde twyes a day / he rought not of lectuaryes and of
medecyns / For great knelyng his knees were hard as the sooles of his feet /
Every day he said three pair of matyns and of hours of the day of our lady
and of the holy ghost with Placebo and dirige A night after his first sleep
he would advise and say certain prayers and psalms / If any envious word.
come in place / he would not be in pledynge of causes / he would have men (...)
s^culer court with him to the mete / For he would win hem (...) bless of
heuene / he would not vysyte his houses of office / (...) here acomptes of his
mynystres / he spente alwey more ^han he had He chalengyd of his seruanntes
clennesse of body by couenaunte written / So that if any of hem fill in to
lecherye / he should take his hyer and take his leeue / and goo his wey /
Tethynges and offrynges and redempcion^ of his sins / he spente only in mylde
uses / he had before him painted the image of our lady and al about him the
passion of our lord / And so the lesson come of the book / and before the
image he had his hedes / and of either come great devotion / the time of etyng
and slepyng and redyng when he might not study he told hit al lost / As
often as he opened his bible / he would worship it with a cross / when the
legacy of the cross was committed to him he took no procuratoryes that him
were granted but ayenste the vsages of other such legates he trauaylled on
his own cost / he preached at oxenford at gloucestre / at wyrcetre / and Reyn.
that fill on the people he made turn again with his prayers^ It happed as he
slepte in his study that a candel fill down on his bible and burnt / but
when he awoke he saw / no brennynge was seen / Also with his pen he made
three crosses on a kybe that he had / and it vanysshed awey / his heeris that
he wered were thrown in to the fire when they were old / but they might not
brenne and in the here is that he wered might uneath any worm be found /
Sometime messagers were sent from Canterbury to Salesbury For edmond tresorer
of that place shol^de come and be Archebisshop of Caunterbury / the deen of
Salesbury spoke to hem and said ye be welcome and euel come / ye be welcome for
ye do worship to our church / but ye be evil come / for ye take our tresoure
with the tresorer / him shamed not to draw of his own hosen and shone / Every
man that he met in the wey / that would be shryuen to hym^ he would light down
of his horse / and here his shryfte / and spare for no let of coming to his ynne
/ another for wind another for reyne / ne for other weder / he ferde as the olif
tree that holdith to yt self the bytternesse in the rynde and heldeth out
toother the swetnesse of the oil / so he was hard to him self / and easy and
goodly to other men / he beete his breast often with his hand and his knees
against the ground / So that clerks that lay in seler^ under him might
uneath sleep For worship of our lady he worshipped al wymmen / but thereby he
was never y wemmed / but in a time one blamed him that was hoomely with him /
For a fair wife that he would often speak with / And he answerde and said / Saw
thou not how fair she was / y know^^che / she has often set by me / but by
her was I never more temp^ed / that I was by the wall / and yet more th^ugh all
that I have trespaced in that manner sin were written in my forhede I shol^de
not be ashamed / he hated takers of yeftes and said in Frensshe Entreprendre /
and prender is but one lettre aloone / At last by exytyng of the devil king
henry and the chapter house of Caunterbury was rebel against him / In that
hurlyng he made it as though he knew it not / and kyssed hem and preserved him
and did to hem al other homely deeds / and when his friends said he was to
mylde / and yafe ensample to other men for to arise in the same wise / he
answered and said the swellyng of the sea as mylk / we shall souke and ete wild
honey in the wilderness of this world with Johan baptist the forgoer of our
lord / the power of taking wreche moote be withholde only in gods hand / I
wol not of other men's defautes get me loenge and vnprouffytable c^st and
trauayll / than he had prelates to geders and axyd how he might releue holy church that was made subgette and thral / It was counseyled that the king and
other men that were rebel should be warned / and if they would not amend /
than the wreche of C^nsures of holy church / should not sl^pe / the holy man
assenteth and and goth to the king / the king axith auysement / and he abides
but al for naught / therefore the king was spared aloone and all other that were
rebel were denounsed acursed / but thereby would not the euel doers be amended
/ Than him was lever suffer the malice for a time than kyth his might in plee
and in stryf / for be took heed that though he had done all that he might /
hit might hap that the Popes legate that was than in england / would undo
al his sentence and deeds and so comfort the king to wors deeds / but if the
Archebisshop were present and corrected not her trespass and errors / hit
might seem that he would allow his deeds by a manner feyned suffraunce /
therefore him was lever be absente for a time for to show there by the sorrow of
his heart and that he was soore agreued with her malice / than his last
sickness byganne to wax grievous and strong / and he went out of poyntney /
to soysy / and he byhyght hem that he would come again on saint Edmondes day /
when the sacrament of the auter was brought him he said thou art my lord /
the I have loved. in the I have trowed / the I have preached / the I have sought
and none other / Men tellyn that it goth in to the womb / but I tell that it
goth in to the soul and thought / than he wesche the wounds of the image of
the crucyfyx / and kyssed hem full sweet / and said / ye shall draw up water
in Joy of our saueours wells /

Capitulum 36
AFter Celestinus the fourth innocencius was Pope enleue^ year and six months
/ he put honest and noble persons in the Cardynals sees that were void / he
made Cardynal Friar hughe of the order of prechours that expowned all the bible
and made great concordaunces upon the bible / This Pope made a cou^seyl at
lugnum in France /. there he canonysed saint Edmond the Archebisshop the
seventh year after his death / And demed that the rebel Emperor Frederyk should
be deposed and set down / At tholet in spain a Jew dygged in his orchard
to make him a more vyneyerde / there he found a stone hool and sound in every
side / In the myddel of that stone / he found a book as great as a sauter
with treenleues written in grue ebrue and latin / and spoke of three worlds /
From adam to Antecryst and declared the proprete of men and set the beginning
of the thirdde world in Christ in this manner / In the thyrdde world gods sone
shall be borne of maid marye / and he shall suffer death for sauacion of
mankind. the Jew radde this / and was crystned anon / In england was so
great derth that a busshel of Corn was sold for twelve schyllynges / That
year was saint edmond tranlasted / and Frederyk the Emperor dyed acursyd /
After him his sone manifred assaylled the kingdom / and the tresour of Scicile
till that charles that was the kings brother of France pryued him both of the
kingdom and of his life / When this Frederik was deed / innocencius the Pope
procured the chesers of thempyre for to chese many / and so were y chosen the
duk of Turing and the Earl of Holande / but they dyed soon / and some cheese
the kings brother of england Rychard duk of Eornewayle / This stryf dured well
many years with well great cost / a ver^yfiour d^uyded the sillables of this
name fredericus in this manner Fre fremit in mundo / de deprimit alta profundo /
Res rimatur / cus cuspyte cuncta minatur / That year at london was made a
solempnel procession toward crystes blood that the patryark of Jerusalem had
sent to king henry / the thyrtenthe day of October lowys king of France went
to the holy land and took damyeta / but in the year after he was take of the
soudan in a battle in the field / and william longa spata was deed / Longa
spata is a long sword / An honderd thousand and fyfty thousand huerdes marked
with the sign of the holy cross come to paris and destroyed hughely the
university and slew many Clerks / King henry yaf to to his eldest son
Edward gascoyn / I^lond wales and Chestreshyre / That year for great hete the
earth was so dry that it bare no fruit / but in the end of heruest fyl so
great rain that the earth might not swolowe thereof came many meschyefs Also that
year deyd saint Robert grosthed bishop of lyncoln the nynth day of october /
He was connyng in all the lyberal arts and specially he expowned many things
in in logyk etyks and astrologye / he sent to the fourth pope innocent a
pystle sharp enough that begins in this manner / Our lord Ihesus Christ he
sent that pystle by cause the Pope grieved the Chirches of england with taxes
and payementis undue and vncustumable / Also for he had yeuen his little neuewe
a chanonrye with the first that voyded in the church of lyncolne / But this
Robert would not receive the child but he wrote to the pope and said that he
another would nor should receive such to the cure of soul that couth not rule
him self / therefore this Robert was somned to the court and acursyd / Then
from Innocents court he appellyd to Crystes own trone / Than after Robertus
death it happed on a night that the Pope lay in his bed and rest / A bishop
appeared to him arayd as a bishop / and spak to the pope and said Arise
wretch and come to the dome / and smote him with his cross on the lift side
right to the h^rte / than in the morrow the popes bed was founden blody and the
pope deed / Herfor though robert was a noble man and did often miracles / the
court suffryd him not to be canonysed / After Innocencius the fourth alysaunder
was Pope seven year and four months / Pees is reformed between king henry and
l^welyn prince of wales at mont gomeryk in this form / that lewelyn and his
successors after that time should do hommage to the kings of England / And
king henry took of him three thousand marck / Herupon henry made his chartre
confermed by auctoryte of the pope / Sone thereafter fyl so great honger that a
busshel of Corn was sold for syxtene schyllynges / that time king henry made
his four half brethren so rich that they despised other lords / Therefore come
to geders at oxenford at fest of the trynyte Simon de montford / earl of
leycetre / Rychard de clare / Earl of gloucetre and other lords and chose
twelve peers / and by counseyll of hem these chaungyd the kings mynystres and
put these the kings four half brethren out of the l^and / That deed was
cause of the barons werre / king henry sayl^d in to France / and made shamely
acorde with the king of France / and foryafe him Normandy with other lands
of beyond see / so that him should leave hoole the land of gascoyn / After
Alysaunder the fourth urban was pope neygh four year / This was first patriark
of Jerusalem Than by help of hem that had y take the sign of the cross he
chas^d the hooste of Rome that manyfredus had put in saint peter's land /
Also the pope yaf the kingdom of Scicile to Charles that was the kings brother
of France if he put thens manyfredus. and so hit was done / About that time
at Teukesbury a Jew fylle in to a gonge on a saturday and would suffer no man
to draw him up for the reverence of his holy day. But Rychard of Clare earl
of gloucetre would suffer no man to draw him up in the morrow on the sunday /
For reverence of his holy day / And so the Jew deyd /

Capitulum 37
THis year fylle stryf between the king and the lords of England for the
king would not hold the ordenaunces / that were ordained at parleament at
^xenford / About saint John's f^ste the natyuyte the lords held in ward the
bishop of herford the pryour of wenlok and other prelates that were alyenes /
other that were next the king they chased out of England and occupied their
goods and catayll / therefore henry put the vniuersyte out of oxenford / At
last the king and the barons put hem self touching the articles in the
ordenaunce of the king of France / and he repreued these articules euerychone
/ but the lords of England forsook his unskillful dome and stood forth as they
had bigo^ne / than lords that maintened these ordenau^ces came to geders at
lewys in southsex the / xiiij day of may / and yaf a battle and took king

eldest son and many other great / And so they compellyd the king to hold
these ordedenau^ces that they had made and held edward eight months at

montford earl of leycetre in the Trynyte even / The kings son Edward of

by cause of solace to prycke a courser and so he escaped unto the hylle

Simon before / This rightful Simon was deed / and many other noble persons /
Of him great fame tellith that he did many miracles / but they were not showed

was Pope as it were four year / After him the Popes see voyded three year and
twey months / This Clement had first wife and children / and was afterward

was absente he was chosen Pope / thereafter as men trowyd with his mylde living
and holy bedes he aqueynt many trybulacions of holy church / Also when

in a sermon. that co^radinus deed should come to naught / That year about all
halowe^ tide Octobon the legate came in to england and ordained many things for
the prouffyte of holy church / By his counseylle king henry granted that
they must raunsonne her lands that were dysheryted for the arisyng against the
king out take the Earl of derby Robert de ferrer for it seemed that he had
most grieved the king than the next year thereafter he grieved the king / and was
taken and diherited till he / other his heirs / other sum who for him might
pay on a day / l / M / pound / At London octobon the legate denounsed the
londoners and the portnens acursyd / and said that they were acursyd in pope
Clements counseyll and he enterdyted hem and forbode hem the conpany of Christian
men / Then he suspended the bisshops of london and of Chycestre of her office
till they were assoylled of the pope / therefore the londonners besyeged octobon
in the toure of london till many bisshops armed had him aweye / This octobon
took dymes of holy church for three year while he was in england and so he
went hi^ weye and of a deken Cardinal he was made Pope / That year the soudan
of Babylon destroyed ermonye and took antyo^he and slew the men that dwellid
therinne and destroyed the noble cite / King henry lay with his host without
london at stratford til that pees was made between him and the barons / Octobon
went out of england with huge tresour / And edward the kings son and many
other took the sign of the cross / Pope Clement deyd / And saint edward king
and confessor is translated the fourth day of october in king henryes time
/ And king henry had the twentyest penny of lewd men's catayl and the dymes of
holy church for three year by assente of the Pope / This year edward the kings
eldest son and his wife / went to the holy land / After Clement the tenthe
gregory was pope four year / the third year of his poperyche he made a counseyl
at lugdnum for the profit of the holy land / For he cast to wend theder in
his own person / In that counseyll were messagers of the Tartres and of the
greeks / the greeks promised that they would come again to the unity of holy church / there were syx honderd bisshops and a thousand prelates / therefore one
said / gregorius denus congregat omne genus / he would by these versus mean
that the tenthe gregory gadered al manner men / there was ordained that noble
statute that never was herd before that all persons with cure should be
priests after that time / And that after that time no man should have leave to
assign his tethynges as he did before at his own will / but al tethynge
should be paid to the mother church / Also this gregory charged holy church
with dymes for six year / he dampened pluralyte of benefyces with cure / Also he
approved sum states of the ordres of beggars as prechours and menours and
sum he suffryd as Carmes and austyns / and sum he reproved as sacfreres /
that were called de penitencia / and de valle viridi and other such Also this
year deyd henry king of england on saint edmondes day of Pontenay / and men
trowyd that skylfully he ended his life in his day for he had trauayled him
wrongfully while he was alive / he had reigned five an^ fyfty year / Also this
year dyed bonefas archbishop of caunterbury / and the pryour of Caunterbury
was chosen archebisshop / but the pope forbadde that election and made

dyuynyte / Among his other noble wrytynges he made noble writing upon precian
/ and upon logyk / Sone herafter lowys king of France and his twey sons the
king of nauern and many prelates went efte to the holy land / But by greet
sickness and euyll^. that was strong in the sea costs of that land / The
Christian host that was of two honderd thousand was disparpled and to shed / for
the popes legate that was ruler of pylgryms in the holy land dyed and the
king of France also / This king while he lay seek prayed besyly in this manner
/ Lord I pray that thou make us despise the wealth of this world and dread none
of his meschyefs / And for the people he prayed in this manner be thou lord to
thyn own people ha^ower and wardeyn And he put to at the end I shall enter in
to thyn hows / and I shall pray to thine holy temple /

Capitulum 38 /
EDward king henryes son came out of the holy land in to england / the
second day of august / and was crowned king the threttenth day before
december. and the morrow after his coronacion / he took openly hommage and fewte
of alysaunder king of Scotl^and / Then the second year he made laws / After

Tarentasius of the order of prechours / a doctor of dyuynyte / After him the
fyfthe Adryan was Pope twey months / Sometime this was sent of Pope Clement
in to england for to allege the stryf between the king and the barons / After
him the / xxj John was pope eight months / he hight before peter / and was
famous in many and diverse scyences / but after that h^ was Pope he doted so
that it seemed that him lacked a great dele of kyndly wit netheles he auau^sed
clerks often in presence of many men / this byhyght him self long lif / but he
fyl down suddenly of a new chamber that he had byld a^ vit^rbe / and deyd after
the syxth day of the falling / After John the thyrdde nychol was pope as it
were three year / This year for lewelyn prince of wales would not come to the

submytted him to the king and yaf him fyfty thousand pound for the trespaas and

pecham Archebisshop in his stead / King edward punysshed the Jews and her
assentours for clyppyng of money / and for evil chaunges. So that he made all
the Jews to be taken in on^ day and sum he henge and put awey the other King
edward and the lords made a statute against maynmort So that after that time
no man should give another selle another byquethe another change another by other
title assygne lands teneme^tes / another rentes to no man of relygyon without
the kings l^ne / The king made smite in co^n new money / halfpeny and
ferdynges al round / thereon it seems that marlyns prophecye is fulfilled that
says the haluendele shall be round / After nychol the fourth honorius was Pope
as it were seven year In his fourth year he changed the copes of Friar Carmes
in to cleene white that were to fore ray barred and bemed. The false walshe
dauyd ro^s against king edward on a Palmsonday / and did english men great
harm and damage / But king Edward came about saint Iohans feste / and wanne
wales and yaf tounes and lands that were in the myddel of wales to lords of
his land and held to him self the Castles / that were on the sea side / Of
that doing came great pees and rest after that time / Herafter about saint
lukes feste lewelyns heed was smyten of and brought to the king and sent to
london and sone thereafter this lewelyns brother david was take that was exyter
of all the woe / In the great parliament at shrowsbury he was first dampened / and
than to draw with horses and than hanged by the throat and than quartred and
deled in diverse places of england Of this lewelyn twey men of relygyon wrote
versus in meter / of the walshmen in this manner / Hic Iacet Anglorum tortor /
tutor venedoru^ / Princeps walloru^ lewelinus regula moru^ / Ge^ma coeuoru^
flos regu^ preteritoru^ / Forma futuroru^ dux laus lex lux ppl^orum / that is
here lies the torme^tour of englissh men wardeyn and Tutor of walsshemen /
prince of wallsshmen / lewelyn ruler of good thewes / Cheef precious stone of
hem that were in his time flower of kings that were before / Ensample of hem
that shall be after this time / leder praysynge law and light of people / But
the englysshmen said in this manner / Hic Iacet errox prynceps predo virorum /
proditor anglorum / fax liuid^ / secta reorum / Numen wallorum / trux dux
homicida pioru^ / F^x troianorum stirp^ mendax causa malorum / That is here
lies the prince of errors Thief and robber of men / Traitor of englisshmen /
a dym brond and set of evil doers / God of walsshmen a cruel duk / a slee^ of
good men / Drastes of Troianes / a falls rote cause of evil de^es

Capitulum 39
AFter the death of alysaunder king of Scotla^nd that dyed without children
great stryf was y moeued who should be king of Scotland after him / and for many
chalengyd that kingdom by cause of nygh kynred and of blood and that might
not be determined al full without the presence of the cheef lord / Than it was
found by writing autentyk and old that the king of england is cheef lord of
scotland / and that he should know and deem in such a manner caas / and for
that it should be known after his time / This year king edward made search all
thabbayes of England of Scotland and of wales for to wit and know what right
he had in that manner deed / Than in the cronykes of maryan the scotte / of
william of malmesbury / of Rogyer of huntyngdon and of raph le bruys hit was
found that in the year of our lord nine honderd and ten king edward the elder
made subgette the kings of scotland and of Cumbres / Also in the same cronykes
it was found that in the year of our lord nine / C / and one and twenty these
foresaid men scotts and Cumbres chese the foresaid edward the elder to be her
lord and her patron / Also there it was found that the year of our lord nine
honderd and syx and twenty Adelstan king of england overcome Constantyn king of
scotland and suffryd him eft to regne under him Also Adelstans brother Edredus
king of england overcome the scotts and the northumbres / and they submytted
hem self to hem and swore him feute / Also there it was found that edward king
of england overcome alpinus sone kynadius king of scotts that swore him feute
/ Also there it was found that canutus king of england and of denmarche the
year of his kingdom xvj overcome malcolin king of scotland and thereafter he was
king of four kyngdoms of england of scotland of denmarche and of norwey / Also
there it was found that saint edward yaf the kingdom of scotland to malcolyn
that was the kings sone of cumbres to hold of him Also william bastard the
syxt year of his kingdom overcome malcolyn king of scotland and took of him an
oath of homage and feute / also william the read did in the same wise as his
fader had don to m^lcolyn kyng^ of Sco^land and to mal^olyns twey sons that
reigned on^ after other / Also Alysander was his brothers successor edgar in the
royam of scotland by assente of king henry the first / Also dauyd king of
scotland did homage to king steven / Also william king of scotland did homage
to the thyrdde henry / the second henryes sone in his coronacion / And also to
henry the fader in his twentyest year of his kingdom / as it is written in a
couenaunte that was written between hem tweyne / Also rogyer of hu^tyngdon says
/ that william king of scoland came to his lord king henry in normandy / and did
homage also to king rychard / and to king John at lyncolne / Also on saint
albo^s cronykes it is found that alisander king of scotland wedded margaret
king henryes daughter at york and did him homage the year of king henry xxxv /
the same is found in the kings chartr^s of scotland / also in the popes
bulls that were sent in to scotland it is found that the kings of scotland
were acursid for they would not be buxom and be obedient to her lords kings of
england / than came to geders at norham in thendes of england toward scotland
the king of england with his wise men / and the king of scotland with the
redyest men and worthyest that he had / there the king of england axed first
that the scotts should pesybly assente (...) is ordenau^ce / touching the king
of scotland / namely for it longed to him by cause by his cheef lordship / the
scotts said that they knew none such soueraynte that longed to the king of
england / and said that they might not answer to such things without an head
and a king to whom it longs to here such tretynges / and yt they should give
none other answer at that time for her oath that they had made each to other
after king alysanders death / the which oath they must bold upon peyn of
cursynge / than king edward took aduisement and made his lettres pate^t to the
scotts and knowleched that the coming of the scotts in to england a this half
the water twede should not eftsoon be to him prejudice of coming eft in to
england ^eraft^r the grettest of scotlond and of england that chalengid right
of the succession in the kingdom of scotland knowleched / and granted by
their lettres patent that they would with good will receive right before this
king / as before the cheef lord / and they would hold ferme and stable all that
he would ordeyne in this forsaid deed / but for it seemed wise men at that time
that king edward might give no right of succession in the kingdom to no man but
if he had erst right and possession in the kingdom of scotland / Therefore in
the kings side of england surete was made to the scotts that the kingdom
should be restored within twey months to him that had right thereto upon peyn
of an honderd thousand pound sterlyngis that should be paid at Rome in help of
the holy land And also upon pain of cursyng and enterdytyng of the king and
of the Royamme of england if he would not restore the kyngedom as it is said /
And so the scotts with her chartres yafe and bytoke to king edward the
kingdom of Scotlond / with Castles with right with custommes and vsages / and
set wardeynes that should save to him that had right all the auau^tage and
profit of the land in the mean time / when this was don after long ple and
disputacion in either side of hem that chalengyd that kingdom the king of
england took heed of the strength of the resons and euydences in either side
and yaf the dome for Johan de baillol / and John knowleched that the king of
england is cheef lord of Scotland^ and did him hommage and swore him fewte /
This year deyd Friar Johan pecham archebisshop of Caunterbury / Master Robert
of wynchestre was Archebysshop after him / also that year madoc a walshman
rered war in wales on a mychelmesse day / therefore king edward came to Chestre
about saint nycola^s feste / and took the isle of mon that is called Anglesia
in latin and bylded new the cite and castle de beel marys / That time the
wodes in wales were hewn down that were great socour to men of the contray to
hyde hem self in war time / and strong castles were made in diverse places by
the sea side / And sone herafter this madoc was taken and brought to london /
After that time werre cessed in wales and walsshmen lived as english men and
gadred tresour and dredde lost of catayl / that time king edward made search
all the abbayes of England and bring to london all^ the money that was y
found / Also he made arrest all the wulles and felles / and thereafter fill a
great derthe of Corn and of wyn

Capitulum 40
AFter the fyfth Celestinus the eight bonefas was Pope enleuen year / This
popes first year was a year of grace / that year he granted large and great
pardon to pilgrims that would come to Rome and vysyte the Apostles Peter and
paul / He made the syxth book of decretales therein he determined many great
doutes / he encorpored many great constitucions extrauaga^t / as the
Constitucion of honorius of adrian / of innocencius of clement and of other
popes / and did awey all that was wrongful A constitucion that is not put / in
the course of law is cleped a co^stitucion extrauagant / This begyled his
predecessor Celestinus and made him to resygne up the poperyche and torn eft
to ankers life / men seyn that therefore celestinus prophesied of him in this
manner / thou come up as a fox / thou shall regne as a lion / and dye as an
hound / for he made pope Celestinus make a co^stitucio^ that he and every pope
might freely resygne up the poperyche / and when he was pope he revoked the
same constitucion / than he ruled strongly and set down sum Cardynals and
some gentilmen de columpna / and withstode the king of France in many points
and not only that but h^ founded with all his might to set down the king of
France / therefore the stuward of france william de longaret a wise man and f^r
casting / and the foresaid brethren de columpna conspyred to geders^ And took
pope bonefas and sent him upon a wild horse without brydel and turned his face
toward the tail and made him prycke so about to the last brethe and slew him
so with pryckynge and with honger / John de baylloll that was made king of
Scotland aroos against the king of england and against his own oath / and that
by counseyll of sum men of Scotl^nd and namely of the abbot of menros / But
Johan was take and dissheryted / Then the year after william waleys of the
nation of Scotts arrayd werre against king edward / but he was chaced the
second year after king edward slew / lx / M / Scotts at fouchirch on a mary
maudelyn day but the Scotts wexed stronger and stronger / xxx / year to geders
unto king edwardes time / the third after the conquest / and beete down
englysshemen often and english places that were nygh to her marches / Sum
said that that myshappe fylle for softness of englyssh men / and sum said
that it was gods own wrech as the Prophecye said that english men should
be destroyed by danes / by Frensshe men and by scotts / as it is touched in
the end of the first book / The king made seyse in to his hond all the
temporalyte of clerks and put hem out of his protection for they would not
reward him of her catail the year before aie^st the scotts for by asse^t of
the clergy robert tharchebisshop had purchaced an inhibicio^ of the pope that
no clerk should reward the king of holy church goods / but many clerks
purchaced for dread the kings protection without the counseyl of the lords /
king edward with little serengthe of english men / and walsshmen sailed in to
flau^dres as it were against the king of France / It was a common saw that
king edward loved so blau^che the kings daughter of France / that he would
gladly yield up gascoyn to the king of France for his daughter blaunche / but
for Edward was old and blaunche wa^s a young wenche / king edward wedded
margaret the kings sister of France / and gate on her twey sons thomas and
Edmonde / king edward dampened sodanly falls money that was slyghtly brought up
/ Men clepin that money pollardes / Crokardes / and Rosoryes and were put
forth little and little and pryuely instead of shyllynges / First he made one
of hem worth an halfpeny / and than he forbad hem about / Also this year
edmond earl of Cornewayle deyd without children / This edmond was the son of
Rychard Earl of Cornewayle / and king of almayne and so that erldome fill
again to the crown / This year was a year of grace / in the which went many
pylgryms to Rome / king edward yaf his son edward the pryncypate of wales and
the Erldome of Chestre / At london william waleys leeder of scotts was honged
and drawn / his heed was smyten of and set upon the bridge of london al men
to behold that there would passe^ His body was quartred and sent in to
diverse places of england / this year king edward sent to pope bonefas
lettres to declare the right and the lordship that England has over the
Royamme and kings of Scotland / For Robert le bruys had pleyned to the Pope
that king edward grieved wrongfully the Royamme of Scotland Therefore the pope
wrote to the king of england that he should leave of such greuynge / but he
might show clerly his right / After the eight bonefas the enleuenth benette of
the order of prechours was pope not fully one year / Of him one said in this
manner / A re nomen habe benedic benefac benedicite / Aut rem peruerte maledic /
malefac maledicite / that is / have thy name of thy deed / say well / do well y
blessed. Other torn the deed / say evil / do evil acursyd / he says thus for
benet is benedictus in latin blessed in english / After benet the fyfte
Clement was Pope as it were twelve year / he trauayled about byldynge of
Castles and gaderyng of tresour / he dampened thordre of Templers / and ordained
the seuenthe book of decretales that hyghte Clementynes / And soon thereafter
in a counseyl that he made at vyen / he revoked the same book / but his
successor the two and twentyest pope John renewed efte that book / and
publysshed it and put it to the course of law canon / This Clement was the
first that chaungyd the popes see from Rome to Auinion / Men wondren of that
deed whether it were done by gods ordenaunce / other by man's foul
hardynesse Also that year king edward made hard inquisicion against euy^ doers
and against hem that trespassed against the crown / that manner inquisicion
hight traylbaston / Robert de bruys took wronfully the kingdom of scotland /
and about Eester he slow Johan le common at dunfre in the church of friar
menours / for he would not asse^t to him in that trayson / but the king of
England came and chasid this Robert and benge the sleers of this Johan That year
king Edward deyd at Carleel and made piers of ganeston that was pryuy with his
son forswere the land of England

Capitulum 41
King edward deyd on saint thomas day the translacion be sides Carleel at
burgh upon the Sond / the year of his kyngedome five and thyrtty Robert
Archebisshop of caunterbury was exyled and he saw his death in his sleep at
Rome / After the first edward his son was king the second Edward after the
conquest / Anon he had home again his leef pyers of Ganeston and yaf him the
ducherye of Cornewayle / and made him wardeyn of england while he was about
his own marriage by yonde the sea at boloyn / he wedded ysabel the only
daughter of phelyp king of France / And came thens again / and was crowned
king at westmynstre the sunday in quinquagesima / that is the day a
fourtenyght after that alleluya is closed / He was crowned of the bishop of
wynchestre / by Auctoryte of pope Clemente / For Robert Archebisshop of
Caunterbury was at that time at Rome exyled out of england / This edward was
fair of body and great of strength and vnstydfast of manners and of thewes /
if men shall trow the common tale / For he forsook the company of lords and
drew him to harlottes / To syngars / to gestours / to carters / to deluers /
and to dykers / to rowers bote men / and ship men / and to other crafts / and
yaf him to great drynkyng / he would lightly tell out pryuy counseyll and
