smite men that were about him for well light trespaas / And did more by other
men's counseyll than by his own / He was to large of yeftes and solempnel in
making of festes Ready to speak and varyaunt of deeds / unhappy ageynste his
enemies / and cruel to his meyne / and loved strongly one of his whistrers and
did him great reverence and worship / and made him great and rich / Of this
doing fill vylony to the louyer / evil speech and bakbytyng to the leef /
sklaundre to the people / harm and damage to the Royamme / he auaunced to
states of holy church / hem that were unable and unworthy that was afterward
a stake in his eye and a spear in his side / In his time was so great derth of
whete / and continual moreyn of beestes that none such was seen before that
time / Than were dymes alwey gadred and contribucions paid / Spirituale and
temporale was alwey pylled and by suffraunce of the pope and by color to
wythstonde the scotts / much good fill to the kings encheytes but by the
kings outrage all was wasted and spente in ydel / but in one point this king
happed well that wales was never rebel against him / In other sides him
myshapped alwey / In his beginning he loved Piers of ganeston and had before
forswore his company at his faders heeste / but he sent after him again from
beyond the sea by cause of him / he was recheles of ysabel the queen / and
rought not of the lords of the land / therefore the lords had indignacion and
put out this Piers over see in to yrlond / there the kings tresoure was
rabbyshly wasted and spente / yet for hope of more pees Pyers was brought
again / but the kings tresour was wasted and spente as it was before. and the
lords aroos and put pyers from the king and took his horses and iis tresour
in northumberlond and chacyd pyers / and besyeged him in the Castle of
scardburgh and took him / and smote of his heed at gaueressyche be sides
warwyck / but when pyers was deed / yet the king vsyd his old manners and
drew to other men / therefore Robert archebisshop of Caunterbury made a
solemynel counseyll of the prouynce / there were ordained many noble statutes
in help of the Royamme / the king was sworn to hold these ordenaunces / And
Robert the Archebisshop yaf his blessing to all that would hem hold and his
curse that would hem break / But than as alweye the king drew to his fautours
and did not as he had promised / therefore was great speech among the comyns and
grutchyng among the great against the king / And hem that were nygh the king /
And specially Robert the Archebisshop. and thomas Earl of lancastre by confort
of this Robert fonded with him many year to wythstonde the kings nycete till
that he yield up the brethe in that stryf at the last end / By ^ordes against
the kings will pyers of ganeston was exyled in to Irlond / and the year after
about the natyuyte of our lady (...) was sent after again and the king came
against him at ch^^tre / But about midwinter Pyers was exiled in to Flaundres
and about Candelmasse y sent after again against her will The king was with
him a while and left him in the castle of scardburgh / there lords besyeged
him / and took him / and brought him to dadynton and slew him besides warwick.
Pyers was heeded a^ gan^ressiche upon the day of saint Gernacius and
Prothacius And the same year on on saint brices day the kings eldest son
the third edward after the conquest was borne at windesore / Tharchebisshop of
winchestre deide and master thomas of Cob^^ was chosen awel noble clerk / by
Instaunce of the king he was put of and translated to wyrceire and waltre
Reynald the kings tresorer was made Archebisshop and sone thereafter the king
went in to Scotland with great boost and great array and (...) he and his were
shamely overcome on a saint Io^ans day / Gentilmen were slain and taken / and
tresour lost / Sum threw awey her wepen and took socour only by flight /
Herafter twelve year contynuelly while this king reigned the north countries of
england were destroyed by the scotts / edward le bruys Robert le bruys brother
went in to Irlonde for to win that londe^ but the fourth year thereafter he
was slain / on a saint Calyxtes day / Also this year about mychelmasse a
knight of lancastreshyre moeued werre against his own lord Thomas earl of
lancastre / but about martynmesse he was taken and beded

Capitulum 42
AFter the fourth clement the two and twentyest Johan was pope about an
eyghtene year / He renewyd the seven books of decretales and auaunced clerks
and ordained general studyes lore of three langages of hebrew / grue^ and latin
/ And first because that hit should seem that he hated taking of yeftes / he
dampened pluralyte of benefyces / So that every creatuure should hold him
appayd with one benefyce with cure / and this pope should have the fruytes of
the other benefyces that voyded long time of years Also he reserved to him self
the first benefyce that voyded by death resygnacion other by translacion / So
that the person that were institute should chese whether he would have the tax
of the benefyce other the ouerpluys / by that cautel come huge tresour to the
popes hand / But the duc of bauaria / that clepyd him self emperor werryd
often against him and bare him down alwey / Also this year was greet death of
men and of beestes and greet falling of reyne in somer and in heruest / thereof
came great derth of Corn^ so that a quarter whete was sold for forty shillyngys
/ A writer that hyghte John had a catte that was homely with him about
pentecost at oxenford / this John said openly that he was heyr of england
Therefore at northampton before the king and lords he was preued falls / and
hanged and drawn / That year twey cardynals come in to england and cursyd
Robert le bruys and his fautours / and enterdyted scotland / king edward
favored the twey spensers hugh the fader and hugh the son ageynste the will
of lords / therefore thomas earl of lancastre and many other withdrewe so the
kings strength / So that they made hem a color as it were by assent of the
king and exyled these spensers and threw down her castles in wales / they
ladde awey the beestes and gadred tresour and occupied gloucestre in the winter
time / and sone thereafter without counseyll of other men the king sent again
for either hughe / than wreth and stryf encreaced from day to day / Among all this twey lords de mortimer took hastily Cytees in the march er the earl of
lancastre might be ready / and pursued the kings knights till that the king
come about by shrowesbury upon hem with a great multitude of footmen / there
for defaute of money / and by cause that therle of lancastre was to long
behind / the knights went awey / and the two mortyners must needs yield hem
and so they did and were prysoned at london / than the king went to
Gloucestre / and had with him thens either spenser / Than he went to lyche
feld about saint Chedde day for to take the earls of lancastre and of and her
fautours that were at Tutbury and at burton but while the king passed the
waterr out of the town at afoorde / the earl of lancastre and his men fled out
of the town of burton to the Cite of burghbrydge / there came andrew of
herkeley in the kings side and slew the Earl of herford right upon the bridge
the syxtenth day before apryll and took the earl of lancastre and many other
noble men / the most dele of hem were in diverse places hanged by the throat /
but the Earl was byheded at his own Castle of Pou^fret / the tenth day before
Apryl^ Of this Earl and of his deeds it is often great strife among the common
people / whether he should be acounced among saints or no / Sum said yes
for he did many alms deeds and worshipped men of relygyon and mayntened a
true quarrel as it seemed to his lives end / Also his enemies dured afterward
but a while and deyde in shameful death / Other seyn the contrary and tellyn
that he was an husbond man / and rought not of his wife and defouled a great
multitude of gentil wymmen and we^ches / if any man offended him a little he
let him sle anon / Apostatas and evil doers he favored strongly for they
should not be punisshed by the lawe^ Also he would commytte all his doings to
one of his secretaryes to do with as he would / Also that be fled shamely in
time of fightyng for the right unto the death / and such one should not be
acounted a saint namely while le was take and slain maugre his trethe / But
offrynges and likynes of miracles that been now done in the place there he was
by^^d^d what issue they shall take it shall be known after this time / From
that time to the syx^h year after the fortune of the spencers began to
encreace / and the condition of the queen drough^ toward seruage till that the
king of France pursued hugely the king of England / for hommage of Gascoyne
was not done / About the Ascencion of our lord the king held a parlemente at
york / there he made hugh the spenser the elder / Earl of wynchestre and
Andrewe of harkley earl of Carleell / The same year about Lammasse the king
went in to Scotlond And though he had none withstandyng / yet he lost many
men with sickness and with honger / About the Natyuyte of our lady the king
came homewarde again. and the scotts come after him and took the castle
norham^ and afterward about saint lukes tide at the abbay of bella lauda upon
blakhammor / they had nyghe take the king at mete if he had not fled / but
they took the Earl of Rychemond / and the kings tresour was lost / the same
year the morrow after saint chaddes day Andrew of harkeley was taken at Carleel
/ as a traitor hanged and drawn and heded and his bowels burnt and quartred
and his heed set^e upon london brygge / At lammasse Rogyer mortimer the
younger / that was in prisonne escaped out of the toure of london by a slepyng
drink that his wardeynes had drunk / About mydlente for to make pees the
queen of england was sent to her brother king of France / that had assaylled
a great dele of gaskoyn / About the natyuyte of our lady the king sent his
son edward in to France for to do the king of France homage for the
ducherye of guyan that was yeuen him / and the king of France made him abide
with his mother in the count of Pontyeu / the mother and the sone dwelled so by
yonde see / and would not come again other durst not for dread of the spensers
/ Then the king of england by counseil of the twey spensers outlawed and
banysshed his wife and his son openly at london in cheepe as traitors of the
Royamme /

Capitulum 43 /
THis year about mychelmasse the Queen of england and her son edward and
Rogyer mortymer that escaped out of the tour of london came in to england with
little strength of Henewers and londed in estsex and went toward london /
there the king was that time / and wonder it was that the land was still all
about without noise and shedyng of blood / And the king fled out of london
in to west wales and they folowyd him easyly a foot pas / That time the morrow
after of saint Calyxtes day by counseylle of the bourgeys of london the kings
tresorer bishop of excetre was heded without the north door of saint poules
church / And in the morrow the toure of london was take by bourgeys of london
in help of the queen and of her son / Sone thereafter on saint Symons even
and Jude the queen and her men took the castle of Brystow / there hugh the
spenser the elder was hanged and drawn and his heed sent to wynchestre / The
same year on saint hughes day the earl of Arundell was take in^ the countray of
shrowesbury / but he was heded at Herford The same weke the king of england
was take in the Castle of neth in west wales / and put in ward in the castle
of kenelworth Hugh the spencer the younger was take with the king and drawn /
at herford byheded and quartred / and his head was sent to london bridge Also
that year in the octaues of twelve day was made a parliament at london / there
by common ordenaunce were solemn messagers sent to the king that was in
prysonne / Three Bisshops / Three Earls / Twey Barons / twey Abbottes / Twey
Justices for to resygne to the king that was than in ward the hommage that
was made to him sometime / For they would no longer have him for their lord /
One of hem sire william trussel / knight and procuratour of all the parlemente
spoke to the king in name of all the other and said these words / I william
trussel in name of all men of the land of england and of all the parliament
procuratour / I resygne to the edward the homage that was made to the sometime
/ And from this time forthward I dyffye the / and pryue the of all Ryall power
/ and I shall never be tendaunt to the as for king after this time / Also this
was openly cried at london / The same year on Candelmasse even / edward the
kings son was made knight /

Capitulum 44
EDwardes sone the third edward after the Conquest a yo^g child of fyftene
year old vnderward yet living his fader was crowned king at westmynstre on a
Candelmasse day /

In his beginning come forth gracious happes and fortune / Then the earth
took plente / the eyer temprure / the sea quyete and pe^s and holy church
fredome^ The thyrdde day of Apryl the old king was brought out of the Castle
of kenelworth to the castle of barkley / there many me^ conspyred for to help
for his delyueraunce / but he deyd about the feste of saint matthew the
ewangelyste / Of his living and of his deeds / it is yet stryf among the people
/ as was sometime of thomas of lancastre whether he should be acounted among
saints or no / For another prysonement another persecucion / and greues preueth
a man a saint / but the holiness of the rather life acorde thereto / For such
ben indiffrent to good and to evil / For ever synful man it is a fair grace of
such peynes with contricion done awey his sins and lassen his peynes in
purgatory / though they make him not flee anon to heuene without any pain
of purgatory / but presumpcion and pride of evil men and sinful trusts and
hops an ydel that they and other such should have no pain in purgatory /
Also lykyng and will that wives have to wend about make tidings spring and
sprede hugely of such worshipynge till the byldyng upon such vnsyker ground
begin to slide / At the parlemente of wynchestre Edmond of wodestok was heded
for he had conspyred ageynste the king as it was said / The foresaid Edmond was
the kings eme and earl of kent / the syxtenth day before Iuyn this third king
edward after the Conquest had his eldest son edward borne of his wife the
queen the earls daughter of henaud / Also that year on the morrow after saint
lukes day / Rogyer mortimer that made men clepe him earl of the march was
taken at notyngham and sent to london / And there by dome af the parlemente he
was hanged and drawn on saint Andrews even / About lammasse Edward de bayllol
that was sometime king of Scotland entered in to scotland for to recover his
kingdom with little strength of english men uneath two thousand and slew
syxty thousand of scotts at gledesmore / The king of England ^ome for hel^pe
of the king of scotland and besyeged Barwyck / the twellyfth day of Iuyll
William de reth a scottiss^e knight promised the king that he would at a
certain day bring the host of scotts to fight with him and to remeue the
syege / And but if he so did he would yield to the king the Cite of berwyk /
In the mean time the Scotts burnt in northumberlond as traitors should / and
besyeged the Castle of banburgh / there in lay the queen of england if they
might in that wise br^ke the syege of barwyk / Then at the day that was set
the seuententh day before lammasse anon at full see / the Scotts came ageynste
englysshmen in three bataylles all a foot and vngyrd in a place fast by barwyk
that is called bothhull besides Halydon English Archers beat down the
Scotts and horsemen pursued hem and chaced hem till it was night / So that
there were deed of Scotts eight earls / a thousand and three honhonderd horsemen
and of other men five and thyrtty thousand / When this was seen barwyk was
yolden up to the king of england / And wonder it is to tell / there were none
deed of the English men's sides / but a knight and a squire and twelve
foot men / In the feeste of geruasius and prothasius / Edward le bayllol verry
king of Scotland did homage for the Royamme of Scotland to edward king of
England at the Castle upon Tyne in presence of three bisshops / of earls / of
Barons and of great multitude of people / And soon thereafter the Scotts were
rebel Therefore in a cold winter the king of England went in galweye and
destroyed the Countraye unto the scottisshe See / and repaired the Castle of
Rokesburgh / and there he socoured him and his men all the winter time / The
two and twentyest pope Johan deyd in the aduente of our lord / And anon in
the same weke the twelueste Benet was made pope / That was fyrse monk / and
then Abbot of white monks / and then bishop in his own dyosyce / and
than Cardynal / and at last pope / Anon he made Constitucions to relygyous
men of diverse ordres touching her Rules and her ordres / About on saint
Gregoryes day in the lent king Edward in full parl^emente at London made a
Ducherye of the erldome of Cornewayle / and yafe it to his eldest son Edward
/ and the Erldome of Chestre yet thereto Also there he ordained five Earls / One
to Derby / another to northampton / the thyrdde to huntyngdon. the fourth to
Salesbury / and the fyfthe to gloucestre / Great stryf fill between the kings
of England and of France / For the king of France bad wrongfully in gaskoyne
many lands and tounes Therefore the king of England proffered the king of
France many fair proferes and meke / for he would have his lands again /
but al for naught / Than the king gadred money in every side / and arayde him
to pass the sea / And about saint margarets day king edward passed in to
flaundres and went thens to Coloyn / there he socyed to him the Emperor
benarrus the brabans and the flemyngys / and by cou^seil of hem he meddled the
arms of france among his own arms and burnt and destroyed the north
cou^trayes of france un to tournay / About Candelmasse king edward came in to
England ageyn / His wif and his childeren that he had get in that side / he
left hem at andwerp in braband as it were for surete of his coming ageyn / and
he made a parliament at london and ordained for the needs and chargid
englisshme^ with tribute of the fyfthe part of her good and catayll and all
men's wolle / And the nynthe scheef of every glebe of england / he ordeygned for
his own iourneyes / and made lords of the next towns about answer him of
the prouffyte that come thereof / Also this year was so great scarsyte of
money / and plente of other things that men sold a quarter whete at london
for twey schyllynges / And a fat ox for an half mark /

King Edward toke^ the sea toward Flaundres with two honderd ships on saint
Iohans baptiste even / But by the coost of Flaundres he met the great nauey
of France strongly arayd Therefore all that day he auysed him and his men what
were best to read / And in the morrow him came to help a noble knight Robert
of moreleye with the north nauey of england / There was a strong bataylle / in
the Sea / Such a bataylle was never seen in the Costs of England / There by
Gods help and favor / Frensshe men and normans were sharply shoten / So^me
slain with strokes / sum / drowned by her own good will and sum were take
and her ships also / out take few that fled awey as fast as they might /
Then the King of England came in to Flaundres and had a great host and
destroyed the northsyde of france / And besyeged the strong Cite of tourneye
somewhat of time / But at last for defaulte of money that his slow
procuratours sent him not out of England trewes were take between the kings
in either side / and so either went his wey / king edward with his naueye
went in to little Brytayne / There he lost many of his men by vnholsomme meet
and drink / But twey Cardynals were sent by the pope and made trues to be
take between the kings for three year in the which time the right that the
king of England chalengyd in the Royamme of France might be declared at
full / In his coming again out of Brytayne / king edward had great dysese by
tempest of the sea / And men said that the king of Fraunces reygromancers
had made that tempest / Pope Benette deyde / And the Archebisshop of Rom was
Pope after him / and was cleped the syxt clement a man of great Clergy / but a
great wastour / and spender / so that he yaf his cardinals dignitees of holy
chirch that voided in england / and fonded to put therefore other tytles in
england / Therefore the king of england was wroth / and the year of our lord a
/ M three honderd / and four and forty / The king fordyde the prouysyons that
the pope had granted / and bad that no man should after that time bring such
provisions upon pain of prisonnemente and of lesynge of his heed / In the
feste of the translacion of saint thomas of Caunterbury king Edward took the Sea vnwyttynge all his men whether he would wend / But by ledynge of a knight
of Harecourt / that was sometime outlawed out of France the king londed at
hoggys bysydes the River of seyn in the south side of normandy / And spoylled
Cadony and other Cytees and so his men were made full rich / But the king of
France had broke the brydges of Ryuers in every side / For the hoostes should
not come to geders and fight There for king Edward roode in normandye and took
prays in every side / On saint Rufus day the martyr that is on saint Austyn
the dectours even that is the seven and twentyest day of lammasse monethe / at
Cressy in pycardy king Edward gloryously overcome the king of Fraunce^ and
chaced him / and slew twey kings of boheme and of mayorck the duk of
lotheryng Twey Bisshops / eight earls / many noble lords / two thousand
knights / And other men without nombre / and chaced the people that fl^dde
awey alive / There phelyp king of France was wounded in the thyghe. and in
the throat / and twyes unhorsed of the king of England as it was said / and
escaped aweye uneath / T^erafter the king of Engl^ond besyeged Caleys twelve
months and more / For Cal^eys was sometime great enemy to english men /
That year in the morrow after mychelmasse day in monte tumba that is the
seuententh day of Octobre englyssh men and specially of the dyosyce of york
seculeres and rugulers beat down the Scotts that were come by entycyng of the
king of France unto Durham / There dauyd be bruys king of Scotland william
douglas and other great lords were take / and the other were deed and chaced
About saint bartholomeus feste Phelyp king of France that had arrayed him as
it were for to fight / and namely for to break the siege of Caleys he fled
awey pryuely in the dawnyng / and left there his tents and a greet dele of
vytayls therein / the men of Caleys saw that and yielded up that Cite to king
edward / than king edward was there a month and ordained for Cal^eys and went
in to england again about mychelmasse / And granted trewes for nine months
at the Instaunce of the Pope / But as he had sometime in coming out of little
brytayne so he had at this time greet tempeste in the sea / and lost thereby
many noble knights / therefore this king edward made a wonderful compleynt /
and said my good lady saint marye / what is hit and what bodeth it that at my
wendyng in to France / I have wind and weder and al thing at my will / and
in my coming again toward england I have tempest and many hard happes / This
year fylle great reyne from the feste of the natyuyte of saint Johan / and
dured till mydwynter next thereafter / So that uneath passed any day but it
rayned by day or by night / That time fill great death of men in all the world
wide / and bygan in lands out of the southeest sides / So that uneath left
half the people alive / And sum house of relygyon of twenty left but tweyne /
The syxthe Pope Clement dyed on saint nycholas day / And anon the Popes cheef
penitancer steven bishop hostiensis was chose pope and was cleped the sixth
Innocent / Also that year byganne great derth of things that should be sold.
so that the sale of things was for double price to that it was wont / Also
the sea and the land byganne to wex more bareyn than they were before / This
year it was acorded and sworn between the kings of england and of France /
out take that the kings seeles were not set to the indentures that were
written / the acorde was that the king of england should have all his lands of
the ducherye of guyan that were taken from him before by the king of France /
So that the king of England should leave and resygne up to the king of France
all the right and claim that he had to the Royamme of France upon that doing
were solempnel messagers sent in the kings half of england Henry the noble
duk of lancastre / henry earl of aru^del / mychel of northburgh bishop of
london and guy de bryan / These were sent to the popes court for to have the
couenauntes / Recorded by the popes bulls / but by sudden fraud of France
and by assente of the pope the couenauntes were put of and undo / Therefore
england arayeth for to fight / for to rekeuer and win the lands that were
take with wrong / And the king of england entered in to France with great
strength of knights But he herd tell that barwyk was y take / and came again
and delyuerd barwyk of the power of scotts / This year was so greet drought
to geder that in three months Apryl / May and Iuyn uneath fill a drope of
reyne down to the earth / On a Friday in a whi^sonweke were twey Freres of the
order of menours burnt at Auinion / for sum falls oppynyons / As it seemed by
the pope and the cardynals / the same year at the natiuite of our lady the king
of englonds eldest sone edward sailed in to gascoyn with many men of arms and
archers to recover and win the lands of the ducherye of guyan that the king
of France had long time wrongfully withholde / there edward dwelled all a year
without any rees of enemies / But in the mean time he took and beat down and
spoylled and burnt huge Cytees that were rebelle against him / as narbon
Carcason and other / but in the end of the year of his coming the one and
twen day of the month of septembre / while the duc of lancastre besyeged the
Cite Breuens in brytayne / Edward passed by the brynkes of the River l^yr that
is of the ducherye of guyan / There came the king of France with a great hooste
and fought with him / but the kings men of France were slain and chased /
And the king of France was take and brought to Burdeaus in gascoyne / and
there he was till whitsontyde / This year about whitsontyde the foresaid edward
sailed out of Gaskoyn in to england with Johan king of Frensshe men / And
anon the Pope sent twey Cardynals in to england for to trete of pees between
the twey kings / The Cardynals dwelled in england a full year / and the
thyrdde Cardynal come of his own head to comfort the king of France / and
dwelled with the other Cardynals at london Also this year that was the year of
our lord a thousand three honderd and seven and fyfty about al halowen tide /
dauyd le bruys king of Scotlond was deliuerd that had be long time in ward
enleuen year in the Castle of odyham / and he paid a great raunsonne / Also
this year at the court of Rome began great stryf between the primate Armacan
and Freres beggars / Also the same year was great destruction in britayne and
in normandy by phelip that was the kings brother of nauerne / And by sire James
pipe and Robert knolles / and many other Englisshe men without he de and
without warraunt of the king of England This year a bo ute the assumpcion of
our lady Edward king of England and his eldest son Edward prince of wales
/ the duck of lancastre / and neighe all the lords of England with a great
hooste of horsemen and of archers gadred with about a thousand chariottes
dwelled somewhat long time at Sandwich^ and about Michelmasse next thereafter /
the forsaide duk sailed to Caleys / the king and the prince sailed to the same
place about about Candelmasse / And bygnnae anon to ride in the Royam of
France / but they lay in the feelde in burgoyn / And in cha^payne to the
annunciacion of our lady / In the mean time the normans landed at wynchelsee
with a little nauey in england the fytenthe day of march and assaylled that
town / and slew men and burnt sum of the town / But there many of the sea
thieves were slain and drowned / and the other part of the Sea thieves fled to
their ships and went out of England as they were compellyd by the Abbot of
bataylle and strength that was with him / This year about saint dunstans feast
edward king of england took trues with the king of France in hope of pees /
and came with his host ageyn in to england / But he lost many men horses and
charyottes besides paris the / xviij day after eester by a storm of weder that
fill there that time / About lammasse next thereafter Armacan and the order of
beggars / of the stryf that was between hem ceessyd by heeste of the pope /
Also the same time the prince of wales / the duc of lancastre / and many other
lords of england and the king of France went to caleys to reform the pees
between England and France / there the pees was reformed and assured with
surete of oath on either side / And the kings of england and of france went
home again to her own kyngdoms about mychelmasse And sone thereafter were
messagers sent to Auinion to the pope to conferme the pees and the couenauntes
on either side /

God be thanked of al his deeds / This translacion is ended on a thursdaye the
eyghtenthe day of Apryll the year of our lord a thousand three honderd and /
lvij / The xxxj year of king Edward the third after the Conquest of England /
the year of my lords age Sir thomas lord of berkley that made me make this
translacion five and thyrtty /

THus ends the book named Proloconycon made and compiled by Ranulph monk of
chestre / which ordained it in latin and at request of the right worshipful
lord / Thomas lord of berkeley it was translated in to englisshe by one Treuisa
then vycarye of the Paryssh of barkley / And for as much as sith the
accomplysshemente of this said book made by the said Ranulph ended the year of
our lord a / M / CCC / lvij / many things have fallen which ben requysyte to
be added to this work / by cause men's wits in this time ben oblyuyous and
lightly forgeten many thyngys dygne to be put in memory / and also there can
not be founden in these days but few that write in their regystres such
things as daily happen and fallen Therefore I William Caxton a simple person
have endeuoyred me to write first over all the said book of proloconycon / and
some what have changed the rude and old englyssh^ / that is to wete certain
words / which in these days be neither vsyd ne understood / and furthermore
have put it in emprynte to the end that it may be had and the matters therein
comprised to be known / for the book is general touching shortly many notable
matters / and also am auysed to make another book after this said work which
shall be set here after the same / And shall have his chapytres and his table a
part For I dar not presume to set my book ne join hit to his / for diverse
causes / one is for as much as I have not ne can get no books of auctoryte
treatyng of such cronykes / except a little book named fasciculus temporum /
and another called Aureus de vniuerso / in which books I find right little
matter sith the said time / And another cause is / for as much as my rude
symplenesse and ignorant making ought not to be compared / set ne joined to his
book / Then I shall by the grace of god set my work after a part for to
accomplysshe the years sith that he fynysshed his book / unto the year of our
lord / M / CCCC / lx / and the first year of the Regne of king edward the
fourth / which amou^te to an honderd and three year /

Incipit Liber vltimus
Then following this fore wreton book of Prolicronycon I have emprysed to
ordeyne this new book by the suffraunce of Almighty god to continue the said
werk bryefly / And to set in hystoriall things / such as I have conne get
/ from the time that he left / that was in the year of our lord a thousand
three honderde and seven and ^yfty unto the year of our said lord thousand four
honderd and syxty and to the first yereof the regne of king Edward the fourth
/

Capitulum Primum
IN the year of our lord a Thousand three honderd eight and fyfty in October
Robert knolles a Capytayne of a greet company of English men and other
held and had won many forttesses in France by Orleaunce in B^ytayne and in
Normandye / And in the same monethe he left his garnysons / and came to fore
Paris / and there by took a strong place named Amblanullers / And they of
Paris sent out men of war ageynste them / but they were anon overthrown
and beten in to the town ageyn / And daily they assaylled the Frensshmen un to
the yates of paris / And held them of Paris so strayte that at last they
were constreyned to bye that place of him and to give to him large money to
depart / And after they destroyed many places in Champayne / And in March
aft^r they took the Cite of Anserre and the Castle / At which pryse were made
three knights / that is to say Robert knolles / Tomelyn Fouque and another /
which three were Capytaynes of great Foyson of Englysshmen / And they pylled
that town / which was Rich as was said / They had as much good and
Iewellys / as was valewyd to five honderde thousand motons of Gold / And the
Raunsonne of prysonners of synguler persons was an over great sum / And
when the Englysshmen had seen the lords of the town and had pylled it viij
days during / they said they would brenne the town so that they that were left
dwelling in the town agreeed to give them to save it forty thousand motons of
gold / and syxty perles valewyd at ten thousand motons of gold / And that
Englysshemen should bear aweye with them above that / as much good as they
would / except the Iewellys of the church of saint Germayn / the which they
should have in pledge for their payemente unto mydsomer / and as to the wallys /
they should break them down / and brenne the gates / and so they did /

In this year of our lord a thousand three honderd syxty / And five and
thyrtty year of the Regne of king Edward the third the pees was fynysshed and
acorded between both kings af France and of England / as it is before said /
And at al halowen tide after both two kings metten to geder at Caleys with
both their counseyls / And there were showed the Artycles and conditions of
the pees and acorde / to which both parties agreed and promised to observe and
keep / where forthwith was song a solemn mass / And after the thyrdde Agnus
dei upon gods body / and also on the myssal^ both kings her sons / and
the grettest lords of both Royames being tho there present swore to hold
observe and keep the said pees and acorde / and all other couenauntes that
were ordained between hem

About this time saint Brygytte an holy wydowe of the Royamme of Swethen had
many reuelacions to be informed unto all thastate of the church / And
Instytued and founded an order new of women and of men / whereof she is
Patrones / her feste is kept the two and twentyest day of Iuyll / In the same
year were great and sudden tempests / and strong lyghtnynge and thondrynge /
by which howsynge b^^stes and trees were perysshed / And the devil appeared in
maunys likeness to much people in diverse places and spak to hem / Also in
diverse places of the world were earth quaues / in so much that Basyle the
Cite fylle down with many Castles about hit / / That time men dwelled in
woods as beestes and durst not enter in to Cytees / That time were many
bataylles / Pestylence and honger in many places / Also in diverse places the
Earth cast out white water / and stynkynge. which ouerthrewe and made to
fall Castles and strong places on many places of the world / In this year in
the feste of Conversion of saint Poule king Edward held a parlamente at
Westmynstre / In which was showed the pees / and acorde made between the two
kings / Item In the same year in the Ascencion even was seen Eclypse of the
Son / Whereupon fill a great droughte / and that for defaute of Rayn fill
great derth of Corn and heye / Also this same year the same monethe fylle
Rain in Burgoyne almoost like to blood / And a Cross almoost reed was seen
in the air there / Also in the same time was seen in France / in England /
and in many other places appyere two Castles / out of which issued out two
hoostes of Armed men / that one was clothed in white / that other in black /
And when the bataylle was bygonne between them / the white overcome the black
/ And soon after the black overcome the white / And then they returned in
to their castles and so vanysshed aweye / In this year was an huge pestylence
/ and this year deyde Sire Harry duck of lancastre / In the same year Edward
prince of wales married the Countess of kente. that was Sir Thomas holandes wife
/ which was sometime dyuorsed fro the Earl of Salysbury / for cause of the same
knight / About this time a great company of diverse nations assemblyd them to
gyder / of whom the governors and leders were Englysshmen / which did much
harm in France / Anon after aroos another company of diverse nations / that
were called the white company which in the countrayes of lombardy did much
harm / This same year Sire Johan of Gaunt sone to king edward the thyrdde was
made duk of lancastre by his wife daughter and heyr of henry duk of lancastre
that deyde /

Also this year was a great wind / which ouerthrewe houses Trees / and many a
steple in England / Item in this year king Edward made Sire leonel his son
duc of Clarence / And Edmond his other son Earl of Cambrydge / In this year
was ordained by a parliament that men of la^we should plete in their mother tongue
/ In that year came in to England the kings of France / Cypres / and scotland
/ Which were worshipfully received / And after they had been here long time /
two of hem went in to their Countrayes again But the king of France for
great sickness that he had abode stylle in England /

Sequitur Capitulum Secundum

Capitulum secundum /
THis year was an huge froste lastyng fro saint Andrews tide unto the
fourtenthe kalendas of apryll / In this year there was a scoler which slepte
contynuelly by the term of seven year in lubyke / And after he awoke and lived
long time / Also this year was a great battle kytwene Sire Johan of Mountford
duc of Brytayne and Sire Charles de bloys / but the vyctorye fylle to sire
Johan through help and socoure of englysshmen / This same year deyde at the
manner of sauoye king Johan of France and after was carried to saint denis in
France / and there bury^d / After Innocent the fyfth urban was pope eight year
/ This was abbot of massylyen^ of saint benettes order doctor of decrees and
reputed an holy man / he made to be preched great pardon to war against the
turks / unto him seint brygytta was sent from Christ for confermacion of her
Rule and order / At last / he was poisoned and deyde / In this year saint
katheryn of Senys was in her flowers an holy virgin of the order of the friar
prechours she had the stygmates in her hands and feet and side which deyde
the year of our lord / M / CCC and four score This year was ordained that Peter
pens from the^^ forth should not be paid / which of old time was granted for
contynuynge of scole in Rome / In this year was borne at bourdeux Rychard
prince Edwardys son / which after the death of his fader and of king edward
also was crowned king in the enleuenthe year of his age by right lygne and
assent of all the comunes of the royame / This year fyl a great variau^ce in
spayn and great war between peter ryghtful king of spain / and Henry his
bastard brother / in so much that king peter came to prince Edward to
bourdeux to axe socour and help of him / on whom he had great compassion and
pity / And by license of king edward his fader / he pourueyed for his aid and
help / In this time was seen three days during in the scottyssh see two Egles
/ One coming out of the south / and that other out of the north / which fought
fyersly to geder / and the south first scomfyted the north egle / and he than
fled home again to his own costys / and anon after were seen many sterrys
gadred to geder on one hepe / which fyl down to therth leming with fire lemes
in man of lightnynges / whose flames burnt men's clothes / and heris walkyng on
the ground / In this year prince edward / and the duk of lancaster his brother
with a gre^e Armee went in to spayn. and had a battle at nazers against Sire
harry the Bastard which had put down king Peter and wan the bataylle / and
had the vyctorye / and put the bastard and his men to flight and there were
slain a syx thousand of the bastardes party and a two thousand prysonners
taken / of whom the Earl of dene Sire bertram claykyn and many other lords
were prisoners / and the noble Prince Edward restored the said king peter to
his Royamme again / In the same year was seen a blasyng sterre named Cometa
between the north and south with bemes toward france / In this year sir leonel
king Edwardes sone duc of clarence went to melane / and married the daughter
of galoys / And in the natyuyte of our lady he deyde / In this year the
bastard of spain reentryd again / and slew the king Peter the two and
twentyest day of august / In this same year the Frensshmen brake the pees /
rydyng in Guyan and Pontiew taking castles and tounes / surmysynge on the
english men subtylly and untruly that they were cause of the brekynge of the
pees. In this same year deyde the Duchess of lancastre and is buried at Powlys
in london

Capitulum Tercium
IN this year / xliiij / of the king was a greet pestylence / and a greet
moreyn of Beestes / And there fylle so great waters that it caused greet
destruction of Corn / in so much that the next year following a busshel of
whete was worth three schyllyngys and four pens / In the last day of may was
holden a parlemente at Westmynstre for the brekynge of the pees of the
Frensshmen / and how the wrongs might be redressyd and aue^gyd / In this said
year in thassumpcion of our lady deyde queen phil^yp / and is buried at
westmynstre / At mydsomer this same year the duc of lancastre and the Earl of
Herford with a great company of men of war went over see toward France /
and on Chalkhylle between saint Omers and guynes was an huge hooste of
frensshmen / and the host of english men fast by the same / which had
long leyn there / and diverse English men yaf counseyll for to fight with the
frensshmen / but the lords and capitayns would not / Anon after it happed that
therle of warwyck come thyderward / And when the Frensshemen h^^de of his
coming er he came fully to land they left their tents and pauylons with all
their vytayl / and fled their weye / And when therle was londed he hasted
toward normandy / And in his coming again toward Caleys he deyde on the
Pestyl^nce / In this year at mydsomer was made an hooste / and Sire Robert
knollys was made governor / And when they came in to France / as long as
they held hem to geder / the Frensshmen durst not come neygh them / But at
last for envy and couetyse that was among them they discorded and sundryd them
in to diverse companyes / which couraged the Frensshmen / in so much that
they came freely on our Englysshmen / and for the most part took and slew hem /
In the same year Pope urban came fro Rome to Auynyon / purposynge to have made a
fynal pees between England and France / But er he began his traytye he deyde
/ Sum say he was poisoned / After urban / the enleuenthe Gregory was pope
eight year / This pope was called to fore Petrus de bello forte / he was deken
Cardynol and deyde in Rome in gods pees / After him followed great trybulacion
in the church which god sh^wyd by ^eu^lacion to saint Brygytte for the sins
of men of the church / In the same year Prince Edward being at Burdeux by
thauys of his counseyl byganne to set Inp^sicions and taxes up on the duchye
of Guyan / wherefore the Cite of lymoge reb^llyd and fought against him / and
other moo also and t^rned from him to the Frensshe king / wherefore he took and
destroyed that Cite And slough all that was therynne / Sone after Prince Edward
came in to England leuynge behind him in Gascoyne the duck of lancastre / and
Sire Edmond Earl of Cambrydge with other worthy men of arms / In the parliament
at Westmynstre was granted to the king a subsydye of fyfty thousand pound to
be paid of the lay fee / And then in hatered of men of the church / the
lords put out of office the chau^celer / the Tresorer / and the pryue Seal
/ and in their stead were put seculer men / In the eight and fourtyest year
of the Regne of king Edward the duk of lancastre / and the Earl of Cambrydge
the kings sons came out of guyan in to england and were married to two susters
/ daughters and heirs of king peter of spain / That same year Frensshe men
be yeged Rochel Wherefore ^^e Earl of Penbroke was sent in to Gascoyn with a
greet company of men of arms / And er they couthe enter in the haven of
Rochel there came upon hem a strong nauye of spain / which scomfyted the
English men / and took the Earl with great tresour and many other noble men /
Then the king with a great host entryd the sea to have reue^ged the siege
of Rochel / but the wind would not serve him / wherefore he tarried long at the sea Cost / abiding after a good wind / but it came not / and so he returned
home again / Then the duc of lancastre with a great host went in to
Flau^dees / and passyd through pycardye to paris / and so through all France /
till he came to burdeux without any resystence / About this time wenzelaus
sone of charles king of Boheme his fader yet living was elect and chosen to be
Emperor / he being a child / of which empire he took none heed / ne rought
not / Wherefore after he had reigned four and twenty year / and after many
warnynges he was deposed / his lecherous life defoul^d his noble wit / and his
end was without worship / For he was never crowned with a dyademe /

In this year were sent fro the pore two bisshops / one of raue^ne and one of
carpentras for to treat between two kings of france and of england / and day
was holden at Brugys in flau^dres / and there were for the king of england the
duc of lancastre / the bishop of london / and many other / And for the
Frensshe king the Duc of Burgoyne / his brother the bishop of Amyens / and
many other but they concluded no thing /

Capitulum quartum
IN the fyftyest year of king edwardes regne on Trynyte sunday that year the
eyghte day of Iuyn deyde the noble Prince edward at kenyngton / and brought to
westmestre where he had his obsequye / and fro thens carried to caunterburye /
and there worshipfully beryed beside saint thomas shryne / About this time
bartholus and baldus greet doctors of law were in her flowers / After the
death of pope gregory the / xj began the worst scysme that ever was in the
church which dured xl / year / For at rome was urban the syxthe chosen by
force and strength of the Romans / And this did the Cardynals for dread /
ageynste their entente and will / therefore they fled to the cite fundorum
saying him not to be pope / And chose in his place Robertum de gebennis / the
same year which was named the seventh clement And thus began the scysme / In
the fyfthe year the mayre of london Adam stable was dyscharged the / xxj day of
march / And nicholas brembre chosen by virtue of a lettre that came from the
king / The same year was a great parlemente at westmynstre / in which the
king axyd a great subsydye / but the Commynes answered that they might no
longer bear such charges / and said they knew well that the king had good
ynowgh for him self and for saving of his Royame / if the Royamme were well
governed / but it had be long evil ruled by evil officers that the land
might not be plentiuous of chaffare marchau^dyse ne Riches / and showed many
complayntes of dyusers officers of the Royamme / And namely on the lord latemer
the kings cha^berlayn / and on dame Alyce pyers / for great wrongs that
mysgouernaunce that were done by their counseylle / desiring that they should
be remeuyd and other put in their stead / such as were wise true / well
proved and of good governance / And so among all other they chees Sire Pyers
delamare a wise knight and eloquent for to be speker for the commynes / And by
cause the same Sire Pyers told and publysshed the truth / rehersynge the
wrongs don by diverse persons of the kings house / Anon after the death of
the good prince Edward he was put in to p^rpetuel prysonne / The same year
anon after Candelmasse during the said parliament a subsydye was granted to
the king both of the Clergy / and of the temporalyt^ / that is to say of
the temporalyte of every person passing fourten year of age / he should have
four pens / except p^ure beggars / And of every man of holy Church benefyced
or promoted twelve pens / and vnpromoted four pens / except the four ordres
of Freres / The same Rychard Prince Edwardys son was made prince of wales /
And to him the king gafe the Ducherye of Cornewayle / and the Erldome of
chestre / In the / lij / year of king Edwardes regne the / xj / kalendys of
Iuyn the said king Edward deyde in his manner at Shene / and from thens brought
to westmynstre / and there buried worshipfully at southe side of saint
edwardes Shryne On whoos soul god have mercy / Amen /

Capitulum 5
AFter king Edward the third Reigned rychard the second that was the noble
prince edwardes sone of wales / which king Rychard was borne at bourdeux / he
was crouned at westmestre / the enleuenth year of his age / In the second year
of his regne the lord latemer and Sire / Rauf Ferys stryuyng and being at
debate with Sire Robert hawle and one shakley^ for the Earl of dene their
prisoner came in to westmynstre chirch and there slough at hye mass time the
said hawle / And Shakle was arestyd and put in the toure of london / It is
said that this was done by commandment of the duc of Gloucetre Wherefore he
came / and was assoylled at westmynstre. and made greet amends and gafe great
gifts and Iewellys therefore to the said church / About this time the fest of
the vysytacion of our lady was bygonne by pope urban the enleuenth after the
form and also the same pardon that is yeuen to the feste of the Sacrament /
which feste is holden the second day of Iuyll / In this time the great
maystre of Rhodes entryd in to Turquye with a great company / And there by the
Greeks / that were with the Turks he was discomfyted and taken / and the
remenaunt of his people deed and taken to fore a Castle callid Sayette / In the
thyrdde year of his regne came certain galeyes of war out of France in to
diverse portis of England and robbed / burnt / and slew much people / in so
much that they came to grauysende and burnt a great part of the town /

In the same year was ordained at a parliament at westmynstre / that every man
and woman past fourtene year of age / should pay to the talage four pens /
wherefore fyl afterward much meschyef For in the fourth year of his regne the
Commons aroos in diverse parties in England / and did much harm / and it was
called the hurlyng time / And they of kente and of Estsex made hem two
Capytayns called Iac straw / and watte Tyler / And they assembled on blacheth
/ and on corpus Cristi day they came in to Southwerk / and let out all the
prisoners of the kings benche and marchal see / And came in to london and
robbed all the alyens and strangers and sl^ughe and made hauoke / On the
morn after they came to the toure of london where the king was present the
same time / and took out the Archebisshop of Caunterbury / and the pryour of
saint Iohans / and a white Friar confessor to the king and smote of their
hedes at tour hill / then come they again to london and slew men of law
/ and other worthy men in diverse parties of the t^une / Then went they to
the duc of lancastres place called Sauoye / and destroyed it down / and bare
(...) the goods that they might find and burnt the place / then went they
to westmestre and saint martyns the grant. and delyuerd them all out of
sayntuarye that were therynne for any manner grythe / Then came they to the
Temples / and to all other Innes of men of law. and despoylled and burnt
their books / Then came they to london again / and took out all the
prysonners felons and other out of newgate / and both countours and destroyed
their books / Then on the monday king Rychard sent for the mayr of london
William walworth / and his aldermen / and they went to speak and know
thentencion of these rebellous people / Then this Iac straw let make an oye
in the field that all his people should come nere and bear his cry and will /
Then the lo^des the mayer and aldermen having indignacion of his presumpcion
and couetyse / and the mayer seenge that he did no reverence to the king
starte to him and slew the said Iac straw Capytayne of the Rebellys / and
anon his head was smyten of / And the head raised up that all might see hit /
And forthwith Incontyne^t all tho Rysers and mysgouerned people sledde awey /
Then the king forthwith dubbyd the mayer knight / and five of his brethren
Aldermen / that is to say Sir william walworth Mayer / Sire Nychol Brambre /
Sir Johan Phylpet / Sire Nychus Twyford / Sire Robert laundre / and Sire Robert
gayton / And after this as they might take and get these rebellys and
mysgouerned people / they henge hem up by ten / by twelve twenty etc / In the
fyfth year was a great earth quaue through out all the world / the one and
twentyest day of may Of which al manner people was sore aferd / This year queen
Anne came in to england and was married unto king richard at westmynstre / In the
syxth year Sire Henry spencer bishop of norwiche went over see with a Croysye
in to Flaundres and gate the towns of grauenyng / burburgh / and Dunkyrke /
And there he did do lade one and fyfty ships with p^llage and goods which
should have comen in to England. But the Bishop let brenne the ships with
all the pyllage in the same haven / And he had a great batayl with the
Flemynges at dunkyrke / and there were slain an huge multitude of Flemynges /
The Bishop with his retenue went and besyeged Ipre long time / but he couthe
not get it / And by cause many of his men deyde there of the flux / he came
again in to england / The same year was a bataylle done within the kings
pala^s at westmynstre for certain points of treasonne between Sire Johan
Ansley knight defendaunt / and garton Squire app^llaunt / And the defendaunt
discomfyted thappellaunt / All this time dured the Scysme / For urban at Rome
was chosen Petrus de thomacellys / and was named Bonefacius Nonu^ / 13 year /
And after Clemens was chosen in Auynyon Petrus de luna / which was named /
benedictus / xiij / and he abode p^pe there two and twenty year / And after
Boneface was Innocencius septimus two year / And after him Gregorius 129.xij /
year / and after him Alexander grecus one year / And then after him Johannes
visesimus tercius / and then at Counseyll of Constance was chosen martinus
quintus / and so of all these foresaid popes from gregorius vndecimus unto
Martinus Quintus endured the scysme by the space of forty year that it was not
known who was the very and undoubted pope

Capitulum sextum /
IN the eight year of king Rychardes regne / Sir edmond of langely Earl of
Cambrydge the kings uncle went in to Portyngale with a great company of men
of Arms and Archers in strengthyng and helpyng the king of Portyngale against
the king of Spain / And there the king of Portyngale had the vyctorye / That
done the Earl of Cambrydge came home again with his Army in to england / The
same year king Rychard held his Crystemasse at El^ham / The king of E^monye
the same time fled out of his own land / and came unto king Rychard for
socour and aid / For the Turkys had devoured and destroyed much of his land
/ The king hauyn^ great pity and compassion of his great meschyef took cou^seyl
(...) on / And it was concluded that the king should give him some good / for
tauenture his people so far it were a great Ieopardye And so the king gaf him
gold and silver and many rich yeftes / and betaught him to god and so he
departed out of England This same year king Rychard with a great and
puissaunt Armee went toward Scotland / And the Scottys sent to the king and
desired and made great labor for to have a tryeus / so a tryeus was taken
and made / and then the king returned to york / and there Sire Johan holand
therle of kentis brother slew therlys sone of stafford / wherefore the king was
sore meued / and returned to london / In the nynthe year of his regne was a
parliament at westmynstre / In which the king made and created two Dukes /
Five Erlys / and a marquys / Sir Edmond of langely the kings uncle Earl of
cambrydge was made duc of york Sire thomas of wodestok his other uncle that was
Earl of bokyngham was made duc of Gloucetre / Sire leonel vere Earl of Oxenford
was made Marquys of deuelyn / Harry bolyngbroke the dukes son of lancastre
was made earl of derby / Sire Edward the dukes sone of york was made earl of
Ruthlond. Sire Johan holond the Earl of kentys brother was made earl of
huntyngdon / Sir Thomas monbray earl of notyngham was made Earl marchal of
England / Sire mychel de la pole knight was made Earl of Suffolk / and
Chaunceler of England / At this same parliament therle of march was proclaimed
heir apparau^te to the crown of England after king Rychard / The said Earl
of march went over see in to Irlond unto his lordship therldome of vlster
which was his by enherytaunce / And there as he lay on a time in a castle of
his / there came upon him greet multitude of wild Irysshe men / and he came
out of his Castle fyers^y with his people / and fought with hem manly / and
there he was slain / In the tenth year the earl of Arondel went to the Sea
with a greet nauye / and there he met an hoole flete coming fro the Rochel
laden with wyn / which were enemies goods which flote he took and brought in
to diverse havens in England / and sum unto london / where men might bye a
tonne of Rochel wyn for twenty schyllynges / In the enleuenth year of his regne
was tharysyng of certain lords in england in destruction of rebellys / etc /
that is to say Sire Thomas wodestok duk of gloucetre / Sire Rychard earl of
arundele / Sire Richard earl of warwyk / Sire harry of Bolyngbroke Earl of
Derby / And Sire thomas monbray earl marchal These five lords of understood
the myschyef and governance of the kings counceylle wherefore they that were
that time of the kings counsel fled out of the land / that is to say
master Alysaunder neuel Archebisshop of york / Sire mychel de la pole Earl of
Suffolk and chaunceler of england / and the marquys of deuelyn / Sir Robert le
vere / these three lords came never again in to england / for they deyde
beyond the sea / These five lords above said made a parliament at westmestre /
and there they took Sire Robert Tresylyon Justice / Sire nychol brembre knight
and Cyteseyne of london / Sir Johan Salesbury knight and vske sergeaunt with
other moo which were Iuged to death and were draw to Tyburn / and there hanged
/ Also in the same parlemente / Sire Simon beuerley knight of the garter / Sire
Johan beauchamp knight styward of the kings house / and sir Johan berneis were
byhedid at toure hylle Also Robert bealknap Johan holte / Johan Carry /
William burgh / Robert fulthorp and Johan lokton Iustyses were exyled in to
Irlond there for to dwell all her life time / In the twellifth year during the
said parliament was holden a general Iustys in smythfelde of lords knights and
squyers for all manner strangers that would come / holdyng (...) household to
hem and all other. And all they of the kyngys house were of one suit / thryr
Cotys / their armies / their sheld^s / and their trappours were browdrid all
with white hertis with Crowns of gold about their necks and cheynes of gold
hangyng thereon which hertys was the kings leuerey that he yaf to lords
ladies knights and squyers to know his household people from other / Then
four and twenty ladres coming to the Iustys ladde four and twenty lords with
cheynes of gold and a^le in the same suit of hertes as is a fore said from the
tour on horsbak through the Cite of london in to smythfeld / To this feste came
many great lords strangers out of France / henaud / Holond and of other
countries / which feste and Iustes endured four and twenty days upon the
kings cost / when the feste was ended and Iustys the king thankyng the
strangers ^aue to them great yeftes / And then they took their love / and so
departed / In the thirtenth year was a bataille dene in the palace at
westmestre bitwene a Squire of nauerne that was with the king / and a squire
callid Johan walssh for points of treasonne / that he of nauerne put upon
this walssh / but in the end he of nauerne was overcome and disconfyted in the
field / and yielded him / And anon he was despoylled of his armure and drawn
out of the palace unto Tyburne / and there hanged /

Capitulum Septimum /
IN the fourtenthe year Sir Johan of Gaunt duk of lancastre with a great hooste
went in to spain to Claim and challenge his right by his wives title unto the
Crown of spain / and he had with him the Duchess his wife and his three
daughters. And thereafter great commynycacion herupon had they were acorded and
concluded that the king of Spain should marye the duck of lancastres daughter
/ And he should give to the duck of lancastre gold and silver / which was
casten in to great wedgys and so many other Iewellys / as much as eight
charyottis might carye / And every year after during the life of the duc / and
his wife / ten thousand marc of gold / Of which gold they of spain should
adventure and here the Ieopardye thereof / and bring yerly unto bayon to the
dukes assygnees / by surete made / Also the duc of lancastre did do marye
another of his daughters to the king of Portyngale the same time / And then
he returned / and came again in to England with his wife / In this year the
Turks made great war ageynste Crystendome unto the Cite of Iene / wherefore
the Iene ways sent to the king of France for aid / and also to the king
of England / And so there were went out of France fyften honderd knights
with the duc of Borbon / and the Earl of ewe / and other / And out of England
went the Earl of Alby a valiant man with certain Archers / And they shipped
at marcellis / and went and besyeged thunes in Barbarye and made there many
skarmuches / and put out often the Sarasyns / but in the end the turk fered /
and made trewes for a seasonne / and delyuerd all the Christian prysonners / and
paid ten thousand du^atis / and so the Christian men returned hoome again / In
the fyftenth year of king Rychardes regne / he h^lde his Crystemas at wodestok
/ where therle of Penbroke a young lord and tender of age would learn Just
with a knight called Sire Johan saint Johan / And rode to geder in the park /
And there the Earl was slain with the knights spear as he cast it from him /
when they had coped / This year Johan hynde being that time mayer of
london and Johan Shadeworth and henry vanner shereues were dysharged of their
offices before saint Iohans day baptyst / and the king seized the fraunchyse
and lybertees of the Cite of london / And ordained and constitued Sir Edward
dalyngredge wardeyn of the Cite / and endured in his office unto the first day
of Iuyll the year / xvj / And then Sir Bowdwyn Radyngton was made wardeyue to
saint Symons day and Jude / The cause there of was for a bakers man beryng a
basket with horse bread in to Fletestrete / there come a man of the bishop of
Salesburyes that took out an horse loof out of the baskette / wherefore the
bakers man strove with the yoman / so that the Bisshops man brake the bakers
man's heed / Then neighbors come about to have rescowed him and to have
arestyd the Bisshops man / But he scope fro hem in to his lords place / The
Constable came and would have bad him out / but they withynne the place kept it
that they might not come in / And then come the mayer with much people and
said / they would have him out or brenne the place / and all that were therein
/ The Bishop being tresorer of England and the archebisshop of Caunterbu^y
went to geder to wyndesore to the king / and made a great complaynte to the
king and his cou^seylle of the Cite of london / And the king sen^e for the
mayer and shereues / and yaf hem great rebukes for thoffence that they had
done against him and his officers in his Chamber of london / And deposed the
mayer and shereues / and ma^de a wa^deyne of the Cite as before is said / In the
syxtenth year the king with drew his courts from westmynstre to york /
which were there holden and kept fro the feste of saint Johan baptyst unto
Crystemasse after / Then at request of the good Queen Anne and of the
bishop of london then called grauesende / the king granted the Fraunchyse
and lybertees to the Cite of london and they of london gaf to saint edwards
shryne a table of silver and enameled stondyng on the Awter / And after this
the mayer Alder men and shereuys met with the king submyttynge them humbly to
him as they ought do / And resseyuyng the king through the Cite with great
tryumphe / and brought him to westmynstre And on the morn after the mayer
aldermen and shreues presentyng the said table and other yeftes prayed the king
of his good and special grace to have their lybertees and Fraunchyses / as
they had to fore time / And so the king granted to them all their asking
and went home again / In this same year the duc of lancastre was sent in to
France to demand a myllion of scutes which was due for the raunson of king
Johan / And diverse places as peytowe Rochell / and a part of Guyan / And he
was answered by the counseylle of France that the men of war of England had
done harm in France above the trewes to the sum of three mylions / which
ought to be repaired first / and so departed again / In the seuententhe year
come out of Scotland certain lorde^ in to England to get worship by fete
of arms / Therle of morryf chalengid the Earl marchal of England to Just
with him on horse back with sharp speres / And so they roode to geder certain
courses / but not the full challenge / For the Scottyssh Earl was cast both
horse and man / and two of his rybbes broken with the same fall / and so borne
home in to his Inn / and anon after was carried homewarde in a littyer / and
at York he deide Sire william darel banerer of Scotlande^ and Sire pyers
Courtney the kings banerer of of england ryden to gyder certain courses of
war hitte and assayed The Scottysshe knight seeing he might not have the beter
/ yafe it over / and would no more of the challenge / Then one Cokburn Squire
of Scotland and Sire nychol hauberk rode five coursys / and at every course the
Scot was cast both horse and man / This same year the seuententh day of Iuyn
deyde the good qu^ne Anne king Rychardes wife / And lies buried at westmynstre
by saint Edwardes shryne /

Capitulum Octauum
IN the year 1494 were trewes taken between the king of France / and the king
of England for four year / Also this same year about Crystemasse king
Rychard went first in to Irlond / After wenzelaus / Rupertus alias Robertus
was Emperor nine year / This Robertus duk of bayer and Count Palatyn on the
Ryn a Just and true man and a catholyke / he was crowned of the nynthe
Boneface the Pope / He entryd in to ytalye with a great army against duk
galyace / but he returned with great loss / About this time was that cursyd
heresye of Johan wyclyf in England / and Johan hus in bohemye / and Jerome of
praghe / which heresye enfected much people And under the habyte of a lamb
hydynge woluysshe cruelte had purposed to subuerte all the state of the
church. And the sklaunderous scysme which was in this evil time was a great
help to them / Also this time the heresyee Adamitarum began to grow in
Boheme / but it was putt down by the bussytys / That was over gross. and
unshamefast / For they went naked / and Indyffrently did their lecherye with
wommen / Petrus de Elyaco / and Johan Gerson his disciple both doctors of
dyuynyte of Paris were in her flowers this tyme^ / In this year were
merueyllous great wyndes three months contynuelly / and specially in september
that ouerthrewe greet trees with fruit howses chymeneyes and steples / And
there was seen in langedok in France / a great sterre and five little sterres
assayllynge the great / and poursyewed it by the space of an hour / and a voys
cryeng fro heuene^ And after was seen a man semyng of Copper holdyng a spear in
his bands by the greet sterre / and smote hit / And after that it was no more
seen / In other places were herd the noise of harneysed men fighting /

In the nynetenthe year of king Rychard / he went to Calays / and married there
queen Isabel the kings daughter of Fraunce^ At which time the Frensshe lords
were sworen on a book that all couenauntes. Forwardys and composicions
ordained and made on both sides should be truly holden and kept without
contradiction or dylaye in any manner wise / And when this Ryal marriage was
done and fynysshed / king Rychard with dame Isabel his queen came in to England
And the mayer of london with all his brethren with great multitude of the
Commons of the Cite and the Craftys resseyued hem worshipfully at Blacheth and
brought hem to saint Georges bar / And there taking their l^ue^ the king
and the Queen roode to kenyngton / And after that withynne a while the queen
came to the Toure of london / at whoos coming was much harm done / For on
london bridge were nine persons crowded to death / Of whom the pryour of
Typtre was one / And from the tour she went through the Cite of london to
westmynstre / and there she was crowned / And after this king rychard by
appoyntemente delyuerd the town of breast to the duc of brytayne / whereof bygon
much trouble and sorrow which dured unto his deth^ In the twentyest year king
Rychard did hold a great feste at westmynstre / At which feste arrived the
Sowdyours that had kept breast / And sat at dinner in the hall / and after
dinner the Duc of Gloucetre said to the king / Sire have ye not seen tho
felawes that sat at dinner in your halle / And the king demanded who they
were / And he said these ben your folk that have served you and ben come from
breast / and now wot not what to do / and have been evil paid / Then the
king said that they shall be paid / Then answered the duc of Gloucetre in a
great furye / Sire ye ought first to put your body in deuoyre to get a
town or a Castle by fayt of war upon your enemies / er ye should selle or
deliver any towns that your predecessors kings of England have gotten and
conquered To the which the king answered right angrely / how say ye that /
Then the duk his uncle said it ageyn / Then the king byganne to wexe
wroth and said Wene ye that I be a merchant or a fool to selle my land /
by saint Johan baptist nay / but truth it is that our Cosyn of britayne has
rendryd and paid to us the sum that my predecessors had lent upon the
said town of Breast / and sith he has paid it is reasonne / that this town
be delyuerd to him again / Thus began the wrath between the king and his
uncle / And afterward at Arondele was a Counseylle of certain lords / as the
duck of Gloucetre the Archebisshop of Caunterbury / The Earls of arondele /
warwyk and marcha^ / and other / For to refourme the rewle about the king /
which lords promised ech^ ta bide by other and so departed / and anon after
the Earl marchal which was Capytayne of Calays bewrayed and let the king
have knowleche of all their counseylle / Whereupon the five and twentyest day
of august / the duke of Gloucetre was arrestyd at plasshey in Estsex / and
brought to the tour of london and from thenn^s sent to Calays / and there
murthred and slain without process of law or Justice / / and therle of
arondel / the Earl of warwyk Sir Johan Cobham / Sire John cheyne knights were
arestyd and put in hold / Save therle of arondel fond seurte tanswere and
went at large till the parliament time / In the one and twentyest year of king
richard at the parliament holden at westmynstre / therle of arondel was brought
to fore all the lords / and there was Iuged to death / that he should goo on
foot fro westmynstre through the Cite of london to the tour hylle / And there to
have his heed smyten of And six lords roode with him to see that Execucion
should be do wi^h great multitude of people of men of Arms and Archers / For
they dredde lest he should be rescowed by men of london / And on the morn
tharchebisshop of Caunterbury his brother was banysshed for evermore / And Sire
Thomas Mortemer was banysshed also / And Sire Rychard Earl of warwyck came to
fore the parlemente / And was Iuged to the same death / but by cause of his age
he was releced to perpetuel prysonne / The Mondaye after Sire Johan Cobham /
and Sire Johan Cheyne were Iuged to be drawn and hanged / but at the Instaunce
of the lords that Judgment was releced unto perpetuel prysonne / And this done
king Rychard made a ryal feste and held open Court / In which feste he made
five Dukes / A marqueys / and five Earls / that is to say the Earl of Derby
was made duc of Herford / The Earl of Ruthlond was made Duc of Anmarle / The
Crle of Kente / Duck of Surrey / The Earl Huntyngdon Duck of Excetre / The Earl
Marchal Duck of Norfolk / The Earl of Somersete Marqueys of Doesete / The
lord spencer / Earl of Gloucetre / The lord Neuyll Earl of westmerlonde / Sire
Thomas Percy / Earl of worcetre / Sire william Scrope Earl of wylshyre / Sire
Johan Montague Earl of Salysbury / And thus there was a greet feste to al
these lords / and to all other that would come /

In the same year fylle a greet debate and dyssencyon between the Duck of
herford Earl of Derby on that one party / And the Duke of Norfolk Earl
marchal on that other party / In so much that they waged bataylle and cast
down their gloves which were taken up before the king and ensealed / And the
day and place assygned at Couentre / To which place the king cam^ the Duk of
lancastre and other lords / And when both parties were in the field ready
for to fight the king took the matere in his own hand / And forthwyth he
exyled and banysshed the Duke of Herford for ten year / And the duke of
norfolk for ever / The Duc of Norfolcke deyde at venyse In the two and
twentyest year of king Rychard there were made blank Charters / to which all
the Rich men of the Royamme were compellyd to set to their seals / And it
was noysed through the Royamme / that he had set England to ferme to Sire
william Scrope Earl of wylshyre / sir Johan busshe / Sire Johan grene / and sir
Johan bagot / and he ordained his uncle Sir edmond of langley duk of yorcke to
be his lyeutenaunt / whiles he should be in Irlond in his absence / In this year
deyde the duc of lancastre / and is buried at powlus in london / Then king
Rychard went in to Irlonde with many lords and great ordenaunce / And there
he was well resseyued / And the wild^ Irysshmen came down to him with their
Capytaynes and yielded them to him / and swore to be his true lyege men / and
did him hommage and feawte Thus he conquered Irlond the most part in a little
while /

Whiles king Rychard was in Irlond thus occupied Sire Harry of Bolyngbrooke
Earl of Derby the duc of lancastres son / whom king Rychard had made Duk
of Herford / And had exyled him for certain causes / and with him
tharchebisshop of Canterbury also londed at rauenspore in the north contre And
by the Color of his title to the Duchye of Lancastre he raised and assembled
the people ever as he went in so much as he had greet multitude of people
/ For the people were so oppressyd with the officers of king Rychard / that
almoost all the Commyns of the land were ready to awayte on the Earl of Derby /
hoping to be releuyd by him / Incontinent tidings came to king Rychard being
in Irlond how he was landed and that the Commons drew fast to him / Anon he
made him ready and came over see in to England with all his hooste / and arrived
in Mylford haven / And there tarried a two days for to refresshe him and his
hooste / And in the mean while the lords and most part of the people
understood that the Earl of Derby bycam strenger and strenger / began to
murmr and to grutche / That seeing / Sir thomas Percy called them to geder
brake the Rdode of his office / For he was styward / and badde every man goo
his wey vnwetyng the king / And so in the night every man went his weye
leuynge the king allone save two or three lords with a few men / which
lords for sewerte and by counseyll of the styward brought the king to the
Castle of Flynt / where he was taken and delyuerd to therle of Derby / which
brought him to london / And then were taken at Brystowe Sire william scrope /
Sir Johan bussh / Sir harry grene / and Sir Johan bagot / But Sire Johan bagot
escaped / And the other that were take were byheded / And thus as he was coming
to london ward / tidings came to the Cite / that king Richard was comen to
westmynstre / And anon the people of london in their furye and wodenesse as
people maliciously set against king Richard their sovereign lord Roose and
purposed if they might have founden to have destroyed him / But the mayer and
aldermen with the sad men of the town with much work turned hem hoome
again to london / yet they took Sire Johan slake dene of the kings chapel /
and put him in ludgate / and Sire Johan Bagot that escaped from bristowe was
take in Irlond and brought to london and set in newegate / Sone after this
king Rychard was brought to the tour of london / and then was there a
parliament / In which king Rychard was deposed of his Crown / And king Henry
chosen and taken for the king / to whom king Rychard resygned the Crown and
the Royamme of England / And then from the tour he was had to the Castle of
ledes in kente / And from thennes he was had to the Castle of Pountfret /

Capitulum 9
Then the duc of lancastre Earl of derby named Henry bolyngbroke was crowned
king of england at westmynstre on saint Edwardes day Confessour^ Then made
the king his oldest son henry prince of wales / Duke of Cornewayle / and
Earl of Chestre / he made Sire thomas of Arondel Archechebisshop of Caunterbury
/ as he was before / And he that was made Archebisshop by king Rychard / he
made him Bishop of london / and he made the Erlis son of Arondel to be put
in p^ssession of all his lands / In the first year of his regne be held his
Crystemas at wyndesore / And on the tweluthe even the duk of Anmarle told the
king how the duc of surrey / the Duc of excetre / the earl of Salesbury and
therle of gloucetre with other of their affynyte were acorded to make a
mommynge / to the king and so for to slay him in the revelling / wherefore the
king the same night came privily to london / and anon these lords that had
purposed to have made this mommery understood that their counseylle was
bewrayed / anon with their people went westward / And at Sysseter the Duke of
Surrey and the earl of Salesbury were taken and biheded and their heedes set
on london bridge / and at Oxenforde were taken two knights blou^t / and sir
benette Sely and wyntercele a squire / which were byheded and quartred and
their heedes set on london bridge / and the quartres sent to other good
towns / And at prithwell in Estsex Sire Johan holonde Duck of excetre was
taken with the Commons of the Countreye / and his heed smyten of / and sent to
london and set on london bridge / Also at Bristowe was take the lord spencer
that was made by king Richard earl of Gloucetre and biheded and his heed sent
to london and set on londonbridge / In the same year Sire Bernarde brokeis.
Sir Johan Selley / Sir Johan mawdelyn / and Sir william Ferby were taken and
set in the tour / And after by Judgment were hanged and byheded / and their
heedes set on london bridge / when king henry saw that these lords thus
