had risen / and assemblyd greet people to have put him to death / and for to
restore king Rychard again to his Crown / and to his Royamme thought
^eschue such peryls / Anon commanded Sir Pyers of Exton that he should goo
strayte to pountfreyte / and deliver the world of king Rychard / And so he
departed fro the king / and went to the Castle of Pountfret / where as king
Rychard was in prysonne / the which was set at table for to dyne / And anon
after Sire Pyers came in to the chamber where the king was / and eyghte men
with him / and each man an axe in his hond / Troth it is when the king saw
Sir Pyers with his Felaushippe enter in to the chamber defensably arrayed / he
shoof the table from him / and sprange in the mids of hem / and caughte an
axe out of one of their hondes / and set him self valyauntly at defense /
And him self defending he slow four of the eyghte / And when the said
Sire Pyers saw the king so defend him / he was soore abashed and gretely
aferde / And forthwith sterte upon the place / where as king Rychard was wont
to sytte / And as king Rychard fought and defended him self going bacwarde /
the said Sire Pyers smote him on the heed with his axe that he fill to ground
/ Then cried king Rychard god mercy / And then he gafe him yet another
stroke on the heed / and so he deyde / And thus was this noble king slain
and murthred / And when the king was deed / the knight that had thus
slain him / set him down by the deed body of King Rychard / And byganne
to weep / saying Alas / what thing have we done / We have put to death him
that has been our king and sovereign lord two and twenty year / Now have I
lost mine honor / Ne I shall never come in place / but I shall be reproched / For
I have done ageynste mine honor / After this the tweluest day of march was
the body of the Noble king Rychard brought through London to Powlus / which
Corpse was leyd on a Charyotte coueryd with black / and four baners / whereof
tweyne were of the arms of saint George / and tweyne of the Arms of Saint
Edward / And there were an honderd men clothed in black each berynge a Torche /
And the Cite of londo n badde thyrtty men in white / Each berynge also a torche
/ And the Corpse was leyd open the vysage that every man might see and know
that it was his body and that he was so deed / For many men byleuyd it not /
And from thennes he was carried to the Frerys at Langley and there he was buried
/ On whoos soul God have mercy Amen / The Common oppynyon of Englysshmen is
that king Rychard deyde not after the manner a foresaid / But that he deyde
other wise / That is to wete that when ^e herd say / that his brother the
Duc of Ex^^^te / The Duc of Surey / The Earl of Salysbury. and the other lords
were deed / He was so angry and so sorrowful / that ^e swore that ^e would
never eete meet And so abode four days without erynge as they say / And
when that king Henry understood that he would not ete / he sent to him two
prelates for to comfort him And when they were come he confessyd him to one of
them / the which gaf him in penance that he should ete his mete / And when
be supposed to have eten / the meet might not goo down / ne auale in to his
stomach For the conduytes of his body were shronken to geder / And then
said the noble king Rychard that it was d^n^ / and that he must needs deye /
and so he deyde / But certes whether be deyde this way / or that other /
Certainly he deyde / and was buried at langley / God have mercy on his soul /
Amen / And then was king Harry peasyly king / Then he fond in king
Rychardes tresorye nine honderde thousand nobl^s without Iewellys and
vessels. which was as much worth or more / And there was founden in the
tresorers keeping of England an honderde and fyfty thousand nobles / and
Jewels and vessel as much or more / And thus king henry had all his
goods / Item This same year king harry sent hoome again king Rychardys wife
Queen Isabel unto the king of France her fader / and put her from her
dowayre

Capitulum decimum
IN the second year of king Harry the fourth Sire Rogyer of Claryngton knight
and two of his men / and the priour of launde with eight Friar mynours were
drawn and hanged for treasonne / In this year began a great debate in walys
between the lord gray Rethyn and ewayn of Glyndor Squire of wales / This Ewayn
raised great nombre of walsshmen and kept the Country with strength and did
much harm. and destroyed the kings towns and lordshippes in walys Robbyng
and sleyng the kings people which continued long time / And took the lord
Gray prisoner and made him to marye his daughter / And held him stylle there
with his wife / And son^ after the lord Gray deyde / Then king Harry with a
great power went in to wales / for to take and destroy the said Ewayn / but
he and all his company fled to the montayns where the king might not hurt
hem for the montaynes / And so the king returned and came again in to
England for losing of his men / In the same year was a great scarcete of
whete in england / a quarter was (...) sixten shyllynges / wherefore merchandise
was sent in to normandy for whete / and from thennes came great plente / Also
Sire william Sawtry priest was degraded of his presthode / About this time the
Duc of Orleaunce sent an herowde of Arms with lettres unto king Harry / by
which he chalengyd for to fight with him withynne lystes at Bourdeux / or in
sum other metely place with an honderd Gentylmen without reproach ageynste
as many Gentle men without reproach / Whereto the king answered again by
lettres worshipfully / rehersynge that at such time as it should plese him / he
would come with such nombre as it apperteyneth to a king / and conquer his
right / At which time he should be answered at full / And so the matter
fynysshed In the thyrd^ year was king henry wedded to dame Jane Duchess of
britain And they were married at wynchestre / And fro thens she came to london /
And so forth to westmynstre / And there she was crowned Queen / In the same
year was dame blaunche oldest daughter to king harry wedded in Coleyn to the
dukes son of bayer with great solempnyte / In the seventh year was seen a
sterre that is called stella Comata / and anon after was the batayl of
shrerewesbury on mary magdalens even in which bataylle was slain Sire Harry
Percy / and Sir thomas percy taken and kept two days / and after he was hanged
byheded and quartred and his heed set on london bridge / And in this batayl
was the Prince shot in to the heed with an arowe / And the Earl of Stafford
was slain under the kings baner / And many other lords knights squyers and
Gentyls were put to death in the said bataylle / In the fourth year came the
Emperor of Constantynople with many great lords and knights in to England to
see the king / the people / and the Royamme / and the Commodytees thereof / The
same year the lord Castle with a great multitude of Brytons and of normans
landed a mile out of Plymouthe on saint Laurence day at after None and came in
to the town on the bakhalf / and there they abode all that day and all that
night till it was on the morn ten of the Clock and Robbed and despoylled all that was in the town / and bare hit awey at her own will / In the fyfthe
year was a great bataylle on the sea at blackpole two mile out of dertmouth
between Englysshmen and Brytons / where thanked be God Englysshemen had the
vyctorye / and there were take slain and drowned moo than five honderd gentyls
of Frensshe men and Brytons / On whom the lord castle was pryncipal leder and
Captain which there was taken and slain / Also this same year william Serle
/ the which was one of hem that murtherd the gooed duke of Gloucetre at Caleys
was taken in the march of Scotland / and brought to london and there he was
drawn / hanged and byheded / and his heed set on london bridge / and his
quarters set up in four good towns / In the syxthe year was a Iustys in
Smythfeld between the Earl of morryf in Scotland and Sire Edmond Earl of kente
upon a challenge made by therle of morryf to Just certain courses of war
with sharp sperys on horsbak / And the Earl of kente had the field / and gate
him there great worship / This same year Sire Rychard Scrope Archebisshop of
york and the lord Monbraye that was Earl marchal of England assemblyd great
power against king harry / And th^kyng met with hem and took hem / and smote of
both their heedes / And soon after god showed and wrought many miracles for
this worthy Clerk Arclebisshop of york / that was so put to death / In the
seventh year the mayer of london Johan wodecok and the comynalte did do break
up all the weerys that were between medewey and kyngeston / by cause they were
set against the fraunchyse of the Cite of london / In the eight year of king
henry dame lucye the dukes suster of Melayn come in to England / and so forth
to london / and there was she ryally married to Sir Edmond holond Earl of kent
in the pryory of saint marye ouerayes in southwerk / The same year sir Robert
knollys knight a great warryour in his time / did do make the bridge at
Rochestre and a chapel at brydges foot / the which Sire Robert deyde and
lies buried in the white Freres in Lond^n / by his wife dame Constaunce / In
the same year Sir Thomas rampston knight constable of the tour of london was
drowned at london bridge as he come fro westmynstre toward the tour in a barge
/ The same year dame Phelyp the younger daughter of king henry was married to the
king of Denmark / In the same year a man that was called the walssh clerk
appelled a knight called Sire Percyual of treasonne / And they fought with in
lystes in Smythfeld / where the knight scomfy^ed the Clerk / and there the
Clerk was despoylled of his armure / and drawn out of the feld to Tyburn and
there hanged In the same year Sir henry Percy earl of northumberlond and the
lord bardolf coming out of Scotland to geder with a great company were taken
by them of the north that fought with them and smote of their heedes and
brought hem to london / and set hem on london bridge / In the / ix / year was
Sire Edmond Earl of kente made Ameral of the sea / which kept the sea
worthyly with many Ryall ships / And at last he londed at the Costs of
Brytayne in the I Will of Bryak / and besyeged the castle / and sawted hit / and
with a quarrel he was slain / but never theles the Castle was gotten / And
then his meyne come home again with therles body which was buried with his
Anncestryes worshipfully / Also this same year was a great Frost that dured
fyftene wekys / which frost destroyed for the most part all the small birds
/

Capitulum xi
This year lowys Duc of Orleauns was slain mescheuously at Paris at
Commandment of the duc of Burgoyne / For it was so that the duc of Orleaunce
had been to vysyte the Queen / And as he returned to his Inneward / certain
persons ordained by the said duc of Burgoyne lay in a wait / and fill on
him and slew him cruelly smiting the brayn out of his heed / And one of his
gentylmen was slain with him / wherefore on the morn was a great counseyll / And
the ya^es of Paris were closed / And all the great lords then being at
Paris were assemblyd / Among whom was the said duc that commysed this murdre /
and there was given strayte commandment to the Provost of Paris that he
should make strayte search to know who had co^mised this great murdre / For
as soon as the murdres had slain the duk / they set an house a fire / And
while the people came for to stau^che the fire / they had their horses ready /
and so escaped and roode in to flaundrys / And on the next day when all the
lords were reassembled there was much axynge and serchyng. who might do
this murdre / Then the said Duc of Burgoyne stood up and said that he him
self had do put him to death for certain causes which he would Iustyfye /
and forthwith he departed out of the counse^l and went to his lodgyng / and
took his horse with a pryuy meyney / and rode strayt to l^yle / and after came al
his other meyny / and so departed he from paris / Whereupon after came the
duchess of Orleaunce his wife the Dukes daughter of Melan with her sons / and
her oldest sons wife suster to the king / which had been to fore queen of
England king Rychardys wife / and required humbly Justice of the king /
which then was in good heel / and sat in the chayer of Justice / To whom
the king said that he would do Justice on them that commysed that horrible
crysme on his seul and only brother / And that they should verily know it in all
have possible / Then after this the duc of Bargoyn made requestys that he
might come to fore the king and his counseyll for to Iustyfye the death of the
duc of Orleau^ce / which was granted / and so came with a great Army in to
Paris / And there to fore the Dolphyn and all the counseylle of the kings in
plain parlemente by a doctor of dyuynyte called master Johan Petyte / he made
his Iustificacion / And after at another day assygned the duchess of
Orleaunce did by another doctoure of divinity make a replicacion / And so that
matter ^enge long / which matter was occasion of Infynyte sorrow in the Royamme
of France / About this time the counseylle of Pyse was / in which was
bygonne the manner to make union in the church / but ^ it prevailed not / In
the tenthe year came the Seneschal of henawd wtth many other gentil men in to
England for to do arms and to g^ete honor and worship / The Seneschal
chalengyd therle of Somersete And therle delyuerd him manly of his chalengys
and wanne thonoure o^ the field. / The next day after came in to the field
another man of the Seneschallys party / and against him came Sire Rychard of a
rondele knight / And the Henewer had the better of him for he brought him on
his knees The thyrdde day came in another And again him came Sire Johan
Cornewayle knight and manly quytte him in the field and had the beter of his
aduersarye On the fourth day came in to the feld another Henewer And ageynste
him came Sire Johan Cheynco son / and he cast ^oune horse and man / And therefore
the king dubbyd him knight The Fyfthe day came in another Henewer / And to him
came Sire Johan Styward knight / which quytte him manly and had the better /
The Syxthe day came another Henewer / And to him came william Porter Squire /
And he had the better of the Henewer / and the king dubbyd him knight The
seuenthe day came in another Henewer / And to him came John standysshe Squire /
and he had the better / and the king dubbyd him knight / The same day came
another Henewer And to him came a squire of Gascoyne / which had the better /
and was dubbed knight / The eight day came in two Henewers / And to hem came two
Sowdyours of Calays / that were brethren which had the better in the field /
And thus ended this Challenge with much worship / The king then fested the
strangers ryally / And at their departing yafe him Rich yeftes / and so
they departed and went home / In the enleuenth year was a battle done in
smythfelde between two squyers / One called Gloucetre / And that other Arthure
/ which well and manly fought to geder long time / And the king for their
manlynes took their quarrel in to his hand / and made hem goo out of the field
to gyder attones / And so they were dyuyded of their bataylle / And the king
yaf hem grace / This same year the Comon^ put up a bylle in the parliament to
the king as for the temporalytres being in the hands of the spirituelte. but
there was none answer given at that time / For the king would be aduysed / After
Rupertus Sygismundus was elect and chosen emperor this same year / and was
Emperor seven and twenty year / This Sygysmundus was king of hongary which
was a very Christian and meke man / also devout and holy / and after
thoppynyon of sum persons worthy to be canonysed / This was a special socour
to holy church which he fond soore afflycte and desolate by the scysme /
but he by his merueyllous wisdom and industrye socoured it gretely / For he
spared not him self / ne his unto the time that there was a very and full union
in the church / He had nine batataylles against the turks / which he al
gate tryumphyng / what shall I say more / but all the lawde that has be given
to Constantyn / Theodosio / To Charles / To Ottone / and all other Emperors
worthy to be preysed / may surely be applied to this Sygysmunde / he was
crowned of Eugenye / After this the Royamme of Boheme was a great pa^te
destroyed by Sygismunde / and the princes of Almayne for the heresye of the
hussytes / And the pope gaf out a Croysye against them / A Croysye given by
the pope is when he gives plain Indulgence to them that make war ageynste
Hethen men / Turks or heretykes / or them that be not obedyente to the church
of Rome / In the same year Johan of badby a falls lollar and heretyke was burnt
in Smythfeld / which byleuyd that the Sacrament was was not gods body /

Capitulum Duodecimum
IN the twellyfth year of king Harry was taken a Squ^er of wales that had been
a rebelle and supporter of owen of glyndor and he was Iuged to death at london /
where he was drawn hangyd and quartred. and his four quartres set up in four
good towns / and his head on london bridge In the thyrtenth year of his regne
deyde Sire Johan Beauford Earl of Somersete Capytayne of Calays / And lies
buried in the Abbaye of the Tour hylle / The same year came the ambassatours of
France from the duc of Burgoyne to the prince king henryes son for help
and socour against the duc of Orleaunce / Then went over / The Earl of
Arondele / the Earl of kyme / and the lord Cobham with many other knights /
and squyers / and had a great retenew against the duc of Orleaunce / And at
sayntelo beside Paris in France they met and had vyctory of the Frensshmen /
and of the Armynaks / And the duc rewarded Rychely our Englyssh men and they
come again / Not long after the duc of Orleaunce sent Ambassatours to king
Harry to have help and socour against the duc of Burgoyne. At which time the
king made thomas his son duc of Clarence / And Johan his sone duc of Bedford
/ And his son vmfrey Duke of Gloucetre / Sire thomas beauford Earl of Dorsete
/ And the duc of Anmarle he made Duck of york / Then he ordained the Duc of
Clarence / and the Earl of Dorsete / and Sire Johan cornewayle with a great
retenue to pass over in to France to help and strength the duck of
Orleaunce / and then the lords with their retenue sailed in to normandye /
And at their londynge met^e ageynste hem the lord ham^o with seven thousand
men of Arms of Frensshemen / which were put to flight / and taken of hem
seven honderd men of Arms of Frensshmen / and took many prysonners / And so
they rode forth through France taking Castles and towns / and slew much
people of frensshme^ and took many prysonners / and so passed forth till they
come to Bourdeux / there restyng them a while / And set the counray in peace
and rest / and then come hoome again / In this year the Coin was lyghted
both of Gold and of silver / and weyed less syn than it did before / In the
/ xiiij year of the regne of king harry there were made galeys of war for the
king purposed to have passed the sea / and so forth unto Jerusalem / but god
vysyted him with great and fervent Infyrmytees / and on a day he was brought to
saint Edward Shr^n to make his offryng and to take his leave / And there being
he becam so seek that they were about him supposed he should have deyd there /
and then they took and bare him in to the abbots place in to a fair large
chamber / and leyde him upon a Paylet to fore the fyre^ And when he was
comen to him self again / and wist not where he was / he axyd of his
Chamberlayn where he was / and how the Chamber was called that he was Inn /
And he told him that he was in thabbots place / and that the chamber was named
Jerusalem / Then he said that his time was come. and that it was prophesied
of him / that he should dye in Jerusalem / and there disposed him to godwarde
and made him ready / and sone after deyde in the same chamber / On whoos soul
god have mercy Amen / Then was the body carried from thennes in a barge by
water to Feuersham / And from thennes to Caunterbury by land / and there by
saint thomas shryne in Cristys church he is buried / Thus ended king harry the
fourth about mydlente sunday in the year of our lord / a thousand four
honderd and twelve

Capitulum xiij
AFter king Harry the fourth reigned harry his son borne at monmouthe in
walys / This Harry which was the fyfth harry after the Conquest was a noble
and wise man / For after his faders death when he had take upon him to be
king / he changed al his Conditions and was suddenly changed and left al
his old wyld manners and charged all them / that had been conuersaunt in his
wild living that they should avoid his presence and come no more therynne /

This man did many greet things in his days / and reigned not fully ten year
/ For in the tenth year of his regne and syx and thyrtty year of his age he
deyde / and is buried worshipfully at westmynstre / In his first year anon
after he was crowned / which was the nynthe day of Apryll / He sent to the
Frerys at langley where the body of king Rychard the second was buried and let
the body take out of therth again and did do bring it to westmynstre in a
Ryal chare couerd with black velvet and baners of diverse arms about / And
all the horses in the chare were couerd with blac / and beten with diverse
Arms / and many a torche brennyng by the chaar till they came to westmynstre /
And there he let make a ryall terment and buried him by queen Anne his wife as
his desire was / About whoos sepulcre there stand four great tapers
contynuelly brennynge / And one day in the weke perpetuelly he has a Dirige
with nine lessons And on the morn a mass / both by note solempnly on which
day is given also wekely in pens to pour people enleuen schyllynges / and viij
d / all ordained by this king upon great pain / And on the day of his
annyuersary is yerly given twenty pond in pens to pour people / Also this king
ordained by his life and founded the chartrous at Shene / And the house of Syon
of saint Brygyttes order / And did much good to the newerke at westmynstre
where he lies buried / and ordained three masses perpetuelly to be songen over
him daily / and also certain lyghtes daily to brenne at hye mass and at
euensong / and twenty pound to be deled in pens yerly at his annyuersarye / All this ordained he by his live beside all his war in France and other greet
acts / On whoos soul Ihesus have mercy Amen / Also in this first year Sire
Johan old Castle lord Cobh^m was take and dampened for an heretyk by all holy church and commyted to the tour^ and from thennes he brake prysonne / and
escaped / And anon after he and his Complyses conspyreden the kings death and
his brethren / and also the destruction of holy chirche^ For they had
purposed to have assemblyd by night in saint gyles field for tachyeuyd their
evil purpose / But blessed be God the king and lords had knowleche of their
entente / and took the field to fore them / and awayted on their coming and
took many priests / clerkys / and other lewd men that were of their sect fro
all the parties of England / wenyng to have founden their Captain there Sire
Johan old castle / but they were deceived For there were take many of them /
and nine and thyrtty were hanged on one day upon a new payr galowes new made
fast by the same field by the hye way / And seven of the gretteste heretykes
were burnt hangyng on the galowes / And anon Sire Rgoyer Acton knight was
taken draw and hanged upon the same galowes for the same cause / In the
second year of his regne byganne the general counseylle at Counstaunce for
the union of holy Church / and for to depose them that were Scysmatykes / and
to chose one very heed and vndubytate pope / Also the same year Johan Claydon
skynnar and Rychard baker of lombardstrete were brent in Smythfelde for heresye
/ Also this same year by thadnys of his counseyle the king sent lettres unto
the king of France that he should render and deliver to him his enherytaunce /
which his predecessors had holden and had to fore him. or else he would do
his deuoyre to great it by the help of god and of his subgettys with the
sword / To whom it was answered that the king was over young and tender of age
to use the war ageynste hem and in derysyon sent to him a tonne full of
Tenyse balls to play with ^ And when the king understood his answer /
anon he let do ca lle a counseylle / and there showed them thismater / matter
/ And there it was concluded by the said counseylle and in especial by the
spiritu^^te that h^ should goo and great normandye / and they would help him to
their power / It is said that the spyritualte f^red soore / that if he had
not had to do without the land / that he would have labored for to have
taken fro the church the temporel possessions / And therefore they concluded
among hem self that they should stire him for to goo and make war over see in
France / for to conquer his ryghtful enherytaunce / And so it was concluded
and acorded that the king and lords with all their power should mete at
Southhampton at lammasse next after / And so the eyghtenth day of Iuyn the
king roode through london with all his hooste ryally toward Southhampton / And
there being ready for to pass and all his lords assembled There was taken
and arestyd for hye treasonne Sire Rychard Earl of Cambrydge brother to the duc
of york / the lord Sccope Tresorer of england / and Sire thomas gray knight /
which should ymagyne the kings death / For which cause they were Iuged and
dampened to death / And there the nine and twentyest day of Iuyll they were
byheded / And then the king and all the lords with their armee took the sea with fyften honderd say^^ys / and arrived at kydkaws in normandy / And fro
thennes went and leyd syege to harflete by land and by water / And leyd his
ordenaunce to the town / And the two and twentyest day of September the
toune^ was given over to him / Then ordained he there capytayne his vncl^ the
Earl of Dorsete / and put out the Frensshmen / and stuffyd it with
englisshmen / Then the king sent in to England / and let cry in every
good town that what crafty man would come theder for to dwell and enhabyte
the town there should have hows and household to him and his heirs for
evermore / Then come theder many crafts men / and enhabyte them there / The
king seeing the town well stuffyd with vytaylle and men / he passyd forth by
land toward Calays / Then the Frensshmen heerynge of his coming brake the
brydges that he should not come over the River of Sum /. Then the king
went so fer upward / that he gate over and came in to Pycardye / And then
were the Frensshmen at Agyncourt Rolandcourt and blangy with all the Ryal
power of France / except the duc of Burgoyne which would not come theder /
ne suffer his son the lord charoyles to come theder / And when the king
saw that h^ might not pass / he took hi^ field with such people as he had /
which were not passing seven thousand fighting men And the most part of
hem were seek of the flyxe / and the yemanry had their hosen teruen or
bounden bynethe the knee having long Iackys^ But every man had a good bow a
sheef arowys. and a swerd Then he set his field / and set the duc of york
in the vauntward / And ordained in the night to fore the bataylle that each man
should make a stake sharp on both^ thendes and pytche it a slope in the ground
to fore him / And so on the morn he had his confessor that made hem to
say a general confession / and gaf them general absolucion / And then the
king roode thurgh^ the field and comforted hem promising to them that he
wol^d rather deye that day than yield him / And then every man took good
heart and courage And so abode the coming of Frensshmen. whom they resseyued
on her stakys stomblynge and falling done horse and man / In such wise that
our men shot on hem / and so fought that through the grace of god the
vyctorye abode with the king / and the Frensshmen overthrown / and were slain
of them enleuen thousand and moo / And many great lords and gentyls take
prysonners / And when the king had thus gotten the Field / tidings came
that there was coming a new battle of Frensshmen toward him / And then he
did do cry and commanded that every man should slay his prysonners And when
the duc of Orleaunce herd that / and other greet lords / they sent word to
the Frensshmen / that if they came on they should be slain / And then the
Frensshmen for sauacion of the prysonners lives withdrewe them / And so the
king had and kept the field / and wanne the worship of the bataylle / And
there were slain in the field three Dukes / Nine Erlys / And Barons nyghe an
honderde / and Gentylmen in Cote armoure / xlv / C / And of the Englyss^e
party the Duc of york / and therle of Suffolk and not twenty persons moo
blessed be god / the duc of Braban was taken a live / but when the king

soul and all other god have mercy Amen / Thus by the help of Almighty God
the king of England with vij / M / Englysshmen wan the feld upon the
Frensshmen which were nombred moo than four score thousand men with all the
ryall lords of France except the king and Dolphyn / And when al was done
the king demanded the herowdes the name of the next place to the field / And

earls of Ewe and of vendon / Burcicaught the marchal of France with many other

that bataylle gate good prisoners or good Iewellis For the Frensshmen were
Richely and costlew arrayed / whereof our peuple had good pyllage /

Capitulum 14
IN the thyrdde year of his regne the emperor of Almayne Sygysmund came in to
England / and was received worworshipfully at dover ky the duc of gloucetre /
And the Cite of london / as the mayer Aldermen and all the crafts in the
most best wise resseyued him at blackheth / the seuenthe day of may / And at
saint thomas wateryng the king him self with his lordys met him and welcomed
him in the most goodlyes^ wise / And took him by the hand / and^ roode forth
with him through the Cite and offrid at powlis / and then rode forth unto
westmestre / where the king lodged him in his own palace / And there abode a
great while at the kings cost /

Then come the Duc of Holonde in to England / whom the king resseiued
worshipfully / and lodged him in the Bishop of Elyes place in holburne /
when the Emperor had seen the manner of this land and the commodytees
thereof / he was elect and chosen to be a brother of the garter / which he took
and received gladly / and ware it ever after / And then the king brought him
to Calays / And theder came to him the duk of Burgoyne for to do hommage to
the emperor for the count of alst in Flaundres / whom the king received
worshipfully / And then after the emperor took leave of the king / and
departed / and so each took leave of other and the king returned again in to
England / And the Emperor went to Zierixsee in Zeland / and then unto
Dordrecht in holonde^ In the fourth year the duc of Bedford / therle of march
and other certain lords with their retenue foughten on the sea against seven
Carryks of gene / and fyfty other vessels as hulkes barges / galeys and
galyetis / Of whom were taken three great carryks with the patrons. and drowned
a great hulke called the black hulk of flaundres. And the remenaunt fled
aweye and this was done on our lady day Assumpcion / Also this year at a
parliament holden at westmynstre was granted to the king an hoole fyftenthe /
and a dyme to mayntene with his warrys / And this year the king sailed with all
his retenewe over see in to normandye again / And londed on lammas day at
Took / And there at landynge the king made eight and forty knights / And
anon the king wanne the Town of Took and the Castle without struck / and
he made Sire Johan kygley Capytayne thereof / And then the king sent therle
marchal unto lovers which they sawted / And anon it was yolden / And therle
brought the keys to the king. and the king delyuerd him the keys again /
and made him Capytayn of lovers / Then the king went to Cane / and besyeged
it / and with a sawte entryd the town and gate it / but the Castle held / and
the Capytayne desired respyte of fourten days for tabyde rescows / and if none
came than to delyuere it / The king granted it him and under the same
apooyntement was the Cite of bayows with other towns and fortresses unto the
nombre of fourtene / upon the hill to fore the Castle of Cane the king pyght
all his tents and pauyllons which seemed a town as much as Cane And when
tidings came that no rescowes would come / at fourten days end the Capytayne
delyuerd the keys and Castle unto the king /

And in like wise was bayons with other fourtene towns delyuerd also / Of
which towns and castles the king made the duk of Clarence Capytayne and
governor / In cane the king heelde his feste of saint George / where he made
fyftene knights of the bathe. And then er he departed he gate valeys and
sent the duc of gloucetre to Chyrburgh for to geete it / which he besyeged
and lay long there / And thus the king sent to diverse towns / and gate daily
many towns / in so much that he gate all the tounes Castles / Pyles /
strengthes and abbeyes unto pount Alarche and fro thens to Roan / About this
time yet continued the counseylle of Constaunce In which was ended the scysme
of forty year / and there was dampened the heresies / and two heretyks that is
to wete Iohanhus and Iherome were burnt / And many good things Institued and
ordained / there was determined decreed by the holy synod that the counseyll
lanfully gadred and assembled representyng the church has universal power
inmedyatly of Christ To whom every astate as well the papal astate as other is
bounden and hold to obey in tho things that touches the general reformacion
of the church that is to wete in feyth and manners al well in the heed as in
the membrys / Item that from then forth on should alwey the general counseyl
be holden fro ten year to ten year. In this counseyll was chosen for to be pope
Martyn / which was martinu s quintu s / and was pope fourten year / And there
was the union which was desired long y had for the defense of the feyth / This
was a mighty Pope above all other / Ryche^ and a man of great Justice / he
held the streets and hye weyes sewrly and in pees / He destroyed heretyks / he
did many good things by help of the noble Emperor Sygysmunde / And for to
recover the holy land / he gadryd much tresoure / but by death that came upon
him / it was let / And a little to fore his death ordained a general counseyll
to be assemblid in Basyle / In the fyfth year of the Regne of king harry the
fyfthe Sire Johan old castle lord Cobham was taken and conuycte by the clergy
for heresye / and dampened to fore the temporal Iuges for tresonne / And so he
was drawn and hanged in saint gyles field upon a new payr of galows with a
cheyne of iron / and under the galewes was made a great fire which burnt
galowes and all / In the syxthe year the king besyeged the Cite of Roan /
which endured half year and more And at last the Cite being in great famyne
put out much people as women and children which deyde for honger. moo than
thyrtty thousand / and also seeing that no rescowse came appointed with the king
and gaf over the town unto him which he received And anon after that Roan was
gotten deep and many other tounes in baas normandye gaf them over without
struck or syege when they understood that the king had gotten Roan /

Capitulum xv
AAlso this same year had been a pees made and sworn between the duc of

should love and assyste each other against their enemies / And after this

/ And for tanenge his faders death he was become english / And then the king

also / which had not ben seen to fore / and all people resorted unto his

steple at london / And this year in the month of August king Harry w^xe seek
at Boys de vyncent / And when he saw he should deye / he made his testament.
and ordeygned many things nobly for his soul / and devoutly resseyued all
the ryghtes of holy church / in so ferforth that when he was enoynted he

syon vt edificentur muri Ierl^m was said / he bade tarry there and said thus O
good lord thou know that mynentent has been and yet is if I might live to

in his time of Christian chyualrye / whom all the world doubted gaf his soul
in to the hands of God / and deyde and made an end of his naturel life at
said Boys de vyncent beside paris / the syx and thyrttyest year of his age / on
whoos soul god have mercy Amen / Then was the body enbamed and cered and
leyde in a ryall chare / and an image like unto him was leyde upon the Corpse
open with diverse baners and horse coueryd rychely with tharmes of England and

many other lords which accompanied the body till it came unto westmynstre by

london with great reverence and solempnyte unto the monasterye of westmynstre /
where as he now rests / On whoos Tomb is a Rich image like him self of
Silver and gylt / where he is daily remembrid and praid fore / On whoos soul
and all Christian god have mercy Amen /

Capitulum xvj
HEre is to be noted / that this king Harry the fyfthe was a much noble
prince after he was king and crowned / How be it to fore in his yongthe he
had been wild / Recheles / and spared no thing of his lusts ne desires / but
accomplisshid them after his liking / But as soon as he was crowned /
enoynted and sacred / anon suddenly he was changed in to a new man / and set
al his entente to live virtuously in mayntenyng of holy church destroyng of
heretykes / keeping Justice / and defending his Royamme and subgettis / And
for as much as his fader hadd deposyd by his labor the good king Rychard And
pytously made him to deye / And for thoffence do to him against his lyegeaunce
/ he had sent to Rome to be assoylled thereof / For which offense the pope
our holy father enjoined him to make him be prayed fore perpetuelly / and like
as he had done to be taken from him his naturell life / therefore he should do
found four tapers to brenne perpetuelly about his body / that for the
extynction of his bodyly life / his soul may ever be remembryd and live in
heaven in spyrytuel life / And also that he should every weke on the day as it
comes about of his death have a solemn mass of Requiem / and on the even
to fore a dirige with nine lessons / and a dole to pour people always on that
day of enleuen schyllynges eight pens to be delyd penny mele. And ones in the
year at his annyuersarye his terment to be holden in the most honest wise and
to be deled that day twenty (...) / in pens to pour people / and to every monk
to have twenty schillynges which all these things performed this noble king
for his fader / For king harry the fourth his fader performed hit not during
his life / whom as it is said god touchyd and was a lepre er he deyde / Also
then this noble Prince l^^te do call all thabbottes and pryours of saint
Benets order in England / and hadd them in the Chapter house of westmynstre for
the reformacion of thordre / wherynne he had comynycacian / and also with
Bisshoppes and men of the spyritualte / In so ferforth / that they doubted
soore that he would have had the temporaltees out of their hands / wherefore by
thaduis labor and procuryng of the spyrytualte encouraged the king to
challenge normandy and his right that he had in France / to the end to set
him a work there that he should not seek occasions to enter in to such
matters / And so all his life after he labouryd in the warrys in conquerynge
great part of the Royamme of France / that by thagrement of the king charlys
had all the governance of the Royamme of France / And was proclaimed Regent
and heyr of France / And so not withstandyng all this great war that he
had yet he remembryd his soul / and also that he was mortal and must deye /
For which he ordained by his life the place of his sepulcre / where he is now
buried and every day three masses perpetuelly to be songen in a fair chapel over
his sepulcre / Of which the myddel mass and the first and the last mass
shall be as it is assygned by him as it appears by these verses following /
Henrici miss quinti sunt hic tabulate
Que successiue sunt per monachos celebrate /

Poscit postremam. Cristus de morte resurgens /

Feria 4 Vltima conceptam / denunciat esse mariam

And yet this noble king harry the fyfthe founded two howses of Relygion / One
called Syon beside braynford of the order of saint Brygytte both of men and
wymmen / And on that other side of the River of Tamyse an hows of monks of the

/ For ever when they of Syon rest / they of the chartrehous done their

/ and by the ryngyng of the bellys of either place / each knows when they

a recluse which shall be alwey a preeste to pray for him by the said
chartrehous / which priest is well and sufficiently endowed for him and a
servant / Loo / Here may all princes take ensample by this noble prince that
regnynge so little time not fully x year / did so many noble acts / as well for

and was virtuous and a great Iustyser In so much that all the princes of

How king harry the syxth reigned being a child not one year of age / and of
