Capitulum 17
AFter king harry the fyfthe reigned harry his son a chil / de and not fully a
year old / whoos regne began the first day of september / the year of our lord
a thousand four honderd and two and twenty / This king being in his Cradel was
much doubted and dradde by cause of the great Conquest of his fader and also
the wisdom and guydynge of his uncles the duck of bedford and the duc of
gloucetre / This year the xxj day of Octobre deyde charles king of France /
and lies buried at saint denis / and then was the duc of Bedford made regent
of france And the duc of gloucetre was made protector and defendour of
England / And the first day of march after was Sir wylliam Tayllour priest
degraded of his preesthode / and on the morn after he was burnt in Smythfeld
for heresye / This year Sire James styward king of scotts married dame Jane
the duchess daughter of Clarence of her first husbond therle of Somersete at
saint mary ouerays Also this year the seuententh day of august was the bataylle
of vernayl in Perch between the duc of Bedford regent of France and the Duc
of alaunson which was a greet bataylle / The duc of Bedford had on his side
with him therle of Salesbury Mountagu the lord talbotte and all the power that
they could make in normandy the garnysons kept / And also many Capytayns with
much people of the duc of Burgoyns / And on that other side was the Duc of
Alaunson / the duc of Turon that was therle douglas / therle of Bougham with
many lords of france / and greet company of Scotts and armynakes / And
then therle douglas called the duc of Bedford Johan with the leden sword /
and he sent him word again that he should find that day that his sword was
of stele / And so the bataylle joined on both sides and fought long that
there wist no man who should have the bet^r a great while / but at last as god
would the vyctory fill on thenglysshe party / For there were slain therle
douglas which a little before was made duc of Turone / therle of Bowhayn.
therle of Almarre / the earl of Tonnar / therle of vauntedore^ and the
vysecounte of nerbonne which was one of them that slew duk Johan of burgoyne
knelyng to fore the dolphyn and many mo unto the nombre of ten thousand and
moo / And there was taken prysonner the duc of alaunson and many other lords
and gentyls of France / but scottys that day were slain down right the
substance of them all / In the third year of king harry the syxth / the duke
of gloucetre married the duchess of Holond and went over see with her in to
henawde for to take possession of his wives enherytaunce / where he was
honorably receyuyd and taken for lord of the land / But soon after he was
feign to return hoome again / and left his wife and his tresour that he
brought with him in a town called mounse in henawd / which promised for to be
true to him / Not withstandyng they deliuerde the lady to the duc of Burgoyne
/ which sent her to gaunt / And from thens she escaped in a man's arraye /
and came in to Zeland to a town of her own called Zierixee / And from thens
she went to a Town in holond called the Ghowde. and there she was strong
enough and wythstode the said Duc of burgoyne / and sone after this the duc of
gloucetre sent over in to Zeland the lord fytzwater with certain men of war
and Archers for to help and socour the said duchess of holond / which londed
at a place in Zeland callid Brewers haven / where the lords of the country came
down and fought with him / and in conclusion was feign to withdraw him and
his meyne to the sea again / but yet he slew and hurt diverse lords and
much people of the cou^treye / And so returned home again and prevailed no
thing

Also this same year therle of Salysbury / therle of Suffolk the lord wylby /
and the lord scalys with their retenue / leyd syege to the Cite of mauns / the
which Cite was yolden to them in short time with many other strong towns
and Castles to the nombre of syx and thyrtty / This time all normandye and a
great part of France unto Orleau^ce was under thobeysaunce of the king of
England / And all the remenaunt of France was in great trybulacion and
meschyef /

Capitulum xviij
IN the fourth year the same night that the mayer of london johan Couentre had
taken his charge was a great watch in london for affraye that was between the
bishop of wynchestre / and the duc of gloucestre protector / For the mayer
with the people of the Cite would abide by the duc of gloucetre as protectoure of
the Royamme / but by labor of lords that went between / And in especial by
the labor of the prince of Portyngale there was appoyntement taken that there
was no harm don And after the bataylle of vernoyll in Perch the Duc of
Bedforde came over in to England / And on whitson^aye this year at leyceter he
dubbed king harry knight / And forthwith the said harry dubbed all these
knights / whoos names follow / that is to wete Rychard duc of york / Also the
sone and heyr of the duc of norfolk / therle af Oxenford / therle of
westmerlond / the sone and heyr of therle of northumberlond / the son and
heyr of therle of vrmond / The lord Roes / Sir James buteler / the lord
matrauas / Sir harry gray of Tankeruyle / Sir william neuyl lord Fauconbrydge
/ Sir george neuyl lord latymer / the lord wellys the lord barkley / the son
and heyr of the lord Talbot / Sir Rauf gray of werk / Sir Robert veer / Sir
Rychard gray / Sir Edmond hongerford / Sir Robert Wynkefeld / Sire Johan
boteller / Sir Raynold Cobham / Sir Johan passhely / Sire thomas tunstal / Sir
Johan Chydyock / Sire Rauf Langford / Sire william drury / Sire william
apthomas / Sire Rychard Carbonel / Sire Rychard wydeuyle / Sire Johan
shyrdelowe / Sir nychol blonket / Sire Rauf ratteclyf / Sire Edmond trafford /
Sire william cheyne / Sire william Babyngton^ Sire Johan June / Sir gilbert
beauchamp / Item / In the fyfthe year the duc of Bedford with the duchess his
wife went over see to Calays / And a little tofore went over harry Bishop of
wynchestre / And on our lady day Annunciacion in our lady church at Calays the
Bishop of wynchestre when he had song mass was made Cardynal / And he
knelyng to fore the hye auter the duc of Bedford set the hatte on his heed.
and there were his bulls red as well of his charge as the reioysyng of his
benefyces spirituel and temporel / Also this year was greet habundaunce of
Rayn / that the substance of heye and Corn was destroyed / For it rayned
almoost every other day / This year the good earl of Salesbury Sire thomas
montagu leyd syege unto Orleaunce / At which syege he was slain with a gonne
/ which came out of the town / on whoos soul god have mercy Amen / For sith
that he was slain Englisshmen never gate ne prevailed in France / but ever
after began to lose little and little till all was lost / Also this same year a
breton murthred a good wydowe in her bed without Algate / which wedowe fond
him for alms / And he bare awey all that she had / And after this he took
the gryth of holy church at saint Georges in southwerke / and there took the
Cross and forswore this land / And as he went it happened that he came by the
place where he did this cursyd deed in the subarbys of london / And the women
of the same paryssh came out with stones and canel dunge and slew and made an
end of him / Notwithstanding the Conestable s and many other men being there
present to keep him / For there were many women^ and had no pity / Also this
year the duck of norfolk with many gentilmen and yomen took his barge the
eight day of nouembre at saint mary ouerayes for to have goon through london
bridge / and through mysguydyng of the barge / it ouerthrewe on the pyles / and
many men drowned / but the duc him self with two or three leepe upon the pyles
/ and so were saved with help of men that were above the bridge / which cast
down Ropes / by which they saved hem self / This year on saint leonards day
king harry being seven year of age was crowned at westmynstre / at whose
Coronacion were made syx and thyrtty knights /

This year on saint georges day he passyd over see to Calays toward France /
About this time and before the Royamme being in great myserye and trybulacion^
the dolphyn with his party began to make war and get certain places /
and make destrusses upon Englysshmen / by the mean of his Capytaynes / that is
to wete la here and poton de sentraylles / And in especial a maid / which
they named la pucelle de dieu / this maid roode like a man / and was a valiant
Capytayne among them and took upon her many and great enterpryses in so much
that they had a believe to have recouerd al their losses by her /
Notwithstanding at last after many great feats by help and prowess of sir
Johan luxemburgh which was a noble Capytayne of the du / kes of Burgoyne / and
many Englysshmen pycardys and bourgoygnons which were of our party / before
the town of Compyne the three and twentyest day of may the said pucelle was
taken in the field armed like a man and many other capytayns with her / And all
brought to Roan / and there she was put in prysonne / and there she was
Iuged by the law to be burnt / And then she said that she was with child /
whereby she was respyted a while / but in Conclusion it was found that she was
not with child / And then she was burnt in Roan / And the other Capytaynes
were put to raunsonne / and entreated as men of war ben acustommed / This
same year about Candelmasse Rychard hounden a wolle packer was dampened for an
heretyke / and burnt at tourhylle / And about midlente Sir thomas baggely
preeste and vycary of mauenden in Estsex besides walden was disgrated and*
dampened for an heretyke / and burnt in Smythfeld. Also in this year while the
king was in France / there were many heretykes and lollars / that had
purposed to have made a rysyng / and cast bylles in many places^ but blessed
be god the Capytayne of hem was taken^ whoos name was william mandeuyle a weuar
of Abendon and bailey of the same town / which named him self Iak sharp of
wygmoryslonde in wales / And afterward he was byheded at Abendon in the
whitsonweke / on the tewisdaye /

This year the seventh day of december king harry the syxthe was crowned king
of France at paris in the church of our lady with great solempnyte / There
being present the Cardynal of england / the Duc of Bedforde / and many other
lords of france and of england / And after this Coronacion and great feste
holden at paris / the king returned from thens to Roan and so towa^rde Calays
/ And the nynthe day of Feuerer londed at dover / whom all the Comyns of
kente met at beramdoun / between caunterbury and dover all in reed hoodes /
And so came forth till he came to blackheth where he was met with the mayer
Johan wellys with all the craftys of london cladde all in white / And so
they brought him to london the one and twe^tyest day of the same month / This
year was a restraynt of the wollys at Calays made by the sowdyours / by cause
they were not paid of their wages / wherefore the duc of Bedford regente of
france being then Capitayn came to Cal^eis the tewsday in the esterweke / and
on the morn after many sowdiours of the town were arested / and put in ward
/ And in the same weke he roode to terewyn / And by the mean of the bishop of
Terewyn he wedded therles daughter of saint poul / and came ageine to Caleis /

And the enleuenst day of Iuin on saint bernabes day there were four^
soudyours of Calays that were chyef causers of the restraynt byheded / that is
to wete Johan maddeley / Johan lu^daye / thomas palmer / and thomas Talbot /
And an Cx / banysshed the town that same time / And before were banysshed ^ixe
score soudyours / And on mydsomer even after came the lord Regent and his wife to
london /

Capitulum 19
About this time Pope martyn deyde / And after him Eugenye the fourth was pope
/ This was pesybly chosen in Rome by the Cardynals and was very and Indubytate
pope / But shortly after he was put and expulsed out of Rome / in such wise
that he was feign to flee naked / In this time was the counseylle of basyle /
to which counseylle he was cyted to come / and because he came not they deposed
him / but he rought not ne set not thereby / but gate the Cite of Rome. and
abode still pope seuentene year / This year about whitsontyde the Heretyks of
praghe were destroyed / For at two iourneyes were destroyed of them moo than
two and twenty thousand with her Capytayns / that is to wete Procapius /
Saplico / and lupus presbiter / Also there was taken a live master Pyers clerk
an Englysshman and heretyke / Also this same year was a great froste and a
strong during enleuen wekes / For it began on saint katheryns even / and
lasted unto saint Scolasticais day in Feuerer in which time the vyntage that
came from bordeux came over shoters hylle / This year was the counseyl of Aras
and a greet traytye between the king of England and the Frensshe king /
where was assemblyd great many of lords of both parties / At which
counseylle was offryd to the king of England many great things by the moyen of
a legate that came from rome / which was Cardynal of saint Cross / which
offres were refused by the Cardynal of England and other lords that were there
for the king / wherefore the duke of burgoyne which had been long English
sworn forsook our party / and returned Frensshe by the meene of the same
legate / and made a pees with the Frenssh king receyuynge of the king for
recompensynge of his faders death the count of pontieu / the lordship of macon
with much other as is specyfyed in the said trayttye / And so our
ambassadors came hoome again in wers^ caas than they went / For they lost
there the duc of Burgoyne / which had been with his bourgonyons and pycardes
a synguler help in all the conquest of normandy and of France / This same
year was a great battle on the sea between the Ieneweys and the king of Aragon
/ of which bataylle the Ieneweys had the vyctorye / For they took the king of
Aragon / the king of nauern / and the greet master of saint James in galyse
with three honderd knights and squyers and much other people / And this was on
saint domynyks day^ This year were seen three sons attones And anon folowyd
the threfolde rule and governance in the church / that is to wete / of
Eugenye / of the counseyle / and of the neutralyte / Also this same year 1434
was a passing great wind by which steples howses and trees were overthrown /
About this time was an holy maid in holond called lydwith which lived long
only by miracle not etyng any mete / This year the duc of burgoyne byganne his
order at lyle of the golden flyes^ and ordeygned certain knights of thordre /
and made statutes and ordenaunces^ much acordynge unto thordre of the garter.
Also this year the Frensshmen had enterprysed to have stolen Calays in the
fysshyng time / For many bootys of France had sauf conduytes to come to Calays
for to take beeryng / And the soudyours of the town had a customme to come
to the church and leave their stauys stondynge at the church door which
stauys the Frensshmen which were arayd like Fysshers had purposed to have
taken so their wepen / and win the town / but one of them lay with a common
woman the night before / and told to her their counseylle / And she on the
morn told the lyeutenaunt / which forthwith commanded that every man should
keep his wepen in his hond sacryng time and other / And when they apperceyued
this that they were myspoynted / they sailed strayte to deep and stale and took
that Town / And on newyers even after they took harflete /

And thus Englysshmen byganne to lose a little and a little in Normandye /

Capitulum visesimum /
THis year was a great noise through al England / how the duck of Bourgoyne
would come and besyege Calays / wherefore the Earl of mortayn with his Army
that he had for to have goone with in to france was countremaunded and
charged that he should go to calais. which was at that time well vitailled and
manned / For sire Johan Ratclif was lyeutena^t of the king in that town / and
the baron of dudeley lyeutenau^t of the castle / and the nynthe day of Iuill
the duke of Burgoyne with all the power of Flaundres and much other people came
before calais and set his syege about the town / and every town of
Flaundres had their tents by them self / And this syege endured three wekes /
In the mean while the duc of gloucetre being protector of england took the
most part of the lords of England and went over the sea to Calays for to
rescowe the town or to fight with the duke and his host if they would have
byden / This time london and every good town of England sent over see to this
rescowe certain people well arayd of the best and chosen men for the war /
And the second day of August the said duke of gloucetre arrived at Calays with
all his army / and five honderd ships and moo / And the duke and all his
host that lay in the syege as sone es they espied the sayllys in the sea /
before they approached calays haven / suddenly in a morning departed fro the
syege / leuyng behind them much stuff and vytaylle / and fled in to
flau^dres and pycardye / and in like wise did the syege that lay to fore
guynes / where as they of guynes took the great gonne of brass which was
called dygeon / and many other great gonnes and serpentyns / And then when
the duke of gloucetre was arrived with all his host / he went in to flaundres
and was therynne enleuen days / and did but little harm / except he burnt
two fair vyllages poperyng and belle / and other howses which were of no
strength / and so returned home again / Also this same year the king of
scottys besyeged Rokesburgh with much pepl^e / but sir Rauf gray departed fro
the castle / and ordained for rescows / but as soon as the king understood his
departing / he suddenly brake his syege / and went his weye leuynge much
ordenaunce behind him / where he gate no worship / This year the second day
of Ianyuer queen katheryn which was the kings mother and wife to king harry
the fyfthe deyde and departed out of this world / and was brought ryally
through london / and so to westmynstre / and there lies buried worshipfully in
our lady chapel / Also this same year the fourtenthe day of Ianyuer fyl down
the gate with a toure on hit on london bridge toward southwerk with two arches
/ and all that stood thereon / This year was a great trayttye holden between
grauenyng and calays between the king and ducke of burgoyne / where for the
king was the Cardynall of England the duck of Norfolk and many other lords /
and for the ducke was the Duchess having full power of her lord / as regent
and lady of his lands / where was taken by thaduys of both parties an
abstynence of war for a certain time in the name of the Duchess / and not
of the duke / by cause he had goon from his oath and lygeaunce that he had
made to king harry / therefore the king never would wrytene appoynte ne have to
do with him after / but all in the duchess name Also this year queen Jane
deyde / the second day of Inyll / which had been king harry the fourthys wife
/ and was carried fro bermondesey unto Caunterbury where she lies buried by
king harry the fourth her husbond / This year deyde all the lions in the
toure of london / the which had not be seen in many years before / out of
mind

Capitulum 21
IN the xvj year of king harry deyde Sygysmu^d Emperor of almayne and knight
of the garter / whose terment the king kept at pawlys in london ryally / where
was made a ryal hearse / and the king in his astate cladd in blewe was at even
at dirige / and on the morn at mass / And after him was elect and chosen
Albert duke of ostryche which had wedded Sygysmundus daughter for to be
Emperor / This was taken and resseyued to be king of boheme and vngary by
cause of his wife that was sigismundus daughter which left after him none
other he yer This albert was emperor but one year / for he was poysond and so
he deyde / sum say he deyde of a flyxe / but he was a virtuous man and
pytefulle / so much that all the people that knew him said that the world
was not worthy to have his presence / In this year was the king of scottys
murthred in his chamber by night pytously which king had be prisoner xv year
in england / And they that slew him were taken afterward and had cruel
justice / this year one owayn a squire of wales a man of low birth / which
had many a day to fore secretly weddyd queen katheryn and had by her three
sons / and a daughter was taken and commanded to newgate to prysonne by my
lord of gloucetre protector of the Royame / And this year he brake prison by
the mean of a priest that was his chappelayn / and after he was taken again by
my lord bemond / and brought again to new gate / which afterward was
delyuerd at large / and one of his sons afterward was made Earl of rychemo^d /
and another earl of penbroke / and the third a monk of westmynstre / which
monk deyde sone after / This year also on newyersday at baynardyscastel fyl^
down a stak of wode suddenly at after none / and slew three men mesch yuously
and foul hurt other / Also at bedford on a shyreday were eyghten men murthred
/ without stroke by falling down of a steyr / as they came out of their
common halle and many foul^e hurt / In the eyghtenth year sir rychard beauchamp
the good earl of warwyck deyde at Roan / he being that time lyeutenaunt of the
king in normandye / and from thennes his body was brought to warwyk / where
he lies worshipfully in a new chapel on the south side of the quyre / Also
this year was a greet derthe of Corn in all england / For a busshel of whete
was worth forty pens in many places of England / and yet men might not have
ynowgh / wherefore steven broun that time mayer of london sent in to pruse / and
brought to london certain ships laden with rye / which easyd and did much
good to the people / For corn was so skarce in England that in some places of
england pour people made hem bread of fern rotes / This year the general
counseyle of basyle deposed pope eugenye And they chese felyx which was duc of
sauoye / And then byganne the scysme / which endured unto the year of our
lord a MCCCC and xlviij / This felyx was a devout prince / and saw the sons
of his sons / and after lived a devout and holy life / And was chosen pope by
the counseyllr of basyle / eugenye deposed / and so the scysme was long time /
and this felyx had not much obedyence because of the neutralyte / for the
most part and well nygh al cristendom obeyed and reputed eugenye for very
pope / god knows who was the very pope of them both / for both occupied
during the life of eugenye / This year Sir Rychard wiche vycary of
hermettesworth was degrated of his prysthode / at powlys / and burnt at toure
hylle as for an heretyk on saint Botulphus day / how well at his death / he
deyde a good christian man wherefore after his death much people came to the place
/ where he had be burnt / and offryd and made a heep^ of stones / and set
up a cross of tree and held him for a saint till the mayer and shreues by
commandment of the king and bisshops destroyed it / and made there a
donghyll. Also this same year the shreues of london fette out of saint martyns
the grant the sayntuarye five persons / which afterward were restored
again to the sayntuarye by the kings Justices / After Alberte the third
Frederyk was chosen Emperor / This Frederyk duke of ostryche was long
Emperor / and differyd for to be crowned at Rome by cause of the scysme / but
after that union was had he was crowned with Imperyal dyademe with great glory
and tryumphe of pope nycholas the fourth / This was a man pesyble quyete and of
synguler pacyence / not hatyng the chirche^ he wedded the king of portyngales
daughter /

Capitulum 22
IN this year dame Elyanore Cobham duchess of gloucetre / was arestyd for
certain points of treasonne leyd ageyn her / whereupon she was examyned in
saint steuens chapel at west mynstre before tharchebisshop of Caunterbury / and
there she was enjoined to open penance for to goo through chepe berynge a ^aper
in her hand / and after to perpetuel prison in to the I Will of man under the
keeping of sir thomas stanley / Also that same time was arestyd master thomas
southwel a chano^ of W^stmynstre master John hum a chappellayn of the said
ladies / master Rogyer bolyngbroke a Clerk using nygromancye /

And one margery Iurdemayn called the wytche of eye ^^syde westmynstre / These
were arestyd as for being of counseyll with the said duchess of gloucetre. And
as for master thomas south well he deyde in the toure the night before he should
have be reyned on the morn / For so he said him self that he should dye in his
bed and not by Justice / And in the year twenty master Johan hum and master
Rogyer Bolyngbrooke were brought to the guydhalle in london / and there before
the mayer / the lords and chyef Justice of England were rayned and dampened to
be drawn hanged and quartred. but master John hum had his chartre and was
pardoned by the king. but master Rogyer was drawn to Tyburne / where he
confessyd that he yde gyltles and never had trespaced in that he deyd fore /
Notwithstanding he was hanged heded and quartred / on whose soul god have mercy
/ And margery Iurdemayne was burnt in Smythfeld / Also this year the lord
Talbotte had leyde syege to dyepe / but the Dolphyn rescowed it / and wan the
bastyle that Englysshmen had made Also this year was a greet effraye in
fletestrete by nyghtes time between men of Court and men of london / and
diverse men slain and sum hurt / and one herbotel was chyef cause of the
mysgouernaunce and effraye / Also this year at the chesyng of the mayer of
london the Commons named Robert Clopton and Rawlyn holond Taylour / And the
Aldermen took Robert clopton and brought him at the right hand of the mayer /
as the customme is / And then certain tayllours and hand crafty men cried
nay nay not this man / but rawlyn holonde / wherefore the mayer that was
padysley sent tho that so cried to newgate / where they abode a great while
and were punysshed / In this year were diverse ambassadors sent in to Guyan
for a marriage for the king for the earls daughter of Armynak^ which was
concluded / but by the mean of therle of Suffolk it was let and put a part /
And after this the said earl of Suffolk went over the sea in to France / /
And there treated the marriage between the king of England and margarete the
kings daughter of Secyle and of Jerusalem And the next year it was concluded
fully that marriage / by which marriage the king should deliver to her fader the
Duchye of Anges. and the Erldome of main which was the keye of normandye /

Then departed the Earl of Suffolk with his wife and diverse lords and
knights in the most ryal astate that might be out of England with new
chares and palfrayes / which went through chepe / and so went over the sea /
and resseyued her / and sith brought her in the lent after to hampton / where
she landed and was ryally resseyued / And on Candelmasse even before by a
greet tempeste of thonder and lyghtnyng at after None / Paulus Steple was
set a fire on the mids of the shafte in the tymbre / which was quenchyd by
force of labor / and specially by the labor of the morrow mass preeste of
the bow in chepe / which was thought Inpossyble / sauf only the grace of god
/ This year was the earl of stafford made and create Duke of Bokyngham / the
Earl of warwyck / Duk of warwyck / therle of dorsete / marquys of dorsete / and
the earl of suffolk was made marquys of suffolk /

Capitulum 23 /
IN this year king harry married at southweke queen margrete / And she came to
london the eyghtenth day of may / And by the way all the lords of england
resseyued her worshipfully in diverse places / and in especial the duc of
gloucetre And on blackheth the mayer Aldermen / and all the crafts in blewe
gowns browdred with the deuyse of his craft that they might be byknowen /
met with her with reed hoodes / And brought her to london / where were
diverse pagentis and countenaunces of diverse historyes she wyd in diverse
places of the cite ryally and costlewe. And the thyrttyest day of may the
said queen was crowned at westmynstre / And there was Iustys three days during
within the sayntuarye to fore thabbay / / This year the pryour of kylmayn
appeled therle of vrmond of treasonne / which had a day assygned to them for
to fight in Smythfeld / and the lystys were made and feelde dressyd / But
when it came to point the king commanded that they should not fight / but
took the quarrels in to his own hand / and this was done. at the Instaunce
and labor of certain prechours and doctors of london as master gylbert
worthyngton parson of saint Andrews in holborne and other / Also this year came
a great ambassate in to england onte of France for to have concluded a
perpetuel pees / but in conclusion it turned unto a tr^ews of a year About
this time deyde saint bernardyn a gray friar which began the new
reformacion of that order in many places / in so much that they that were
reformed ben called obseruauntes / which obseruauntes ben encreaced gretely in
Italye and in almayne / This Bernadyn was canonysed by pope nycholas the fyfthe
in the year thousand four C and fyfty / Johannes de capestrano was his
disciple / which prouffyted much to the reformacion of that order / for whom
God showed many miracles also / Here is to be noted that from this time forward
king harry never prouffyted ne went forward / but fortune began to turn
from him on all sides / as well in France / normandye / guyan / as in England
/ Sum men hold oppynyon that king harry gaf commyssion plenerly to sire
Edward hulle Sire Robert roos / the dene of saint seneryns and other to
conclude a marriage for him with therle of Armynaks suster / which was promised
as it was said and concluded / But afterward it was broken / for by the mean of
the marquys of Suffolk it was broken / And he wedded Queen margrete as a fore
is said / which was a dear marriage / for the Royamme of England / For it is
known verily that for to have her was delyuerd the duchye of angeo / and the
erldom of main / which was the keye of normandy for the Frensshmen tentre /
And above this the^ said marquys of Suffolk axyd in plain parliament a
fyftenth and an half for to fetch her out of France / Lo what a marriage was
this / as to the comparysone of that other marriage of Armynak / For there should
have been delyuerd so many castles and towns in Guyan / and so much good
should have been youe^ with her / that all england should have been thereby
enryched / but contrary wise fylle / wherefore every greet prince ought to
keep his promise / For because of brekyng of this promise / and for marriage of
queen margrete what loss has had the Royamme of England / by losyng of
normandye and guyan by dyuysion in the Royame / the rebellyng of Commons against
their prince and lords / what dyuysyon among the lords / what murdre and
sleyng of them / what feldes foughten and made / In conclusionthat man y a man
has lost his life / the king deposed the queen with her sone feign to flee in
to scotland / and from thens in to France / and so to lorayn the place that
she came first fro / Many men deem that the brekyng of the kings promise to the
suster of therles of Armynack was cause of this great loss and aduersyte

Capitulum 24
IN the year xxv. of king harry was a parliament at bury called saint edmondes
burye / about which was commanded all the comyns of the country to be there
in their most defensable array for to awayte upon the king / To which
parliament came the duc of gloucetre hunfreye the kings uncle / which had been
protector of england all the non age of the king / And anon after he was in
his lodgyng he was arestyd by the vysecounte bemonde the conestable of England
/ whom accompanied the duc of Bokyngham and many other lords / And forthwith
all his servants were commanded for to depart fro him / and two and thyrtty
of the chyeef of hem were also arestyd and sent to diverse prysons^ And v or
vj days after this said arest / the said duke was deed / on whoos soul god
have mercy / But how he deyde and in what manner the Certaynte is not to me
known / Sum said he deyde for sorrow / sum said he was murthred between
two fetherbeddes / other said that an hot spyt was put in his fundament /
but how he deyde god knows / to whom is no thing hid / And then when
he was so deed / he was leyd open that al man might see him / And so both
lords and knights of the shyres with bourgeyses came and saw him lie deed /
but wound ne token could they not perseyue how he deyde / Here may men mark
what this world is This duk was a noble man and a great clerk / and had
worshipfully ruled this Royamme to the kings behoef / and never could be
found fawte with him / but envy of them that were governors / and had
promised to deliver the Duchye of Angeo and the Erldome of mayn caused the
destruction of this noble man / For they drad him that he would have enpesshyd
that delyuerance / And after they sent his body to saint Albons with certain
lyghtes for to be buried. And so Sire geruays of clyfton had than the charge
to conueye the corpse / And so it was buried at saint albons in thabbay / And
five persons of his household were sent to london / and there were rayned and
Iuged to be drawn hanged and quartred / of whom the names were Sire Rogyer
chamberlayne knight and myddelton Squire / herbard a squire arthur a Squire /
and Rychard Nedham / which five persons were drawn from the tour of london
through c^epe unto Tiburne / and there hanged and let down quyck / and then
strypt for to hau e ben heded and quartred / And then the marquys of Suffolk
showed there for them the kings pardon under his great seal / and so they were
pardonned of the remenaunt of the execucion and had their lives / And so they
were brought again to london / and after freely delyuerd / Thus began the
trouble in england for the death of this noble duke / All the commons of the
Royamme began for to murmr and were not content / After that pope Eugenye
was deed nycholas the fyfth was elect pope / This nycholas was chosen for
Eugenye yet having the scisme / Notwithstondyng he gate the obedyence of all
christian Royammes / For after he was elect and ^^^red pope / Certain lords of
France and of England weere ^^nte in to sauoye to pope Felyx for to entreat
him to cesse of the papacye. And by the special labor of the bishop of
norwyche / and the lord of saint Iohans he cessyd the second year after that
Nycholas was sacred / and the said Felyx was made legate of France and
cardynal of sauoye / And resygned the hoole papacye to nycholas / and after
lived an holy life and deyd an holy man / And as it is said god showed miracles
for him / This was the three and twentyeste Scysme / between eugenye and Felyx /
and dured sixtene year / the cause was this / the generalle counseylle of
basylle deposed eugenye which was only pope and Indubytate for as much as he
observed not and kept the decrees and statutes of the counseylle of Counstance
as it is said / nether he rought not to give obedyence to that general
counseyll / whereof roo^e a great alteracion among wrytars of this matter pro
and contra which can not acorde unto this day / One party seyth that the
counseylle is above the pope / that other party says nay. But the pope is
above the counseyll / God blessed above all things give and send his pees in
holy church spouse of Christ Amen / This nycholas was of Iene comen of low
birth a doctor of dyuynyte an ac^ if man / he reedefyed many places that were
broken and ruynous / and did do make a great wall about the palace* and made
the wall new about Rome for dread of the turks / And the people wondered of
the ceesynge and resygnynge of Felyx to him / consyderyd that he was a man of
so low birth And that other was of affynyte to all the most part of Cryste^
princes / whereof there was a verse publysshed in Rome in this manner / Lux
fulsit mundo cessyd Felyx nycholao.

Capitulum 24
IN the year of king harry xxvij being trewes between France and england a
knight of the english party named Sir Fraunceys Aragonoys took a town of
normandy named Fogyers. ageynste the trewes / of which taking byganne much
sorrow and loss / For this was the occasion by which the Frensshe men gate
all normandy / This year a Squire of england named chalons did arms with a
knight of France named Sire lowys de buyel to fore the Frensshe king / and
ran the Frensshe knight through with a spear and slew him in the field In the
year xxviij was a parliament holden at westmynstre And from thennes adiourned to
the black Frerys at london / And after Crystemasse to westmynstre again / And
this same year Robert of Cane a man of the west contre with a few ships took
an hole flote of ships coming out of the baye laden with salt / which
ships were of pruys / Flaundrys / Holand and Zeland / and brought hem to
hampton / wherefore the marchaunt^s of england being in flaundres were arestyd
in Brugys / Ipre and other places / and might not be delyuerd ner their dettys
dyscharged till they had made a poyntement for to pay for the amends and
hurtes of tho ships / which was paid by the merchants of the staple every
penny / And in like wise the merchants and gods being in danske were also
arestyd and made great amends. This same year the Frensshmen in a morning
took by a train thea town of pou^t al arche and therynne the lord
Fawconbrydge was taken prysonner / And after that in decembre Roan was taken
and lost / being therynne the duc of s^mersete edmund / therle of shrewsbury /
which by appoyntement left pledgys and lost all normandye / and came home /
And during the said parliament the duck of Suffolk was arestyd and sen^e in to
the tour / and there was a monethe / and after the king did do fetch him out
/ For which cause all the comyns of England were in a great rumor what for
the delyueraunce of Angeo and mayn and after for losing of al normandye / and
in especial for the death of the good duke of gloucetre / in so much that in
sum places men gadred to geders and made ^em Capytaynes as blewe berd and
other / which were resysted and taken and had Justice and deyd / And then
the said parliament was adiourned to leycetre / And theder the king brought
with him the duke of Suffolk / And when the common hows understood that he
was out of the tour and comen theder / they desired to have execucion on them
/ that were cause of the delyueraunce of normandy / and had been cause of the
death of the duc of gloucetre / and had sold gascoyne and guyan / of which
they named to be gylty the duc of Suffolk as chyef the lord say / the Bishop
of Saslebury / Danyel and many moo / And for to pease the Commons the duck of
Suffolk was exyled out of england five year / And so during the parliament
he went in to norfolk and there took shippyng for to goo out of the Royame
in to frau^^e / And this year as he sailed on the sea / a ship of war
cal^yd the nycholas of towr met with his ship and fond him there in whom
they took out / and brought him in to their ship / to fore the master and
Capytayns / And there he was examyned and at last Iuged to the death / And so
they put him in a Cabon / and his chappellayne for to shryne him / And that
done they brought him in to dover roode / and there set him in to the boot /
and there smote of his heed / and brought the body a land upon the sondes
and set the heed thereby / And this was done the first day of may / Loo what
avails him now this delyueueraunce of normandye / And here ye may see how he
was rewarded for the death of the duck of gloucetre / Thus began sorrow upon
sorrow and death for death /

Capitulum 26
THis year of our lord a thousand four honderd and fyfty was the great grace of
the Iubilee at Rome / where was greet pardonne / in so much that from all
places of Crystendome great multitude of people resorted theder / This year Sire
thomas cryell was overthrown at fermygny and many Englysshemen slain and
taken prysonners / This same year was a great assemblyng and gaderyng to geder
of the Commons of kente in greet nombre / and made an Insurrection and rebellyd
ageynste the king and his laws And ordained hem a Capytayne called Johan Cade
an Irysshe man / which named him self mortymer Cosyn to the ducke of york /
And this Capytayne held these men to geder and made ordenaunces among them and
brought hem to blackheth where he made a bylle of petycions to the king and his
counseyll / and showed what Inyuryes and oppressions the pour comyns suffryd /
and all under color for to come to his above / And he had a great multitude
of people / And the seue^tenth day of Iuyn the king with many lords Capytayns
and men of war went toward him to the blackheth / And when the capytayne of
kente understood the coming of the king with so great a puyssau^ce / he
withdrewe him with his people to seuenok a lytil vyllage / And xxviij day of
Iuyn being with drawn and goon / the king came with his army set in order
and enbataylled to the blackheth / and by aduys of his counseyll sent sir
vmfrey stafford knight. and william stafford Squrer two valiant Capytains with
certain people to fight with the capytayne and to take him / and bring him and
his accessaryes to the king. which went to seuenock / and there the
Capytayne with his felauship met with hem / and fought against hem / and in
conclusion slew them both and as many as abode / and would not yield hem nor
flee / During these scarmuche fill a great varyaunce among the lords men and
common people being on blackheth against their lords and capytayns sayyng
plainly that they would goo to the capytayne of kente to assyste and help him
/ but if they might have execucion on the traitors / being about the king /
whereto the king said nay /

And they said plainly that the lord say tresorer of eng / land the Bishop of
Salysbury / / the abbot of gloucetre / danyel andtreuylyan and many moo were
traitors / and worthy to be ded / wherefore for to plese the lords meyne and
also sum of the kings hows the lord say was arestyd and sent to the Toure
/ of london / And then the king herynge tidings of the death and
ouerthrowynge of the staffords withdrewe him to london / and fro thennes to
kyllyng worth for the king ne the lords durst not trust their own household
meyne / Then after that the Capytayne had had this vyctory upon the
staffordes / anon be took sire vmfrayes salade and his brygantyns smyten full
of gylt nails / and also his gylt spores and arrayed him like a lord and a
Capytayne / and resorted with all his meyne / and also mo than he had to fore to
the blackheth again / to whom came tharchebisshop of Caunterbury / and the
duck of Bokyngham to the blacheth and spoke with him / And as it was said they
fond him wytty in his talkyng and his requestys / and so they departed And the
thyrdde day of Iuyll he came and entryd in to london with all his people / and
there did make cries in the kings name and his that no man should rob ne
take no man's good / but if he paid for it / and came riding through the Cite
in great pride / and smote his sword upon / london stone in Canwyckstrete /
and he being in the Cite sent to the tour for to have the lord say / and so
they fette him and brought him to the guyldhalle before the mayer and Aldermen
/ where he was examyned / and he said he would and ought to be Iuged by his
peers / And the commons of kent took him by force from the mayer and officers
that kept him / and took him to a pryeste to shryue him / And ^r he might be
half shryuen they brought him to the standard in Chepe / And there smote of his
head / on whoos soul god have mercy Amen. And thus deyde the lord say
tresorer of England After this they set his heed on a spear / and bare it
about in the Cite / And the same day at mile end crowmer was byheded And the
same day before at after none the capytayne with certain of his main went to
phelyp malpas hows / and robbyd him and took away much good. And fro thennes
he went to saint margrete patyns to one gherstys hows / and robbyd him also.
At which robbyng dyuerce men of london of their neighbors were at it / and
took part with them / For this robbyng the peples hertes fill from him / and
every thryfty man was aferd for to be served in like wise. For there was many a
man in london that awayted / and would feyne have seen a common robberye /
which god forbede / For it is to suppose if he had not robbed / he might
have gone f^r er he had be withstonde / For the king and all the lords of
the Royame were departed except the lord scales that kept the toure / And the
fyfthe day of Iuyll he did do smite of a man's heed in Southwerke / And the
night after the mayre of london the aldermen and the Commons of the Cite
concluded to drive awey the Capytayne and his hooste / and sent to the lord
scales to the tour and to matthew gogh^ a Capytayne of normandye that they would
that night assaylle the Capytayne with them of kente / And so they did and
came to london bridge in to Southwerke / er the Capytayne had any knowledge
thereof And they fought with them that kept the bridge / And the ke^tysshmen
went to harnoys and came to the bridge and shot and fought with hem / and gate
the bridge / and made them of london to flee / and slow many of hem. And this
endured all the night to and fro till nine of the clock on the morn / And at
last they brent the drawebrydge^ where many of them of london were drouned /
In which night Sutton an alderman was slain / Rogyer heysaunt and matthew gogh^
and many other / And after this the chaunceler of England sent to the
Capytayne a pardone general for him and another for all his meyne / And then
they departed from southwerke every man home to his hows /

And when they were al departed and goone / there were proclamaciones made in
kente / southsex / and in other places / that what man could take the capytayne
quyck or deed should have a thousand marck / And after this one Alysaunder
Iden a squire of kente took him in a gardyn in southsex / and in the taking
the capytayne Johan cade was slain / and after byheded and his heed set on
london bridge / / And anon after then the king came in to kente / and did
his Justices sytte at caunterbury and inquire who were accessaryes and chyef
cause of this Insurrection / And there were eight men Iuged to death in one day
and in other places moo / And fro thennes the king went in to southsex / and
in to the weste country / where a little before was slain the bishop of
Salysbury / And this same year were so many Iuged to death that three and twenty
hedes stood on london bridge attones /

Capitulum 27
IN the year thyrtty the duck of york came out of the march of wales with
therle of deuenshyre and the lord Cobham with great puyssaunce for reformacion
of certain Iniuryes and wrongs / and also to have Justice on certain lords
being about the king / And took a field at brentheth beside dertford in kent
/ which was a strong field / for which cause the king with all the lords
of the land went unto the blackheth with a great multitude of people armed and
ordained for the war in the best wise / And when they had musteryd on the
blackheth / certain lords were sent to him for to treat and make
appoyntement with him which were the Bishop of Ely and the Bishop of
wynchestre / and therles of Salysbury and of warwyk And they concluded that the
duck of Somersete should be had to ward / and to answer to such artycles as
the duk of york should put to him / And then the duc of york should break
his field and come to the king which was all promised by the king And so the
king commanded that the duke of somersete should be had in ward / And then
the duck of york brake up his field. and came to the king and when he was
come / contrary to the promise a fore made. the duke of somersete was present
in the field awaytyng and chyef about the king and made the duke of york ride
to fore as a prisoner through london / and after they would have put him in
hold / but a noise aroos that the earl of march his son was coming with
ten thousand men to london ward / whereof the king and his counseyl fered /
and then concluded that the duc of york should depart at his will About
this time byganne greet dyuysyon in spruse between the great master and the
knights of the duche order which were lords of that country / For the Commons
and towns rebellyd ageynste the lords / and made so great war that at last
they called the king of pole to be their lord / which came and was receyuyd
and laid syege to the castle of maryenburgh / which was the chyef castle and
strength of all the land / and wanne it / and droofe out the master of
danske and all other places of that land / And so they that had been lords
many years / lost all their seygnorye and possessions in tho lands /

In the year of our lord a thousand four honderd and three and fyfty the cite
of Constantynople themperyal Cite of Greece was taken by the turk / the
Emperor slain / and Innumerable christian people destroyed and put in Captyuyte
/ by which pryse Christian feyth perysshed in greece / and the turk enhaunced
gretely in pride / And the year of our lord a thousand four honderd and three
and fyfty on saint edwardes day the queen margaret was delyuerd of a fair
prince / which was named Edward / That same day Johan norman was chosen for to
be mayer of london / And the day that he should take his oath at westmynstre /
he went thither by water with all the crafts / where a fore time / the mayer
aldermen and all the crafts / Rode a horsback / which was never vsyd after /
For syn that time they have ever goone by water in barges / ye have well
understand to fore how that Contrary to the promise of the king and also the
conclusions taken between the king and the duke of york at brentheth / the
duke of somersete went not to ward / but abode about the king and had great
rewle and was made Capytayne of Calays / and rewlyd the king and the Royamme
as he would / wherefore the great l^ordes of the Royamme and also the commons
were not plesyd / for which cause the duke of york the Earls of warwyck and of
Salysbury with many knights and squyers and moch^ people came for to remeue the
said duke of Somersete and other fro the king / And the king herynge of their
coming thought by his counseylle for to have gone westward and not for to mete
with hem / And had with him the Duke of Somersete / the Ducke Bokyngham / the
earl of stafford / therle of northumberlond / the lord clyfford and many other
/ And what time that the Duk of york and his felawship understood that the king
was departed with these said lords from london / Anon he changed his wey and
costed the country and came to saint albons the three and twentyest day of may
/ and there met with the king. to whom the king sent certain lords and
desired hem to keep the pees and depart / but in conclusion whiles they
treated on that one side / therle of warwik with the march men and other
entrid the town on that other / and fought against the king and his party /
and so byganne the bataylle and fyghtyng / which endured a good while / but
in conclusion the duck of york obtained and had the vyctorye of that Iourneye.
In which was slain the duke of Somersete / therle of northumberlond / the
lord Clyfford and many knights and squyers / And many mo hurt / And on the
morn after they brought the king in great astate to london / which was
lodged in the bisshops palace of london / And anon after was a great parliament
/ In which parliament the duke of york was made protector of England / And
therle of warwik Capytayne of Calays / And therle of Salysbury chauncel^r of
england / and all such persons as had the rewle to fore about the king
were set a part and might not rewle as they did to fore / In this year
deyde pope nycholas the fyfthe / and after him was Calyxte the thyrdde / This
calyxte was a cat^lane / and an old man when he was chosen and continuelly
seek / wherefore he might not perform his zele and desire that he had ageynste
the turks conceived / and the cause of lettynge thereof was his age and
sickness / This Calyxte Institued and ordained the feste of the
transfyguracion of our lord to be hallowed on saint sixtes day in August by
cause of the great vyctorye that they of hungary had ageynste the turks that
same day / he was chosen pope the year of our lord thousand four honderd and
five and fyfty / And deyde the year thousand four honderd and eight and fifty /
that same day that he ordained the feste of the transfyguracion to be hallowed /
In this year fill a great affraye in london against the lombardes / The cause
bygan by cause a young man took a daggar from a lombard and brake it / wherefore
the young man on the morn was sent for to come to fore the mayer and aldermen /
and there for the offense he was committed to ward / And then ne the mayer
departed from the Guyldhalle for to goo hoome to his dinner / but in Chepe the
young men of the mercerye for the most part prentyses held the mayer and
shreues still in chepe / and would not suffer him to depart unto the time /
that their Felaw which was committed to ward were delyuerd / and so by force
they rescowed their felawe from prysonne / and that / done the mayer and
shreuys departed / And the prisoner delyuerd which if he had be put to prison
had been in ieopardy of his life / and thus began a rumor in the cite against
the lombardes / and the same euenyng the handcrafty people of the town aroos
and ran to the lombardes howses / and despoylled and robbed diverse of hem /
wherefore the mayer and aldermen came with the honest people of the town and
droof them thens and sent sum of them that had stolen to newgate / And the
young man that was rescowed by his felaws saw this great rumor affraye and
Robberye ensiewed of his first meuyng to the lombard / departed and went to
westmynstre to sayntuarye / or else it had ^osted him his life / For anon
after came down one Oyer determyne / for to do Justice on all them that so
rebellyd in the Cite / ageynste the lombardes. on which satte with the mayer
that time William marowe / the duke of Bokyngham and many other lords for to
see the execucion done / But the Comyns of the Cite secretly made them ready /
and did arm them in their howses / and were in purpose for to have rongen the
common belle / which is named bow belle / But they were let by sad men /
which came to the knowleche of the ducke of Bokyngham and other lords / and
Incontinent they aroos for they durst no longer abide / For they doubted that
the hoole Cite would have arysen ageynste them / But yet nevertheless two or
three of the Cite were Iuged to death for this robbery and were hanged at Tyburne
/ And anon after the king / the Queen and other lords Rode to Couentre / and
withdrewe hem from london for these causes / And a little to fore the duke of
york was sent fore to Grenewych^ / and there was dyscharged of the
protectourshippe / And my lord of Salysbury of his chauncelership / And after
this they were sent fore by preuy seal for to come to Couentre / where they
were almoost deceived and therle of warwyck also / and should have been destroyed
if they had not seen well to / etc /

Capitulum 28
THis year were taken four great Fysshes between Eerethe and london / that one
was called mors maryne / the second a swerd Fysshe / the other tweyne were
whales / In this year for certain effrayes done in the north country between
the lord egremond / and therle of salysburyes sons / the said lord egremond
whom they had taken was condemned in a great sum of money to the said earl
of Salysbury / and therefore commysed to prison in newgate in london / where
when he had been a certain space brake prison and three prisoners with him
and escaped / and went his way / Also this year therle of warwyk and his wife
went to calays with a fair felawship and took possession of his office /
About this time was great reformacion of many monasteryes of relygyon in
diverse parties of the world / which were reformed after the first Institucion
and continued in many places. Also about this time the craft of Enpryntyng was
first found in magounce in Almayne / which craft is multyplyed through the
world in many places. and books ben had great chepe and in great nombre by
cause of the same craft

This year was a great battle in the marches between hongary and turkye at a
place called Septegrade / where Innumerable turks were slain more by miracle
than by man's hond / For only the hand of god smote them / Seint John of
capestrane was there present / and provoked the christian people being then
aferd to poursiewe the turks where an Infynyte multitude were slain and
destroyed / the turks said that a great nombre of Armed men followed them /
that they were aferd to turn again / they were holy angels / This year the
prysonners of newgate in london brake their prysonne and went upon the leedes
and fought against them of the Cite and kept the gate a long while but at
last the town gate the prysonne on them / and than they were put in fetherys
and yrons and were soore punysshed in ensample of other / In this year also was
a great earth quaue in naples / in so much that there perysshed forty thousand
people that sanke there in to therth / Item In the year six and thyrtty saint
Osmond sometime bishop of Salysbury was canonysed at Rome by pope Calyxt / And
the sixtenthe day of Iuyll he was translated at Salysbury by the Archebisshop
of Caunterbury and many other bisshops / And in August after Sire pyers de
brese^ seneschal of normandy with the captain of deep and many other
capytaynes and men of war went to the sea with a great nauye and came in to
the downs by nyght^ and on the morn erly before day they londed and came to
Sandwyche both by land and water / and took the town and ryfled and
despoilled it / And took many prisoners / and left the town al bare / which
was a rich place and much good therynne / And ladde with hem many rich
prisoners / In this year in many places of France / Almayne / Flaundres /
Holond / and Zelond children gadred them by great companyes / for to goo on
pylgremage to saint mychels mount in normandye / which came fro fer contreyes /
whereof the people merueylled and many supposyd that sum wicked spyryte meuid
them to so do / but it endured not long by cause of the long way and also
for lack of vytayll as they went. In this year Raynold pecok / Bishop of
Chychestre was founden an heretyke / and the thyrdde day of December was
abiured at lambhyth in the presence of the Archebisshop of Caunterbury and many
Bisshops and doctors / and lords temporal / and his books burnt at poulus
cross / Ye have herd to fore how certain lords were slain at saint Albons
/ Wherefore was alwey a grutche and wrath had by the eyres of them that were so
slain against the Duke of york / the Earls of warwyck and of Salysbury /
wherefore the king by thaduys of his counseylle sent for them to london / To
which place the Duke of york came the syx and twentyest day of Ianyuer with
four honderd men / and lodgeat Baynardys castle in his own place / And the
fyftenth day of Ianyuer came therle of Salysbury with five honderd men / and was
lodged in therber in his own place / And then came the dukes of excetre and
of Somersete with eight honderd men / and lay without tempelbarre / And the
Earl of northumberlonde the lord egremond / and the Lord clyfford with fyftene
honderd men / and lodged without town And the mayer that time gefferey boleyn
kept great watch with the Commons of the Cite and rode about the Cite by
Holburn and Fletestrete with a five thousand men well armed and arayd for to
keep the pees / And the fourtenth day of Feuerer therle of warwyck came to
london from Calays well beseen and worshipfully with six honderd men in reed
Iaquettys browdryd with a ragged staf behind and before / And he was lodged
at gray Freres / And the seuententhe day of March the king came. to london
and the queen / And there was a concord and pees made among these lords /
and they were set in pees / And on our lady day the xxv day of march a
thousand four honderd and eight and fyfty / the king / queen. and all these
lords went on. procession at powlus in london / and anon after the king and
lords departed / In this year was a great affray in fletestrete between men of
court and men of the same street / In which affray the queen's attorney was
slain.

Capitulum 29
ALso this same year as the Earl of warwyck was at a counsel at westmynstre /
All the kings household meyny gadred them to geder for to have slain the said
earl / but by help of god and his friends he recoueryd his barge / and escaped
their evil enterprise / how well the Coques came rennynge out with spyttes and
pestels against him / And the same day he roode toward warwyk / And sone after
he gate him a commyssion / and went over see to calays / Sone after this
therle of Salysbury coming to london was encou^trid at bloreheth with the lord
audeley / and much other people ordained for to have destressid him / but he
having knowleche that he should be met with / was acco^panyed with his two
sons sir thomas and sir Johan neuyll / and a greet felawship of good men /
And so they met / And fough^e to geders / where therle of salysbury wanne
the feld / And the lord audley was slain and many gentill men of chesshyre and
much people hurt / And therles two sons were hurt / and going homeward
afterward they were taken / and had to Chestre by the queen's meyne / After
Calyxte / pius was pope and was chosen this year 1458 / And he was called to
fore Eneas an Eloquent man and a poet laureate / he was Ambassa^our of the
Emperors before time / And he wrote in the counseylle of basylle a noble
trayttye for thauctoryte of the same. Also he canonysed saint katheryne of
Senys / This pope ordained great Indulgencys and pardonne to them that would go
war against the turk / and wrote an Epistle to the great turk exortynge him
to become christian / And in the end he ordeygned a passage ageynste the Turk
at Ankone / To which much people drew out of all parties of Crystendome / of
which people he sent many hoome. again by cause they suffysed not / And anon
after he deyde at the said place of Ancone / the year of our lord a thousand
four honderd and liiij the xiiij day of August / In the year eight and thyrtty
of king harry the duke of york / the Earls of warwyck and of Salysbury saw
the governance of the Royamme stood most by the queen and her counseylle /
and how the great princes of the land were not called to counseylle but set
a part / and not only so / but that it was said through the Royame that tho
said lords should be destroyed utterly as it openly was showed at bloreheth
by them that would have slain the Earl of Salesburye / Then they for sauacion
of their lives and also for the common well of the Royame thought for to remedy
these things / assemblyd them to gyder with much people and took a field in
the west countray / to which the earl of warwyck came from calays with many of
thold soudyours / as andrew Trollop / and other / in whose wysedomes as for the
war he much trusted / and when they were thus assemblyd and made their
field / the king sent out his commissyons and preuy sealys unto all the
lords of his royamme to come and awayte on him in their most defensable wise
/ and so every man came in such wise that the king was strenger / and had
much more people than the duc of york / and the Earls of warwyck / and
Salysbury / For it is here to be noted that every lord in england at this time
durst not dysobeye the queen / For she rewlyd peasybly all that was done about
the king / which was a good simple and Innocent man / And then when the
king was comen to the place where as they were / the duck of york and his
felawship had made their field in the strengest wise / and had purposed
verily to abyden and have foughten / But in the night Andrew Trollop and all
the old Soudyours of Calays with a greet felawshippe / suddenly departed out
of the dukes hooste / and went strayte unto the kings field / where they were
resseyued Ioyously / For they knew the entente of the other lords and also
the manner of their feld And then the duck of york with the other lords
seeing them so deceived took a counseylle shortly in that same night and
departed from the Field leuynge behind them the most part of their people
to keep the Field till on the morn / Then the Duke of york with his second
son departed through walys toward Irlond leuynge his oldest sone therle of
march with the Earls of warwyck and of Salesbury / which to geder with three
or four persons roode strayte in to deuenshyre / and there by help and aid
of one denbam a squire / which gate for them a ship / which cost enleuen
score noblys / and with the same ship sailed fro thens in to garneseye / And
there refresshyd them / and from thennes sailed te Calays / where they were
received in to the castle by the postern er they of the town knew of hit /
And the duk of york took shippynge in wales and sailed over in to Irlond where
he was well resseyued

Capitulum Trisesimum
Then king harry being with his hooste in the field not knowing of this
sudden departing on the morn fond none in the field of the said lords.
sent out in all haste men to follow and poursiewe after to take hem / but
they met not with them as god would / and then the king went to ludlowe and
dispoylled the castle and the town / And sent the duchess of york with her
children to my lady of Bokyngham her suster / where she was kept long after /
And forthwith the king ordained the duc of somersete Capytayne of Calays / And
these other lords so departed as a fore is said were proclaimed rebellys and
great traitors / Then the duke of Somersete took to him all tho Soudyours
that departed fro the field / and made him ready in all haste to goo to Calays
and take possession of his office / And when he came he fond the Earl of
warwyck therein as capytayne / And therles of march and salysbury also / And
then he londed by Scales and went to guysnes / and there he was resseyued /
And it fortuned that sum of tho shippis that came over with him / came in to
Calays haven by their free will / For the shipmen ought more favor to the
Earl of warwyck than to the Duke of Somersete /

In which ships were taken diverse men^ as Ienyn Fynkhyll / Johan felaw /
ka^lles and purser / which were byheded sone after in Calays And after this
daily came men over See to these lords to Calays / And byganne to wexe strenger
and strenger^ And they borrowed much good good of the staple / And on that
other side the duc of Somersete being in guysnesgate people to him / which came
out and scarmusshed with them of Calays / and they of Calays with them which
endured many days / during thus this daily scarmuchynge / much people daily
came over unto these lords / Then on a time by thaduys of counseylle the
lords at calays sent over Master Denham with a great felawship to Sandwyche
/ which took the town / And therynne the lord Ryuers and the lord scales his
son / and took many ships in the haven / and brought hem all to calays /
with which ships many maronners of their free will came to Calays to serve
the Earl of warwyck / And after this the Earl of warwyk by thaduys of the
lords took all his shippis and mannyd them well / and sailed him self in to
Irlond for to speak with the duke of york / and to take his aduys how they
should enter in to England again / And when he had been there and done his
erandes / he returned again toward Calays / and brought with him his mother
the Countess of Salysbury / And coming in the west countraye upon the sea the
duk of excetre admyral of england being in the grace a dieu accompanied with
many ships of war / met with therle of warwyck and his flote / but they
fought not / For the substance of the people being with the duke of excetre
ought better will and more favor to therle of warwyck than to him / And so
they departed and came to Calays in saefte / blessed be god /

Then the kings counseylle seeing that these lords had gotten these ships
from Sandwiche and taken the lord Ryuers and his son ordained a garnyson at
Sandwiche to abide and keep the town / And made one mountford Capytayne of the
Town / And that no man / ne vytaylle ne merchant that should goo in to
Flaundres should not goo to Calays / Then they of Calays seeing this made out
master denham and many other to goo to Sandwiche / And so they did / and
assaylled the town by water and by land / And gate it and brought mountford
their Capytayne over see to rysebank and there smote of his heed / And yet
daily men came over to them out of all parties of England /

Capitulum Trisesimum Primum^
ANd after this the said earls of march warwyk and of salysbury came over see
to dover with much people and there landed / to whom all the cou^tray drew and
came to london armed And for to late the lords of the kings counseylle know
their troth / and also their entente / assemblyd them and told them / that
they intended no harm unto the kings person / sauf that they would put fro
him such persons as were about him / And so departed fro london with a
great puyssaunce toward norhampton / where the king was accompanied with many
lords and had made a strong field without the town / And there both parties
met and was foughten a great bataylle^ In which battle were slain the duck
of Bokyngham / therle of shrowesbury / the vysecounte Beamond / the lord
Egremond and many knights and Squyers and other also / And the king him self
taken in the field / and afterward brought to london / And anon afterward was
a parliament at westmynstre / during which parliament the duck of york came onte
of Irlond with therle of Rutland rydyng with a great felawship in to the palace
at westmestre and took the kings palace And came in to the parliament chamber /
and there took the kings place / and claymed the croune as his propre
enherytaunce and right / and cast forth in writing his title / and also how he
was ryghtful Eyer / wherefore was much to do / but in conclusion it was
appointed and concluded that king harry should regne and be king during his
naturel life / For as much as he had been so long king / and was possessyd / And
after his death the duke of york should be king and his eyres kings after him
/ And forthwith should be proclaimed eyr apparaunt / And should be also
protector and Regence of england during the kings life / with many other
things ordained in the same parliament / And if king harry during his life went
from this appoyntement / or any article concluded in the said parliament he
should be deposed / and the duke should take the crown and be king / all which
things were enacted by thauctorite of the said parliament / At which parliament
the Commons of the Royamme being assemblyd in the common hows comenynge and
treatyng upon the title of the said duc of york / suddenly fill down the
crown which henge then in the mids of the said hows which is the
fraytour of thabbay of westmynstre / which was taken for a prodyge or token
that the regne of king harry was ended and also the crown which stood on the
byest tour of the stepel in the Castle of dover fill down this same year /

Capitulum 32
Then for as much as the queen with the prince was in the north / and
absented her from the king / And would not obey such things as was concluded
in the parliament / hit was ordained that the duck of york as protector should
go norward for to bring in the queen and subdue such as would not obey / with
whom went the earl of Salysbury / Sire Thomas neuylle his son with much
people / And at wakefelde in Crystemasse weke they were all overthrown and
slain by the lords of the queen's partye^ that is to wete the duk of york slain
therle of Rutland / Sire thomas neuyll and many moo / Therle of Salysbury was
taken a live and other as Johan harow of london Capytayne of the foot men /
and hanson of hulle / which were brought to pountfret / and there after byheded
and their hedes sent to york and set upon the yates / And thus was that
noble prince slain the duke of york / on whoos soul and on all christian
sowles god have mercy Amen / And this time therle of march being in
shrewesbury heeryng the death of his fader / desired assistence and aid of the
town for to avenge his faders does / And from thennes went to walys / where
at Candelmasse after he had a batayl at mortemers cross against therles of
penbroke and of wylshyre / where the earl of march had the vyctorye / Then
the queen with the lords of the north after they had distressyd and slain the
duck of york and his felauship / came southward with a great multitude and
puyssance of people for to come to the king / and defete such conclusions as
had been taken before by the parliament / Ageynste whoos coming the Duke of
norfolk / the earl of warwycke with much people and ordenaunce went unto
saint Albons / And ladde king harry with hem / And there encountryd to geder in
such wise and fought that the duke of norfolk / and therle of warwyk with
other of their party fled and lost that Iourneye / where king harry was
taken / and went with the queen and prince / and his son / which tho had
gotten that field / Then the queen and her party being at their above sent
anon to london / which was on Asshwednesday / the first day of lent for
vytaylle / which the mayer ordained by thaduys of the aldermen that certain
carts laden with vytaylle should be sent to saint Albons to them / And when
tho carts came to crepylgate / the Commons of the cite that kept that gate took
the vytaylles from the carts / and would not suffer it to pass / Then were
there certain Aldermen and comeners appointed to goo to barnet for to speak
with the queen's cou^seylle for to entrete that the northern men should be sent
home again in to their countraye again / For the Cite of london dredde soore
to be robbed and despoylled / if they had come And thus during this trayttye
tidings came that the Earl of warwyk had met with therle of march on
Cotteswold coming out of wales with many wallshmen / And that they both were
coming to londonward / Anon as these tidings were known the trayttye was
broken / For the king / queen prince / and all the other lords that were with
hem departed from saint albons northward with all their people / yet er they
departed they byheded the lord Boneyle / and Sir thomas cryel / which were
taken in the Iourneye done in the shroftewysday. Then the duchess of york
being at london and herynge of the loss of the Field of saint albons sent
over see her two young sons George and Rychard which went to vtrecht / And
phelyp malpas a rich merchant of london / thomas vaghan squire and master
wylliam hatteclyf / and many other feryng the coming of the queen to london
took a ship of Andwerp for to have goone in to Zeland / And on that other
coost were taken of one Colompne a Frensshman a ship of war and he took hem
prisoners / and brought hem in to France / where they paid great good for
their raunsonne / and there was much good and richesse in that ship /

Capitulum Trisesimum Tercium /
Then when the Earl of march and therle of warwyk had met to geder on
Cottiswold Incontinent they concluded to go to london / And sent word anon
to the Mayer and to the cite that they should come / Anon the Cite was glad
of their coming hoping to be relyeuyd by them / And so they came to london /
And when they were comen and had spoken with the lords and astates /
then being there concluded for as much as king harry was gone with them
northward / that he had forfayted his crown and ought to be deposed acordyng
unto the acts made and passed in the last parliament / /

And so by thaduys of the lords spirituel and temporel then being ot
london^ the earl of march Edward by the grace of god oldest sone of Rychard
duke of york as ryghtful heyr and next enherytour to his fader / the fourth
day of march the year of our lord Lix took possession of the Royamme of
England at westmynstre in the great halle. And after in the church of the
abbay and offryd as king berynge the Septre Royal / to whom all the lords
both spirituel and temporell did hommage and obeyssaunce as to their
sovereign / lyege / and lawful lord and king / And forthwith it was proclaimed
through the Cite king Edward the fourth of that name / And anon after the king
roode in his Ryall astate norward with all his lords for to subdue his
subgettis that time being in the north / and tauenge his faders death / And on
palmsonday after he had a great bataylle in the north country at a place
called Towton not fer fro york / where with the help of god he gate the field
and had the vyctorye^ where were slain of his adversaries xxx thousand men and
moo as it was said by men that were there / In which bataylle was slain the
earl of northumberlond / the lord clyfford / Sir Johan N^uyll / the Earl of
westmerlandes brother / Andrewe Trollop / and many other knights and squyers /
Then king harry that had been king being with the queen and Prince at york
/ heerynge the loss of that feld and so much people slain and overthrown /
anon forthwith departed al three with the duc of Somersete / the lord roos and
other toward scotland / And the next day king Edward with all his army
entryd in to york / and was there proclaimed king / and obeyed as he ought to
be / And the mayer Aldermen and comyns sworn to be his lyege men / and when
he had tarried a while in the north and that all the country there had
turned to him / he returned southwarde leuynge the Earl of warwyck in tho
parties for to keep and govern that country / And about mydsomer after the
year of our lord god a thousand four honderd and syxty / And the first year
of his regne he was crowned at westmynstre and enoynted king of England
having the hoole possession of all the hoole Royamme / whom I pray god save
and keep / and send him thaccomplysshement of the remenaunt of his rightful
enherytaunce by yonde the sea / And that he may regne in them to the playsyre
of almighty god / herthe of his soul / honor and worship in this present
life / and well and prouffyte of all his subgettis / and that there may be a
very fynal pees in all christian Royames that the Infydeles and myscreauntes may
be withstanden and destroyed / and our feyth enhaunced / which in these days
is sore mynuysshed by the puyssaunce of the Turks and hethen men / And that
after this present and short life we may come to the everlasting life in the
blysshe of heaven / Amen

And here I make an end of this little work as nygh as I can find after the
form of the werk to fore made by Ranulph monk of Chestre / And where as there
is fawte / I beseech them that shall read it to correct it / For if I could
have founden moo stories / I would have set in hit moo / but the substance
that I can find and know I have shortly set hem in this book. to thentente
that such^ things as have been done sith the death or end of the said book of
polycronycon should be had in remembrance and not put in oblyuyon ne
forgetynge / prayenge all them that shall see this simple work to pardone me
of my simple / and rude writing / Ended the second day of Iuyll the xxij year
of the regne of king Edwardthe fourth and of the Incarnacion of our lord a
thousand four honderd four score and tweyne /

Fynysshed per Caxton
